Response Message: Title: Presentation of Critical Limb Ischemia Patient   Good day  colleagues. I wish to present the case of a 69 year old female patient  Mrs. Sarah Thompson.   Mrs. Thompson is a resident of Brooklyn  New York. She has been known to have a longstanding history of uncontrolled type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for over 25 years. This has been complicated with Diabetic Neuropathy and Retinopathy. Furthermore  she has a history of smoking approximately a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years. She also suffers from Hyperlipidemia and Hypertension  which were discovered a decade ago along with moderate renal insufficiency. She reportedly has been taking medication for these conditions but adherence has been sporadic.  Recently  she presented in our clinic with complaints of progressive severe rest pain in her right leg over the past few weeks that worsens at night and even causes her to lose sleep. Her pain substantially intensifies when her leg is elevated  especially in bed  and relieves somewhat when she dangles her leg over the bed. She also reports non-healing sores on her foot and thickened and discolored toenails.  Physical examination showed weakened pulses in the right leg  cold skin  and substantial loss of hair on the limb. The foot was mildly swollen and there was notable discoloration of the toes consistent with cyanosis. Foot ulcerations with gangrene were evident. Neurological examination revealed significant loss of sensation in her foot.  The combination of her clinical history  symptoms and physical examination findings  points out to a severe peripheral artery disease  particularly Critical Limic Ischemia (CLI). However  she will require further diagnostic assessments including Ankle-brachial index and Imaging tests for confirmation and appropriate treatment planning. Early revascularization is her best chance for limb salvage.  In conclusion  Mrs. Thompson's condition is a result of the interplay of multiple risk factors comprising of Diabetes Mellitus  Smoking  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  and moderate renal insufficiency. This case underscores the significance of managing these key modifiable risk factors for CLI  for preventing disease progression and associated complications.

Patient Presentation: We have a 68-year-old African American male patient  Mr. John Smith  presenting with critical limb ischemia involving his right lower extremity. Mr. Smith reports experiencing a dramatic increase in rest pain over the past few weeks  particularly at night  paired with non-healing ulcerations on his right foot.   Medical History:  Mr. Smith has an extensive medical history  notably characterized by Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which he has been managing successfully with oral antidiabetic medication for the past 15 years. He also has been treated for Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years. His medication regimen includes metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. In addition  Mr. Smith has a significant 30-pack-year smoking history  but he quit smoking approximately five years ago.   Prior relevant investigations included a lower limb arterial Doppler ultrasound conducted 8 months ago  the findings of which suggested moderate peripheral artery disease. The patient is not known to have any allergies  and there is a family history of cardiovascular diseases  particularly myocardial infarctions in his father and older brother.   Given the nature and severity of Mr. Smith’s symptoms  coupled with his past medical history  a clinical diagnosis of critical limb ischemia appears warranted  warranting further evaluation  confirmation through diagnostic tests  and formulation of a suitable treatment plan.

Title: Clinical Case Presentation of a Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Introduction: We present the case of a 75 -year old Caucasian male patient  Mr. A  who arrived at the emergency department complaining of lower extremity pain that significantly impedes his daily functioning  particularly during exercise and sometimes at rest.   Demographics & Lifestyle: Mr. A was born and currently resides in the urban area of New York City. He is a retired engineer  a long-time widower living alone who occasionally receives home assistance. He admits to a 50-year history of smoking a little over 1 pack of cigarettes per day.  Past Medical History: Mr. A suffers from long-standing chronic conditions that are relevant to his current condition:  1. Cardiovascular Health: Mr. A has a 10-year history of hypertension. His blood pressure has oftentimes poorly controlled with medication regimen – Lisinopril 20mg daily and Atenolol 50mg daily. In 2015  he also suffered from an acute myocardial infarction requiring angioplasty and stent placement.  2. Diabetes status: He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus approximately 15 years ago. It is managed with Metformin 1000mg twice daily  yet his HbA1c levels remain consistently high at around 8.5%.  3. Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD): With a 5-year history of PAD  he initially reported intermittent claudication which has recently worsened.  4. Lipid profile: He shows dyslipidemia with an LDL of 140 mg/dL  HDL 35 mg/dL  Triglycerides 220mg/dL. He has been taking a maximum dose statin (Atorvastatin 80mg) daily.  Conclusion: All these circumstances  combined with the patient's age  chronic tobacco usage and lack of exercise  have led up to his present situation. Upon examination  his right lower extremity showed signs of pallor  significant hair loss  absent distal pulses  and dependent rubor which is indicative of critical limb ischemia. Pain onset at rest signifies that his condition is in an advanced stage. With these considerations in mind  multidisciplinary team coordination is crucial for this patient’s clinical management plan.

Title: Patient Presentation with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe is a 68-year-old African-American male  retired school teacher  who resides in Calgary. He has been a chronic smoker for over 40 years and also frequently consumes alcohol. He has been a patient at our medical facility for 15 years.  Presenting Concern: Mr. Doe presents with a 6-month history of progressive pain in the right lower limb  particularly in the calf region. He reports the pain intensifies while walking and relieves during rest (Intermittent Claudication). Lately  he has been experiencing rest pain especially at night  along with numbness and a cold sensation in the same limb.  Physical Examination: Mr. Doe appears to be in apparent distress due to pain. Examination results reveal weak or absent pulses in the right lower limb  pallor on elevation  and dependent rubor. There is also evidence of non-healing ulcers located on the right foot's digits and heel area. The right lower limb skin appears shiny and hair growth seems minimal compared to the left leg.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia which are being managed with medication. On both counts  compliance to the medication has been suboptimal. He was also diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago  for which he is on a regulated diet and oral hypoglycemic agents.  Family History: There is a family history of cardiac disease. His father passed away from a myocardial infarction at 67 and his older brother underwent angioplasty at the age of 62.  Considering his age  lifestyle  and clinical presentation  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia secondary to peripheral artery disease (PAD) is highly likely. He is immediately referred for further vascular imaging and angiography to confirm the diagnosis and plan possible revascularization.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information:  Mr. John Stevens  a 72-year-old African-American male  presents with rest pain and skin ulcers on his right lower limb  which have significantly worsened in the last few weeks.   Demographics: Mr. Stevens is a retired construction worker and has been living with his wife in suburban America after retirement. He is a former smoker with a history of two packs a day for 20 years  but has abstained from smoking for the past 5 years. He drinks alcohol occasionally. Mr. Stevens is moderately obese with a BMI of 33 and leads a sedentary life. He is insured and is financially independent.  Medical History: Mr. Stevens has a history of several chronic issues due to his previous lifestyle choice. This includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both under reasonable control with medications. He has also been treated for hyperlipidemia with statins. He hasn't had any hospitalizations in the last 10 years except for a gall bladder removal surgery about eight years prior  but none for any cardiovascular disease. There is a family history of peripheral artery disease in his father who died of a sudden heart attack at the age of 79.   Presenting Condition: Mr. Stevens has been complaining of severe pain in his right foot  especially at night. He noticed ulcers  which have been persistent for six weeks despite conservative local wound care. Upon examination  the patient exhibited known lower extremity signs of critical limb ischemia like cold foot  shiny leg skin  hair loss  and non-healing ulcers on the foot mainly on his toes. His pulse in the right lower leg and foot was markedly diminished compared to the contralateral limb.  In summary  Mr. Stevens presents critical limb ischemia  likely resultant of his uncontrolled diabetic and hyperlipidemic condition combined with a history of heavy smoking. Immediate attention is required to prevent worsening of condition and possible loss of his limb.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in an Elderly Female with Diabetes  Demographic Information: Patient Profile: Mrs. L  a 73-year-old Caucasian female patient hailing from California is currently presenting symptoms of critical limb ischemia (CLI).   Lifestyle: She leads a sedentary lifestyle and has a past history of smoking for over 40 years. She is retired and lives with her husband.   Past Medical History: Her past medical history includes type 2 diabetes for 30 years with suboptimal glycemic control. She also has hypertension which has been managed with medication. Three years ago  she was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and has been undergoing treatment since then. A review of her family history revealed that her father had atherosclerosis and her mother suffered from heart disease. She has no known allergies.   Presenting Symptoms: Mrs. L came to the hospital with complaints of severe pain in the lower limbs  especially during physical activity  which she described as 'claudication.' On some occasions  she experienced pain at rest as well. She reported chronic non-healing wounds on her right foot and her foot had noticeable discoloration. She also mentioned feelings of coldness in the lower limbs and loss of hair in the affected areas.   These symptoms have been gradually intensifying over the last six months  impacting her quality of life  and restricting her to home due to reduced mobility.

Presentation of Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Demographics: Patient Name: John Doe Age: 68  Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Engineer Residence: Boston  Massachusetts Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has been dealing with significant health issues over the past years. He has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 20 years ago which has been poorly controlled. The patient had myocardial infarction 10 years ago and was diagnosed with Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease  followed by hypertension managed with oral medications. Upon follow-ups  he has disclosed that he is a former smoker with a 40 pack-year history but has been tobacco-free for 15 years now. Additionally  Chronic Kidney Disease – Stage 3 has been an alarming concern contributing to his deteriorating health.  Presenting Complaint: For the past 2 months  the patient has been experiencing severe pain in his right lower limb  especially while walking a short distance which he has been attributing to his advancing age. However  in the past couple of weeks  he noticed persistent pain  even at rest  particularly at night. This was accompanied by changes in skin color  slowed hair growth  and a noticeable decrease in temperature of the leg compared to the other limb.  Diagnosis: Upon physical examination  a significantly weak pulse was detected in his right leg. An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test was conducted immediately suggesting severe peripheral artery disease. Further investigations with duplex ultrasonography indicated severe stenosis of the femoral artery. Based on these findings and clinical presentation  the diagnosis was consistent with Critical Limb Ischemia.  Management Plan:  The patient was immediately referred to a vascular specialist. An Angiogram was recommended to determine the blood flow needs and angioplasty or bypass surgery are the procedural options depending on angiogram results. Further  close involvement of a Diabetes Specialist and Nephrologist is prudent to manage his comorbid conditions. Patient education regarding lifestyle modifications including a balanced diet  regular physical activity  strict glycemic control and routine monitoring was emphasized.    Prognosis: As the patient is presenting with severe symptoms at advanced stages of the disease  his prognosis will depend on the promptness of the treatment  comprehensive management of his comorbid conditions  and adherence to the prescribed treatment plan. It is crucial to closely monitor for any signs of infection or non-healing ulcers which may lead to possible amputation if left unattended.

Title: A Case Presentation of a Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Background: Mr. James Arthur  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented with symptoms consistent with critical limb ischemia (CLI). He is retired and resides in the suburbs with his wife. Mr. Arthur has a history of occasional smoking and moderate alcohol consumption.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Arthur had been experiencing severe pain at rest  non-healing ulcers  and tissue necrosis in his right lower leg for several weeks. He reported a significant loss of hair in that area  coldness  and color changes. He also mentioned significant weight loss  loss of appetite  and bouts of insomnia due to sharp  shooting pain  especially during the night.   Medical History: Mr. Arthur has a known history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus (for over 20 years)  coronary heart disease  and had a stroke at the age of 65. He has a history of smoking 10-15 cigarettes a day for the past 50 years. He is on multiple anti-hypertensive medications  oral hypoglycemic agents  and statins. He has been somewhat non-compliant with his medication regimen  especially for his diabetes.  Family History: Mr. Arthur comes from a family with a significant history of heart disease. His father died at 68 due to a myocardial infarction  and his older brother was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) in his early 50s.  Physical Examination: Our examination revealed pallor  weak pulse  and decreased sensation in the right lower leg. The right leg also had multiple sores that were not healing. ABI (Ankle-Brachial Index) was found to be significantly below the normal range in the right leg  further confirming PAD.  Overview: This presentation of Mr. Arthur exemplifies a typical critical limb ischemia case  a severe form of peripheral artery disease  characterized by chronic ischemic rest pain  ulcers or gangrenes in the affected limb. His history of cardiovascular ailments  diabetes  and long-term smoking habit increases his risk for developing advanced peripheral artery disease resulting in critical limb ischemia. Early diagnosis and a multidisciplinary approach to management  including risk factor modification  revascularization  and wound care  are needed to prevent limb loss and improve overall prognosis.

Patient Presentation:   The patient in question is Mr. John Doe  a 75-year-old gentleman  residing at 123 Main St  New York  NY. He is Russian American and primarily speaks English at home. He is a retired construction worker and has been independent in his activities of daily living until his recent physiological changes.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a significant history of cardiovascular diseases. He has been dealing with chronic hypertension for over 20 years and diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 10 years ago. Mr. Doe's diabetic condition is managed with oral hypoglycemic agents  while his hypertensive status is controlled with a calcium channel blocker. He also has a five-year history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) but has been noncompliant with the prescribed medication regimen and lifestyle modifications. His other medical issues include hyperlipidemia and a previous episode of cerebral infarction without residual deficits. He was a heavy smoker but quit about five years ago.  Presenting Conditions:  Mr. Doe presents with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). His typical symptoms consist of severe pain in his feet  especially at night; wounds on his feet and toes that are not healing; and a noticeable decrease in the temperature of his lower leg. Notably  he reports that he was initially having claudicating pain  which has progressively worsened over time  and now the pain is consistent even while at rest. He also observes that the color of his right foot has gradually changed to pale and shiny. The symptoms have severely affected his quality of life  with limitations in normal activities.   Given his extensive history of cardiovascular disease and non-compliance with PAD treatment  his current presentation with CLI is not out of character. Referral to a vascular specialist is immediately required to prevent further complications  including potential loss of the limb.

Patient Presentation: Ladies and Gentlemen  I would like you to meet Mr. John Bennett  a 65-year-old Caucasian male from the urban areas of San Francisco  presenting with symptoms of critical limb ischemia (CLI).   Medical History: Mr. Bennett  a retired policeman  has an extensive past medical history which includes type 2 diabetes  which he has had for 25 years. This condition  unfortunately  is poorly controlled  as evidenced by his latest HbA1c of 8.5%.  Furthermore  he has a known history of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  diagnosed 10 years ago  for which he has been on Aspirin and Atorvastatin. Despite management  he has had two previous hospital admissions in the past 5 years due to exacerbations of PAD. Moreover  he has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both controlled with medications. He also has a 40 pack-year smoking history  but successfully quit smoking five years ago.   Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Bennett presents with increasing pain in his left leg  specifically in his calf and foot. The pain is severe and persistent  awakening him from sleep  and not relieved by rest. He also complains of non-healing wounds on the foot. In addition to these symptoms  he reports intermittent claudication and symptoms of rest pain occurring over the past three weeks. On physical examination  the left leg appears pale and cool to touch. The ankle-brachial index (ABI) is suggestive of severe ischemia.   In summary  the overall clinical scenario of Mr. Bennett is suggestive of critical limb ischemia secondary to long-standing diabetes and peripheral artery disease. Given his symptoms  a comprehensive evaluation and timely intervention will be warranted to alleviate symptoms and prevent adverse outcomes such as limb loss.

Patient Presentation:   Good morning  we are presenting Mr. Robert Turner  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  resident of Pittsburgh  PA. He's a retired mechanic  not involved in any strenuous physical activity post retirement  but used to be a moderate smoker until he quit 10 years ago.  The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe rest pain in his right lower limb  especially while sleeping or at rest. He also reported ulcers and sores which are slow to heal on his lower right leg and foot. The patient also mentioned an increased progressive difficulty in walking distances that he could previously manage comfortably  and has noticed that his right foot feels colder compared to the left.  The pain and coldness intensified drastically in the last 24 hours  prompting the patient to seek medical help. A quick physical examination revealed that pulses were absent below his right knee  his foot was pale and cool to touch  and the pain worsened upon elevating the limb. He was also found to have a gangrenous toe.  Mr. Turner’s past medical history includes a diagnosis of Type II Diabetes Mellitus 15 years ago and Hypertension 5 years ago  both are being managed with oral medications. Cardiac history features an MI treated with angioplasty 8 years ago. He underwent screening colonoscopy 4 years ago which was unremarkable.  In conclusion  Mr. Turner’s age  prior medical history with smoking  DM  Hypertension  and MI  his symptoms of rest pain  non-healing wounds  and the absence of foot pulses point towards a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia. His rapid deterioration over the past 24 hours marks an alarming sign  which requires immediate intervention.  Upon diagnosis  Mr. Turner would need intensive management  possibly including medications  revascularization procedures  or amputation depending on the severity of ischemia and his overall health condition. His case emphasizes the necessity of early detection and aggressive management of peripheral arterial diseases  especially in patients with multiple risk factors like Mr. Turner.

Patient Presentation:  Good Morning/Afternoon   Today I would like to present a case of a 68-year-old Caucasian male who is suffering from Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). Mr. John Doe is a retired teacher  living in the semi-rural area of Newton  Iowa. He has a significant past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for 15 years  and peripheral arterial disease diagnosed 3 years ago. Despite consistent interventional measures  Mr. Doe's lower limb condition has progressively worsened.   The patient is a former smoker  who quit 5 years ago but smoked for 30+ years  consuming 1 pack a day. He is also diagnosed with hypertension  and he's been under medication for the past 10 years. He does not consume alcohol or use illicit drugs. In terms of the family history  his father had myocardial infarction at the age of 72 and his mother was a diabetic patient. The patient's BMI is 30 indicative of obesity.  Mr. Doe presents with non-healing wounds on his right foot  which have been present for the last two months despite regular wound care. He also reports rest pain  particularly at night  which has been disturbing his sleep.   Upon physical examination  there were no palpable pulses in the right leg and foot. The skin is cool to touch and atrophic with some areas of discoloration. His ABI (Ankle-Brachial Index) was less than 0.3  and Doppler ultrasound revealed multiple stenotic lesions in lower leg arteries.  Thank you.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a Middle-Aged Diabetic Female  Patient Information:   Ms. Linda Smith  a 54-year-old African-American female  presents with a 2-week history of progressive onset of severe pain in her left lower extremity. The pain  which is more severe during rest and at night  is compounded by intractable wounds and ulcerations on her lower limb and foot. Ms. Smith resides with her family in New York and works as a high school teacher.  Relevant Past Medical History:   Ms. Smith has a ten-year history of non-insulin dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus which is poorly controlled  evidenced by her recent Hemoglobin A1C result (HbA1C) of 9.2%. She also has a five-year history of hypertension  for which she is being treated with a thiazide diuretic and an ACE inhibitor. However  she reports irregularity in taking her antihypertensive.  Other relevant medical history includes obesity  with a body mass index (BMI) of 32 kg/m2 and hyperlipidemia  managed with statins. She quit smoking 8 years ago but had a history of 15 pack-year tobacco use.  Family history reveals both parents had diabetes  her father had hypertension and her mother had a heart attack in her 60s.  Clinical Presentation:  On physical examination  her left lower limb appears pale and cool to touch with a diminished pulse. There are dark discolored patches indicative of ulcerations  and few necrotic tissues are also visible in between her toes. Her BMI remains elevated at 32 kg/m2. The blood pressure in her left ankle is also significantly lower compared to her arms  indicating the possibility of peripheral arterial disease (PAD).  In summary  this is a case of a middle-aged diabetic female presenting with uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  obesity  and hyperlipidemia. The current symptomatology indicates critical limb ischemia  a severe stage of PAD most likely due to poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension. Immediate intervention and management are required to avert limb amputation or other equally severe consequences.

Patient Presentation:  We are presenting a 68-year-old African-American male patient  Mr. John Thomas  who has been diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI). Residing in Chicago  Illinois  Mr. Thomas is a retired high school teacher who is widowed and living with his adult daughter. He has a history of smoking for 30 years  although he quit approximately a year ago. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are medically managed yet poorly controlled.  Mr. Thomas has been experiencing progressively worsening rest pain in his right leg for the past six months. Over the last two weeks  he also noticed the appearance of non-healing ulcers on his right foot. Physical examination confirmed the presence of atrophic skin changes  absent distal pulses  cold skin  and numerous ulcers over the right foot.  Clinical investigations have shown increased fasting blood glucose and lipid levels. An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was performed  indicating an index of 0.40 for the right leg and 0.95 for the left leg  suggesting significant peripheral arterial disease in the right leg. Duplex ultrasound  performed to further characterize the vascular status  demonstrated complete occlusion of the right superficial femoral artery and further ischemic changes consistent with critical limb ischemia.  This case underscores the need for urgent revascularization procedures for Mr. Thomas to prevent the progression to limb loss. He has been referred to a vascular surgeon and will require meticulous blood glucose and blood pressure management  along with a strict wound care regimen. His case emphasizes the significance of early detection and intervention in patients with risk factors for peripheral artery disease to avoid the debilitating consequences of critical limb ischemia.

Presentation Topic: Critical Limb Ischemia Patient Case Study  Meet Mr. Richard Martinez  a 72-year-old Hispanic male from San Diego  California  presenting with critical limb ischemia (CLI). Mr. Martinez is a retired construction worker and currently lives with his wife. He has a daughter and two grandchildren living nearby. Mr. Martinez maintains a fairly active lifestyle despite his age and enjoys walking his dog every morning around the neighborhood. He has had no known allergies and is a non-smoker.  Mr. Martinez has had a long-standing history of controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia  leading to peripheral arterial disease (PAD)  diagnosed five years ago. He was managed with statins  antiplatelets  and antihypertensive medications. He also has early-stage chronic kidney disease that was identified during initial screening for hypertension workup. He does not have diabetes  heart disease  or any malignancies.  Concerning his CLI  he began experiencing classic symptoms about 6 months ago  primarily persistent leg pain  especially at rest. The pain is predominantly in his right calf and foot  and has recently become so severe that it is disrupting his sleep. He also felt coldness in his right foot  often accompanied by pale or bluish discoloration. His daughter and wife became concerned when they noticed a non-healing ulcer on his right foot's lateral aspect - a development which brought him to medical attention. Doing house chores and walking his dog  which he used to enjoy  have become increasingly challenging for him due to his pain and immobility.   These symptoms point towards critical limb ischemia  which is a severe stage of peripheral arterial disease. His physical examination and diagnostic tests like Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) and Doppler ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis.   Critical limb ischemia  like in Mr. Martinez's case  is a significant risk factor for lower extremity amputation unless it's properly treated. The management strategy would primarily aim to re-establish blood flow through revascularization therapies such as angioplasty  bypass surgery  or endarterectomy along with efficient wound care.   Mr. Martinez's case emphasizes the importance of recognizing and treating critical limb ischemia promptly to prevent serious complications like limb loss and to improve the quality of life.

Patient Presentation: We have an 80-year-old female patient  Mrs. M.J  who is diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). She lives in an assisted living facility in Somerset  New Jersey and is a retired school teacher.   Medical History: Mrs. M.J has a long-standing diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  first diagnosed at the age of 55. She also has Hypertension and Hypercholesterolemia  both of which have been managed with medication for the past 10 years. Moreover  she has a history of smoking for around 40 years  although she quit 10 years ago. There is a record of peripheral artery disease (PAD). The PAD has been managed conservatively for several years  but despite the management  she has progressively worsening symptoms.  Current Symptoms: Recently  she was admitted to the hospital due to severe rest pain in the right lower foot for the past week. The pain increases at night and tends to decrease with hanging her limb over the side of the bed. She has also observed non-healing ulcers on the big toe of her right foot. There is no report of fever  but she mentioned an unintentional weight loss in the last month. No allergies are reported.   Physical Examination: Vitals revealed a blood pressure of 145/80 mmHg  a resting heart rate of 80 bpm  and a BMI of 29. Significant findings on examination include pallor  diminished pulses below the right knee  coldness of the right foot  a decubitus ulcer with necrotic tissue on the right big toe  and decreased sensation below the right ankle.   Based on the above data  CLI is a serious condition that needs urgent attention in order to salvage the limb and ensure patient survival. An urgent vascular consultation has been sought for Mrs. M.J to determine the best plan of action.

Patient Presentation:  Patient's Name: [Confidential] Gender: Female Age: 78 years  Race: Caucasian  Residential Status: Lives independently  Occupation: Retired Teacher  Chief Complaint: Increasing pain in the left foot  especially when at rest.  Present Illness: Patient has been experiencing progressive pain in her left foot for last 5 months  which has now escalated to severe. The pain is mostly felt at night or while resting. She has also noticed intermittent claudication and discoloration  with the extremity being colder than the rest of her body. There is a non-healing ulcer on her left heel.  Past Medical History: Patient was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago  which is managed with Metformin. She also has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and has been smoking for 30 years approximately  only recently quitting 3 years past. She underwent coronary artery bypass grafting surgery (CABG) 5 years ago for ischemic heart disease.  Family History: The patient’s father had peripheral artery disease (PAD) and her mother had Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.   Allergies: The patient is allergic to Penicillin  causing rash and shortness of breath.  Medications: She takes Metformin for her diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  Atorvastatin for high cholesterol levels  and Aspirin for prophylaxis against heart disease.  Physical Examination: Lower limb examination shows pallor  absent pulses and a chronic non-healing ulcer on the heel of the left foot.   Given the above clinical findings  history of diabetes  coronary artery disease and hyperlipidemia  plus the smoking history  we are considering a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia. Further diagnostic procedures including Angiography will be carried out to confirm this diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  We present the case of Mr. James Lopez  a 68-year-old male patient of Hispanic ethnicity  residing at 132 Central Park  New York City. He is a retired high school teacher and has a history of smoking for about 10 years from the age of 30 to 40  but quit 28 years ago.  Mr. Lopez is presenting with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  characterized by the onset of severe pain in his right lower limb  particularly his lower leg and foot. His pain is exacerbated by physical activity and gets marginally better during rest periods  accompanied by numbness  muscle weakness  and a noticeable loss of hair on the affected leg. Furthermore  Mr. Lopez also reported intermittent claudication  the onset of pain with exertion and relief with rest.  His relevant past medical history includes Type II Diabetes Mellitus  diagnosed 10 years ago  and controlled with insulin injections coupled with dietary modifications. He also has a history of hypertension for which he's taking Lisinopril. Mr. Lopez had a Coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) 5 years ago following myocardial infarction. He has been adherent to medications and regularly attended his cardiac rehabilitation. He has no known allergies to medication or food and no family history of limb ischemia.   This complex interplay of his past medical history  primarily his longstanding diabetic status  previous myocardial infarction  and history of smoking  has increased his susceptibility to develop peripheral arterial diseases  potentially leading to his currently presenting severe form  Critical Limb Ischemia  that needs immediate medical attention.  This is an urgent case requiring the initiation of limb salvage investigations with the possibility of revascularization interventions and aggressive control of risk factors to prevent the disease's further progression. Due to his medical history  we must consider the increased risk of surgery  coordinating multidisciplinary care involving cardiology and vascular surgery teams.   The main goals of his treatment would be pain relief  wound healing on his right lower limb  prevention of limb amputation  improving his quality of life  and treating modifiable risks.

Patient Presentation:  We are here to discuss the case of Mr. Thomas Peterson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  who resides in Austin  Texas. He has been suffering from intermittent claudication and leg pain that has recently modified into sustained pain even at rest  concerning for critical limb ischemia.  Mr. Peterson has a significant past medical history including type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past fifteen years  both currently being managed with medication. He has also undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) around five years ago for symptomatic coronary artery disease. Additionally  he was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) approximately two years ago  which adds to his risk of developing critical limb ischemia.  Furthermore  he admits to a 40-year history of smoking  consuming approximately one pack of cigarettes per day. He has attempted to quit smoking numerous times  but has been unsuccessful thus far. Mr. Peterson does not have any history of alcohol or substance abuse.  His family history reveals occurrences of cardiovascular diseases  with his father succumbing to a myocardial infarction at age 78 and his older brother having been diagnosed with PAD.  In summary  this patient’s longstanding history of smoking  uncontrolled diabetes  and hypertension alongside with diagnosed peripheral artery disease  pose a high risk for the development of critical limb ischemia. Immediate assessment and management of his current symptoms are of utmost importance to prevent limb loss and enhance his long-term quality of life.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 67-year-old African American male named Mr. Jerrod Thompson  who has resided in Franklin  Tennessee for the past three decades. He worked in construction until five years ago when he retired. The patient is a widow with three adult children and three grandchildren. He currently lives alone and is able to drive and maintain routine daily activities independently.  Presenting concern: Mr. Thompson presents to the clinic with complaints of severe  recurrent foot pain  particularly in his left foot. He reports that the pain is worse at night and that often hanging his foot over the side of the bed seems to alleviate the symptoms. In addition  a non-healing wound has been noticed on the big toe of the same foot for the past few weeks.  Past medical history: Mr. Thompson has a significant past medical history  including type II diabetes mellitus since the age of 45 which is controlled with Metformin  peripheral artery disease diagnosed 3 years ago  and hypertension for the past 15 years controlled by Lisinopril/Hydrochlorothiazide. Furthermore  he is a former smoker  who quit 7 years ago  having previously smoked one pack per day for almost 35 years.  Clinical findings: On physical examination  the patient's left lower limb had significantly reduced pulsations. The skin of the left foot appeared pale with signs of atrophy and the mentioned non-healing ulcer on his big toe. No edema was noted. His ankle-brachial index was less than 0.4. Doppler ultrasound further confirmed a significant decrease in vascular perfusion to the left lower limb.  Case Conclusion: Considering the patient's clinical symptoms  physical findings  and past medical history  particularly of diabetes mellitus and peripheral artery disease  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) is suggested. This is a severe blockage in the arteries of the lower extremities  which markedly reduces blood-flow leading to pain  skin ulcers or gangrenous tissue. This is a serious condition and warrants immediate attention and intervention.  Next Steps: The patient's condition renders him at risk of amputation if left untreated. As a result  he has been referred to a vascular surgeon for further management which might include revascularization via angioplasty or bypass surgery. In addition  the patient is recommended to have tight glycemic control to prevent progression of vascular disease.

Patient Presentation:  We are looking at the case of Mr. Richard Davidson  a 75-year-old Caucasian male who was referred to the vascular lab with symptoms consistent with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). Mr. Davidson is a retired construction engineer and veteran who lives with his wife in Flagstaff  Arizona. He has presented with rest pain  numbness  and color change in his left lower limb that has progressively worsened over the last 2 months to the point where he is incapable of walking without intense discomfort.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Davidson has a significant history of cardiovascular diseases  with a prior Myocardial Infarction about ten years ago. He is hypertensive and has Type II Diabetes Mellitus which he has been managing for the past 15 years. He has a known history of Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) for which he had undergone angioplasty in his right leg 5 years ago. Approximately three years back he was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia. He has a 50 pack-year history of smoking  though he quit almost a year ago.  Medications include aspirin  atorvastatin  metformin  and lisinopril.  Family history indicates his father had atherosclerosis and succumbed to a stroke  while his mother had hypertension.  Physical Examination:  On examination  his left lower leg appears discolored  and the foot is cold to touch  suggestive of diminished blood supply. Arterial Doppler could not detect a sufficient pulse in his left foot. There were no signs of infection  ulcer  or gangrene  at the moment.  Overall  due to the significant past medical history including PAD  diabetes mellitus  and smoking in combination with the physical findings  the primary working diagnosis is Critical Limb Ischemia. Urgent angiography and vascular consultation are warranted to manage and mitigate the risk of the potential loss of limb. With aggressive management  it is hoped his prognosis can be improved.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Johnson. He is a retired teacher and resides in the city with his wife.  Presenting Problem: Mr. Johnson has presented with symptoms indicative of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). He reports to have been experiencing significant and persistent pain in his right lower limb  which has been particularly severe in his calf and foot even during rest. He has also identified slow-healing ulcers on his toes and a noticeable difference in temperature between both legs  with the right leg being cooler.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has been a smoker for the past 40 years recently quit 6 months ago. He has known history of cardiovascular disease  with a previous diagnosis of Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) 5 years ago  for which he underwent a bypass surgery in the right lower limb. He is also living with Type 2 diabetes  diagnosed 10 years ago  and has been on oral hypoglycemic agents. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  managed with medications. No known allergies have been recorded.   Family History: There is a significant family history of cardiovascular disease. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 68.  Overall  Mr. Johnson's presenting symptoms  along with his past and family medical history put forth a strong indication of Critical Limb Ischemia. Further diagnostic evaluations would be required to provide definitive diagnosis. Prompt recognition and treatment is crucial  as CLI can potentially lead to limb loss if not addressed in a timely manner.

Title: Clinical Presentation of Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Profile  Name: Mr. Henry Jenkins  Age: 72 years old  Sex: Male  Race: African American  Occupation: Retired Electrician  Past Medical History:  Mr. Jenkins has a known history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  for which he is on medication (Metformin). He was diagnosed approximately 10 years ago and his records indicate inconsistent control of glycemic index levels. He also has a history of high blood pressure  for which he takes Lisinopril  and hyperlipidemia  controlled with Atorvastatin. As per his medical records  he was diagnosed with both hypertension and hyperlipidemia 6 years ago. He also has a 40-pack year history of smoking but quit smoking 5 years ago. He has no known allergy to any medications.  Clinical Presentation:  Mr. Jenkins presented to the clinic with progressive pain in his right lower leg  which has worsened considerably over the past week. He described the pain as being severe  constant and unrelieved with rest. He noticed that the pain intensified during mild leg elevation and lessened when he positioned the leg dependently. The pain has also evolved to disturbing his sleep.  On physical exam  his right lower leg appeared paler than the unaffected left leg  there was loss of hair growth  and the leg was cold to the touch. Upon examination  both posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses were absent. The presence of non-healing ulcers was noted on the tips of his right toes.  Conclusion:  Given the significant pain at rest  presence of non-healing ulcers and absence of peripheral pulses  the findings are consistent with a preliminary diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI). Mr. Jenkins’ past medical history of diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  along with his past smoking history  make him a high-risk candidate for peripheral artery disease leading to CLI. A vascular surgery consultation has been advised for further evaluation and management of this patient.

Patient Presentation:  Patient’s Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68-years-old  Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Electrician  The patient lives with his wife in a suburban setting. He presents with consistent  severe pain in his right leg when at rest. The pain is usually at a level 7 out of 10 and often disturbs his sleep. Patient describes the pain as burning and cramping sensation localized in his calf and foot. Upon physical examination  the foot appears pale and cold  with delayed capillary refill. There are also signs of skin breakdown and minor ulceration on the heel.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a significant past medical history including type 2 diabetes mellitus  which he has had for 25 years and is managed with insulin and oral hypoglycemic agents. He has a history of hypertension controlled with medication  hyperlipidemia managed with statins  and a 40-year history of heavy smoking. He has been hospitalized twice for cardiac issues - myocardial infarction 10 years ago and cardiac catheterization indicating a moderate vessel disease 5 years ago. Patient has been non-compliant with smoking cessation advice. No known allergies.  Summary:  Given the patient's reports of pain  observed physical symptoms  and past medical history  clinical suspicion is strongly oriented toward critical limb ischemia. The patient’s longstanding diabetes  smoking history  and cardiovascular disease represent significant risk factors. Moreover  the presence of rest pain and trophic changes such as skin pallor  coolness  delayed capillary refill and ulceration are indicative of advanced chronic limb-threatening ischemia. Immediate vascular consultation  diagnostic angiography and possible revascularization are advised.

Patient Presentation:  Meet Mr. Thomas Jenkins  a 72-year-old male Caucasian from Albany  New York. Mr. Jenkins presented to the emergency department due to severe pain in his left lower extremity  particularly in his foot. The pain  which he described as sharp and constant  has been disturbing his sleep over the last two weeks. Apart from the pain  he also reported that his left foot is noticeably colder than the right and  recently  he observed an ulcer in his left toe that seems not to be healing despite caring for it at home. The combination of severe pain  difference in temperature between the two limbs  and non-healing ulcer is suggestive of critical limb ischemia.  His past medical history is quite significant. Mr. Jenkins has been a known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 15 years  and has had difficulties managing his blood sugar levels despite regular medications. Additionally  he has a history of hypertension  treated with medication for the past 10 years. He also has high cholesterol levels and coronary artery disease  for which he underwent an angioplasty procedure six years ago. Notably  Mr. Jenkins has a 40-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day  although he quit smoking approximately five years ago.  In terms of family history  both of his parents had diabetes and hypertension. His father had a heart attack at the age of 68 and his mother had a stroke at the age of 74.  Mr. Jenkins’ past surgical history includes the aforementioned angioplasty and an appendectomy at 32 years of age. He reported no known allergies.   To sum up  Mr. Jenkins  a 72-year-old male presenting with severe pain  temperature difference between limbs  and a non-healing ulcer in his left lower extremity  has a past medical history significant for diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  coronary artery disease  and a long history of smoking  indicating a high risk for arterial diseases like peripheral artery disease and critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  We are discussing Mr. Patrick Wilson  a 72-year-old African-American male patient from Ohio  who presented to this clinic with symptoms consistent with critical limb ischemia.   Patrick reports exact symptoms of extreme pain in his right leg  particularly below the knee  which tends to intensify while walking or exercising and somewhat subside when he rests. He has even experienced instances of pain while at rest  compelling him to elevate his leg for temporary relief. His foot often feels cold and displays a noticeable change in color to a pale or bluish hue.  Upon review of his past medical records  it’s significant to note Mr. Wilson is a former smoker and quit the habit 15 years ago. He has a long-standing history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He had undergone a previous percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for myocardial infarction 10 years ago. Thereafter he had been taking medications religiously  including aspirin and statins.  Moreover  he had a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)  and his father suffered from a stroke  indicating a probable genetic disposition to vascular diseases  justifying his high risk of peripheral arterial disease which has now manifested as critical limb ischemia.  He has kept a healthy diet  limiting sodium and sugar intake. Still  his blood sugar levels have been challenging to manage  frequently straying from recommended levels  hampering his condition.  In conclusion  considering his symptoms and his background of various concurrent illnesses  there is an immediate need for rigorous evaluations to prevent the progression of the condition which might lead to limb loss. We will have to aggressively treat his modifiable risk factors  chiefly tight glycemic control and hypertension  along with initiating therapies targeted at revascularization and pain management. We plan for a multidisciplinary approach involving geriatrics  endocrine  cardiology  and vascular surgery to achieve the best possible outcome.

**Presentation of a Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia**  Patient Profile: Name: Mr. Samuel Thompson Age: 67 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Engineer Residence: Boston  Massachusetts  Insurance: Medicare   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Thompson presents with severe pain in his right lower leg for the past three weeks. The pain has been unresponsive to over-the-counter pain medications and has now increased in intensity over the past few days  making it difficult for him to sleep at night. Additionally  he has noticed a considerable decrease in physical activity due to the pain  and the skin on his foot has turned a pale color.   Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia dating back 10 years. He has been compliant with medications for these conditions  including amlodipine 5mg once daily for hypertension and atorvastatin 20mg once daily for hyperlipidemia. Additionally  he has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit smoking about 5 years ago. He doesn’t have any known allergies. He has a past surgical history of a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) 7 years ago due to ischemic heart disease.  Family History:  Mr. Thompson's father died at the age of 72 due to a heart attack and his mother of a stroke at 78. His younger sister is living with diabetes mellitus.  Physical Examination:  On examination  his right foot is cold to touch compared to the left. There is a delay in capillary refilling time and there are no palpable pulses in the right posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis. His foot appears pale and distal leg hair is absent. No obvious wounds or ulcers were found.  Given Mr. Thompson’s clinical presentation and his past medical history  he is suspected of having critical limb ischemia  a severe blockage in the arteries of the lower extremities  which markedly reduces blood flow.   Plan:  Order labs including complete blood count  comprehensive metabolic panel  coagulation studies  and a lipid panel. Also  place an order for a lower extremity arterial duplex Ultrasound to assess his vascular health and to confirm the suspected diagnosis. He will likely need consultation with a vascular surgeon for further management. Further medications and treatment will be based on diagnostic results and the severity of his condition. His case should be managed as urgent due to the risk of limb loss.

Patient Presentation:  Our patient is Mr. John Doe  a 70-year-old Caucasian male currently living a sedentary lifestyle in the city. He has been a smoker for over 40 years and has a moderate daily intake of alcohol. He is retired and lives with his wife and suffers from critical limb ischemia (CLI). CLI onset in his case was gradual  with the first showing of intermittent leg pain and cramping while walking  which became resting ischemic pain accompanied by the presence of sores and wounds on the toes and feet that are not healing properly.  He presents with a past medical history notable for hyperlipidemia  type II diabetes mellitus  and hypertension  diagnosed approximately 10 years ago and has been managed with oral antidiabetic agents and antihypertensive drugs. Smoker's cough is present. He also had an episode of myocardial infarction about 3 years ago. BMI is 30  indicating obesity.  On physical examination  both lower limbs are cool to touch  with a weak or diminished pulse in the peripheral limbs. There is noticeable skin discoloration  with slow capillary refill and skin atrophy. Chronic ulcers are present on the lower limbs  toes are noted to be necrosed. His lipid panel and HbA1C levels are notably high.  In short  this patient demonstrates both the typical comorbidities and the clinical presentation of critical limb ischemia  likely resulting from long-term atherosclerotic disease driven by his history of smoking  diabetes  obesity  and hyperlipidemia. Further evaluation and management will focus on his overall cardiovascular health  measures to mitigate ischemia  and specific wound care to help prevent amputation.

Presentation of Patient With Critical Limb Ischemia  Demographics:  Patient Name: Mr. Carlos Gomez Age: 68 Sex: Male Race: Hispanic Occupation: Retired Engineer  Chief Complaint:  The patient presents with persistent rest pain in his right lower extremity and non-healing ulcers on his right foot that have been present for more than 3 weeks. The pain has been progressively getting worse and is disturbing his sleep. He also reports coldness of the foot and lack of sensation.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Gomez was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago and has been on medication to control his blood sugar levels. His diabetes has mostly been under control except for a few episodes of hyperglycemia.   He was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago. The patient has been on a regimen of ACE inhibitors and beta blockers to manage his blood pressure.  Mr. Gomez was also diagnosed with high cholesterol levels 8 years ago and has been on statins ever since. He has a past history of myocardial infarction 5 years ago and was managed with angioplasty and stenting.   He has Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) diagnosed around 8 years ago and has been on antiplatelet drugs (aspirin) and statins. He also attempted lifestyle modifications including tobacco cessation and regular exercise.  Mr. Gomez has been a smoker for past 30 years but quit smoking 7 years ago. He occasionally consumes alcohol.  Family History:  His father had diabetes and passed away due to myocardial infarction. His mother also had diabetes and passed away at an old age due to complications related to the disease.  Review of Systems:  Endocrine: Well controlled diabetes  follow up checks indicates no diabetic retinopathy or nephropathy. Cardiovascular: Hypertension managed with drugs  previous history of myocardial infarction  diagnosed with PAD. Respiratory: History of smoking  occasional shortness of breath. Skin: Non-healing ulcers on the right foot and decreased sensation.  In conclusion  the patient’s past medical history of diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Peripheral Arterial Disease with his smoking habit escalating his risk factors  present the characteristic symptoms of Critical Limb Ischemia. The persistent rest pain and non-healing ulcers indicate a severe form of Peripheral Arterial Disease.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 64-Year-Old Male Patient   Demographics:   The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian male named John Doe who resides in an urban setting in New York City. He is a retired something and lives with his wife  two adult children  and three grandchildren. The patient is a smoker with a 40-year history (2 packs/day). Mr. Doe is a heavy drinker with an average of five to six alcoholic beverages per day and has a sedentary lifestyle due to his chronic leg pain.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a past medical history significant for Type-2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 18 years ago  hypertension diagnosed 16 years ago  and dyslipidemia diagnosed 12 years ago. His diabetes has been poorly controlled  with recent HbA1c records varying between 8.5-9.0. He was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) 5 years ago and has been experiencing worsening symptoms ever since. A pertinent part of his history includes having intermittent claudication as well.   Presentation:  Mr. Doe presents with intense  unrelenting pain in his right lower limb  notably worst at night. He also reports rest pain  indicating severe ischemia. On examination  the foot appears pale and cool  with shiny  atrophic skin. There are no palpable pulses below the popliteal artery. Non-invasive testing revealed an ankle-brachial index of 0.30  indicative of severe PAD. Distal gangrene is present on his big toe  and he has an ulcer on his foot that has not healed for a couple of months.  In conclusion  the history  clinical presentation  and investigative studies suggest that Mr. Doe suffers from Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  the severe form of peripheral artery disease. Therefore  urgent medical intervention and lifestyle modifications are needed to prevent limb loss and other serious complications.   Interventions:  The patient has received pain management and initiated on antithrombotic  statin  and antihypertensive therapy. Also  aggressive treatment of his diabetes is essential to slow the progression of atherosclerosis. Due to the involved toe's gangrene  the patient has been evaluated for either possible angioplasty or bypass surgery versus major amputation. He greatly benefits from a smoking cessation plan and alcohol intervention. A dietary consult was also arranged to address the nutritional factors contributing to the disease course. A referral to vascular surgery is warranted considering the severe ischemia and gangrene.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Alistair Green  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  was brought into our clinic with complaints of extreme restlessness  severe pain in the lower extremities  particularly in the left foot  even when at rest.   Medical History: He is a long-term smoker with a 30-pack year history and admits to consuming alcohol moderately. His past medical history includes chronic hypertension  diabetes mellitus for which he has been on Metformin for the past 8 years  and intermittent claudication which he has been managing for the last six years. He also had a minor stroke seven years ago  resulting in minimal residual right-sided weakness but did not lead to significant functional impairment.  The severity of the pain has now risen significantly  disturbing his sleep and affecting his day-to-day life  which led him to seek medical assistance. Upon physical examination  the left foot has pale skin and a notably lower temperature than the right  with absent pedal pulses and slow capillary refill. Mr. Green reported that the pain is alleviated when he places his leg in a dependent position  indicating probable gravity-facilitated blood flow.  In conclusion  consistent with the symptoms  history and physical examination  Mr. Green is presenting with critical limb ischemia likely secondary to peripheral arterial disease  exacerbated by his smoking habits and underlying medical conditions. Immediate attention and intervention are required to prevent further complications such as tissue necrosis or gangrene and potential limb loss.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 67-year-old African American male named John Smith  who resides in Brooklyn  New York. He has been married for 44 years  is retired  and lives with his wife. The patient was previously employed as a taxi driver  a job he held for over 30 years. He is a non-smoker  does not take any recreational drugs  but consumes moderate amounts of alcohol. There is no known family history of cardiovascular disease.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a significant medical history worth noting. He has type 2 diabetes  which has been managed with insulin and oral medication for 15 years. The patient also has hypertension  controlled with the use of an ACE Inhibitor named Lisinopril. Mr. Smith has documented hyperlipidemia  managed with a statin named Atorvastatin. He currently suffers from peripheral arterial disease (PAD)  confirmed five years ago with an ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.6. An ABI less than 1.0 indicates PAD. There is also history of intermittent claudication  though recent events suggest a progression to critical limb ischemia.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith presents with a worsening condition of pain in his right lower limb at rest. The pain significantly intensifies during the night and is primarily localized in his foot and calf muscles. He also has complaints of toe ulcers that are not healing and persistent feet coldness. This has led to difficulty in walking  sleeping  and generally reduced quality of life.  Given his presentation  and his medical background  the suspicion is that Mr. Smith’s PAD has progressed to critical limb ischemia. This is a severe stage of PAD where blockage in the arteries severely reduces blood flow to the extremities resulting in pain at rest  non-healing wounds  and even gangrene. Immediate investigation and intervention are crucial at this point as this poses a high risk of amputation or even death.

Patient Presentation:  We are currently treating a 67-year-old African-American male patient diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI). Reports indicate that patient is having classic symptoms of critical limb ischemia such as rest pain  non-healing wounds  and gangrene in the right lower extremity  predominantly  his right foot.  Demographic Information:  The patient is a retired construction worker  married with three children  and lives in a suburban community. He is a non-smoker and denies use of any recreational drugs. He admits to consuming alcohol socially but within moderate limits. He is independent in his daily activities.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a significant past medical history including type II diabetes mellitus  which has been poorly controlled over the last decade. He has been diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD)  for which he had undergone previous angioplasty approximately two years ago. He also deals with long-standing hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both being managed with medication.  The patient had a myocardial infarction about five years ago  followed by a successful angioplasty and placement of a drug-eluting stent. However  he has shown poor medication compliance behaviour since his operation.  In addition  he was diagnosed with stage II chronic kidney disease secondary to his diabetes around six years ago and is under nephrology follow-up.  Furthermore  the patient`s family history involves cardiovascular disease as his father had a myocardial infarction in his early 50's. His mother on the other hand  had suffered a stroke at the age of 68.  Evaluation and treatment strategy for this patient will revolve around his vascular and nonvascular risk factors. Expectedly  it will involve multidisciplinary team input.

Patient Presentation:  Our patient today is Mrs. Kimberly Sanchez  a 64-year-old Hispanic female with a medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) poorly controlled with Metformin and hemoglobin A1c of 8.5%. She is a long-term smoker with a 40-pack-year smoking history and reports rare alcohol consumption. She has no allergies and claims to have a relatively active lifestyle despite having recently retired from her accounting profession.   She has been suffering from chronic peripheral arterial disease (PAD) for the past couple of years. Recently  over the past three months  her condition has escalated to critical limb ischemia (CLI). She reports experiencing severe pain in her right lower leg even while at rest and shows significant power loss. Mrs. Sanchez' ulcers on her right toe persist despite regular wound dressings. Furthermore  her right foot feels cold to touch  with a noticeable delay in capillary refill.  The patient has been adhering to oral antiplatelet therapy and statins as prescribed for her PAD. Her other medications include Metformin for T2DM  as well as aspirin and Clopidogrel for secondary prevention of cardiovascular events. She does not have a family history of thromboembolic disease.  In summary  Mrs. Sanchez  aged 64 years  from a Hispanic background  is experiencing critical limb ischemia which poses significant threat requiring appropriate intervention. Her primary risk factors include poorly controlled diabetes  chronic smoking  and a history of peripheral arterial disease complicating her clinical situation.

Patient Presentation  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68 Sex: Male  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Construction worker   Clinical Presentation: Mr. John Doe presents with symptoms that correspond to Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). He complains of unrelenting foot pain which is particularly bothersome at night. He describes the pain as severe  and it necessitates him to hang his foot over the side of the bed for relief. Additionally  he mentions intermittent claudication  which is a tight  cramping  or heavy type of pain in his right leg that is triggered by walking. Mr. Doe also reports reduced mobility and noticed a non-healing wound on his right heel recently. No immediate family history of peripheral vascular diseases was noted.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a significant medical history which includes long-standing uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He has a 45-year history of heavy smoking but quit five years ago when diagnosed with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). He has survived one prior myocardial infarction and currently takes daily low-dose aspirin and a statin for secondary prevention. He was previously diagnosed with peripheral artery disease five years ago  and intermittent claudication was well-controlled on cilostazol until recently.  Summarily  Mr. Doe's risk factors including diabetes mellitus  hypertension  smoking history  and established peripheral artery disease make him susceptible to critical limb ischemia. Further clinical assessment and investigations are highly warranted to confirm the diagnosis and plan suitable interventions.

Patient Presentation:  Our patient is Mr. Jackson  a 68-year-old African American male  who has presented with symptoms consistent with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).   Past Medical History:  Mr. Jackson has a significant past medical history  which includes hypertension for over 15 years  type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack year smoking history. About seven years ago  he had undergone percutaneous coronary intervention related to Acute Myocardial Infarction and has had chronic kidney disease (Stage 3b) for about 10 years. He also has a history of peripheral artery disease  which was diagnosed about 5 years ago.   Present Illness:  He has been experiencing a rapid progression of rest pain in his lower extremities  particularly severe in his right leg over the past couple of weeks. He complains of severe foot pain as well  particularly at night. He has also developed ulcers on his right foot for which he is getting regular dressing. He reports occasional claudication pain  difficulty in walking and recently he has noticed loss of hair on his right leg. He denies any fever or signs of systemic infection.  Family History:  His father had a stroke at an old age  and his mother has a history of coronary heart disease. His sister was also diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus Type 2.  Social History:  The patient is a retired mechanical engineer. He has been a smoker for around 40 years and moderately consumes alcohol. His diet primarily consists of high carbohydrate and high saturated fat foods. He lives with his wife  and they have two adult children.   The aforementioned information correlates with the symptoms of CLI  such as pain at rest and the presence of non-healing ulcers or gangrene. His risk factors include age  race  long-standing diabetes  smoking  hyperlipidemia  and high blood pressure. Considering his symptoms and past medical history  it is crucial to further investigate and manage the condition promptly to prevent further complications.

Patient Presentation: We have a 65-year-old Caucasian male patient named Mr. Charles  who has visited our facility complaining of extreme discomfort in his right lower limb. He reports that the pain  primarily in his foot  has been progressive and significantly worsens when resting  often awakening him at night. He mentions the pain subsides slightly when he hangs his foot over the edge of his bed. He also notes additional symptoms  such as coldness of the debilitating leg  a noticeable reduction in hair growth on the limb  loss of pulse or a weak pulse in the limb  and delayed wound healing on the foot.  His past medical history is significant. He has been diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus for the past ten years  which has been relatively poorly controlled. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and has been a heavy smoker for the past 30 years  smoking approximately twenty cigarettes per day. He was diagnosed with hypertension five years ago  for which he's actively receiving treatment. Mr. Charles has never been diagnosed with heart disease or any vascular disease before.  There are no known drug allergies. However  due to his poor diabetes control  Mr. Charles is currently on metformin  gliclazide  and regular insulin administration. He is also taking atorvastatin for his hyperlipidemia and ramipril for his hypertension.  In light of his symptoms  history  and habits  his condition aligns with critical limb ischemia  a severe blockage in the arteries of the lower extremities  which significantly reduces blood-flow. It is most commonly seen in patients with diabetes  hypertensives  individuals with high cholesterol  and chronic smokers  as in Mr. Charles's case.   This is a serious condition as it may lead to amputation and could potentially be life-threatening. Hence  it would be important to immediately investigate and initiate appropriate medical and possibly surgical intervention  based on the extent of the ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  I would like to introduce a 69-year-old African-American male patient  Mr. Jackson  who is currently presenting with critical limb ischemia. He is a well-known artist in the community and a retired high school teacher. He lives with his wife and the couple enjoys gardening and walking in the local park. He neither smokes nor consumes alcohol. Ethnicity has no bearing on his social connections or preferences  and he enjoys a wide network of friends from various backgrounds  races  and cultures.  Medical History:  He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes 13 years ago and has been managing it with lifestyle modifications and medication. Good compliance to medication has been noted. For the past 9 years  he has also been treated for mild hypertension. He had an episode of deep vein thrombosis 6 years ago that was successfully managed.  Current Presentation:  For the past three months  Mr. Jackson has been suffering from progressively worsening pain in his right calf particularly at rest or even minor activities such as walking short distances which previously were easily manageable. His clinical examination indicates ischemic rest pain  non-healing ulcers  and noticeable temperature difference in the lower right extremity. These symptoms clearly indicate a severe case of critical limb ischemia. He also reported intermittent claudication and symptoms of paresthesia  alongside frequent nighttime cramping in his legs. The patient also demonstrated a significant loss of pedal pulses in the right foot.  Recommendations:  Considering Mr. Jackson’s current symptoms and past medical history  he is at a fairly high risk of limb loss if not provided with immediate intervention. The extremity has to be revascularized as soon as possible via either endovascular techniques or surgical bypass in order to avoid amputation. Alongside  optimization of diabetes and hypertension control is absolutely necessary with close monitoring and adjustments to his current medication regimen.

Presentation Title: Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction   Patient's pseudonym: Mr. John Smith  Demographics: 67-year-old African-American male  Slide 2: Background Information Primary Complaint: Prior to admission  Mr. Smith has been experiencing progressive discomfort on his left lower leg. He describes it as an extreme burning sensation  more noticeable at nighttime inconveniently disturbing his sleep. He also reports non-healing ulcer on his left foot.  Slide 3: Patient's Past Medical History Mr. Smith has a significant history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and peripheral arterial disease. He has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Previous medical interventions include regular diabetic control medication and lifestyle modification advice such as dietary changes and exercise. He is also a known hypertensive patient.  Slide 4: Physical Examination Findings  Examination revealed a pale  cold left leg with loss of hair on the shin and foot. An ulcer was also detected on his left  forefoot  presenting with blackish discoloration at its center. Distal pulses were not palpable on the left leg.   Slide 5: Concluding Remarks Considering Mr. Smith’s medical history  his persistent lifestyle habits  and his current complaints  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia was made. His condition is severe  and immediate medical attention was recommended to prevent further complications such as limb loss. His management plan involves revascularization procedures  optimized control of co-existing medical conditions  and implementation of healthier lifestyle changes.  This case underscores the importance of early recognition and intervention in managing critical limb ischemia  especially in high-risk populations like diabetics and smokers. The involvement of specialists for the management of this critical condition from the point of diagnosis is crucial  as a delay can lead to potential irreversible consequences. It is a reminder of how long-standing uncontrolled chronic diseases can potentially lead to such critical conditions.

Subject: Patient Presentation – Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Profile: The patient is a 74-year-old African American male patient named Mr. Jackson. He is a retired construction worker and lives with his wife. He is a nonsmoker but has a history of moderate-to-severe alcohol consumption. He weighs about 220 lbs and stands at 5'9''.  Presenting Issue: Mr. Jackson presents with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) with persisting discomfort and pain in his right lower extremity  particularly at rest and at night. He describes this pain as excruciating and says that it often interrupts sleep. He also reports decreased capabilities in daily activities  including walking and climbing stairs.   Physical Examination: Upon examination  the patient shows tangible signs of tissue loss  ulceration  and gangrene in the right foot. There's noticeable skin pallor upon leg elevation and rubor on dependency. Furthermore  palpation revealed a significant decrease in limb temperature compared to the unaffected left lower extremity. Pulse examination showed the absence or decrease of both dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses on the right leg.   Past Medical History: Mr. Jackson has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years  controlled on metformin. He also lives with hypertension for 15 years  controlled on ACE inhibitors. He suffered a myocardial infarction 8 years ago  post which he underwent coronary stent placement. He also reports a history of hyperlipidemia for which he is on statin medication.  Family History: There's a notable history of heart disease and diabetes in his family. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 68  and his elder sister has been living with diabetes for over 15 years.  In summary  the patient’s life history  especially regarding the presence of significant comorbidities  makes him susceptible to developing CLI. His diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  and history of coronary artery disease confirm this predisposition. We will need to develop a comprehensive management plan for Mr. Jackson to maintain limb viability and improve his symptomology.

Title: Presentation of a patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient: Mr. John Doe  Age: 68 years  Sex: Male  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Engineer  Presenting Complaint: Severe Rest Pain  Profound Weakness  and Non-healing ulcers on both lower limbs.  Demographics: Mr. Doe is a resident of Springfield  Illinois. He lives with his wife and his medical care expenses are mainly covered by Medicare.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has had a significant history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for 15 years  controlled with diet and metformin. He also has a 20-year history of smoking (1 pack/day  but quit 5 years ago). He was diagnosed with high cholesterol and hypertension 10 years back  which is presently under control with medication.  Active Medications: Metformin for Diabetes  Lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension  and rosuvastatin for high cholesterol.  Physical Examination: Drastic weight loss noted. Both lower limbs show severe muscle atrophy with notable non-healing ulcers present on feet. Distal pulses are absent on both limbs. Skin is dry and pale  with areas of discoloration.   Laboratory Findings: Elevated blood sugar levels and increased total cholesterol levels were observed. A significantly low ankle-brachial index was found  indicating severe peripheral arterial disease.   Preliminary Diagnosis: Taking into account history  physical examination  and lab results  Mr. Doe’s presentation is consistent with a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia  likely secondary to his long-standing diabetes and vascular disease.  Conclusion: Mr. Doe’s case mandates urgent intervention - both peripheral vascular and glycemic management - to prevent potential limb amputation and to manage the severe pain effectively. A team-based approach involving a vascular surgeon  endocrinologist  dietitian  and primary care physician would ensure optimal care.
