Author:   Dr. XYZ  Specialist in Internal Medicine  Springfield Health Center.  Date: DD-MM-YYYY.

Introduction: We are presenting a case of a 65-year-old Hispanic male named Mr. Carlos Rodriguez who has recently been diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).   Demographics: Mr. Rodriguez is a retired factory worker  residing in Brownsville  Texas. He lives with his wife and his grandchildren. He has a fifteen-year history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. He quit smoking 10 years ago after a 30-year history and continues to drink alcohol moderately. His BMI indicates he is obese and he has a sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History: Mr. Rodriguez has managed his diabetes with oral antihyperglycemic drugs and follows up in a local diabetic clinic every three months. He has a well-controlled HbA1C status. His hypertension is managed with ACE inhibitors. Besides  he has dyslipidemia for which he has been taking statins for the past ten years. Five years ago  he had a myocardial infarction for which he underwent angioplasty and since then  he has been on low dose aspirin. His adherence to medication and regular follow-up has been satisfactory.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez visited the clinic complaining of severe pain in the lower right leg  which has been progressing over the last month. He particularly mentioned rest pain and non-healing ulcer over his right foot. Further examination revealed decreased pedal pulses suggesting CLI.  Importantly  Mr. Rodriguez’s CLI most likely results from advanced peripheral artery disease (PAD)  contributed by his long-standing diabetes and history of cardiovascular disease  smoking  obesity  and sedentary lifestyle which all represent significant risk factors. This case demands immediate consideration for angiography and further interventions with a multidisciplinary care approach considering the severity of the patient's symptoms and risk factors.  In summary  this case presents the challenge of managing a patient with CLI  in the context of multi-system complications and multiple risk factors potentially contributing to his current condition.

Patient Presentation:  Our patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. P  presenting with critical limb ischemia.   This patient hails from La Jolla  California and works as a retired school teacher. His socioeconomic status is middle class with currently good healthcare insurance through Medicare.   Medical History:  Mr. P has a significant medical history of uncontrolled Type II diabetes for the past 15 years.  He has been a smoker for over 40 years and consumes alcohol socially. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  periodically following a moderate medication regimen to control these conditions.  Symptoms & Primary Concern:  He reports experiencing significant pain in his lower right extremity  especially at night  for the past two weeks. The pain is described as a continuous  burning sensation accompanied by numbness and tingling. Recently  the pain has escalated to disruptive levels  disturbing his sleep and impacting his ability to perform daily activities. He also reports a non-healing wound on the same leg  which is a secondary concern as it indicated poor circulation in the limb. There are no known allergies.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the lower right leg cold to touch  hairless  and has a noticeably paler complexion compared to the left leg. There are no palpable pulses in the right dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial.   Assessment:  Clinical presentation  history of smoking and diabetes  and physical findings strongly suggest Critical Limb Ischemia.  Plan:  The patient requires urgent evaluation and intervention  and will potentially need imaging to assess the severity and location of the blockage. Management will include optimization of his comorbidities  cessation of smoking  possible medical and/or endovascular intervention  and maybe a possible referral to a vascular surgeon.   In summary  Mr. P is an elder  Caucasian male  with a history of uncontrolled diabetes  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and smoking; now presenting with critical limb ischemia  primarily affecting his right lower extremity.

Patient Presentation  I am presenting Mr. Samuel Johnson  a 69-year-old African American male with a history of unmanaged Type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He presents with complaints of persistent pain and non-healing sores on his left foot for the past eight weeks  which have recently worsened.  Mr. Johnson is a retired construction worker  from Clayton  Missouri. He stays with his wife and his current BMI is 29. He has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years  which adds to his risk factors.  The patient reports severe pain in the left lower leg even while at rest. The pain amplifies at night while sleeping and gets relieved slightly when the foot is kept in a dependent position. He also reports that the left foot feels colder than the right. On physical examination  his left foot shows signs of tissue loss  pale skin color  absence of hair growth  brittle toenails  and distressing resting pain. Physical exam also revealed diminished pulses in the left lower extremity.  Mr. Johnson's medical history includes Type 2 diabetes which he has had for 20 years  but has been poorly managed due to his non-compliance with lifestyle modification and irregular follow-ups. His hypertension has also been poorly controlled for the past 10 years  and he has a significant history of hyperlipidemia.  He has not been hospitalized before for any similar condition. There is no known history of vascular or heart disease in his family. He does not have any known allergies.  Given his current symptoms and medical history  Mr. Johnson is suspected of critical limb ischemia. Comprehensive vascular testing and imaging might be needed to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the extent of arterial disease.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia Case Presentation  Patient Details: Patient: Mrs. Dorothy Langley Age: 74 years Sex: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Langley reports having severe pain in her right lower limb  especially when at rest. She mentions having intermittent claudication symptoms during walking for the past several months. She also points out that the resting pain is worse at night  disturbing her sleep. Pain scale is reported to be 7/10. She also noticed the presence of two small non-healing sores on her right foot  and on examination  parts of her foot has become blackish.   Past Medical History: Mrs. Langley is a known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 15 years  frequently has uncontrolled blood glucose levels. She has Hypertension for 10 years  and Dyslipidemia for 7 years  and her last lipid profile reports high LDL levels. She has been a Smoker for 50 years  with an average of 15 cigarettes a day.   Family Medical History: There is a family history of cardiovascular disease; both her father and mother had coronary artery disease.   Drug History: She has been on oral hypoglycemics  ACE inhibitors  and statins in prescribed doses.  Previous Investigations: An ABI (Ankle-Brachial Index) test was ordered  which came back as 0.4 (indicating severe blockage).  Impression: Considering patient's age  history  complaints  examination  and investigations  Mrs. Langley is likely presenting with signs of critical limb ischemia  associated with peripheral arterial disease related to longstanding diabetes mellitus  dyslipidemia  hypertension  and smoking. Prompt intervention is necessary to manage her condition.  Future Plan: An urgent referral to Vascular Surgery team is advised for revascularization therapy after discussing the potential benefits and risks. Patient education about the prognosis and necessity for regular follow-ups and strict control and management of known risk factors is recommended.

Patient Presentation:  We have a 67-year-old Caucasian male patient  known by the name Mr. Ted Williams  presenting with signs and symptoms that appear to be consistent with critical limb ischemia. The patient has reported experiencing severe pain in his right lower limb  even while resting  and a non-healing ulcer on his right foot. There are color changes in the right foot with coldness and noticeably less hair growth. These symptoms have been significantly affecting his quality of life.  The patient's medical history indicates a powerful predisposition for peripheral artery disease. He has been a heavy smoker for 45 years and has a history of poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus. He has been on insulin therapy for the last 5 years. Mr. Williams also suffers from hypertension and had a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. While his ejection fraction was maintained  his effort tolerance has been steadily declining since the incident.   There are no known alcohol or drug issues  however  he has been struggling with obesity  with a BMI of 32. His psychosocial history is significant for major depressive disorder  for which he has been on antidepressant therapy.   Mr. Williams lives alone  and given his current symptoms  there are concerns about his mobility  and consequently  his ability to manage his daily activities and diabetes. Family support is minimal  as his only daughter lives out of state. He is currently retired  having worked as a truck driver for a major part of his life.  Given Mr. Williams' current symptoms and previous medical history  critical limb ischemia is suspected  warranting further investigation  including angiography to understand the extent of limb ischemia. If left untreated  he may face limb amputation  underlining the need for immediate  aggressive intervention. His quality of life and independence are noble goals worth striving for in the treatment plan.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) Patient   Greetings    Today  I am presenting the case of a 65-year-old  Asian male  referred to as Mr. K  diagnosed with critical limb ischemia. He is an ex-smoker  with a 40-pack year history  heavy drinker and had a sedentary lifestyle for the past 20 years since he retired. His body mass index is 29 kg/m2  indicating that he is in the overweight range.  Past Medical History: Mr. K has a history of Type-II diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years  controlled with metformin  and hypertension  managed with losartan. He was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) 5 years ago and had undergone a peripheral angioplasty. He denies any history of heart disease  stroke or kidney disease.    Presenting Conditions: He arrived at the clinic with complaints of severe pain in his right lower limb. His pain had gradually increased over the past few weeks  even at rest. He reports a notable decrease in exercise tolerance due to the pain  with previous claudication at 100 meters  now down to less than 20 meters. Sleep quality is compromised due to the severe pain  particularly during the night.  Examination: On physical examination  his right foot was cold to touch and had a dusky appearance. Distal pulses in the right lower limb were not palpable and capillary refill time was delayed. He has significant motor and sensory loss in the affected limb.  Currently  Mr. K's situation is quite precarious and demands immediate attention. His case of critical limb ischemia necessitates firm control of his diabetes and hypertension  and likely revascularization procedures to save the limb and avoid amputation. A multidisciplinary approach with tight glycemic control  blood pressure control  pain management  wound care  and physiotherapy would be vital for his recovery. Evaluation by a vascular surgeon is urgently needed.   Thank you for your attention. Any insights or recommendations for Mr. K’s management are much appreciated.

Patient Profile Presentation:  Patient Name: Mr. Robert Johnson. Gender: Male. Age: 65-years old. Race: Caucasian.  Occupation: Retired Accountant. Marital Status: Married  with three adult children. Religion: Roman Catholic. Home address: 23 Blue Jay Street  San Francisco  California.  Presenting complaint: The patient presents with severe pain at rest in the right lower limb  worsening over the past two weeks  accompanied by preliminary gangrene in the toes.   Medical History:   Mr. Johnson has a long-term history of Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus  inadequately controlled over the past ten years despite oral hypoglycemic agents. He has been a smoker for 30 years but quit ten years ago. He has a history of hypertension for the past fifteen years  managed with ACE inhibitors and Diuretics. He also has a five-year history of hyperlipidemia and is on Statin therapy. He had an MI about four years ago and underwent angioplasty and stent placement.  Family History:   His father died of a stroke at the age of 70. His mother died of colon cancer at 76. There is a familial history of coronary artery disease and hypertension  with two of his brothers being treated for the same.  Social History:  Mr. Johnson is a non-drinker. As a retiree  he lives a predominantly sedentary lifestyle. He has been making efforts to maintain a healthy diet due to his diabetes.  Summary:  Mr. Robert Johnson is a 65-year old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and coronary artery disease. His current state of critical limb ischemia is most likely a consequence of his long-standing peripheral arterial disease  exacerbated by his diabetic status  and complicated by the onset of tissue loss in the form of gangrene. The severity of his symptoms  including rest pain and gangrene  suggests it is an advanced condition that might require aggressive therapies. Mr. Johnson’s chronic smoking and sedentary lifestyle might have also contributed to his condition. Engaging this patient in an immediate management plan is crucial to improve outcomes and prevent limb loss.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  brought in by his spouse due to severe  persistent pain in his left lower leg. The patient calmly reports that the intense pain has been present for about two weeks  progressively getting worse over time with significant worsening in the last 48 hours. The pain is not relieved by rest and has now begun to disturb his sleep.  Patient resides in the rural heartland  and is a retired farmer with a 40-year history of heavy smoking. His alcohol intake is moderate with no history of illicit drug use. His spouse reports a family history of arterial diseases  including his father who had an above-knee amputation due to Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD).  Regarding his past medical history  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 12 years ago and has been on Metformin therapy. Subsequent to this  he was diagnosed with systemic hypertension 10 years ago  and he has been receiving treatment with ACE inhibitors. Lastly  there is a record of intermittent claudication and a remote history of myocardial infarction approximately 7 years ago.  On physical examination  his left foot appears discolored (cyanotic) with the toes being especially affected. Additionally  an ulcerative lesion is noted on the plantar surface of his foot. Tests show decreased pulses distal to the popliteal artery  and a non-invasive study reveals significant stenosis in the left superficial femoral and posterior tibial arteries. The diagnosis of critical limb ischemia is made considering his symptoms and findings.   Based on the severity of the condition and considering his risk factors  including age  hypertension  diabetes mellitus  past history of myocardial infarction  and chronic smoking  he is at high risk of limb loss if not urgently treated. His presenting symptoms of severe rest pain and evidence of tissue loss (ulceration) signify the critical nature of the situation. Now he is being referred to a vascular surgeon to discuss angioplasty or possibly bypass surgery.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Ronald Thompson is a 69-year-old Caucasian male who presents with symptoms suggestive of critical limb ischemia in his right lower extremity. His chief complaints are severe pain in the calf and foot  non-healing wounds on his toes  and weakness in the right leg. Onset of symptoms has been gradual over the last six weeks  but the pain has intensified in the past week  particularly at night and while resting. He also reports noticeable changes such as discoloration and coolness of the limb.   Mr. Thompson is a retired mechanic with a past medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  controlled on Metformin  and Hypertension managed with Losartan. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history  having quit 5 years ago. He admits being non-compliant with his diabetic diet and medications at times. Notably  there is no history of coronary artery disease or stroke. Mr. Thompson’s family history revealed that his father had peripheral artery disease and underwent leg amputation later in his life.   Mr. Thompson's physical examination revealed a pale  cold right lower limb with diminished peripheral pulses. A non-healing ulcer was noted on the big toe. Other systemic examinations were normal. Further investigations including angiography are planned to confirm the extent of the vascular occlusion. Considering the clinical presentation and background  the provisionary diagnosis of critical limb ischemia has been established.   In conclusion  Mr. Thompson’s risk factors for developing CLI include advanced age  male gender  diabetic status  a past history of nicotine addiction  and a familial predisposition to peripheral artery disease. These factors contribute significantly to the presentation of critical limb ischemia in him. Immediate treatment options to restore the blood flow would be discussed upon confirmation of diagnosis.

Slide 1: Patient Presentation  Our patient  Mr. Williams  is a 68-year-old Afro-American male  a retired veteran  who presents with symptoms of critical limb ischemia (CLI). His concerns are severe  progressive pain in the lower extremity primarily at rest  non-healing wounds on the lower left leg  high cholesterol  and high blood pressure.   Slide 2: Patient Details  Mr. Williams is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. He is married and lives with his wife. He follows an average diet but struggles to maintain a regular exercise regimen due to his current condition. Other underlying conditions include hypertension  managed by antihypertensive medications  hyperlipidemia  managed with statins  and a previous MI (myocardial infarction) five years ago  which was managed with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
