Slide 1: Patient Introduction - Our patient is Mr. John Smith  a 71-year-old African-American male  retired  married  who resides in uptown New York.   Slide 2: Symptoms Presentation - Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department with severe pain in his right lower limb. The pain has increased progressively over three weeks and is now constant even while resting. - There is also a non-healing ulcer on his right big toe.  - He reports feeling continuous coldness in the limb  with noticeable paleness and at times a blueish tint.  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Mr. Smith is a known hypertensive for ten years and has Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past five years with inconsistent glycemic control. - He has been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease two years ago. - He is a 50-pack year smoker  with a history of heavy alcohol use but abstinent for the last year. - Further  he had an episode of Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) about three years ago but has had no recurrence till date.  Slide 4: Family Medical History - His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65 and his mother has been diabetic.   Slide 5: Current Investigation & Status - Physical examination revealed a weak pulse further down his right leg  pallor  absent hair  brittle nails  and delayed capillary refill time.  - His Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) is less than 0.4  confirming severe limb ischemia. - He was immediately referred to the vascular surgery team for further evaluation. - The critical limb ischemia (CLI) is judged severe  based on clinical symptoms and the patient's overall medical status.  Slide 6: Current Treatment & Management - His diabetic medications have been rescheduled  along with adjustment of his hypertensive medications. - He is under immediate pain management with analgesics. - Suitable surgical intervention is being planned by the vascular team  either a bypass grafting/stenting. - His case is high risk  given his severe CLI and existing comorbidities. However  it is crucial for saving his limb.  Slide 7: Next Steps & Monitoring - Continued close monitoring of his vital signs  blood glucose levels  renal functions are required. - Emphasis on the importance of a low-fat diet  glucose control  smoking cessation  and foot care will be imparted.  - A follow-up with the surgery team and his regular physicians will be required post his discharge.   Slide 8: Conclusion - It is critical to manage Mr. Smith with a multidisciplinary approach  involving his physicians  vascular surgery team  dieticians  physical therapists  and nursing staff for optimal patient outcomes.

Patient Presentation:  We are discussing the case of Mr. John Smith  a 66-year-old Caucasian male presenting with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). He is a retired engineer  a non-vegetarian  and resides in New York with his wife. He has a history of 40-pack year smoking but quit 5 years ago.   His significant past medical history includes Type II Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 15 years ago with poor glycemic control (latest HbA1c is 9%)  Hypertension for the past 10 years controlled on medication  and Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD). He underwent a left femoropopliteal bypass 3 years ago. Additionally  he has a known history of Hyperlipidemia and Chronic Kidney Disease Stage 3. He has no known drug allergies.  Recently  Mr. John has been experiencing rest pain in the right lower limb  worsening over the last couple of weeks. There are non-healing ulcers in right foot for about 4 weeks duration. He also has noted color changes in his right foot. Further clinical examination showed weak pedal pulses in the right foot  prolonged capillary refill time  and decreased sensation in the same noted region  clinically suggesting critical limb ischemia. These symptoms have significantly impacted his mobility and quality of life.  In conclusion  Mr. John Smith  a 66-year-old male with multiple comorbidities including poorly controlled Diabetes  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  PAD  and CKD  presents with severe ischemic rest pain in the right foot  non-healing ulcers  and signs of advanced peripheral arterial disease. The overall clinical findings suggest a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia in the right lower extremity. Further diagnostic studies and therapeutic interventions are necessary for better limb salvage and to prevent further complications.

Patient Presentation  Introduction:  We present a case of a 73-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI). The patient is retired and lives with his son in the downtown area of the city.  Medical History:  The patient has a known history of long-standing tobacco use  having smoked 1 pack a day for about 50 years. He's a known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) for the past 12 years  and Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) for the last 10 years. His T2DM is currently being managed with Metformin. Hyperlipidemia has also been noted  which he manages with a statin therapy.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented to the clinic with severe rest pain in the right lower limb  especially in his foot. His son also noticed a non-healing wound on the patient’s right foot's sole. The patient has been experiencing intermittent claudication  particularly after walking a distance of around 100 feet  which was relieved with rest.  Physical Examination:  Gait was observed to be antalgic. Upon inspection  there was evidence of diminished hair growth on the lower extremities  skin pallor and shiny appearance  and a poorly healing ulcer located on the sole. Peripheral pulses were weak. The right foot was cold compared to the left one.  Assessment:  Upon evaluation  the patient's symptoms of rest pain  slow-healing foot ulcer  and intermittent claudication imply that he may have advanced PAD  also known as critical limb ischemia.   Planned Management:  Further investigations  including an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) and arterial duplex ultrasonography  are arranged to confirm the diagnosis. Depending on the severity  the patient may require revascularization surgery  aggressive control of modifiable risk factors  and medical management to alleviate symptoms. A referral to a dietician may also be necessary to help manage hyperlipidemia and diabetes better.  This case highlights the importance of early recognition and management of CLI  especially in high-risk individuals  to prevent irreversible damage and potential limb loss. Smokers  diabetics  and people with hyperlipidemia have a significantly higher risk of developing PAD and CLI.

Good afternoon everyone. Today  I am going to present the case of a 68-year-old Caucasian male who came in with severe rest pain in the lower extremities  specifically the left leg  for the past two months. He also noted non-healing ulcers on his left foot. He was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia.  He is a retired mechanical engineer and lives with his wife. He is a smoker with a history of consuming one pack of cigarettes daily for approximately 40 years. He quit smoking five years ago. He has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus for 15 years  hypertension for about 13 years  hyperlipidemia  intermittent peripheral artery disease  and stroke with full recovery about a year ago.  His blood pressure was noted to be high on multiple occasions despite being on 2 antihypertensive drugs. His diabetes was sub-optimally controlled with a recent HbA1c level of 8.0% while on Metformin. His hyperlipidemia had been well-managed on statin therapy.  His presenting complaints combined with his past medical history and risk factors like diabetes  hypertension  and a previous pattern of smoking strongly suggest the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia. A comprehensive vascular assessment would be appropriate to characterize his ischemic disease fully and help inform subsequent treatment decisions.

Presentation of Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  I. Patient Identification and Demographic Information:  Mr. Jonathan Brown is a 65-year-old Caucasian male standing 5’11” and weighing 210 lbs  hailing from Springfield  Missouri. He is retired  having previously worked as a machine operator for a local firm.   II. Chief Complaint:  Mr. Brown presented to the ischemia clinic complaining of severe  persistent pain in his right lower leg that has worsened over the past two weeks. He also noticed that his right foot turned paler compared to the left one and complained about cold sensations.   III. Past Medical History:  Mr. Brown has a notable past medical history of Type 2 Diabetes for the last 15 years and hypertension for the last 10 two years. He has been managing these conditions with oral medications as prescribed by his primary care physician. Mr. Brown admits to smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for about 40 years. He denied a history of hyperlipidemia  stroke or coronary artery diseases.  IV. Recent Illnesses and Medications:  Other than his chronic conditions  Mr. Brown had a sinus infection three months ago  for which he was treated with antibiotics. He is currently taking metformin for diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and aspirin as a prophylactic measure.   V. Family History:  His father died of a heart attack at 72  and his mother died at 76 due to a stroke. He has one sister living diagnosed with diabetes and one brother living who is healthy.  VI. Social and Lifestyle History:  Mr. Brown lives alone in a bungalow and carries out his daily activities independently. He has a son and daughter living nearby who visit him regularly. Since his retirement  he has engaged in usual house chores and gardening. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in processed foods.   In conclusion  Mr. Brown’s convergent risk factors: advanced age  persistent smoking  uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  sedentary lifestyle  and poor diet  fit the typical profile of a patient at high risk of developing critical limb ischemia. His current symptoms: severe leg pain and color changes in the foot  strongly suggest his condition. The next steps involve diagnostic tests such as ankle-brachial index  Doppler ultrasound  and CT angiography. If confirmed  the initiation of rapid intervention will be crucial to prevent further progression and possible limb loss.

Patient Presentation  Our patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting with critical limb ischemia in his right lower extremity. He is a long-term resident of a mid-western U.S. city  retired from a career as a truck driver.   His BMI of 28 classifies him as overweight. He has been a chronic smoker for the past 40 years  but has been attempting to quit for the past 2 years. He admits to occasional alcohol drinking during social events.  The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and peripheral artery disease. He reports being treated for hypertension for nearly 20 years and being diagnosed with diabetes 10 years ago which he acknowledges to poorly control  often leading to significant blood glucose fluctuations.  The patient also has a surgical history of appendectomy in his 30s and an inguinal hernia repair in his 50s. His mother had a heart disease  and his father had a history of stroke  introducing a genetic predisposition to cardiovascular disease.  In terms of his symptom presentation  the patient has been experiencing rest pain in his lower right extremity for the past few weeks  which has been progressively worsening. Over the past few days  he also noticed a dusky discoloration of his right foot. He reports significantly reduced physical activity due to the pain.  To summarize  we have a 72-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled diabetes  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease  who is currently presenting with critical limb ischemia. The top priority at this point would be to stabilize the patient and develop a treatment plan to manage his ischemia.

Presentation of Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information:   Mr. John Smith  a 70-year-old African-American male  presents with critical limb ischemia.   Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Smith reports that he has been suffering from severe pain in his right leg for the past few weeks  particularly below the knee  which is more profound during evenings and nights. He has observed that his right foot tends to be colder than the left one and has noticed a pale discoloration. He also has non-healing ulcers on his lower right leg while expressing difficulty in walking due to intense pain.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has extensive medical history including hypertension for which he has been on medication for the past 10 years. In addition  he has type 2 diabetes mellitus that he has been managing with both oral medications and insulin for 15 years. He has had two myocardial infarctions  one occurring 5 years ago and another 2 years ago. He is a former smoker with a 45-pack-year history  which he quit 5 years ago after his first myocardial infarction.   He has a family history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD)  chronic kidney disease  and cardiac diseases. His father had a history of PAD  his mother suffered from chronic heart disease  and his older brother passed away due to a heart attack.   Patient's Lifestyle:  Mr. Smith is retired and lives alone. He enjoys playing chess and reading books. His diet could be better as he enjoys snacking and regularly consumes fast food. Although he is aware of the importance of regular exercise  he finds it very challenging due to his current condition and pain in his leg.   This constellation of age  gender  race  and lifestyle  along with his genetic predisposition and a history of smoking  hypertension  diabetes  and heart problems  places Mr. Smith at a high risk for severe forms of peripheral artery disease such as Critical Limb Ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  Patient's Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 67 years Sex: Male  Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Manufacturing Supervisor  Mr. Smith presents with a primary complaint of severe pain in his left lower leg  especially noticeable at rest. He reports that the pain tends to escalate at night and is alleviated when his leg is in a dependent position. He also mentions that he has noticed a non-healing wound on his left foot  which has been present for several weeks. Mr. Smith informs of experiencing numbness and coldness in his left foot with diminished hair growth in that region and a noticeable color change in his left foot to a pale  almost bluish hue.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes for which he is on medication  for the past 15 years. He is also a former smoker  having quit smoking five years ago after almost 40 years of nicotine abuse. Unfortunately  he has a sedentary lifestyle and his dietary habits are poor. He has also had a previous history of transient ischemic attacks (TIA). There are no known drug allergies. He has had no surgeries in the past.  Family History:   There is a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father suffered from ischemic heart disease and died of heart failure at the age of 72  and his elder sister underwent a bypass surgery for peripheral arterial disease (PAD) while in her 60s.   This complete information alongside Mr. Smith’s symptoms suggest that he may be presenting with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe obstruction of the arteries in the lower extremities which significantly reduces blood flow and is a serious form of Peripheral Arterial Disease. Immediate medical attention is imperative to prevent serious complications such as amputation or even death.

Patient Presentation:  We have a 68-year-old African-American male patient presenting with symptoms of critical limb ischemia (CLI). His full name is Mr. John Smith with an address at 204 Elmwood Street  Chicago  IL. He is a retired bus driver and predominantly left-handed. His symptoms include severe pain in his left leg  non-healing sores and ulcers on the lower surface of his leg  and a marked decrease in temperature at his foot.  Mr. Smith has a significant past medical history  which primarily includes type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin and insulin for the last 12 years. He has a history of hypertension controlled by lisinopril for the past 8 years. He is a former smoker and quit smoking ten years ago. He also shows signs of mild chronic kidney disease based on his recent laboratory results.  His family history is notable for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. His father died at age 65 due to a heart attack  and his older brother underwent a bypass surgery at age 60. Mr. Smith's BMI places him in an overweight range  indicating lifestyle changes should be incorporated into his treatment plan.  Prior to his CLI diagnosis  he had peripheral artery disease  which was diagnosed 5 years ago and treated with exercise  a cholesterol-lowering diet  and medications.   Currently  the lack of sufficient blood flow to the left foot  secondary to the longstanding peripheral artery disease  has resulted in critical limb ischemia. There is no known history of allergies  and he reports adherence to his prescribed treatments.  In terms of social history  Mr. Smith has been married for 45 years  has two grown-up children  and lives with his wife. He denies alcohol or substance abuse.   The next steps include revascularization  either through surgery or endovascular intervention. Given his age and comorbidities  a careful evaluation of the benefits versus risks is needed.   In conclusion  Mr. Smith's CLI relates to his longstanding diabetes  hypertension  former smoking habit  and familial predisposition to atherosclerosis. Aggressive management of these underlying conditions is essential to delay the progression of his illness.

Presentation of Patient:  Our patient today is Mr. James B. Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male from Lexington  Kentucky. He is a retired account manager and is currently residing with his wife. He is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. His BMI is calculated as 28  which categorizes him as overweight.  Main Complaint:  Mr. Smith has presented with critical limb ischemia (CLI) characterized by chronic ischemic rest pain  ulcers  and/or gangrene in his lower extremities - specifically his right leg  due to objectively proven arterial occlusive disease.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has an extensive past medical history that is significant for several comorbid conditions. He was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus in 1995  with poor glycemic control. He also suffers from Hypertension since 2000 and has been on anti-hypertensive medication. He suffered a minor heart attack in 2003 for which he has been on medication. His lipid profile has been abnormal with high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL). Consequently  he is on a strict low-fat diet and lipid-lowering medications.  Family History:  His family history reveals that his father had suffered from coronary artery disease and his mother was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus.  Social History:  Mr. Smith has a history of moderate alcohol consumption  consuming approximately 10-14 units of alcohol per week. He has been a non-smoker for his entire life. He is a retired accountant  lives with his wife and has a caregiver visiting him daily for assistance.  Review of Systems:  On review of systems  Mr. Smith denies any chest pain  palpitations  or breathing difficulty  but acknowledges decreased exercise tolerance due to the pain in his legs. He also mentions intermittent numbness in his affected lower limb.  To summarize  Mr. Smith has several cardiovascular risk factors such as Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and hyperlipidemia that have increased his susceptibility to developing peripheral artery disease (PAD) and have exacerbated his CLI. It is imperative to manage these risk factors and treat his CLI as soon as possible to alleviate symptoms  prevent progression of the disease  and avoid potential limb loss.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) Case Presentation  Patient: Mr. John Smith is a 75-year-old Caucasian male.  Demographics: He resides in a suburban setting in Chicago  Illinois. He is a retired automobile engineer with a moderate socioeconomic status. He lives with his wife and their two dogs.  Chief Complaint: John was admitted to our hospital with severe rest pain in the right lower limb  exacerbated by the last 48 hours with difficulty in walking. Notably  he describes a consistent numbness and cold sensation in his foot and calf  with mild discoloration of toes.  Past Medical History: He has a significant past medical history of hypertension (HTN) controlled with medication and type-2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) for the last ten years  currently managed with oral hypoglycemic. He also has a pack-year smoking history of 35 years but quit five years ago. There's no previous history of stroke or any other cardiovascular event.  Medication History: He is currently on Lisinopril for hypertension control  Metformin for diabetes control  and Atorvastatin for cholesterol. He adheres to his medications properly.  Family History: His father had a myocardial infarction (MI) and his sister has been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD).  Physical Examination: On examination  his right foot is colder than the other  pale and has diminished hair growth. Pedal pulse on the right foot is poorly palpable. Capillary refill time is delayed.  Based on the above-mentioned information  Mr. Smith’s symptoms are highly suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). We need to run a thorough diagnostic evaluation  including but not limited to  ultrasound Doppler  CT angiography  and/or ankle-brachial index. Interventional measures need to be considered along with aggressive medical management of his T2DM and HTN.  In conclusion  Mr. Smith's case illustrates how modifiable risk factors like smoking  poorly controlled diabetes  and hypertension contribute to the development of peripheral arterial disease and subsequent critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation  I wish to bring your attention to Mr. Leonard  a 67-year-old African-American male who presents with critical limb ischemia (CLI). He is currently suffering from severe pain in his left lower limb. The discomfort persists even when he is at rest and there have been non-healing ulcers present on his left foot for the past few weeks.  Mr. Leonard has been battling Non-insulin dependent Diabetes Mellitus for the past 18 years. He is also hypertensive and was diagnosed with this condition 10 years ago  which is currently managed with medications. His medical history also indicates a past incident of transient ischemic attack (TIA) about 4 years ago. Unfortunately  Mr. Leonard has also been a regular smoker for over 40 years.  In reviewing his family history  it is important to note that his father suffered a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 72 and his mother had a history of stroke in her later years. Further  Mr. Leonard's older sister is also a diabetic and has chronic kidney disease.  Mr. Leonard has been noncompliant with his diet and diabetic medications in recent years  leading to poorly controlled diabetes. His BMI upon examination was 30  indicating obesity. In addition  the duplex ultrasound revealed severe peripheral artery disease (PAD) in the left limb.  In conclusion  Mr. Leonard's established risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  tobacco use  family history of cardiovascular disease  attempted diet and medication non-compliance  and obesity have come together to exacerbate his condition resulting in critical limb ischemia. He will require urgent vascular surgical consultation with the consideration for revascularization. Continuous monitoring and stringent control of his diabetes and hypertension are also crucial in order to avoid further complications.

Patient Presentation:  We have a 69-year-old African American male patient  Mr. Johnson  who presents with critical limb ischemia (CLI). He is a long-term resident of a rural community in South Carolina and lives on a limited income. He has been a smoker for over 45 years and has a medical history of poorly controlled type II diabetes for almost 20 years. The patient is also hypertensive and has had hyperlipidemia for a decade  both under insufficiently managed medical treatment due to financial constraints and inconsistent follow-up visits.  For the past few weeks  Mr. Johnson has been experiencing severe pain in his right lower leg  both at rest and during physical activities  with the pain increasing at night. He also reports non-healing wounds on his foot and coldness in the lower leg. He has lost significant weight over the past month and experiences difficulty in walking due to the pain. His previous medical records show evidence of peripheral arterial disease (PAD).  Overall  Mr. Johnson's lifestyle  prolonged history of smoking  uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  coupled with symptoms of rest pain  non-healing wounds  and weight loss  make him highly predisposed to developing critical limb ischemia. Further diagnostic testing and immediate intervention are required to prevent the complications associated with this condition such as tissue loss  sepsis  and limb amputation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Anthony  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the hospital complaining of severe pain in his right limb. He is a retired school teacher and lives by himself. He is a long-time smoker with a 30-pack-year history and is a sociable consumer of alcohol. He describes the pain as persistent and worsening over the last couple of weeks. He often experiences pain at rest and particularly at night. He also reports difficulty in walking due to the pain and noticed discolouration of his foot.  Mr. Anthony has had a past medical history of uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus for the past 20 years. In addition  he was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 10 years ago for which he has been on medication  but with questionable compliance. He underwent angioplasty for coronary artery disease 5 years ago.  On physical examination  there are several non-healing ulcers on his right foot. His right lower leg appears to be pale  cold to touch with attenuated pedal pulses. His capillary refill time is more than five seconds. Further  a noticeable hair loss on the right lower limb adds to the severity of the condition.  Given his clinical signs and symptoms  history of diabetes and peripheral vascular disease  Mr. Anthony’s condition strongly indicates critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  The patient  Mr. Thomas Sanchez  is a 72-year-old Hispanic male who arrived at the clinic with severe  critical lower limb ischemia in his right limb. He has been complaining of escalating pain in his right lower limb for the past several weeks. He reports that this leg discomfort also interrupts his sleep and affects his ability to walk  further complicating his preexisting mobility issues. His current symptoms include rest pain  non-healing sores on his toes  and a cold sensation in his right lower extremity. Additionally  the skin of his right foot appears to be pale and slightly mottled.  He has a significant past medical history  which includes type 2 diabetes for the past 25 years  controlled hypertension for the past 15 years  and a known case of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) for which he's been undergoing treatment for the last 10 years. He has a 50 pack-years smoking history but has been a non-smoker for the past five years. He has stated his adherence to the prescribed medications for his existing conditions.  His family history is notable for cardiovascular disease  including his father’s myocardial infarction at a similar age and a brother with a history of angina.  He has no known allergies to medication. Current medications include Metformin 1000mg twice a day  Lisinopril 20mg/day  and Aspirin 100mg/day.  Given these demographic and medical details  the patient's critical limb ischemia and PAD are likely relating to his longstanding diabetes  smoking history  and familial predisposition to cardiovascular illnesses. Further diagnostic evaluations and formulation of a treatment plan are required.

Presentation of Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information:  • Name: Mrs. Betty White • Gender: Female • Age: 67 years old • Occupation: Retired school teacher • Ethnicity: Caucasian • Marital status: Widowed  Presenting Complaint:  Mrs. White was brought to the emergency department by her daughter who noticed her mother's left leg had turned pale and cool to touch. Mrs. White reported that she has been experiencing an increasing level of pain in her leg in the last few days  which mostly intensifies at rest  particularly at night. Besides  she mentioned that she has been finding it hard to walk even short distances without feeling severe pain. On questioning  she revealed that the pain is localized  radiating from the calf muscle towards her toes. She also admitted to noticing some black spots on her toes.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. White has a history of long-standing  uncontrolled type II diabetes. She was diagnosed 15 years ago and has had trouble managing her blood sugar levels due to a lack of consistent medication intake and poor diet control. She has struggled with regular follow-ups and has often missed her appointments with her diabetic care provider. She also has a background history of hypertension diagnosed seven years ago. Her medications include metformin  glipizide  and nifedipine. She quit smoking ten years ago but admits to a 20-year history of smoking prior to quitting.  Family History:  There is a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases. Her father died due to myocardial infarction and her older brother has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery. She also has a sister who is managing hypertension and diabetes  similar to her.  Social History:  Mrs. White lives alone but her daughter checks on her daily. She denies alcohol consumption. She was a school teacher until she retired ten years ago. She has minimal physical activity and admits to consuming a diet high in carbohydrates and fats.   This is a case of critical limb ischemia  highly suspected to be secondary to her peripheral artery disease  which happens as a complication of long-standing  poorly controlled diabetes  hypertension  and prior history of smoking. This diagnosis would be further confirmed by conducting an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test followed by angiography. Prompt management is needed in this case to prevent further complications like tissue necrosis and limb amputation.

Patient Presentation:  I would like to present a case of an 82-year-old African-American female known as Mrs. T. She resides in Fort Lauderdale  Florida. She has been a widow for the past 10 years and lives alone with the support of local community health care services. She is a former high school teacher who retired twenty years ago  and her primary language is English.  Mrs. T was referred to our clinic with the presenting concern of chronic leg pain over the last six months. She reports progressive pain in her right lower limb  even while at rest  and she identifies intermittent claudication. She has also noticed a non-healing wound on her right foot. The pain is excruciating enough to disrupt her sleep  indicating toward critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Mrs. T has a significant past medical history. She has been managing Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) for the past 15 years  which remains poorly controlled despite medication. She was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago  which is currently controlled with antihypertensive medication. She is also managing hyperlipidemia for the past 8 years.    She has a 30 pack-years smoking history but quit five years ago upon being diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She denies any history of alcohol or illicit drug use. Her surgical history includes hysterectomy and cholecystectomy. Mrs. T has a pacemaker due to tachy-brady syndrome about three years ago. She doesn’t have any known allergies.  Her family history includes coronary artery disease (CAD) in her father  who passed away from a myocardial infarction in his 70s. Her mother had stroke at the age of 82.   Given the severe pain  non-healing wound  and her classic signs of limb ischemia  there is a high level of clinical suspicion for the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia. An urgent vascular surgical consultation and appropriate diagnostic tests have been ordered to initiate the appropriate therapeutic management.

Subject: Clinical Presentation of Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information: - Name: John Smith - Age: 67 years old - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired engineer - Marital status: Widowed  Presenting Complaint: Mr. John Smith is a 67-year-old male patient presenting with severe pain in the right lower limb  which is non-responsive to analgesics and has been worsening over the last week. The patient also mentions having intermittent claudication for more than 6 months now. He reports of non-healing ulcers on his right foot  and the area looks blackened. Furthermore  he mentions that the right foot often feels cold compared to the left foot.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a significant medical history which includes: •	Hypertension •	Type II Diabetes Mellitus  •	Hyperlipidemia •	Coronary Artery Disease for which he had Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting 5 years ago. •	Smoking history - The patient has a 40-pack years history of smoking (he smoked a pack a day for 40 years but quit four years ago). •	Alcohol consumption - Minimal; he consumes alcohol socially.  Family History: •	His father died of heart attack at the age 70. •	His mother died at the age of 80 from diabetes related complications.   On examination  the pulses in the right lower limb are diminished. There is pallor and coldness of the right foot with non-healing ulcers observed on his right foot.  Investigations:  A non-invasive vascular study will be suggested to confirm the diagnosis. It includes Ankle-brachial index  Doppler ultrasound  CT angiography  and MR angiography.  Impression:  Among the preliminary impressions  the patient's symptoms  coupled with his past medical history  are suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia of the right lower extremity. The proposed plan is to confirm the diagnosis with the help of further investigations and then refer the patient to a vascular specialist for revascularization strategies to prevent limb loss.   The patient will be educated about the seriousness of his condition  potential complications if left untreated  and the necessity of adherence to therapy to prevent possible limb amputation.   Team comments: Given his significant risk factors including age  hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  CAD  and significant smoking history  this patient will continue to be followed up closely by a multidisciplinary team involving a primary care physician  endocrinologist  cardiologist  vascular surgeon  and a diabetic nurse specialist.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Gender: Male Age: 64 Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Teacher  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Doe presents with critical limb ischemia  primarily characterized by major leg pain at rest  non-healing wounds on feet  and tissue loss. The start of these symptoms has been traced back to approximately three months ago  progressively becoming more severe over time.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has had a long history of cardiovascular disorders  notably a history of Coronary Artery Disease. He also has been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus two type for 15 years. Consequently  he has been put on insulin therapy and has had previous instances of non-compliance with medication. His important records include a history of smoking for about 25 years  although he quit 5 years ago. Mr. Doe also dealt with high cholesterol before his retirement.  Current Medication:  Mr. Doe is currently under insulin therapy for type 2 diabetes and maintains a regimen of statins for high cholesterol.  Family History:   His father had a history of ischemic heart disease and passed due to a myocardial infarction in his late 60s. Mr. Doe's mother lived into her late 80s and suffered from hypertension and type 2 diabetes.  Social History:   Mr. Doe is a widower who lives with his daughter in the city. He has a limited physical activity. After retiring from his job five years ago  he’s majorly engaged in indoor activities only. He quit smoking five years ago and refrains from alcohol consumption.  Risk factors:  These include a history of smoking  advanced age  diabetes  high cholesterol  sedentary lifestyle  and existing cardiovascular conditions.  Physical Examination:  The physical exam conducted revealed a non-healing wound on his right foot  tepid peripheries  and diminished pulses in both lower limbs  more prominently on the right.  Taken together  Mr. Doe’s presenting complaint  medical history  physical examination  and risk factors are consistent with critical limb ischemia  a severe manifestation of peripheral arterial disease  primarily driven by a longstanding history of poorly controlled diabetes and a history of cardiovascular disease. He’s being referred for further investigations including an ankle-brachial index  duplex ultrasonography  and if needed  angiography.

Title: Case Presentation on Critical Limb Ischemia   Subject: Mr. James Kemp  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  Primary complaint: Mr. Kemp reports experiencing rest pain and non-healing sores on his left foot for the last two weeks. He also presents with noticeable discoloration of the affected foot  which appears pale and cold to touch.   Demographics: The patient is a retired schoolteacher  living in rural North Carolina. He is a lifetime nonsmoker and reports moderate alcohol use. He lives with his wife  with three adult children living independently. He does not report any known genetic or familial diseases.   Past medical history: Significant for multiple risk factors for atherosclerosis including hypertension (diagnosed 12 years ago)  hyperlipidemia (diagnosed 10 years ago) and type II diabetes mellitus (diagnosed 8 years ago). The patient had a myocardial infarction four years ago  which was managed percutaneously with drug-eluting stents. He has been taking aspirin  metformin  a statin and an ACE inhibitor for his conditions.  Physical assessment: The patient exhibits a weak pulse in the left dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial arteries in comparison to the other foot. He shows signs of ischemic ulceration on the left foot  with the affected area showing a dark discoloration.   Vital signs: Blood pressure is 142/88 mm of Hg  heart rate is 88 bpm  respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute  body temperature is 98.2°F  oxygen saturation is 98% on room air  and body mass index (BMI) is 31.   Clinical impression: The patient's symptoms  along with a compromised blood supply evident from a weak pulse  suggest a severe form of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  probably critical limb ischemia (CLI). The presence of risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and history of coronary artery disease further support this impression. Investigations like angiography  ankle-brachial index  and Doppler ultrasound may be necessary to visualize the extent of arterial obstruction  followed by relevant treatment strategies such as bypass surgery  angioplasty  or potentially amputation  if ischemia is severe. The patient also needs optimized control of his risk factors.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Brown  who resides in suburban New York.   Presenting symptoms: Mr. Brown presents with complaints of rest pain in the right lower extremity  which has been progressively worsening over the past six months. The patient notes that the pain seems to escalate at night when in bed  often waking him up and is relieved when his leg is hanging down. Additionally  he has developed a non-healing ulcer on the right foot's first toe. He also reports experiencing symptoms of intermittent claudication. He denies experiencing fever  chills  or recent trauma.   Past Medical History: Mr. Brown has an extensive past medical history  most notably  a known case of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  which is managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. His other conditions include hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with ACE inhibitors and statins  respectively.  The patient has a 45-pack year history of smoking but quit ten years ago after undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery for ischemic heart disease. Mr. Brown also has peripheral artery disease  for which he had stents placed in his left lower extremity two years ago.  Family History: His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  with both his father and older brother suffering from myocardial infarctions in their 50s. His mother died at the age of 70 due to stroke. Also  his sister  who is 68  lives with diabetes and hypertension.  Social History: Mr. Brown lives with his wife and is retired. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use but admits to a sedentary lifestyle due to his current physical limitations.  Physical Examination: Physical examination reveals a pale and cold right foot with reduced capillary refill. A non-healing ulcer measuring 1.5cm in diameter is seen over the dorsum of the right first toe. There are notably diminished dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses on the right side.  Based on the patient's history and physical findings  a presumptive diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia is made. Further tests including Ankle-brachial Index and angiography are planned to confirm the diagnosis and to decide on the appropriate line of management  which could be either surgical revascularization or endovascular intervention.         Given Mr. Brown's history of smoking  diabetes  and previous peripheral artery disease  it's clear he's at a high risk for developing severe peripheral arterial disease like critical limb ischemia. Therefore  it's of utmost importance to manage his risk factors more effectively and possibly prevent progression or recurrence of the disease.

Patient Presentation  I am presenting a case of a 65-year-old male Asian patient who was recently diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). The patient's name is Chin Lim  residing at Beijing  China. He came into the clinic primarily complaining of continuous and noticeable leg pain even while at rest  coupled with accessibility issues due to non-healing sores  ulcers and gangrene signs on his toes and feet.   Mr. Lim is a retired construction worker  a nonsmoker  but with significant alcohol use history. He has a health profile with the following past medical history:   1. Diabetes Mellitus  Type 2 for the last 20 years with inconsistent blood sugar control. 2. Hypertension with medication management since the last 15 years. 3. Angioplasty (PTCA) for significant Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) five years ago. 4. History of Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD).  In terms of family history  Mr. Lim had a father who suffered a myocardial infarction at an early age and a mother who also suffered from diabetes and hypertension  which suggests a potential hereditary predisposition to such conditions.  Given the reduced oxygen supply and chronic inflammation due to Diabetes and Hypertension  which likely resulted in poor peripheral circulation  this case of Critical Limb Ischemia is consistent with atherosclerosis progression.  Further investigations and relevant interventions are necessary to confirm the diagnosis and extend patient-relevant care to prevent disease complications such as lower limb amputations. Immediate action and disease management are essential to mitigate the risk of cardiovascular events or even death.  This case underscores the importance of early detection  strict regulation of comorbid conditions  and adopting a more proactive approach towards one's health  especially with such significant past medical history.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a Diabetic Patient   Patient Information: Patient's Name: Mr. John Ramirez Age: 64 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Hispanic  Occupation: Retired construction worker  History: Mr. Ramirez  a retired construction worker  suffering from Type 2 diabetes for the past 15 years has presented today with excruciating pain in his left leg. His pain has been worsening over the time period of the last couple of months and has been non-responsive to standard analgesics recently. Furthermore  he experiences temperature changes  weakness and numbness in the affected limb and has been finding it difficult to walk short distances.   Medical History: Along with the diabetes diagnosis  Mr. Ramirez unfortunately has a history of untreated hypertension and significant atherosclerosis  both identified ten years ago. He has also been a heavy smoker for over 40 years. Unfortunately  he has been rather non-compliant with his prescribed medications due to lack of health insurance coverage.  Physical Examination: On examination  his left foot was found to be pale  cold to touch with weak peripheral pulses. Foot ulcers were seen on the distal end of the left leg. The Ankle-Brachial index revealed a reading of less than 0.4  indicative of severe arterial disease.   Summary: In light of his medical history and the physical examination results  Mr. Ramirez is likely suffering from Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  an extremely serious form of peripheral artery disease (PAD). His condition is very severe and necessitates immediate intervention. Recommended steps include lifestyle modifications  cessation of smoking  strict control of diabetes and hypertension  and pharmacological interventions such as anti-platelets or anticoagulant drugs. Surgical revascularization may also be an option depending on the extent of the disease.  We  as a healthcare team  must consider Mr. Ramirez's socioeconomic constraints in managing his disease. It is critical that we take a comprehensive approach and make every possible effort to maximize the preservation of his limb while optimizing his quality of life.

Patient Presentation: Ms. Susan Thompson is a 68-year-old  Caucasian female presenting with symptoms indicative of critical limb ischemia in her left lower extremity.   Demographic Information: She hails from a suburban community  lives with her retired husband  and is a non-smoker. Susan is a former elementary school teacher and has been retired for 8 years now. She denies any use of illicit drugs or alcohol consumption but admits to a sedentary lifestyle over the past few years.  Past Medical History: Susan has a significant medical history  including Type II diabetes mellitus for the last 20 years which she manages with Metformin. She also has high blood pressure treated with Amlodipine and a record of high cholesterol levels managed with Atorvastatin. She was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) 5 years ago. No known drug allergies have been noted.  Clinical Presentation: Susan complains of extreme pain in her left foot  even during rest  and this has been increasingly disturbing her sleep. The pain has worsened considerably over the past week. She also reports having coldness in the lower leg  numbness or weakness  and ulcer formation with no signs of healing on her left toe. She also confessed to experiencing impotence  which is affecting her personal life. She mentioned that she started limping due to the pain which interrupted her daily activities.  In conclusion  considering her history of diabetes  hyperlipidemia  high blood pressure  PAD  and her current symptoms  Ms. Thompson's condition appears consistent with critical limb ischemia. This necessitates further vascular evaluation and immediate intervention to prevent advancement into severe stages potentially leading to limb loss.

Title: Presentation of Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Introduction: Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents with clinical symptoms and signs consistent with critical limb ischemia. Born and raised in Chicago  Mr. Smith is a former coal miner  leading an active lifestyle  with some exposure to heavy  manual labor during his earlier years. He was referred by his primary care physician for further evaluation and management.  Presenting Symptoms: He reports a six-month history of severe  constant burning pain in his right lower leg worsened by activities and somewhat relieved by rest. About two weeks ago  the pain became more intense and persistent  occurring even at rest with associated progressive discoloration and coldness of his right foot. He also noticed few non-healing sores on his toes.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a ten-year history of well-controlled type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hyperlipidemia. He had been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) three years ago for which he is on Aspirin therapy. He underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery eight years ago. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years  currently  on two packs a day  and consumes alcohol occasionally.  Family History: Mr. Smith has a family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father had a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his older sister has a history of stroke at the age of 60.  Physical Examination: Examination showed a well-nourished man in no apparent distress but with obvious discomfort in the right lower extremity. His right foot was noticeably cold with decreased capillary refill  and there was an absence of both dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses. There were several small  necrotic ulcers over the tips of his toes.  Diagnosis and Management: Based on his presentation  history  and physical examination  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia associated with Peripheral Artery Disease was made. Mr. Smith requires immediate intervention  given his unrelenting pain  foot discoloration and non-healing sores. Decision was made for an urgent consultation with a vascular surgeon to discuss potential limb salvage interventions.

Patient Presentation:   Our patient is a 74-year-old African American male who presents with a severe complaint of constant and recurring acute pain in his right lower limb  more so during the night and often results in sleep disturbance. He reports the pain as being at its worst when the leg is elevated. He also complains of experiencing coldness  numbness and tingling sensations in his lower extremity. Notably  he disclosed the presence of a non-healing wound on his right foot that has persisted for the past three weeks.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and dyslipidemia controlled with medications  type II diabetes mellitus managed with oral hypoglycemic agents for the past 10 years and a known history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). He quit smoking 5 years back  after 30 years of a pack-a-day habit. His BMI categorizes him as mildly obese.  Upon physical examination  there were notable changes in skin color and texture on his right lower leg and foot  with delayed capillary refill above the ulcerated area indicating poor perfusion. The non-healing wound on the foot appears as a shallow crater with a pale base and well-defined edges. Pulses in his right leg appear diminished  and greater than 2+ difference compared to his left side.  In conclusion  the patient's symptoms - rest pain  non-healing foot ulcer  and the physical findings of peripheral pulse deficits - are suggestive of critical limb ischemia (CLI)  an advanced form of PAD. His risk factors include advanced age  African American race  history of smoking  hypertension  dyslipidemia  diabetes  and obesity  all of which increase his susceptibility to atherosclerosis and in turn CLI. A comprehensive diagnostic and management plan should be formulated immediately to prevent limb loss.

Patient Presentation:  Good afternoon everyone  I will be presenting a patient with Critical Limb Ischemia.  Our patient is Mr. James Peterson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  currently living in Brooklyn  NY. He was admitted to the ER for severe rest pain in his left lower extremity  consistent with the typical presentation of critical limb ischemia. The pain has been increasing progressively over the last three weeks  causing a significant decrease in his mobility  and disturbing his sleep. On physical examination  there were marked pale areas on the left foot  significant muscle atrophy around the calf region  and evident ulcers along the inner aspect of his foot.   Delving into his past medical history  Mr. Peterson is a former smoker  having consumed 1-2 packs/day for approximately 35 years before quitting five years ago. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 20 years ago  which has been moderately controlled with insulin therapy. He also has a history of hypertension  managed with B-blockers and ACE inhibitors. Four years ago  he was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) for which he underwent an angioplasty of the right lower limb.   Mr. Peterson's past surgical history includes an appendectomy and cataract extraction. His family history is significant  with both parents succumbing to heart disease in their late 60s.   Given his advanced age  smoking history  diabetes  hypertension  and history of PAD  Mr. Peterson represents a typical patient with critical limb ischemia - it is likely that his condition has progressed due to the cumulative effect of his risk factors.   This concludes my presentation of Mr. Peterson. Thank you.

Patient Presentation :   I would like to present a patient  Mr. John Doe  a 70-year-old Caucasian male who hails from New York  USA. He had reported a Chief Complaint of worsening pain in his left leg that started two months ago. The pain is described as severe and persistent  which gets even worse during nighttime or when he elevates his leg. He also complains of his left foot being unusually cool to the touch with a noted dark discoloration on his toes.   In terms of past medical history  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes twenty years ago  which is poorly controlled. He was diagnosed with Hypertension fifteen years ago. He is an ex-smoker  having quit smoking 10 years ago  but smoked for approximately 30 years prior to quitting. He was also diagnosed with Peripheral Arterial Disease  and has undergone multiple unsuccessful percutaneous interventions.   Family history includes heart disease and Type 2 diabetes on his father's side  both grandfather and father passed away due to complications linked to cardiovascular diseases.   Upon examination  Mr. Doe's left foot has noticeable gangrenous changes on the tips of his toes  compromised pedal pulses  and an Ankle Brachial Index (ABI) of 0.4  indicating severe arterial insufficiency. His ABI on the right is 0.9  which is borderline normal.  In conclusion  Mr. Doe's history of long standing poorly controlled diabetes  smoking  and hypertension makes him a high risk patient for severe peripheral artery disease  manifesting now as critical limb ischemia. Immediate intervention  including possible surgical approach and improved control of his risk factors  is indicated. Mr. Doe's scenario underscores the importance of rigorous preventive care in high-risk patients with peripheral artery disease.

Patient Presentation:   We are discussing Mr. Robert Wilson  a 69-year-old Caucasian male with critical limb ischemia. Mr. Wilson is a retired mechanical engineer  married with two adult children. He is a resident of the local town since birth and is quite active in community services.  Medical History:   The patient has a 10-years history of type II diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia indicating a significant vascular disease risk. There are also prior cardiac issues with an incipient record of myocardial infarction experienced five years ago. There is a long-standing history of tobacco usage  though quit three years ago but had a 30-pack year smoking history. Patient has no known allergies. There's no family history of limb or peripheral vascular diseases.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Wilson presented to the ER with complaints of severe  continuous pain in his lower left limb  predominantly at rest  that has been worsening over the last three weeks  accompanied by non-healing sores and ulcers on the foot. He also pointed out noticeable color changes in the limb  significant hair loss  reduction in muscle mass  and numbness in the affected area. He noted occasional episodes of feeling cold in the lower limb and has experienced significant difficulties in walking due to the pain.  Overall  the past medical history  along with his presenting complaints  has led to a working diagnosis of critical limb ischemia.   Further examinations are to be carried out  but the patient's condition necessitates urgency in diagnosis and treatment due to the high risk of amputation or even death if left untreated. We will require vascular imaging studies and would consider revascularization procedures  dependent on the severity and extent of vascular occlusion found.

Presenting Patient: Mr. John Wilson  a 72 year old male  retired construction engineer.  Demographic Information:  Mr. Wilson is a Caucasian male  married with two adult children. He resides in the suburban area with his wife. He admits to being a former heavy smoker  with a 50 pack year history  but quit 10 years ago. He is a social drinker and denies any illicit drug use or toxic exposure.  Chief complaint:  Mr. Wilson presents with severe chronic pain in his right lower leg  which has worsened over the past six months. The pain was initially intermittent  more pronounced during walking and relieved by rest. Recently  it has nagged him even at rest  particularly at night. His right foot appears paler than the left  and feels cold to touch.   Past Medical History: Mr. Wilson has a significant medical history which includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  all managed with medication. He had a myocardial Infarction 5 years ago  for which he underwent angioplasty and he has been on cardiac medications since then.   Review of Systems:  Mr. Wilson complains of a weight loss  fatigue  decreased appetite  and difficulty in sleeping due to persistent pain. No complaints of fever  cough  chest pain  palpitation  gastrointestinal or urinary symptoms.   Family History: His father died of a heart attack at the age of 70 and his mother died of a stroke at the age of 65. His elder brother had a quadruple cardiac bypass surgery at the age of 55.  Conclusion: Given my client's history of cardiovascular disease  longstanding uncontrolled diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension  along with typical symptoms and physical findings  I suspect his presenting complaint can be attributed to Critical Limb Ischemia  a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet and legs) and has progressed to cause severe pain and skin ulcers or sores. His history of being a heavy smoker also plays a significant risk factor. Immediate vascular assessment is warranted and appropriate interventions are to be undertaken.

Patient Presentation:  We have a 72-year-old female patient  Mrs. Eleanor Park  she is a resident of Baltimore  Maryland. She belongs to the Caucasian ethnicity and lives with her 75-year-old husband. She is a retired school teacher and enjoys gardening as her hobby.   The patient has been suffering from progressive pain in her right lower extremity over the past few weeks which has now become unbearable and chronic  restricting her mobility. The pain persists even during resting hours  indicating critical limb ischemia. Intermittent claudication initially presented six months ago  which has intensified over the period. There's also noticeable discoloration and coolness in comparison to the left lower limb  indicating severe ischemia. No latency in capillary refilling  though.   From her medical records  the patient has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 20 years  managed with Metformin. She has hypertension under control with daily doses of Amlodipine. She had suffered a Myocardial Infarction 5 years ago  which was managed successfully with Percutaneous Transluminal Coronary Angioplasty (PTCA) and drug therapy. The patient is also a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago. She does not consume alcohol.  Family history includes Cardiovascular Diseases on the father's side  who died due to a massive stroke. Mother had passed away due to old age with Alzheimer's disease. Her younger brother is living with diabetes and hypertension  echoing a pattern of familial hypertension and diabetes.  Given her medical history  age  and current symptoms  she is at high risk and immediate diagnostic and intervention strategies are required to prevent limb loss in this case of critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  Good morning everyone   Today  I am presenting a 68-year-old African American male  Mr. Jackson  who currently lives in Portland  Oregon. He is a retired steelworker  a regular smoker for the past 45 years  and has a history of occasional alcohol consumption.  Mr. Jackson had no significant health complaint until five years ago  when he was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Despite several management strategies  his diabetes and hypertension poorly controlled. He also has a regarded history of hyperlipidemia.   He presents today with a chief complaint of severe pain in his left lower limb  particularly in the calf and foot  for the past six months. The pain exacerbates with even minimal exertion and occasionally occurs at rest. He reports having non-healing wounds on his left foot and states that it worsens over time. Furthermore  he mentions intermittent claudication  deterioration in his mobility  and immense pain disrupting his sleep at night which suggests rest pain.   He does not have any known allergies. He has been adhering to a regimen of Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin for his diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia respectively  with irregular compliance. Mr. Jackson has no surgical history  and there is no noted familial predisposition to vascular diseases.  In summary  Mr. Jackson’s prolonged smoking history  poor control of risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes  as well as his typical symptoms  suggests a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). However  further investigations  such as Ankle-brachial index (ABI) and imaging studies like Doppler ultrasound  CT angiography or MR angiography  will be beneficial to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of the disease.   Thank you for your attention. I welcome any questions and collaborative discussion on Mr. Jackson's diagnosis and potential treatment options.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Williams is a 62-year-old Caucasian male presenting with critical limb ischemia (CLI) in his left lower extremity. Criminal limb ischemia is a severe blockage in the arteries of the limb or limbs that significantly decreases blood flow leading to pain and tissue death  thus leading to amputation if left untreated.   Mr. Williams first noticed pain in his lower leg about six months ago that has progressively worsened. He reports the pain has significantly increased over the last two weeks. Recently he's started to feel the pain even at rest. He also reports non-healing ulcers on his left foot  and he feels the foot is colder than the right one.   In terms of Mr. Williams' past medical history  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago  which he has managed with oral hypoglycemic agents and lifestyle modifications. He was also diagnosed with hypertension five years ago  which he controls with lifestyle modifications and antihypertensive medication. Mr. Williams is a former smoker who stopped 10 years ago  after a 30-year history of daily smoking.  There is no known family history of cardiovascular disease or peripheral artery disease. He has no known allergies. He is retired and lives with his wife. He exercises 3 to 4 times weekly  mostly walking in his neighbourhood.   Mr. Williams' illness is consistent with the development of CLI  contributed to by his past medical history of long-standing diabetes and smoking. These are significant risk factors for peripheral arterial disease which is the most common cause of CLI. His hypertension can further aggravate atherosclerosis. This man needs comprehensive medical care and treatment planning to prevent possible limb amputation. His treatment should include aggressive medical therapy  potential revascularization procedures  preventative foot care  and effective management of diabetes and hypertension.

Patient Presentation:  Good evening  I'm presenting a 63-year-old African-American male patient  Mr. Anthony Sanders  with critical limb ischemia. Mr. Sanders has been a pack-a-day smoker for the past 40 years and has a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and peripheral arterial disease.   Mr. Sanders was first diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease about a decade ago  reporting intermittent claudication in his right calf. In recent months  however  he complained of escalating pain in the same leg while at rest  particularly at night  which was relieved by hanging the limb over the side of the bed. He also revealed that an ulcer about the size of a half-dollar has appeared on his right foot  specifically on the great toe  which has not shown significant healing despite regular care and efforts to maintain foot hygiene.  Upon examination  the patient's right leg appeared pallid compared to the left  with decreased hair growth  dystrophic toenails  and a cold sensation to touch. His foot pulses were notably decreased  and an ankle-brachial index was obtained revealing a reading of 0.40 on the right side  indicating severe ischemia.  The primary aim for Mr. Sanders' management is to alleviate pain  to heal his foot ulcer  and to prevent limb amputation considering his quality of life and overall functional status. Given his history and recent symptoms  vascular surgery consultation would be an appropriate step moving forward.   The patient's critical limb ischemia seems to be intricately linked to his longstanding smoking history  peripheral arterial disease  and poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes. Thus  managing these conditions while working on wound care  pain control  and possible revascularization will be integral parts of his treatment and monitoring plan.   Given his risk factors and current state  Mr. Sanders needs appropriate education on limb care  importance of good foot hygiene  optimal control of diabetes  aggressive management of blood pressure  and assistance in smoking cessation to prevent any further progression.

Title: Case Presentation – Critical Limb Ischemia Patient  Patient's Profile: Name : Mr. Johnson  Age : 68 years old Race : Caucasian Gender : Male Occupation : Retired Engineer  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Johnson presents with chronic  profound pain in his lower right leg  particularly when he tries to walk or exercise. Accompanying this  he reports coldness in his lower leg  some numbness  and the presence of non-healing ulcers on his foot. His wife also noticed a change in the color of his leg which shows pallor in elevation and bright red in dependent position - indicating severe blood flow deficiencies.  Demographics: Mr. Johnson is a former smoker and has a significant history of alcohol consumption. He follows a diet that is high in saturated fats  contributing to his obesity (BMI 32). Despite his retired status  he is quite active societally  regularly participating in community service and catch-ups with his grandchildren. He enjoys good familial support but finds it hard to maintain adherence to his medication regimen.  Past Medical History: History remarkable for 20 years of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and 15 years of hypertension  along with occasional instances of arrhythmia. He underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) from a previous diagnosis of coronary artery disease 5 years back. He was also diagnosed with peripheral artery disease in his left leg last year and underwent a percutaneous transluminal angioplasty successfully. Oral antiplatelet therapy has been part of his chronic medication besides his diabetes and hypertension medications.  Clinical Summary: Given the demographics and past medical history  the chronic limb-threatening ischemia symptoms can be attributed to a combination of Mr. Johnson's non-compliance with his chronic medications  his long-term diabetes  obesity  history of smoking  and poor diet choices that have likely contributed to atherosclerotic progression. Further investigations are needed to assess the extent of the disease and to plan the necessary interventions. His prognosis would depend largely on his adherence to treatments and lifestyle modifications.

Patient Presentation  Good day everyone  the patient I am discussing today is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting with critical limb ischemia (CLI). He is a retired school teacher and currently lives with his wife; he has no dependents with him. He has been a lifelong smoker with a pack-year history of 48  and has been an occasional alcohol drinker.   Regarding relevant past medical history: The patient has an established diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus and has been on oral hypoglycemics for the past 15 years. His sugar control  however  has been suboptimal. He also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which he has been managing with medication for 10 years. The patient is currently on medication for both conditions. Eight years ago  he was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease which was being managed conservatively till now.  The patient has now presented with worsening rest pain in his right lower limb  which has been troubling him for the past 6 months. His recent symptoms include non-healing ulcers and significant weight loss resulting from decreased appetite.  Evidently  our aim will be to provide symptomatic relief  to prevent the progression of the disease  and to avoid limb amputation using possible intervention  such as vascular bypass surgery. However  further investigations are required to confirm the severity and the best treatment approach.  In conclusion  this patient is a classic presentation of Critical Limb Ischemia  which is unfortunately too common amongst patients with risk factors like smoking  diabetes  and hypertension. Early recognition and aggressive management of these risk factors are imperative in preventing such severe complications.  Does anyone have any questions about this patient's history or condition?

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  I. Patient Demographics  - Name: John Smith - Age: 65 years old  - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired engineer - Marital Status: Married - Insurance: Medicare - Address: 1026 Elms Road  New York  NY  II. Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith visited the hospital with severe pain in his lower legs and feet  which has escalated over the last month. He expressed that the pain is more severe at night and elevating his limbs often offers little relief. He has also noticed wounds on his feet that are slow to heal and some areas of skin discoloration.  III. Past Medical History:  - Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes 15 years ago  which is poorly controlled. - Cardiovascular disease diagnosed 10 years ago. - History of hyperlipidemia. - Nonsmoker  but smoked one pack a day for 20 years before quitting 15 years ago. - Penicillin allergy.  IV. Medications:  He is currently on Metformin  Lisinopril and Atorvastatin.  V. Family History:  His father suffered from peripheral artery disease and had a stroke at the age of 72. His mother had hypertension and his sister was recently diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes.  VI. Social History:  He lives with his wife and is retired. He used to enjoy walking in the local park with his wife  however  due to pain and discomfort he is unable to do so.  VII. Physical Exam:  On examination  Mr. Smith's lower limbs appeared pale and cold to touch  with a marked decrease in popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial pulses. Non-healing ulcers were noted on his feet.  VIII. Diagnostic Impression:  Based on the clinical presentation and physical examination  the patient is likely suffering from Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  which fits with his history of diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Further diagnostic procedures such as ankle-brachial index  ultrasound and angiography should be conducted for a definitive diagnosis and potential consideration for revascularization procedures.  IX. Treatment Plan: Pending formal diagnosis  possible plans include aggressive control of his diabetes and hyperlipidemia  pain management  wound care  smoking cessation education even though he has quit  and possibly referring the patient to a vascular surgeon.

Presentation of Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Description: The patient  Mr. R.J.  is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents with the classic symptoms of Critical Limb Ischemia. He is retired and lives with his wife in the city. He has a 40-pack year history of smoking but claims to have quit five years ago. He is a former machinist and was regularly exposed to potential environmental toxins and pollutants. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle post-retirement and a diet rich in fatty  processed foods.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. R.J. came to the hospital complaining about intense leg pain that is continuous even when at rest  particularly in his right calf. He reports a worsening pattern of cramping and pain during locomotion known as intermittent claudication. He also notes discomfort at night  preventing sound sleep. On inspection  for the last week  his right leg shows signs of non-healing ulcers on his toes and a noticeable color change to a bluish hue.  Past Medical History: His medical record shows a history of hypertension and type II diabetes  both maintained with medication and lifestyle modifications. A history of coronary artery disease was diagnosed eight years ago; underwent angioplasty with stenting five years ago. No history of surgeries or post-surgical complications  no allergies to medications or food. Family history reveals his father had peripheral artery disease and his mother had stroke and hypertension.  In summary  the patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of smoking and sedentary lifestyle who presents with symptoms suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia  including unrelenting lower limb pain and skin ulcers. His cardiovascular risk factors include hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and coronary artery disease. Immediate evaluation and intervention are necessary to prevent potential complications such as severe infection or limb loss.

Patient Profile:   Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 66 years  Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired construction worker  Residential Area: Urban  Presenting Complaint:  Patient presents with symptoms of critical limb ischemia (CLI) including severe pain in his right lower limb  extending from his thigh to his toes  which intensifies further during the nights. Title: Presentation of a Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia   Patient Information: Our patient is a 67-year-old African American male  weighing 80 kg  and reports as a non-smoker. The patient resides at an assisted living facility in Charleston  SC  and retired 5 years ago from a career in construction.   Presenting Issue: The patient is presenting with acute onset of pain in his right lower extremity  specifically in the calf area  that's unrelieved by rest. The patient describes the pain as a severe burning sensation  rating it 7 out of 10 on the pain scale. The pain is accompanied by numbness and coldness in the extremity. The patient also indicates a recent history of non-healing ulcers on the foot.  Past Medical History: Notably  the patient has a long-standing history of peripheral artery disease. His past medical history also shows a record of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are being managed with Lisinopril and Metformin respectively. He further suffers from occasional episodes of angina. The patient underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery 8 years ago for the management of ischemic heart disease.  Family History: His father succumbed to a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. Both the patient's mother and older brother were diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hypertension.  Current Assessment: Given the history and current symptoms  the patient is suspected to have critical limb ischemia (CLI)  a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.    Further tests  including imaging of the blood vessels via ultrasonography or angiography  are recommended to confirm the diagnosis and severity of the disease  and to guide interventional or surgical procedures if necessary.

Patient Presentation:  This is a case of Mr. Allen  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  who presents with complaints of severe rest pain in the right lower extremity  particularly in the foot. He reports a significant weight loss in the past few months due to loss of appetite. There is no associated fever  trauma or surgery prior to the onset of symptoms.  Mr. Allen is an ex-tobacco smoker  with a 40-pack-year smoking history (stopped 5 years ago)  has been consuming alcohol occasionally for the past 25 years  and does not report any form of recreational drug use. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he is on oral medications  peripheral artery disease (PAD)  for which he had undergone angioplasty of the left limb two years ago  and hypertension  which is well controlled on a prescribed antihypertensive medication regimen.  Upon examination  noticeable signs include skin discoloration on the right foot  non-healing ulcers on the foot's lateral aspect  and thickened toenails. Furthermore  peripheral pulse assessment shows significant attenuation of the dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses. His BMI indicates he is overweight.  Diagnostic tests are planned to confirm the definitive diagnosis  but the presenting symptoms and history are suggestive of critical limb ischemia (CLI). Early intervention is key to avoid severe complications such as limb amputation. The multidisciplinary approach to his management would involve a vascular surgeon  primary care physician  dietitian  and diabetes educator  given his underlying comorbidities.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presents with critical limb ischemia of his right lower extremity. He currently resides in Raleigh  North Carolina and is a retired engineer. He has been married for 50 years with three grown children and six grandchildren.  His presenting symptoms include severe pain in his right foot at rest  non-healing sores on his right lower leg and foot  and a noticeable color change in his right foot to a pale coloration. Additionally  the patient has reported increasing difficulty in walking due to muscular fatigue and weakness in the right leg.
