He has a significant past medical history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  which he has had for the past 25 years. The patient has been moderately compliant with diabetic diet and medication. Due to this  his blood sugar levels are inconsistently controlled. He has a history of diabetic peripheral neuropathy which was diagnosed 10 years ago. Additionally  the patient has been diagnosed with hypertension and high cholesterol levels. He has been on medication for both for the past 15 years.  He is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago after a 30-year smoking history. He denies alcohol use but admits to occasional over-the-counter NSAID use for arthritis.  Family history includes his father  who passed away at the age of 65 from a myocardial infarction. The patient's mother is alive at 90 with a history of stroke at age 80. His two older brothers are alive and well  but one is also a diagnosed Type II diabetic.  On physical examination  the right foot showed decreased capillary refill  loss of hair  thinning skin  and ulcerations at the heel and distal aspect of the big toe.  The patient is concerned about his health status as his pain and mobility difficulties are affecting his quality of life. This requires immediate and comprehensive medical attention to alleviate his symptoms and prevent further complications. Talk therapy and support could also be beneficial considering the risk of emotional impact due to chronic disease and decreased mobility.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Description:  The patient is a 75-year-old African American male  Mr. John Doe. He is a retired engineer  living with his wife in their home. His BMI is 28. He is a former smoker with 20 pack-years but has been tobacco-free for the last 15 years. Mr. Doe consumes alcohol occasionally during social events  denying any habitual use.   Chief Complaint: Mr. Doe presents with non-healing ulcers in his right foot  which have persisted for approximately five weeks. He describes experiencing severe pain in his right leg  even while at rest. He also reports discomfort while walking  necessitating frequent breaks before reaching his destination.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe's past history includes Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which he has managed for the past 20 years with metformin. He also has a history of uncontrolled hypertension  for which he has been prescribed lisinopril. His medical history also includes hyperlipidemia  which is managed with atorvastatin. He had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago  with a subsequent double vessel coronary artery bypass graft  which has left him with occasional angina. He admits to poor medication adherence due to medication cost.   Family History: His family history is significant  with an elderly father who suffered a stroke and a sibling who died of myocardial infarction at a young age. His mother had diabetes and a younger brother currently being treated for peripheral artery disease (PAD).  Current Diagnosis: After complete physical examination  including an ankle-brachial index test and arterial doppler ultrasound of the lower extremity  Mr. Doe has been diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) as the cause of his consistent lower extremity pain and non-healing foot ulcers. His clinical presentation  his chronic conditions  particularly poorly managed Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension  coupled with his smoking history  make him high risk for this condition.  Recommended course of action:  CLI is a serious condition requiring prompt revascularization intervention. A multidisciplinary approach involving a vascular surgeon  diabetic specialist  and wound care expert is recommended to manage this case effectively. Timely intervention will significantly reduce the chance of major limb amputation and improve quality of life. Mr. Doe will also need counseling and assistance regarding medication adherence  lifestyle modification  smoking cessation  and glucose control.   Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of recognizing the symptoms of CLI promptly and addressing the risk factors to salvage the limb and improve patient outcome. Special emphasis should be put on managing diabetes and hypertension  and controlling and treating hyperlipidemia.

Patient Presentation:  Our patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting with critical limb ischemia primarily in the right lower extremity and symptoms of muscle pain  cold feet  and non-healing ulcers. The patient has been a smoker for 50 years with approximately a 30 pack-year history. He quit smoking  though  two years ago. He has a fairly sedentary lifestyle and his diet could be described as high in processed and fatty foods.   Past Medical History:   He has been living with uncontrolled type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the last 20 years  complicated with peripheral neuropathy. His HbA1c level fluctuates between 7.5% and 9.0%. He also has Hypertension that is relatively controlled with medications.   The patient was diagnosed with Chronic Kidney Disease stage 3 about five years ago and is under a nephrologist’s care. He has a history of Coronary Artery Disease and has undergone Percutaneous Coronary Intervention with stenting two years ago.  The patient denies any history of stroke  transient ischemic attack  atrial fibrillation  deep vein thrombosis  or pulmonary embolism. He does not take any anticoagulants but is on a statin for Dyslipidemia.  Family History:   He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father had a heart attack in his 60s and his mother died of stroke in her 70s.  In conclusion  the patient is at significant risk due to his long history of smoking  uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  dyslipidemia  chronic kidney disease  and CAD. His sedentary lifestyle and poor diet also factor into the high risk. Urgent comprehensive assessment by a vascular surgeon is mandatory for this case.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. George Palmer is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  currently living in Jacksonville  Florida. He is a retired army veteran and has been relatively active since his retirement. Mr. Palmer presented complaining of severe pain in his right lower extremity  particularly when he walks  along with numbness and tingling sensation. He has noticed that these symptoms worsen when the leg is elevated and also reports coldness in the affected extremity.  Demographics:  Mr. Palmer was born on September 7  1952  making him 68 years of age as of the present time. He was born in Atlanta  Georgia and moved to Jacksonville  Florida upon retirement. He is a widower with 2 children  both currently living out of state. He lives alone but maintains a close relationship with his daughter who visits frequently.  Past Medical History:  In 2006  Mr. Palmer was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. His diabetes has been reasonably well-controlled with Metformin and diet changes  although he mentions recent struggles with maintaining strict diet control due to living alone. His most recent HbA1c was 7.8%  suggesting poor glycemic control in the past few months.   In 2013  he was diagnosed with hypertension which has been under control with Lisinopril. He also was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia in 2015  managed by a combination of diet and statin therapy (Atorvastatin). He reports good adherence to his medication regimen but admits to occasional lapses due to forgetfulness.  He has a significant history of tobacco use  with a 40-pack year history (2 packs/day for 20 years). He successfully quit smoking in 2011 following a diagnosis of COPD. Despite this  he does experience chronic shortness of breath and utilizes an albuterol inhaler for symptomatic relief. He denies a history of coronary artery disease  stroke or peripheral artery disease.  Given his presentation and past medical history  it is plausible that Mr. Palmer may be experiencing critical limb ischemia  which may be due to underlying peripheral vascular disease  likely secondary to longstanding diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and history of smoking. It is strongly advised that further diagnostic investigations  potentially including angiography among other tests  be pursued to confirm this diagnosis and guide subsequent treatment.

Patient Presentation:  Today we are discussing an individual named Patricia Thompson  a 68-year-old Caucasian female diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI). Patricia resides in a rural residential area and had retired from her teaching profession.  Patricia presents with complaints of pain  aching  and cramping in her right lower extremity  consistent with CLI's typical symptoms. She has noticed that this discomfort is amplified during periods of physical activity but eases up when at rest. She's recently noticed a non-healing wound on her right foot  accompanied by pallor in her leg.  Her medical history is highly relevant to today's presentation. She has a 15-year history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus and has struggled with poor glycemic control  despite multiple medication adjustments.   Patricia has also been treated for hypertension and high cholesterol over the last ten years and has been on an antihypertensive and statin regimen. However  she admits struggles with lifestyle modification and medication compliance due to various socio-economic issues  such as lack of access to healthy foods and physical activity opportunities in her rural community.  In addition  Patricia has a 30-year smoking history (1 pack per day)  and although she has made several attempts to quit using nicotine patches and gum  she has consistently relapsed back into her smoking habits.  On examining her family history  her father suffered a myocardial infarction in his early 60s  and her older brother was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) in his late 50s.  Her physical examination revealed significant findings  include abnormal lower extremity pulse examination with weak dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses  skin color changes  and skin ulcers on her right foot  which are indicative of advanced PAD and critical limb ischemia.  In conclusion  Mrs. Thompson's primary risk factors contributing to her CLI include her long-standing diabetes  smoking history  uncontrolled hypertension  and high cholesterol levels  accentuated by her genetic predisposition. It is vital to formulate an aggressive treatment plan considering these factors to prevent limb loss and other serious complications.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Anthony Davis  a 67-year-old African-American male  presents with critical limb ischemia. The patient has been experiencing severe pain in his left leg  which has exacerbated in the past couple of weeks. He has also noted noticeable changes in the color and temperature of the affected limb. In addition  he reports intermittent sores that are slow to heal.   The patient has a past medical history significant for atherosclerosis  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker with a 30-year pack history  although he has quit 5 years back. There is no history of any major surgical procedures and his immunizations are up to date. His current medications include atorvastatin  low-dose aspirin  and amlodipine.   Family history is remarkable with both his father and older brother having peripheral arterial disease  with his father having had a below-the-knee amputation due to complications of this condition. There is also a generational history of cardiovascular disease in his family  with several close relatives having heart attacks at relatively young ages. The patient is retired and lives alone in his house. He manages his daily activities independently but reports some difficulty in ambulating due to his current leg discomfort.   This combination of demographic details  personal habits  family history  and concomitant medical conditions puts Mr. Davis at an escalated risk for peripheral artery disease and its severe form - critical limb ischemia  which he now appears to be suffering from. He requires immediate diagnostic intervention for further evaluation and treatment planning.

Presentation of Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Demographic Information: The patient is a 70-year-old African American male named Mr. John Doe  living in New York  USA. He is married  retired  and lives with his wife. His primary language is English  and he is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. He is covered by Medicare and his income level is middle class.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe was diagnosed with type II Diabetes 10 years ago  which has been managed through insulin administration and other oral medications. He also suffers from hypertension for which he has been on medication for roughly 15 years. He suffered a Myocardial Infarction 5 years ago  which has escalated his cardiac health concern. Notably  he has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; both his father and paternal grandfather passed away from heart diseases in their late 60s.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe is presenting with symptoms consistent with Critical Limb Ischemia. These symptoms include severe pain in both legs  even while at rest  that has been worsening over the past few weeks. He also reports having ulcers on his feet that are not healing and a noticeable decrease in the temperature of his legs. He has experienced no trauma or injury to either of his lower extremities.  These symptoms have led to difficulties in performing daily activities and have compromised his quality of life. Considering his advanced age  history of diabetes  hypertension  heart attack  and a genetic predisposition to heart diseases  he is categorized as a high-risk patient.   An immediate and detailed assessment is crucial for Mr. Doe to prevent further deterioration and potential limb loss due to Critical Limb Ischemia. He is in need of a comprehensive treatment strategy that includes an aggressive plan to manage his diabetes  hypertension  and leg pain  along with potential surgical intervention.

Presentation of Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain in his right lower limb. He lives in Greensboro  North Carolina  and was brought in by his daughter. His primary language is English and he is retired from a job in transportation. He is a non-smoker and denies alcohol or substance use.  Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a complex past medical history. Significant conditions include Type II diabetes which has been poorly controlled for the past ten years. He also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia which are controlled with medication. Interestingly  he was diagnosed with Peripheral Artery Disease about five years ago. His surgical history includes a coronary artery bypass graft for ischemic heart disease in the past.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presents with critical limb ischemia of his right lower extremity characterized by pain in the calf  which escalates at night and also during mild physical activities. He also reports intermittent claudication  progressively worsening over the past six months. This has significantly compromised his walking distance and overall mobility.  Physical Examination:  Physical examination revealed a significantly decreased temperature on his right lower extremity compared to left. Additionally  there was notable pallor upon elevation and peripheral cyanosis. Notably  his right foot was pale with reduced capillary refill (greater than 3 seconds) and weakened pedal and dorsalis pulses. There were early-stage ischemic ulcers on his toe and black discoloration suggesting gangrene development.   In conclusion  Mr. Doe is suffering from Critical Limb Ischemia which seems to have progressed significantly due to his past medical conditions  particularly his diabetes and peripheral artery disease. His condition is severe and requires immediate attention to prevent further complications like infection and possible amputation.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Antonio  a 73-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic with complaints of intense  constant pain in his right lower limb  which is exacerbated when he is in a resting position. He reports that the pain has been progressing over the past two months while his foot has developed a noticeable discoloration  changing to a dark purplish color.   Upon examination  his right foot is cold to touch with diminished pulse strength. There also appears to be a non-healing wound on the ball of the foot which the patient reports has been present for the last three weeks.   He has a significant medical history  including Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which has been poorly controlled for the last 15 years. He also suffers from hypertension and Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD)  diagnosed 10 years ago. The patient has been a heavy smoker for the past 50 years. His surgical history is non-significant. His medications include Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Aspirin for PAD.  Family history includes Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and myocardial infarction.   Given the patient's history and symptoms  Mr. Antonio is suspected to have Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Further diagnostic studies are recommended to confirm the diagnosis  evaluate the severity of the disease  and plan an appropriate therapeutic strategy.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Anita Castro  a 72-year-old Hispanic female  presents to the clinic today accompanied by her son. She has chronic pain in her left lower leg and foot  especially when at rest. She reports that the pain disrupts her sleep and has made mobility difficult. She also notes intermittent complaints of cold and pallor in the respective leg  and her son points out a non-healing ulcer on her left foot that has persisted for several weeks. On top of these  a noticeable limp can be observed as she walks.  Her past medical history includes a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  poorly controlled despite regular insulin therapy and dietary modifications. She also has a 30-year history of smoking 1 pack per day  though she quit 3 years ago. She also has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago  after which she was placed on multiple cardiac medications.  The patient lives alone  their diet is not always appropriate and she struggles with medication adherence; often because she forgets to take them. She has no known drug allergies. Her father passed away after a stroke and her mother had diabetes.  Given the chronicity of the symptoms  the long-standing history of uncontrolled diabetes and smoking  along with the presence of other risk factors  the clinical suspicion of critical limb ischemia is high and warrants immediate diagnostic workups.

Patient Presentation:  Patient:  Mr. Alberto Martinez  a 68-year-old male from Hispanic background  presents with complaints of severe  consistent pain in the left lower limb  particularly in the foot and calf region. The patient has a long-standing history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus (over 20 years) with irregular blood sugar management. Past medical records also reflect high blood pressure (hypertension) and consequential damage to the kidneys (nephropathy). He was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) 2 years back.  Symptoms:  Mr. Martinez complains of sharp  burning pain in the left foot  which increases at night causing disturbed sleep (rest pain). He reports foot sores and ulcers which heal slowly or not at all. The patient notes a diminished quality of life as the persistent pain forces him to reduce his daily activities. On probing further  the patient admits experiencing erectile issues lately  which he initially dismissed due to his age.  Physical Exam:  On physical examination  the left foot appears discolored (pallor). Palpation reveals an absence of pulsation in the left foot and lower peripheral region. Nonhealing ulcer observed on the ventral aspect of the left foot. Noticeable muscle atrophy observed on the left leg. Hair loss in the left foot and toe region is evident. There is no evidence of fever  and other vitals are within normal limits.  Relevant Past Medical History:  - Type 2 diabetes mellitus (poorly controlled) - Hypertension - Nephropathy - Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) - History of smoking and alcohol use - Dyslipidemia (high levels of low-density lipoprotein and triglycerides and a low level of high-density lipoprotein) - Obesity (BMI: 33)    This consistent symptomatology and medical history reveal a presentation of critical limb ischemia. Referral to a vascular specialist  immediate intervention  and stringent glycemic control would be the next steps to avoid amputation and improving quality of life.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Smith  a 75-year-old African American male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack-year history of smoking  presents with a chief complaint of rest pain in his left lower extremity. He reports this pain is particularly worse at night  forcing him to hang his foot over the side of the bed for relief  and describes it as a constant  severe  burning sensation. He also notes a non-healing ulcer on his left big toe with associated discoloration of the toe. Further  he reveals that the pain eventually wakes him up at night and is relieved only by walking around his room.   Upon physical examination  his left lower extremity is found to be colder compared to the other leg. The limb is pale in appearance  sparse hair  brittle nails  and the capillary refill time (CRT) is significantly delayed. The left dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are barely palpable.   Relevant past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension on medication  active nicotine dependence  poorly controlled diabetes with retinopathy and neuropathy  and hyperlipidemia. Mr. Smith has undergone coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery five years ago. He has no history of stroke  kidney disease  or claudication. He does not consume alcohol and lives alone. His medications include insulin  metformin  an ACE inhibitor  a beta-blocker  a statin  and aspirin.

Patient Presentation:  A 75-year-old African-American male  Mr. AD  presents an abrupt onset severe resting pain in his right lower extremity  which dramatically worsens at night. As a retired steel worker  he has a history of long-term heavy smoking  about two packs a day for the past 50 years  and also had poorly controlled type-2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 15 years ago and peripheral arterial disease (PAD) diagnosed around five years ago.   His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases - both his father and elder brothers died from myocardial infarctions. The patient does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He's been gradually losing weight for the past few months and also noticed that his right foot is constantly cold and its skin looks pale.  Physical examination showed an ulcer on the dorsal aspect of the right foot near the big toe  having a diameter of about 2 cm with gangrenous changes. Palpation of the right lower limb reveals no palpable pulses. The Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) is significantly decreased to 0.4 on the right side  while it is 0.9 on the left side.  The patient is on metformin along with antihypertensive drugs  statin and anti-platelet agent for his past medical conditions. He adheres to his medication regimen  but struggles with diabetes control and cessation of smoking. The patient lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver. He expresses severe distress about the possibility of amputation.   Given the above findings  critical limb ischemia is suspected.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old female  Mrs. Smith  currently a retired nurse  presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent  excruciating pain in her right lower leg which she describes as a deep-seated ache intensified at rest. The pain has been disrupting her sleep for the past two weeks. She also reports experiencing intermittent claudication or discomfort with walking  but these episodes have been progressively worsening over the past 6 months. She noted the appearance of non-healing sores on her right foot two weeks ago. On inspection  the skin of the affected leg appeared pale  and pulses were weak. Further examination revealed a small  ulcerated wound on the dorsal aspect of the foot.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Mrs. Smith shared a past medical history significant for 15 years of type-2 diabetes mellitus  which is somewhat controlled through oral hypoglycemic medications. She also has been diagnosed with high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels over the past 10 years  managed by anti-hypertensives and statins respectively. Mrs. Smith is a former smoker with a 20 pack-year history who quit about a year ago after experiencing a minor myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  John Doe  a 72-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for poorly controlled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and tobacco use presented to the ED with severe pain in his right lower extremity. The patient reports that the pain is a sharp  9/10 intensity pain that is constant and non-radiating. Motor and sensory function are impacted distal to the knee  and he describes the foot as feeling “cold and numb.” This has been a chronic issue but has drastically worsened over the past week. He mentioned recent non-healing ulcers on his right foot and noted that he has lost weight unintentionally over the past few weeks.  Review of systems is significant for decreased appetite and generalized fatigue. Pain is unrelieved with over-the-counter medications and is associated with decreased sleep. He denies fever  chills  recent trauma  chest pain  or shortness of breath. The patient has intermittent claudication with pain upon minimal exertion which subsides with rest.  On examination  the right lower limb is noticeably cooler compared to the left. Capillary refill time is prolonged at over 5 seconds in the right foot compared to under 3 seconds in the left foot. No palpable pulses are detected in the right popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial regions. The right foot is pale and dry skin with multiple sores that are slow to heal. There is no noticeable edema  but atrophy of the muscles of the right leg distal to the knee is observed. There are tobacco stains on his fingers and his breath smells of tobacco.  On obtaining the patient's social history  the patient mentioned he smoked 1 pack of tobacco daily for the past 50 years  he consumes alcohol on social occasions  and he is non-compliant with medications for his diabetes. There is no familial history of peripheral vascular disease or similar symptoms.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is an 80-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  chronic kidney disease on dialysis  and a previous history of smoking with 20 pack years. He presents to the emergency room with worsening rest pain in his right lower extremity  primarily in his foot  for the past week. Pain is described as a sharp  constant 8/10 pain which worsens at night and when he elevates his leg  alleviated somewhat by dangling the leg off the bed. Accompanied by a noticeable change in skin color - from normal to pale and mottled  loss of hair on the affected leg  and delayed healing of injuries on the limb. The patient reports having a small foot ulcer on the big toe two weeks ago  which seems to be not getting better. He also reports weakness and fatigue but denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or constitutional symptoms.       Relevant Past Medical History: 1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (uncontrolled) 2. Hypertension (poorly controlled) 3. 20 Pack Years Smoking History 4. Chronic Kidney Disease Stage 5 on Hemodialysis 5. Previous Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) diagnosis for which patient was non-compliant with medications and lifestyle modifications.                    6. No known allergies to medication.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Thompson  a 65-year-old African-American male  presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  constant pain in his right lower leg which started about 2 days ago. The patient reports that the pain is present even while at rest  and he describes it as a burning and cramping sensation. He also notes the presence of a non-healing wound on the foot of the same leg. He finds certain relief when he hangs the leg off the edge of the bed.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Thompson has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both of which are currently managed with medication. He has smoked approximately 1 pack per day for 40 years and his lifestyle includes a sedentary job and minimal exercise.  On examination  the patient's right lower leg appears pale and colder than the left  and there are marked diminution of the pulses distally in the right leg  along with an ulcer on the foot. The ankle brachial index (ABI) is 0.4 on the right leg  signaling severe peripheral arterial disease.  The findings are suggestive of critical limb ischemia  likely secondary to his long-standing smoking habit and poorly controlled diabetes.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Donald  a 68-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department complaining of persistent severe pain in his left lower limb  particularly in the calf area. Pain increased over the past two weeks  now disturbing his sleep. Widowed  lives alone  retired engineer  non-smoker  occasional alcohol consumer  denied drug use.  The pain is 8/10 on the numeric rating scale  intermittent in nature  worse at night  and slightly relieved with analgesics. He also noticed a non-healing ulcer on his left foot which appeared three weeks ago. He complains of coldness in his foot and intermittent numbness.   Vital signs at presentation were blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  pulse 80/min  respiratory rate 18/min  temperature 36.7℃  and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. On examination  his left foot was noticeably cooler than the right one  with delayed capillary refill. A small ulcer (~1 cm in diameter) was observed on the lateral aspect of the left foot with surrounding erythema.  Past medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin for the past ten years  hyperlipidemia  and previous myocardial infarction two years ago. Medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He also reported undergoing angioplasty following the myocardial infarction but has no known allergies. The patient has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having passed away from a heart attack and his mother from a stroke.   This clinical scenario with history and examination findings is suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) of the left lower extremity.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old male patient  Mr. Smith  comes to the clinic. He is a Caucasian man with a history of type-2 diabetes that was diagnosed 10 years ago and has been poorly controlled. He has been a smoker for the past 30 years. His body mass index is 29  indicating obesity. He reports experiencing chronic pain in his left foot  even at rest  over the past few weeks. The pain is severe enough to interrupt his sleep at night. He reports no known allergies.  On physical examination  his left foot is cooler than the right one  with marked pallor  diminished pedal pulses  and slow capillary refill. There are signs of tissue loss with an ulcer on the dorsal aspect and thickened toenails  suggesting a lack of circulation and poor wound healing.   He admits to skipping his diabetes medication regimens at times due to difficulty affording his medication. He is currently on metformin for diabetes  an aspirin a day for heart disease prevention  and a statin for hyperlipidemia. His family history is significant for heart disease  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at age 56.   This presentation strongly suggests critical limb ischemia  likely secondary to peripheral arterial disease  compounded by his diabetes and smoking.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male named Mr. Johnson who presents with severe  recurrent pain in his right foot more in the toe regions that is unrelieved at rest. Mr. Johnson reports the pain as sharp and constant  and characterizes it as a 9 on a scale of 1 to 10 which gets more intense during night making him rise from sleep. The pain has been present for the last six months and is progressively getting worse. He also reports non-healing ulcers or sores on the toes of his right foot which showed color changes and atrophy. Upon physical examination  his right foot is cold to touch  with diminished pulses and pale skin.  Mr. Johnson has a history of type 2 diabetes diagnosed 10 years ago and hypertension diagnosed five years ago. He has been adherent to his medications for both conditions. He is a former smoker with a 20 pack-year smoking history  but quit about a year ago. He had a heart attack seven years ago  for which he underwent angioplasty. Mr. Johnson leads a sedentary lifestyle and his diet usually consists of high-carbohydrate  high-fat foods.   Due to his history of diabetes and heart disease with presence of peripheral artery disease symptoms  there is high suspicion that Mr. Johnson could be having critical limb ischemia  warranting immediate investigation and intervention.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James  a 75-year-old African-American male  presents to the emergency department with excruciating pain in his left leg  which he notes has been progressively worsening over the last couple of weeks. The pain initially commenced while he was walking but now persists even at rest  primarily at night. He also complains of occasional numbness and cold sensation in his left foot. His sleep is severely disturbed due to the pain.   On physical examination  there are noticeable sores on the left foot which are not healing as expected. Pulses  notably the pedal pulse  are absent in the same extremity. His left leg is paler compared to the right leg.   Relevant past medical history includes hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus for 15 years  dyslipidemia  and a 40-pack-year history of smoking. He also had a previous myocardial infarction 5 years back which was managed with coronary artery bypass grafting surgery. The patient is currently on multiple medications including Metformin  Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Aspirin.  He is a retired engineer  living with his wife in their own house. His wife notes that he has been steadily decreasing his activities due to his leg pain. She also shares concern regarding his poor dietary habits and irregular management of his diabetes.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented himself to the emergency department with severe pain in his left lower leg. The pain which is especially noticeable at rest  had been ongoing for several weeks and has been progressively worsening. He describes the pain as nagging and constant  which often intensifies at night  disturbing his sleep.   Upon physical examination  his left foot appears slightly pale and cooler compared to the right one. Mr. Johnson also reports having noticed slowly healing sores on the same foot.   His medical history is notable for uncontrolled type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years  though he claims reduced frequency now  and life-long sedentary lifestyle. There is also a history of coronary artery disease  for which he underwent angioplasty 5 years ago. Family history reveals both his father and grandfather had peripheral artery disease.   The patient's pertinent medications include oral hypoglycemics for diabetes  anti-hypertensives  statin therapy for hyperlipidemia  and a daily aspirin.   Given the chief complaint of rest pain alongside slowly healing sores and significant past medical history  a high suspicion for critical limb ischemia (CLI) was raised. The patient's long-term smoking  uncontrolled diabetes  and hypertension put him at high risk for developing CLI. Further investigations were subsequently arranged for definitive diagnosis and appropriate management.

Patient Presentation  Mrs. Gonzalez is a 72-year-old Hispanic female presenting to the outpatient clinic with a 3-week history of worsening right leg pain  which has significantly intensified over the last 2 days. She describes the pain as severe  constant  non-radiating  and is most notable at rest  especially at night. Mrs. Gonzalez reports that the pain is rated as an 8 on a 10-point scale. She reports accompanying numbness and coldness in her right foot  with observable color change to bluish-grey. The patient expresses concern about difficulty in sleeping and walking due to the pain.  She has a long-standing history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She has been a heavy smoker for the past 50 years  averaging about 10-15 cigarettes per day. Her medications include Metformin 1000mg twice daily  Lisinopril 20mg daily  and Simvastatin 40mg at bedtime. Her surgical history is significant for a cholecystectomy 10 years ago. She denies any known drug allergies.   Upon examination  the right lower extremity was noted to be cool to touch with weak peripheral pulses. There are non-healing ulcers on the heel and distal toes of the right foot. Her left lower extremity appears normal.  Given the patient’s symptoms  her prolonged smoking history  and poorly managed diabetes  the current presentation is highly suggestive of critical limb ischemia pending further diagnostics.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Franklin is a 72-year-old African-American male patient who presents to the emergency department with severe  unrelenting pain in his left lower extremity extending from his hip to his calf. The pain has been gradual in onset but has become progressively worse over the last two weeks. He states the pain is most intense at night and has been interfering with his sleep.  Mr. Franklin has a 50 pack-year smoking history and has been a chronic alcohol user for several decades. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago  which is poorly controlled  with recent Hemoglobin A1c levels around 9.8%. He also has a history of peripheral artery disease (PAD) diagnosed 2 years ago  hypertension  and high cholesterol levels  both of which are controlled with medication.  On visual examination  Mr. Franklin's left foot appears pale when elevated and red when hanging down. His left foot is cold upon touch and has a weak dorsalis pedis and posterior tibialis artery pulse. He has not noted any recent trauma to the lower extremity. Upon neurological examination  the sensory functions of the foot are diminished.   He experiences pain while walking short distances (less than 100 meters) and has an ulcer on the bunion of his left foot that has not healed despite treatment.  Considering his history of smoking  alcoholism  uncontrolled diabetes  PAD and the physical symptoms  there is a high suspicion of critical limb ischemia. Further diagnostic testing  such as an ankle-brachial index (ABI)  Doppler ultrasound and/or angiogram would be recommended.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is an 80-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Johnson who resides in a local assisted living community. He presents to the emergency department complaining of increasingly unbearable pain in his right lower leg  which he says began several weeks ago. He initially experienced cramping during physical activity  then it progressed to pain at rest  especially at night. Over the past few days  his foot also started feeling cold  and he noticed a bluish discoloration.  Past Medical History (PMH):  Mr. Johnson has a long-standing history of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is poorly controlled  complicated by peripheral neuropathy. He reports a smoking history of 40 pack-years but quit ten years ago. His other medical history includes hypertension and previous myocardial infarction. His medications include Metformin for Diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension.  He underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery approximately 5 years ago. His family history is notable for heart disease and stroke. He had no known drug allergies. Physical examination reported reduced distal pulses in his right lower extremity along with bluish discoloration. He has a non-healing ulcer on his right big toe. With this history and physical examination  he is suspected to have critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old African American male  presenting with complaints of non-healing sores on his left foot  particularly the big toe  and severe pain in his left calf when walking for more than five minutes. The pain usually resolves with rest but has become increasingly frequent. This has significantly affected his mobility for the last several weeks.  John is a retired truck driver  lives with his wife  and is a 20-pack-year smoker.  He has a medical history significant for Type-2 diabetes mellitus  managed with Metformin  Hypertension managed with Amlodipine and Lisinopril  and hypercholesterolemia controlled with Atorvastatin. He also has a past surgical history of appendectomy at age 35 with no notable complications.   John has allergies to shellfish and penicillin  which cause skin rashes. His family history includes heart disease in both parents and Type-2 diabetes mellitus in his elder brother. He is currently taking medication for diabetes  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia.   On physical exam  an ulcer is clearly visible on the big toe of the left foot  with surrounding erythema. Pedal pulses are weak and capillary refill time is delayed in his left foot. The left calf muscle shows signs of atrophy. There are no similar findings in the right lower limb.  The symptoms and findings indicate a possible diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia. Further investigations including ABI (Ankle-Brachial Index)  Doppler study  and angiography are planned to confirm the diagnosis and guide potential interventions.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old African American male  currently residing in Boston. Mr. Smith presents today complaining of severe pain in his right leg  unrelieved by rest  persisting for the past two weeks. He reports awakening from sleep due to the intensity of the pain. He also mentions a non-healing ulcer on his right toe  which has been present for about 3 weeks. On examination  peripheral pulses in the right leg are significantly reduced and the extremity is cold to touch. The ulcer over the right toe is 2 cm in diameter  with blackened and necrotic edges.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has been a smoker for the past 40 years and consumes alcohol occasionally. He has been diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago  for which he is on metformin. His blood glucose levels have been poorly controlled due to non-compliance with the medication. He also has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  being managed with amlodipine and atorvastatin respectively. He has a family history of peripheral artery disease and stroke. He has had no previous surgeries. Mr. Smith denies any known drug allergies. He is retired and lives alone; his wife passed away 2 years ago. His son visits him once a week.

Patient Presentation  A 66-year-old African American female presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of severe  unremitting pain in her right lower limb  which she describes as present even at rest. Patient reports the pain is a 8/10 and worsens upon elevation of the limb. She also mentions an ulcer on the right toe that has not healed in the past two months.   The patient has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. She has been smoking 1 pack per day for the past 40 years. She is on insulin therapy  atorvastatin  and amlodipine. Her family history reveals her mother and older brother both had peripheral artery disease and amputations in the past. The patient reports non-compliance with her diabetes medications due to costs.  The patient has a poor nutritional status and has limited access to health care due to socio-economic barriers. She is retired from her job as a school teacher and is living alone. She reports feeling depressed due to her chronic medical conditions and limited social support. There was a documented 10-pound weight loss over 2 months.  Physical exam reveals a temperature of 99F  pulse rate of 90 beats/minute and blood pressure of 155/92 mmHg. The skin of the right lower limb is cool to touch  with noticeable hair loss and shiny appearance. On examination  the right foot dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are absent. A non-healing ulcer with evidence of necrosis was noted on the right great toe.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 68-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe rest pain in his left lower extremity. The pain has been persistent for the past 2 weeks  growing increasingly severe  and causing the patient to lose sleep. He also notes a non-healing wound on his left heel that he noticed approximately one month ago. He denies fever  chills  or other systemic symptoms.  Past Medical History:  His medical history is notable for poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack year smoking history. He had a myocardial infarction requiring stent placement three years ago. Unfortunately  he has not been able to maintain compliance with his medication regimen due to financial issues.  On physical examination  his left foot is cold to touch  with decreased sensation and weak distal pulses. There is a 2 cm ulcer over the left heel with surrounding erythema  but no signs of active infection. The right lower extremity is warm with normal pulses. An Ankle-Brachial index is performed yielding a result of 0.4 on the left  indicative of severe peripheral artery disease.  With these findings  the patient is suspected of having critical limb ischemia and is referred for urgent vascular surgery consultation. Intervention is vital to prevent limb loss.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Smith is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with signs indicative of critical limb ischemia in his left lower extremity.   History:   He complains of rest pain in his left leg  especially notable at night  causing him to have disturbed sleep. He states that even when at rest and elevated  the pain doesn't subside and has noticed a steady increase in severity over the past three months. He reports intermittent claudication initially  but it evolved into continuous pain recently. He also reports some non-healing sores on the lower part of his leg.  Past Medical History:  He has a significant medical history of uncontrolled Type II Diabetes Mellitus for around ten years  hypertension for 15 years  and Coronary Artery Disease for which he had a bypass surgery seven years ago. He is on daily oral hypoglycemics  antihypertensive medications  aspirin  and a statin.   His lifestyle history revealed that he is a former smoker who quit smoking five years ago after being diagnosed with emphysema  a type of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He is not an alcohol consumer and denies illicit drug use. He also denies any known allergies to food or drugs.   He is retired and lives with his wife. Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction in his sixties. The patient is concerned about the increasing pain and the sores not healing despite local care.

Patient Profile: Ms. Jenkins is a 70-year-old African-American female presenting to the emergency department with severe leg pain at rest  non-healing foot ulcers  and noted discoloration on her lower extremities indicative of critical limb ischemia (CLI).   Complaint: She reports the pain in both legs has been ongoing for approximately two months but has recently increased in severity. The pain increases at night and is mildly relieved when she dangles her feet off the side of her bed. She also reports significant weight loss over the last few months  likely secondary to loss of appetite and general malaise.  Past Medical History: Her past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  peripheral artery disease  and hyperlipidemia. She previously smoked a pack of cigarettes a day but quit 5 years ago. She has had no previous surgeries or hospitalizations.  Family History: No family history of similar symptoms have been noted  but her mother had a heart attack at the age of 75.  Current Medications: She is currently on metformin for her diabetes  lisinopril for her hypertension  a statin for her hyperlipidemia and aspirin as prophylaxis for her peripheral artery disease.  Physical Examination: On exam  she appears frail and in distress. She has bilateral foot ulcers with noticeable gangrene on her right foot. There are notable areas of skin discoloration and thinning. Both of her lower limbs are cold to the touch. Her dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are both absent bilaterally.  This presentation is representative of a patient experiencing significant complications from multiple modifiable risk factors. Her diagnosis of diabetes and hypertension  along with her history of tobacco use  has likely contributed to the progression of her peripheral artery disease  resulting in critical limb ischemia.

Patient Information: Mr. Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presenting with severe  unbearable pain in the right lower extremity  at rest  mainly in the foot  for the last four days. The issue started about 6 months ago with initial pain while walking  which resolved with rest (indicating intermittent claudication). However  the pain has now become persistent and is causing sleep disturbances. Reports increased sensitivity to cold and noticed a blueish discoloration of the toes and says the foot feels numb and tingly.  Past Medical History: He has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for 15 years and hypertension for 10 years. Records show suboptimal control of both conditions over the last 5 years. There's also a recent diagnosis (1 year ago) of peripheral arterial disease  with non-compliance to prescribed medications.  Social History: He is a retired accountant  lives with his wife  and has a 40-pack yearly smoking history. He stopped drinking alcohol two years ago. His diet mainly consists of fried foods and meat with moderate physical activity.  Family History: A strong family history of cardiac diseases  his father died of a heart attack and his older brother has undergone a coronary angioplasty. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus.   Clinical Examination: The right foot shows a cold touch with dry  scaly skin. There are a few non-healing ulcers present on toes and the heel with diminished pedal pulses. Doppler examination revealed significantly reduced ankle-brachial index. Absence of hair growth was noted along with bluish hue to the right foot. The left foot has normal perfusion and sensation.  The patient exhibits signs of anxiety and distress  secondary to the chronic intense pain. He is also concerned about the possibility of losing his leg. These symptoms are consistent with a presentation of critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnathon Wilson is a 74-year-old African American male  presenting with complaints of severe rest pain in his left lower limb  primarily located in the foot. He reports that the pain intensifies at night and sometimes eases when he lets his foot hang off the bed. A nearby family member also informed of the existence of non-healing ulcers on his left foot toes.  Mr. Wilson has a past medical history notable for chronic hypertension for the past two decades and diabetes mellitus diagnosed 12 years ago  for both of which he has been on medication. The patient also has been a heavy smoker (1 pack per day) for the past 50 years. He has undergone treatment for a myocardial infarction (MI) 3 years ago. Examination of his left lower limb revealed pallor  cooler to touch with feeble pulses  and non-healing ulcers. Previous ankle-brachial index (ABI) of the affected limb has been reported as less than 0.4  indicating severe limb ischemia.   In the current presentation  his pain has not subsided despite maximum dosage of pain-relievers. Given his clinical picture  there is a suspicion of critical limb ischemia  impending risk of limb loss  and needs immediate attention.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old African American male patient  retired truck driver  presents to the clinic with severe pain in his right lower leg that has worsened within the last few weeks. He describes a burning pain that is persistent even at rest. The patient reveals that he had to start sleeping with his leg hanging over the side of the bed as this position somewhat alleviates the pain. He also mentions having noticed a non-healing wound on his right foot. It first appeared as a minor cut after accidentally hitting his foot on a kitchen table three weeks ago but has since increased in size despite using over-the-counter medication.   Past Medical History:  He is a former smoker  quitting five years ago but had a forty year pack history prior to quitting. He has a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past ten years  which he monitors with Metformin but admits to poor dietary compliance. He also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin  respectively. His father suffered a heart attack at the age of 64.   The patient denies any chest pain  palpitations  dizziness  dyspnea or cough. On physical examination  the right lower limb is colder compared to the left which is normal  with delayed capillary refill. The pulses are weak on the right side compared to the left side. Motor and sensory functions are intact in both limbs. Overall  the patient’s presentation is highly suggestive of critical limb ischemia with possible underlying peripheral artery disease (PAD).

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Antonio Hernandez  a 72-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic today with painful blue-black discoloration of his right foot which has been progressive over the past 8-10 days. He also reports intermittent claudication on walking more than 50 yards. Mr. Hernandez also has a history of numbness and rest pain in the same foot at bedtime for more than two months.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Hernandez was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus 25 years ago and had been managing it with metformin  intermittent insulin use  and dietary measures. He also has a history of persistent smoking (30-pack-year history). He has been hypertensive for more than 10 years and takes Losartan for it. His last recorded blood pressure in the clinic was 150/95 mm Hg. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and isophane insulin. Around six years ago  he was diagnosed with Stable Angina and was managed conservatively with medications. His family history is noteworthy- his father died of myocardial infarction and his mother had a cerebrovascular accident.  Surgical History:  Mr. Hernandez underwent a coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) twelve years ago  and cholecystectomy due to gallstone disease around ten years ago. He had poor wound healing after CABG with a prolonged recovery period.   Summary:  Given the history of intermittent claudication  rest pain  and progressive changes in skin color  along with substantial history of diabetes  hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and smoking  the likely diagnosis is critical limb ischemia  potentially resulting from peripheral arterial disease.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male patient  Mr. Johnson  came to the emergency department complaining of severe  persistent pain in the right lower leg  which intensifies at night or when the leg is elevated. Pain has been present for the last 15-16 days and is unresponsive to over-the-counter analgesics. His right foot is noticeably colder than the left one  with delayed capillary refill and a faint pulse. He also noticed a small non-healing ulcer on the dorsal aspect of his right foot.  The patient is a long-standing hypertensive with poor adherence to medication for the past 30 years  and a history of 20 pack-years of smoking but quit five years ago. He had also been diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus ten years ago which is on oral hypoglycemic agents. He is not aware of any history of cardiovascular or any other chronic diseases in his family but his father  2 brothers  and 1 sister were diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. The patient is a retired engineer  lives with his wife  and occasionally consumes alcohol.  Physical examination reveals that both his feet are pale  the right foot being more so. His blood pressure is 190/110 mmHg. His pulses were diminished in the right femoral  popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial arteries.  From his medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  long-standing smoking habit  poorly controlled diabetes  and the resultant peripheral arterial disease  the patient may be presenting with critical limb ischemia. He needs immediate intervention to save his limb and reduce his risk of significant morbidity and mortality.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department reporting severe pain in his left lower leg. He describes the pain as continuous and unrelenting  even when he rests. He states the pain has increased over the last two weeks. Additionally  he reports noticing that his foot is a darker color than it used to be and his toes look bluish.  He is a non-smoker and abstains from alcohol but has a significant medical history of type 2 diabetes which he has had for the last 15 years  poorly controlled hypertension  and high cholesterol. In addition  there was an incident 3 years ago where he underwent angioplasty for a heart attack. Mr. Smith states that he is on metformin for his diabetes  a statin for his cholesterol  and an ACE inhibitor for his hypertension.  Furthermore  he reports that he has had difficulty with walking because of leg pain for the past few years  but it has never been as intense as the current pain. He has also observed that he has lost weight over the last few weeks due to decreased appetite. His family history is also significant for cardiovascular diseases with his father having passed away from a stroke.  Upon physical examination  his left foot is cold compared to the right foot  the peripheral pulses of the left foot are weak and there are non-healing ulcers on the distal aspect of his foot. No signs of infection are present in the area. Data from an Ankle-brachial index (ABI) indicates significantly reduced blood flow to his left lower extremity.  Based on this information  Mr. Smith is suspected of having critical limb ischemia  specifically in his left lower limb. A recommendation is made for an urgent angiogram to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the possibility of surgical revascularization or angioplasty. He is educated about the importance of tight glucose and blood pressure control and is made to understand that failure to treat could result in possible amputation of his limb.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Williams is a 66-year-old Caucasian male  known to have a 15-year history of uncontrolled type-2 diabetes mellitus and peripheral arterial disease (PAD). He also has a history of cardiovascular disease with myocardial infarction three years ago. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years. He comes in today complaining of increasing pain in his left lower limb over the past six weeks. He describes the pain as severe  burning  and constant  even during rest  especially at night. He also states that he had noticed a non-healing ulcer on the dorsum of his left foot and discoloration of his toes. On further probing  he reports he has suffered from intermittent claudication for several years  with walking distance becoming shorter of late. He denies any fever or chills  but does confirm a significant loss of weight and appetite. He lives alone  is retired  and is not very active  using a cane to move around his home due to his significant leg pain. He admits adherence to medication  including aspirin and statins  has been suboptimal. On examination  the left foot is found to be cooler than the right  with a non-healing ulcer on the dorsum and mottled discoloration of the toes. There are absent pulses distal to the femoral artery on the left side. His right lower limb shows adequate perfusion and intact pulses.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old African American male who presents to the vascular outpatient clinic with non-healing ulcers on his left foot for the past 6 weeks. In addition to the ulcers  he reports resting pain in the lower portion of his leg  usually at night. The pain often interrupts his sleep compelling him to hang the leg over the edge of the bed to attain relief.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a long-standing history of poorly controlled diabetes for 30 years and hypertension for 25 years. He also has a 45 pack-year history of smoking but quit 2 years ago. He had a previous myocardial infarction 4 years ago and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention at that time. Stents were placed in the left anterior descending artery. Mr. Smith also had a stroke approximately one year ago with minor residual right-sided weakness.   Currently  he is on metformin  lisinopril  amlodipine  aspirin  and atorvastatin. He has noticed significant weight loss in the past couple of months  although unintentional.  Family History:  His father had peripheral artery disease and underwent amputation. His mother died at a young age due to a stroke. He also had a brother who had a heart attack and died at the age of 52.  Social History:  Mr. Smith is a retired Truck Driver  lives alone and is able to perform his activities of daily living independently. He is a widower with 3 grown-up children who live out of state. He denies any alcohol use but admits to a strong smoking history.  On physical examination:  Significant findings include delayed capillary refill time  atrophic skin changes  weak or non-palpable pulses  presence of ulcers and significant hair loss on the lower extremities. There are no signs of acute inflammation  and the ulcers are clean with no signs of infection. The remainder of the physical examination is basically unremarkable. He appears older than his stated age and seems markedly cachexic. He uses a cane for walking due to right-sided weakness post-stroke. He has no other complaints.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Riley  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with severe pain in his left lower extremity. He reported a three-week history of progressive  excruciating  rest pain in the foot that worsens at night. He also noted the presence of non-healing ulcers on his left heel and great toe.   Mr. Riley is a long-term smoker  averaging about one pack a day for 50 years. He reports a previous history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was previously diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease two years ago but has not been regular with his medications or follow-up visits. He has no known allergies. His father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 70  and his mother had a stroke at the age of 75.  On physical examination  the left foot was pale with a noticeable temperature difference compared to the right foot. The foot pulses were not palpable  and the ankle-brachial index on the left was 0.39. Non-invasive vascular labs confirmed the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia.   Mr. Riley reports being adherent with his antihypertensive medication but irregular with medication for diabetes and peripheral arterial disease. He admits to a poor diet and lack of exercise due to chronic leg pain and shortness of breath due to smoking.   The patient's economic status is low  with limited access to health resources as he lives in a rural area. He has a high school education and worked as a mechanic before retirement. He lives alone since his wife died five years ago.  Social support is minimal due to estrangement from his two adult sons.   Given the findings of risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  hyperglycemia  and a previous perivascular disease  Mr. Riley's condition is alarmingly consistent with late-stage critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Roberts  a 72-year-old African American male  presents with chronic foot pain at rest that has progressively worsened over the last month. He says his feet often feel cold and numb  and he's noticed that a sore on his right foot isn't healing. He describes an intermittent claudication  stating that he is unable to walk more than 50 yards without experiencing severe leg cramps. He admits to feeling weak and notes unexplained weight loss.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Roberts has a long-standing history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is poorly controlled despite being on Metformin. He is also a former smoker with a 50-pack year history  and continues tobacco use in the form of smokeless tobacco. He has Hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril  and Hyperlipidemia  which is managed by Atorvastatin. He has Coronary Artery Disease  having previously undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) seven years ago  and Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD)  for which he has received angioplasty in his left leg. There is no history of cerebrovascular disease or trauma. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in sodium and saturated fat. He also has a double below-knee amputation on the right side.   Family history is significant for coronary artery disease in both parents  with his father having died from a myocardial infarction in his early sixties. No family history of blood clotting disorders or autoimmune diseases. His medications are up-to-date and he shows compliance with the prescribed regimen.  The patient's symptoms and past medical history make it highly probable that he is presenting with critical limb ischemia.

Patient Information: Mr. John Davis  Age 68  Male  Long-time smoker  Construction worker  Chief Complaint: Severe pain in right leg at rest  with foot ulcers and discolored skin.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Davis  reports experiencing ongoing discomfort and pain in his right leg for the past six weeks that is exacerbating. The pain is primarily located in his foot and is worst at night. He also noted the presence of an ulcer on the right foot which is not healing  and the skin on his foot has started to turn a darker shade. He denies trauma or injury. He has attempted over-the-counter pain relievers  but they do not seem to ease his symptoms.  Past Medical History: Mr. Davis has long-term uncontrolled hypertension and high cholesterol. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years back but does not maintain strict glycemic control due to his lifestyle and economic condition. He also has a 40 pack-year history of smoking and consumes moderate alcohol weekly. He had a stent placed three years ago for a significant coronary artery disease.  Family History: His mother died at 75 with heart problems  father died at 70 due to lung cancer  and elder brother is living with chronic kidney disease.  Review of Systems: General: Fatigue  Chronic Weakness. Cardiovascular: History of heart disease. Respiratory: Chronic shortness of breath  cough. Gastrointestinal: Normal. Endocrine: History of Type II Diabetes. Musculoskeletal: Osteoarthritis right knee.  Physical Examination: General appearance is aged and distressed. Right lower limb cold to touch with active ulcerations on the foot. Palpable femoral pulse  but weak or absent popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial pulses. Intact sensation  but decreased strength.  Assessment: Critical limb ischemia of right lower limb  likely due to peripheral arterial disease.  Plan: Urgent vascular surgery consultation  angiogram. Counseling patient for strict glycemic control and smoking cessation. Optimization of cardiovascular drugs including statins.

Chief Complaint:  ""Severe pain in my left leg even when I'm at rest and non-healing ulcers on my toes.""  Patient Information:  John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  lifelong smoker  currently residing in Seattle.  History of Present Illness:  Mr. Doe complains of severe  unrelenting pain in his left leg that began approximately one month ago  initially ignorable but has gradually worsened over time. The pain persists even when he is not moving the leg or during rest  especially at night. In addition  he notes the recent appearance of non-healing sores on his toes that began as minor cuts but haven't healed for two weeks. He denies any history of trauma or injury. The cold temperature seems to exacerbate the pain. He reports no swelling or fever.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension for which he takes Amlodipine 5mg daily and type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin 500mg twice a day. He had a myocardial infarction about five years ago  after which he was prescribed aspirin and a statin. He admits to smoking a pack of cigarettes daily throughout his adult life but denies any alcohol or substance abuse. He has never been diagnosed with any clotting disorders  renal diseases  or peripheral arterial disease. His surgical history is unremarkable.  Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his mother died at 75 due to heart failure. His brother  who is 65  was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease last year.   Social and Environmental History: Retired high school teacher  living with his wife  a retired nurse. They have two adult children in good health. He is a lifelong smoker with an intake of one pack per day for approximately 45 years. He denies any illicit drug use or alcohol intake. He has a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity.  Review of Systems:  In general  he feels fatigued. His appetite is less than usual  but he denies unintentional weight loss. No other symptom pertaining to other systems.  Physical Examination: Examination of the left lower extremity shows coolness to touch  dry skin  weak pulses  and non-healing sores on the toes. No visible evidence of deep vein thrombosis or edema.  Based on these findings  a direction towards critical limb ischemia can be suggested. Further diagnostic investigation is needed  particularly arterial Doppler ultrasound  to confirm the diagnosis and delineate the extent of the disease.

Patient Presentation: The patient is a 75-year-old male of African-American descent  known to be a chronic smoker for at least 50 years  and is presenting with severe  consistent pain localized to his right lower leg that has been worsening over the last few weeks. The patient also mentions experiencing numbness  coldness  and weakness in the same leg. He also  informs of a non-healing ulcer on his right heel.   Relevant Past Medical History: The patient has a significant history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  for which he is on oral medication. He was diagnosed with Hypertension 15 years ago  managed with low dose ACE inhibitors. Additionally  he suffers from peripheral artery disease  diagnosed a few years ago  for which he is under medication and routine checkups. He also suffered from a myocardial infarction 10 years prior for which he underwent CABG. The patient also reports a history of hyperlipidemia.   His lifestyle includes a sedentary routine with little physical activity  and a diet high in fats. He has been advised to quit smoking and take up exercise several times but acknowledges non-compliance  stating that he has not been able to make these lifestyle modifications. His BMI indicates that he also suffers from obesity.   Family history is significant for diabetes in his mother and coronary artery disease in his father. The patient is a widower and lives alone. He is retired from a desk job and is financially stable.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Clarke  a 75-year-old Hispanic male from Miami  Florida  presents to the emergency department with a complaint of severe pain in his left leg  which he's been experiencing for the last four weeks. The pain has gradually become so intense that it now disturbs his sleep and has led to a progressive loss of colour in the foot. Mr. Clarke also reports the presence of a non-healing ulcer on his left heel and difficulty walking due to pain.  John is retired and lives with his wife. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history  has been treated for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past ten years  and has a history of type 2 diabetes managed with oral medications. He was also diagnosed with peripheral artery disease five years ago. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  including his father  who died due to a heart attack at the age of 68.  On examination  his left foot appears to be pale and cool to touch  with absent pulses below the knee. The mentioned ulcer is about 2 cm in diameter  with necrotic tissue at its center. His right leg appears to be normal  with palpable pulses and no skin changes. Remainder of his examination is largely unremarkable.  Based on his history  clinical presentation and physical examination  a preliminary diagnosis of critical limb ischemia in his left leg is made.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Anderson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male presenting with severe rest pain in his left lower extremity. The pain  concentrated in his calf and foot  is consistently present but intensifies when he lays down. He mentions it often wakes him at night if his foot is not hanging from the side of the bed. Mr. Anderson reports a significant history of a 25-year  pack-a-day smoking habit  which he quit 5 years ago.   Additionally  Mr. Anderson has a notable history of uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension  for which he is currently taking prescribed medications. His peripheral pulses are weak in comparison with his right leg  and he has visible trophic changes in his left foot  such as hair loss and shiny skin. There is also a non-healing ulcer on the heel.   He has no known family history of peripheral artery disease but has a father and brother with heart diseases. Referring to his occupation  Mr. Anderson used to work as a plumber but has been retired for about 4 years now.  On reviewing his previous medical reports  Mr. Anderson was hospitalized for a myocardial infarction around 3 years ago. He hasn't undergone any surgeries in the past. There's no history of allergy to any drugs or foods. However  he is potentially non-compliant with his diabetic medications. His BMI is 32  indicating obesity.  Clinically  these symptoms seem indicative of critical limb ischemia on the left side  likely due to his uncontrolled diabetes and history of smoking. Further diagnostic investigation is required to confirm.

Patient Information:   A 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired Army officer  presenting to the Emergency Department. He resides in an assisted living facility.  Chief Complaint:   Severe pain in the right lower limb for the past 3 days  not improving with over-the-counter painkillers.  History of Present Illness:   The patient describes the pain as a constant  burning sensation that stands at an intensity of 8/10. The pain is worst in the foot but diffuses up to the calf. He mentions that the pain sometimes lessens with limb elevation but amplifies during walks or other forms of exertion. He also reports that the foot appears paler than the left one and feels cold to touch.  Past Medical History:   He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (on insulin) for the past 20 years  hypertension for the last 30 years  and an ischemic heart disease with an episode of myocardial infarction 10 years ago. He was a two-pack-per-day smoker for 50+ years but quit 5 years ago.  Drug History:   The patient is currently on regular treatment with Insulin  Metoprolol  Clopidogrel  and Lisinopril.  Review of Systems:  Distinctive symptoms of rest pain  non-healing sores  and coldness of the lower limb.  Physical Examination:   On examination  the patient's right foot shows pallor and mottling. A non-healing  shallow ulcer is seen on the tip of the right big toe with slight gangrene. Distal pulses (Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial) are markedly weakened on the right side.  These clinical presentations hint towards critical limb ischemia in the patient  and proper diagnostic and management procedures need to be initiated at the earliest to prevent further complications.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with severe pain in his left lower extremity  which had been escalating in intensity over the past 48 hours. He also reported progressive numbness and discoloration of his left foot  along with an open  non-healing wound on his left big toe.  The patient’s past medical history is significant for a 30-year history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  as well as hyperlipidemia and a 50-pack year smoking history. He had a prior toe amputation on the right foot approximately 2 years ago due to a similar  non-healing wound.   On physical examination  there was notable pallor  decreased temperature  and absence of pulsation on the dorsalis pedis and the posterior tibial arteries of the left foot. Sensation was significantly diminished in the left foot compared to the right. The open toe wound was noted to be blackened at the edges  with necrotic tissue visible and no signs of active bleeding.  The patient was immediately referred to vascular surgery due to concerns about possible critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old African-American male  presents to the outpatient department with a chief complaint of excruciating pain in his lower left leg that has been intensifying over the last few months. The pain now interferes with his daily activities and often wakes him up at night. He also reports a non-healing wound on his left foot that has been present for a couple of weeks. On further questioning  the patient admits to occasional swelling of the lower limb and a subtle change in the color of his left foot. He denies any recent trauma or injury to both his legs.  Past Medical History:  He is a known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 15 years with poor glycaemic control. He also has a long history of hypertension and is being treated with antihypertensive medication. The patient is a long-term smoker  with a history of more than 30 years of tobacco use. The patient also has been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) a year ago but has been non-compliant with his medication and follow-up visits. Mr. Johnson also has a relevant familial history  as his father had a history of coronary artery disease and stroke.  Social History:  He lives alone as a retiree  is a widower with no children. He has been reliant on his daily stipend for food and medication  which might have contributed to poor medication compliance. He admits to consuming alcohol moderately. He does not engage in physical exercise frequently due to chronic pain.
