Patient Presentation:  Ms. Gonzalez is a 75-year-old Latina woman known to have a 20+ year history of poorly controlled type II diabetes and peripheral vascular disease. She has had no previous surgeries or interventions. Ms. Gonzalez has not seen a physician in several years due to financial constraints and has been managing her sugar levels and overall health as best as she can on her own.  Ms. Gonzalez presents today with a complaint of severe pain in her right lower leg  which she reports has been steadily worsening over the past three months. The pain is constantly present  even at rest  and most intense in her foot and calf. She has noticed some color changes to her lower leg particularly turning dark purple when it is in a dependent position. She reports trouble sleeping due to the pain and has noted an open sore on her foot that has not been healing. She also has difficulty walking more than a few steps without pain which she describes as crippling.  Smoking history: Former smoker  quit 15 years ago.  Alcohol use: None.  Illicit drug use: None.  Family history: Father and older brother both had 'poor blood flow' in their legs leading to amputations in the late stages of their lives.  She lives alone but has supportive neighbors who have been encouraging her to seek medical help. She is retired and reports financial troubles  which have resulted in her not seeking care earlier.  Findings on physical examination: 1) Lower extremity exam reveals slightly decreased temperature to palpation of the right foot compared to the left. 2) There are diminished pulses in the right lower extremity and an ulcer on the plantar surface of her foot. 3) Moderate to severe pain on even slight movement of her right toes. 4) Muscle wasting in her right calf and thigh is evident  with slightly reduced strength.   Her symptoms and past medical history are concerning for progressing critical limb ischemia. Immediate attention is warranted due to the potential risk of limb loss with delayed treatment.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 75-year-old African American male  comes into the office for consultation regarding left leg pain.  Chief Complaint: Severe pain in the left lower extremity for last two weeks  at its worst at rest and during the night.   History of Present Illness: The patient details a gradual onset of pain in the left leg over the past six months  though the pain worsened considerably in the past two weeks. Describes it as severe  burning pain primarily in his foot and calf. Symptoms associated with non-healing wounds on his foot. He also complaints of having trouble walking due to pain.  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of smoking for 40 years  hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 10 years  and peripheral artery disease (PAD) diagnosed 5 years prior.   Social History: The patient is a retired warehouse employee living with his wife. He admits to a smoking habit of a pack of cigarettes a day for the past 40 years. Drinks alcohol socially. He has no known drug allergies.  Review of Systems: All other systems were reviewed and were negative.  Physical Examination: Physical examination revealed an extremely pale left foot with poor capillary refill. Diminished pulses were noted in the left dorsal pedis and posterior tibial arteries. Non-healing ulcers observed on the dorsum of the foot.  Based on the patient’s presentation - severe rest pain  non-healing wounds  and significant smoking and PAD history - this appears to be a case of critical limb ischemia. Further diagnostic evaluation and management would be necessary.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Stevens  a 72-year-old African American male  former smoker with a 30-pack-year history and a sedentary lifestyle  was brought to the emergency department by his wife complaining of severe and persistent pain in his left leg at rest for the last 72 hours. The pain has been constant  8/10  and hasn't responded to over-the-counter pain relievers. His wife added that recently he had been complaining of coldness in the foot and occasional numbness. Over the past week  he stood up with difficulty and reported having severe pain even while sleeping.  His past medical history is significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  coupled with poor glycemic control  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and he had a myocardial infarction about 3 years ago but did not require any intervention. He has a 10-year history of intermittent claudication symptoms managed conservatively. He also reported erectile dysfunction developing over the past year. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin.  Physical examination revealed a thin  anxious elderly man in severe distress  with a BMI of 22. Both feet were cold to the touch  but the left was colder. There were absent pulses below the knee in the left leg  especially dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial artery. The left foot appeared slightly pale compared to the right foot. There were ulcers on the heel and dorsal aspect of the left foot  with signs of necrosis but no signs of infection. The capillary refill time of the left toe was more than 5 seconds.  His severe unilateral limb pain at rest  physical examination findings  coupled with pulse abnormalities  and non-healing ulcers and tissue loss are indicative of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). Urgent consultation with vascular surgery and cardiovascular medicine was sought.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 67-year-old African-American male presenting with severe rest pain on his left lower limb for the past several weeks. His pain has worsened over time and is now unbearable  particularly during the night.  He reports to have noticed a non-healing ulcer on his left foot. On physical examination  it reveals a 2cm ulcer on the medial aspect of the left foot with surrounding erythema and slight temperature elevation.  On further inquiry  Mr. Johnson reports to have been a smoker for 30 years  but quit smoking 10 years ago. He has a known history of uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 15 years and has been on oral anti-diabetic medications. He mentions having taken treatment for Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) diagnosed 5 years ago.  Mr. Johnson also has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and was treated for a myocardial infarction 8 years ago. He's currently taking antihypertensives and cholesterol-lowering drugs. His personal history shows a sedentary lifestyle.  No known drug allergies and not currently on anticoagulant. His BMI is 31  pointing out to being obese. Additionally  his family history is significant for stroke and coronary artery disease in a sibling and parent  respectively.  The bluish discoloration of the toes  weak distal pulses  and coldness of the left foot accompanied by the rest pain and ulcer suggests a likely diagnosis of critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  A 69-year-old African American male presents with severe rest pain in his right lower extremity that has been ongoing for the past three weeks. The patient describes his pain as a burning sensation around the calf and foot regions. The pain tends to get worse during the night and sometimes awakens him from sleep.  In addition to the pain  he has been experiencing some skin discoloration and temperature changes in his right leg. He has also noticed sores on his toes that do not seem to be healing. He denies any recent trauma to the area. He also denies experiencing any chest pain or shortness of breath.  His vital signs upon initial presentation are as follows: Blood pressure 135/85 mmHg; Heart rate: 80 bpm; Respiratory rate: 16/min; Temperature: 98.6°F; Pulse oximetry: 98% on room air. On physical examination  the right leg appears pale compared to the left. Pulse is weakly palpable in the right femoral  popliteal  and dorsalis pedis arteries. The patient's right foot is cool to the touch with poor capillary refill (>3 seconds).  The patient's past medical history is significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and a 45-pack-year smoking history. He was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease two years ago  but he did not follow-up regularly with his primary care physician or adhere to prescribed medications due to lack of health insurance. He does not have any known drug allergies.   Family history is relevant for a father who died from an acute myocardial infarction at the age of 67 and a mother with a history of stroke. The patient is retired and lives alone. He quit smoking a year ago but still consumes alcohol socially. He does not engage in any exercise due to his severe leg pain. He is currently not on any medication.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with symptoms of severe pain in his right lower extremity that has been progressively worsening for the past few weeks. The pain is present even at rest and awakens him in the middle of the night. He also notes that the coloration of his right foot has darkened  it feels cold to touch  and he has lost sensation. He has noticed the presence of non-healing sores on the foot. Physical examination revealed weak or absent pulses in the right lower limb.  His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 20 years  poorly controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents  hypertension and a 30-pack year smoking history. He has no known allergies. He is retired and lives with his wife. His regular medications include Metformin  Lisinopril and Aspirin. His family history is notable for coronary artery disease in his father.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John is a 68-year-old African-American male who presents to the clinic with complaints of severe and continuous pain in his right lower leg and foot  present even at rest. He reports that the pain is often worsened at night and he has even noticed ulcers developing on his foot that don't seem to be healing. Furthermore  he reports his foot often feels cold to the touch and is a noticeably deathly pale color.   Upon questioning  the patient notes he has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  Type 2 diabetes mellitus and a 50-year history of smoking one pack per day  although he quit five years ago. He takes medications for his hypertension and diabetes and follows his prescribed diet and physical exercise. He denies any known allergies to food or drugs.  He has experienced intermittent claudication in the past–pain while walking that subsides with rest–but has never had these continuous  severe symptoms. He reports that these symptoms have been present for about four weeks now  progressively worsening over that time.   Family history is significant with paternal grandparents both having had peripheral artery disease  and a father who died of a myocardial infarction at a young age. The patient is retired  lives with his wife  and denies drinking and drug use. He is worried about the possibility of losing his foot due to the symptoms.

Patient Presentation:  An 85-year-old African American male presents at the clinic today with prime complaints of severe and persistent pain in his left lower leg  which has been bothering him for the last 2 months. The patient has a chronic history of diabetes mellitus (Type-2) for the past 10 years and hypertension for 7 years  both of which are reasonably managed with medications. He denies any smoking or alcohol abuse in the past or present and maintains a balanced diet. The patient has a family history of peripheral artery disease (PAD) with his elder brother suffering from the same. The pain in his leg is intensified during night-time  causing sleeping disturbances and is being somewhat alleviated when hanging the leg down. The patient also notes that he recently noticed the development of non-healing ulcers on his left foot. Upon physical examination  low-temperature foot  pallor  and diminished pulses in the left foot are noticeable. With these symptoms  the possibility of the patient suffering from critical limb ischemia is suspected.

Patient Information:   Mr. John Smith  a 66-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Issue:  Mr. Smith presents to the clinic with severe pain in his right lower leg  persistent even at rest. He has also stated that he has begun to notice non-healing wounds and gangrenous changes in his toes. He reports experiencing night time leg cramps as well.  Medical History: Mr. Smith has a significant history of 10 years of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  a 40 pack-year history of smoking  and he suffered a myocardial infarction two years ago. His current medications include metformin for his diabetes  aspirin for secondary prevention of cardiovascular events  amlodipine for hypertension  and statins for hyperlipidemia  which was diagnosed concurrently with his myocardial infarction. His diabetic management is suboptimal  with his last glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1C) seven months ago being 9.5.  Family History: There is a strong family history of peripheral arterial disease and coronary artery disease  with his father having died of a heart attack at the age of 72  and his elder brother also having undergone a percutaneous coronary intervention procedure for severe coronary artery disease.  Social History: He is a retired truck driver and lives with his wife. He admits to being a heavy smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. He has no known allergies.  Physical Examination: On examination  his right foot is cold to touch with diminished peripheral pulses. There are several gangrenous toes. No bruits are heard over the femoral arteries. His ankle-brachial index is significantly reduced at 0.5. His other vital signs include temperature 98.4F  heart rate 87 beats/min  respiratory rate 16 breaths/min  and blood pressure 150/90 mmHg.  Summary:  A case of critical limb ischemia likely secondary to advanced peripheral arterial disease and poorly controlled diabetes in a patient with known cardiovascular disease and an extensive smoking history. Immediate vascular intervention is necessary to alleviate pain and prevent limb loss.

Patient Information: A 70-year-old African-American male  retired construction worker  non-smoker  presents to the clinic.  Chief Complaint: Severe pain in the right lower limb even while resting  and non-healing sores on the toes and feet.  History of Present Illness: He reports constant  sharp  burning pain in his right foot for the last 1 month. The patient also describes non-healing ulcers localized on his toes and feet that started a few weeks back  initially mild but have progressively worsened. He has been experiencing coldness and noticeable color changes in his right foot. Disturbed sleep due to the pain. The pain is not relieved by over-the-counter medications.  Past Medical History:   1. Hypertension – diagnosed 15 years ago  currently under medication. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus – diagnosed 10 years ago  generally well-controlled with medications. 3. History of a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 8 years ago  with no known neurological deficits currently. 4. Hypercholesterolemia - diagnosed 5 years ago  on medications. 5. Peripheral artery disease (PAD) - diagnosed 5 years ago  has shown disease progression.  Medications:   1. Lisinopril for hypertension 2. Metformin for diabetes mellitus 3. Atorvastatin for hypercholesterolemia 4. Clopidogrel for TIA and PAD  Family History: Father died of myocardial infarction. Mother has hypertension.  Social History: Patient denies alcohol  tobacco  and illicit drug use. Lives alone. Has a home health aide who comes every other day.  Review of Systems: No other complaints.  Physical Examination: Patient appears uncomfortable due to pain. Vital signs are stable. Noted paleness and cyanosis in the right foot  non-healing ulcers on toes and foot  decreased sensation to touch  decreased pedal pulses  atrophic skin changes  and absent hair growth. No evidence of infection.  The presentation is indicative of critical limb ischemia. Further diagnostic tests including Doppler ultrasound  CT angiography  and Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) are advised and early consultation with a vascular surgeon is recommended.

Patient Presentation  Demographics: Mr. Brown  an African-American male aged 68.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Brown presented with complaints of severe  continuous pain in his right lower leg  even when at rest.  History of Present Illness: He reports progressive tightening discomfort over the past three months  becoming severe in the last week. The pain is particularly severe at night and tends to disturb his sleep. He has to often hang his leg at the bed edge for some relief. Upon further questioning  he admits to having significant weight loss and lack of appetite due to pain. Mr. Brown has also noticed that his right lower leg is colder compared to the left and appears slightly discolored. There is no reported history of trauma.  Past medical history: He has history of type II diabetes mellitus for the past 20 years  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and is a former cigarette smoker (quit four years ago but had 40 pack years smoking history). He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting seven years ago.  Family History: Father had coronary artery disease. Mother had hypertension. No family history of peripheral artery disease  stroke  or aortic aneurysm.  Social History: Retired teacher. Lives with wife. Regular alcohol consumption (2 units per day). No illicit drug use.   There is no known drug allergy. Medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Aspirin.   Physical Examination: His BMI is 25.4. Right foot is pale  cool to touch with delayed capillary refill. Non-healing ulcer (1.5cm x 2cm) present on right heel. No signs of infection. Feeble to non-palpable pulses in the right leg (Popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial). Normal left leg pulses.  Following the clinical examination  the differential diagnoses were mainly peripheral artery disease (PAD)  specifically critical limb ischemia.   The doctors planned for Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) for further clarification and CBC  coagulation profile  fasting lipid panel  kidney function test for baseline investigation. Patient is also planned for arterial Doppler ultrasound of right lower extremity  contrast angiography  and if necessary  a CT angiogram to further investigate the severity of the possible peripheral arterial disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Anderson is a 68-year-old African American male presenting with severe  chronic pain in his right lower extremity  particularly below the knee  which has been worsening over the last three months. The pain has been unresponsive to over-the-counter pain medications and it significantly increases when the limb is at rest or when he sleeps  often resulting in awakening him up from sleep. He also reports coldness and numbness in the affected leg  coupled with a noticeable decrease in mobility. His foot appears pale with an absent posterior tibial pulse  accompanied by non-healing ulcers on his toes.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Anderson has been diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes over the last 15 years and hypertensive for ten years  both of which are fairly controlled with medications. He has been a chronic smoker but has quit smoking for five years now. He underwent CABG (Coronary Artery Bypass Graft) three years ago due to coronary artery disease. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  Aspirin  and Simvastatin. He occasionally takes Ibuprofen for his leg pain.  Family history reveals his mother died due to stroke and his father battled with coronary artery disease.

Patient Information: Mr. Elliot  a 69-year-old African-American male  retired mechanic  Chief Complaint: Progressive pain in the left foot at rest  worse during the night. Non-healing wound on the big toe.  History of Present Illness: The patient has been experiencing severe pain in his left foot for about 2 weeks  more pronounced at night. He noticed a small wound on his big toe about 1 month ago which has progressively increased in size and depth. The wound presents with discharge and is painful. He has also noticed that his foot often feels cold and turns pale when elevated. Walking short distances has become increasingly difficult due to the pain and discomfort.  Past Medical History: Mr. Elliot has a significant past medical history of hypertension  type-II diabetes mellitus (poorly controlled)  dyslipidemia  tobacco use (quit 5 years ago after smoking a pack a day for 35 years)  and peripheral arterial disease.  Medications: Metformin 500mg BID  Atorvastatin 20mg daily  Lisinopril 10mg daily  Amlodipine 5mg daily  Aspirin 81mg daily.  Family History: Father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 82. Mother passed away from breast cancer at 79. Two older siblings  one with a history of stroke and another diagnosed with kidney disease.   Social History: Retired mechanic  living with wife. Alcohol use: 1-2 beers/week; Smoked for 35 years  quit 5 years ago. No illicit drug use.   Physical Examination: Pale left foot with decreased temperature when compared to right foot. A non-healing  clean-edge ulcer with purulent discharge on the big toe of left foot. Diminished pedal pulses bilaterally  more pronounced in the left foot.   Assessment: Possible diagnosis of critical limb ischemia  given his past medical history of peripheral arterial disease  classic symptoms  physical examination findings  and risk factors (such as diabetes  smoking history  age  hypertension  and ethnic background).

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old male Caucasian patient  presents stating that he has been experiencing a severe increase in pain in his left lower leg and foot over the past 5 weeks. Mr. Doe describes the pain as constant and increasing with any movement  but also present at rest. It is severe enough to prevent him from sleeping well and interrupting his daily activities. He also reports a noticeable loss of hair on the leg  a visible ulcer on his left foot that has not improved despite prescribed antibiotic treatment  and chronic fatigue. He has a long-standing history of Type II Diabetes and Hyperlipidemia  having been diagnosed approximately 20 years ago. His medications include Metformin and Atorvastatin. He has a positive family history for peripheral arterial disease. He also admits to heavier alcohol and tobacco consumption of approximately 40 years.  On examination  there is a palpable chill in his left foot and ankle  the skin is pale and shiny with a ulcer about 1.5cm diameter on the plantar aspect of foot. No distal pulses could be palpated in the left foot and weak in the left popliteal area but stronger in the right lower limb. Foot blanches with elevation and gets reddish when placed down. His ankle-brachial index (ABI) is significantly reduced and below 0.4.   Diagnosis:  These symptoms and clinical findings are very suggestive of critical limb ischemia (CLI)  possibly due to peripheral arterial disease secondary to his diabetes. A Doppler ultrasound or angiogram diagnostic test will be necessary to confirm.

Patient Profile: John Doe  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presents with significant rest pain in the right lower extremity.  Presenting Symptoms: Patient complains of persistent pain in the lower extremity  particularly when he is at rest or during the night. He describes a continual burning sensation in his toes and the soles of his feet that is not alleviated by elevating the limb. There are also non-healing ulcers noted on his right foot.  Past Medical History: He has a 10-year history of Type 2 diabetes  complicated by peripheral neuropathy. He also suffers from chronic hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and has a 30-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes per day  which he quit two years ago.  Physical Exam Findings: Upon physical examination  the right foot is noted to be cooler than the left  and there is diminished dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulse on the right side. There is also evidence of dry gangrene on the right fifth toe.  The patient's symptoms  his significant smoking history  long standing diabetes  and the observed physical findings suggest the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia. Further evaluation and treatment options are being considered.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Walters is a 72-year-old African-American male who presents to the emergency department with severe rest pain and ulcers on his right foot that have not healed for 2 months. His pain has significantly worsened over the last week to a level of 9/10 and is located in his foot and calf  particularly at night. He reports difficulty sleeping and has been unable to walk due to the pain.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Walters has a substantial history of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypertension. He has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He underwent a right lower limb angioplasty 3 years ago and was prescribed aspirin and a statin which he admits to not taking regularly. He has no known drug allergies.  Family History:  He has a family history of PAD and coronary artery disease  with his father having had a heart attack at the age of 75.  Social History:  He is a retired mechanic and lives with his wife. He admits to leading a sedentary lifestyle.  Physical Examination:  The physical examination revealed an obese male (BMI of 30)  in distress due to pain. His right foot appears pale and cyanotic with two ulcers on the great and the second toe  each measuring about 3 cm in diameter. The right foot was cold to touch and had a weak dorsalis pedis pulse. The left foot remained pink with strong pulses and no ulcerations.  Given his presentation and past medical history  the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia is considered  and he is managed accordingly with immediate attention to pain control and optimizing blood flow to the limb.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. M is a 67-year-old African American woman who presents to the clinic with severe pain in her right leg  which she notices  is particularly worse following physical activity but is also present at rest. She states that the pain makes it difficult for her to sleep at night. Ms. M mentions the pain is concentrated below the knee  primarily in her calf.  She has been experiencing discoloration and ulcerations in the lower part of her right leg. The ulcer on her big toe has been worsening  with limited healing over the past weeks  raising concerns. She does not experience any chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations. She has some difficulty in walking long distances  which she attributes to the leg pain.  Past Medical History:  She has a significant history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  all of which are treated with medication but she admits to frequently forgetting her doses. She has a 40 pack-year smoking history but has not been successful in quitting despite multiple attempts. She experienced a transient ischemic attack 2 years ago but has since been stable on aspirin. She has no known allergies to medications.  Family history includes a father who died from myocardial infarction and a brother with peripheral artery disease. She is currently living alone since her husband passed away five years ago  and she has three grown children living out of state. She retired from her secretarial job two years ago.

Patient Presentation:  A 64-year-old African-American male presented to the emergency department with severe pain  pallor  and coldness in his left lower extremity that started six hours prior to arrival. The pain  which he described as a sharp  ""10-out-of-10"" discomfort  did not respond to over-the-counter pain medication.  The patient displayed signs of rest pain  especially at night when lying flat  and said that he had to hang his leg over the bed's edge to find some relief. He also noted that sores and ulcers on his lower leg and foot had been stubbornly slow healing  with some ulcerations showing no signs of healing at all. Upon examination  the patient’s left lower extremity was cold to touch without palpable pulse  and visible skin discoloration was observed.  His past medical history was significant for Type II diabetes mellitus for which he was on Metformin  hypertension managed by Lisinopril  and a 30-year history of smoking  approximately one pack a day. He also reported that he had been diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) two years ago but did not follow up on medical treatment as recommended.   No known allergies were identified and family history revealed that his father had had a below-the-knee amputation due to PAD complications. The patient denied any alcohol or illicit drug use.   This male patient’s demographic details and extensive past medical history of smoking  diabetes  hypertension  and PAD increase his risk for critical limb ischemia. His race  being African-American  also places him at a higher risk. His PAD's mismanagement amplifies these risks  demonstrating the necessity of appropriate long-term management with patients suffering from PAD to avoid progression to critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old African-American male  presents to the Emergency Department  escorted by his son. He complains of sharp  intense pain in his right lower leg  which he describes as being continuous  even at rest  and escalating over the past two months. He rates it as an 8 on a pain scale of 0 to 10. The pain is so severe it usually wakes him from sleep. Over the counter analgesics do not alleviate the pain. Additionally  he mentioned that his right foot is unusually cold to touch and has noticed a color change to slightly blue.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson is a known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 15 years ago  along with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed by medication. He was a one-pack a day smoker for 40 years  but he claims to have quit approximately five years ago. He also briefly mentions a history of occasional intermittent claudication over the past few years.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 65-year-old male with a significant history of 20 years of poorly controlled Type 2 diabetes mellitus and a deep venous thrombosis 6 years ago. He has a smoking history of 20 packs per year. His BMI is 29 indicative of overweight. He is currently taking Metformin and Warfarin.   Over the last one week  Mr. Doe is experiencing a severe pain in his left lower extremity even while at rest. He initially ignored thinking it as a regular pain associated with ageing  but it started increasing in intensity over time  disturbing his sleep.   Along with increasing pain in the leg  he noticed that his foot started to appear darker than usual with a bluish-black discoloration. The discomfort aggravated with physical exertions like walking (claudication) and lessened upon elevating the limb. He also reported an open sore (ulcer) on his big toe that has not healed for the past 3 weeks.  On initial physical examination  the left leg appears pale and cold to touch when compared to the right. The left foot shows a painful non-healing ulcer over his big toe showing signs of necrosis. The distal pulses in the left leg (dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial) are not palpable. No audible bruits present on auscultation of the femoral region.  On this presentation  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia is highly suspected.

Patient Information: Mr. Robert Sanchez  65-year-old Hispanic male  retired  married.  Chief Complaint: Severe pain in the right leg that has lasted for the past four days.  History of Present Illness: Patient reports intermittent claudication over the past six months  progressively worsening to constant pain even in rest over the last 4 days. The pain is significantly severe  limiting his daily activity. The right foot has developed a pale coloration and feels cold to touch. Patient also noted a sore on the foot that is not healing.  Past Medical History: Patient has history of long-term smoking (around 40 pack years)  uncontrolled Diabetes Mellitus for 10 years  Hypertension for 15 years  and high cholesterol levels. Patient had a myocardial infarction five years ago and was treated with balloon angioplasty and a stent. He does not have any known allergies.   Family History: Father died from a myocardial infarction at 67  mother died from a stroke at 72  one brother has diabetes and hypertension.  Social History: Patient is a retired mechanic  lives with his wife. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years with an average of 20 cigarettes per day. Drinks alcohol occasionally. Maintains a diet high in fat and carbohydrate.  Medications: Metformin  Lisinopril  Simvastatin  baby Aspirin all taken regularly.  Review of Systems: Decreased appetite but no weight loss. No fever or chills. Patient seems to experience fatigue and shortness of breath sooner than usual.  Physical Examination: Vital signs stable. Pale right foot compared to left  diminished to absent right pedal pulses  a small ulcer on the right big toe  capillary refill was delayed on right foot. There were no signs of infection. Cardiac and lung exams were within the normal limits.  Based on the aforementioned details  he likely has critical limb ischemia secondary to peripheral artery disease  further complicated by his diabetes  and smoking history. An urgent vascular surgery consult has been advised.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Sanchez is a 68-year-old male of Hispanic descent presenting with rest pain in his left lower leg that has been increasing for the past two months. He reports that the pain worsening  especially during the night making it difficult to sleep. The pain is alleviated when he dangles his leg over the side of his bed. In addition  he has noticed that his toes have a bluish discoloration and are chronically cold. He is worried because an ulcer has developed along his lateral malleolus that was initially small but has enlarged over time.   Past Medical History: Mr. Sanchez is a former smoker with a 40-pack-year smoking history. He quit 10 years ago. He has a past medical history significant for poorly controlled Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 20 years. He also suffers from atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease with a previous MI (Myocardial Infarction) 6 years ago. He has hyperlipidemia and hypertension managed with statins and ACE inhibitors. His family history is significant for peripheral artery disease; his father developed gangrene in his foot in his later years.

Patient Information: A 67-year-old African American male presents to the outpatient clinic.  Chief Complaint: Severe pain in the right lower limb  which increases at rest and is often unbearable during night-time. He also complains of a non-healing ulcer on his right foot.  History of Present Illness: He says the pain started gradually  increasing over the last couple of months. The patient noticed a small wound on his foot about 2 weeks ago  which has now become bigger with blackening in some areas. He has noticed some loss of hair on his lower limb. He has not had any trauma to the foot. He denies fever  chills  or any other systemic symptoms.  Past Medical History: He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM) and Hypertension (HTN) 3 years back  for which he is on Metformin and Ramipril. His DM and HTN have been poorly controlled. He is a smoker with approximately 30 pack-years history.  Family History: His father died of a heart attack at the age of 70. His mother had DM and HTN and died due to renal failure at 76.  Review of Systems (ROS): General: Weight loss of approximately 5 pounds in the last month Cardiovascular: No chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath Gastrointestinal: No abdominal pain  nausea or vomiting  Physical Examination: Vital Signs: BP: 150/92  Pulse: 100/min  Temp: 98.6°F  Respiratory Rate: 18/min  Cardiovascular: S1 & S2 present  no added sounds Abdomen: Soft  non-tender Lower Extremity: Amputation of all toes except for the big toe on the right foot; area surrounding the wound is blackish and cold; diminished right femoral  popliteal  dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses compared to the contralateral limb. Hair loss present.  Based on the history and the findings on examination  the patient is likely to have developed critical limb ischemia in the setting of peripheral artery disease.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson  a 63-year-old African American male  presents in the emergency department complaining of acute  severe pain in his left lower leg which has been escalating over the last few weeks. He describes the pain as constant and not mitigated by rest. He also mentions intermittent claudication during minor physical activity such as walking short distances.   Upon examination  there is an ulcer on the anterior aspect of his left foot and a color change  appearing pale and cooler to touch as compared to the right foot. He also reports decreased sensation in his left foot  and he has noted some hair loss on his left leg. Distal pulses are irregular and weak in his left foot.   His vital signs are stable - BP: 145/90 mmHg  pulse: 86 bpm  respiration: 18 bpm  and body temperature: 98.4 degrees Fahrenheit.   Past medical history is significant for Type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he takes Metformin  and hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril. He is a former smoker  with a 30 pack-year history  but quit 10 years earlier. His BMI is calculated to be 28  qualifying as overweight. His lifestyle is rather sedentary as he is retired and spends most of his time at home. His dietary history includes a preference for processed foods and fast food  with minimal fruits and vegetables.  In view of these findings  the patient is suspected to have critical limb ischemia (CLI)  probably due to peripheral artery disease (PAD).

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old non-Hispanic white male  currently living alone and working as a retired engineer  presented to the clinic with a complaint of rest pain in his right foot persisting over the past week. He stated that the pain was severe enough to wake him from sleep and was accompanied by numbness and occasional tingling. He also reported that the color of his foot had darkened and has noticed a decrease in temperature to touch. He denies any history of trauma or recent injury.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe has a documented history of hypertension  diagnosed at age 50  which is under control with Lisinopril. He has an uncontrolled type-2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed at 55 years old  currently on Metformin. His most recent HbA1C reading  taken six months ago  was 8.9%. He has a 30-year history of smoking one packet of cigarettes per day but quit 5 years ago. The patient also suffered a mild stroke two years ago with a full recovery. No allergies have been documented in his medical record. His family history showed his father had a myocardial infarction at age 70 and died at 75 due to stroke. His mother was diagnosed with type-2 diabetes. He is currently not on any blood thinners or anti-platelet medication.   Physical Examination:   On physical exam  his foot appeared discolored and cold to touch. Palpation of the right foot revealed absent right posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses.   Diagnostic Evaluation:  Based on the physical examination  rest pain  discoloration  and history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  and previous stroke  a presumptive diagnosis of critical limb ischemia was made. Mr. Doe has been advised for further diagnostic testing to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old African American male is brought into the clinic today with a chief complaint of severe rest pain in his right lower extremity. The pain is often accompanied by numbness  extreme coldness  and changes in skin color. The patient also mentions an unhealing wound on his right heel that has been present for approximately two weeks.   He reports a past medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (diagnosed 10 years ago) with poor blood sugar control (last HbA1c was 8.5%)  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and he is a two-pack-a-day smoker with a 40-year smoking history. He has a history of peripheral arterial disease diagnosed 5 years back with no history of angioplasty or bypass surgery and admits to non-compliance with prescribed medications (antiplatelets and statins) and lifestyle modifications due to lack of comprehensive health literacy.  His family history is significant with his father and two uncles who were diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). His social history includes alcohol usage limited to occasional drinks and he lives with his wife as the primary caregiver.  On physical examination  there is noticeable pallor when the right foot is elevated and dusky redness when it is dependent. The right foot is cooler compared to the left foot. Palpation reveals absent pulses on the affected extremity (right femoral  popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial). There is a visible ulceration on his right heel with dry gangrene of the adjacent toes.  Based on the medical history and physical findings  the patient is believed to be presenting with the severe stage of peripheral artery disease known as critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Jones is a 70-year-old Caucasian male referred to the peripheral vascular clinic presenting with severe rest pain in his right lower leg. He reports the pain has been worsening over the past five months  and is now intolerable. The pain particularly intensifies when his leg is elevated  especially at night. He suffers from intermittent claudication walking close to half a block  leading to a significant decrease in his activity level. On further exploration  he reports an approximate of 22-pound unintentional weight loss over the past four months  due to loss of appetite and occasional nausea.  His medical history is significant for a 40-pack year history of smoking (only quit five years ago)  Type 2 diabetes mellitus under poor control (HbA1c at 9.6%)  hypertension  and a myocardial infarction eight years ago. He has been compliant with his medications  which include metformin  lisinopril and aspirin.  Upon physical examination  his right foot was markedly colder than the left  with mottled skin and decreased hair growth. Pedal pulses (dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial) were not palpable in the right foot. Distinctive signs of muscle atrophy and shiny skin were also evident on the right lower limb.  Given the severity of the rest pain  the chronicity of symptoms  and his risk factors of diabetes and smoking  Mr. Jones was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia  the most severe form of peripheral artery disease. Prompt diagnostic tests including Ankle-Brachial Index and angiogram were ordered for further evaluation.

Patient Information: 66-year-old Caucasian male   Chief Complaint: Severe rest pain in the right foot for three weeks  increasing progressively despite medication for pain.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports he was previously able to walk a few blocks without experiencing any pain in his right foot  but that changed three weeks ago when he began to experience severe pain  which he describes as aching and throbbing. This pain now occurs both at rest and with minor exertion. He also complains of a nonhealing ulcer on his right big toe that started 2 weeks ago. He denies any history of fever  excessive weight loss or chest discomfort.  Past Medical History: The patient has a long history of uncontrolled Type 2 diabetes for the past 12 years and hypertension for 10 years. He smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 30 years  but stopped smoking five years ago when diagnosed with COPD.  Review of System: Denies any signs of chest pain  palpitations  dyspnea  gastrointestinal or genitourinary symptoms  or changes in bowel or bladder habits.   Family History: His father had peripheral artery disease and underwent a bypass surgery in his late sixties.  Physical Examination: A painful  nonhealing 2 cm ulcer noted on his right big toe. Pulses are absent in the right leg.   Social History: The patient lives with his wife in a suburban home. He is a retired mechanic. He does not consume alcohol. He is currently on various medications for his diabetes  hypertension and COPD.  This presentation is consistent with a case of critical limb ischemia  particularly concerning due to the potential risk of amputation if not managed immediately. The patient's uncontrolled diabetes and extensive history of smoking are likely major contributing factors  with his family history suggesting a potential genetic predisposition.

Patient Information: 68-year-old African American male.  Chief Complaint: Experiencing severe pain in the lower left leg that is not alleviated with rest. Pain seems worse at night and often interferes with his sleep. Reports of non-healing sores on the same foot  which developed about two weeks ago.  History of Present Illness: Patient first noticed mild pain in his leg about four months ago after walking short distances  typically relieved with rest. The pain progressively increased over the course of the past month and is now constant and severe. Recently  he also found ulcerations near the toe region which are not healing. He denies any history of trauma. He reports experiencing symptoms of intermittent claudication previously.  Past Medical History: Patient has a documented history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 12 years. He also maintains a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker with a 25 pack-year history who quit 6 years ago.  Medications: Metformin  Lisinopril  Simvastatin  daily aspirin.  Physical Examination: Significant for pallor and coolness of the left leg with decreased pulses compared to the contralateral side. Noticed two open sores on the foot  one on the toe and one on the heel with mild erythema and no apparent signs of infection. Distal hair loss and thickened nails were observed.  These symptoms collectively suggest that the patient may be suffering from critical limb ischemia  a severe manifestation of peripheral arterial disease. By history  physical examination and risk factors like advanced age  diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a significant smoking history  the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia is considered. Further diagnostic tests and vascular consultation would be necessary for the definitive diagnosis and management plan.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James is a 71-year-old African-American male with a long history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He has been a smoker for over 40 years  and his lifestyle is largely sedentary. He also has a history of high cholesterol levels and has been on medication for the same.   He presents today with complaints of severe  constant pain in his lower left leg  especially the foot  even during rest. He reports intermittent claudication  with the pain increasing significantly in the last two weeks. Mr. James also indicates that he has noticed some sores on his toes that do not seem to heal. He has been unable to sleep due to the pain and often has to dangle his leg over the side of the bed to relieve it.   Examining his leg shows an absence of pulses both dorsally and posteriorly. His left foot appears pale and slightly discolored  and is cold to touch in comparison with his right foot. Two ulcers are noted on his left toes  surrounded by discoloration and hard tissue. Distally  there is noticeable hair loss and shiny skin. Capillary refill time is delayed significantly. The patient exhibits no signs of systemic infection but is clearly distressed by pain.   The patient continues to live with his wife and is fairly independent with the activities of daily living  but has been restricted recently due to the pain in the leg. He is compliant with his medications but admits to not managing his diet and exercise for his diabetes as well as he should.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Smith is a 75-year-old African American male who presents with excruciating pain in his right lower leg at rest  which has been ongoing for the past 3 weeks.   History of Present Illness:   Aside from the pain  Mr. Smith explains that he has noticed poor healing of a minor wound on his right foot. His symptoms have been getting progressively worse  with the excruciating pain disturbing his sleep at night. He reports a significant decrease in his physical activity due to the pain and discomfort.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has a known 15-year history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. He has no known drug allergies but takes Metformin and Atenolol for his diabetes and hypertension  respectively. He underwent percutaneous transluminal angioplasty for chronic total occlusion of his right popliteal artery four years ago. His family history consists of cardiovascular diseases  including his father who had a fatal heart attack at the age of 65.  Vital Signs & Physical Exam:   Vital signs are within normal limits. A physical exam of the lower extremities reveals cold right foot with non-palpable distal pulses  shiny skin  absent hair growth on the right leg  and a purple hue to the right foot and lower leg suggesting poor oxygen supply to his limb.   The provided information is suggestive of critical limb ischemia with possible concomitant peripheral artery disease due to significant cardiovascular risk factors with a history of prior peripheral intervention.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the clinic with complaints of worsening bilateral leg pain  particularly in his right calf  over the last six months which has progressed to rest pain and non-healing ulcers on his right foot for the past three weeks. He reports that the pain is severe and disrupts his sleep. Mr. Johnson also mentions that he experiences relief after placing his legs in a dependent position. He has had a significant loss of body weight due to loss of appetite.  Mr. Johnson has a 40-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day and moderate alcohol use. He has had Type 2 Diabetes for the past 10 years and has a history of hypertension which has been managed with medication for the past 15 years. He also had a myocardial infarction approximately five years ago. There is no known family history of peripheral arterial disease.   On examination  both his feet are cold to touch with decreased capillary refill time (>3 seconds). His right foot exhibits dry gangrene with two ulcers on the dorsal aspect  each measuring 2-3 cm in diameter with necrotic bases. His popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial pulses are not palpable on the right and are diminished on the left. Lower extremity oedema was also noted. His body mass index is 21.  Mr. Johnson's lifestyle  coupled with his medical history suggests an advanced peripheral artery disease which has likely progressed to critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation: Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old African American male  presented to the clinic with bilateral lower extremity pain and non-healing sores on his right foot. The pain  described as a constant  burning sensation  is particularly severe when he's laying down and slightly mitigates when he hangs his feet over the side of his bed. He also reports experiencing fatigue and weakness in both legs  which has inhibited his ability to walk long distances without rest. Furthermore  he mentioned that his right foot feels cool to touch and appears pale. His pain level is recorded as 7/10.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a significant medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is poorly controlled  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He's also a former smoker  having quit 5 years ago but had a 40-pack year history. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 8 years ago after having a myocardial infarction. Records also reveal that he had a transient ischemic attack 2 years back  from which he fully recovered. He is currently on metformin  lisinopril  atorvastatin  and aspirin.  Demographics: Mr. Doe is a retired school bus driver  living with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. They have two adult children who live out of state. He is financially secure  with health insurance coverage. He denies alcohol use but has a history of heavy tobacco use. He is not actively engaging in regular physical activities  has poor dietary habits  and is obese with a BMI of 32.   Given his symptoms and history  the clinical suspicion of critical limb ischemia is high  necessitating further investigation and intervention. His uncontrolled diabetes and long history of smoking add significant risks too.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J is a 78-year-old Caucasian male presenting with severe  unrelenting pain in his left lower leg  which he rates as a 9 on a 10-point pain scale. The pain  characterized as aching and burning  is most severe in the foot and has persisted for 6 months. Over the last month  it has become constant  even at rest  and has significantly interfered with his sleep and daily activities  especially walking.  Mr. J reports that his left foot often feels cold and has a bluish discoloration. He also reveals recurrent heel ulcers over the past 5 months  which he believes are taking longer to heal than previously. The patient denies any recent trauma or injury to the leg. His symptoms have mildly responded to over-the-counter pain medication.  He has an extensive past medical history of atherosclerosis  type 2 diabetes mellitus for 18 years  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack-year history of smoking  though he quit 5 years ago. He underwent a coronary artery bypass graft surgery about 12 years back. He has no known allergies.  On a physical exam  the left leg is noticeably colder compared to the right. Pulses in the left leg are weak and barely palpable  while the right leg pulses are within a typical range. There is a noticeable loss of hair on the left leg and foot. An ulcer  approximately 2.5 cm in diameter  with minimal drainage and signs of infection  is observed on the left heel. The foot appears to be cyanotic and dystrophic nails are noticed.  This clinical scenario suggests critical limb ischemia  primarily resulting from peripheral arterial disease exacerbated by long-standing diabetes  atherosclerosis  and a history of tobacco use.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Philip Anderson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a persistent  severe and unrelenting pain in his right lower limb. He describes the pain as dull and aching  occurring even at rest  with escalating intensity over the past two weeks. Mr. Anderson also mentions persistent coldness of the leg  pallor  and numbness.  The patient is a former construction worker who recently retired after 40 years in the trade. He has a 35-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day but quit approximately two months ago. He has a medical history of obesity  hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and peripheral arterial disease (PAD). His last lower extremity angiogram was performed five years ago  which confirmed the diagnosis of PAD.   Mr. Anderson's medication regimen includes amlodipine 10mg for hypertension  metformin 500mg for diabetes  and low-dose aspirin. He admits to being non-compliant with his medications over the past month due to financial constraints. He also admits to inadequate management of his diabetes and hypertension.   Furthermore  he discloses that he has unexplained weight loss  loss of appetite  and has been unable to walk short distances due to pain  which indicates possible advanced disease. He has no known allergies and his family history includes a father with coronary artery disease and a mother with stroke. He lives alone  and his daughter helps with groceries and weekly house cleaning.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jones is a 78-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a one-month history of worsening right lower extremity pain. He describes the pain as constant  sharp  and located primarily in his right foot and calf. His pain significantly increases with walking and sometimes occurs at rest. He also reports an ulcer on his right big toe that has been present for a few weeks  which is not healing.  He has a past medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes mellitus that has been poorly controlled over the years  peripheral artery disease diagnosed 2 years ago  hypertension  and a 50-pack year smoking history  although he quit 10 years earlier.  He had applied a local ointment for the ulcer  but it did not improve. He reports no fevers  chills  or other systemic symptoms.  On physical examination  his right lower extremity is noted to be cooler compared to the left. Peripheral pulses are diminished in his right foot. He has a 2x2 cm ulcer with black eschar on his right great toe with minimal serous drainage.  This presentation is concerning for critical limb ischemia  a severe stage of peripheral artery disease  typically associated with rest pain  non-healing wounds  and risk for limb amputation if not promptly treated. His risk factors include his age  diabetes  history of smoking  and existing diagnosis of peripheral artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. M is a 75-year-old African-American female presenting to the ER with complaints of rest pain in her right lower extremity which she states has been worsening over the past several weeks. The pain is localized to her foot and is described as burning and cramping. The pain is severe enough that it leads to awakenings in the night. She also mentions existence of non-healing sores on her right foot. Ms. M reports a history of claudication in the same extremity  but the pain which was previously relieved with rest has now become constant. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness.  Upon examination  the lower extremity is cool to touch  with diminished pulses and sensory loss. There is a noticeable pallor when the leg is elevated and dependent rubor on lowering. The non-healing ulcers are noted on the foot  with a few areas showing signs of infection.  Past Medical History: Ms. M has a successful history of managing hypertension and type 2 diabetes for the past 15 years and was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) three years ago. She is also a long-term smoker and confesses to have struggled with quitting smoking in the past. She underwent a coronary artery bypass grafting five years ago following a diagnosis of coronary artery disease.  This woman's past medical history and examination findings point towards critical limb ischemia  necessitating further urgent investigation to confirm the diagnosis and consideration of revascularization options.

Patient Presentation: A 68-year-old African American male patient presents to the clinic complaining of severe  persistent pain in his right leg that has been worsening over the past few weeks. The pain is especially intense in his foot  even while at rest. He reports having a few non-healing ulcers on his foot and also displays signs of significant weight loss. The patient experiences difficulty in walking and has also reported instances of disturbed sleep due to the intensity of the pain. He has no known allergies.  Demographics: The patient is a retired military serviceman  a widow  and lives alone. He is a current smoker (40 pack-years) and consumes alcohol occasionally. The patient is also obese and has a sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of Type-2 diabetes mellitus for the past 8 years  hypertension for about 15 years  peripheral artery disease  and dyslipidemia. He has undergone angioplasty of the left lower limb 3 years ago. He was non-compliant with prescribed medications and follow-up appointments  often citing personal and financial constraints.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mr. Robinson Age: 68 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Complaint: Severe pain in the lower right leg and foot  even while at rest; non-healing wound on the lower leg.  Past Medical History:  1. Patient has a 40-year history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with daily insulin injections and a special diet. 2. Patient also has high blood pressure  controlled with medication and regular monitoring. 3. 10-year history of hyperlipidemia. 4. Previous smoker  quit 5 years ago but smoked 1 pack a day for 30 years. 5. Family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a heart attack at 70 years.  Clinical examination reveals a cold right foot with absent distal pulses. A deep ulcer measuring approx 5cm in diameter is present on the medial aspect of the right lower leg  exhibiting necrotic tissue in its bed and surrounding erythema. No signs of infection are detected. The patient reports that the lesion started as a small wound around 6 weeks ago that has progressively worsened.  Further diagnostic work-up and consultation with a vascular surgeon is ordered to confirm diagnosis of suspected critical limb ischemia (CLI). The patient's upper limb blood pressure is normal  but his ankle-brachial index (ABI) scores are less than 0.4  indicative of severe limb ischemia. Angiography displays a severe blockage in both the arteries supplying his right lower limb. His glycemic status  lipid profile and renal functions are out of normal range. The patient is indicated for urgent angioplasty with the possibility of bypass surgery. Advice for better glycemic control  lipid-lowering medications  and wound care are also given.

Patient Presentation  Mr. John Smith  a 68-year-old male  presents to the emergency department with severe rest pain in his left lower extremity persisting for the last 2 weeks. Patient describes the pain as burning and continuous  rating it 8/10 on the pain scale. The pain is worse at night and he's often awakened by it.   Past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years. He is also a two-pack-per-day smoker  accumulating a 35 pack-year smoking history. He has a history of a transient ischemic attack (TIA) about 5 years ago; however  the patient states no known history of coronary artery disease or myocardial infarction.   The patient reports that his symptoms have progressed over the past month  from intermittent claudication to this severe rest pain which is not relieved by analgesics. He also mentions a non-healing ulcer on his left toe  and he has noticed that his foot feels cold to touch. His symptoms have led to difficulty in walking and impairment in his daily activities.   Patient's current medications include metformin for diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and simvastatin for hyperlipidemia.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 72-year-old African American male presents to his primary care clinic with chief complaints of rest pain especially at night in his right lower extremity  and a non-healing wound on his right foot for the past few weeks. The pain  palpable around the calf region  is described as severe  burning  and is present even without any physical activity or exertion. The pain worsens when his foot is elevated and slightly alleviates when it is dependent.   Past Medical History: The patient's medical record indicates an extensive past medical history that includes uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  peripheral arterial disease and a 40-year history of smoking two packs per day  which he stopped around 4 years back.  He reported a history of endovascular surgery for left lower extremity two years ago. He has been non-compliant with his medications  has a poor diet  and lacks a regular exercise regimen despite previous counseling and education. Family history indicates both his father and elder brother also suffered from peripheral arterial disease and coronary artery disease. Mr. Smith retired 10 years ago from a high-stressed job and lives with his wife and has limited social connection. His activities of daily living have been impaired due to pain-induced sleep disruption and the fear of losing his foot or probably his life.

Patient Presentation:  We have a 68-year-old African-American male patient presenting with severe pain in his right lower leg  particularly when walking  which could indicate the onset of critical limb ischemia. The pain has persisted for the past few weeks and is accompanied by chronic fatigue and shortness of breath. He has also observed discoloration and non-healing ulceration in the lower leg.  Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. Samuel Jackson Age: 68 years Sex: Male Race: African-American Residential Address: Florida  United States Employment: Retired school teacher Marital Status: Widower  Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Jackson is diagnosed with Type II diabetes  which has been managed with oral medications for the past 10 years. He also had a history of hypertension  which has been controlled with medication since the diagnosis 12 years ago. He was a heavy smoker throughout his life  though he quit five years ago. Mr. Jackson's father had needed a heart bypass operation in his sixties  indicating a family history of cardiovascular diseases. Lately  his leg pain has been so severe that it disrupts sleep  and he has been often found positioning his leg over the edge of the bed. He also confirmed a significant weight loss over the past few months due to loss of appetite. Interestingly  his last lower limb pulses assessment  conducted a year ago  was normal.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Jane Jones is a 67-year-old African American female presenting to the emergency department today with the chief complaint of severe  worsening pain in her left lower leg.   She states the pain has been ongoing for about six weeks but has increased significantly in intensity over the past two weeks. In addition  she mentions experiencing rest pain  particularly at night  with the pain temporarily relieved upon dangling the leg over the bedside. She also describes non-healing ulcers over the distal portion of the left foot.  She has a 35-year history of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus which has been poorly controlled due to noncompliance. She is also a smoker  averaging half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years  and has been diagnosed with hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Furthermore  she has a history of coronary artery disease and suffered a non-ST elevated myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) two years ago.  On examination  the left lower extremity is colder compared to the right  with diminished distal pulses. The skin shows signs of atrophy  hair loss and there are multiple ulcers with foul-smelling discharge.  Imaging studies and formal vascular studies would be necessary to further evaluate the severity of her condition and to validate the diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia. Her high risk factors including diabetes  smoking history  long-standing hyperlipidemia and hypertension  indicative symptoms and signs  point towards an urgent need to address her deteriorating peripheral arterial disease.

Patient Presentation:  Patient: John Peterson is a 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a three-week history of severe pain in the left lower limb  particularly when walking or lying flat. He describes it as a continuous  burning pain that does not improve with over-the-counter pain relievers. He also notes that his left foot has developed a persistent  non-healing sore and there is noticeable blackening of some toes.  Demographics: He is a retired truck driver  lives with his wife of 45 years  and is currently a regular smoker with a 50-pack year smoking history.  Medical History: Mr. Peterson has a 10-year history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He reports that he is non-compliant with his prescribed anti-diabetic and anti-hypertensive medications due to financial constraints.  Family History: Both of his parents had cardiovascular disease  his father dying from a heart attack at the age of 65  and his mother suffering multiple strokes prior to death.  Surgical History: He has had no surgeries in the past.   Social History: He denies alcohol or illicit drug use. He admits to a diet high in processed and fast foods.  Physical Examination: On examination  the left lower limb is significantly colder than the right. Pulses in the left foot are not palpable. There are ulcers seen on the left foot along with gangrenous changes on several toes. Capillary refilling time on the left foot is markedly prolonged. No edema noted.   These findings  together with the patient’s history  are highly suggestive of critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Patricia Harrison is a 78-year-old African-American female who presents to the office with a 2-week history of debilitating pain in her right lower leg and foot. The pain is severe  continuous and tends to increase at night  mostly described as dull and aching. Recently  she’s also noticed a non-healing ulcer on her right foot that has progressively worsened over the past week.  Patricia has a significant history of smoking  consuming 1 pack/day for the past 60 years but quit 5 years ago due to a diagnosis of COPD. She has a past medical history significant for hypertension for which she takes amlodipine  type 2 diabetes managed by metformin and insulin  and hyperlipidemia controlled by statins. She also has a history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) diagnosed approximately 10 years ago.  She’s also experienced episodes of claudication when walking moderate distances but managed to control the intermittency of these episodes by moderating her activity level and daily walks.  She resides in a nursing home and has limited mobility. There’s no known history of drug allergies. However  she has no reported right lower extremity trauma or preceding infection. Her family history includes a father who had an amputation procedure due to peripheral artery disease.

Patient Profile: Mr. James Harmon  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the vascular clinic accompanied by his son.  Chief Complaint:  He complains of intense pain in his left lower limb  even while resting. He rates his pain as a 9 on a scale of 10. It particularly disturbs him at night. He also observed a discoloration of his left foot  which now feels cold to touch. He mentions there is a non-healing wound on his left toe.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Harmon is a known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus since the last 15 years  and Moderate Hypertension since the past 10 years. He also reveals a history of a heart attack 5 years ago  post which he was on aspirin and statins. He confessed that he is a heavy smoker  with a 40-pack-year history.  Review of Systems: Mr. Harmon has lost 15 pounds of weight over the past two months and feels tired after minimal activity. His appetite has also decreased. His son reports that Mr. Harmon is increasingly becoming forgetful.  Physical Examination: On examination  there was a clear pulse deficit in the left foot compared to the right with diminished peripheral sensations. The small  non-healing ulcer was present on his left toe. The temperature of the left foot was comparatively lower  and it had a bluish discoloration suggesting cyanosis. However  no signs of deep vein thrombosis were noted.  Plan:  Start the patient on opioid analgesics until his pain subsides and admit him for further diagnostic investigations  including peripheral angiography  and possible vascular surgical consult. Control his diabetes and hypertension optimally. Provide him education and support to quit smoking. Also  refer him for a cardiology check-up and neurology referral for his memory issues.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 75-year-old Caucasian male with a significant history of smoking (1 pack/day for 40 years)  uncontrolled hypertension  and longstanding Type 2 diabetes mellitus presenting with worsening pain in his left lower extremity for the last two months. He reports constant  severe ache in his calf even at rest  which intensifies at night. The pain often wakes him up from sleep. He needs 2-3 pillows to elevate his leg in order to fall asleep. Moreover  he notes the onset of a non-healing ulcer on his left big toe that's been there for several weeks.   Upon examination  the left foot has a temperature cooler than the right one  absent pulses in left posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis. There's an ulcer measuring 1cm in diameter with black eschar at the base on the tip of the left big toe. The left calf is relatively atrophic when compared to the right calf.  He recalls being diagnosed with peripheral artery disease approximately 5 years ago but was not compliant with medications and lifestyle modification  due to disregard for the potential complications associated with his condition.   In sum  the patient's critical risk factors include his advanced age  smoking history  poorly controlled hypertension  diabetic status  non-compliance with prescribed medications  and the presence of peripheral artery disease. These factors suggest a significant likelihood of his current symptoms being due to critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 70-year-old African American male from rural South Carolina who presents to the vascular clinic with a complaint of increasing right lower extremity pain over the last three months. The pain is significantly worse when he walks even short distances but also present at rest  particularly at night. He describes the pain as “burning” in nature that does not radiate. He also references a mild intermittent paralysis in the foot.   He has observed that his right foot appears paler and cooler to touch compared to his left foot. Lately  he has also noticed a ulcer on the heel of his right foot that he first noticed two weeks ago. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness. He has never had a similar episode in the past.  His past medical history includes hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  for which he takes amlodipine and metformin  respectively. He also has a 40-pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He does not engage in regular physical activity due to arthritis. His diet is predominantly Southern-style cuisine with a high intake of fried foods and processed meats. He is noncompliant with his diabetic diet. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 76. He has been using over-the-counter wound ointments for the ulcer but with minimal improvement.  Physical examination revealed an underweight man in obvious distress due to right lower limb pain. Right foot was noted to be cold  and pale  particularly when elevated. Phone-brachial index was significantly reduced on the right side (0.4). A non-healing  painful ulcer was noted on the heel of the right foot. Rest of the systemic examination was normal.   On discussing the history and physical findings  Mr. Johnson was informed that his symptoms were consistent with critical limb ischemia and will require further investigation and prompt management to prevent progression.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 65 years Sex: Male Occupation: Retired carpenter Ethnicity: Caucasian  Chief Complaint:   John presents with severe pain in his right lower leg both at rest and during activities  affecting his mobility and sleep quality. He describes the pain as a constant burning and sometimes aching feeling. He also mentions that the leg feels unusually cold and has noticed skin color changes  turning more pale.  History of Present Illness:  The symptoms started gradually about 6 months ago but have intensified in the last 3 weeks. He initially dismissed the symptoms as symptoms of aging. There have also been ulcerations on his toes that haven't healed in over a month.  Past Medical History:  John has been a smoker for the past 40 years. He has a known history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago and peripheral artery disease diagnosed 5 years ago. Furthermore  he experiences episodes of chest pain for which he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting about three years ago.   Medications:  He's currently on metformin for diabetes  aspirin and simvastatin for cardiovascular disease  nitroglycerin for angina  and uses a topical cream for his leg ulcer.  Family History:  Both of his parents had a history of hypertension and died of cardiovascular events. His elder brother has Type 2 diabetes and peripheral artery disease.  Social History:  John lives alone since his wife passed away 2 years ago. He has 2 children who stay in another city and visit him occasionally. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history and used to consume alcohol socially but quit after his cardiac surgery. He does not exercise regularly.  Review of systems:   John has been experiencing fatigue and decreased appetite. No recent weight loss  fever  cough  shortness of breath  heart palpitations  or gastrointestinal symptoms.  Physical examination:  Upon inspection  John's right lower leg and foot appear pale and shiny with visible hair loss. There are two ulcerated areas on his toes  poorly healing with sluggish capillary refill. Pedal pulses are absent on palpation.

Patient Information: 75-year-old African American male   Chief Complaint: Severe  constant pain in the right lower leg  even while at rest.   History of Present Illness: The patient has been experiencing dull  cramping pain in his right calf for the past six months  which has progressively worsened over time and now occurs even during rest. The pain is relieved moderately with elevation and worsens with ambulation. The patient reports non-healing ulcers on the right foot. There is a decreased sensation in the foot. The patient also notes the foot is noticeably cooler than the left foot.  Past Medical History: He has a 15-year history of poorly controlled type II diabetes and hypertension. He is also a former smoker with a 40 pack-year history but quit 10 years ago. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 5 years ago for severe coronary artery disease. There is a history of high cholesterol levels but no other significant medical or surgical history.  Allergies: None known  Current Medications: Metformin  Lisinopril  Clopidogrel  and Statin  Social History: He lives with his wife and is retired. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use.  Family History: His father had coronary artery disease and died from a stroke. His mother had diabetes.   Physical Examination: Blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg in right arm and 145/85 mm Hg in left arm. The heart has regular rhythm; no murmurs heard. Lung fields are clear. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Right lower extremity reveals a cold foot  delayed capillary refill  non-healing ulcers  and absence of distal pulses. Left lower extremity findings are within normal limits.  This presentation is consistent with a case of critical limb ischemia in the right lower extremity  likely secondary to peripheral artery disease  requiring urgent evaluation and treatment.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old African American male  presents with severe  unrelenting pain in his right foot which started 2 weeks ago. The pain often intensifies at night  disturbing his sleep. He states that the pain somewhat improves when he lets his leg hang over the side of his bed. He also mentions a non-healing ulcer on his right foot  which has been present for 4 weeks  gradually increasing in size.
