Upon screening  he reports a 30-year history of heavy smoking; about twenty cigarettes per day but quit 3 years ago. His past medical history includes a 10-year history of uncontrolled Type II Diabetes Mellitus  and medication-controlled Hypertension. The patient also has a history of peripheral artery disease and had undergone left leg angioplasty 5 years ago.  There’s no past history of any major surgeries  allergy  or other significant medical conditions. He is unmarried and lives alone  and is a retired carpenter by profession. He is currently on Metformin  Lisinopril  and Aspirin. There’s no history of any illicit drug use  excessive alcohol intake  or sexually transmitted diseases. His family history is significant for early onset coronary artery disease and stroke. His mother passed away at the age of 60 due to a heart attack.  The patient appears moderately distressed due to pain. His right foot appears pale with a noticeable ulcer on the plantar surface. The skin is cool to touch. Popliteal  posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses are notably weaker in the affected leg as compared to the left leg. Further  he has loss of hair on the affected leg and shiny skin. Preliminary conclusion suggests possible Critical Limb Ischemia. Urgent vascular consultation and diagnostic angiography are recommended.

Patient Presentation:   Ms. Susan Williams is a 65-year-old African American female who resides in an assisted living facility. She comes in today  accompanied by her son  complaining of severe rest pain in her left leg that she describes as “a constant  sharp pain” that gets worse at night. Her son also reports that he has noticed a non-healing ulcer on the left foot toe which was previously just a blister from her new shoes last month. Ms. Williams also mentions intermittent claudication (she experiences severe pain in her left calf even after a short distance of walking). Her pain is reported to be worse when her leg is elevated  primarily at rest and is relieved when dangled.   Past Medical History:  Ms. Williams reports that she is a two pack/day smoker for the past 15 years. She admits to ALD (Alcohol Liver Disease) and has been a chronic alcohol consumer for the past 20 years; she also mentions diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension. On further inquiry  Ms. Williams also admits to past episodes of TIA's (Transient Ischemic Attacks). She denies any known allergies to medications.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  the left lower extremity is cold to touch  with significantly reduced capillary refill time compared to the right leg. There is noticeable loss of hair on the leg  shiny atrophic skin and the toenails appear thickened. The non-healing ulcer on the left toe is about 3x3 cm with depth reaching the subcutaneous tissue and scanty purulent discharge. Her peripheral pulses (Dorsalis Pedis and Posterior Tibial) are not palpable on the left side whereas they are normal on the right side. The ankle brachial index (ABI) is 0.3  suggesting severe peripheral artery disease.  The rest of the complete physical examination  including cardio-respiratory and neurological examination  is essentially within normal limits.   Based on the patient’s clinical history  physical examination and risk factors (diabetes  smoking  and hyperlipidemia)  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia is fairly suggestive. Further diagnostic tests including angiography are planned for confirmation of the diagnosis. Ms. Williams is immediately advised for smoking cessation and management for the risk factors has been refined.      Ms. Williams has been informed about the gravity of her disease  the necessity of its urgent management and possibility of limb amputation if not managed promptly. She seems to understand and agrees to abide by the medical advice.

Patient Presentation:  A 69-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of progressive right lower extremity pain. Initially  the patient was able to walk short distances  but the pain has now become so severe that it torments him even at rest  described as a constant  throbbing ache localized mainly to his right calf and ankle.   The pain escalates at night  necessitating him to dangle his leg over the bedside for temporary relief. He also noticed a dark  non-healing ulcer on the medial aspect of his right ankle 2 weeks ago  which concerns him  plus the recent onset of coolness to touch and pallor on his right foot.   As for past medical history  he is a former smoker with a 50-pack year history and quit smoking 2 years ago. He also has a 15-year history of uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus with a recent HbA1c of 9.3%  hypertension diagnosed 8 years ago  currently on treatment  and was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease 3 years ago. No known family history of aneurysm or claudication. No known allergies reported.   The patient admitted to poor diet control despite his diabetes and hypertension and hardly exercises due to chronic lower limb discomfort.   Given the ongoing pain  unhealing ulcer  and poor circulation symptoms  a preliminary diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia is suspected.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mr. John Anderson Age: 72 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired construction worker  Chief Complaint:   Mr. Anderson presents at the clinic today with a 2-week history of worsening pain in both lower extremities  particularly at night  causing him numerous sleep disturbances.   History of Present Illness:  He explains that the pain mostly affects his calves and becomes more severe when walking but eases when he rests. He also reports experiencing extreme coldness in both legs  with his left foot occasionally turning a pale color. He noticed a few open sores on his feet that have not healed. He adds that he's lost a significant amount of weight over the past few weeks unknowingly.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Anderson has been a smoker for the past 50 years  with a 40 pack-year history. He has a history of type 2 diabetes for 15 years and hypertension for 20 years. He had a myocardial infarction five years ago and underwent coronary artery bypass grafting surgery. He briefly mentions that his mobility had been steadily declining over the past two years due to chronic arthritis.   Family History:  His father died of a stroke in his 80s  and his mother passed away from complications of diabetes. He has an elder brother who survived a myocardial infarction and is currently managing hypertension and diabetes.  Social History:  He is a widower who lives alone but with weekly visits from his daughter. He doesn't consume alcohol and quit smoking after his cardiac surgery. He does not engage in regular physical activity.  Review of Systems:  He denies experiencing chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  abdominal pain  or any changes in bowel or bladder function.   Physical Exam:  On examination  both legs appear pale  with cold temperature to touch especially in his left foot. Peripheral pulses are reduced in both legs. Multiple non-healing ulcers are noted on both feet  more prominent on the left foot.  Based on these findings  the working diagnosis for the patient is critical limb ischemia  and he is advised to get further diagnostic tests such as Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  Doppler ultrasound scan  angiography  and blood tests.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old African American male who presents to the clinic with complaints of extreme pain in his right lower extremity  rest pain and minor ulcers that have been persisting for the past three weeks. His pain is primarily persistent at rest and intensifies upon elevation of the limb. He also reports that the leg feels cold to touch compared to his left extremity.   He is a former smoker with a smoking history of 35 packs/year but quit 10 years ago. He has a known history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus and has been taking anti-hypertensives and oral hypoglycemic agents regularly. His family history reveals his father had peripheral artery disease and his elder brother underwent a below-knee amputation due to severe peripheral arterial disease.   He is retired and lives with his wife. He reports having trouble with mobility and his sleep is interrupted due to pain and occasional numbness. His wounds are slowly healing despite timely local care which is causing great discomfort to him.  On physical examination  he has a diminished pulse in the right lower extremity  decreased sensation along with pallor  and an ulcer on the right great toe. There are also patches of dry skin and hair loss noted on that leg. His vitals are stable and other systemic examinations are normal.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Rosa Martinez is a 70-year-old Hispanic female  comes into the clinic complaining of ongoing severe and worsening pain in her right lower leg for the last 6 weeks. Ms. Martinez states she experiences this pain even while at rest and notes that her leg often feels cold to touch. The pain has been disrupting her sleep at night and has made it increasingly difficult for her to walk or participate in daily activities. She also reports noticing a non-healing wound on her right foot.  In her past medical history  Ms. Martinez has diagnosed and treatment-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. For years  she was a two pack-a-day smoker but quit ten years ago after being diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Furthermore  she reveals she was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) around five years ago.   Her father had a history of heart disease and her mother was diabetic. Her family history also reveals several members with various vascular diseases.  Currently  she lives alone and is retired. She states her diet is predominantly homemade Hispanic cuisine. All these factors make her situation worth investigating for critical limb ischemia.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Smith is a 73-year-old African American male presenting with complaints of severe pain in his left lower leg and foot. The pain has been worsening over the past month and now it is bothering him even at rest at night. He mentions he's been waking up because of the pain and would have to dangle his feet over the bed to get any relief. Additionally  he's noticed that his left foot looks discolored  slightly bluish and cold. He also reports the non-healing nature of a small wound on the left big toe.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has been a chronic smoker since his twenties and also has a known case of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 10 years  Hypertension for 18 years  and Hyperlipidemia for 15 years. He previously was diagnosed with Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) 5 years earlier. He has a history of stroke with no residual deficits five years ago and coronary artery disease  with a stent placement to his left anterior descending artery three years ago.   Family History:   There is a family history of heart diseases with his father dying in his 50s from a myocardial infarction. His older brother also underwent bypass surgery at the age of 60.   Social History:   He's been retired for the past 8 years  lives with his wife  and is considerably active in the local community. Despite repeated advice  he didn't quit smoking and consumes alcohol socially. He admits to not monitoring his diet strictly and being fairly sedentary. He does not do any illicit drugs.   Current Medication:  He's been managed on Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes  Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension  and Atorvastatin 40mg daily for high cholesterol. Clopidogrel has been prescribed since his stent placement.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 72-year-old African-American male named Mr. Johnson. He presents with complaints of rest pain in his left lower leg that's been worsening over the past few months. The pain is primarily in his calf and toes and it prevents him from getting sleep at night. He reports a sensation of numbness and coldness in the foot and also noticed a slowly healing non-traumatic ulcer on his big toe.  His past medical history is significant. He has severe obesity  poorly controlled type 2 diabetes with peripheral neuropathy  and a 40-year history of heavy smoking. He also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and was diagnosed with non-obstructive coronary artery disease three years ago. Mr. Johnson has shown non-compliance with his medication regimen  largely due to financial constraints. He is not under any major psychiatric treatment but has had depressive episodes in the past.  He is retired  lives with his wife and their pet dog  and his two children live nearby. His wife mentions that the patient has limited mobility due to severe pain  and his activity is much decreased since his leg pain started. Currently  Mr. Johnson uses a walking cane but struggles with distance and stairs due to the pain.  In terms of family history  both of Mr. Johnson's parents had diabetes and his father had a history of stroke. His older sister underwent a below-knee amputation due to complications of peripheral artery disease.  This information is suggestive of a patient with critical limb ischemia  which is likely due to his peripheral artery disease  exacerbated by nicotine abuse  diabetes  and non-compliance to medication.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 70-year-old African-American male presenting with severe pain in the right lower extremity consistent with critical limb ischemia. The pain is noted to be consistently present at rest and particularly intense during nights. The patient has also noted skin color changes with the leg becoming paler  along with observed non-healing ulcers on the toes of the right foot. Title: A Case on Critical Limb Ischemia   Slide 1: Introduction  Critical limb ischemia (CLI) is a severe obstruction of the arteries which seriously decreases blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Our case revolves around a 65-year-old African American male  a retired construction worker; a resident of Houston  Texas. He has a history of smoking  and is a known hypertensive and diabetic for 15 years.  Slide 3: Presenting Complaints  The patient has reported experiencing rest pain in the right lower extremity for six months with the development of non-healing ulcers on the same limb  predominantly around the foot and toe area.  Slide 4: Medical History  - Known case of hypertension for 10 years  under medication. - Diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago  poorly controlled. - Long standing history of smoking – 20 cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. - No known drug allergies reported  Slide 5: Clinical Examination  On examination  the patient’s right lower limb was colder compared to the left. Distal pulses (dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial) in the right lower limb were non-palpable. Non-healing ulcers with necrotic patches were seen around the right foot and toe area. No signs of deep vein thrombosis were noticed.  Slide 6: Investigations & Diagnosis  Based on the clinical findings  the patient was suspected of having critical limb ischemia  which was further confirmed by investigations like an ankle-brachial index (ABI)  Doppler ultrasound  CT angiography showing severe blockages in the distal parts of the right lower limb arteries.  Slide 7: Management Plan  The patient was treated with revascularization therapy through angioplasty aimed at restoring the blood flow  along with aggressive management of associated risk factors. Patient also received appropriate wound care for the non-healing ulcers.  Slide 8: Summary  Patients with CLI have a high risk of mortality and amputation. Timely intervention and aggressive control of risk factors significantly reduce the complications and improve quality of life. In this case  the interplay of diabetes  hypertension  and smoking significantly contributed to the severity of the patient’s condition. Hence  highlighting the importance of risk factor management in CLI prevention.  Slide 9: Q & A  Open the floor for any questions or comments.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Case Study Presentation: Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 2: Demographics Title: Patient Demographics - Patient: 68-year-old male  - Employment Status: Retired  - Ethnicity: Caucasian  - Residence: Urban environment   Slide 3: Past Medical History Title: Relevant Past Medical History - Smoker for over 40 years - Chronic hypertension diagnosed 15 years ago  - Hyperlipidemia diagnosed 20 years ago  - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago  - Previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) occurred 5 years ago   Slide 4: Critical Limb Ischemia Title: Current Diagnosis  - Presenting complaint: Intense rest pain in the right leg exacerbating at night - Physical Examination: Non-healing ulcers on the right foot with notable absence of pulses in the right lower extremity.   Slide 5: Diagnosis Confirmation Title: Diagnostic Testing  - Angiogram: Severe occlusion of the right common inferior femoral artery.  Secondary findings included multiple stenoses in distal arteries. - Doppler ultrasonography: Severe reduction in blood flow in the right lower extremity. - Blood tests: Elevated HbA1c level indicating poor glycemic control measures.  Slide 6: Treatment and Prognosis Title: Management and Prognosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) - Interventional strategy: Surgical bypass or endovascular intervention - Medicinal management: Antiplatelet therapy  statins  and pain management - Prognosis: Dependent upon comorbidities  timing of intervention  and the patient's adherence to the treatment.  Slide 7: Importance of Early Detection Title: The Implications of Critical Limb Ischemia - Early diagnosis and treatment of CLI can greatly improve prognosis.  - Patient education on optimal management of diabetes  hypertension  and smoking cessation can prevent progression of peripheral artery disease (PAD) to CLI.  Slide 8: Conclusion - By addressing lifestyle risk factors and through careful clinical monitoring  the severity of CLI can be significantly reduced  leading to a better quality of life and reduction in severe outcomes such as limb amputation.  Slide 9: Questions and Discussion Title: Questions and Further Discussions - Open floor for questions  insights  and further discussions on the presented case and CLI in general.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a Geriatric Patient  Slide 1: Introduction - Patient Profile: 72-year-old African American male - Occupation: Retired electrical engineer - Chief Complaint: Severe pain in left lower limb at rest  with accompanying skin breakdown and ulceration  Slide 2: Past Medical History - History of Type II Diabetes: Diagnosed 10 years ago  managed with oral hypoglycemics - Hypertension: Diagnosed 7 years ago  controlled with medication - Tobacco Use: Smoked 20 cigarettes a day for over 40 years  quit 5 years ago - No known allergies or history of surgeries  Slide 3: Current Medical Status - On a continuous regimen of hypoglycemics and blood pressure medication - Presenting signs: Persistent rest pain for the past 3 months  non-healing foot ulcer for last 6 weeks - Observable skin breakdown and pale  cool leg  Slide 4: Clinical Examination - Peripheral pulse examination revealed absent left tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses  - Buerger's test was positive - Left lower limb ischemia rated on Fontaine's stage IV  Slide 5: Diagnostic Investigations - Doppler Ultrasound: Revealed significant reduction in ankle-brachial pressure index (ABI) of the left leg (0.4) and plaque formation - MRI Angiogram: Highlighted significant blockage in left iliac and femoral arteries - Blood tests: Showed elevated HbA1c  indicating poor diabetic control  Slide 6: Diagnosis  - Diagnosis is critical limb ischemia (CLI)  primarily caused by peripheral artery disease (PAD) exacerbated by poor control of blood glucose levels and history of tobacco use  Slide 7: Treatment Plan  - Implement aggressive management of blood glucose levels and hypertension - Collaborate with vascular surgeons for possible endovascular therapy or bypass surgery - Regular wound care and management for the foot ulcer - Long-term  patient education on diabetes management and healthy lifestyle habits to prevent further complications   Slide 8: Prognosis and Long-Term Care  - Early recognition and treatment of CLI are vital to prevent limb amputation  - Regular follow-ups for monitoring response to treatment  - Encouragement for patient self-management of diabetes and hypertension   Slide 9: Conclusion - This case underlines the importance of managing risk factors in patients with chronic conditions to prevent severe complications like critical limb ischemia. - Involvement of a multidisciplinary team  including vascular surgeons  diabetologists  and wound care specialists  can provide a comprehensive patient care approach.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Presentation  Slide 1: Introduction Case Study: Mr. James Miller - Age: 65 - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired accountant - Ethnicity: Caucasian  Slide 2: Past Medical History - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 15 years ago.  - Hypertension: Under medical control for the past 10 years. - Smoking: Smoked 1 pack/day for 30 years  quit 5 years ago. - Family History: Father died from a stroke at 67  mother has peripheral artery disease (PAD).  Slide 3: Presenting Problem  Mr. Miller reported a gradual onset of pain in his left leg  particularly when walking and climbing stairs (also known as claudication). Additionally  he has experienced rest pain for the past three months  specifically at night.  Slide 4: Physical Exam Observation of the lower limb revealed: - Loss of hair on the foot and shin - Pale leg when elevated  dusky red color when dependent - Reduced temperature  compared to the right leg - Absence of pulses in the left lower limb - Non-healing ulcer on the left big toe  Slide 5: Assessment and Analysis Considering Mr. Miller's age  medical history  and physical examination findings  there is a high suspicion of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe stage of peripheral artery disease. He presents classic symptoms of CLI like claudication  rest pain  and non-healing wounds.  Slide 6: Investigations To confirm CLI  recommended tests include: - Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  - Doppler Ultrasound  - CT Angiography/MR Angiography - Angiography   Slide 7: Treatment and Management Once CLI is confirmed  a multi-disciplinary approach to management is necessary. This includes: - Interventional procedures to restore blood flow (angioplasty  stenting  bypass surgery) - Wound care and management of the toe ulcer - Optimal Diabetes and Hypertension control  - Lifestyle modifications such as diet and exercise - Smoking cessation therapy  if applicable - Possible medications could include antiplatelets  statins  and pain management options - Regular follow-ups for monitoring   Slide 8: Conclusion  Critical Limb Ischemia is a severe form of PAD which can lead to amputation if not promptly diagnosed and adequately treated. Thus  early diagnosis  aggressive risk factor modification  revascularization  robust multidisciplinary approach  and patient education are key to CLI management. In Mr. Miller's case  judicious intervention based on medical and surgical management can help to restore his quality of life.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Case Study: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Slide 2: Demographics  Patient's information: 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  smoker (30 pack-years)  moderate alcohol consumption.  Slide 3: Past Medical History History of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and dyslipidemia.  Previous myocardial infarction 5 years ago with stent placement. No history of prior surgical interventions.  Slide 4: Presentation Presented with rest pain in the right foot  worsening over the past 3 months.  Intermittent claudication after walking less than 100 yards.  Recently developed non-healing wounds on the right foot.  Slide 5: Physical Examination Signs of atherosclerosis (absent pulses  bruit) in right lower extremity. High blood pressure (140/90 mmHg). Discoloration (pallor) and coolness of the right foot.  Non-healing ulcers on the right foot  gangrene of the distal toes.  Slide 6: Investigation • Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) - Right: 0.45  Left: 0.9 • Duplex ultrasound - Significant stenosis of the right popliteal artery. • Computed Tomography Angiogram (CTA) confirmed the above findings. • Lab results - Elevated blood glucose and HbA1c levels.  Slide 7: Diagnosis Confirmed Critical Limb Ischemia (Rutherford Class 4) due to peripheral arterial disease (PAD) secondary to uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and hypertension.  Slide 8: Treatment Options 1. Aggressive medical therapy (Antihypertensives  Antiplatelet  Statins  Glycemic control). 2. Endovascular intervention (e.g.  angioplasty  stenting) for revascularization. 3. Surgical bypass if revascularization fails. 4. Limb amputation as the last resort.  Slide 9: Prognosis and Follow-up • Depending on the success of the treatment  prognosis varies. • Regular follow-ups needed to monitor the condition and manage complications. • Emphasis on lifestyle changes such as smoking cessation  regular exercise  and a healthy diet.  Slide 10: Conclusion CLI is a serious condition that requires aggressive medical treatment and lifestyle changes. Early detection and control of risk factors such as diabetes and hypertension can prevent or slow down the progression of the disease.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: A Study of a Case: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Slide 2: Demographics & Identification Patient: Mr. X  60-year-old Caucasian male.  Slide 3: Chief Complaint Mr. X. presents with worsening pain in the left lower limb  ulcerations on the foot  and reports of intermittent claudication - especially triggered by minimal physical activities.  Slide 4: Past Medical History  Mr. X suffers from comorbidities including hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus poorly controlled  and a 45-year history of smoking. He experienced a mild stroke 7 years ago  with the residual effect of minor weakness in his right hand.  Slide 5: Clinical Findings On examination  the left lower limb showed rest pain  intermittent claudication  foot ulceration  and gangrene in the distal toes. Pulses were weak down the limb. Foot was pale with a cool temperature  persistent sores  decreases the mobility of toes  and non-healing wounds. Evidence of severe peripheral arterial disease.  Slide 6: Diagnostic Assessment The Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) result was 0.3; Lower than normal range indicative of severe limb ischemia.  Color Doppler Ultrasound revealed a significant decrease in blood flow in the lower extremity.  CT angiogram showed occlusion of the left femoral artery and severe stenosis in the peroneal arteries.  Slide 7: Concluding remarks and discussion Mr. X was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia  a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has escalated to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores. His case is a clear indicator of the importance of early detection  effective management of associated risk factors  and timely initiation of treatment.  Slide 8: Management  CLI being a serious condition  warrants immediate intervention. The management plan was twofold - controlling risk factors such as elevated blood sugar  blood pressure  and smoking cessation; and revascularization therapy to restore the blood supply to the affected limb.   Slide 9: Conclusion CLI is a severe condition that can lead to amputation or death if not appropriately treated. It emphasizes the importance for clinicians to watch for signs of lower extremity arterial disease closely in all patients  particularly in those who have risk factors.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: ""Critical Limb Ischemia - A Case Study""  Slide 2: Patient Background - Age: 68 years - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired school teacher - Race: Caucasian - Location: Kansas  USA  Slide 3: Past Medical History - History of smoking (stopped 10 years ago) - Diagnosed with Type II Diabetes 15 years ago (managed) - Previous occurrences of intermittent claudication - 2 years ago  diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD)  Slide 4: Presenting Complaint Patient presented with severe pain in the right lower leg. The pain has been increasing over the last month  interfering with daily activities and sleep.  Slide 5: Symptoms - Rest pain in the right leg  especially at night or when the leg is elevated - Non-healing wound on right foot - Noticeable decrease in temperature of the right lower limb compared to the left - No palpable pulses in the right leg  Slide 6: Clinical diagnosis  Symptoms and indications are consistent with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Slide 7: Investigations - Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) - Doppler Ultrasound - CT Angiography - Blood tests to assess kidney function and coagulation status  Slide 8: Diagnosis Confirmation Tests confirm diagnosis of critical limb ischemia secondary to severe peripheral artery disease.  Slide 9: Management Plan Patient will need vascular intervention  which may include angioplasty  stenting  or bypass surgery  and will be referred to a vascular surgeon. Controlling diabetes  pain management  and wound care will also be vital parts of the treatment plan.  Slide 10: Conclusion Critical limb Ischemia is a severe form of PAD  often associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent limb loss. This case emphasizes the importance of considering CLI in patients with PAD who present with rest pain  a non-healing wound  or gangrene.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Study   Description: This presentation will outline the case of a patient diagnosed with critical limb ischemia. We'll discuss the demographics  past medical history  symptoms  diagnosis process and management strategies used to treat this condition.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics   Title: Patient Information  Description: The patient under discussion is a 67-year-old African American male  a retiree and residing in Boston  Massachusetts. The patient lives with his spouse; has limited mobility due to underlying issues; however  he is quite active within his home.  Slide 3: Patient Medical History  Title: Past Medical History  Description: The patient has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  Moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  and Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD). He has been receiving medications such as metformin for diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension  and he has a 30-pack-year smoking history.  Slide 4: Current Situation  Title: Presenting Symptoms and Diagnosis  Description: The patient presented with excruciating pain in his right lower limb despite being at rest. There was also an observable ulcer formation on his right foot. He reported that the pain worsened especially at night. Upon clinical examination and Ankle-Brachial Index test  critical limb ischemia was suspected which was later confirmed by an angiography.  Slide 5: Critical Limb Ischemia   Title: Understanding Critical Limb Ischemia   Description: Critical limb ischemia is a severe condition characterized by chronic ischemic rest pain  ulcers  or gangrene in the limb due to arterial insufficiency. Our patient’s diabetes and long-standing smoking habit worse his PAD  leading to this condition.  Slide 6: Treatment and Prognosis   Title: Management Plan  Description: The primary goal is to relieve pain  heal the ulcer  and prevent limb loss. The patient has been recommended for revascularization through angioplasty. He has been referred to dietary counseling for proper diabetes management. Smoking cessation counseling has also been set-up.  Slide 7: Conclusion   Title: Patient-Centric Approach   Description: With early detection and a patient-centered approach  the prognosis of critical limb ischemia can be greatly improved. Close monitoring and active participation of the patient in his care plan will also be key in managing the ischemic limb and the underlying conditions.   Slide 8: Questions   Title: Open for Discussion  Description: We can now open the floor to questions  insights  and further discussion about the case and critical limb ischemia in general.

Title: A Case Study of a Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction - Presenting a case of Mr. X  a 65-year-old African American male diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Slide 2: Demographics - Patient: Mr. X  65 years old  African American male. - Occupation: Retired engineer. - Residential Location: Suburban region in North Carolina.  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 15 years ago. - History of Hypertension for the last 10 years  on medication. - Previous smoker  quit 12 years ago. - Documented history of peripheral artery disease (PAD).  Slide 4: Current Clinical Symptoms - Mr. X presents severe pain in his right leg; worse at night  impairs his sleep. - Ulcers present on his right foot  slow to heal. - The right foot is observed to be cooler than the rest of the body. - Decreased pulse in the right leg.  Slide 5: Diagnosis - The patient's symptoms  history of diabetes  hypertension  and PAD  combined with physical examination and duplex ultrasound findings  lead to the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia.  Slide 6: Treatment Plan - Angioplasty for the revascularization of the ischemic leg. - Anticoagulant therapy to prevent the formation of blood clots. - Pain management with medications including NSAIDs  and opioids if necessary. - Optimal control of diabetes and hypertension. - Comprehensive wound care for the foot ulcers.  Slide 7: Prognosis and Follow-up - Continuous lifestyle modification advice provided  focusing on nutrition and exercise. - Strict follow-up checks for vascular assessment  diabetes  and hypertension control. - Regular foot care and education to avoid the risk of amputation. - Multidisciplinary approach involving the patient  family  podiatrist  nursing staff  and vascular team for the best outcomes.   Slide 8: Conclusion - This case emphasizes the importance of early detection  management  and appropriate treatment of CLI  particularly in patients with comorbidities such as diabetes and hypertension.

Title: Management of Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction Critical limb ischemia (CLI) is a severe peripheral artery disease where the blood flow in the arteries is severely reduced. It is often characterized by chronic ischemic rest pain  ulcers  or gangrene in one or both legs attributable to objectively proven arterial occlusive disease.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Our patient is a 65-year-old African American male  retired truck driver  a smoker with a history of hypertension and diabetes for the past ten years.  Slide 3: Presenting Complaint The patient presents with severe pain in his right leg  particularly at rest  and a non-healing ulcer on his right foot that has been present for the past three months.   Slide 4: Past Medical History Patient has had a 10-year history of poorly managed type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He quit smoking five years ago but smoked two packs per day for nearly 25 years. No known allergies or drug intolerances.  Slide 5: Clinical Examination  Patient's right foot is cold to the touch with a noticeable difference compared to the left foot. Visible ulcer on the right foot with darkened skin around the wound. Pedal pulses were weakly palpable.  Slide 6: Further Investigations - Ankle-brachial pressure index: Found to be lower than 0.4  corroborating the diagnosis of CLI. - Doppler Ultrasound: Revealed significantly decreased blood flow in the right lower limb. - Blood Tests: Revealed poorly controlled diabetes and raised cholesterol levels.  Slide 7: Diagnosis Based on the clinical presentation  history  and the investigations  the patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia  possibly due to diabetic peripheral arterial disease.  Slide 8: Treatment Plan The treatment plan includes: - Aggressive control of existing risk factors i.e.  blood glucose  blood pressure  and cholesterol. - Revascularization procedure (angioplasty or bypass surgery) considered due to the severity of symptoms and risk of limb loss. - Pain management and wound care are also integral to the treatment plan to avoid infection.  Slide 9: Prognosis and Follow Up The prognosis of Critical Limb Ischemia is variable depending on control of risk factors  success of revascularization  and patient compliance to treatment and lifestyle changes. The patient will require regular follow ups to monitor his wound healing  pain  and overall improvement.  Slide 10: Conclusion Early diagnosis  control of risk factors  and aggressive initial treatment are crucial in managing CLI to avoid limb loss and improve quality of life for the patient.                  Questions and Discussion.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in an Elderly Male Patient  Slide 1: Introduction Critical Limic Ischemia (CLI) is a severe obstruction of the arteries that significantly reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and even skin ulcers or sores.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Patient X is a 75-year-old African-American male  retired mechanic  currently residing in an assisted living facility. He is a non-smoker  moderate drinker  with a reported inconsistent diet. He presented with complaints of severe pain in his right lower leg and foot.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Patient X has a past medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD). The patient underwent bypass grafting for the left leg due to PAD 5 years ago.  Slide 4: Recent Symptoms Over the past week  Patient X reported worsening pain in his right foot  particularly at rest. There has also been the development of a non-healing ulcer on his right big toe. The pain has been increasing  disturbing his sleep and affecting his mobility.  Slide 5: Physical Examination Upon examination  the right foot was noted to be cooler than the left. Pulses in the right foot were not palpable. A non-healing ulcer measuring 2cm x 2cm was observed on the dorsal aspect of the right big toe.  Slide 6: Diagnosis  Based on symptom presentation and clinical findings  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) in his right lower leg was made. The diagnosis was further confirmed with ankle-brachial index testing and Doppler ultrasound which showed significantly reduced perfusion to the right lower extremity.  Slide 7: Management and Treatment Plan The treatment plan includes optimizing medical therapy for PAD  particularly glycemic control for his diabetes and antihypertensive therapy. Patient X was also referred to Vascular surgery for consideration of revascularization options  either endovascular intervention or bypass surgery  needed to restore adequate limb perfusion.  Slide 8: Conclusion  Patient X’s case underscores the critical importance of early detection and appropriate management of PAD in high-risk populations like elderly  diabetic  hypertensive patients to prevent dire consequences such as CLI. It is essential that clinicians provide aggressive intervention  combined with optimization of risk factors  to improve outcomes in these patients.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Presentation  Slide 1: Introduction   Critical limb ischemia (CLI) represents the most advanced stage of peripheral artery disease  characterized by chronic pain at rest  non-healing wounds  and gangrene. Today  we will look into a patient's case diagnosed with this condition.   Slide 2:  Demographics  Our case involves a 68-year-old male patient from an African-American background. He's a retired construction worker being a lifetime non-smoker and an occasional alcohol drinker.   Slide 3:  Presenting Complaints  The patient was presented with intensifying rest pain in his right leg  especially severe at night. He also reported a non-healing wound on the right foot  which is persistent for the last two months.   Slide 4: Past Medical History & Concurrent Diseases  The patient was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 16 years ago  which is currently poorly controlled. He also suffers from hypertension and high cholesterol levels. History of myocardial infarction about five years ago was also observed.  Slide 5: Medications   The patient is on Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for managing cholesterol levels. He was also on daily low-dose aspirin therapy following his myocardial infarction.  Slide 6: Examination & Investigation  Upon physical examination  there was notably diminished sensation in the right lower limb. The skin was cold to touch with absent peripheral pulses. Doppler ultrasound confirmed reduced blood flow.   Slide 7: Diagnosis  Given the chronic rest pain  non-healing wound  and the results of physical examination and ultrasound scan  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia in the context of peripheral artery disease was reached.  Slide 8: Treatment & Prognosis   The patient was scheduled for angioplasty for revascularization. Alongside  medical drug therapy was optimized  and he was referred to a dietitian for better glycemic control. Early recognition and treatment can prevent major amputations and improve overall quality of life.  Slide 9: Conclusion  This case highlights the importance of early detection and proactive management of underlying comorbid conditions in patients with critical limb ischemia. Further  it reinforces the need for effective patient education about disease management and lifestyle modifications. ------------------------------------- Please note this is a fictitious case created for the purpose of this request.

Title: A Case Study Presentation on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction  Patient X  a 68-year-old male  presents with a case of critical limb ischemia (CLI).   Slide 2: Demographics He hails from an urban setting  has a history of smoking (~30 years)  and moderately heavy alcohol use. Mr. X is a retired blue-collar worker and lives alone  though he has a supportive community surrounding him.  Slide 3: Past Medical History His medical past is significant  with a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 15 years and diagnosed hypertension for the past 10 years. No history of heart disease  but he suffered a minor stroke 2 years ago with no residual deficits.  Slide 4: Recent Developments  Recently  he has complained of severe pain in his right leg  especially on movement  with intermittent claudication that initially began a year prior but has since escalated in intensity.  Slide 5: Physical Examination Upon examination  noticeable was an absent popliteal pulse in the right leg. The limb was cold to touch  pallor on elevation and dependent rubor were observed. There were noticeable ulcers over the leg suggestive of long-standing ischemia.  Slide 6: Diagnostic Evaluation  He was subjected to Ankle-Brachial Index  which revealed a value less than 0.4 on the affected side. On further evaluation via Duplex Ultrasonography  significant arterial blockages were noticed.   Slide 7: Treatment Initiation After evaluation  a decision was made to initiate medical therapy while weighing revascularization options. He was started on antiplatelet drugs  statins  and pain management measures.   Slide 8: Conclusion  CLI presents a serious challenge  risking limb loss and negatively affecting the quality of life. Given the early presentation in our patient  favorable outcomes can be anticipated with immediate medical intervention and long-term management.   Slide 9: Future Implications This case highlights the importance of early detection and intervention in CLI  especially in high-risk populations with multiple comorbidities. Patient education on the complications linked with diabetes and hypertension and promotion of a healthy lifestyle form an integral part of effective disease management.

Title: A Case Presentation on Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Slide 1: Introduction  Objective: To examine the case of a patient diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia.  Slide 2: Demographics  Patient Profile: Mr. X  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  non-smoker  presented to the clinic with significant discomfort in his left lower extremity.  Slide 3: Chief Complaint  Mr. X reported intense  recurrent pain in his left leg  especially at night  causing severe sleep disturbances. He complains of rest pain localized to the foot and calf  and profound difficulties with ambulation.  Slide 4: Past Medical History  In Mr. X's medical history  he has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years. He also reports intermittent claudication over the past two years with declining control. Mr. X is being treated for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has no known drug allergies.  Slide 5: Physical Examination  Upon examination  there were noticeable temperature differences between the affected limb and the healthy right limb. The left foot was pale  with observable hair loss  and delayed capillary refill. A distal pulse in the left limb wasn't palpable  but there was a barely detectable femoral pulse.   Slide 6: Diagnostic Results  After performing Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) and Doppler ultrasound  Mr. X showed a reduced ABI ratio on the left leg  indicating severe arterial blockage. His ultrasound results confirmed lower extremity vascular occlusive disease.   Slide 7: Prognosis & Management  CLI is a severe condition with high morbidity and mortality rates. This case needs prompt medical attention  managing underlying conditions  and possibly interventional procedures.   Slide 8: Conclusion  Medicine is coordinated under the guidance of a multidisciplinary team. The primary goals are relieving rest pain  healing ulcers  preventing limb loss  improving functional status  and patient's quality of life. Periodic monitoring and patient adherence to medication and a healthy lifestyle are crucial to managing this condition.   Slide 9: Questions & Answers  Open for questions and discussions.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Study  Slide 1: Demographic Information Here we present the case of John  a 68-year-old African American male. John is retired and living with his wife in a suburban community. He has a history of smoking for 35 years but quit smoking 10 years ago.   Slide 2: Past Medical History John has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes for 20 years and has been managing it with medications. He also has a history of hypertension and has been taking antihypertensives for 15 years. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago. He is overweight with a BMI of 32 and has difficulty walking due to severe osteoarthritis in his knees.  Slide 3: Presenting Symptom John was first presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe rest pain in the right lower leg which has grown increasingly worse over the past 6 months  and he has noted a non-healing ulcer on his right foot.  Slide 4: Clinical Examination Upon physical examination  his right foot appeared pale with poor hair growth and brittle nails. Notably  no palpable pulses were found in the right lower limb. The ulcer spotted is about 4cm in diameter  located on the plantar surface of his foot.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Tests John underwent several diagnostic tests including an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) which reveals a score of less than 0.40; suggesting severe arterial disease. Doppler ultrasound identified significant stenosis of the right lower extremity arteries.  Slide 6: Diagnosis and Management John was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI). Management of John's condition begins with aggressive risk factor modification including optimal control of his diabetes and hypertension. He was also advised on weight management and provided with resources to help maintain a healthy lifestyle.  Slide 7: Intervention John underwent revascularization to restore the blood flow in his right leg. Additionally  regular dressings were initiated for his ulcer. Follow-up appointments were scheduled for monitoring healing progress and response to treatment.  Slide 8: Discussion In conclusion  critical limb ischemia is a severe condition that needs urgent attention. Risk factors such as smoking  obesity  diabetes  and hypertension should be well-managed to prevent the progression to CLI. Early detection remains crucial for the best patient outcome.  Slide 9: References (Include relevant references here)  Slide 10: Questions Open the floor to questions.

Title: Case Presentation: Critical Limb Ischemia   Slide 1: Patient Demographics  - Patient X  65-year-old Caucasian male. - Occupation: Retired teacher. - Social History: Non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumption.  Slide 2: Chief Complaint  - Patient presents with continuous rest pain in the lower left extremity spreading below the knee  associated with non-healing wounds on the foot.  Slide 3: Past Medical History   - Previous Hypertension  - Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the last 10 years  poorly controlled. - History of Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) for 5 years - Previous myocardial infarction 2 years ago. - No known allergies.  Slide 4: Vitals  - Blood pressure: 155/90 mmHg  - Pulse rate: 85 bpm  - Respiratory Rate: 18 breaths/min - Temperature: 98.6°F - Oxygen saturation: 94% on room air.  Slide 5: Physical Examination   - General appearance: Appears weak and anxious. - Lower limbs: Pale  cold left lower limb with noticeable muscle atrophy. Non-healing ulcers noted on left foot. - Cardiovascular: Regular rhythm and no murmurs noted. - Respiratory: Clear bilateral air entry with no added sounds. - No neurological deficit.  Slide 6: Investigation Findings  - CBC: Hb 12.5 g/dl  TLC: 7500/cc (normal)  Platelets: 150000/cc (normal). - Blood Sugar fasting: 160 mg/dl  PP 250mg/dl. - Lipid profile: Elevated LDL  normal HDL and triglycerides. - Doppler ultrasound: Significant decreases in blood flow to the left lower extremity. - Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI): Left: 0.40 (severe blockage)  Right: 0.9(normal)  Slide 7: Diagnosis   - Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) secondary to uncontrolled Diabetes and PAD.  Slide 8: Treatment & Recommendations  - Antiplatelet and statin therapy. - Diabetes and hypertension control. - Vascular consult for possible revascularization approaches. - Local wound care. - Pain management and lifestyle modifications. - Follow-up after two weeks or as needed.  Slide 9: Conclusion  - Patient with CLI requires an integrated vascular team care approach to address all the concurrent contributing factors. - Coordination with other healthcare providers is essential for effective management. - Proper adherence to medication and lifestyle modifications are key to prevent progression and complications. - Early intervention is essential in the management of CLI to prevent limb loss.

Title: A Comprehensive Study on Critical Limb Ischemia : A Patient Case  Slide 1: Introduction Patient Profile: Mr. Smith  a 65-year-old African-American male  with a history of heavy tobacco usage (40-pack years)  presented to the outpatient clinic complaining of severe pain in his right lower limb  primarily in the calf region. The pain had gradually increased in intensity over the six months prior to the visit. He also mentioned intermittent claudication and the feeling of coldness in the involved area  with visible skin discoloration.  Slide 2: Past Medical History Mr. Smith has a medical history significant for hypertension (controlled with ACE inhibitors)  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (sub-optimally controlled with Metformin) for 10 years  and he is a known case of established peripheral artery disease (PAD).  Slide 3: Symptoms & Signs Besides rest pain  Mr. Smith's ischemic rest pain was mainly persistent at night  alleviated by hanging the lower limb in a dependent position. Physical examination revealed weak peripheral pulses  trophic changes in the form of hair loss  and dry shininess of skin - suggestive of severe limb ischemia.  Slide 4: Diagnostic Evaluation We conducted an ankle-brachial index (ABI) which showed a result of < 0.4. Duplex ultrasonography demonstrated significantly decreased blood flow in the right lower limb. A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed multiple significant stenoses in the femoro-popliteal and infra-popliteal vessels.  Slide 5: Diagnosis Based on the suggestive clinical history  physical signs  and supportive investigations  a clear diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made in Mr. Smith's case.  Slide 6: Treatment & Management Initial management involved optimizing his medical treatment  including better glycemic control  tobacco cessation  and improving his antihypertensive therapy. After careful consideration  Mr. Smith underwent successful infra-popliteal bypass surgery and is currently undergoing a rehabilitation program.  Slide 7: Conclusion This case highlights the importance of early recognition of symptoms of CLI in patients with significant risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  and smoking. Early intervention can help prevent the progression of the disease  potentially avoid limb amputation  and improve the quality of life.   Slide 8: Discussions & Recommendations It's essential to educate the patients about the risk factors and early symptoms  encourage them to lead a healthy lifestyle  and ensure regular follow-ups for the at-risk population.   Slide 9: Q&A Discussion with the audience about any questions or comments regarding the presentation.

Title: Case Study: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 65-year-old Male Patient   Slide 1: Introduction - Subject: 65-year-old African American male referred to us for evaluation and management of critical limb ischemia. - History: Retired construction worker  lived with wife in urban environment  smoker for the last 40 years.  Slide 2: Chief Complaints - Main Complaint: Severe pain in the right leg at rest.  - Secondary Complaint: Non-healing wound on right foot.  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago  poor glycemic control. - Obesity: Body Mass Index (BMI) of 35.  - Hypertension for the past 10 years  controlled on medication. - History of transient ischemic attack (TIA) 3 years ago with no residual symptoms.  Slide 4: Clinical Evaluation - Physical Examination showed significant pallor and coolness of right foot  with poor popliteal and foot pulses.  - Observed non-healing ulceration on right forefoot with gangrenous changes. - Pain rating of 8/10 during rest  increasing with movement.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Investigations: - Duplex Ultrasound confirmed severe peripheral artery disease in right lower limb. - CT Angiography revealed extensive atherosclerotic lesions  especially in popliteal and foot arteries.  Slide 6: Hospital Course and Treatment - Patient hospitalized for management of critical limb ischemia  Intravenous antibiotics initiated for foot infection  and pain management started. - Consulted with vascular surgery for potential revascularization procedures. - Blood glucose managed with insulin; antihypertensive and antiplatelet therapies optimized. Introduced smoking cessation strategies.  Slide 7: Conclusion - Case underscores the significance of prompt diagnosis & comprehensive management of critical limb ischemia  including wound care  revascularization  strict glycemic control and lifestyle modification. - Reiterates importance of preventive care & early intervention in diabetics and smokers to reduce risks of peripheral arterial disease and associated complications.

Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction Critical limb ischemia (CLI) is a severe obstruction of the arteries which notably reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.  Slide 2: Patient Identification  Patient X is a 64-year-old African American male with a history of smoking and limited physical activity. He complains of severe pain in his left leg  noticeably increased during activities like walking or climbing stairs.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Patient X is diabetic for the last 20 years  controlled by insulin and diet. He also suffers from moderate hypertension for which he is on medications. The patient had a prior transient ischemic attack but no stroke. He has a history of hyperlipidemia as well.  Slide 4: Symptoms Patient X reports frequent cramping in the left calf and foot  even at rest  and has noticed a non-healing wound on his left foot. He reports a decrease in temperature in the left leg along with a noticeable pallor.   Slide 5: Diagnosis Considering his risk factors and symptoms  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia was made based on patient's information  physical examination and duplex ultrasonography confirming peripheral artery disease of the lower limb.  Slide 6: Treatment and Management The first line of treatment was to control risk factors  with optimization of his diabetic control and antihypertensive treatment  along with strong advice for smoking cessation. For pain management  analgesics were given.   Vascular intervention was planned for revascularization to save the limb and prevent amputation. The patient underwent an endovascular procedure with balloon angioplasty.  Slide 7: Follow-up and Prognosis The patient is scheduled for regular follow-up visits to monitor his symptoms and response to treatment. Medications for diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia were reviewed and adjusted. Smoking cessation support is continued.  Slide 8: Conclusion Early recognition of risk factors and symptoms of CLI  followed by prompt treatment  vastly improves the prognosis and reduces the risk of amputation or tragic consequences.  Slide 9: Questions and Discussion Invitation for queries  added insights  and a meaningful discussion regarding the case study.

Title: Case Presentation - Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Slide 1: Introduction  - Patient Demographics: Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents with complaints of rest pain in his right leg and numbness in his foot for several days. - Occupation: John is a retired veteran.   Slide 2: Past Medical History  - Hypertension diagnosed approximately 15 years ago. - Type II diabetes for the last 10 years  moderately controlled. - Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) from smoking history (35 pack years  quit 8 years ago). - No known allergies.  Slide 3: Review of Symptoms  - Persistent pain in the right calf  right heel  and foot  mostly during the night. - He also complains of numbness and coldness in the right foot. - Further  he reports a loss of appetite and recent unintentional weight loss.  Slide 4: Physical Examination  - Upon examination  his right foot was pale and cold to touch. - Reduced sensation and absent pulses (Posterior Tibial and Dorsalis Pedis). - Visible atrophy of calf muscles  no visible wounds  or blisters.  Slide 5: Diagnosis  - Given the history  present symptoms  and physical examination  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia on the right lower extremity  a severe presentation of peripheral arterial disease (PAD).  Slide 6: Investigation  - Doppler ultrasound revealed significantly reduced blood flow in right lower limbs. - Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was indicative of CLI (Value < 0.4) - Angiography demonstrated multi-segmental atherosclerotic occlusions in the distal right femoral artery and both popliteal and tibial arteries.  Slide 7: Management and Treatment  - According to TASC II guidelines regarding infra-inguis femoral disease  the patient was advised for revascularization. - Endovascular v/s Surgical intervention weighed considering patient's overall health status. - If unsuccessful  amputation may be considered to improve the quality of life.  Slide 8: Prognosis  - Early intervention could have a positive impact on maintaining quality of life  reducing symptom severity  and amputation avoidance. - However  long-term prognosis is generally poor due to the associated comorbidities and a late stage of the disease.    Slide 9: Conclusion  - Emphasize on regular follow-up and lipid profile monitoring. - Strict Glycemic & Blood pressure control with lifestyle modifications. - Continue with antiplatelet  statin  and pain medication as prescribed.   Slide 10: Lessons learnt from the case  - Timely diagnosis and management of CLI could prevent catastrophic results  like the need for amputation. - Importance of primary care management of chronic conditions like Diabetes and Hypertension to prevent cardiovascular complications.   Slide 11: Q&A  - Proceed with any questions.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Case Presentation: Critical Limb Ischemia Subtitle: A Comprehensive Review of Patient Symptoms  Treatment and Progress  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Title: Overview of patient’s demographic - Age: 58 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Taxi driver - Ethnicity: Hispanic - Smoking Status: Non-smoker - Alcohol: Moderate drinker   Slide 3: Past Medical History Title: Medical Background  - Diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 20 years - Managed with Metformin & Lifestyle Modifications - History of hypertension for 10 years - No known allergy to any medications or substances  - No previous surgeries  - Family history of cardiovascular disease  Slide 4: Current Symptoms  Title: Presenting Symptoms - Report of severe pain in lower legs especially during movement / walking  - Coldness and numbness in left foot - Skin discolouration – dark spots on left foot - Slow healing foot ulcer on left heel   Slide 5: Diagnosis Title: Diagnosis: Critical Limb Ischemia Through medical consultation and diagnostic tests (Blood tests  Doppler Ultrasound examination and Angiography)  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia has been made.  Slide 6: Treatment Plan Title: Initial Management Plan - Control risk factors: monitoring and managing diabetes and hypertension - Pharmacotherapy: Anti-platelet therapy and Pain management - Revascularization: Surgery or angioplasty - Wound care: Frequent dressing and possible debridement   Slide 7: Rehabilitation and Follow-Up Measures Title: Long-term Management and Follow Up - Monthly reviews to monitor wound healing and circulation status - Continued management of diabetes and hypertension - Lifestyle modifications: Diet and Exercise  smoking and alcohol cessation if applicable - Regular surveillance for early detection of re-occlusion   Slide 8: Conclusion Title: Conclusion Our goal is to achieve limb salvage  enhance wound healing  relieve ischemic pain  and ultimately improve our patient's quality of life. The multi-disciplinary approach with vigilant follow-ups will ensure optimal care for our patient with critical limb ischemia.   Slide 9: Q&A Title: Question & Answer Open floor for any queries  suggestions  or discussion points related to the presented case.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction - A study of a case involving a 68-year-old male diagnosed with critical limb ischemia which is the advanced stage of peripheral artery disease.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics and History - Name: Patient X - Age: 68 - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Patient X has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and has been a heavy smoker for over 40 years.  - Past surgical history includes appendectomy and gallbladder removal. - Patient X has been taking an ACE inhibitor for his hypertension  and metformin for his diabetes.  Slide 4: Current Presentation  - Patient X presents with severe pain in his left leg on walking short distances  which is getting progressively worse. The pain also often occurs at rest  particularly during the night.  - His left foot is noted to be pale and cold  with decreased pulse in the left pedal region.  Slide 5: Tentative Diagnosis - These symptoms and the patient’s history suggest he may be suffering from critical limb ischemia  the severe form of peripheral artery disease.  Slide 6: Diagnostic Tests  - The diagnosis can be confirmed by a series of tests including ankle-brachial index (ABI)  doppler ultrasound  angiogram  and CT or MRI scanning.  Slide 7: Anticipated Prognosis - This condition requires immediate attention. If left untreated  it may result in serious complications such as severe infection  non-healing ulcers  gangrene or may even need amputation.  Slide 8: Treatment Plan  - The treatment plan will aim to relieve the pain  heal the ulcers if any  prevent limb loss  and improve mobility. It may involve medications  angioplasty  stenting  or bypass surgery. - The patient will also be counseled to quit smoking and to control his diabetes and blood pressure effectively.   Slide 9: Conclusion - Early recognition  correct diagnosis  and immediate treatment of critical limb ischemia can significantly enhance the quality of life  avoid serious complications and limb amputation.  Slide 10: Queries? - Open for any questions and discussion.

Title: Case Study Presentation: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Slide 1: Introduction  Our patient today is a 72-year-old African-American male with a significant history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and high-grade peripheral artery disease (PAD).  Slide 2: Past Medical History  The patient was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type II 20 years ago; unfortunately  his diabetes has been poorly controlled. He was also diagnosed with peripheral artery disease 5 years ago. He has a history of smoking  though he quit 3 years ago. He has had prior minor toe amputation due to non-healing ulcers. His other past medical history comprises hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms He presented with ongoing sharp  shooting pain in his right lower extremity  particularly at rest  and with progressively worsening discoloration  coldness of the limb  and absent pulses in the right foot. He reported non-healing ulcers and gangrene on his toes.  Slide 4: Diagnosis Based on clinical evaluation  angiography  and non-invasive vascular studies  he was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  the most severe form of PAD.  Slide 5: Treatment The patient was offered revascularization procedures  including angioplasty and bypass grafts  to improve the blood flow. Additionally  he was prescribed pain management therapy  diligent wound care  medication regimens to control his diabetes  and advised on maintaining a healthy lifestyle.  Slide 6: Follow-up  Long-term monitoring is required due to the high risk of recurrence and cardiovascular events. Adequate glycemic and blood pressure control is essential  along with lifestyle modifications like regular exercise and a balanced diet. Regular podiatric assessments were also recommended.  Slide 7: Conclusion  This case illustrates the crucial role of early detection and management of diabetes mellitus and peripheral artery disease in preventing complications like critical limb ischemia. Patient education about lifestyle modifications and adherence to treatment plans is paramount in reducing morbidity and mortality.   Slide 8: Questions Open for any questions.

Title: A Case Presentation on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction  • Topic: Clinical Case Study of Critical Limb Ischemia • Objective: Understand the patient's condition and discuss potential treatment options.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  • Patient: Mr. Brown • Age: 70 years old • Gender: Male  • Occupation: Retired Engineer • Ethnicity: Caucasian  Slide 3: Past Medical History  • Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes 15 years ago • Long-term smoker  45 pack-years • Hypertension diagnosed ten years ago • Previous medical interventions: Appendectomy  cataract surgery • Current medications: Metformin  Lisinopril  Aspirin  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints  • Chronic  non-healing ulcer on the right lower limb  • Persistent muscular pain (claudication) in the right leg  • Reduced sensation in the right foot   Slide 5: Physical Examination Findings  • Weak peripheral pulses in the right lower extremity • Pallor of the right foot • Evident gangrenous changes in the toes • BMI borderline high: 26  Slide 6: Diagnostic Test Results  • Ankle-brachial index (ABI): right: 0.4  left: 0.9 • Doppler ultrasound: Reduced blood flow in right superficial femoral and popliteal arteries • CT angiography: Multifocal stenosis in lower limb arteries  Slide 7: Diagnosis: Critical Limb Ischemia  • Severe blockage in the arteries of the lower extremities  significantly reducing blood flow • Developed due to long-standing peripheral artery disease (PAD)  compounded by risk factors of diabetes and smoking  Slide 8: Treatment Plan  • Immediate revascularization - Angioplasty/stent or bypass graft • Rigorous control of blood glucose and blood pressure  • Smoking cessation • Aggressive wound care • Pain management  Slide 9: Prevention Measures  • Encourage regular exercise • Dietary adjustment for diabetes and weight control • Education about foot care and early detection of symptoms  Slide 10: Conclusion  • Critical Limb Ischemia  although severe  can be managed with a structured treatment plan. • Multidisciplinary approach for optimal care of the patient • The importance of preventive care & regular follow-ups.

Title: Management & Treatment of Critical Limic Ischaemia in an Elderly Patient  Slide 1: Patient Introduction We present a case of Mr. John Anderson  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  living in an urban area. He has been independently managing activities of daily living.  Slide 2: Previous Medical History Mr. Anderson's medical profile reveals a history of tobacco use - a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He has been suffering from diabetes mellitus for a decade  hypertension for 15 years and Dyslipidemia for the last 5 years. He underwent bypass surgery for coronary artery disease two years back.   Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms  The patient presented with severe  consistent pain in his right lower limb  persisting for the past week. The pain worsens during any physical activity and somewhat relieves on rest. He described it as a burning sensation accompanied with coldness and numbness.   Slide 4: Examination Findings Upon examination  the right limb appeared pale and cool  suggesting inadequate blood supply. Pulses in the right lower limb were also noted to be weak. There was no visible injury or trauma  but a non-healing wound on the right foot was spotted.   Slide 5: Diagnosis Considering the patient's severe continuous pain  clinical signs  and a history of peripheral vascular disease  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made. This was confirmed by an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test and Doppler ultrasound indicating advanced peripheral artery disease.  Slide 6: Management and Treatment Plan The treatment plan for Mr. Anderson primarily involves pain management and optimizing limb perfusion. Revascularization  through angioplasty or bypass surgery  will be the groundbreaking decision depending on the extent and location of the blockage. Alongside  he will be advised for strict blood sugar  cholesterol  and blood pressure control.  Slide 7: Patient Education Mr. Anderson will be educated about CLI  its causes  and consequences  the importance of medication adherence  lifestyle modification - including smoking cessation  maintaining a healthy diet  regular exercise  regular check-ups  wound care  and immediate consultation in case of any changes or progression of symptoms.   Slide 8: Conclusion This case serves as an important reminder of the significant burden of cardiovascular disease and peripheral vascular disease in the elderly  highlighting the necessity for appropriate diagnosis  timely treatment  and ongoing disease management to prevent severe complications such as limb loss.  Slide 9: Questions and Discussion Open for queries  sharing insights  discussing similar case experiences to enhance care for patients with CLI.

Title: A Case Presentation on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction - Definition: Critical limb ischemia (CLI) is a severe obstruction of the arteries which dramatically reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Patient: Mr. John Smith  60 years old  Male - Occupation: Retired engineer - Lifestyle: Moderate drinker  heavy smoker for 30 years - Ethnicity: Caucasian  Slide 3: Past Medical History -Mr. Smith has a notable medical history that includes:    - Hypertension diagnosed 8 years ago    - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago    - Dyslipidemia diagnosed 3 years ago - Unfortunately  Mr. Smith has been partially compliant with his prescribed medications.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms  - Mr. Smith presented with:    - Increasing pain in his right lower leg  worse on walking and at night.    - Sores on his right lower leg and foot that are not healing as usual.    - Noted a pale blue color of right foot and lower leg.     Slide 5: Relevant Investigations - Ankle-brachial index (ABI) confirmed a significant decrease in blood flow to the right leg. - Doppler ultrasound showed significant arterial stenosis in the right lower limb. - Blood tests indicated poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension.  Slide 6: Diagnosis and Prognosis - Based on Mr. Smith's symptoms and investigative findings  he was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia in the right leg. - In terms of prognosis  CLI is a serious condition which can potentially lead to an amputation if not managed effectively and promptly.  Slide 7: Management Plan - Mr. Smith’s immediate management involved aggressive risk factor control such as optimization of blood pressure and glucose levels  cessation of smoking  and a course of anti-platelet and statin therapy. - This was followed by revascularization procedures for the right lower limb with angioplasty. - Mr. Smith was also started on a comprehensive wound care program for his non-healing ulcers.  Slide 8: Patient Education & Follow-up - Patient education focused on lifestyle modifications  medication compliance  and early recognition of symptoms of disease progression. - A regular follow-up plan was established to monitor disease progression and the effectiveness of the treatment.    End of Presentation.

Title: A Case Study – Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Patient Introduction  Our case subject for today is Mr. X  a 68-year-old Caucasian male. He's a retired factory worker and has a past medical history of smoking  hypertension  elevated cholesterol levels  type 2 diabetes  and peripheral artery disease (PAD).  Slide 2: Initial Presentation  Mr. X first presented with severe pain in his right foot. The pain had been escalating over the past six weeks and was increasingly noticeable even when at rest or during the night. He mentioned it was effectively disturbing his sleep. He also reported noticing a wound on his right foot that has been slow in healing than normal.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Mr. X has been a smoker for 40 years and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hypertension 15 years ago  conditions for which he has been undergoing irregular treatment. He was diagnosed with Peripheral Artery Disease 3 years ago with symptoms primarily manifesting as intermittent claudication.  Slide 4: Clinical Examination & Diagnosis  Upon examination  his right foot was colder compared to the other & showed color changes. There was a noticeable absence of pulse and the presence of a non-healing ulcer on the foot. An Ankle Brachial Index (ABI) test along with Doppler ultrasonography confirmed the poor vascular circulation & reduced blood flow to the limb. Angiography further corroborated the diagnosis  highlighting significant blockages in the arterial supply to his right lower limb. This led to the diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Slide 5: Treatment & Management  The severity of his CLI necessitated a two-pronged approach: handling the present severe symptoms and managing the underlying disease processes. Initially  Mr. X underwent a successful angioplasty  which was aimed at re-establishing the blood flow. Post-procedure  he was prescribed anti-platelets and statins to further combat the PAD. Pain management was done with analgesics and efficiently controlled. Apart from this  his hypertension and diabetes were managed more stringently  and he was also put on a smoking cessation program.  Slide 6: Current Status and Prognosis  Three months post-treatment  Mr. X reports a significant reduction in pain and a healed foot ulcer. He’s managed to control his diabetes and hypertension more effectively and has made strides towards smoking cessation. The long-term prognosis is a function of the management of underlying health conditions.   Slide 7: Conclusion   This case illustrates the complex interplay between multiple comorbidities resulting in critical limb ischemia. Early identification  aggressive management of the causative factors  and timely intervention can drastically improve the outcomes and quality of life in individuals affected by CLI.

Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Patient Demographics - Age: 62 years old - Sex: Female - Ethnicity: African-American - Occupation: Retired Nurse - Residence: Suburban  Slide 2: Past Medical History - History of Diabetes Mellitus for 20 years  poorly regulated. - Hypertension for 15 years  under treatment. - Previous Smoking History- Quit 10 years ago  had a 30 pack-year smoking history before quitting. - Familial history of cardiovascular diseases. - Hyperlipidemia diagnosed 7 years ago. - Previous episode of a stroke with partial left-sided weakness  no residual deficits. - No known allergy history.
