Slide 1: Introduction Title: Case Presentation: A 65-Year-Old Female with Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 2: Demographics & Presenting Complaint  Patient information: The patient is a 65-year-old African-American female  retired nurse  who reported to the emergency department with increasing pain and discoloration in her left foot  existing for over a week.  Slide 3: Past Medical History The patient has a well-documented medical history  including hypertension for the last ten years and type 2 diabetes mellitus for about 15 years  both managed with medication. She also has a 20-year history of smoking  averaging 10 cigarettes per day. There's a known family history of peripheral artery disease in her brother.  Slide 4: History of Present Illness Approximately one week prior to presentation  the patient noticed ascending redness and swelling in her left foot. Her symptoms progressively worsened  associated with intense rest pain especially at night and non- healing wound over the dorsum of left foot.  Slide 5: Preliminary Examinations On physical examination  her left foot appeared with dark discoloration  particularly in the toes. Bite marks were visible on the dorsum. Pulses in the affected foot were absent while being present on the right foot.   Slide 6: Diagnostic Assessment  Investigations confirmed critical limb ischemia. The complete blood count  renal function  and electrolytes levels were within normal range. The Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) came out to be 0.4 for the left foot. Doppler ultrasound demonstrated poor blood flow in the left lower extremity. An angiogram exhibited a severe stenosis in the main artery of her left leg.  Slide 7: Management and Treatment  Primary management for the patient includes immediate revascularization to restore blood flow. However  due to her comorbidity  surgical bypass has significant risks.   Slide 8: Conclusion This case highlights the fact that Critical Limb Ischemia  although a common condition  can lead to severe consequences if not promptly diagnosed and treated. Risk factor management and early revascularization in appropriate patients should be the primary focus to prevent major amputations.   Slide 9: Questions? An opportunity for the audience to ask questions or share their experiences related to similar cases.

Title: A Case Presentation of Advanced Critical Limic Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction ------------------- - Age: 68 Years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired Mechanic - Residential status: Resides with wife in suburban neighbourhood  Slide 2: Presenting Complaints ------------------- - Patient presents complaining of intense pain in the right lower limb  especially during the night or while at rest - Experiences feelings of numbness and coldness in the mentioned limb - Difficulty in walking due to pain (intermittent claudication)  Slide 3: Past Medical History ------------------- - Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago - History of Hypertension for the past 7 years - Patient also has a history of smoking and is currently under a smoking cessation program  Slide 4: Recent Medical Interventions ------------------- - Regular administration of Metformin for diabetes management - Antihypertensive for blood pressure control - Maintained on statins for hyperlipidemia  Slide 5: Clinical Examination ------------------- - Examination reveals a weak pulse in the right femoral  popliteal and tibial arteries - Presence of non-healing ulcers on the foot - Suspected gangrene formation noted due to the discoloration of the toes  Slide 6: Diagnostic Considerations ------------------- - An angiogram was advised to visualize the blood flow  revealing significant blockages  - Doppler ultrasound to measure and compare the blood pressures in the limbs confirmed the reduced blood flow  Slide 7: Impression ------------------- Based on the patient's history  physical examination and diagnostic tests  he has been diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia  which is in an advanced stage.   Slide 8: Management Plan ------------------- - Immediate referrals made to a vascular surgeon for possible intervention - Intensified hypertension and diabetes control  including diet regulation - Smoking cessation support to be doubled - Wound care for non-healing ulcers commenced - Pain management plan put in place  Slide 9: Conclusion  ------------------- This case underlines the significance of early detection and intervention in cases of peripheral arterial disease  given its often irreversible progression to critical limb ischemia if left unchecked. Slide 1: Case Introduction Today  we are reviewing the case of a 65-year-old African American male who presented with symptoms of critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Slide 2: Demographics  The patient is a retired warehouse worker  a widower who lives alone  with a history of smoking for the past 45 years  consuming 1 pack per day. He consumes alcohol occasionally and has a diet consisting primarily of processed  fried  and high cholesterol food.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Our patient has a history of Type II diabetes mellitus and chronic hypertension  well-managed with medication. His previous records also indicate peripheral artery disease (PAD) diagnosed five years ago and was prescribed a regimen of aspirin and clopidogrel. There were irregular follow-ups  suggestive of inconsistent medication adherence.  Slide 4: Presenting Concern  Currently  the patient reports progressive rest pain in his right lower limb over the past month  affecting his sleep. He also mentions a non-healing ulcer on his right heel for eight weeks.  Slide 5: Examination  Physical examination revealed a cold right foot with no palpable pulse and a non-healing  necrotic ulcer at the heel. Slight blue discoloration in toes is evident.  Slide 6: Diagnosis  Given this history and examination  we can diagnose the patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  the severe stage of PAD where rest pain  non-healing ulcers  and gangrene are evident  threatening amputation if not treated promptly.  Slide 7: Next Steps The patient has been referred for immediate angiography to assess the extremity's vascular status. Additional tests will provide information for a potential revascularization procedure. Our discussions will also include cessation of smoking  strict diabetes control  and a healthier diet to mitigate further risks.   Slide 8: Conclusion  This case emphasizes the importance of proactive management and patient adherence in chronic conditions like PAD to prevent progression into CLI. Every medical professional must be vigilant to recognize the early signs of CLI for a timely intervention  potentially saving a limb and ensuring the patient's quality of life.

Title: Case Presentation on Critical Limb Ischemia   Slide 1: Introduction   Case is about Mr. Johnson  a 62-year-old African American male with a significant past medical history of critical limb ischemia.  Slide 2: Demographics  - Name: Mr. Johnson - Age: 62 - Sex: Male - Race: African American - Occupation: Retired civil engineer  Slide 3: Past Medical History   - Diabetes Mellitus Type II  diagnosed 12 years ago  under management with Metformin - Hypertension  for the last 10 years  under control with Lisinopril - Hyperlipidemia  first diagnosed 7 years ago  managed by Statins - Smoker  1 pack for the last 40 years - History of intermittent claudication for 6 years  Slide 4: Current Complaint  Presented with severe pain in his left lower limb  specially calf muscle  with noticeable changes in skin color and temperature to touch. The pain has been on and off but now has progressed to a more consistent and non-relieving one over the course of three weeks.   Slide 5: Physical Examination   - The left lower limb was pale  colder to touch as compared to the right lower limb - Reduced capillary refill time in left foot - Absent dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses in the left foot - Grade 3 ulcers present on the left heel and dorsum of the foot  Slide 6: Diagnosis and Management   Diagnosis was critical limb ischemia of the left lower limb  corroborated with Ankle-Brachial Index and color Doppler ultrasound. Recommended immediate intervention with angiography  possible angioplasty  and establish an aggressive regimen to manage his diabetes  hypertension  and cholesterol levels. Title: Case Presentation on Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Slide 1: Introduction CLI is a severe obstruction of the arteries  seriously decreasing blood flow to the extremities.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Patient X  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  who has been smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for the last 35 years  active alcohol consumption.  Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms Complaining of rest pain  non-healing ulcers on left lower extremity  and gangrene in foot. Reported significant weight loss in the past six months.  Slide 4: Past Medical History 1. Long history of type 2 diabetes poorly controlled with insulin injection 2. Hypertension managed with HCTZ 3. Peripheral artery disease (PAD)  diagnosed 5 years ago 4. Former asbestos exposure  Slide 5: Physical Examination On examination  grossly necrotic lesions  non-palpable pedal pulses  brawny discoloration on the left lower extremity  peak systolic leg/brachial index of 0.4  indicative of severe arterial insufficiency.  Slide 6: Diagnostic Workups Ordered duplex ultrasound  CT angiography and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA)  and ABI (Ankle-Brachial Index) test for greater clarity on the extent and severity of the condition.  Slide 7: Diagnosis Confirmed CLI as final diagnosis based on clinical history and examination  coupled with imaging reports that revealed severe stenosis in the left leg arteries.  Slide 8: Treatment and Management Plan to initiate conservative management with strict glycemic control  hypertension  and cholesterol management  smoking cessation. As the condition escalated  angioplasty + stenting  and revascularization surgery was planned  debridement of necrotic tissues and antibiotic therapy to combat infection  pain management.   Slide 9: Prognosis and Conclusion CLI is associated with high rates of limb amputation and cardiovascular mortality. In our patient  the presence of diabetes will make wound healing difficult. Highlighting the importance of preventing risk factors  proper diagnosis  and timely treatment for CLI.

Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia   I. Introduction  Let's discuss the case of a patient diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe obstruction of the arteries that significantly impairs blood flow into the hands  feet  and legs and can occasionally affect the arms.  II. Demographics  Our patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female with a considerable background in smoking and a sedentary lifestyle. She hails from a low socio-economic background and has been accessing public health facilities for her primary healthcare.   III. Past Medical History  This patient has a known history of high-risk factors contributing to CLI which includes the following:  1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 10 years ago  her recent HbA1C level was 8.5%  suggesting poor glycemic control. 2. Hypertension: Under control with amlodipine 5mg once daily. She was diagnosed 15 years ago. 3. Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 5 years ago  under control with simvastatin.  4. Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD): Diagnosed 3 years ago  our patient has been monitored for warning signs of progressive disease.  IV. Presenting Complaints  She presented with complaints of rest pain in her right leg  ulcers in her right foot  and significant difficulty in walking due to the pain -- all indicative symptoms of CLI.  V. Conclusion  To summarize  our patient’s past medical history of long-standing diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and PAD  along with her lifestyle risk factors such as smoking  makes her risk profile for CLI considerably high. Addressing these through medical intervention and lifestyle modifications is crucial in managing her condition and preventing severe consequences  such as amputation.  End of Presentation.

Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Slide 1: Introduction - Name: John Doe - Age: 68 years old - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired engineer  Slide 2: Past Medical History - Hypertension for the last 20 years. - Non-insulin dependent Diabetes Mellitus for the last 10 years. - Smoker  having smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 50 years. Title: A Clinical Case Study of Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction  - Patient Profile     - Age: 73 years old     - Gender: Male     - Occupation: Retired Naval officer     - Ethnicity/Race: Caucasian  Slide 2: Past Medical History  - Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 20 years ago - Hypertension - Dyslipidemia - Coronary artery disease with PCI (Percutaneous Coronary Intervention) done ten years ago - Family history of cardiovascular diseases - Smoker for 50 years  20 cigarettes a day until 3 years ago  Slide 3: Recent Health Issues - Persistent non-healing wound on the right foot for 2 months - Increasing bilateral leg pain while walking  gradually worsening over the past 6 months - Foot pain worsens at night and relieved slightly by hanging legs off the side of the bed. **Slide 1: Introduction** Title: Case Study: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)   **Slide 2: Patient Demographics**  Our patient  Mr. X  is a 72-year-old African American male with symptoms suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia. He is retired and lives with his wife in the suburban areas.   **Slide 3: Medical History**  Mr. X has been managing Type II diabetes for the past 10 years  and Hypertension for the last 8 years. He has also been diagnosed with Hyperlipidemia. He has a prior history of peripheral artery disease(PAD) diagnosed 5 years ago  for which he underwent bilateral lower extremity angioplasty. Mr. X has a 30 pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago.   **Slide 4: Presenting Complaints**  Mr. X reported severe pain persisting in his right foot at rest  which intensified over the past few weeks. He mentions difficulty in walking due to the pain and has also noticed a certain amount of skin discoloration in the leg.  **Slide 5: Clinical Examination**  Upon examination  Mr. X's right foot appeared pallorous with evident skin discoloration. Pedal pulses were markedly diminished. Temperature was reduced compared to the left foot  suggesting poor perfusion.  **Slide 6: Radiological Evidence**  His angiogram demonstrated multiple segment stenosis and occlusion in his right lower extremity arteries  indicative of severe PAD  which is in line with his symptoms.  **Slide 7: Diagnosis**  Given the clinical presentation along with radiological findings and his history of both diabetes and PAD  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia was made.  **Slide 8: Treatment**  Mr. X was immediately started on anticoagulants and a cholesterol-lowering agent. An endovascular procedure was planned to restore the blood flow to the affected limb.  **Slide 9: Management**  The management of Mr. X involves a multidisciplinary team. His condition will be monitored closely with regular follow-ups  including physiotherapy and rehabilitation  nutritional advice  vigilant foot care  and suitable lifestyle modifications.     **Slide 10: Conclusion**  Early identification and treatment of CLI are key to prevent irreversible damages. Providing patient education on disease risk factors and the importance of adhering to prescribed treatments is crucial to achieve optimal outcomes.

Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction Critical limb ischemia (CLI) is a severe obstruction of the arteries often attributed to peripheral artery disease. It markedly reduces blood flow to the extremities  often leading to severe pain  skin ulcers  gangrene  and increased risk of amputation.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  We present the case of a 68-year-old African American male  retired coal miner  a lifetime non-smoker residing in an urban setting.   Slide 3: Past Medical History  The patient has a history of poorly controlled Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 25 years  uncontrolled hypertension for 10 years  and diagnosed hyperlipidemia. Has a family history of cardiovascular diseases but no known genetic disorders.  Slide 4: Clinical Presentation  The patient presented with unhealed ulcers on his right foot  severe pain in the lower legs even at rest  and notable muscle atrophy in the affected limb. The extremity shows color changes and reduced temperature indicative of reduced blood flow.   Slide 5: Diagnosis  Comprehensive vascular examination and non-invasive vascular studies were performed showing reduced arterial pressure and poor blood flow in the right limb. Further confirmed by angiography showing multiple occlusions in the arteries of the lower limb accounts for the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia.  Slide 6: Management Plan  The case required aggressive control of the patient's diabetes and hypertension. Revascularization was attempted via angioplasty  atherectomy  and stent placement to improve blood flow. Secondary preventive measures are also implemented including smoking cessation  diet regulation  and medications like antiplatelets and statins thereby preventing disease progression.   Slide 7: Prognosis  The prognosis of CLI primarily depends on successful revascularization and management of the systemic disease. Therefore  patient compliance  follow-up visits and continued disease management were emphasized to him.    Slide 8: Conclusion By learning from this case  it is hoped that healthcare professionals can better identify symptoms of CLI and promptly refer such patients for vascular assessment  thus preventing disease progression and improving patient outcomes.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia: A Patient Case Study  Slide 1 - Introduction - Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) refers to a severe obstruction of the arteries  dramatically reducing blood flow to the extremities - primarily legs and feet.  - The disease often leads to pain  skin ulcers  or gangrene.  - CLI is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention.  Slide 2 - Patient Demographics - Patient X is a 64-year-old African American male. - He is a retired construction worker and a smoker for 40+ years. - Patient lives in a rural area with limited immediate access to medical care.  Slide 3 - Previous Medical History - History of Type II diabetes and Hyperlipidemia. - Treated for peripheral artery disease (PAD) two years ago. - Frequently complains of lower back pain; uses NSAID painkillers regularly.  Slide 4 - Presenting Symptoms - Over the past six months  Patient X reports increasing leg pain while walking short distances.  - Recently  pain has been persistent even at rest  especially during night. - Notable loss of hair on both legs and feet. - Developed an unhealing wound on his right foot two weeks ago.  Slide 5 - Diagnosis - Diagnosis of CLI is suggested by characteristic symptoms and confirmed by Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test showing an ABI of less than 0.4. - Doppler ultrasound shows significant narrowing and blockages in the femoral and popliteal arteries. - No signs of distal pulses found in the physical examination.  Slide 6 - Treatment Strategy - Considering Patient X's severe symptoms and the presence of tissue loss  we prioritize revascularization. - The decision should be made between surgical and endovascular revascularization based on anatomy  patient's fitness for surgery  life expectancy  and patient preference. - Aggressive wound care  tight glucose control  cessation of smoking and regular follow-ups are strongly advised.   Slide 7 - Conclusion - CLI is a marker of systemic atherosclerosis and is associated with high rates of cardiovascular mortality. - Timely recognition and aggressive treatment can maximize limb salvage and improve patient's quality of life.  This presentation illustrates the imperative need for medical practitioners to maintain a high level of suspicion for CLI  especially in patients with known risk factors  in order to initiate early intervention.

Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction  - A 67-year-old African-American female presents herself to the hospital with severe rest pain in her left lower extremity.  - The pain has been persisting for the last 3 months.   Slide 2: Past Medical History  - The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago.  - She also has a history of hypertension and moderate atherosclerosis.  - She is a former smoker who quit five years back. - The patient is on Metformin  Lisinopril  and low-dose Aspirin as her regular medication regimen.  Slide 3: Present Complaints - The pain exacerbates mostly at night when she's off her feet and results in frequent sleep disturbance.  - She also complains of left foot discoloration and coldness.  - Her pain is uncontrollable  even with maximum doses of over-the-counter pain medication.   Slide 4: Examination and Diagnosis  - Clinical examination reveals pallor on elevation of the left foot. There are ulcerations noted on the tips of the left foot toes. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are absent on palpation. - The Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) is calculated at 0.4. An angiogram shows a multi-segmental  critical occlusion of the left lower limb's arteries. - Considering the above findings  the patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Slide 5: Treatment and Management - The patient was referred to a vascular surgeon for surgical revascularization. - Aggressive pain management was initiated with opioids. - Patient's diabetes management was also reassessed in light of her current health status.  Slide 6: Prognosis  - Early detection and treatment can significantly improve the patient’s quality of life. - Patient education regarding proper foot care and maintaining control of diabetes are pivotal in managing the condition and preventing complications.  Slide 7: Summary  - Critical Limb Ischemia  especially when associated with diabetes and atherosclerosis  is a serious condition that requires immediate attention. - This case underscores the importance of early detection  comprehensive evaluation  and aggressive management for preventing severe consequences like limb amputation or life-threatening infection.

**Slide 1: Introduction**  - Topic: Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Study  **Slide 2: Patient Demographics**  - Age: 62-year-old - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Hispanic - Occupation: Retired Construction Worker - Lifestyle: Moderate drinker  Non-smoker - Locale: Urban area  **Slide 3: Chief Complaint**  - Complaint: Severe pain in the right lower leg  even at rest  markedly increased compared to past months.   **Slide 4: Past Medical History**  - Diabetes Mellitus: Patient has been living with Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 28 years. - Hypertension: Patient under antihypertensive medication for the last 10 years. - Peripheral Arterial Disease diagnosed 5 years ago.  **Slide 5: Detailed History of Present Illness**  - The patient reports intense pain especially at night  when lying flat.  - The pain has escalated over the past few months.  - Physical Examinations showed cold  bluish foot with weak or no pulse.  **Slide 6: Diagnostic Tests**  - Ankle Brachial Index (ABI): ABI score of 0.4 (normal ABI score: 1.0 - 1.4) - Doppler Ultrasound: Significant stenosis of the arteries in the right leg - Computed Tomographic Angiography: Confirmed severe blockages in the blood vessels of the lower right leg.  **Slide 7: Diagnosis**  - The tests and symptoms indicate that the patient is suffering from Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe obstruction of the arteries in the lower extremities  which markedly reduces blood flow.   **Slide 8: Treatment plan**  - CLI is a serious condition often associated with underlying illnesses like diabetes.  - Early diagnosis and effective management  such as intense surveillance and intervention  are crucial to preserve the limb and improve quality of life.

Title: A Case Presentation on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Welcome  Welcome everyone. Today  we will discuss a case of a patient suffering from Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Slide 2: Overview  CLI is a severe obstruction of the arteries which reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.  Slide 3: Patient Demographics  Our subject is a 68-year-old African-American male  Mr. A  living in a suburban area. He's a retired engineer  married  father of two  and was a heavy smoker until 5 years ago.   Slide 4: Medical History  Mr. A suffers from Chronic Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD)  Hypertension  and Type II Diabetes. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease. His PAD was diagnosed about a decade ago.  Slide 5: Presenting Complaint  About 2 weeks ago  Mr. A started experiencing increased painful ulcers on both limbs  particularly on the right foot. The pain often intensifies during the night  leaving him restless. There's also notable skin discoloration on his toes and decreased temperature of his lower extremities.  Slide 6: Investigations and Diagnosis  Investigations show below-normal ankle-brachial index (ABI)  suggestive of severe disease. An angiogram revealed multilevel occlusive disease with poor infrapopliteal runoff. He was diagnosed as a case of CLI.  Slide 7: Management  The goal of management in Mr. A`s case includes improving functional status  healing the ulcers  preventing major amputation  and prolonging survival. He was recommended revascularization for limb salvage. Besides  controlling factors such as hypertension  hyperglycemia  and dyslipidemia  cessation of smoking  and exercise are crucial components of treatment.  Slide 8: Prognosis  As we know  critical limb ischemia can have a severe impact on lifestyle and longevity. With optimal management and lifestyle modifications  we aim to improve Mr. A's quality of life and limit disease progression.  Slide 9: Conclusion  This case aims to enhance your understanding of recognizing and managing CLI effectively. What seems like a simple symptom of pain can sometimes be an indicator of a severe underlying condition  such as CLI.  Slide 10:  Questions & Discussion  Let's open the floor for questions and a brief discussion.  [End of presentation]

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Case Presentation: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Slide 2: Demographics Patient X is a 69-year-old  African-American male. He is a retired factory worker with a moderate income. He is a current smoker and has a BMI of 28 indicating overweight. He lives with his wife and has two grown-up children.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Patient X has a significant medical history of Type II Diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past 15 years. He was also diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) 3 years ago. He has been on regular medication for all these conditions but admits inconsistency in medication adherence and lifestyle modifications.  Slide 4: Current Medical Issue The patient presented with severe rest pain in his right lower limb which had intensified over a week  along with skin discoloration and the development of non-healing ulcer over his right foot.   Slide 5: Diagnosis  Given the patient's history and presenting complaints  a working diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia was considered. This was later confirmed through an examination and diagnostic tests  including an Ankle-brachial Index (ABI) and Doppler ultrasound showing severely reduced blood flow.  Slide 6: Treatment Plan Immediately upon diagnosis  aggressive management was initiated to control pain and any concomitant infection present due to the non-healing ulcer. Long term management involves cessation of smoking  intensive lifestyle modifications  optimal control of diabetes and hypertension. Medical treatment includes anti-platelet drugs  Statins and Cilostazol. Revascularisation by endovascular intervention or bypass surgery is also considered to restore blood flow to the limb and prevent amputation.  Slide 7: Conclusion Critical Limb Ischemia is a serious condition that needs an aggressive and comprehensive approach to management to improve prognosis and quality of life. Patient X's case is a lesson in the importance of early detection and maintenance of chronic conditions like Diabetes and PAD.   Slide 8: Questions & Feedback Invitation to the audience to ask any questions and provide feedback about the presentation.

Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction  Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African American male  residing in New York City  employed as a retired police officer.   Slide 2: Past Medical History  Mr. Johnson has a significant past medical history marked by Type 2 Diabetes for the past 15 years  Stage Two Hypertension for 10 years  and Hypercholesterolemia for 12 years. He used to smoke for 25 years but quit smoking 15 years ago. There is no family history of cardiovascular disease.   Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms  Mr. Johnson presents severe pain in his right lower thigh  calf  and foot that started approximately four weeks ago. He experiences relief at rest but has difficulty walking. For the last week  the pain has started waking him up at night. Thorough examination revealed rest pain  non-healing sores  reduced mobility  and discoloration (pale/ bluish) in the right lower limb  suggesting severe symptoms of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Slide 4: Diagnosis and Assessment  A diagnosis of CLI was confirmed using Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test and Doppler ultrasound. Lower values indicated restricted blood flow. Blood tests indicated poor glycemic control and elevated cholesterol levels.  Slide 5: Treatment Plan  Intervention proposes a Corrective Revascularization Surgery as the first line of approach. Mr. Johnson’s diabetes and cholesterol levels should be meticulously controlled. The cessation of tobacco is advised to improve chances of surgical success and reduce risk of postoperative complications. Regular exercise or physiotherapy after surgery will be needed. Antithrombotic medications and statins will supplement the treatment.  Slide 6: Prognosis  Due to the severity of his condition  Mr. Johnson faces a high risk of amputation if unsuccessful in re-establishing blood flow. However  with successful revascularization and adherence to the treatment  he stands a reasonable chance of resuming normal life.  Slide 7: Discussion & Conclusion  This case underscores the high risk of CLI in individuals with uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension. This underscores the need for regular screening and monitoring for patients with similar backgrounds to ensure early diagnosis and intervention for CLI. Preventive measures like smoking cessation  increased physical activity  and a healthy diet can significantly curtail the risks of vascular disease in high-risk populations.

Title: A Case Presentation on Critical Limb Ischemia   Slide 1: Introduction ""Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) is a severe manifestation of peripheral arterial disease that contributes to the risk of limb loss and increased mortality rates. Today  we're studying a pertinent example that highlights its clinical significance.""  Slide 2: Patient's Demographics ""Mr. X is a 68-year-old African-American male  living in urban surroundings in Seattle. He has enjoyed a sedentary lifestyle for many years and has a history of smoking one pack/day for the past four decades.""  Slide 3: Presenting Complaint ""The patient came forward in the outpatient department with complaints of excruciating pain in his right leg  especially at night. The pain becomes non-existent when hanging the leg off the bed or standing. Mr. X also reported a non-healing wound on his right foot.""  Slide 4: Past Medical History ""Mr. X has a significant medical history of Type-II Diabetes Mellitus for the last 15 years  Hypertension for the past 10 years  and a previous history of intermittent claudication. Both the diabetes and hypertension have been poorly controlled.""  Slide 5: Physical Examination ""On examination  the right foot appeared colder than the left. Capillary refill was delayed. A non-healing ulcer was noted at the tip of the right big toe. An absence of both posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses was noted in the right leg.""  Slide 6: Diagnostic Outcome ""An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was carried out showing a result of less than 0.4 (indicative of Critical Limb Ischemia). Lower limb Doppler studies confirmed significant stenosis in right femoral  popliteal and tibial arteries.""  Slide 7: Management Plan ""Mr. X was immediately referred to the Vascular Surgery team for further evaluation. Pending further assessments  he was started on antiplatelet therapy  statins to control hyperlipidemia and aggressive control of his diabetes and hypertension was sought.""  Slide 8: Case Significance ""This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition of symptoms like rest pain and formation of non-healing wounds in patients with known risk factors. Early intervention in CLI cases like Mr. X may reduce the risk of limb amputations.""   Slide 9: Conclusion  ""CLI is a serious condition that requires immediate attention. As healthcare providers  awareness about the risk factors can help in the prompt diagnosis and treatment of this condition  thereby preventing consequences such as limb amputation & promoting better patient outcomes.""

Title: A Case Study of Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction  Patient Profile: Mr. Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and smoking  presents to the clinic complaining of severe pain in his left lower extremity. The pain is persistent even at rest  mostly occurring at night.  Slide 2: Past Medical History  Medical History: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years ago  for which he takes Metformin. He also takes daily Statins for hyperlipidemia diagnosed 8 years ago. Moreover  Mr. Smith has had a 40 pack-year smoking history  though he recently quit about 6 months ago.  Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms  Clinical Presentation: The patient reports left foot claudication  non-healing wounds on the left foot  and severe pain that disrupts his sleep - symptoms suggesting a chronic critical and worsening limb ischemia.  Slide 4: Examination Findings  Physical Examination: Objective findings reveal an absent popliteal and pedal pulse on the left. The examination also reveals pale coloration when the limb is elevated and hyperemia when dependent. There is also a noticeable coldness of the left foot compared to the right.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Approach  Investigations: This presentation necessitates an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) to evaluate the arterial sufficiency followed by Doppler Ultrasound  CT angiography  or MR angiography.  Slide 6: Discussion  Critical Limb Ischemia: Mr. Smith’s presentation is consistent with critical limb ischemia (CLI). CLI is a severe condition characterized by chronic ischemic rest pain  nonhealing wounds  or gangrene due to peripheral arterial disease.  Slide 7: Management and Prognosis  Treatment Plan: Mr. Smith's case involves managing risk factors  revascularization via endovascular techniques or bypass surgery  and possible limb amputation if there is extensive tissue loss. Additionally  attention to wound care and proper foot care is essential.  Slide 8: Conclusion  Conclusion: Early recognition and proactive strategies of CLI are crucial in preventing major amputations in patients. We strongly underline the significance of diabetes management  smoking cessation  and effective treatment of hyperlipidemia in such cases.   Slide 9: Further Research Directions  Research Directions: Further studies are needed to assess the effectiveness of various endovascular procedures and their optimal timing for critical limb ischemia patients.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Study   Slide 1: Introduction - Patient X is a 70-year-old male with a long history of smoking and uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Slide 2: Past Medical History - Patient has been battling uncontrolled diabetes for the past 20 years. - Chronic smoker with 40 pack-years history. Attempted quitting on numerous occasions with limited success. - History of hypertension and occasional chest pain – suggestive of possible cardiovascular disease. - Had a transient ischemic attack five years ago.   Slide 3: Presenting Complaints  - Patient reports experiencing severe pain in the right leg  especially while walking  over the last 2 months. - The pain began as mild discomfort but has progressively worsened over time.  - Rest pain present  meaning pain also experienced in rest or during sleep. - Wound on right foot with little to no healing seen  present for 4 weeks  suggestive of tissue necrosis.  Slide 4: Physical Examination  - Examination revealed a poorly healing ulcer on the right foot. - Diminished pulses confirmed in the right leg. - Patient's right foot was noticeably cooler than the left one. - Ankle-brachial index less than 0.4 showing critical ischemia. - Toes have a cyanotic appearance  suggesting severe oxygen depletion.    Slide 5: Diagnosis - Based on the patient's medical history  clinical symptoms  and physical examination findings  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was determined.  Slide 6: Treatment and Management Plan  - Multidisciplinary approach involving vascular surgeons  interventional cardiologists  endocrinologists  and a nursing team. - Management with anti-platelet medication and statins to control underlying atherosclerosis. - Consideration of revascularization through angioplasty or bypass surgery. - Wound care and possibly hyperbaric oxygen therapy for wound healing. - Blood glucose levels need stringent control and cessation of smoking is crucial.  Slide 7: Prognosis and Conclusion  - With timely diagnosis and appropriate interventional measures  the potential loss of the limb can be prevented. - Reduction of cardiovascular risk factors and lifestyle modifications will play an integral part in managing this condition.   Slide 8: Questions? - Open floor for any questions and further discussion.  End of Presentation

Ankle-brachial index (ABI) was 0.3 on the right side  suggesting severe perfusion problem.    Slide 5: Diagnosis  Given the patient’s symptoms  physical examination findings  and diagnostic results  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made.  Slide 6: Treatment and Follow-up  Patient was treated with revascularization surgery to restore blood flow  supplemented with aggressive wound management and optimal control of her diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. Patient showed significant improvement after treatment and will continue to be monitored for complications related to her condition.  Slide 7: Discussion and Learning Points CLI is emergent and requires immediate attention to prevent limb loss. Risk factors include smoking  diabetes  and other conditions that affect circulation. The case underscores the importance of early detection  prompt treatment  and management of underlying conditions.  Slide 8: Conclusion CLI is a severe condition requiring urgent medical attention to prevent severe complications such as limb amputation. It is essential to manage the risk factors and educate patients about the signs and symptoms for early detection and treatment.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Case Study of a Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Our subject is a 65-year-old Caucasian male. He has been a smoker for over 40 years and has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes and Hypertension  which are both under control with medication. He is retired and lives with his wife.  Slide 3: Previous Medical History The patient has had a history of peripheral artery disease which he was diagnosed with around ten years ago and has been on medication ever since. He also underwent angioplasty three years ago due to the severity of the disease.   Slide 4: Current Medical Issue Recently  he has been complaining about severe pain in his right leg that worsens when walking or climbing stairs  which affects his sleep and daily activities. He developed a non-healing ulcer on his right foot for the past two months.  Slide 5: Diagnosis Upon examination and relevant diagnostic tests  the patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI). This is the severe obstruction of the arteries which significantly reduces blood flow to the lower extremities and is characterized by rest pain  non-healing ulcers  and gangrene.  Slide 6: Treatment The patient underwent an endovascular procedure to improve the blood flow in his right leg  along with rigorous wound care for the foot ulcer. He was also advised to adopt a healthier lifestyle which includes quitting smoking and maintaining optimal control of blood sugar and blood pressure levels.  Slide 7: Prognosis and Future Recommendations Post-treatment  the patient saw significant improvement in his symptoms. Physicians expect a slow but steady recovery  given the patient's adherence to medical advice and lifestyle changes. This case underlines the importance of timely diagnosis and management of CLI to prevent major amputations  improve quality of life  and prolong survival.   Slide 8: Conclusion Through this case study  we can identify the importance of lifestyle and preventative health in managing diseases like CLI. It's critical to educate patients about the risk factors involved and the serious consequences of delayed treatment.

Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia   Slide 1: Introduction Patient: Mr. Lopez  a 67-year-old man.  Medical History: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hyperlipidemia  Smoking (quit 5 years ago) Presenting complaints: Constant  severe pain in the right foot which worsened over the past three weeks  ulcers on the foot which are not healing.  Slide 2: Past Medical History  1. Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago  irregularly takes prescribed medications. Last HbA1c  eight months ago -  9.0%. 2. Hyperlipidemia diagnosed 6 years ago  takes statins intermittently.  3. Smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for over 30 years but quit five years ago.  Slide 3: Current Issue  1. Mr. Lopez reports severe  agonizing pain in his right foot  persisting even at rest. 2. Noted to have non-healing ulcers on the dorsum of the foot. 3. He reports difficulty in walking due to severe pain and discomfort.  Slide 4: Clinical Examination Upon physical examination: 1. Threatened gangrene noted on toes. 2. Absent peripheral pulses in the lower extremity. 3. Reduced sensation along the affected foot. 4. Evidence of significant muscle atrophy and mild skin discoloration.  Slide 5: Diagnosis Given the history of diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia and a previous smoking habit along with the clinical findings of rest pain  non-healing foot ulcers  threatened gangrene  and absent peripheral pulses  Mr. Lopez was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Slide 6: Management  Immediate appropriate intervention can prevent amputation or limb loss. Options include: 1. Endovascular therapy (angioplasty  stenting) 2. Surgical bypass 3. Pharmacotherapy to address underlying disease (tight glucose control  lipid-lowering agents  antiplatelet) 4. Pain management 5. Wound care  minor amputations if necessary  Slide 7: Conclusion Critical Limb Ischemia is a severe form of peripheral artery disease  often associated with grave outcomes. Early recognition and comprehensive management are key to reduce morbidity and improve the quality of life. As healthcare professionals  promoting awareness about this condition and its correlation with modifiable risk factors like diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and smoking is crucial.

Title: Case Presentation: Understanding Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction - Definition of Critical Limb Ischemia: A severe form of Peripheral Arterial Disease marked by chronic ischemic rest pain  ulcers  and gangrene in the limbs caused by significant stenosis or obstruction of the arteries.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Person: Mrs. Green - Age: 70 years old - Gender: Female - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired schoolteacher  - Lifestyle: Sedentary  non-smoker  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago - History of Hypertension controlled with medication - History of Hyperlipidemia - Family history of Cardiovascular diseases - Underwent bilateral knee replacements five years ago  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints - New Onset of severe rest pain in her left foot  - Non-healing ulcers on her left foot - Noticed a decrease in temperature of her left foot compared to the right one   Slide 5: Investigations  - Ankle-brachial index test demonstrated a score of 0.4 (Severely abnormal) - Duplex Ultrasound showcased a doppler signal indicative of stenosis - CT Angiography pipe-lined occlusion seen in the left common iliac artery  - Foot biopsy of ulcer showed ischemic changes   Slide 6: Diagnosis - Based on the findings  Mrs. Green was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 7: Management and Treatment  - The approach is two-pronged which incorporates Medical and Interventional management - Medical management: Improved glycemic control  continuation of antihypertensive  and aggressive low-density lipoprotein (LDL) control  - Interventional: Revascularization via angioplasty  bypass surgery and in severe cases  amputation  Slide 8: Prevention - Rigorous control of blood sugar  blood pressure  cholesterol - Lifestyle modifications: Regular exercise  balanced diet - Cessation of tobacco if applicable  Slide 9: Conclusion - With proper management and lifestyle changes  there is a possibility for Mrs. Green to limit potential complications and achieve a better quality of life.  - Emphasis on the commonness of this condition in patients suffering from Diabetes Mellitus and how early detection can make a difference.

Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction This presentation outlines a case involving a 68-year-old African-American female in the context of critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Slide 2: Patient Background The patient is a retired school teacher. She is obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 34 kg/m2 and is a smoker with a 30-pack-year smoking history. She was previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and controlled hypertension. In addition  the patient has a family history of peripheral artery disease.  Slide 3: Present Illness The patient presented with a six-month history of worsening leg pain in her right lower extremity while walking which typically subsides with rest. Over the past month  she has been experiencing rest pain  particularly at night  and has noticed a non-healing ulcer on her right great toe.   Slide 4: Physical Examination Physical examination revealed a shallow  painful ulcer with dry gangrene on distal phalanx of the right great toe. Pulses in the right foot were diminished  and foot temperature was reduced compared to the contralateral limb.   Slide 5: Investigations & Diagnosis An Ankle-brachial index (ABI) showed readings of 0.5 on the right and 1.1 on the left. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed severe stenosis in the right femoral and popliteal arteries. These findings are consistent with critical limb ischemia  Rutherford Classification category 4.  Slide 6: Management The patient consented to revascularization therapy. A successful right femoropopliteal bypass was performed. In addition to this  she was prescribed antiplatelets  statin therapy  and pain relief was managed using opioids. Patient was also advised for lifestyle modifications such as smoking cessation  weight loss  and diabetes management.  Slide 7: Follow-Up Post procedure  the patient showed significant improvement in symptoms. At a 3-month follow-up visit  her ulcer had healed  her rest pain had resolved  and her right foot pulses were palpable.   Slide 8: Conclusion Timely identification and intervention can significantly improve outcomes in patients with CLI. Comprehensive management consists of revascularization  cardiovascular risk factor modification  and symptomatic treatment. The benefit of these measures is seen with the patient's improved symptoms at follow-up.

Title: Case Presentation: Critical Limb Ischemia    Slide 1: Introduction - Patient: 72-year-old Caucasian male  - Chief Complaint: Constant and severe pain in the right leg at rest  skin ulcers  and color changes in the feet.  Slide 2: Demographics - Occupation: Retired construction worker - Lifestyle: Smoker for 50 years  occasional alcohol consumption - Family History: Hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes and Peripheral Artery Disease on the maternal side  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Type 2 Diabetes diagnosed at age 46 - Hypertension diagnosed at age 52 - History of intermittent claudication  - History of mild stroke with full recovery at age 68  Slide 4: Clinical Summary - Patient presents with critical limb ischemia (CLI) as indicated by rest pain  ulcers and color changes.  - The patient's longstanding history of Type 2 Diabetes and Hypertension  together with his chronic smoking habit  are consistent risk factors for CLI.    Slide 5: Diagnostic Tests and Results - Ankle-brachial index (ABI) test: Indicated significant reduction in right leg. - Doppler Ultrasound: Showed a significant decrease in blood flow to the right leg. - Angiogram: Confirmed severe blockage in the arteries of the lower right leg.    Slide 6: Physical Examination - Reduced pedal pulses in right leg. - Ulcers on the lower leg with signs of necrosis. - Lower temperature in right leg compared to the left.    Slide 7: Conclusion - Given this patient's prior medical history combined with current physical examination and test results  he was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia.     Slide 8: Management and Treatment Plan  - Initiated on medications to manage the condition and improve blood flow. - Counselling on lifestyle changes – smoking cessation  healthy diet  and exercise. - Vascular surgery consultation for possible revascularization. - Regular follow-ups for monitoring and a tailored comprehensive rehabilitation plan.   Slide 9: Prognosis - With immediate intervention and lifestyle changes  the potential for limb salvage is good but regular monitoring is necessary due to the progressive nature of the condition.   Slide 10: Key Takeaways - Importance of early detection and intervention. - Increased prevalence in those above 70 and with a history of Hypertension and Diabetes Type 2. - Importance of lifestyle modification in overall management.    Slide 11: References - List of used images  data  citations.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Case Presentation - Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 2: Overview of Case Patient Demographics: A 62-year-old male  African American  smoker with a body mass index (BMI) of 28. Occupation: retired military.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Significant history of type-2 diabetes for past 20 years  well-controlled on insulin. Patient has high cholesterol and hypertension. No known allergies.  Slide 4: Social History  20-year pack smoking history. No alcohol or illicit drug use. Lives alone  no family history of similar symptoms.  Slide 5: Presentation Patient came in with severe pain in his right leg  rest pain  numbness  and skin ulcers that do not seem to heal for past two weeks.  Slide 6: Examination Findings Physical examination reveals cold right foot with weak pulse  pallor on elevation  delayed capillary refill  and non-healing ulcer on right big toe.   Slide 7: Investigations  The patient was directed for further investigations including Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  Doppler ultrasound  and CT angiography to confirm the diagnosis.  Slide 8: Diagnosis  Confirmation of Critical Limb Ischemia based on clinical symptoms and investigations   Slide 9: Management Plan - Patient is advised to stop smoking immediately - High-intensity statin therapy for cholesterol control - Optimal glucose control to manage diabetes - Antihypertensive medication for blood pressure control - Referral to vascular specialist for possible revascularization procedure  Slide 10: Follow-up and Prognosis Regular monitoring of the patient is required to assess the success of treatment and adjust medications if needed. Despite treatment  the patient remains at high risk for amputation.  Slide 11: Lessons to Learn Early identification and aggressive management of risk factors are key to delay the progression of critical limb ischemia. Consider urgent referral for all patients with signs of critical ischemia. Title: A Clinical Case Study on Critical Limbic Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction - Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) is a severe peripheral artery disease leading to chronic pain  non-healing sores or gangrene. It is an advanced form of peripheral artery disease  where the blood flow is critically reduced.   Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Patient: Mr. A  75-year-old Caucasian male  - Occupation: Retired school teacher   - Background: Non-smoker  moderate drinker  Slide 3: Presenting Complaint - Chief complaint: Intense and consistent pain in the right lower limb  more at rest  especially at night. Reports non-healing wounds in legs and toes.  Slide 4: Past Medical History - Diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus 15 years ago.  - Three-year history of Hypertension. - Previous episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) - Underwent coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery 5 years ago.  Slide 5: Symptoms  - Severe pain in right lower leg  even while at rest.  - Presence of non-healing ulcers on leg and gangrene on toe. - Decreased mobility due to pain. - Disturbed sleep because of nocturnal pain.  Slide 6: Clinical Examination - Significant decreased pulses in both lower limbs. - Presence of dry gangrene on the first and second toes of the right foot. - Bruits over femoral arteries.  Slide 7: Diagnostic Tests  - Ankle-Brachial index (ABI) shows decreased ratio (<0.4)  indicative of severe peripheral artery disease. - Doppler ultrasound confirms severely reduced blood flow. - CT angiogram shows multiple blockages in the arteries of right lower limb.  Slide 8: Diagnosis - Based on clinical presentation  examination findings  and diagnostic tests  Mr. A was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia.  Slide 9: Management Plan  - Initiation of Prostaglandin E1 infusion for relief of rest pain. - Optimal control of diabetes and hypertension. - Endovascular intervention  aiming at revascularization  to restore leg perfusion and prevent limb loss.  - Regular wound care management and counseling for lifestyle modifications.   Slide 10: Prognosis and Follow up  - Regular follow-ups every three months to monitor disease progression and management. - Patient education about risk factors and complications of the disease. - Sustained lifestyle modification guidance to prevent further progression.    Slide 11: Conclusion - Early diagnosis and timely intervention can potentially prevent limb loss and improve the quality of life in patients suffering from CLI. Holistic care involving regular follow-ups and healthy lifestyle guidance is key to managing the disease.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: ""Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Study""  Slide 2: Patient Demographics The case under review involves a 65-year-old African American male. The patient is a retired school teacher  a non-smoker  habitual alcohol drinker  and lives an inactive lifestyle with high consumption of fats and low fruits and vegetable diet.  Slide 3: Presenting Complaints The patient presented with a six-month history of progressive pain in the right lower limb  especially during walking  difficulty in wound healing  and a cold sensation in the right foot.  Slide 4: Past Medical History He has a significant past medical history that includes Type-2 diabetes mellitus under insulin treatment for 15 years  Hypertension for 10 years  stable angina for 7 years  and a past episode of a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years ago. No known allergies reported.  Slide 5: Examination Findings On investigation  he was found to have a weak pulse in the right femoral artery and absent pulses in the lower right leg. The right foot was colder compared to the left foot. An ulcer was noted on the right heel.  Slide 6: Diagnosis After further vascular studies and radiography  the diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) secondary to Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) was reached.  Slide 7: Management and Treatment  Management decided was revascularization via angioplasty and a supervised exercise program  along with strict control of his diabetes and hypertension. His lifestyle modifications were advised including a balanced diet  cessation of alcohol  and daily physical activity.  Slide 8: Prognosis  Regular follow-ups have been scheduled. The patient is responding well to the treatment; however  CLI is a serious condition which requires consistent monitoring and management.  Slide 9: Learning Points CLI is a severe presentation of PAD. It is essential to control the underlying risk factors like Diabetes and Hypertension  and early identification plays a crucial role in prognosis. Regular exercise and adopting a healthy lifestyle aids in disease management.   Slide 10: Conclusion In conclusion  timely diagnosis  coordinated vascular care  risk factor control and patient's adherence to treatment plan are crucial in the management of CLI.   Slide 11: References Relevant references and peer-review papers about CLI.

Title: Case Presentation: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 65-year-old Male Patient  Slide 1: Introduction Mr. X  a 65-year-old Caucasian male from a suburban Ontario town  presents with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). He is a retired mechanic who lives with his wife.  Slide 2: Present Illness Mr X. has been experiencing pain in his right leg for the past two months. The pain intensifies after walking small distances and is relieved by rest. Recently  he has been experiencing pain at rest also.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Mr. X has had a history of hypertension for 15 years  controlled with medication. He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes mellitus eight years ago  for which he takes oral hypoglycemics. He is a former smoker  who quit 5 years ago after a 30 years habit of 1 pack per day.  Slide 4: Family History His father passed away from a Myocardial Infarction at the age of 72. His mother died of a stroke at an age of 81. He has a younger sister diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes.  Slide 5: Examination Upon examination  Mr. X's right leg is noted to be cooler than the left leg. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses of the right leg are nonpalpable.   Slide 6: Investigations Ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) was 0.5 in the right limb and 1.2 in the left limb  indicating severe arterial disease in the right lower extremity. Doppler ultrasound showed severe stenosis of the right common femoral artery and complete occlusion of the right superficial femoral artery.    Slide 7: Diagnosis These evaluations resulted in a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia in Mr. X.  Slide 8: Management & Follow-Up Considering the severity of his condition  a combination of medical management and revascularization intervention may be required. His case requires further consultation with vascular surgeons for a suitable approach. His follow-up would involve monitoring his clinical symptoms and ABPI measurements. His lifestyle modification and control of risk factors  especially his diabetes and hypertension  will be crucial in the management process.  End of Presentation.

Presentation Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia   Slide 1: Introduction  ""Today  we will dive into a detailed case study of a patient suffering from Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe arterial obstruction condition marked by chronic ischemic rest pain  ulcers  or gangrene.""  Slide 2: Demographics  ""Our patient of interest is a 67-year-old African-American male. He is a retired construction worker  non-smoker  and observes a diet where fat  especially saturated fats  amount to about 35% of his total daily caloric intake. He does not consume alcohol. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is within a healthy range.""  Slide 3: Past Medical History  ""His past medical history is significant for poorly controlled type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and high cholesterol -all risk factors for CLI. His father also suffered the same disease.""  Slide 4: Symptom presentation  ""He reported to the clinic complaining of severe pain in his right lower limb that worsened over the past few weeks  accompanied by a non-healing foot ulcer. The pain tends to increase with rest  especially during the nighttime. He also mentioned the progressive darkening of his toes.""  Slide 5: Examination and Diagnosis  ""Upon examination  we noted skin discoloration  dry gangrene in some toes  and non-pulsatile pedal arteries. An angiogram was performed which revealed severe blockages in his lower extremity arteries  confirming the diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia.""  Slide 6: Treatment and Prognosis  ""Given his severe symptoms and the presence of gangrene  we opted for a combination of endovascular therapy for revascularization and debridement of the gangrenous tissue. He was enlisted into a comprehensive care plan involving aggressive control of his diabetes  hypertension  and cholesterol  alongside dietary counseling and physiotherapy post-procedure.""  Slide 7: Conclusion  ""In conclusion  this case illustrates the progression and complications of CLI  and the importance of aggressive  targeted management in patients with comorbidities such as DM  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. It emphasizes the vital role of early detection and intervention in preventing limb loss.""

Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction A review of a case involving a 65-year-old African-American male patient who presented with critical limb ischemia.   Slide 2: Demographic Information The patient is a retired factory worker  aged 65  living in an urban area. He is a non-drinker and non-smoker. He has a family history of diabetes and hypertension.  Slide 3: Medical Background The patient has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) and hypertension  both diagnosed 10 years ago. He has been managing his diabetes with oral medications and diet modifications. Hypertension was controlled by ACE inhibitors.   Slide 4: Current Medical Issue  The patient was admitted due to worsening pain in his right lower extremity which had been ongoing for the past three months. Despite analgesics  the pain intensified making it hard for him to perform daily tasks. Pain was notably more severe at rest and at night.   Slide 5: Examination and Diagnosis Upon physical examination  the right foot was pale  cold to the touch with diminished pulses. Wounds were evident in the distal part of the same limb. An arterial Doppler study confirmed decrease in ankle-brachial index. Diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was confirmed based on history  clinical findings and investigations.  Slide 6: Treatment Plan Due to the severity of ischemia  patient was referred for revascularization procedures - angioplasty with stent implantation. Post intervention  patient received antiplatelets  anticoagulants and statins therapy. Further wound care  glycemic control  and blood pressure management were also addressed.   Slide 7: Prognosis and Follow-up CLI is a severe condition with significant morbidity and mortality if not promptly identified and treated. The goal of the treatment is not only limb salvage  but also pain relief and improved quality of life. Regular follow-up visits were scheduled to monitor the healing process and to ensure medical management for his comorbid conditions are optimal.  Slide 8: Conclusion This case highlights the need for early identification  aggressive treatment and preventative strategies for critical limb ischemia patients  especially those with underlying risk factors such as diabetes and hypertension. Continuing patient education on lifestyle modifications and medication adherence is crucial in managing such cases.   Slide 9: Questions Time for any questions or comments about this case study.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a Geriatric Patient  Slide 1: Introduction Case centers on Mrs. Wilson  a 72-year-old Caucasian female  who presents with critical limb ischemia  characterized by severe pain in her right lower extremity  non-healing wounds  and tissue loss.   Slide 2: Demographic Information Mrs. Wilson is a retired school teacher living with her husband in a suburban neighborhood. She has a 45-pack-year smoking history and an overall sedentary lifestyle. She does not consume alcohol or use illicit substances.   Slide 3: Past Medical History Mrs. Wilson has a significant medical history: diagnosed with Type II Diabetes 8 years ago  currently uncontrolled; Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  both managed with medication; and a history of transient ischemic attacks. No known drug allergies.   Slide 4: Previous Surgical History She underwent total knee replacement surgery on her right knee 4 years ago  followed by physiotherapy and rehabilitation. No other significant surgical history is present.  Slide 5: Recent Symptomatology Recently  Mrs. Wilson noticed unbearable pain in her right leg  particularly at rest  and a wound on her foot that refuses to heal. Pain is exacerbated by short-distance walks  and relieved only by hanging her leg at the bedside.  Slide 6: Physical Examination On examination  her right foot appeared pale and cold with an ulcerated wound at the plantar aspect of her forefoot. Lower limb pulses were weak  and distal sensation was reduced.   Slide 7: Investigations Vascular studies including Duplex ultrasound and angiography confirm the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia. Laboratory tests highlight uncontrolled blood glucose levels and increased blood pressure.  Slide 8: Diagnosis The clinical context  along with investigative reports  confirmed Mrs. Wilson's condition as Critical Limb Ischemia  secondary to atherosclerotic peripheral arterial disease  significantly influenced by her uncontrolled diabetes  smoking  and sedentary lifestyle.  Slide 9: Treatment Plan Given her age and comorbidities  revascularization through endovascular procedures will be considered initially  aimed at pain relief and prevention of limb amputation. Concurrently  aggressive risk factor modification will be employed  which includes optimizing glucose control  antihypertensive therapy  lipid-lowering agents  cessation of smoking  and guideline-directed antiplatelet therapy.  Slide 10: Conclusion This case illustrates the complexities of diagnosing and managing vascular complications in geriatric diabetic patients. Proper risk stratification  aggressive management of modifiable risk factors  and appropriate therapeutic intervention can notably improve quality of life in such patients.

Title: A Case Study - Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction • Patient: Mr. Andrew Smith  a 72-year-old retired engineer. • Presenting Symptom: Severe pain in his right lower limb  especially when at rest.  Slide 2: Demographics & Lifestyle • Resident: Boston  Massachusetts.  • Marital Status: Widower  lives independently. • Lifestyle: Non-smoker  consumes alcohol socially. Has a balanced diet but leads a sedentary lifestyle.  Slide 3: Past Medical History • Diagnosed with Hypertension and Type II Diabetes (poorly controlled for the past ten years). • Had suffered a transient ischemic attack seven years ago.  • History of intermittent claudication for the past two years.  Slide 4: Current Medical Status  • Physical examination revealed absent pulses in the right femoral  popliteal  and pedal regions.  • Positive Buerger's test on the right lower limb. • Recent weight loss due to decreased appetite and increased metabolic demands from ischemic pain.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Testing • Duplex ultrasound showed decreased blood flow in the right femoral and popliteal arteries. • Computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed a high-grade occlusive lesion in the right femoral artery. • Blood analysis confirmed uncontrolled blood sugar levels.  Slide 6: Diagnosis  • Based on clinical examination and Imaging studies  Mr. Smith diagnoses with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) in the right lower limb.  Slide 7: Treatment Plan  • Aggressive management of Mr. Smith's underlying conditions - Hypertension and Diabetes. • Revascularization procedure in the form of percutaneous transluminal angioplasty. • Regular monitoring to detect any deterioration in conditions and to prevent amputation.  Slide 8: Patient Education & Prevention  • Education on the importance of stringent control of blood pressure and blood sugar levels. • Motivate him to lead an active lifestyle and recommend low impact exercises. • Discuss the benefits of a healthy diet and maintaining a healthy weight. • Regular follow-ups to monitor signs of recovery or progression.  Slide 9: Conclusion • Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial in managing Critical Limb Ischemia effectively. • Focus should also be on managing underlying conditions and promoting a healthier lifestyle to reduce the likelihood of recurrence.  Slide 10: References • List of sources and references to ensure credibility and provide further reading material for audience.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Case Presentation: Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 2: Demographics Patient Information:  - Gender: Male - Age: 70 years - Race: African American - Profession: Retired Construction Worker  Slide 3: Symptoms at presentation - Pain in right leg at rest - Coldness and numbness in lower extremity - Dusky discoloration of foot - Ulceration on toes - Decreased mobility  Slide 4: Past Medical History - Diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus 15 years ago - Has a 30-year history of smoking (currently smoker) - Diagnosed with Peripheral Arterial Disease 5 years ago - Hypertension - Hypercholesterolemia without statin therapy - Previous history of a minor stroke with full recovery  Slide 5: Physical Examination - Pulses in the right lower extremity were not palpable - Capillary refill time was delayed  - Sensation to touch was decreased  and mobility was restricted in the right lower extremity - Body mass index 28.5 kg/m2 (overweight)  Slide 6: Diagnostic Tests - Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) showed index of 0.3 on right leg (indicating impaired blood flow) - Doppler ultrasound revealed severe stenosis in right femoral and distal popliteal arteries - MRI showed multiple areas of blockages in lower limb  Slide 7: Diagnosis  - Diagnosis: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) - Due to his severe symptoms  he was classified as Rutherford category 4 (Ischemic rest pain)    Slide 8: Treatment - Urgent surgical revascularization intervention - Title: A Case Presentation on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction - Brief overview of the disease - Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  which is a severe obstruction of the arteries which drastically reduces blood-flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and even skin ulcers or sores.  Slide 2: Patient's Demographics - Patient X  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  recently retired from his job as a truck driver  presented to the emergency department with pain in his left lower leg.   Slide 3: Past Medical History - A smoker for over 40 years and diagnosed with hypertension four years ago. - In 2018  he was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia. - He underwent angioplasty of the right coronary artery three years ago after a mild heart attack.  Slide 4: Current Complaints - Patient presents with severe  constant pain in his left lower leg.  - Pain increases while walking  with the patient able to walk only short distances – a condition known as claudication. - Reports non-healing sores on his left foot.  Slide 5: Physical Examination - On examination  weak pulses are palpable in the left foot.  - Skin of left lower leg is shiny with hair loss. - A non-healing ulcer is noted on the ball of the foot  with digital discoloration observed.  Slide 6: Investigations & Diagnosis - Lower extremity Doppler ultrasound shows significantly reduced blood flow in the popliteal artery. - Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) shows a value of 0.5 – confirming the diagnosis of CLI.  Slide 7: Treatment & Management  - Multifaceted approach includes smoking cessation and good glycemic control. - Pharmacotherapy including antiplatelet drugs and statins. - Considering severity  patient referred to vascular surgeon for angioplasty or bypass surgery options.    Slide 8: Patient Education - Importance of managing risk factors such as controlling blood sugar levels and blood pressure  maintaining cholesterol levels  and quitting smoking. - Importance of foot care and recognizing symptoms of worsening condition.  Slide 9: Summary & Conclusion - Brief summary of the patient's case. - The importance of early diagnosis and timely management in CLI to prevent serious complications like limb amputation.  End of Presentation. Thank you for your attention. Are there any questions?
