Title: Case Presentation: Understanding Critical Limb Ischemia   Slide 1: Introduction Patient: Mr. John Doe Gender: Male Age: 65 Ethnicity: Caucasian   Slide 2: Past Medical History  - Diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 15 years ago - Diagnosed with Hypertension 10 years ago - History of smoking - 1 pack/day for 40 years; quit five years ago - High cholesterol level diagnosed 7 years ago  Slide 3: Present Symptoms - Complaints of a recurring pain in his left lower leg that intensifies when walking but subsides at rest (Intermittent claudication) - Noticed non-healing ulcers on left foot  with noted temperature difference compared to other foot - Palpably weak pulse in left foot  Slide 4: Diagnosis - Taken together  these symptoms suggest the patient suffers from Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  most likely caused by peripheral arterial disease  exacerbated by his diabetes  hypertension  and history of smoking.  Slide 5: Examination and Tests - Ankle-Brachial Index test confirms low blood flow to the affected limb. - Doppler Ultrasound visualizes narrowed arteries and identifies blood clots. - A subsequent angiogram gives a detailed view of blockages.  Slide 6: Treatment Plan - Conservative therapy including optimal diabetes  blood pressure  and cholesterol management along with lifestyle modifications (balanced diet  exercise  and complete smoking cessation) - Supervised exercise program to improve walking distance and reduce symptoms - Catheter-based procedures or bypass surgery to restore blood flow - Close monitoring for wound infection and treatment for the non-healing ulcers  Slide 7: Conclusion - CLI poses a serious threat  but early identification and management can potentially mitigate severe outcomes  including amputation. - Emphasise on the importance of patient education  compliance with medications  and lifestyle modifications to prevent disease progression.

Title: A Case Study of Critical Limb Ischemia   Slide 1: Introduction Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) is a severe obstruction of the arteries which drastically reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and even skin ulcers or sores.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Our patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker. He's a former smoker with a 20-year pack history  moderate drinker  and has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 10 years.  Slide 3: Past Medical History History of poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He had a myocardial infarction 7 years ago and had a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) to manage his ischemic heart disease. He has been experiencing symptoms of intermittent claudication for the past year.  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints The patient arrived at the clinic with excruciating pain in his left foot which had been worsening over several weeks  disturbing his sleep even at rest. He revealed a non-healing wound on his left great toe which he had noticed around four months ago.  Slide 5: Examination Findings Clinically  his lower left leg was found to be cold with weak or absent peripheral pulses. The skin of his foot showed signs of mottling and the toe wound showed tissue necrosis indicative of gangrene.  Slide 6: Diagnosis  Diagnosis of critical limb ischemia was confirmed with abdominal ultrasound  ankle-brachial index  and CT angiography showing multi-level peripheral arterial disease with infra-popliteal disease being predominant.  Slide 7: Treatment & Prognosis Treatment includes aggressive management of modifiable risk factors  pain management  wound care  revascularization procedures  or in severe cases  amputation. Early intervention and aggressive treatment can improve prognosis and limb salvage.  Slide 8: Conclusion  Our patient's past history of smoking  diabetes  heart disease  and his advanced age put him at a higher risk of developing CLI. This case highlights the importance of comprehensive management of CLI that involves risk factor modification  timely diagnosis  and appropriate intervention.  Slide 9: Questions? Inviting any questions/comments from the audience.

Slide 1: Introduction Today's case study covers a patient suffering from Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe obstruction of the arteries which drastically reduces blood flow to the extremities  primarily the legs and feet  and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.   Slide 2: Patient Demographics Our patient is a 78-year-old African American male  retired construction worker  living in an urban residential setting. He is a nonsmoker and refrains from alcohol. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is 29  classifying him as borderline obese.  Slide 3: Past Medical History The patient has a significant past medical history - he was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) twenty years ago. He was also diagnosed with hypertension fifteen years ago  and peripheral arterial disease (PAD) ten years ago. Despite consistent efforts to manage these conditions  his health has been progressively deteriorating.   Slide 4: Medications  The patient is currently on Metformin to control T2DM  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Aspirin daily as prescribed by the cardiologist due to his PAD. Medication compliance is generally good  as confirmed by his primary care physician.   Slide 5: Recent Symptoms The patient reported experiencing severe pain at rest in his right lower limb for the past three weeks. He also pointed out a non-healing ulcer on the big toe of his right foot  which appeared about three months ago. As these symptoms are consistent with late-stage PAD or Critical Limb Ischemia  he was referred for vascular consultation.  Slide 6: Diagnostic Procedures Initial evaluation through palpation revealed absent pedal (dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial) pulses in his right foot. A diagnostic duplex ultrasound was done  demonstrating significant stenosis in the distal right superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery  supporting the diagnosis of CLI.   Slide 7: Conclusion The important lesson from this case is the significance of long-term management and follow-up in patients suffering from chronic diseases such as diabetes and hypertension  as neglected PAD has led to critical limb ischemia in this patient. A multidisciplinary approach including aggressive risk factor modifications  revascularization  and wound care management will be crucial in the proposed treatment plan to prevent limb loss.  Slide 8: Future Considerations There is a need for increased focus on public health intervention  patient education  and periodic surveillance to reduce the burden of CLI. This includes promoting healthy lifestyles  early diagnosis of PAD in high-risk individuals  and the optimal use of current treatment options.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia: Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction  - Subject: Mr. Davis  a 72-year-old African American male - Diagnosis: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Slide 2: Patient Background  - Occupation: Retired teacher - Habits: Regular smoker and drinker for the past 45 years - Lifestyle: Sedentary  with limited physical activities  Slide 3: Medical History  - Chronic diseases: Type II Diabetes and Hypertension - Operations: Underwent heart bypass surgery at the age of 62 - Medications: On metformin  antihypertensive drugs and low-dose aspirin  - Family history: His father suffered from heart disease and passed away at the age of 65.   Slide 4: History of Present Illness  - Presentation: Mr. Davis visited the doctor with the complaint of severe pain in his right calf muscle that had been persisting for over two weeks. - Accompanying symptoms: Coldness in the right lower limb  noticeable paleness  and absence of foot pulses. - Wound: Noted a non-healing wound on his right heel.   Slide 5: Advanced Findings  - Ankle-brachial index confirmed severe reduction of blood flow in the right lower limb. - Angiography: significant artery stenosis seen in the lower right limb  - Bloods: High HbA1c  suggesting poor blood sugar control.   Slide 6: Diagnosis  - Mr. Davis was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia on the right leg due to Peripheral Artery Disease.  Slide 7: Management  - Multifactorial approach including managing diabetes  hypertension and lipid levels - Smoking cessation and lifestyle adjustment interventions - Initiation of anti-platelet and statin therapy - Surgical options: angioplasty/stenting  bypass grafting  or amputation all considered based on his condition    Slide 8: Conclusion and Prognosis  - Critical emphasis on timely diagnosis and early intervention  - Mr. Davis faced the risk of limb loss if not properly managed  - Importance of a holistic medical approach towards CLI considering his co-morbidities  Slide 9: Follow up  - Frequent follow-ups for monitoring progress and managing complications - Work closely with a nutritionist for diet adjustments - Collaborate with a physiotherapist for physical activity plans

Title: A Case Presentation on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction - A brief discussion about Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI): a severe obstruction of the arteries which significantly reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Patient: Mr. A  a 65-year-old African American male  - Occupation: Retired Factory worker - Resident: Urban neighborhood   Slide 3: Past Medical History  - Hypertension and hyperlipidemia for 10 years  both well controlled with medication - Type 2 diabetes mellitus for 17 years (poor glycemic control) - 20-cigarette per day smoker for 40 years - No previous episodes of cardiovascular disease  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints - Severe pain in his right lower limb even at rest - Presence of non-healing sores on his right foot - Discoloration of toes (necrosis)  Slide 5: Physical Examination - Cold to touch right lower limb - Diminished pulse in right leg - Presence of necrotic tissue in the toes - Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) measured as <0.4   Slide 6: Investigations - Duplex ultrasound: Severe stenosis of the right tibial and the peroneal artery - Angiogram: confirms above and identified location suitable for bypass graft  Slide 7: Diagnosis - Diagnosis: based on clinical findings and confirmatory diagnostic tests  Mr. A was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 8: Management - Multi-disciplinary approach in combination with optimized medical therapy. - Endovascular procedure (angioplasty/stenting) and bypass surgery. - Smoking cessation therapy and aggressive control of blood sugar levels - Regular follow-up for assessing the arterial inflow  wound healing  and pain management.  Slide 9: Conclusion - Patients with CLI require early identification and aggressive management to improve their prognosis and quality of life. - Importance of lifestyle changes and control of risk factors in managing CLI.  Slide 10: Questions? - Open the floor for questions and discussion related to the case.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Case Presentation: Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Patient: Mr. J.R.  60-year-old male - Ethnicity: African-American - Occupation: Retired Electrician - Lifestyle: Moderate Smoker; alcohol intake occasional  Slide 3: Presenting Complaint - Main complaint: Severe pain in the right lower leg  even at rest. - Accompanied by: Non-healing sores on the right foot and lower leg  noticeable coldness in the right lower leg  and color change to bluish-pale.  Slide 4: Past Medical History - Has a ten year history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Well-controlled with oral medication and diet modification. - Diagnosis of Hyperlipidemia and Hypertension 15 years back: Taking statins and ACE Inhibitors. - Underwent Coronary Artery Bypass Graft surgery 5 years ago.  Slide 5: Past Surgical History - Major surgery: Coronary Artery Bypass Graft  5 years back - Minor surgeries: Appendectomy  two decades back  Slide 6: Current Medication and Allergies  - Medication: Metformin  Lisinopril  Simvastatin  daily Aspirin - No known drug allergies  Slide 7: Progressive Symptoms - Intermittent Claudication for the past year - Rest Pain over the last month - Recent onset of non-healing foot ulcers over the last two weeks. Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Slide 1: Introduction  Patient Demographics: Patient X is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired  with a history of moderate alcohol consumption and smoking.  Slide 2: Medical Background  Failed attempts at smoking cessation. Has been smoking approximately a pack per day since his teenage years. He also reports a low-level activity  functioning mainly as a couch potato  but sometimes walks short distances to and from local amenities.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  - Hypertension: Has been diagnosed and treated for hypertension for the past 15 years.  - Type II Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 10 years back and is currently on Metformin. - Coronary Artery Disease: He underwent Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) about 7 years ago. - Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD): Diagnosed with early-stage PAD 5 years ago that gradually worsened over time.   Slide 4: Recent Medical Concerns  - Over the past year experienced rest pain in his right leg  increasingly severe over the past three months. - Skin discoloration and the formation of non-healing ulcers on his foot. - He also reported a loss of hair on his lower extremities. - These symptoms are suggestive of critical limb ischemia.   Slide 5: Diagnosis  - ABI test showed a score of less than 0.40 in his critical leg. - Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  Magnetic Resonance Angiogram (MRA)  confirmed right leg CLI.  Slide 6: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  CLI is a severe obstruction of the arteries which has markedly reduced blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.  Slide 7: Treatment Plan  - Revascularization by peripheral angioplasty. - Optimal wound care for the foot ulcers. - Strict glucose control  smoking cessation  and supervised exercise therapy. - Aggressive modification of other cardiovascular risk factors.  Slide 8: CLI and Patient Care  - The critical nature of CLI requires immediate medical intervention. - Patient education on lifestyle changes to slow disease progression and prevent amputation. - Monitoring for complications and follow-ups are crucial.  Slide 9: Conclusion  Importance of early recognition  prompt treatment  and comprehensive care in the management of patients with critical limb ischemia.  Slide 10: Questions and Discussions.

Title: A Case Examination: Patient with Critical Limic Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction -The intent of this presentation is to discuss the case of a patient suffering from critical limb ischemia  a severe obstruction of the arteries that significantly reduces blood flow to the extremities.   Slide 2: Patient Demographics  - Our subject  Mr. J  is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who resides in an urban area. He is a retiree with a 30-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day  although he quit ten years ago. He drinks socially and maintains a high-fat diet. He has a family history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD)  and his father died of a stroke.  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Mr. J was diagnosed with hypertension aged 40  type 2 diabetes aged 48  and hyperlipidemia aged 55. He’s been on consistent treatment for these conditions. He's had no prior surgeries. He experienced occasional bouts of claudication in his right leg  increasing in severity over the past six months.  Slide 4: Presenting Complaint  -Mr. J presents with excruciating pain in his right leg  particularly when at rest  coupled with noticeable skin discoloration and coldness in the limb.  Slide 5: Clinical Findings and Diagnosis - Physical examination reveals absent pulses distal to the right femoral artery. Doppler ultrasound indicates significant stenosis in distal right femoral and popliteal artery. Given the patient’s symptoms  history  and findings  the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia is established.  Slide 6: Discussion  - Considering Mr. J’s lifestyle  habits  and medical history  his case underscores the critical links between smoking  unmodulated diet  chronic diseases such as diabetes and hypertension  and the development of vascular pathologies  including critical limb ischemia.  Slide 7: Treatment Plan  -Treatment for Mr. J will aim to restore blood flow  starting with medication to prevent clotting  pain management and lifestyle modifications. Endovascular procedures or bypass surgery may be considered for revascularization given the severity of his condition.  Slide 8: Conclusion  - This case emphasizes the importance of early intervention and management of risk factors to prevent severe manifestations like critical limb ischemia. Our role as medical practitioners is pivotal to ensure patients have a better quality of life through education  preventive measures  and early treatment plans.

Title: Case Study: Critical Limic Ischemia in Elder Diabetes Patient  Slide 1: Introduction - Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) defined as a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood flow to the extremities and has progressed to cause limb pain at rest.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Patient X  a 64-year-old White Male  retired construction worker. Title: A Clinical Case Study of Critical Limic Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) is a severe manifestation of peripheral arterial disease  characterized by recurrent pain at rest  vibrant skin changes  and leg ulcers or gangrene. Today  we will analyze a case of a patient diagnosed with CLI.   Slide 2: Case Presentation  Demographics:  Our patient is a 68-year-old African-American male  retired from construction work  currently residing in an urban area with a moderate quality of life. He has limited physical activity due to severe pain in the lower limbs.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  He has a long history of the following: - Cigarette smoking (40 pack for 30 years) - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (diagnosed 15 years ago) - Hypertension (diagnosed 10 years ago) - Dyslipidemia (diagnosed 5 years ago)  Slide 4: Symptomology  The patient reports: - Progressive pain in the legs for the past six months  - Intermittent claudication - Lower limb pain when resting  worsening at night - Previous ulceration on the left lower limb which healed poorly   Slide 5: Physical Examination  Upon examination  the patient has: - Distal pulses absent bilaterally - A cold left foot - Pallor on elevation and rubor on dependency - A non-healing ulcer on the left heel  Slide 6: Diagnostic Tests  Performed tests include Ankle-Brachial Index and Doppler Ultrasound  showing: - An Ankle-Brachial Index of 0.40 (normal values above 0.9) - Doppler Ultrasound indicating severe multi-level peripheral arterial disease  Slide 7: Treatment and Management  A revascularization approach has been suggested to resolve the arteriogenic component of the patient’s problem  given the severity of the symptoms.   Concurrent management will include: - Smoking cessation  - Glycemic  blood pressure  and lipid control - Antiplatelet therapy - Adequate pain control  Slide 8: Conclusion  To manage CLI effectively  a multi-disciplinary approach including revascularization procedures  concurrent management  lifestyle changes  and patient education is essential. This case study emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis  comprehensive treatments  and follow-up care in the management of Critical Limb Ischemia.

Title: Case Presentation on Critical Limb Ischemia  Slide 1: Introduction - Patient: 65-year-old male - Chief complaint: Severe pain in the right lower leg  with noticeable skin color changes - Occupation: Retired mechanic  Slide 2: Past Medical History - History of smoking (40 years  quit 5 years ago) - Type II Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago - Hypertension diagnosed 8 years ago - No previous hospitalizations or surgeries  Slide 3: Current Medications - Metformin  - Lisinopril  Slide 4: Physical Examination Findings - Lower extremities: Pale  cold skin in the right lower leg  decreased hair growth  nail deformities - Pulses not palpable in the right lower leg - Capillary refill time >3 seconds in the right foot - Pain scores: 7/10 - No signs of infection or ulcerations  Slide 5: Diagnostic Workup - Ankle-brachial index (ABI): 0.4  right leg  - Doppler ultrasound: Decreased blood flow in the right popliteal artery - Angiography: Severe occlusion in the right distal superficial femoral artery  Slide 6: Diagnosis - Critical Limb Ischemia - Patient meets criteria for critical limb ischemia (CLI): Chronic ischemic rest pain  non-healing ulcer  or gangrene - Right lower extremity is threatened due to severe arterial occlusive disease  Slide 7: Risk Factors - Patient’s history of tobacco use and poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension have contributed to the development of peripheral artery disease and subsequently  critical limb ischemia  Slide 8: Management Plan - Optimization of medical therapy for diabetes and hypertension - Cessation of nicotine use - Encourage aerobic exercise - Initiate dual anti-platelet therapy - Consideration for revascularization surgery   Slide 9: Conclusion - The patient is at risk for amputation if swift  appropriate management is not initiated. - Regular follow-up and lifestyle modifications are critical in the management of Critical Limb Ischemia.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Discussion  Slide 1: Introduction to Critical Limic Ischemia Critical limb ischemia is a severe obstruction of the arteries which considerably reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet and legs) and has progressed to the point of causing severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Our case involves a 72-year-old Hispanic male who is a retired truck driver. He has resided in Chicago  Illinois  for the past five decades.   Slide 3: Past Medical History The patient has a significant past medical history that includes type 2 diabetes Mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He was a heavy smoker but quit smoking 10 years ago.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms His primary complaints are progressive claudication  pain in his lower left leg  and non-healing ulcers on the left foot. He reports worsening pain  especially during the night  which affects his sleep.   Slide 5: Diagnostic Investigations  Angiography shows significant atherosclerotic disease in the left tibial and peroneal arteries. He has an ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.4 on the left and 1.0 on the right. There is evidence of multiple small non-healing ulcers on his left foot and left lower leg on physical examination.  Slide 6: Diagnosis  Given the patient's severe symptoms  history of poor risk factor control  notable differences between the right and left ABI  and results of angiography  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia is established.  Slide 7: Management Plan  The management plan proposed includes medical therapies and surgical interventions. Antiplatelet and statin therapies are indicated to prevent thrombosis and lower cholesterol levels. Referral to a vascular surgeon for consideration of revascularization for limb salvage has been made. Glycemic control and further smoking cessation intervention should also be addressed.  Slide 8: Conclusion  This case underlines the importance of early diagnosis and comprehensive management in patients with peripheral artery disease  especially in those at high risk of progression to critical limb ischemia. Optimizing management of modifiable risk factors is key to improving patient prognosis.

Title: A Case Study on Critical Limb Ischemia   Slide 1: Introduction - Brief overview of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  an advanced stage of peripheral artery disease causing severe blockages in the arteries limiting the blood flow to the extremities.  Slide 2: Case Presentation - Patient Demographics: 72-year-old Caucasian male - Past Medical History: History of uncontrolled Type II Diabetes Mellitus (DM)  Hypertension (HTN)  and a 20-year history of heavy smoking  Slide 3: Details of Present Symptoms - The patient complains of chronic pain in his left leg  notably worsened during minor physical activities such as walking  and longstanding non-healing ulcer in the lower leg.  - Experienced occasional episodes of numbness and coldness in the leg  Slide 4: On Examination - Physical examination reveals a palpable abdomen and a weak left dorsalis pedis compared to the right - Signs of peripheral neuropathy and dry skin - Sizable non-healing ulcer visible on the lower left leg  Slide 5: Imaging & Diagnostic Findings - Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was noted to be 0.4 in the left leg (a value < 0.9 indicates peripheral artery disease) - Doppler Ultrasound showed significant stenosis and diminished blood flow in the left leg peripheral arteries - CT Angiogram confirmed occlusions in the left leg arteries  Slide 6: Diagnosis - Considering his past medical history of DM and HTN  chronic leg pain and non-healing leg ulcer  along with the clinical and imaging findings  patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia.  Slide 7: Treatment Plan - Initiated conservative management including antiplatelet therapy  statins  antihypertensive  strict glycemic control and smoking cessation advice - Discussed options for revascularization procedures such as angioplasty  stent or bypass grafting - Regular wound care for ulcer management and suggested consultation with a dietician for nutrition optimization  Slide 8: Prognosis & Outlook - Emphasized that treatment response can be variable and the serious nature of the disease which can lead to amputation if not treated effectively. - Explained the importance of intervention to preserve limb function and improve quality of life.  Slide 9: Conclusion - Reiterate the importance of early diagnosis and possible preventive measures for CLI  particularly in patients with risk factors like Type II DM  HTN and smoking. - Patient education is key to management and potentially altering the course of the disease.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: ""Case Study: Management of Critical Limb Ischemia""  Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Age: 65 years - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Hispanic - Occupation: Retired construction worker  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Hypertension  well-controlled under medical regimen - Type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed ten years back  with glycemic variability. - History of smoking for 30 years  quit 5 years ago. - Family history of cardiovascular diseases  Slide 4: Presenting Complaint - Complaint of severe right lower extremity pain at rest  which has been progressively worsening over the last two weeks - The patient also notices sores on his right foot that aren't healing  Slide 5: Physical Examination - Examination reveals weak pulses in the lower right leg - The sores are located on the foot  about 0.5 cm in size  surrounded by discolored skin - Skin temperature decline in right foot  increased capillary refill time  Slide 6: Ancillary Investigation - Doppler ultrasound study concluded reduced blood flow to the right lower limb - Angiogram confirmed a significant blockage in the right popliteal artery - Blood tests showing moderate anemia and poor glycemic control  Slide 7: Diagnosis - Based on the clinical findings and investigations  the patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia  Slide 8: Management - A multidisciplinary approach consisting of vascular surgeons  endocrinologist  dietitian  and physiotherapist was established - Endovascular procedure to restore blood flow - Adjustments to diabetic medications for better control - Counseling for lifestyle modifications including strict diet control  exercise  and foot care - Regular follow-ups scheduled for monitoring the recovery and disease control  Slide 9: Prognosis - The outcome and prognosis are variable depending on how well the diabetes and other risk factors are managed  patient's response to treatment  and the extent of the disease itself. It is essential that the patient adheres to the management plan to minimize complications and maximize prognosis. Owing to the central role that diabetes and other modifiable risk factors play in this condition  lifestyle modification and adequate control of these conditions cannot be over-emphasized.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Report  Slide 2: Demographics & Past Medical History Patient Profile: 65 years old African-American Male Medical history: Hypertension  diabetes mellitus  heavy smoker for over 30 years.   Slide 3: Presenting Complaints The patient reported progressive pain in his lower limbs  especially right leg  particularly at night and while walking minimal distances. Resting leg pain has been present for the past three weeks.  Slide 4: Symptoms The patient complains of color changes in leg  significant hair loss  ulcers  and sores on his right foot that doesn’t heal  severe weight loss.   Slide 5: Previous Interventions The patient was initially treated with oral medications for peripheral artery disease and pain  with unsatisfactory results.    Slide 6: Physical Examination Upon examination  the right foot was noticeably cooler to touch than left  bulging veins were observed. Pulse in right leg was weak compared to left.   Slide 7: Diagnostic Assessments Performed tests: Ankle-brachial index  Doppler ultrasound  Angiogram. Test results showed greatly reduced blood flow in the right leg  associated with atherosclerotic blockages.  Slide 8: Clinical Diagnosis Based on symptoms  physical examination findings  and diagnostic tests  the patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI)  a severe form of peripheral arterial disease.  Slide 9: Treatment Plan The patient was referred to a vascular surgeon for further management. Surgical interventions such as angioplasty  bypass surgery  and thrombolysis were considered according to current guidelines. Amputation may be considered as a last resort.  Slide 10: Conclusion This case exemplifies the importance of early detection of peripheral arterial disease and the necessity for aggressive treatment in preventing progression to CLI  reducing morbidity and mortality. A 63-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes  hypertension  peripheral artery disease  and a 20-year pack smoking history now presents with critical limb ischemia on the right leg.

72-year-old Hispanic male with a history of diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia now presenting with critical limb ischemia characterized by rest pain  non-healing ulcers  and fear of potential amputation.
An 82-year-old African-American female with a history of Diabetes Mellitus type 2  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia is urgently admitted for critical limb ischemia in the right leg.

A 68-year-old diabetic male smoker with a history of hypertension and peripheral artery disease presents with severe pain and tissue loss in the right lower extremity  suggestive of critical limb ischemia.

A 68-year old  African-American male  with history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and peripheral arterial disease  presents with critical limb ischemia characterized by severe pain in the right lower limb and non-healing ulcers.

""A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of type II diabetes  hypertension  and long-term smoking  now presents with critical limb ischemia characterized by severe pain and developing gangrene in the right lower extremity.""

A 68-year-old female patient with a past medical history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus  hypertension  dyslipidemia  and current smoking  was admitted with severe rest pain  non-healing ulcers in the right foot  indicative of critical limb ischemia.

A 67-year-old African American male patient with a 10-year history of poorly controlled Type-2 Diabetes  unmanaged hypertension  and a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with Critical Limb Ischemia  evidenced by severe pain and gangrene development in his left lower extremity.

A 68-year-old male smoker with a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and peripheral artery disease presents with severe  rest pain and non-healing ulcers on his left foot  suggestive of critical limb ischemia.

""An 82-year-old male with a medical history of uncontrolled type-2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presents with rest pain and non-healing ulcers in the left lower extremity  suggestive of critical limb ischemia.""
""72-year-old male diabetic smoker with a history of peripheral arterial disease  now presenting with acute critical limb ischemia of the right lower extremity.""

A 68-year-old Hispanic male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease  now presenting with severe rest pain  non-healing ulcers and gangrene in the right lower limb indicative of critical limb ischemia.

A 67-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and tobacco use presents with severe pain in lower extremities  non-healing ulcer on right foot and rest pain indicating critical limb ischemia.

A 68-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presents with severe rest pain equivalent to Rutherford classification 4  indicating for the critical limb ischemia.

A 78-year-old African-American male  a hypertensive  diabetic and ex-smoker  with a past history of stroke and peripheral artery disease  now presents with worsening pain in the left lower extremity  indicative of critical limb ischemia.

""A 67-year-old male with a past medical history of unmanaged type II diabetes and peripheral artery disease presents with worsening pain and non-healing ulcers in right limb  indicative of critical limb ischemia.""

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of long-term smoking  uncontrolled diabetes  and peripheral artery disease  now presents with severe  unrelenting rest pain and gangrenous changes in the left lower extremity  strongly suggestive of critical limb ischemia.

A 67-year-old male with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presents with critical limb ischemia characterized by constant leg pain  non-healing ulcers  and a faint distal pulse.

A 67-year-old male smoker with a history of uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension presents with rest pain and non-healing ulcers in the right lower limb  consistent with a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia.

""72-year-old Hispanic male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  previous stroke  and peripheral artery disease  now presenting with rest pain and non-healing ulcers consistent with critical limb ischemia.""

A 68-year-old male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes type II  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 40-year heavy smoking habit presents with non-healing ulcerations over the right foot and severe rest pain  indicative of Critical Limb Ischemia.

A 65-year-old male patient with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with critical limb ischemia  demonstrating severe pain and skin ulcers on the right lower extremity.

A 68-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and chronic smoking presents with critical limb ischemia  characterized by rest pain and non-healing ulcers in his right lower extremity.

""A 68-year-old African American male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  and peripheral arterial disease presents with critical limb ischemia  characterized by rest pain and non-healing ulcers on the right lower extremity.""
A 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history of Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and a 40-pack-year smoking habit now presents with critical limb ischemia.

A 65-year-old male patient  smoker with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2 and peripheral arterial disease  presents with rest pain  non-healing ulcers and gangrene in the right foot indicating critical limb ischemia.

""An 82-year-old male patient  ex-smoker with a past medical history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension and peripheral artery disease  now presents with severe rest pain and non-healing ulcers on his right foot  suggesting a case of critical limb ischemia.""

A 76-year-old male with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus  coronary artery disease  and hypertension presents with signs of critical limb ischemia  indicated by non-healing ulcers and rest pain in the lower extremities.

Patient is a 65-year-old African-American male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type 2  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presenting with clinical symptoms of severe rest pain in his right foot for the past one week. The pain intensifies when lying down and lessens when foot is in a dependent position. Physical examination reveals cool skin  loss of hair  and palpable absence of pulse in the right foot. Patient also documents a non-healing ulcer on the dorsal surface of his right foot for past one month. The severity of pain deprives patient of sleep and he expresses concern over worsening necrosis in his foot due to inadequate blood supply  indicative of a possible critical limb ischemia.

A 65-year-old  Caucasian male with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension  presents with rest pain in the left lower extremity (Rutherford Category 4). He describes the pain as severe  persistent  worsened over a period of weeks  and is mostly felt in the calf  foot  and toes. Apart from the severe rest pain  he also reports intermittent claudication  a painful cramp that occurs in leg muscles while walking and immediately relieved with rest. On physical examination  the left foot is pale  cold to touch with a weak or absent dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses. The patient also has non-healing ulcers on the dorsum of the left foot and distal third of the left leg with surrounding erythema and tenderness. He also reports unintentional weight loss. His pain has disrupted his sleep and causes him to dangle his leg over the side of the bed for relief. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history and currently smokes one pack per day.

A 65-year-old African American male  with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia for the past 20 years  presents with two weeks of constant  severe  rest pain in the right foot. The pain is a 9/10  worse at night  awakened him from sleep  and improved with dangling the foot. He also reports a non-healing ulcer over his right great toe for the last three weeks. On examination  a 2 cm ulcerated lesion is found with gangrenous changes on the distal endpoint of the toe. There were no palpable pulses in right popliteal  dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial artery; capillary refill time was delayed. The right foot appeared paler compared to the left  with severe dryness and desquamation of skin. Lower left limb examination findings revealed palpable peripheral pulses with warm skin. The patient's symptoms are consistent with critical right lower limb ischemia requiring urgent intervention.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 25-year history of smoking  who presents with worsening right leg pain for the past two weeks. The pain  which he describes as a burning or cramping sensation  has been progressively increasing in severity  affecting his calf and foot even at rest. Further  due to this pain  he experiences significant difficulty while walking  which has limited his activity levels. In addition  he has noticed ulcers on his right toes and a profound decrease in the temperature of his right foot when compared to his left foot. He denies having fever or chills. Upon physical examination  diminished pulses were noted in the right lower extremity along with skin pallor and thinning. Doppler study showed decreased blood flow in the right lower extremity. He also has decreased capillary refill in his right foot. He is currently on regular antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications. His compliance with medications is satisfactory. His family history is notable for peripheral artery disease in his father. The patient's symptoms and signs are concerning for critical limb ischemia  needing immediate vascular consultation.

A 68-year-old African-American male patient with a past medical history of severe peripheral artery disease  poorly controlled type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and a 40-pack year smoking history presents with severe rest pain in the right lower limb for the past 36 hours. The pain is associated with tingling and numbness and is rated 8/10 in severity. The rest pain has escalated over the past week  primarily disturbing his sleep. He reports intermittent claudication earlier in the week. He also reports non-healing wounds on his right foot; the largest is approximately 2 cm in diameter and reveals exposed bone. Physical examination reveals cold right foot with loss of hair  skin atrophy  pallor on elevation and dependent rubor. Pulsations in the right femoral  popliteal and dorsalis pedis arteries are absent. Neurological examination reveals decreased sensation to pain  temperature and touch below the right knee. Patient’s labs indicate elevated glucose and LDL levels. ABIs (Ankle-Brachial Index) were 0.4 and 0.85 in the right and left leg respectively.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus type II and smoking presents with severe pain in his left foot at rest. The pain has been experiencing for the past 3 weeks has exacerbated in the past 7 days. Upon inspection  he exhibits a non-healing ulcer on his left big toe  surrounding skin discoloration  and decreased sensation in the foot. He also reports an inability to walk due to pain  and coolness of the involved extremity. There is no history of trauma or injury to the foot. He has never had similar symptoms before. Note that he is on oral hypoglycemic agents and has a 45 pack-year smoking history. He denies any history of cardiovascular disease  hypertension  or hyperlipidemia.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old  Caucasian female  Medical History: History of type two diabetes mellitus (DM2) poorly controlled  dyslipidemia  hypertension  and active smoking of 20 pack-years.  Active Complaint: The patient presents to the outpatient vascular clinic with critical limb ischemia (CLI) symptoms; she has a two-month history of progressive rest pain in her right lower extremity  with shuffling gait  and numbness. Over the last week  she also noticed a non-healing ulcer located on her right forefoot. Her pain is partially relieved with opioids  but it has affected her sleep and quality of life. There is no history of fever or trauma.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  there is a 2 cm non-healing ulcer noticed on the plantar aspect of the right foot with mild purulent discharge. The peripheral pulses on the right leg  including dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial  are barely palpable  with a prolonged capillary refill time. There are also signs of atrophy in the right lower extremity compared to the left. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable  with normal sensorium  cranial nerves examination  and chest and abdomen examination.  Work-up: The patient will undergo necessary peripheral arterial disease (PAD) work-up  including routine blood  infective markers  HbA1c  renal function  Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  Doppler ultrasound  angiography (computed tomography or MR angiography for details of the lesion) for establishing the diagnosis and plan for revascularization technique.

A 62-year-old African American male  with a medical history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and twenty-pack-year smoking habit  presents to the clinic with worsening pain in his right leg that he describes as sharp and severe. The pain originally was intermittent or ""claudication"" but has now progressed to be persistent over the last few weeks. He also reports temperature differences between both legs. On examination  the right leg appears pale  especially in comparison with the left  with poor nail growth. There is also a poorly healing ulcer on the dorsal aspect of the right foot. Palpation confirms absence of pulses distal to the right femoral artery. These signs suggest critical limb ischemia in the context of longstanding peripheral artery disease which may be associated with his poorly managed atherosclerotic risk factors.

A 71-year-old African-American male with a known history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by peripheral neuropathy for the past 10 years  hypertension  and a 40-pack-year smoking history  presents with continuous severe pain at rest in the right foot for the last 2 weeks. He also reports a first-time discovery of a non-healing ulcer on the dorsal aspect of his right foot and recognized progressive discoloration involving the right foot. Upon examination  diminished pulse was noted in the anterior and posterior tibial arteries. He has non-pitting edema and the right foot is cold to touch with mottling observed. He has a history of intermittent claudication for which he has not sought medical attention. There is no reported history of cardiac disease or stroke. The patient’s pain is aggravated by elevation of the limb and relieved by handing it down. His current medications are Metformin  Lisinopril  Atorvastatin and Aspirin.

Mr. Smith  a 65-year-old African American male  with a 20-year-history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  and a 40 pack-year smoking history comes to the clinic complaining of severe left lower leg pain at rest for the past two weeks. He reports intermittent claudication over the past six months  which has progressively worsened. Recently  he has also noticed an ulcer on the left lower leg which refuses to heal. He complains of difficulty in walking and experiences pain even at rest. On evaluation  the left lower extremity is cooler than the right  with diminished pulses in the left foot. There is a non-healing ulcer measuring 2.5 cm on the dorsum of the left foot and the left great toe. The patient also reports a significant unintentional weight loss over the past six months. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.

A 66-year-old African-American male  with a known medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension and a 40-pack-year smoking history  presented with a complaint of chronic  non-healing wounds on the right foot accompanied by severe rest pain  particularly at night  for the past 4 weeks. On physical examination  the foot was observed to be pale and cold with diminished pulses and there is evidence of necrotic tissue around the wounds. The patient also reported significant unintentional weight loss over the past 2 months.

A 72-year-old African American male  a smoker with a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  peripheral artery disease  and hypertension  presents with worsening rest pain in his right lower leg. Over the last four weeks  he has experienced intensified pain that disrupts his sleep. Additionally  he has noticed a non-healing  dusky ulcer measuring 2x2 cm on his right great toe. Clinical examination reveals a markedly decreased popliteal and absent dorsalis pedis and posterior tibialis pulses in the right leg  along with bluish discoloration and coldness of the foot. The left leg shows decreased but palpable pulses. He denies chest pain  dyspnea  or other systemic symptoms. Critical limb ischemia driven by long-standing peripheral artery disease and superimposed diabetes mellitus is suspected.

An 83-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease (PAD) presents with increasing pain in his right lower extremity over the past two weeks. The pain is worsened with activity and somewhat relieved by rest  but lately has been persisting at rest as well. On further examination  he describes intermittent non-healing ulcers on his right foot over the past month and a half and marked difficulty walking due to pain. He also confirms having cold sensation in the limb and noticed the skin of his right foot and leg looking pale. This patient's presentations suggest critical limb ischemia (CLI) secondary to progressive PAD – an ominous sign indicating severe arterial disease.

A 65-year-old African American male with a known medical history of diabetes mellitus and 25 years of strong nicotine dependence presents with complaints of rest pain in his left lower limb which has been aggravating for the past two weeks. The pain seems to worsen at night and while in a recumbent position. He also reports foot cramps and a non-healing wound on his left foot measuring approximately 2cm in diameter. On physical examination  the patient's left foot appears pale with an absent dorsalis pedis pulse. Distally  the foot is cold to touch with noticeable loss of hair on the toes and foot. The toenails appear thickened and discolored. He also has a non-blanching  circular ulcer with a foul smell on the lateral aspect of the foot. The patient denies any history of trauma  deep venous thrombosis  or peripheral arterial disease. No history of recent hospitalization or surgery. He has never been screened for peripheral arterial disease despite his high risk status.

A 75-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and 50-pack-year smoking history  now presents with severe  constant rest pain in his right lower extremity that has been progressively worsening over the past two weeks. The pain is described as burning and sharp  located at the feet  and is notably worse at night. The patient also reports a non-healing ulcer on his right foot along with noticeable changes in his skin color to a bluish tinge suggesting cyanosis  further associated with an unpleasant odor. He denies any history of trauma  fever  or chills. Upon examination  right foot is cold to the touch  distal pulses are absent  and there is a loss of hair around the lesion and distally. There is a presence of a 2 X 3 cm necrotic wound with evidence of infection on his right great toe. He also reports a significant weight loss over the same period due to reduced appetite secondary to pain. These symptoms suggest the patient is suffering from critical limb ischemia.

A 66-year-old African American male  known hypertensive  diabetic  and heavy smoker  presents with an intense  persistent pain in his left lower extremity  which worsens upon walking  and a non-healing ulcer on the left foot. The pain has been progressively worsening over the past three weeks and is now accompanied by a noticeable coldness of the foot and weakness  resulting in difficulty walking. Examination reveals weak distal pulses  pallor on elevation of the limb and dependent rubor. The patient's symptoms present a typical picture of Critical Limb Ischemia likely due to Peripheral Artery Disease  worsened by his comorbid conditions and lifestyle choices.

A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and a 20-pack-year smoking habit  presents with severe right leg pain that has worsened over the past month. The pain  initially intermittent claudication progressing to critical limb ischemia  is worse at rest and often awakens him from sleep. He reports recent non-healing ulcers on his right foot and complains about feeling coldness in the same leg. He denies chest pain or shortness of breath. On examination  his right lower extremity is cold to touch  pallor on elevation  dependent rubor  marked decreased pulses with an ABI of 0.4  and has gangrenous changes of his first and second toe. The left foot exam is significant for dry skin  onychomycosis and decreased dorsalis pedis pulse. Current medications include metformin  lisinopril and aspirin.

A 68-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for type II Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  and Chronic Kidney Disease  presents with worsening 3-week history of increasingly severe rest pain in his right leg. The patient reports the pain as sharp  with a severity of 8/10  which worsens at night. He also reported persistent numbness and tingling in his right leg that has been progressively getting worse over the last 2 weeks. He reported having noticed a wound on his big toe that has not improved or healed. Upon examination  the affected leg was found to be cold to touch compared to the other  had diminished pedal pulses and weak popliteal pulse. The wound on the toe identified by the patient was a dry gangrene with clear demarcation. The patient also reported having a history of intermittent claudication  especially when walking up the stairs but has observed a decrease in the distance he can walk without feeling pain over time. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history and was on daily low-dose aspirin  statins  ACE inhibitors  and insulin therapy for his chronic diseases. The recent onset and worsening of ischemic rest pain  numbness and gangrenous wound indicates critical limb ischemia.

Patient is a 75-year-old African American male with a known history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  presenting with severe worsening pain at rest in his left lower limb for the past 48 hours. Pain is described as sharp  worse at night  and unrelieved by analgesics. There is associated numbness  and his foot appears mottled and cold to touch. He denies any history of trauma. He has significant past surgical history of right below-knee amputation secondary to critical limb ischemia two years ago  which was complicated by chronic kidney disease stage IV. He is a former smoker with a 50-pack-year history  but quit smoking post amputation. He has mild dyslipidemia and long-standing peripheral arterial disease. No known allergies. He takes regular insulin  metformin  Lisinopril  Atorvastatin and Aspirin. Previous attempts for limb revascularization were unsuccessful. Family history reveals father died with complications of stroke and mother has diabetes. His BMI is 30  heart rate 96 bpm  blood pressure155/96 mmHg  respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min  and his oxygen saturation is normal on room air.

Patient is a 72-year-old male with a known medical history of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia who presents with rest pain in the right lower extremity for the past week. He also reports a non-healing ulcer on the right foot for 3 weeks. Symptoms are worse during the night and relieved with dangling the leg from the side of the bed  without any improvement with analgesics. On examination  his right foot is cold with diminished pulses and he has a 2 cm non-healing ulcer in the medial aspect of the right foot. The ankle-brachial index(ABI) is 0.4 on the right side  suggesting critical limb ischemia. Monofilament testing reveals loss of protective sensation in the right foot  consistent with diabetic peripheral neuropathy.

A 70-year-old African-American male with a 5-year history of poorly managed type 2 diabetes and peripheral artery disease  presents with acute onset of excruciating pain in his left lower leg. The pain intensifies at rest and at night. Once reliant on his walking stick  he has now become progressively less mobile over the last 3 weeks due to the severity of the pain and has developed a non-healing ulcer on his left big toe. He has no known allergies but admits to a 30-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes per day. The patient also notes intermittent claudication  more intense in his left leg and left foot coldness. He has lost 10 pounds unintentionally in the span of a month. His current medications include metformin and aspirin. No history of surgical interventions. Family history includes a brother who had a toe amputation due to diabetes. His vital signs show a BP of 140/75 mmHg  a heart rate of 85 bpm  and an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male  ex-smoker with a history of type 2 diabetes and peripheral arterial disease  presents to the ER with acute onset of severe rest pain  non-healing ulcers  and black discoloration of the right foot. The pain has been progressively worsening over the past 48 hours and is unrelieved by analgesics. Physical examination revealed decreased capillary refill time  cold skin  weak absent pulses in the affected limb  and signs of significant weight loss. Doppler ultrasound demonstrated decreased blood flow in the distal part of the limb. The patient has background retinopathy and chronic kidney disease due to longstanding DM. Current medications include metformin and a statin. His compliance with medications has been good. His family history was significant for coronary artery disease. This patient’s presentation and background suggest critical limb ischemia  possibly secondary to worsening peripheral arterial disease.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a long-standing history of poorly controlled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and peripheral artery disease presents with worsening lower left limb pain for the past week. The pain particularly worsens when he walks  easing somewhat when he is at rest. However  over the past two days  the pain has been persistent and severe  even at rest. Patient describes the pain as a deep  aching discomfort. He notes associated color changes in his foot  converting from regular appearance to a pale color. He also reports that his left foot feels unusually cold compared to the right. On physical examination  his left foot appears pale and shiny with some visible hair loss. These symptoms of rest pain  color changes  and cold foot represent critical limb ischemia  likely related to his uncontrolled diabetes and pre-existing peripheral artery disease.

A 67-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and a 30-pack-year smoking history  presents with gradually progressive pain in his right lower limb over the past 6 months. He describes the pain as a severe  persistent burning sensation that primarily affects his foot  worsens with leg elevation  and partially relieves with leg hanging down. He also reports rest pain interrupting his sleep at night. Upon physical examination  his right foot appears pale and cold with slow capillary refilling  weakly palpable pedal pulses  and presence of non-healing ulcers at the tips of his toes. The patient also mentions significant involuntary weight loss due to diminished appetite. No notable family history of peripheral artery disease or related conditions. Review of systems was otherwise unremarkable.

Patient is a 75-year-old African American male  known case of hypertension and long-standing Type II diabetes mellitus  presenting with severe  constant rest pain (8/10 intensity) in his left leg for the past two weeks. The pain is associated with intermittent claudication and is exacerbated during any kind of activity. He reports non-healing ulceration on the left foot for the last 7 days. He also confirms experiencing occasional palpitations. There is a 30-pack year history of smoking. The patient denies drug use. He is a retired construction worker and lives with his wife who is his primary caregiver. His father passed away due to myocardial infarction and his mother was diabetic. On examination  left lower limb pulses  including dorsalis pedis and posterior tibialis are not palpable. There is mottling and coldness observed on the distal left lower leg and foot with an approximately 3 cm ulcer showing signs of infection and necrosis on the dorsal aspect of the left foot. Rest of the physical and neurological examination is normal. Initial investigations reveal elevated HbA1c and mildly elevated white cell count. The patient's problem represents critical limb ischemia  likely secondary to peripheral arterial disease with a possible superimposed infection.

A 70-year-old male patient  with a known medical history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (type 2)  hyperlipidemia  and chronic heavy tobacco use  presents with a 2-week story of pain in his left lower leg at rest. The pain worsens at night causing sleep disturbances and is associated with discoloration (pale when elevated and purple-red upon dependency)  coolness of the foot  and non-healing ulcers on the toes. On physical examination  there were absent pulses in the left foot and diminished popliteal pulses on the same side. The ankle-brachial index (ABI) is less than 0.5 on the left lower extremity  confirming reduced blood flow. This symptom complex suggests the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia.

An 80-year-old female with a history of uncontrolled Type II diabetes mellitus and peripheral arterial disease  now presenting with intense rest pain in her left lower extremity. She describes the pain as continuous and more severe at night. Her pain has been escalating over the past week. Physical examination reveals an absence of dorsalis pedis and posterior tibialis pulses in the affected limb and dry gangrene on the left foot. The limb is cold to touch  and she also reports that she is unable to lift her left foot at the ankle suggesting possible peripheral neuropathy. The patient has intermittent claudication (pain while walking) over the past three months  suggesting the presence of long standing arterial insufficiency. She also has episodes of non-healing ulcers over the past two months. Her other significant medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

Patient is a 69-year-old Hispanic male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  peripheral arterial disease (PAD)  and smoking  presents with non-healing ulcers on the dorsum of his left foot for approximately 3 weeks. The patient experiences pronounced rest pain  particularly at night. The pain is described as a continuous  severe burning sensation that extends from the heel to the toes that gets slightly relieved on dangling his foot. On physical examination  there is noticeable hair loss on the distal portion of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. The foot feels cold to touch and peripheries are cyanotic with absent pedal pulses. The wound on the dorsum appears full-thickness with a necrotic base  surrounding epidermal detachment  and foul-smelling discharge suggestive of potential infection. He has been experiencing intermittent claudication over the last year during moderate to high-intensity walking activities that subsided at rest. There is a major concern for critical limb ischemia.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents with persistent pain in the right lower leg. The patient notes the pain has been becoming gradually worse over the last 3 weeks and is now associated with rest pain  particularly at night  and non-healing ulcers on his right foot. On further inquiry  he admits to being a former smoker with 30 pack years history  who quit 5 years back. Physical exam reveals a cold right lower leg with diminished peripheral pulses and cyanosis. The right foot shows a black discoloration in the toe regions. Both the ABI and Doppler ultrasound support a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia.

A 67-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for smoking  uncontrolled hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with severe resting pain in his right foot for the past 1 week. The patient also reports rapid progression of tissue loss on his foot over the last 4 days characterized by dry gangrene on the right hallux. He also describes intermittent claudication occurring at less than half a block  which has led to significant difficulty in walking. He denies any chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  but admits to poor glycemic control and adhering poorly to his antihypertensive medication. His family history is significant for peripheral artery disease (PAD) in a brother. On physical exam  the right lower extremity is cold to touch from mid-calf down  pulses are non-palpable in the right foot  and there is a black discoloration of the right hallux. This presentation is consistent with right lower extremity critical limb ischemia  possibly secondary to severe peripheral artery disease.

A 67-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  peripheral artery disease (PAD)  and 40-pack year smoking history  presents with severe rest pain in the right lower extremity that has progressively worsened over the past two weeks. He describes it as a sharp pain  located in the calf and foot  which intensifies when he's in bed and prevents him from sleeping. He also presents with non-healing ulcers on the toes of his right foot. On physical examination  his right foot appears pale  cold to touch with weak distal pulses  capillary refill time is greater than 3 seconds  and he has a loss of hair on the lower leg. His blood pressure is within the normal range. His Ankle-brachial index (ABI) test shows low values  suggestive of severe PAD.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of heavy smoking  uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and peripheral artery disease presents with severe rest pain in his right lower extremity extending from his hip to his foot for the past two weeks. The pain  described as sharp and 10/10 in intensity  is worsened with elevation of the limb and slightly relieved at rest in a dependent position. The patient also reports a non-healing ulcer on the sole of his right foot for the past month despite ongoing wound care. On physical examination  the leg appears pale with elevation and dusky red when dependent. It is cool to touch  and distal pulses are not palpable. The foot ulcer is poorly defined  deep with black necrotic tissue on the base. There is associated severe nocturnal pain disturbing the patient's sleep and causing significant distress. Given this clinical presentation  this patient is suffering from Critical Limb Ischemia  the severe manifestation of peripheral artery disease.

A 72-year-old African-American male with a known medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  peripheral artery disease (PAD)  and chronic smoking  presents to the clinic with progressively worsening rest pain in the right lower extremity  especially at night. He's noticed a non-healing ulcer on his right toe for the past two weeks. On examination  there is decreased temperature  mild pallor  and loss of hair in the distal part of the right leg. Pulses in the right lower extremity are diminished compared to the left. The wound on his toe is noted to measure approximately 1.5 centimeters in diameter  its base is pale and covered in slough. The findings are highly suggestive of a late-stage peripheral artery disease known as critical limb ischemia.

A 72-year-old African American female with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents with severe rest pain in her right lower extremity for the past week. The patient describes the pain most intense in her foot  especially at night. She has experienced intermittent claudication over the past 6 months  but this has become significantly worse over the past couple of weeks. She has also noted the skin on her foot appears pale  cool to touch  and has small non-healing ulcers on the big toe. She reports no history of smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use. Family history is significant for peripheral artery disease in her mother. Patient denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncopal episodes. Her diabetes is poorly controlled with a recent Hemoglobin A1C of 9.0%  and she has associated peripheral neuropathy. She has been non-compliant with her antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications. Her pulses in the right foot are not palpable  and an ankle-brachial index on the right is 0.4. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

A 64-year-old African American male with a history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-year pack history of smoking presents with severe pain in his right lower extremity for the past two weeks. The patient reports a gradual onset of rest pain which has exacerbated over the last three days. He states that the pain is primarily located in his foot and becomes worse at night  making sleep challenging. Upon further investigation  the patient also reports ulceration on his right toe  which has shown no healing progress within their period of appearance. He experiences a loss of sensation and a marked decrease in the temperature of the right foot compared to the left. He denies episodes of fever  chills or any systemic symptoms. On physical examination  there's a notable absence of the right pedal pulse. Previous management of his ailments includes daily oral antidiabetic and antihypertensive medication  along with prescribed statins for high cholesterol and attempts at smoking cessation. The patient's uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension  along with his history of hyperlipidemia and significant smoking history  make him a high-risk candidate for peripheral artery disease with current critical limb ischemia.

A 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Peripheral Arterial Disease  previous tobacco use  and Hypertension  presents with severe rest pain in his right foot and two non-healing ulcers  one on his right foot and the other at the lateral surface of the right lower leg. He reports a progressive worsening of the pain  especially at night. He also notes an intermittent claudication distance of less than 100 meters and persistent coldness of the right lower extremity with associated numbness and paresthesia. Physical examination confirms distal right leg atrophy  loss of hair growth on foot  coolness of the skin to touch  and a significantly reduced pulse strength in the right foot. He has not had any fever  weight loss  or notable trauma in the recent past.

Mr. Smith  a 75-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-year pack history of smoking presents to the ED with severe rest pain in his right lower extremity for the past two days. The pain is constant  worse at night  and is associated with some color changes (pallor initially  now appears dusky) and coldness to the touch. The patient also reports 2 episodes of non-healing ulcerations on his right foot over the past year. He denies any recent trauma  insect bites  or fever. His vitals are stable. On physical examination  the right lower extremity is cold with sluggish capillary refill  no palpable pulses (femoral  popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial)  and there is an ulceration on the right heel with some black eschar. There is also significant hair loss on the right lower extremity. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. The symptoms and findings are suggestive of right lower extremity critical limb ischemia likely secondary to peripheral artery disease  complicated by a non-healing foot ulcer. Immediate vascular surgery consultation  diagnostic angiography  and potential revascularization are indicated  given the severity of symptoms  limb threat status  and high risk associated with the patient's comorbidities.

A 66-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and past tobacco use  presents with severe rest pain and non-healing ulcers on his right lower limb for the past 3 weeks. The patient reports experiencing worsening pain mainly at night  alleviated by hanging the leg over the bed. The pain score is 8/10  described as a burning sensation  with occasional numbness  located on the lower leg and foot. On physical examination  there are two palpable non-healing ulcers  one on the ankle (2 cm x 1.5 cm) and the other on the heel (1 cm x 1 cm)  characterized by pale granulation tissue  with peripheral callus formation. Decreased skin temperature  absence of dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses  and pallor on elevation  and dependent rubor in the right foot were noted too with a ABI score of 0.30 in the right lower limb. He also has a notable history of non-compliance with medication due to the lack of health insurance.

A 74-year-old male African American patient with a known history of poorly controlled diabetes  peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and hypertension  presents with increasing pain in his right lower extremity  rest pain  and non-healing wounds on the great toe. He also reports intermittent claudication along with noticeable changes in skin color and loss of hair on the affected leg. He has been a heavy smoker for the past 40 years. He has undergone angioplasty twice before. He is significantly distressed by the rest pain and his corresponding inability to maintain his daily activities.

Demographics: A 70-year-old male.   Medical History: Known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 20 years  with suboptimal glycemic control. A known smoker with a 50 pack-year history.  Presentation: The patient presents with severe rest pain in the right leg  predominantly at the calf and foot regions  most noticeably preventing sleep at night for the last two weeks. The patient also reported the presence of non-healing ulcers on his right foot. On examination  the limb appears pale and cold on palpation  with diminished peripheral pulses. Digital palpation revealed delayed capillary refill and there was a loss of sensation over the foot. Doppler ultrasound revealed markedly reduced ankle-brachial index (ABI) on the right side. Absence of hair on the skin over the leg and the presence of shiny  taut  and dry skin are other observed findings.

A 72-year-old African-American male  with a past medical history of diabetes  hyperlipidaemia and 30-pack year smoking history  presents with a 1-month history of severe rest pain in his left lower limb  which has significantly worsened in the last week. He also reports a non-healing ulcer over the left medial malleolus  noticed around two weeks ago. He denies trauma or injury. On physical exam  the left lower extremity is cold to touch  with diminished pulses  a painful non-healing ulcer  and noticeable muscle atrophy. He has no fever or chills  but reports difficulty in sleeping due to the pain  which significantly impairs his quality of life. The patient's symptoms and history suggest critical limb ischemia  likely related to severe peripheral arterial disease  due to long-standing risk factors including diabetes and smoking.

A 68-year-old male smoker with a history of uncontrolled diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease  presents with rest pain in his right lower extremity for the past month. The pain is severe enough to interrupt his sleep and is associated with non-healing ulcers on his foot and noticeable color changes. There is no history of trauma or injury to the foot. On examination  right lower limb shows pallor  loss of hair  absent foot pulses  presence of multiple non-healing ulcers on digits  and superficial skin necrosis indicative of critical limb ischemia. Additionally  he complains of a significant weight loss during the month.

An 80-year-old white male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus  hypertension  peripheral arterial disease  and a 60-pack-year smoking history  presents with severe resting pain in his right lower leg for the past several days. The pain has progressively gotten worse and is associated with deterioration in the color of his foot which appears dusky and non-palpable pedis pulse. He also reports minor non-healing wounds on the leg. He admits difficulty walking due to pain and has suffered from a disturbing sleep pattern due to nighttime leg pain. Physical examination shows a cold  pale extremity with sparse hair  decreased sensation plus visible skin changes with dry  scaling lesions and ulceration on the tips of toes.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with significant past medical history of uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes Melitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 year pack history of smoking presents with severe  worsening pain in his lower left leg  even at rest. The pain is described as sharp and burning which has become continuous over the past 1 week. The patient also complains of intermittent claudication  non-healing sores and noticeable color change in his lower leg. On examination  decreased hair growth  dry and shiny skin on the leg  weak or absence of pulses  coldness in lower leg  loss of muscle mass  and pale blueish discoloration of the skin are found.

A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled type II diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year smoking history  presents with a six-month history of worsening bilateral lower extremity pain. The pain is severe  persistent  involving both rest and exertion  and is associated with non-healing ulcers on both feet. On physical examination  his lower limbs are cold to touch with diminished peripheral pulses  presence of ischemic rest pain  and numbness. His toenails are thickened and skin is shiny and atrophic. His ulcers show signs of grave ischemia with localized gangrene. He also reports significant weight loss due to reduced diet from fear of exacerbating the pain associated with meals. These symptoms are suggestive of critical limb ischemia necessitating immediate medical attention.

A 65-year-old  African-American  male patient with a known history of poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus and peripheral artery disease presents with steadily worsening pain in his right lower limb over the last three weeks. He also reports loss of sensation and color changes in the limb  with the foot appearing pale and cool to the touch. The deterioration of his limb is consistent with the non-healing ulcer on the right heel  coupled with an inability to walk due to the severe pain  even at rest. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medications. He is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history  currently non-active for the last 5 years. The presenting symptoms are suggestive of critical limb ischemia.

A 62-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and 15-pack-year smoking  presented with critical limb ischemia. He complains of severe resting pain in his right foot of three weeks duration  associated with non-healing ulcer on his right heel. He describes the pain as sharp and constant  with no relieving factors. He also reports progressive color change of his foot ranging from pallor when elevated to duskiness in dependent position. On physical examination  the foot is cold to touch with weak pulses  a non-healing ulcer is noted on the right heel and the patient exhibits pain on passive movement of the toes. Additional notable findings include loss of hair in the lower limbs  toenail changes and dry  scaly skin.
