A 65-year-old African-American male  retired police officer  with a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and peripheral arterial disease  presents with progressive bilateral lower limb pain at rest and non-healing ulcers on his right foot. Pain is described as severe  consistent  and not eased with over-the-counter medication. He reports accompanying symptoms of noticeable coldness in his feet and a decline in his ability to walk over the past three weeks due to the combination of pain and weakness. A known smoker for the past 40 years  he has a BMI of 28.9 with diet-controlled hypercholesterolemia. There is no known family history of peripheral arterial disease. Upon physical examination  distal pulses in both lower limbs are markedly decreased and there is pallor on elevation of the right foot. He has also noticed a decrease in hair growth on his lower legs.

A 55-year-old African-American male with a known history of poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack-year smoking history presents with three weeks of progressive  severe  and rest pain in his left lower extremity  which has now escalated to intense pain requiring opioid medication. The pain is notably worse when the leg is elevated and improves slightly with dependency. He also has local wounds on the left foot that have failed to improve with topical treatment over the last week and are associated with minimal serous discharge. He complained of an inability to walk due to severe pain and a feeling of coldness in his left foot. On physical examination  the left foot appeared pale with diminished pedal and posterior tibial pulses  cold to touch compared to the right foot  and there were non-healing ulcers on the distal end of the left foot. Pain is elicited upon raising the leg to a 30-degree angle within 1 minute. No observable edema. Previous related interventions include medication for diabetes and hypertension.

A 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and 40 pack-year smoking habit  presents with excruciating pain in his left lower extremity  especially at rest. He reports his symptoms having persisted for the last three weeks and progressively worsening. He was unable to sleep due to the pain and noticed that his left foot appeared pale and felt cold to touch. He also has ulceration and gangrene in his left foot. Upon physical examination  he had a significantly diminished dorsalis pedis pulse on the left side. His ankle-brachial index (ABI) was below 0.4 on the left side. He had no history of intervention on his vascular system. The findings are consistent with critical limb ischemia.

A 72-year-old white male  lifetime smoker with a medical history of poorly controlled Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease  presents with a 3-day history of rest pain in his right lower extremity. The pain is a 10/10  severe  persistent  and worsening  and disrupts his sleep. He also reports a non-healing ulcer on his right foot  present for the past 3 weeks. Upon physical examination  the right foot appears pale with poor capillary refill. Pedal pulses are absent and the foot is cold to touch. Patient also reports significantweight loss in the past few months. His previous medications include daily doses of metformin  losartan  and aspirin. His last HbA1c check  3 months ago  was 8.6%.

Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for diabetes mellitus type 2  peripheral artery disease  hypertension  and a 30-pack year smoking history. He presents with complaints of worsening pain in his left lower extremity  mainly concentrated at the calf and foot  that has gradually escalated over the past few weeks. Pain is particularly intense at rest and often wakes him up at night. On observation  the skin of the left lower limb appears pale  shiny  pulseless with marked loss of hair growth  and some non-healing ulcers are noted on the foot. He reports a significant decline in his walking distance and notes that he experiences severe pain after walking only a few meters  hence stopped going out due to the intensity of the pain. He has not noticed any similar symptoms in the right lower extremity.

Patient is a 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  peripheral artery disease (PAD)  and hypertension. He presents with a 3-day history of acute rest pain in his right lower leg accompanied by non-healing ulcers on the toes. Physical examination revealed a cold  cyanotic right foot with weak arterial pulses  pallor on elevation  and dependent rubor. Pedal pulses are non-palpable. ABI (Ankle Brachial Index)  typically low in this population  was indeed low – at 0.4. These symptoms and signs suggest the likely onset of critical limb ischemia (CLI)  presumably secondary to severe PAD exacerbated by poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension.

A 67-year-old African American male with a 30-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus poorly controlled on metformin  and a 25 pack-year history of smoking presents with a 6-week history of rest pain in his lower left limb. He reports his foot often feels numb  and he has observed a lack of hair growth on that leg. He mentions the pain worsens when he raises his limb  and relieves when he hangs his leg over the bed. Upon examination  distal pulses are not palpable in the left leg  and the skin temperature is notably decreased compared to other areas. There are non-healing wounds on the dorsal surface of his left foot. Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) revealed a reading of 0.50 suggesting critical limb ischemia. The patient's BMI is 29 and he has a past history of hyperlipidemia managed with statins. He denies any chest pain or previous symptoms of coronary artery disease. Other significant history includes hypertension controlled on medication and early-stage chronic kidney disease.

A 72-year-old African American male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  tobacco smoking  and peripheral artery disease presents with escalating severe rest pain in his right leg over the past six weeks. The pain  which is worse at night  prevents him from sleeping. He also reports intermittent claudication while walking short distances over the last few years  and significant weight loss due to decreased appetite. Physical examination reveals skin pallor  absent peripheral pulses in the right leg  and a non-healing wound on his right foot with evidence of gangrene. The patient also has diminished sensation in peripheral limbs  suggesting diabetic neuropathy. His history of previous bypass surgery in the same leg  seven years ago  raises suspicion of graft occlusion. His lab work shows elevated fasting glucose levels and HbA1c  indicating poorly controlled diabetes. Ankle-brachial index confirms a significant drop in the right leg  consistent with advanced peripheral artery disease. The overall clinical scenario signifies critical limb ischemia due to progressive peripheral arterial disease precipitated by diabetes and tobacco abuse.

An 80-year-old Caucasian male with a known medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease presents with 3 weeks of progressive rest pain in his right lower extremity. The pain is severe  waking him up at night  and is associated with non-healing ulcers on the dorsal aspect of the right foot. He also reports noticeable pallor and coolness in his right foot compared with the left and has had difficulty walking due to the pain. He denies any trauma or injury. He has a 40-pack year smoking history but quit 5 years ago. He is adherent to his medications including metformin  lisinopril  and aspirin. On physical examination  the right foot appeared pale with absent posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses. Two dry gangrenous ulcers were noticed on the dorsum of the right foot.

A 65-year-old African American male with a 20-year history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 40 pack-year smoking history presents with sudden severe pain and coolness in his left leg below the knee that started 12 hours ago. He also reports a 3-month history of intermittent claudication especially when walking up the stairs. He now also notices rest pain in the left foot especially at night and non-healing ulcers on the left toes. He denies chest pain  palpitations  or shortness of breath. Examination reveals a significantly diminished left pedal pulse  pale and cold left foot with non-palpable distal pulses  small necrotic ulcers on the left toes  and decreased sensation to pinprick in the left foot. No significant bruit over abdominal or iliac arteries. His blood pressure is 150/90  heart rate is 85 and regular  respiratory rate is 22  and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.

A 70-year-old African American male with a past medical history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertensive heart disease  and long-term heavy smoking presents with rest pain in his right foot. The patient also reports a nonhealing  painful ulceration on his right great toe that developed approximately 2 weeks ago. On examination  the patient's right lower extremity is noted to be cool to the touch  with weak pedal pulses and marked pallor elevation. His ankle-brachial index is significantly reduced suggesting severe peripheral artery disease. He reports severe pain  particularly at night  prompting him to keep his foot hanging off the edge of his bed in an attempt to relieve discomfort. He denies any history of claudication  chest pain  or transient ischemic attacks.

A 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes  peripheral artery disease  and hypertension  presents to the clinic with severe  recurrent pain at rest in his right lower extremity lasting for several weeks. The patient also reports non-healing ulcers on his right foot and toes. Physical examination reveals diminished pulses in the popliteal  posterior tibial  and dorsalis pedis arteries on the right side  and foot skin atrophy. He has a history of smoking two packs of cigarettes daily for the last 50 years. He has not been compliant with his home medications  his blood glucose and blood pressure levels have not been under control. An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) reveals a value of 0.5 on the right side  indicating severe arterial disease. With his presentation of chronic ischemic rest pain  non-healing wounds  and ABI value  he has a differential diagnosis of critical limb ischemia.

Patient is an 83-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for uncontrolled Type-II Diabetes Mellitus  hypertension  and 50-pack year smoking history  presenting with a one-week history of progressive severe rest pain in his right lower extremity  non-healing ulcers on his right foot  and mild loss of sensation. He reports the pain is worse at night and a bit relieved when he dangles his foot off the bed. Physical examination reveals decreased pulses  cold and pale foot  and necrotic tissue around the foot ulcers. The patient also suffers from noticeable weight loss and limited mobility due to the pain. No history of intermittent claudication. No known allergy on medications. Patient is socially active with a history of occasional alcohol use. The symptoms and signs suggest critical limb ischemia with possible peripheral artery disease.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a history of heavy smoking  type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and high cholesterol presents with rest pain in the right lower extremity. He reports consistent  worsening pain over the last three months  which wakes him up at night. He also notes the development of non-healing sores on his right foot. Physical examination reveals pallor  diminished pulses in the right lower extremity  coolness on touch below the right knee  and multiple necrotic ulcers on the right foot. The patient is diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia secondary to severe peripheral arterial disease.

A 72-year-old African-American female with a medical history significant for long-standing uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type 2  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension presents with progressively worsening rest pain in her right lower extremity over the past 2 weeks  which now interrupts her sleep. Examination reveals non-healing ulcerations on her right foot and decreased right lower extremity pulses. Her history and examination are consistent with right lower extremity critical limb ischemia.

John Doe is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a relevant medical history of Type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  PAD (peripheral arterial disease)  hypertension  and a 30-packs/year smoking history who presents with severe calf pain  non-healing sores in his right foot  and persistent rest pain for the last three weeks. He also reports having experienced an unintentional weight loss of about 15 pounds over the past 6 months. On examination  there are dry necrotic ulcers at the tip of the right toe  poor nail growth  and an absence of distal pulses in the right foot indicating decreased blood flow. The pain worsens upon elevation of foot and decreases when foot is at rest or dangled  indicating critical limb ischemia.

A 65-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and a 20-pack year smoking history presents with non-healing ulcers on his left foot that started 2 weeks ago. The patient notes severe rest pain in the foot during the past few days  described as a continuous burning sensation that worsens at night with additional numbness and weakness. He also states reduced sensation in the limb and decreased temperature in comparison to the other limb. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. He has not been compliant with his medication due to financial concerns. His family history is significant for heart disease and stroke. His blood pressure is 150/90  pulse 72  and appearance pale and sweaty. Physical examination reveals pallor and coolness of the extremities  absent pedal pulses  and non-healing ulcers on his foot. An initial ischemic rest pain has gradually turned into tissue loss  leading to the suspicion of critical limb ischemia.

Mr. Brown  a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and a 40-pack-year smoking history  presents with a three-week history of non-healing wound on his left lower extremity. The wound is accompanied by rest pain described as a constant  severe burning pain that often gets worse during the night. He also reports a recent history of claudication symptoms  with pain in the calf muscles during minimal activity such as walking. His history also indicates that the signs and symptoms have been progressive with the worsening of pain and lack of improvement in the wound condition despite prior treatments. Physical examination reveals a cool left foot with diminished dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses. The wound is around 3 cm in diameter located on the dorsal aspect of the foot with visible gangrenous changes and signs of infection noted. A palpable contralateral femoral pulse is diminished with mono-phasic flow on handheld doppler. There has been a noticeable loss of hair on the left lower leg. His blood pressure is 130/65 mmHg and blood sugars are poorly controlled with HbA1C at 8.5%. He is at risk for critical limb ischemia needing immediate intervention.

A 72-year-old African American male  with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and 40-pack year smoking history  now presents with a 3-week duration of escalating rest pain in his right lower extremity. The pain intensifies when he lies flat and partially alleviates when he dangles his foot off his bed. He has also noticed a non-healing ulcer on his right big toe accompanied by color change to purple. He denies any prior history of claudication  significant weight loss or fevers. His physical examination reveals diminished pulses in the right distal extremity with a cold  pale foot and absent dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses bilaterally. The toe ulcer is 2 cm in diameter and involves the full thickness of the skin.

A 68-year-old African American male with a known medical history of long-standing uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presents with severe pain in his left foot  that has been progressively worsening over the past few weeks. The patient describes the pain as constant  burning  and worsened at night  with no relief from over-the-counter pain medications. The pain also intensifies when his foot is elevated. On physical examination  the patient’s left foot is markedly pale and cool to touch  with signs of dry gangrene noted on the toes. Pulses in the left foot are barely palpable and the ankle-brachial index is 0.4 indicating impaired blood flow. No ulcers or edema were present. His blood glucose levels are above target ranges and he reports non-compliance with his antihypertensive medications. The patient has a 40-pack year history of smoking and admits to having quit 3 years ago. He denies any known history of heart disease or stroke. He underwent angioplasty of the right leg for peripheral arterial disease 2 years ago. The patient is not on any anticoagulant therapy.

A 76-year-old Caucasian male  lifelong smoker with a known medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease (PAD)  presents with complaints of severe rest pain in his right lower extremity for the past one week. The pain is noticed predominantly in the foot and is worse at night  disturbing his sleep frequently. He also mentions non-healing ulcers on his right toes. He denies any trauma or application of any topical agents to these areas prior to the onset of the symptoms. He also reports occasional episodes of claudication. He has a significant history of not adhering to his medication regimen including insulin and antihypertensives. Objectively  the patient appears in distress due to pain. Physical examination reveals an absence of both popliteal and dorsalis pedis pulses in the affected limb  pale and mottled skin  non-healing necrotic ulcers on the tips of right toes  and reduced sensation in the lower limb. No known drug allergies. The patient lives alone with assistance from a part-time caregiver. His dietary history is characterized by a high intake of saturated fats and poor glycemic control.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known 15-year history of type II diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents with severe  persistent pain in the lower right leg  most intensively around the calf  and a non-healing wound on the right foot. The pain persists even at rest and is escalated while walking  resulting in significant limited mobility. On physical examination  the extremity appears discolored with a palpably weak pulse. The patient reports intermittent numbness and coldness in the affected leg and has recently experienced significant unintentional weight loss.

A 71-year-old African American male  a smoker with a significant past medical history of hypertension  poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus type 2 for 15 years  and peripheral artery disease presents with progressive worsening of pain at rest in his right lower limb for the past four weeks. The pain is severe  located in the calf and foot  and is not relieved by changing positions. He also noticed the development of non-healing ulcers on the same foot. The patient reports significant weight loss in the past two months as he avoids eating to prevent the severe post-meal pain. Examination reveals a pale  cold right foot with absent peripheral pulses  a necrotic ulcer on the lateral aspect of the foot  atrophic skin changes  and shiny skin. His dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are non-palpable on the right foot  with capillary refill time more than 3 seconds. He also reports frequent  sleep-disturbing night cramps in his calf. He has not noticed similar symptoms in the left lower limb.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for smoking  uncontrolled type two diabetes  hypertension  and peripheral arterial disease presents to the clinic with severe rest pain in his left foot and calf that has progressively worsened over the past week. The patient reported a non-healing ulcer on his left heel and lower extremity hair loss. He has experienced symptoms of critical limb ischemia including his foot appearing pale when it is elevated and hyperemic when it is in a dependent position. The severe pain has disrupted his sleep and limits his mobility to the extent that he required a wheelchair for ambulation. His symptoms are consistent with worsening peripheral arterial disease leading to critical limb ischemia.

A 63-year-old African American male with a history of poorly managed type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents with severe rest pain in his lower limbs  particularly the right leg. The pain has been progressively increasing over the last month  with more intense pain over the last week. He states the pain becomes so intense at night that he needs to hang his leg over the side of the bed to alleviate it. Recently  he has also noticed a non-healing ulcer on his right big toe. Inspection reveals a dry gangrenous 2 cm ulcer on the right big toe and pale  cold extremities with absence of popliteal and dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally. Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) is 0.45 on the right side and 0.7 on the left side. Patient is a former smoker  having quit 12 years ago. There is no family history of peripheral artery disease (PAD).

A 65-year-old male patient with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 30-pack-year smoking habit presents with severe  persistent rest pain in his right lower leg of two weeks duration. The pain is so intense it interrupts his sleep. He reports bluish discoloration of his right foot and has noticed non-healing ulcers on his toes. Examination reveals weak right pedal pulses  cool skin temperature  and loss of hair on the right lower limb. By his history and physical exam  the patient has advanced stage of peripheral artery disease  suggestive of critical limb ischemia.

A 65-year-old African-American male  smoker with 10-pack year history  with known type-2 diabetes  peripheral arterial disease  and hypertension presents with a 3-week history of progressive pain in his left lower leg which worsens at night. He reports the pain is severe and does not receive relief after taking analgesics. Physical examination reveals pale and cold skin of the left leg  palpable popliteal artery but no distal pulses  and an ulcerated wound on the heel. He also has decreased sensation to touch in the leg and foot. The ankle-brachial index is 0.5 on the left side. He denies any chest pain or dyspnea. Rest of the examination is normal. The patient also mentions a history of significant weight loss over the past year  which was not intentional. He admitted to increased alcohol use over the last 5 years. Family history reveals his father experienced a below-knee amputation due to similar complications at an age similar to his.

A 65-year-old African American male with history of smoking  uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and peripheral artery disease presents with severe rest pain in his right lower limb  particularly at night. The pain has been progressively worse over the last three weeks  also associated with non-healing ulcer over right heel. Physical examination reveals a decrease in temperature and an absence of the right pedal pulses. The patient also demonstrated pallor on leg elevation and dusky red discoloration on leg dependency. No swollen joints  lesions or hematomas were noted otherwise. A comprehensive foot examination reveals dry skin  aneurysmal dilatations  hair loss  thickened nails and an ulcer with gangrenous changes on the heel of the right foot. The patient denied any fever  chills  or any recent trauma. He has no known drug allergies. His surgical history is negative and he hasn't been on any medications yet.

A 68-year-old African American male with a 25-year history of uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension  presents with increasing rest pain in his left leg  noticeable for the past month. The pain is most severe in the foot and exacerbated at night. He reports non-healing ulcers on his left big toe and lateral foot  first noticed 3 weeks ago. He has significant tobacco use history  with 40-pack years. He also has associated symptoms of weight loss and fatigability. No known family history of peripheral vascular disease. Notably  there is no history of claudication. On physical examination  the patient’s left foot is markedly cool with diminished dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses. Multiple ulcerations are evident on the left foot  the largest of which measures approximately 2 cm in diameter on the big toe. There is also noticeable muscle atrophy and hair loss on the left lower leg.

A 72-year-old male patient with a past medical history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus and peripheral arterial disease (PAD) presents with severe rest pain in his right leg that started about two weeks ago. He is a former smoker and quit 5 years ago. He mentions the pain is persistent even at rest  which is aggravated during cold weather and eased when the limb is lowered. He reveals ongoing issues of non-healing small ulcers between toes on his right foot over the past month. On examination  the patient is in distress  the right lower extremity is cold to touch  with noticeable hair loss  pallor on elevation  and delayed capillary refill. Pulses on the affected extremity are not palpable. These symptoms suggest critical limb ischemia (CLI) which is a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood-flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.

A 78-year-old African-American male patient with a past medical history significant for poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 45-pack years smoking history presents with severe  rest pain in his left lower limb particularly while sleeping at night. The pain is described as a dull ache and he rates it 8 on a scale of 10. The patient also reports having developed a non-healing ulcer on his left big toe that started as a small blister but worsened over a month. He denies fever but admits to unintentional weight loss. Physical examination reveals weak peripheral pulses in the left lower extremity  left foot cold to touch  atrophic skin changes  and a 2cm x 3cm ulcer on the plantar aspect of the left big toe with blackened edges and necrotic tissue at the base. His right limb appears normal with palpable pulses. The patient's blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg with otherwise normal vital signs. He takes metformin  lisinopril  atorvastatin  and occasional over-the-counter pain medication. He quit smoking 5 years ago. Labs show hemoglobin A1C at 8.5% (goal is under 7% for adults with diabetes) suggesting that his diabetes is poorly controlled  but other tests including renal function test  liver function test and lipid profile are within normal range. The patient lives alone and is retired. The combination of resting pain and a non-healing wound suggests the patient is suffering from a case of critical limb ischemia  risk factors include his age  race  male gender  longstanding uncontrolled diabetes  and smoking history.

A 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and a 40 pack-year smoking history  presents with a six-month evolution of progressive right lower limb pain. He describes the pain as burning and severe  which intensifies when his leg is at rest. It is so severe that it wakes him up at night  seriously affecting his sleep quality. The pain is partially relieved when his limb is in a dependent position. In addition  over the last month he has noted a slowly healing wound on his right heel and has recently noticed his right foot turning a pale and cool to touch. He denies any fever  chills  or any changes in other parts of his body. His family history reveals that both his parents had peripheral artery disease. He has been non-compliant with his diabetic medications and has had an irregular follow up. His last HbA1c  done 8 months ago  was 9.2%.

A 65-year-old African American male with a history of long-term  uncontrolled type II diabetes  peripheral arterial disease  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic with severe pain in his left lower limb. The pain has been progressive and persistent over the past three weeks  impeding his ability to participate in daily activities and interfering with his sleep. He reports that the pain is present even at rest. He also complains of increasing fatigue. Upon examination  the physician noted the absence of a palpable pulse in the affected limb  coldness of the foot  and non-healing ulcers on the posterior aspect of his foot. He has a smoking history of 30 pack-years and denies any alcohol or drug abuse. His medications include insulin  statins  and antihypertensives. His family history is positive for cardiovascular disease. He has no known drug allergies.

Patient is a 72-year-old Hispanic male  long-term smoker with known history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus type 2 and peripheral artery disease. He presents with acute onset  severe rest pain in his right lower leg which started about a week ago  accompanied by non-healing ulcers on the toes of the same foot. He also reports progressive fatigue  recent weight loss  and notable limitation of physical activities due to pain. On examination  the right foot is cold to touch with diminished pulses  signs of cyanosis  and signs of local infection around foot ulcers. Patient displays an overall unhealthy lifestyle with poor diet  sedentary behavior  and continued heavy smoking. He has been non-compliant with prescribed medication for diabetes and peripheral artery disease  consists of metformin and statin therapy respectively. He denies chest pain or breathlessness. No known allergies. There's no family history of any similar symptoms or cardiovascular disease. Physical examination reveals pallor and weak pulses in both lower extremities  more pronounced on the right side  along with brittle nails  hair loss  and shiny skin on the right lower leg and foot. Findings are consistent with critical limb ischemia  likely resulting from underlying peripheral artery disease exacerbated by uncontrolled diabetes and heavy smoking history.

A 68-year-old male smoker with a history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia presents with severe rest pain in the left lower limb for the past 2 weeks. He has also been experiencing non-healing ulcers on the left foot for the past month. On examination  the foot was pale and cool with weak dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses. He has a history of transient ischemic attacks but no history of myocardial infarction or stroke. He denies any other complaints such as fever or weight loss. His current medications include Glimepiride 2mg daily  and Atorvastatin 40mg daily.

Patient is a 70-year-old African American male with a past medical history of long-term smoking  uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and peripheral artery disease now presenting with critical limb ischemia. He complains of severe worsening pain in his left lower extremity that significantly increases with physical activity but that is also present during rest. The patient has also noticed a non-healing ulcer about 2 cm in diameter on his left big toe. Patient reports unrelieved pain at night and interrupted sleep due to the pain that improves when his leg is in a dependent position. On examination  peripheral pulses are weak; skin is characterized by pallor  decreased temperature  and has a shiny appearance with hair loss. Capillary refill is delayed. Initial workup confirms clinical suspicion  with Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) showing a value below 0.4 for the affected leg. The patient is also at high risk for amputation due to PAD progression.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2 and peripheral artery disease  presents complaining of severe progressive pain and discoloration in the right lower limb for the past 2 weeks. He reports the pain to be constant  and worsening over this period. The pain is associated with non-healing ulcers on his right foot. He has a 30-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes daily. On examination  the foot is pale  cold and right pedal pulses are absent. There is a notable loss of hair on the lower portion of the right leg. The right foot exhibits ulcerations with blackish discoloration on the toes. There is no history of fever  chest pain  shortness of breath or similar pain in the other limbs.

A 68-year-old African-American male smoker with a known history of peripheral artery disease  uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with severe  persistent pain and coldness in his right lower limb  particularly in the calf and foot. The patient also reports rest pain and non-healing sores on his right foot. An ankle-brachial index was noted to be 0.4. The patient’s pain becomes worse at night and slightly alleviates with hanging his leg off the bed. In addition  the patient has developed non-healing ulcers on his toes despite antibiotic therapy. Skin changes such as shininess and loss of hair on the foot and lower leg are noted. Pulses in the right lower extremity are non-palpable. No history of intermittent claudication was reported. Patient’s family history indicates his father underwent treatment for peripheral artery disease.   The symptoms are suggestive of critical limb ischemia  a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed beyond intermittent claudication to pain at rest  suggesting imminent risk of loss of the limb if not promptly treated.

A 68-year-old African American male  known case of Type II diabetes mellitus for 15 years with poor control (latest HbA1c was 8.5%) and longstanding hypertensive  presents with progressive  recurring severe pain in the right calf over the past 3 weeks. The pain is noted to be worse at rest and often disrupts sleep. He also reports a non-healing ulcer on his right big toe. He admits to having a 20-pack-year history of smoking and has been a non-drinker all his life. His other significant medical history include a previous MI 10 years back. There is no history of thromboembolic disease  but there is significant family history of cardiovascular disease. The patient has noticed temperature difference between his legs  with the right foot being colder. On physical examination  the right foot is noted to be pale with a mottled appearance  right pedal pulses are diminished. There is a 2 cm ulcer on dorsum of right big toe with surrounding erythema. The ulcer is clean with granulating tissue but no drainage is seen. Neurological examination reveals decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick over distal extremities  most pronounced on the right foot. This history is concerning for a critical limb ischemia.

A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presents with severe rest pain in his left lower extremity. The patient reports a 6-month history of chronic non-healing ulcers in his left foot. The pain has become unbearable over the past few weeks  and he describes it as a constant  sharp  burning pain especially during the night. The patient reports that hanging his leg over the edge of the bed often minimally reduces his pain. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history and his medications include atorvastatin and metformin. On physical examination  his left foot is cold to touch with diminished distal pulses in the left lower extremity. There are multiple tender  necrotic  deep ulcers on the anterior and lateral aspects of his left foot with surrounding erythema and mild purulent discharge. No edema or localized lymphadenopathy are noted.

A 75-year-old African-American male  known diabetic for 15 years  and a about 20-year history of smoking (50 pack-years)  presents to the clinic with rest pain and non-healing ulcers on the left foot. The patient reports having these symptoms for the past 2 months. On examination  the foot is pale and cool to touch with a visibly necrotic toe. The dorsalis pedis pulse could not be palpated. Additionally  the patient manifests an intermittent claudication - difficulty walking due to pain in calf muscles to further signify the severity of the case. There is also a prior history of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  with a preceding angioplasty done 10 years ago. Blood pressure readings are on the higher end of normal  and he has been previously diagnosed as hypertensive. His lifestyle is sedentary and diet includes significant animal-based products.

A 62-year-old African American male with a known history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and chronic heavy smoker (30 pack-years) presents with severe  continuous pain in his left lower extremity  particularly in the calf  lasting for more than two weeks. The leg pain is worsening and has become increasingly unresponsive to analgesics. He reports functional impairment due to the pain  and recently he started limping because of the discomfort. He also notes a non-healing ulcer on his left big toe and decreased temperature of the left foot compared to the right. Further examination reveals weak or absent pulses in the left leg  and a bluish discoloration over the foot. The left foot is noticeably thin with atrophy of the skin and muscles  and decreased hair growth. Eco-Doppler studies indicate severe peripheral arterial disease. On inquiry  he reports a progressive decline in exercise tolerance over the past year due to leg pain. He denies any chest pain  dyspnea  or recent weight loss. His last HbA1c reading was 9%  blood pressure averages 150/95 mm Hg and serum cholesterol is also elevated. Current medications include metformin  lisinopril and atorvastatin.

A 64-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for poorly controlled type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and Hyperlipidemia presents with a three-week history of severe  continuous and progressive rest pain in the lower left leg. He reports non-healing ulcers on his left foot and loss of hair on the skin on his lower leg. On examination  his left foot is cold to touch with an absent posterior tibial pulse and reduced dorsalis pedis pulse. His pain is accentuated when the leg is elevated and relieved when dependent  suggestive of dependent rubor. He is a long-term smoker with significant pack-years history.

A 72-year-old obese African American male with a significant past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  peripheral artery disease  and a 40-pack year smoking history  presents with a 3 week history of progressive  severe pain in the lower right leg  particularly at rest  alongside non-healing ulcers on the toes and black discoloration. Lower limb pulses are either weak or non-palpable on physical examination. He reports a notable decline in his ability to walk over the course of a few weeks and significant weight loss. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  and dizziness. On inspection  toes show gangrene with dry  necrotic tissues. The patient expresses his concern over a possible need for amputation  as he's been having a persistent and intense sensation of coldness in his right leg.

A 70-year-old African-American male with a 15-year history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by peripheral neuropathy and poorly controlled hypertension presents with severe  persistent pain in his left foot for the past two weeks. The pain is described as 8 on a scale of 1-10  with 10 being the worst possible pain  and is not relieved with rest. He also reports the presence of non-healing foot ulcers on the foot. On examination  the left foot is noticeably cooler than the right one and the popliteal and dorsalis pedis pulses are weakly palpable. His left foot displays dusky discoloration  trophic skin changes  and the aforementioned ulcers. He rates the pain at rest as 5/10. The patient also shares that he has a 45 pack-year smoking history  but quit 5 years ago after a mild stroke. The patient's lifestyle is largely sedentary owing to his retirement from work as an office accountant. He lives alone  and manages his diabetes with insulin and oral hypoglycemics. His last HbA1c taken 3 months ago was 8.5%.

A 67-year-old male patient with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and tobacco abuse presents to the clinic reporting severe pain in his right lower leg. The pain is persistent even when at rest and increases in severity when walking. He also noticed that his right foot is cold and has darkened in color recently. He denies any chest pain  palpitation  or shortness of breath. His previous medical records reveal a history of peripheral artery disease. He has no known allergies. The patient is a retired construction worker and lives with his wife. Examination reveals a diminished pedal pulse and nonhealing ulcers on the right lower leg.

A 73-year-old African American female with a significant past medical history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus (HbA1c of 11.4% last month)  hypertension  and a 50-pack-year history of smoking presents with severe pain in her left lower limb. The pain  which she first noticed 2 weeks ago  is predominantly at rest but intensifies upon elevation. She mentions intermittent episodes of numbness and cold sensation in the same limb. Despite optimal analgesia  she reports that her sleep is frequently disturbed due to the pain. On examination  there is notable pallor and coolness of the left lower limb compared to the right  absence of the dorsalis pedis pulse  and ulcers on her toe tips suggesting gangrenous changes. The symptoms point towards chronic critical limb ischemia potentially as a result of peripheral artery disease which has likely been progressing due to her uncontrollable diabetes  prolonged history of smoking  and hypertension.

A 68-year-old African American male with a significant medical history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year smoking history presents with a 2-week history of constant aching pain in right lower leg  non-healing ulcer on his right heel  and noted coldness and color change to a pale hue. The pain is particularly pronounced when his leg is elevated and somewhat relieved when it is in a dependent position. He denies experiencing any fever  trauma  or similar symptoms in the other leg.

A 72-year-old black male with a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus for 20 years  hyperlipidemia  and smoking presents with a two-week history of progressive rest pain in his right foot accompanied by non-healing ulcers on his toes. He also notes increasing difficulty while walking  which he attributes to the pain. He denies any trauma or recent changes in his medications. On physical examination  there is a notable absence of pulses in the right foot  the presence of dry  gangrenous ulcers along the line of his toes  the foot is cold to touch  and he has decreased sensation in the same limb. This patient has critical limb ischemia secondary to presumed peripheral arterial disease exacerbated by uncontrolled diabetes and other typical risk factors including smoking and hyperlipidemia.

A 72-year-old African-American male with a known medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease presents with severe  unrelenting right lower extremity rest pain. He reports that this pain has worsened over the past two months  is not relieved by analgesics  and even interrupts his sleep. In addition to rest pain  he reports the development of non-healing ulcers on his right foot that have worsened over the past two weeks despite oral antibiotic treatment. He also admits to a history of smoking for the past 50 years  though he reportedly quit a year ago. Physical examination demonstrates diminished pulses in the right leg  dark-colored toe ulcers  and areas of skin discoloration indicative of chronic ischemia. Furthermore  the patient has an abnormal ankle-brachial index reading of 0.4 on the affected side.

A 70-year-old African-American male with a known history of uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  and Tobacco use disorder  presents with 2 weeks of worsening pain in his right lower leg at rest  especially at night. He describes the pain as severe  burning  and located mainly in the calf and foot. He also reports of non-healing ulcer located on the lateral side of his right foot. Examination reveals pale  cool foot with absent pedal pulses bilaterally  and a 3 cm ulceration on the lateral aspect of the right foot with surrounding erythema. The patient also exhibits significant weight loss over the past 6 months.

A 72-year-old male patient  with a past medical history of uncontrolled Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and a 45-year pack history of smoking  presents with critical limb ischemia. The patient reports increasing right lower extremity rest pain over the last 2 weeks  characterized as sharp and constant. The pain is 8 out of 10 on the pain scale and is worst at night  preventing the patient from sleeping. He also includes having noticed a non-healing ulcer on his right foot. On physical examination  the right lower extremity is cold to touch  with noticeable pallor  diminished distal pulses  and loss of hair on lower extremities. Doppler Ultrasound reveals significantly decreased ankle-brachial index.

Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of smoking (45 pack-years)  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus (poorly controlled) who presents with increasing left lower extremity pain at rest over the past 3 weeks. The pain intensifies when in a supine position and is somewhat relieved when his leg is in a dependent position. He reports a characteristic ""coldness"" to his foot and chronic non-healing distal toe ulcers. On examination  his left leg displays pallor on elevation  his peripheral pulses are absent  and the foot has significant areas of black necrotic tissue. He rates his pain as 7/10. He denies chest pain or other symptoms suggestive of heart disease. His father had similar symptoms in his seventies. He has no known drug allergies and is currently taking metformin  statins  and antihypertensives.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old male patient presented with critical limb ischemia (CLI) complains of severe and consistent pain in his left foot  particularly below the knee. He also experiences significant walking difficulties and even experiences pain at rest.  Demographic Characterization:  Mr. A is a 65-year-old Caucasian male and a retiree living in a suburban area with his wife. He has a history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for the past three decades  but claims to have quit smoking five years ago. He also has a history of high fat diet and has moderate alcohol consumption habits.  Relevant Past Medical History:  1. Diabetes Mellitus: The patient has a known history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 15 years  which is currently being managed with oral hypoglycemics. However  he has been inconsistent with his medicines and dietary habits.  2. Cardiovascular Disease: The patient has a significant history of cardiovascular disease. He had a myocardial infarction approximately 5 years ago which was treated with angioplasty and stent placement.   3. Arterial Hypertension: Mr. A has a chronic history of high blood pressure  which began approximately 20 years ago. Currently  he takes an ACE inhibitor daily to manage this condition.  4. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has been diagnosed with high cholesterol levels. He has been prescribed statins but is not consistent with taking the medication.  5. Intermittent Claudication: The patient has been suffering from intermittent claudication for the past two years  indicating peripheral arterial disease.  Impression:  The patient's symptoms  along with his relevant past medical history of cardiovascular disease  diabetes  and smoking habit  strongly indicate critical limb ischemia. It is critical to manage this immediately to prevent further complications such as gangrene  non-healing wounds  and possibly limb amputation.

Patient Information:  Patient ID: 00123 Name: John Doe Gender: Male Age: 75  Demographics:  John Doe is a 75-year-old retired schoolteacher residing in a suburban community about 15 miles from the medical center. He lives with his wife and has regular visits from their adult children who live nearby. Due to debilitating symptoms from critical limb ischemia  John is no longer able to walk without assistance or perform regular daily activities independently.   Pertinent Past Medical History:  1. Cardiovascular History:      - 20-year history of hypertension  controlled by medication.     - 10-year history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  poorly controlled.      - History of coronary artery disease requiring a bypass surgery 6 years ago.     - Chronic smoker (40-pack years).  2. Peripheral Vascular Disease:     - Diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) 5 years ago  has undergone a number of procedures including balloon angioplasty and stenting.     - Presenting with worsening claudication and rest pain in the lower extremities now consistent with critical limb ischemia.     3. Other Significant Medical History:    - Diagnosed with hyperlipidemia  controlled by statins.    - Prostate cancer  treated with no evidence of disease for the past 5 years.      Current Complaint:  John has been experiencing escalating leg pain over the past three months  leading to a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia. The pain is noted to be more severe at night and often disturbs his sleep. He has recently noticed a non-healing wound on his foot that has been present for about a month. Combined with the unbearable pain  this has led to a decline in his mobility.  Clinical Examination:  Physical examination revealed a pale  cool foot with delayed capillary refill time  and a non-pulsatile dorsalis pedis artery. An ulcer was also noted on the dorsal surface of the foot  measuring about 2 cm in diameter with no signs of infection.  Further Investigation:  John is awaiting further diagnostic investigations including an arterial Doppler ultrasound and possible angiogram to assess the extent of his peripheral vascular disease and to determine suitable treatment options.

Problem Representation:  Chief Complaint: Severe leg pain with minimal or no activity and ulcerations on toes.  Demographics: A 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired car mechanic  a moderate smoker with a 50 pack-year smoking history  living in an urban setting.  Relevant past medical history:  - Diagnosis 10 years ago with type 2 diabetes mellitus - Diagnosed 6 years ago with peripheral artery disease - Underwent Angioplasty 6 years ago - Diagnosed 4 years ago with hypertension  - Diagnosed 3 years ago with hyperlipidemia - Diagnosed last year with end-stage renal disease  started hemodialysis.  Social History: Lives with wife  retired  moderate alcohol consumption about once per week  moderate smoker  Family History: Father had coronary artery disease  brother has type 2 diabetes  and mother had hypertension.  Review of System:  - General: Intermittent fatigue  occasional mild fever. - Cardiovascular: Intermittent chest discomfort. - Pulmonary: Shortness of breath while doing daily household chores  no chronic cough - Gastrointestinal: Mild loss of appetite  no chronic constipation or diarrhea. - Endocrine: On medication for type 2 diabetes and follows the dietary regime. - Genitourinary: Frequent urination  on hemodialysis. - Neurological: Giddiness - Musculoskeletal: Severe  recurrent cramps in his legs mainly during the night - Skin: Found ulcerations on the toes of his right foot  Other relevant information:  - Current Medication: Anti-diabetic medication  statins  and anti-hypertensive medication. - Allergies: No known drug allergies.    Vital signs during the visit: - Blood Pressure: 150/90 mmHg - Pulse: 100 beats per minute - Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute - Oxygen Saturation: 95% on room air  - Temperature: 98.7°F - Body Mass Index (BMI) : 30 (Obesity)    Physical Examination:  - General: Conscious  oriented  - Chest: Bilaterally clear - Cardiovascular: Tachycardic  regular rhythm - Abdomen: Soft  non-tender - Lower extremities: Decreased bilateral peripheral pulses  Ulcers seen on the right toes - Neurological: No gross neurological deficit. - Skin: Pale  cool to touch with visible non-healed ulcers on right foot toes.

PROBLEM REPRESENTATION  DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION: Patient Name: John Doe Age: 65 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Insurance: Medicare Residence: Urban area  PRESENTING PROBLEM: Patient presents with severe  persistent pain in his right lower limb  notably in his foot  even while resting. He complains of non-healing sores on the foot and has noticed some color changes in the foot  turning pale  purplish  or blue. He reports some difficulty walking and intermittent claudication.  PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  1. Cardiovascular Diseases:     - History of hypercholesterolemia managed with statins.    - Previous myocardial infarction with stenting.    2. Metabolic Conditions:    - Patient is a diabetic (Type 2)  well controlled on Metformin.   3. Lifestyle Factors:     - 40 Pack-year history of smoking  quit 5 years ago.    - No history of drug or alcohol abuse.  4. Medication History:    - On anti-coagulant therapy with Clopidogrel.    - On statin (Atorvastatin) for hypercholesterolemia.    - On anti-diabetic medication (Metformin).  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: No complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations. No signs of neurologic changes or altered sensation in affected limb. No gastrointestinal or urinary complaints.

Problem Representation:  Patient Identification: A 68-year-old African American male presents with critical limb ischemia.   Chief Complaint: The patient reports severe rest pain in the lower leg  particularly in the calf region  accompanied by coldness  numbness  and a noticeable pallor. The pain is progressively getting worse and noticeably increases during the night.   Past Medical History: According to his medical history  the patient has Type 2 diabetes for more than 20 years and peripheral artery disease diagnosed 5 years ago. The patient also mentions a 45-year history of smoking  currently smokes half a pack per day.  Medication History: Current medications include Metformin for diabetes  Aspirin and Statin for peripheral artery disease.  Family History: His mother died of myocardial infarction in her late 60s  and his father had a stroke at age 72. His elder brother has Type 2 diabetes and coronary artery disease.  General Examination: Patient is moderately obese with a BMI of 31.1. A physical examination reveals foot pallor on elevation  dependent erythema  and absent pedal pulses. Loss of hair is also observed in the lower limbs.   Social History: The patient is retired. He lives with his wife. He used to work in a manufacturing company where he used to have significant job-related stress. The patient has a history of excessive alcohol consumption in his 40s and 50s but stopped over ten years ago.   Psychiatric history: The patient reports occasional feelings of depression related to his medical issues but has never sought psychiatric treatment.  Activity Level: The patient is partially bedridden and is wheelchair-dependent for mobility outside the house due to severe leg pain and impaired limb function.   Sexual and Reproductive History: The patient has two grown children with his wife and reports no major issues in the reproductive domain. He reports some difficulty with erectile function  which he attributes to his diabetes.

Patient Identifier: John Doe  Demographic details:  Age: 68 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  Residential status: Lives alone Location: New York City  Presenting Problem: The patient is presenting with severe pain in his right lower leg that has been escalating over the past week. The pain  initially only present during periods of physical activity  has become consistent even at rest. The patient has also expressed concern over the noticeable paleness and coldness of the affected limb.   Medical History:  Diabetes Mellitus: The patient has a 10 year history of type II diabetes that he manages through a combination of diet  physical activity and oral medication. His recent HbA1c was 7.5%.  Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD): Diagnosed 5 years ago  it has been managed with lifestyle changes and medication.  Hyperlipidemia: Patient has a history of high cholesterol levels managed through diet and medication.  Smoking: Patient is a former smoker. He quit 6 years ago but has a 30-pack year history of smoking.   Family history: There is a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 72 and his brother has angina pectoris.  Previous Surgeries: Patient underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) about 8 years ago.  Risk Factors: The patient's type II diabetes  history of PAD  hyperlipidemia and personal and family history of heart disease put him at a higher risk for conditions like critical limb ischemia.  Allergies: The patient has no known drug allergies.  Current Medications: He is currently taking Metformin for diabetes  Atorvastatin for cholesterol and Aspirin for his PAD.  Review of Systems: General - significant weight loss over last 6 months  Cardiovascular - intermittent claudication  Respiratory - No issues  GI - no issues  Musculoskeletal - pain in lower extremities  Integumentary - paleness and coldness of lower right extremity  Neurological - no issues.  Physical Examination: BP- 140/85mmHg  PR-80/mt  SPO2- 96%. Cold and pale right lower limb  delayed capillary refilling time in right foot and diminished sensation. Pulses in right leg reduced.  Impression: Based on the symptoms  clinical findings  and history  the patient is highly suspected for critical limb ischemia. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) test  ultrasound and angiogram are recommended for definitive diagnosis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with a chief complaint of severe pain and numbness in his right lower extremity for the past two weeks. The pain intensifies upon elevation and at rest. He has visible non-healing ulceration on his right foot. He also reports that his right foot becomes particularly pale when he elevates his leg and adopts a dusky hue when his leg is in a dependent position. He mentions that he has lost some weight and his appetite in the last month.  Demographic Information:  - Age: 72 years - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired salesman  Past Medical History:  - Diabetes mellitus type II diagnosed 18 years ago - Hypertension diagnosed six years ago - Hyperlipidemia diagnosed five years ago - 40 pack-year smoking history - History of peripheral arterial disease diagnosed around three years ago  for which he underwent angioplasty in the right leg.  - He is currently on metformin  lisinopril and atorvastatin.  The above-mentioned representation is a typical example of a patient with critical limb ischemia (CLI). CLI is a severe form of peripheral arterial disease  and it occurs when the arteries that supply blood to the legs become narrowed or blocked. This condition is associated with various risks including non-healing sores or gangrene  which may eventually lead to amputation. It's notable that this patient has several risk factors for CLI e.g. age  gender  race  diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking.

Patient Profile:   1. Name: John Doe 2. Gender: Male 3. Age: 62 years  4. Ethnic Background: Caucasian 5. Occupation: Office Clerk (retired)  Past Medical History:   1. Hypertension: Diagnosed at the age of 48 years. Patient has been on anti-hypertensives consistently. 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed at the age of 50 years. Patient has been on oral hypoglycemic agents. His glycemic control has been suboptimal. 3. Dyslipidemia: Diagnosed at the age of 54 years. Patient is on statins for the control of cholesterol. 4. Coronary Heart Disease: The patient had an apparent ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI) at age 57  for which he underwent coronary artery bypass surgery. 5. Tobacco Use: The patient has been a chronic smoker for the past 40 years  averaging about 10-15 cigarettes a day. 6. Family History: Patient’s father died due to a heart attack. His mother had type II diabetes and hypertension.  Presenting Symptoms:   1. Critical Limb Ischemia: In the past few weeks  John has been experiencing severe pain in his right lower limb  particularly in the foot (rest pain). The pain is worse at night and eases slightly when he dangles the leg off the side of his bed. 2. Distal Ulcerations: He noticed the development of non-healing ulcers  particularly on the tips of his right foot and calf. 3. The right lower limb is cold compared to the left. He has also noticed changes in the color of his foot  sometimes appearing bluish (cyanosis). 4. There is absence of pedal pulse on the right foot. 5. Other Symptoms: John has also experienced episodes of unexplained tiredness  mild chest pain during exertion and occasional blurring of vision.  This patient has a significant history of cardiovascular risk factors including hypertension  diabetes  dyslipidemia  coronary artery disease and chronic tobacco use which predispose him to Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) leading to Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). His symptoms of rest pain  distal ulcerations and absence of pulse are characteristic of CLI. His current condition may require aggressive treatment  such as surgical intervention  to establish revascularization and avoid potential limb loss.

Problem Representation:  Patient Description:  A 67-year-old African American male  former 30-pack year smoker  with a known medical history significant for Type II diabetes mellitus and severe peripheral artery disease presents with severe rest pain  non-healing wounds on the left lower extremity.  Symptoms:   The patient reports a dull ache and burning sensation in his left calf and foot for the past month  which becomes especially intense during hours of sleep. He also mentions a non-healing ulcer on the left heel and dark discoloration of the toes associated with weight loss and muscle wasting.   Medical History:   He has a past medical history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus poorly controlled with Metformin and diet  non-compliance with medication due to financial constraints  Severe Peripheral Artery Disease treated with percutaneous transluminal angioplasty 7 years ago. Additionally  he has a long history of tobacco use and sedentary lifestyle but reports quitting smoking 3 years ago.  Medications:   Metformin  Aspirin  Multivitamin supplements.   Family History:   His mother deceased due to a heart attack at mid-sixties and father from cerebral stroke at early seventies. He also mentions a brother who recently underwent a limb amputation for a similar reason.   Social History:   He lives alone in an urban area and worked as a truck driver before retiring. He has one son and one daughter  both live separately. He denies alcohol/drug use.  Physical Examination:   On examination  he has a thin body habitus  is not in acute distress. The left lower extremity is cold to touch  and there are decreased pulses in the left popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial arteries. A non-healing ulcer with a necrotic base is noted on the left heel and gangrenous changes were observed on the left toes. The rest of the physical examination is normal.   This patient's problem of non-healing wounds and severe pain at rest in the left lower limb  in the presence of peripheral artery disease and diabetes Mellitus  can be represented as Critical Limb Ischemia.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 69-year-old African American male presents with progressive pain in both legs at rest and non-healing ulcers on the distal aspect of the left foot for the last five months.  Demographic Details: The patient is a smoker with a 40-pack year history and has been a chronic alcoholic for more than 15 years. He is retired and has led a sedentary lifestyle for over two decades. He lives alone in a one-bedroom apartment and is dependent on social services. He has a limited support system with only one daughter who lives in another state. The patient's nutritional status is poor.  Relevant Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus type II about ten years ago and hypertension five years ago. He has a history of chronic kidney disease (stage III) recognized two years back. In the last five years  he has developed signs of peripheral arterial disease  which remained untreated due to the patient's socioeconomic conditions and lack of awareness. He was on oral hypoglycemic agents  antihypertensives  lipid-lowering medications  and has been regular on his dialysis sessions.  From a cardiovascular perspective  he had a non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) three years ago  managed conservatively due to his high risk for intervention. He has been in NYHA functional class II congestive heart failure (CHF) since his NSTEMI. There is a known history of mild intermittent claudication over the last two years.  Examination:  Physical examination reveals weak peripheral pulses in both lower limbs  more so in the left  and a non-healing ulcer with signs of infection on the left foot. Dry scaly skin with hair loss on both lower limbs is noted. Cardiac auscultation reveals a systolic murmur. There are no notable findings on the chest and abdominal examination.  Problem Statement:  The patient's presenting complaint  progressive rest pain in both legs  non-healing ulcers  physical findings  and background medical conditions indicate a case of Critical Limb Ischemia likely due to advanced Peripheral Arterial Disease exacerbated by poorly controlled diabetes  hypertension  smoking  and chronic kidney disease. His overall prognosis is poor due to his advanced age  severe comorbidities  socio-economic struggles  and lifestyle choices. Personalized management strategies  considering all these challenges  needs to be implemented.

Problem Representation:  A 68-year-old African-American male with a long history of smoking  dyslipidemia  hypertension  and poorly controlled diabetes  presents with complaints of severe pain in the lower right limb. The pain aggravates with physical activity and occasionally disturbs his sleep.  On further inquiry  he mentions experiencing intermittent claudication  progression to resting pain and persistent wounds on the foot that haven't healed for several months.   On physical examination  there is a notable absence of pulses in the right lower limb  hair loss  patchy areas of skin discoloration  and presence of non-healing ulcers on the foot.   The above symptoms suggest a diagnosis consistent with critical limb ischemia. The patient's potential risk factors include his race  age  smoking history  dyslipidemia  hypertension  and uncontrolled diabetes. His clinical signs such as intermittent claudication progressing to rest pain  non-healing wounds  and absence of pulses further support the diagnosis. The next step would be to conduct appropriate tests and radiological imaging  such as arterial Doppler ultrasound  to confirm the preliminary diagnosis and severity of the condition.   In the patient's past medical history  it is vital to note any history of peripheral artery disease  cerebrovascular disease  coronary artery disease or any prior surgical revascularization or angioplasty procedures  as these could influence disease management and prognosis.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 67  Gender: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Postman Lifestyle: Smoker (40 pack years)  sedentary  Address: New York  USA Contact: (555)-123-4567 Referrer: Local Physician  Past Medical History:  1. Diabetes Mellitus Type II: Patient has a 15 years history of diabetes. It is moderately controlled with oral hypoglycemics.  3. Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD): Diagnosed with PAD 5 years ago  has been on conservative management since.  4. Previous myocardial infarction: Patient had a heart attack 7 years ago. Post MI  he has been on antiplatelet drugs.  5. High cholesterol: The patient has had elevated cholesterol for around 10 years  managed with statins.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient reports a 6 months history of severe  constant pain in his right lower leg  especially in the foot  even while resting. He also complains of non-healing ulcers on his right foot and discoloration of the toes. The symptoms have been progressively worsening over time. He reports the pain is occasionally intense enough to wake him from sleep at night.  Possible Diagnosis:  Considering the medical history and current symptoms  John Doe seems to have critical limb ischemia. An arterial Doppler ultrasound and angiogram may be helpful to confirm the diagnosis and decide on the best course of treatment.  Plan:  John's case needs urgent attention as Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) can lead to limb amputation if not treated promptly. He should refrain from smoking and improve his physical activity level (as tolerable)  which could help in improving his condition. Furthermore  his blood pressure  diabetes and cholesterol should be managed more aggressively. A surgical consultation for possible angioplasty or bypass surgery should be arranged based on the assessment of his angiogram.

Patient Information: - ID: Patient X - Age: 72 - Sex: Male  - Ethnicity: African-American  - Resident: Urban area - Occupation: Retired warehouse worker  Chief complaints: - Severe pain in the left lower extremity  even at rest - A non-healing wound on the left foot   Medical History: - Known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 20 years - Hypertension for 15 years - Peripheral artery disease diagnosed 5 years ago - Stroke 2 years ago with recovery  - Ex-smoker quit 10 years ago (2 packs per day for 30 years)  Family History: - Father died due to myocardial infarction at the age of 69 - Brother has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  Physical Examination: - Left foot is paler compared to the right foot  cold to touch - Weak pulses in the left leg  - Ulcer on the dorsal part of the left foot  gangrenous changes noticed   Diagnostics: - Blood tests indicating poor glucose control over the past three months - Decreased ankle-brachial index on the left side compared to the right  - Duplex ultrasound showing limited blood flow in the left lower extremity - CT angiography confirming critical limb ischemia  showing multiple blockages in the left leg  Current Medications: - Antihypertensive drugs - Oral hypoglycemic agents for diabetes - Statins for cholesterol control - Antiplatelet drug   Scope of Problem: - Critical Limb Ischemia (left leg) due to multiple arterial blockages - Severe pain in the rested condition - Non-healing left foot wound  Patient's Preferences: - Expresses fear about the possibility of amputation - Wants to avoid surgery if possible. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  - A 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired  married  with a BMI of 28 living in an urban area. Physical Examination: - Gangrenous patch observed on the left foot's big toe. - Absence of distal pulses in the left foot. - Significant reduction in hair growth on the left leg. - Body mass index (BMI) indicates overweight status. - Blood pressure 145/90 mm Hg. - Blood glucose levels and HbA1c were elevated on routine check-up.  Relevant Laboratory Investigations: - Elevated lipoprotein levels (Hyperlipidemia) on routine check-up tasks. - Slightly raised creatinine levels indicating mild renal impairment. - Elevated levels of C-reactive protein (CRP) indicating inflammation.  Key Pointers: - The combination of the patient's smoking history  long-standing diabetes  and the presence of peripheral symptoms points towards critical limb ischemia.

Patient Demographic Representation:  - Name: Patient X - Age: 70 years - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Military Officer - Marital Status: Married - Residence: Lives in an urban area  Problem/Chief Complaint:   The patient presents with complaints of progressive pain in the lower extremities  with more severe pain in the right leg. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  Mr. S  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a complaint of severe and continuous pain in his left leg that occurs at rest and interferes with sleep. The pain has been worsening progressively over the last several months. The patient also mentions the presence of non-healing ulcers on his left foot. He is a smoker with 40 pack-years history. His main concern is the pale coloration  coldness  and numbness he has noticed in his leg and foot. He is a known diabetic (Type 2) and hypertensive for the past 15 years. The patient's prescriptions include metformin 500mg twice daily and amlodipine 5mg once daily. He states adherence to the medication. His BMI is 28.5 kg/m². The patient's father had peripheral vascular disease and underwent a leg amputation.  Key Findings:   1. Severe  continuous pain in his left leg  more pronounced during rest and night. 2. Non-healing ulcers on the left foot  indicating probable tissue necrosis. 3. Pale coloration  coldness and numbness of the left leg  suggestive of inadequate blood supply. 4. History of smoking  which is a risk factor for peripheral vascular disease. 5. Presence of comorbidities like diabetes and hypertension  both of which are risk factors for vascular complications.  6. A family history of peripheral vascular disease and leg amputation.  Problem Summary:  This is a 67-year-old male with history of diabetes  hypertension  and smoking  who presents with severe rest pain  foot ulcers and signs of poor circulation in his left lower limb  indicating critical limb ischemia. Given his underlying risk factors  he requires an immediate assessment of limb viability with vascular imaging  and likely urgent intervention to re-establish blood flow and prevent limb loss. His personal and family medical history suggest an increased predisposition to peripheral artery disease.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the hospital.  Presenting Disease:  The patient reports experiencing intermittent claudication  characterized by pain in his right leg when walking that subsides when at rest. He describes the pain as aching  cramping  or a sense of fatigue in his muscles. Over the last few weeks  he has noticed a progressive non-healing wound on his right foot and increased pain even at rest. The pain is severe enough to prevent him from sleeping. He also reports noticeable weight loss. Given these symptoms  a primary clinical concern is critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Relevant Past Medical History: Patient has a 20-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and high blood pressure. He was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) five years ago  and has been on aspirin and statin therapy since then. Despite these interventions  his condition has progressively worsened. He has been a heavy smoker for the past 50 years. There is no known family history of cardiovascular diseases  strokes  or peripheral artery disease.   Patient's history of diabetes  hypertensions  smoking  and his advanced age places him at increased risk for developing critical limb ischemia resulting from progression of peripheral arterial disease. His condition points to the need for urgent intervention to restore blood supply and avoid possible amputation.

Patient Information: - Name: John Doe - Age: 68 years - Gender: Male - Race: African American - Occupation: Retired truck driver - Marital Status: Married  - Residence: Urban  living alone  Medical History: - Smoking history: 30 pack-years - Alcohol consumption: Occasional drinker - No known drug allergies - Chronic conditions: Diabetes mellitus (type 2  diagnosed 15 years ago)  Hypertension (diagnosed 20 years ago) - Previous surgeries: Cholecystectomy (gall bladder removal  10 years ago)  Current Medications: - Metformin: 500 mg twice daily for diabetes - Lisinopril: 10mg daily for hypertension  Family History: - Paternal: Died of myocardial infarction  aged 65 - Maternal: Hypertension  - Siblings: One brother with coronary artery disease  Presenting Complaint: Patient is presenting with a 3-month history of pain in lower left limb  especially when walking  indicating intermittent claudication. He reports non-healing wounds on his foot and decreased temperature of the affected limb compared to the other limb. His condition has progressively worsened over the past 2 weeks with severe pain even at rest  suggesting the development of critical limb ischemia (CLI). There are no signs of fever or systemic illness  and peripheral pulses are not palpable in the affected limb.  Conclusion: Considering the patient's demographic information  medical history  and presenting complaint  an assessment for peripheral arterial disease and critical limb ischemia is warranted. Diabetes and smoking are significant risk factors  and he has symptoms suggestive of severe  progressive ischemia in the affected limb. These symptoms warrant immediate intervention to alleviate pain  heal the wounds  and prevent further limb loss and potential cardiovascular complications. The patient should be referred urgently to a vascular specialist for further evaluation and proposed vascular intervention. Management should also involve aggressive risk factor control  including smoking cessation and strict glycemic control. His family doctor should be informed and involved in managing his chronic medical conditions.
