Problem Representation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a significant past medical history of tobacco use (smoked 1 pack/day for 40 years  quit 8 years ago)  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with severe  persistent pain in his right lower leg and foot for the past four weeks. His pain is worse at rest and especially disturbs his sleep. He also reports difficulty walking short distances due to this pain. On a recent physician examination  it was noted that his right foot was cool to touch with diminished pulse. His capillary refill was delayed and his foot was discolored  indicative of poor perfusion. Further investigation through Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) showed results below the normal range. His medical history also included mild peripheral neuropathy diagnosed a year ago  and a myocardial infarction 7 years ago for which he was treated with a drug-eluting stent and optimal medical therapy.  He currently takes aspirin  a beta-blocker  an ACE inhibitor  and a potent statin  supplemented by insulin and metformin. The patient has been on these medications for several years and has been generally adherent  however  glycosylated Hb levels have been erratically controlled  hovering around 8-9% on his last few clinic visits. He has been counseled multiple times about strict glycemic control  dietary measures  and regular exercise. Despite mitigating his tobacco use 8 years ago  he's been struggling to control his diabetes and maintain a steady exercise regimen due to his worsening limb symptoms and ischemia.  The combination of distressing rest pain  evident signs of impaired tissue perfusion  and significant risk factors suggest this patient is suffering from critical limb ischemia. The severity of symptoms and uncontrolled diabetes implies a poor prognosis and highlights the need for intervention.

Patient Profile:  - **Name:** John Doe - **Gender:** Male - **Age:** 72 years old - **Occupation:** Retired teacher - **Marital Status:** Widowed - **Location:** Suburban setting in NY - **Ethnicity:** Caucasian  Health Insights:  - John has a long-standing history of smoking approximately 2 packs per day for around 30 years  but he quit 10 years ago. - He is overweight with a BMI of 28.5 kg/m2. - High blood pressure diagnosed 8 years ago  on medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily). - John was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 15 years ago. Now  his diabetes is poorly controlled with a recent HbA1c of 8%. - He also suffers from high cholesterol  which is controlled with statin therapy (simvastatin 40 mg daily). - History of a Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) with full recovery about 5 years ago.  Presenting complaint:  - John now presents with severe pain in his right foot  especially at night and at rest. - He reports the foot feels cold and is paler in comparison to the other. - Ulcer has developed on the toe that is not healing and causing intense pain. - He has also complained of decreased mobility due to pain and this was affecting his quality of life.  Diagnosis & Problems:  - Main problem: Having these signs and symptoms  John is highly suspected to have Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). - CLI is a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores. Risk factors like smoking  diabetes  high blood pressure  high cholesterol levels  and being overweight come into play in John's case. If not treated in a timely manner  CLI can result in the need for limb amputation. - John's difficulty controlling his blood sugars is a significant risk factor for the development and progression of peripheral arterial disease. - In addition  poorly controlled diabetes can also lead to the development of peripheral neuropathy  contributing to the development of ulcers. - His history of TIA suggests the presence of systemic atherosclerosis  increasing the risk of CLI.  Plan:  - Immediate assessment and complete vascular study needs to be done to confirm the diagnosis. - John may need aggressive treatment including lifestyle modification  medications  or even surgery to alleviate his symptoms and save his limbs. - His diabetes and hypertension management also need to be reassessed.

Patient Problem Representation:  Demographics:  - A 72-year-old Caucasian male.   Presenting Complaint:  - The patient reports persistent  severe pain in his right lower leg and foot at rest. Past Medical History:  - He has a significant history of coronary artery disease (CAD) for which he underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) ten years ago.  - He has been managing type 2 diabetes mellitus with metformin for the past 18 years and reveals inconsistent glycemic control. - The patient is a current smoker for more than 50 years with unsuccessful quit attempts. He drinks alcohol occasionally.   Clinical Findings:  - On examination  the right foot appears pale  cold with diminished dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses.  - The foot wound measures 2 cm with a yellowish base and surrounded by hyperpigmented skin.  Based on the history  physical examination  risk factors  and assuming normal blood tests and negative relevant imaging for other issues  the problem likely to be evaluated is critical limb ischemia (CLI). CLI is a severe obstruction of the arteries which drastically reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and even skin ulcers or sores.

Patient Information: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male of medium build  presenting with symptoms of chronic limb ischemia.   Presenting Complaint: The patient reports an extended period of severe  unrelenting pain in his right lower limb. This pain is notably exacerbated when the limb is elevated and somewhat relieved when the limb is in a dependent position. The patient has experienced progressive difficulty in walking due to pain (claudication)  and he notes having rest pain in his foot. Visible atrophy of the muscles in the affected leg is noticed  and there are clear symptoms of chronic foot ulcers that are not healing.    Past Medical History: Upon reviewing the patient’s medical history  it was noted that he is a recidivist smoker for the past 45 years  with a pack-a-day habit. He also has a consistent history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago  but it has not been well-controlled. He is not under regular follow-up for his diabetes  which has potentially contributing to the microvascular and macrovascular complications he is experiencing. No history of any thromboembolic events in the past.   Family History: The patient's father passed away from myocardial infarction at the age of 72.   Social History: He is a retired steelworker who currently lives alone at home.   Current Medications: Metformin  Insulin  Aspirin  Lisinopril and Atorvastatin.   Allergies:  No known drug allergies.   Review of Systems: Significant for uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia.   Physical Examination: Lower extremity examination reveals diminished pulses in the right foot  ABI of 0.4 on right side  dry gangrene of the right big toe  and some trophic skin changes on the leg. Pain upon elevation of leg  relieved by hanging leg off the edge of the bed. No evidences of cerebrovascular or cardiovascular diseases.   Impression: Given the patient’s age  lifestyle and presenting symptoms  differential diagnoses will be focused on Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) secondary to peripheral artery disease (PAD) due to long-standing uncontrolled diabetes and smoking habit. This is further complicated by the patient's hypertension  hyperlipidemia and smoking habits.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 67-year-old African American male with a history of type 2 diabetes  peripheral artery disease (PAD)  hypertension  and chronic kidney disease  presents with progressively increasing pain in his right calf worsened by walking (claudication) and relieved with rest over the last four months. He smoked heavily in the past and recently quit a year ago. He reports a nonhealing ulcer on his right heel.  Past Medical History (PMH): 1. Type 2 diabetes mellitus (on a metformin regimen) - Diagnosed 10 years ago. 2. Peripheral artery disease (PAD) - Diagnosed five years ago. 3. Chronic kidney disease (stage 3) - Diagnosed two months ago. 4. Hypertension - Diagnosed 15 years ago. 5. History of heavy smoking (40 pack-years)  quit last year.  Review of Systems (ROS): Positive for rest pain and nonhealing wounds on the extremities. He denies chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  fever  and weight changes. His pain is 8/10 at rest  worsens with activity  non-radiating and is located in the calf muscle.  Socioeconomic status: Retired construction worker. Lives with his wife. Their only daughter lives out of state.  Representative Problem: The patient represents a typical case of suspected critical limb ischemia (CLI)  clinically manifested with rest pain  nonhealing wounds  and claudication. Given the concrete vascular risk factors present in his profile  including uncontrolled diabetes  PAD  hypertension  CKD  and smoking  a clinical suspicion of CLI becomes highly likely. Hyperlipidemia  a typical risk factor for CLI  is notably absent from this patient's profile  which might warrant consideration in the problem list. The nonhealing ulcer on his leg further raises the suspicion of CLI.  Next Steps: CLI is a severe manifestation of PAD and requires emergent attention due to the risk of limb loss. The next steps should include further diagnostic evaluation beginning with Ankle-Brachial index (ABI) followed by angiography (CTA / MRA or traditional) for definitive diagnosis. Referral for vascular surgical consultation is crucial given the severity of symptoms and presence of nonhealing ulcers. Concurrent wound care management for the heel ulcer and optimization of his risk factors should also be part of his continuing care.

The patient also has a history of hypertension  under treatment with calcium channel blockers for the past five years. He also complains of occasional episodes of angina  which he usually manages with sublingual nitroglycerin. His mother died of stroke in her seventies  and his father has peripheral artery disease.  Current Medications: Metformin 1000 mg twice daily for diabetes  amlodipine 10 mg once daily for hypertension  Atorvastatin 20 mg once daily for hyperlipidemia  and nitroglycerin tablet sublingual as needed for angina.  Based on the demographic  clinical and historical data  the significant issues to address include severe peripheral artery disease with critical limb ischemia and nonhealing foot ulcer. Peripheral Artery Disease with Critical Limb Ischemia 4. Non-healing Foot Ulcer 5. History of Smoking 6. Overweight & Sedentary Lifestyle.

The patient's symptoms of rest pain and non-healing ulcers  and the difference in temperature between the limbs are signs of critical limb ischemia.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 65 Sex: Male Race: White Occupation: Retired engineer Insurance: Medicare Residential Status: Living with spouse Presenting Complaint: Pain in the left leg  increasing in severity over the past couple weeks  especially after any physical exertion or even rest. He has been a chronic alcoholic and chain smoker. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 76-year-old male of African-American descent  retired construction worker.  Demographics: The patient is a long-time smoker with a 35 pack-year history; he gave up smoking two years ago. He lives alone and has a family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 64  and his elder brother is living with diabetes and peripheral artery disease (PAD).  Presenting Symptoms: The patient complains of severe pain in his right lower limb  which sometimes extends to his hip. The pain is particularly intense when walking and sometimes disturbs his sleep. He reported that he has noticed his right foot appearing bluish  there are ulcers around his toenails  and he often feels cold on that foot as compared to the other foot.   Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 10 years ago and has been on medication. He has been regularly assessed for his blood pressure and cholesterol levels. 7 years back  he was diagnosed with diabetes and has been managing it with medication  diet  and exercise. However  his glucose control has been suboptimal. He has no known allergies.  Review of Systems: The patient denies symptoms of chest pain  palpitations  or shortness of breath. No recent history of fever  weight loss  loss of appetite  or fatigue. The patient also denies any abdominal or back pain.   Physical Examination: Examination of the right foot reveals a lack of pulsation in the foot's dorsal and post-tibial arteries. There is coldness to the touch  with pallor on elevation and dependent rubor  and with noticeable loss of hair on the leg. There are two non-healing ulcers on the big and second toes  with mild discharge but no signs of cellulitis or deep tissue infection. The left foot appears normal.  Investigations: Initial investigations include the Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  blood tests for kidney function  and HbA1c levels. Further diagnostics would be guided based on the results of these investigations. Possible follow-up exams could include duplex ultrasound  CT angiography  or angiogram.  Impression: The patient's symptoms and examination findings suggest a picture consistent with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  possibly due to advanced Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD). His age  smoking history  and pre-existing conditions (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes) increase risk. The patient requires urgent vascular evaluation and management to prevent limb loss and mitigating other potential complications. Differentiating whether the CLI is due to embolic or thrombotic causes might help dictate his medical or surgical management.

Summary:  This is a 67-year old African-American male with significant risk factors including smoking  diabetes  hypertension and hyperlipidemia that are likely contributing to his presentation of critical limb ischemia. His history of coronary artery disease  strokes  and chronic kidney disease further compounds the complexity of the management plan.

Patient Profile:  Demographic Information: - Name: John Doe - Age: 66 years - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Engineer - Marital Status: Married - Address: 1234 Maple Street  Springfield  Illinois  Presenting problem: John is presenting with severe pain in his right lower leg which has worsened over the last few weeks. The pain is particularly bad when he walks or when he is lying down. He also reports experiencing numbness and coldness in the affected limb. On further examination  the affected leg appears to be shiny and bluish in color.   Past Medical History: - Smoker for 40 years  recently quit 1 year ago. - History of peripheral vascular disease diagnosed 10 years ago. - Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 15 years ago  and is on oral medication. - Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  controlled with medication. - History of two myocardial infarctions: one 8 years ago  the other 5 years ago. - Previous diagnosis of high cholesterol  controlled with statins.  Family History: - Father died of heart disease at age 70. - Mother had type 2 diabetes and hypertension.  Medications: - Metformin for type 2 diabetes. - Lisinopril for hypertension. - Atorvastatin for high cholesterol.  Allergies: - No known allergies.  Tariff Score (used to assess the severity of John's peripheral arterial disease): 5. This score is high  likely indicating critical limb ischemia.  Objective: The main objective is to manage John's critical limb ischemia  preserving the limb if possible and reducing pain. This may include medical management of his risk factors (smoking cessation  better diabetes control  and cholesterol management) and potentially revascularisation procedures (angioplasty  bypass surgery).   All medical decisions will need to account for John's extensive comorbidities and his reasonably advanced age. Given his past myocardial infarctions  together with the severity of the critical limb ischemia  John's cardiovascular risk is considerable. Treatment of his presenting problem must be accompanied by aggressive management of these risk factors to reduce the likelihood of further cardiovascular events.

Patient Representation:  Patient: Mr. John Doe  Sex: Male  Age: 70 years old  Race: Caucasian  Residence: Urban Area  Occupation: Retired engineer  Language Spoken: English  Marital Status: Married  with 3 adult children  Smoking History: Ex-smoker – smoked approximately a packet a day for 30 years. Patient Profile: - Name: John Doe - Age: 73 - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Carpenter - Residence: Urban apartment - Lifestyle: Sedentary lifestyle  former heavy smoker (30 pack-years)  occasional alcohol drinker   Presenting Complaint:  John reports an acute onset of severe left lower leg pain at rest within the last 72 hours  which he describes as a constant burning sensation  combined with progressive numbness. The pain intensifies further at night and elevating the limb does not seem to relieve it. He mentions an ulcer on his left foot which is not healing.   Relevant Past Medical History:  - Three-year history of Type 2 Diabetes  which is currently managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. - Hypertension for the past 10 years  currently on antihypertensive medications. - Previous history of a mild stroke 4 years ago with no residual deficits. - Diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) 2 years ago. - History of intermittent claudication  progressing over the last 18 months. - Had an angioplasty of the left anterior tibial artery 8 months ago.  - Underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 5 years ago.  Family History: - Father deceased due to myocardial infarction at the age of 62. - Mother deceased due to stroke at age 72. - One brother with known coronary artery disease.  Clinical Examination Findings:  - Left lower limb notably cooler than the right. - Non-healing ulcer on the left foot with palpable bone. - Weak or absent distal pulses in the left lower limb. - Buerger's test: Elevation of limb leads to pallor  and dependency leads to rubor.  Diagnostic Tests:  - Lower limb angiogram: It shows significant stenosis of the distal aorta and both iliac arteries  and occlusion of both superficial femoral arteries. - Ankle-brachial index (ABI): below 0.4 on left  0.7 on the right.  - Doppler ultrasound: Reveals reduced blood flow in the left lower limb arteries. - Blood tests: Raised HbA1c  cholesterol and triglyceride levels. - CT Angiography: Reveals obstruction in the lower extremity arteries.  Based on the above information  a problem representation might be: ""A 73-year-old male former smoker with a history of diabetes  hypertension  PAD  and previous angioplasty presenting with severe rest pain in the left lower limb  a non-healing foot ulcer  diminished lower extremity pulses and critical biopsy results  indicative of advancing peripheral arterial disease and critical limb ischemia.""

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 68 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Marital Status: Married Occupation: Retired Military Personnel   Description: Mr. Doe presents with symptoms suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). He complains of severe pain in his right leg – especially in the calf region. He also reports symptoms of Rest Pain  characterized by a burning or aching sensation at rest which intensifies during night and partial relief is achieved by lowering the extremity. The patient is also observed to have non-healing ulcers on his toes and foot.  Past Medical History: 1. Diagnosed with Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago. 2. Hypertensive for the past 5 years. 3. Has a history of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) and underwent angioplasty 7 years ago. 4. He has been a smoker for around 30 years but quit after his CAD diagnosis. 5. History of peripheral artery disease (PAD) diagnosed 2 years back.  Family History: His father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 75  and his mother has a history of high blood pressure. His younger sister has diabetes.  Current Medications: 1. Metformin 500 mg twice daily for managing his diabetes. 2. Lisinopril 10 mg once daily for hypertension. 3. Aspirin 81 mg taken once daily for heart health. 4. Atorvastatin 20 mg per day for cholesterol management.  Screening & Assessment: CLI is a severe stage of PAD caused by the reduced blood flow to the legs and feet. To confirm CLI  an Ankle Brachial Index (ABI) test or imaging tests can give us a better idea of his condition.  Plan: 1. Lower the extremity to reduce Rest Pain 2. Refer to a vascular surgeon for a consultation 3. Improve blood sugar control  blood pressure  and cholesterol levels 4. Advise for lifestyle modification like a healthy diet and exercise  5. Initiate discussions about the possibility of revascularization procedures like angioplasty or bypass surgery.  Summary: Mr. Doe  a 68-year-old male with a history of type-2 Diabetes  Hypertension  and Coronary Artery Disease presents with severe leg pain and non-healing ulcers on his toes and foot suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia. The diagnosis needs to be confirmed by further assessment and managed by a combination of medical treatment  lifestyle modification  and possible surgery.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:   A Caucasian man aged 72 years presents with the main issue of critical limb ischemia (CLI) in his right lower limb. A heavy smoker with a pack history of 40 years  he admits to continuous and restful moderate-to-severe pain in the affected limb.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a significant history of peripheral artery disease (PAD) which has been under treatment for the past 10 years. There is a long-standing history of hypertension and dyslipidemia  inadequately controlled with medication. Last year  he was diagnosed with a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and went through a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for the same. In addition  he had undergone a right femoral artery bypass grafting procedure two years ago for severe obstructive disease. Lastly  the patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus for 15 years with poor glycemic control and consequent diabetic neuropathy.  Supporting Details:  Considering these comorbidities  the patient has an elevated risk of cardiovascular incidents and disease progression. He still maintains a smoking habit despite health education and counseling. Clinical examination shows reduced or absent right pedal pulses  and the foot is cold to the touch. A six-minute walk test shows limited mobility due to pain. The patient's ankle-brachial index (ABI) was 0.4 (indicating severe arterial disease)  and his HbA1c level is 8.5% (suggesting poorly controlled diabetes).  Problem List:  1. Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) 2. Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) 3. Hypertension 4. Dyslipidemia 5. Previous Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) 6. Previous Femoral Artery bypass grafting 7. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 8. Diabetic Neuropathy 9. Current heavy smoker 10. Impaired mobility.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  - Gender: Male - Age: 65 years old - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired office worker - Lifestyle: Sedentary lifestyle with 30 years history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily.   Clinical Presentation: - Chief complaint: Severe pain in lower left leg especially while walking and at rest. - Pain level: 8/10 - Duration of symptoms: For the past 2 months  progressively worsening.  Past Medical History: - Hypertension (HTN) diagnosed 15 years ago  taking Antihypertensive (Amlodipine). - Type II Diabetes Mellitus (DM) dated back 10 years  managed with Metformin and lifestyle modifications. - Chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 3 diagnosed 5 years back  regular follow-ups and diet control. - Dyslipidemia diagnosed and being treated for last 8 years (Statin therapy) - Coronary artery disease (CAD): Underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 3 years back. - No known allergies. - Family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Social History: - Smokes two packs of cigarettes a day for about 30 years. - Consumes alcohol occasionally.    Physical Examination: - Lower left leg: Pallor  diminished pulses  absence of hair growth  non-healing ulcer on the anterior surface. - Other systems: Within normal limits.  Investigations: - Ankle-brachial index (ABI): <0.4. - Doppler ultrasound: Reduced blood flow in left lower limb. - Blood reports: Elevated HbA1c  elevated creatinine levels. - EKG: No findings suggestive of acute cardiac ischemia. - X-Ray foot: no obvious bony injury or abnormality seen.  Impression: The patient is a 65-year-old male who has presented with the symptoms of critical limb ischemia in his left leg which has been evident for the past 2 months. His medical history is significant with long-standing hypertension  diabetes mellitus  CKD  dyslipidemia  and CAD. The key concerning factors include history of smoking  sedentary lifestyle  and poorly controlled DM. The initial examination and investigations are suggestive of critical limb ischemia.    Management plan: Rendering immediate medical attention towards managing the ischemia and preventing potential complications like limb loss or heart attack is the priority. Hence  the measures taken are directed towards lifestyle modifications (smoking cessation  physical activity)  optimization of antiplatelet therapy  revascularization strategies if necessary  meticulous foot care  control of blood sugar levels  and hypertension. Consultation with vascular surgeon for further care.

Problem Representation:  Patient Information: - Demographics: 72-year-old African-American male - Social history: Smoker (30 pack year history)  sedentary lifestyle  retired truck driver - Family medical history: Younger brother died of a myocardial infarction at aged 64  father died from stroke at age 76  Past Medical History: 1. Patient Problem Representation:  Demographic Information: The patient is a 70-year-old African American female residing in an urban area. She is a retired teacher and lives independently in her own home. She is a widow and has 2 adult children living in the same city. She is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.   Clinical History:  She has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus (poorly controlled with metformin)  and hypercholesterolemia. She also has peripheral vascular disease  with prior angioplasty in the right lower limb conducted 3 years ago. Moreover  her diet is less than optimal  with a preference for fast food and sugary snacks. She also has a sedentary lifestyle due to her limited mobility as she finds it strenuous to engage in physical activity.   Presenting Complaint:  Recently  she has been experiencing increased pain in her right leg  especially during walking (claudication). The pain is described as sharp  constant  and is not relieved by rest. She also reports frequent episodes of numbness and coldness in the same leg. There are visible skin changes  including non-healing ulcers  and diminished pulses. These symptoms are suggestive of critical limb ischemia  likely progression of her peripheral vascular disease.   Family History:  She has a strong family history of heart disease. Her father died of a myocardial infarction at 60  and her mother has chronic heart failure. Her older sister was recently diagnosed with carotid artery disease.   Medications and Allergies:  Besides metformin  she takes lisinopril for her hypertension and atorvastatin for her high cholesterol. She is allergic to sulfa drugs  which causes her skin rash.  Social History:  She has a supportive social network with regular contact with her children. However  her children are not aware of the full extent of her health issues. She has a pet cat  and she maintains independent living with help from a daily aid caregiver  who assists with housekeeping and grocery shopping. She also attends church services every Sunday.  Health Beliefs:  The patient acknowledges her health issues but has difficulty adjusting her lifestyle and diet. She agrees to take her medication regularly but is hesitant about invasive treatment options due to fear and lack of understanding.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 78-year-old Caucasian male patient.  Chief Complaint:  Severe pain in his right lower extremity  even when at rest. The pain has been progressively worsening over the past few months.  History: According to the medical history  the patient has been suffering from diabetes mellitus for the past 14 years and has been treating it with insulin injections. The patient has also been diagnosed with hypertension 8 years ago  which he manages with prescribed medications. 20 years ago he was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease. He used to be a heavy smoker but has quit smoking ten years ago. He is currently experiencing unremitting pain in his right foot  particularly in the toes  which seems to be relieved to a certain degree when hanging the foot off the edge of the bed. A diminished pulse was observed during physical examination and advanced lower extremity atrophy is witnessed. The patient has also complained about impotence and has been losing weight despite having a normal appetite. This will guide diagnostic reasoning and subsequent management strategies for the patient's ischemia.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Q. Public Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Issue: The patient presents with symptomatic critical limb ischemia in his right leg which is characterized by pain in the limb  even during rest  with known evidence of progressive worsening over the last three months. There has been no known alcohol or substance abuse. A history of peripheral arterial disease diagnosed 5 years ago is noted. He underwent percutaneous angioplasty for his left leg 2 years ago.  No known allergies to medications have been reported. The patient's family history includes a father who died from a heart attack at 70 and a mother with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.  Current Medications: The patient is taking Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Aspirin as a blood thinner. Imaging Findings: Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremity reveals significant stenosis in the right femoral artery. Working Diagnosis: The patient is diagnosed with critical limb ischemia of the right lower extremity  potentially secondary to peripheral arterial disease  hypertension  and poorly controlled diabetes mellitus.  Plan: The recommended plan is to control the risk factors by optimizing medical therapy. Diabetes and hypertension should be controlled. An urgent vascular surgery consultation is warranted. Patient Problem Representation:  Demographics: Mr. White  a 72-year-old African American retired construction worker  lives with his wife in their suburban home. He is a lifetime non-smoker but has a history of heavy alcohol intake.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with a one-month history of progressive dull  cramping  and severe pain in his right lower limb  which is aggravated with activity (exertional pain) and at rest  primarily at night. He also complains of non-healing ulcers on his right foot that have been present for two weeks.  Past Medical History: 1. Cardiovascular system - He has a ten-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and five-year history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus (poor metabolic control). 2. Respiratory system - He has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to occupational asbestos exposure. 3. Musculoskeletal system - He suffers from arthritis but is unable to take non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) due to an established diagnosis of peptic ulcer disease. 4. Other - The patient underwent treatment for alcoholic cirrhosis three years ago. He has tried multiple times to abstain from alcohol but has frequently relapsed.  Family History: The patient has a family history of peripheral artery disease and cardiovascular diseases. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62.  Review Of Systems: The patient reports no fever  no chest pain or palpitation  no dyspnea  and no abdominal pain. He has noticed a slight intolerance to cold conditions and has lost about 5 pounds over one month due to decreased appetite.  Medication History: He takes amlodipine for his hypertension  metformin  and glimepiride for his diabetes. He also uses an inhaler (budesonide and formoterol) for his COPD.  Psychosocial History: He has been retired for 7 years and mostly stays at home due to his restrictive physical condition. He has infrequent social interactions and identified himself as a ""loner"". He has a past history of depression and was treated with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor  which he stopped taking a year ago due to financial constraints.  Relevant Clinico-pathological correlation: The presentation of pain on exertion and at rest  non-healing ulcers  and sensation of cold in the limb is suggestive of critical limb ischemia  a severe manifestation of peripheral artery disease. This condition is primarily due to a significant reduction of blood flow in the peripheral arteries  often due to atherosclerosis. The patient's underlying uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension greatly contribute to the risk of atherosclerosis. The weight loss may be attributable to potential underlying malnutrition and poor appetite due to pain and depression.

Problem Representation:   A 68-year-old African-American male patient presents with a complaint of severe  unrelenting pain in his right leg at rest accompanied by the presence of non-healing ulcers on his right foot. The pain often intensifies during the night and temporary partial relief is achieved by hanging his leg off the side of the bed. Physical examination reveals cooling of the skin in his right foot  absence of pulse in the right foot dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial arteries  and the presence of dark necrotic tissue in the foot’s lateral aspect.  Demographic Characteristics: - Age: 68 years old - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: African-American - Occupation: Retired construction worker  Social History: - Lives alone  has regular visits from his adult children - Smoker (1 pack per day for the last 40 years) - No record of alcohol or illicit drug use  Past Medical History: - History of controlled type-2 diabetes for the past 12 years - Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago - Diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) 5 years ago - Underwent an endarterectomy for left-sided PAD 3 years ago - History of dyslipidemia  Current Medication:  - Metformin for diabetes - Lisinopril for hypertension - Statin for dyslipidemia  Family History: - Father died of myocardial infarction  - Mother had a stroke  The patient's symptoms of severe pain at rest and the presence of non-healing ulcers and necrotic tissue indicate critical limb ischemia  which is a result of severely obstructed arteries and drastically reduced blood flow. The patient's long history of smoking  along with his hypertensive  diabetic  and dyslipidemic status dramatically increases his risk for this condition and might have contributed to the rapid progression of PAD observed in this patient. Immediate attention is required to prevent amputation of the affected limb.

Problem Representation:  Patient Description: Mr. Jones is a 68-year-old African-American male presenting with excruciating pain in his left foot that started two weeks ago while at rest  causing him many sleepless nights. The pain intensity escalates when his leg is elevated and alleviates somewhat when he drops his leg down. He also complains of non-healing wounds on his toes. He has a long-standing history of uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus (diagnosed for 18 years) and hypertension (diagnosed for 16 years) that require medication. He has been a heavy smoker for the past 35 years and has been consuming alcohol moderately for about 30 years. He hasn't been physically active due to work commitments in the past. He has a family history of peripheral artery disease. For the last couple of years  he has been experiencing progressive fatigue and muscle pain in his left leg while walking that improved with rest (claudication).  Critical information: Diabetes  hypertension  heavy smoker  alcohol consumption  physical inactivity  family history of PAD  symptoms of claudication  Problem Representation: The patient presents with critical limb ischemia  characterized by severe rest pain  non-healing wounds  and history of claudication - a disease manifestation of severe peripheral arterial disease. His diabetes  hypertension  smoking history  and alcohol consumption are significant risk factors for PAD. With concomitant risk factors  his disease is likely to progress further if he doesn't adhere to treatment. His sedentary lifestyle also increases his risk level. The positive family history of PAD raises concerns about a possible genetic predisposition.

Problem Representation: A 70-year-old African American male  a long-term smoker with a history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes and hypertension is presenting with symptoms consistent with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). The patient is also known to experience dyslipidemia and obesity. He has a history of Transient Ischemic Attacks related to peripheral artery disease.   Given he is a chronic smoker and his past medical history  he is at high risk of CLI. His symptoms have progressed over the past few weeks  they include resting leg pain  non-healing wounds on his left lower extremity  and reduced mobility due to pain. This patient’s worsening symptoms suggest severe blood flow reduction  endangering his lower extremities. His extensive medical past indicates multiple risk factors for the advanced stage of peripheral arterial disease  making CLI a likely diagnosis.   The primary concern is the risk of amputation if circulation to the affected limb does not improve  which may result in an immediate threat to his limb's viability. Additionally  CLI is a signal for advanced systemic atherosclerosis  hence there’s also an increased risk for heart attack and stroke. Due to his age and existing comorbid conditions  the patient may require an aggressive multidisciplinary treatment approach  and lifestyle modifications to manage and mitigate further complications.   Further diagnostic procedures and management plan should be directed by an appropriate specialist  such as a vascular surgeon  to confirm the severity of the disease and guide subsequent treatment options. The approach should focus on relieving symptoms  improving his quality of life  preventing limb loss  and addressing cardiovascular risk factors.

Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 6 years ago and on medication (Simvastatin 20mg  once at night).  4. Coronary Artery Disease: Had a myocardial infarction 3 years ago and underwent angioplasty.  5. Elder sister has hypertension and diabetes.  8. Allergies: None.  Recent Evaluations:  The patient's blood glucose levels are uncontrolled  with the latest HbA1c result being 9.5% (should be < 7% for diabetic patients). LDL cholesterol (180 mg/dL) and blood pressure readings (160/90 mmHg) are also significantly above the target range (< 100 mg/dL and 130/80 mmHg  respectively).  Summary:   This 65-year-old patient presents severe peripheral artery disease manifesting as critical limb ischemia in his right leg  a complication of his poorly controlled diabetes and other comorbidities. His past history of coronary artery disease and stroke elevates his risk levels for future cardiovascular events  and his poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia further compromise his cardiovascular health. The uncontrolled nature of his multiple chronic conditions indicates a possible need for stricter management of his ongoing care regimen.

Problem representation:  A 68-year-old African-American male with a known history of type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents with severe  unrelenting pain in his left leg  described as a continuous  heavy sensation that significantly increases when he is not in an upright position. He describes the pain as 9 out of 10 in severity scale. It started roughly three days ago  associated with a non-healing ulcer on the same leg. His leg is noticeably paler compared to the contralateral limb. The patient also admits to occasional sensation of numbness and cold in the affected limb. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking and has minimal alcohol consumption.   In his medical history  he was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease 2 years ago but was not compliant with prescribed medication. He had a myocardial infarction five years ago  which required coronary artery bypass graft. Furthermore  he was diagnosed with renal insufficiency constant to his diabetes three years ago  requiring hemodialysis. He is currently taking insulin  metformin  aspirin  and a statin. Despite aggressive management of his diabetes  his last HgA1c was 8.4  indicating poor glucose control.   His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease with his father dying of a stroke at the age of 62 and his mother diagnosed with congestive heart failure. His brother and sister both have type II diabetes.  This patient's clinical picture and medical history are suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia in the setting of advanced peripheral arterial disease  likely exacerbated by his non-compliance to medications  poorly-controlled diabetes  smoking habits  and his history of renal insufficiency requiring hemodialysis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. John Grey  who currently presents with critical limb ischemia in the right lower limb. He is a retired mechanic and a current smoker with a 40 pack-year smoking history. He is a known hypertensive for 10 years and also has a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient lives alone  is independent with all of his activities of daily living  and does not have any known drug allergies.   Presenting Problem: The patient reports a two-month history of progressively worsening pain in his right calf  particularly while walking (""claudication"") and  now  at rest. This is associated with decreased temperature and pallor of the right foot  and mild foot drop. He also reports ulcers on his toes that are not healing despite regular dressing and antibiotic therapy for the past 2 weeks.   Past Medical History: Mr. Grey was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago  which is currently controlled with Losartan. He was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago and is being managed with Metformin. There is no known history of coronary artery disease or stroke  although he has not undergone any specific cardiac evaluation. His sister died of myocardial infarction at the age of 67. There is no other relevant surgical or family history.   Clinical Encounter: Upon examination  there is pallor and decreased sensory and motor function in the right foot. The right femoral pulse is feeble  and the popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial pulses are absent. There is a non-healing ulcer present on the great toe. Blood investigations show a HbA1c level of 7.2.  This case represents a typical presentation of a patient with critical limb ischemia with background risk factors of smoking  hypertension  and diabetes.

Problem Representation: A 67-year-old  Caucasian male of average weight and height  non-smoker  and diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes is presenting symptoms of critical limb ischemia. Problem Representation:  Patient Information:  A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a body mass index (BMI) of 29.5 kg/m^2  currently a smoker with a history of 40 pack-years.  Presenting Complaint: The patient claims persistent and severe rest pain in his right foot for the last month  characterized by a crampy and dull sensation. He describes consistent numbness and coldness in the same limb  worsening during the night while resting and slightly resolved when hanging the foot over the bed.  Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension for the last 10 years under medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily)  Type 2 diabetes mellitus (managed with metformin 500mg twice daily)  and hyperlipidemia (controlled with atorvastatin 20mg daily). The patient had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago  treated with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)  and has been on Aspirin 75mg and Clopidogrel 75mg since then.   Social History:  Retired insurance agent  lives with his wife in an urban town. He admits to smoking (1 pack/day for 40 years) and occasional alcohol use.  Family History:  Father had stroke at 67  mother had breast cancer diagnosed at 61  one brother with coronary artery disease  one sister with no significant diseases.  Physical Exam: Pale  cool  and pulseless right foot with blackish discoloration in the toes (indicative of tissue necrosis). Auscultation of the heart and lungs are normal  and the abdomen is soft and non-tender.   Diagnostic evaluation:  The ankle-brachial index (ABI) demonstrates values of 0.3 on the right side and 0.9 on the left side. ABI < 0.4 is indicative of severe peripheral artery disease.   Plan: Considering the critical limb ischemia diagnosis  urgent peripheral angiography and possible revascularization procedure are planned. The need for escalation of antiplatelet therapy and smoking cessation are emphasized. Antidiabetic therapy might require optimization for better sugar control. Diet  exercise  and other lifestyle modifications will be discussed with the patient and his family to combat obesity and promote health.

Name: John Doe   Age: 72     Sex: Male     Ethnicity: Caucasian     Occupation: Retired     Marital Status: Married     Living Situation: Lives with spouse   Insurance: Medicare     Chief Complaint: Increasing pain in the left lower extremity  particularly at rest and at night. Cardiovascular System: No murmurs heard upon auscultation. Regular rhythm. Lungs: Clear breath sounds bilaterally. No wheezes  rales  or rhonchi. Abdomen: Non-distended  no organomegaly. Bowel sounds present. Musculoskeletal System: Muscles of left lower extremity appear atrophied when compared to the right. Extremities: Grossly normal apart from the left lower limb. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: James Smith  a 65-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department with severe pain in his left lower extremity. He is a known smoker with a 40-pack year history and works in a construction company. A resident of New York City but originally hailing from Alabama  he lives with his wife and reports a family history of heart disease.  Key Symptoms: Patient reports of persistent resting pain for the past 2 weeks being predominantly in the foot  specifically heel and forefoot that increases in severity upon elevation. He explained the pain is unlike anything he has experienced before  rating it 9 on a scale of 1-10. He also noticed ulcerations on his big toe that have not improved with over-the-counter remedies  and slower healing bruise on his leg. He has described having claudication symptoms for the past few months but has not sought any treatment.  Past Medical History: The patient has hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus that are well-controlled on medication. He also has dyslipidemia as a comorbidity. He was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease 1 year ago. No history of previous surgeries.   Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  his left lower extremity is noticeably cooler than the other and the skin is paler and shiny. An ulcer is visible on the great toe and has a pulse rate that is weaker in comparison to the right lower extremity.  Investigations: The ankle-brachial index (ABI) recorded was 0.3. Duplex ultrasound showed severe stenosis in the left superficial femoral artery. Complete blood count  renal function  and serum lipid profile are under process.   Clinical Impression: Considering the above information  the patient has presented with symptoms concerning for Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  with the most probable cause being his pre-existing peripheral artery disease  exacerbated by his lifestyle and other comorbidities. Immediate and appropriate treatment needs to be planned to alleviate the pain and to save the limb  which at this moment is at high risk for amputation.

This warrants urgent evaluation and possible intervention to restore blood supply and prevent limb loss. Further investigation would be necessary to confirm diagnosis.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Information:  Patient: Mr. Johnson  a 70-year-old White male  Past medical history:  - Type 2 diabetes mellitus (poorly controlled) - Current smoker (40-pack-year smoking history) - Hypertension (on medication) - History of peripheral artery disease - Previous cardiac bypass surgery  - Dyslipidemia - A family history of heart disease   Presenting symptoms: - Recurrent and uncontrolled rest pain in the right lower limb noticeable for the past three weeks  especially distally (below the knee region) - Pain even while resting and worsens during the night - Non-healing wound on the right foot and noticeable skin discoloration - Reduced mobility  affecting quality of life  Physical examination: - Absent peripheral pulses in right lower limb - Pale and cold right foot with noticeable muscle atrophy - Presence of necrotic tissue around plantar ulcers - Signs of impaired sensory and motor function  Given the patient's clinical history  demographic factors  and physical findings  all signs point towards Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  which is the advanced stage of peripheral artery disease.  Supporting lab/Imaging findings (hypothetical): - Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI): <0.4 in right leg  indicating severe disease - Doppler ultrasound: Reduced blood flow in right leg arteries - Angiogram: Significant blockages in lower extremity arteries - Blood work: Uncontrolled blood glucose levels; Abnormal lipid profile  Plan: Immediate vascular consultation is recommended for possible intervention given the severity of symptoms and to prevent limb loss. This could include angioplasty or surgical bypass. He will continue hypertension and dyslipidemia management with medication adjustment as needed. It is highly advised that Mr. Johnson's type 2 diabetes be better managed to support wound healing. He will also be advised cessation of smoking  started on a graded exercise therapy  and provided diet modifications. He might also benefit from consultation with a podiatrist for wound care.   This problem representation is constructed to provide an overview of Mr. Johnson's case  summarize his condition  support a potential diagnosis  and guide treatment plans effectively. However  the information should be construed as hypothetical and not medically diagnostic in any manner.

Patient Information:  Mr. C  an 82-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department complaining of severe pain in his left leg  which had intensified over the week. The patient resides in a living care facility in the city and has a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes per day for over 60 years  having quit 4 years ago.  Past Medical History:  Mr. C has a significant medical history including poorly-controlled Type II Diabetes Mellitus for over 15 years  hypertension  coronary artery disease- status post coronary artery bypass surgery six years prior  chronic kidney disease stage III  and a confirmed 10-year history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) affecting both lower limbs  primarily the left leg.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  Mr. C’s left foot was found to be cold to the touch  barely grasping any detectable pulse. There were visible signs of gangrene on the lateral aspect of the foot and the leg showed signs of reduction in hair growth  both indicative of poor blood supply to the area. He had a loss of protective sensation as confirmed by the inability to sense monofilament touch on most parts of the foot. His blood pressure was slightly elevated  and blood glucose was poorly controlled.  Diagnosis:  Following a series of diagnostic measures  including Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  Doppler ultrasound imaging and Computer Tomographic Angiography (CTA)  a clinical diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) was confirmed. The ABI was less than 0.40  and the Doppler showed diminished bi-directional flow pattern in the lower extremity arteries  while the CTA revealed multiple arterial lesions and a significant blockage in the distal left superficial femoral artery.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given his age  multiple co-morbidities  and the extent of the disease  it was concluded that Mr. C was not a suitable candidate for revascularization. He was instead managed with aggressive risk factor control measures. His analgesic regimen was optimized for pain management  and he was given intravenous antibiotics following the diagnosis of wet gangrene. Measures were initiated towards optimizing his blood glucose control and improving his overall cardiovascular health.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient's foot pain showed moderate improvement with the new pain management regimen. Despite difficulties  the patient’s blood sugar levels were better controlled with an altered antidiabetic regimen. He was referred to a nutritionist to help manage his dietary intake and improve his control of diabetes. Palliative care services were also provided to the patient to manage the disease progression psychologically. The patient was scheduled for weekly follow-ups.  Given the severity of the disease progression and patient's overall health status  a multi-disciplinary team involving vascular surgery  endocrinology  cardiology  dietetics  and palliative care was formed for his future course of treatment. The option of amputation was discussed  but the patient was initially hesitant. Therapeutic decision-making was challenging considering the patient’s co-morbidities  however it was decided that this would be kept as a last resort  following determination of his potential for healing post-amputation and his overall risk from surgery.   In conclusion  this was a case of advanced critical limb ischemia emphasizing the need for early detection and rigorous disease management in patients with a high-risk profile  such as longstanding smokers  diabetics  and hypertensive individuals  to prevent potentially debilitating outcomes.

Title: Severe Critical Limb Ischemia in a Diabetic Patient with Hypertension  Patient Detail: Mr. M  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presented with severe pain in his left leg  rest pain  and non-healing ulcers in the foot. He reports the pain to be persistent  unrelieved with rest  and increasingly disruptive to his sleep. The patient is a retired mechanic  a smoker for 40 years with a moderate alcohol intake  and has a sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 15 years  that is managed with Insulin and Metformin. He has also been treated for Hypertension for 8 years with Ramipril. He neither had a history of peripheral arterial disease nor any arterial interventions.  Clinical Findings: On inspection  Mr. M's left foot exhibited non-healing ulcers on the big toe and heel with discoloration of the surrounding skin. There was an absence of pulse palpation in the left posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries. The Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was evaluated at 0.4 on the left side  confirming severe ischemia. Pain-free walking distance was significantly reduced (<50 meters). Mr. M also reported intermittent claudication of his right leg.  Investigative Studies: An angiogram showed severe occlusions of the left superficial femoral artery  and less severe stenosis of the right femoral and popliteal arteries. The left infrapopliteal arteries were also occluded.  Treatment & Prognosis: Revascularization was proposed as the preferred treatment strategy considering the severity of symptoms and findings. Endovascular therapy couldn't be done due to the severity and location of the blockage  leading to a decision for bypass surgery. After proper risk assessment and necessary preparation  a femorotibial bypass using a vein graft was performed. The patient was also prescribed dual antiplatelet therapy and a statin  with optimization of his diabetes and hypertension management.  The postoperative period was uneventful and follow-up at 1 month demonstrated improved ischemic symptoms and start of ulcer healing. The patient was enrolled in a structured exercise program and advised on lifestyle modification including dietary changes  smoking cessation  and regular foot care.  In conclusion  this report emphasizes the association between diabetic angiopathy  sedentary lifestyle  and smoking in the severe progression of critical limb ischemia. Early detection and aggressive multidisciplinary management can yield suitable outcomes  however  the importance of primary prevention should be underscored to all patients  particularly those with multiple predisposing factors.  Disclaimer: This case report is a fictional account produced for illustrative purposes only. Any resemblance to actual persons or events is coincidental.

Patient Information  Patient: 64-year-old Caucasian male Home Town: New York City  Presenting Condition  The patient presented with a three-month history of incipient left foot pain  which was progressive and primarily noticed at rest. It was accompanied by paresthesia and numbness  primarily at night. Additionally  the patient reported a loss of appetite  weight  and intermittent episodes of fever.  Medical  Personal  and Family History  The patient has a history of cigarette smoking (30-pack year history)  controlled hypertension  and type 2 diabetes  which was diagnosed 8 years prior and has been controlled with metformin. He reported no history of heart disease  pulmonary disease  or renal disease in himself or his immediate family. His family history does report numerous cases of type II diabetes and different types of cancer (lung  colon).  Physical Examination and Clinical Test Results  On examination  the patient’s vital signs were generally stable: pulse 80 beats per minute  blood pressure 140/80 mm Hg  temperature 37.8°C  and respiratory rate 17 breaths per minute. His left foot was cold with diminished sensation and poor distal pulsation. Digital gangrene was evident on the distal phalanx of the left big toe. Distal pulses in the left lower limb were absent  and dusky discoloration was present below the mid-shin level. The right lower extremity was normal with palpable pulses. Blood tests showed increased WBCs  and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Peripheral angiography was performed which showed multi-level peripheral artery disease with a complete blockage of blood flow in the left limb from the mid-popliteal artery to the foot.  Diagnosis  Considering the clinical manifestation  examination findings and angiography results  the patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI) in the left limb.  Treatment and Follow-Up   The patient was immediately started on an intravenous antibiotic regimen for infection management along with low molecular weight heparin for anticoagulation. He underwent successful infrainguinal bypass surgery to restore the blood supply. After the operation  he was monitored in the hospital for a couple of weeks  and his pain noticeably improved as his foot warmed up. The patient was subsequently discharged with instructions for continual foot care  blood sugar management  and a strict cessation of smoking. Regular follow-up assessments for limb examination  wound care  and re-vascularization patency have been arranged.  The patient’s history of smoking and type II diabetes  both risk factors for CLI  highlights the importance of further research and awareness of the preventive measures in such high-risk individuals.

Patient Information  A 75-year-old African American male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of rest pain and non-healing ulcers on his left foot. His weight is 89 kg and he is 5’7” tall. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history. He also has a past medical history significant for type II diabetes mellitus.  Clinical Findings  On physical examination  the patient appears uncomfortable and in distress. His vital signs are stable. Lower-extremity examination reveals a temperature difference between the right and left foot. The patient’s left foot is cool to touch with prolonged capillary refill  and non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are observed. The foot has multiple necrotic ulcers covering the plantar surface and lateral malleolus with no signs of infection surrounding the ulcers. There are no palpable femoral pulses. Sensation is intact but decreased to both pressure and temperature. Peripheral neuropathy is observed on monofilament exam.  Diagnostic Assessment  A series of diagnostic studies were conducted on the patient. Non-invasive studies include an Ankle Brachial Index (ABI)  which resulted in a low ABI of 0.4 on the left while a normal ABI of 1.2 on the right. A computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the lower extremities depicted severe atherosclerotic disease of the left common iliac artery with multiple blockages in the popliteal and anterior tibial arteries. Bypass grafting deemed impossible due to multiple blockages. The nature and extent of the disease confirmed the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI).   Therapeutic Intervention  Following diagnosis  a below-knee amputation was suggested as the viably best option. Patient and family were reluctant to proceed with this plan initially but agreed after counselling about the risks and consequences of a non-operative approach. During the postsurgical period  the patient received intense rehabilitation care and continued to take aspirin  high-intensity statin and his diabetes medication.  Follow-up and Outcomes  At the two months follow-up  the patient’s stumps had completely healed without signs of infection. He has also started using prosthetics under the supervision of a rehabilitation specialist. His pain has disappeared and the HbA1C level is 7.2%. The patient is now ambulating with the use of a wheelchair and is in the process of receiving physical therapy for prosthetic fitting and ambulation training.   Patient's Perspective  The patient expressed concern about his ability to manage at home. He was referred to a social worker to outsource homecare resources  and the diabetic nurse planned for home visitation for insulin training. He was grateful for the information received and decision made to improve his quality of life.  Conclusion  This case illustrates the severe manifestations of peripheral arterial disease and the importance of early diagnosis and preparing patients for potential life-altering decisions. Regular screening and early interventions are crucial  especially in high-risk patients with diabetes and smoking histories.

Title: Severe Peripheral Artery Disease Resulting in Critical Limb Ischemia - A Case Report  Introduction:  This case report involves a 73-year-old Caucasian man with severe Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) leading to Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Patient Information:  The patient is a retired 73-year-old Caucasian male residing in Chicago  Illinois. He is a former chain-smoker with a 50 pack year history but quit smoking ten years ago. He has a medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 18 years  Hypertension for 20 years  Dyslipidemia for the past 15 years  and Chronic Kidney Disease stage 3. His surgical history was remarkable for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 8 years ago. His body mass index was 29.1 kg/m2  indicating obesity. His regular medications include Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for dyslipidemia.  Clinical Findings:  The patient presented with a six-month history of severe excruciating pain in his left lower extremity  even while at rest. He experienced the most pain in his foot. He reported having non-healing ulcers on the foot over the past three months  associated with noticeable skin color changes. Physical examination revealed an absent dorsalis pedis pulse and a barely palpable posterior tibial pulse on the left lower extremity. The affected limb was observed to be cold with a pallor appearance  and gangrenous changes were seen in the toes.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Ankle-Branchial Index (ABI) showed a low value of 0.3 on the left side  confirming severe PAD. Doppler ultrasound showed a monophasic waveform suggestive of significant stenosis in the left femoro-popliteal and tibial arteries. Angiography further corroborated these findings and revealed complete occlusion of the left popliteal artery and severe stenosis distally.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the severity of limb ischemia and the onset of gangrene  an immediate decision for emergency left lower limb revascularization was made to salvage the limb. Unfortunately  an attempt using endovascular techniques was unsuccessful due to the critical nature of the disease. Finally  a left below-knee amputation was performed with the goal of relieving pain  preventing systemic sepsis  and improving his overall quality of life. Post-amputation  rehabilitation support and prosthetic interventions were planned for the patient.  Follow-up:  The postoperative period was uneventful  with good pain control and wound healing. The patient was subsequently discharged and referred to cardiac and diabetic specialists for optimization of his cardiovascular risk factors. Regular follow-up visits were scheduled every three months. A prosthetic fitting was arranged  and the patient was connected with the physiotherapy department for further rehabilitation.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the aggressive nature of PAD in patients with diabetes and the importance of early detection and treatment. Primary care physicians must remain vigilant about PAD  especially in high-risk patients. A multidisciplinary approach involving various specialists is crucial in managing such complex patients.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 68-year-old female patient with a history of Diabetes and Hypertension  Case Report:  Patient Information: The patient  a 68-year-old Caucasian female with previous medical history significant for Type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease (PAD)  presented to the hospital with extreme pain in her right lower extremity.  Clinical Findings: The patient reported experiencing a gradual increase of pain in her right lower extremity over the past few weeks  especially when walking. Subsequently  it continued to escalate even at rest. Other symptoms noted were a decrease in skin temperature in the affected limb  absence of peripheral pulses  and discoloration  ranging from pallor to cyanosis when elevated and erythema when dangled  indicative of severe circulatory deficit.  Diagnostic Assessment: An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test was performed which scored significantly less than 0.4 and non-invasive vascular study demonstrated diminished flow to the distal extremity. The pulse volume recordings  with severely decreased amplitude  were also indicative of severe PAD. A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) was done for further assessment and revealed a complete occlusion in her right Superficial Femoral Artery (SFA) along with multilevel tibial disease. These findings confirmed the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Therapeutic Intervention: Due to her critical condition and her risk factors (diabetes and longstanding hypertension)  a decision was made for the patient to undergo endovascular revascularization with Drug-Eluting Balloon (DEB) angioplasty and stenting. Following the procedure  antiplatelet therapy with Aspirin and Clopidogrel was initiated for the management of the disease.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Post-procedure assessments showed immediate amelioration in her symptoms. Pulse presence was reported in her right foot at discharge. On her 4-week follow-up  she reported significant improvement in her right leg pain. Examination showed healing of minor wounds noticed at the presentation. An ABI reading was improved. The patient was referred to a diabetic educator and a dietitian for better control of her diabetes and hypertension.   Patient Perspective: The patient was satisfied with the treatment outcome and was relieved from the disabling pain that significantly affected her quality of life. She realized the importance of controlling her diabetic and hypertensive conditions and pledged to follow a healthier dietary pattern.  Conclusion: This case underlines the importance of early recognition and aggressive management of risk factors in patients with PAD to prevent the progression to critical limb ischemia. The multidisciplinary approach towards the condition can drastically improve patient outcomes and their quality of life.

Patient Information:  Mr. X  a 78-year-old Caucasian male was presented to our hospital with complaints of chronic progressive pain in his left lower limb. He is a retired high-school history teacher  married with two children  and a resident of North Carolina. He has a 45-year history of smoking and enjoys drinking socially. He is not currently working and denies the use of any illicit drugs or medications.   Medical History:  Mr. X has been diagnosed with hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago. Mr. X has been complying with antihypertensive medications  statins for hyperlipidemia  and metformin for diabetes mellitus but control is suboptimal. He had an MI (Myocardial Infarction) 5 years ago and was treated with PCI (Percutaneous Coronary Intervention). He has no known allergies to drugs or food.   Presenting Complaints:  The patient first noticed rest pain 6-months ago. He complained of severe pain in his left leg that seemed to worsen at night. He also stated that the pain worsened after walking and was partially relieved by dangling the leg off the bed. He attributed the pain initially to his age but as the pain progressively worsened  he decided to seek medical help.   Physical Examination:  On physical examination  there was evident pallor  reduced temperature  and decreased hair growth in the left leg. Peripheral pulses were not palpable in the left foot. No ulcerations or gangrene were visible  but the foot appeared dusky. A comprehensive cardiovascular examination was also conducted due to his previous MI.  Investigations:  Doppler ultrasound examination was done for both legs which confirmed significantly reduced blood flow in the left leg  indicative of severe ischemia. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) indicated a score of less than 0.40 in the left leg suggestive of critical limb ischemia. Further angiography indicated severe multi-level atherosclerotic occlusive disease.   Case Management:  Initially  conservative management including optimal glycemic  blood pressure  and lipid control was attempted but symptomatic relief was minimal. Given the severity of his disease and symptoms  he was evaluated for revascularization interventions. He underwent a successful endovascular intervention which included angioplasty.   Follow-up:  Post-procedurally  his rest pain resolved considerably and blood flow to the left foot improved. He received smoking cessation counseling  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia management education. He was advised to continue his aspirin and statin therapy and was discharged to continue physical rehabilitation at home. Mr. X is scheduled for follow-up visits to monitor his progress and to manage any potential complications.   This case highlights the importance of early recognition of critical limb ischemia in patients with a long history of smoking and poor control of diabetes and hyperlipidemia. Timely intervention can drastically reduce the risk of limb amputation and improve quality of life.

Patient Information:  Name: Anonymous Age: 68 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired construction worker  Clinical History:  The patient has a known history of 30-year tobacco use  controlled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  and iliofemoral peripheral artery disease (PAD) diagnosed 3 years ago. Further history reveals PAD-related intermittent claudication (onset 2 years ago) with non-healing ulcers on the right foot incurred over the last six months.   Present Illness:  The patient presented in the Emergency Department with severe rest pain in his right leg  non-healing ulcerations on the right foot and noticeable coldness in the distal extremities  all of which exacerbated over the past week. His regular medications include metformin for diabetes  amlodipine for hypertension  and an aspirin-clopidogrel combination for PAD.  Clinical Examination:  On examination  the patient was afebrile  blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg  heart rate was 88 bpm  and BMI was 29. The right lower extremity was noticeably cool to touch with weak distal pulses. A non-healing ulcer was found on the plantar aspect of the right foot and additional digital gangrene present at the right hallux.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Ankle-Brachial index (ABI) indicated an ischemic index value of 0.4 on the right leg. Doppler ultrasound revealed markedly decreased arterial blood flow in the right lower extremity. Confirmatory angiography showed right critical limb ischemia (CLI) with multilevel occlusive disease extending from the iliac artery to the distal femoral artery.  Treatment:  An urgent endovascular revascularization was planned. The patient underwent successful atherectomy and balloon angioplasty of the iliofemoral arteries and distal femoral artery. Subsequently  he was managed with aggressive wound care and antibiotics for the ulcers and gangrene.  Follow-Up:  Post-intervention  the patient has shown significant improvement. His rest pain has been alleviated and digital pulses are palpable in the right foot. The foot ulceration has shown signs of healing with the infection being under control successfully. He has been advised for diabetic control  lifestyle modifications including strict smoking cessation  and regular follow-ups for the monitoring and management of peripheral artery disease.   Summary:  This case highlights the importance of early detection and urgent management of critical limb ischemia in patients with multi-morbidity factors. Further  the patient's case underscores the necessity of comprehensive patient education on their part in managing their vascular diseases effectively.

Title: A Case Report of Critical Limb Ischemia in a High-Risk Patient  Abstract:  We present a case report of a 65-year-old Caucasian male patient with a history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and peripheral arterial disease (PAD) who was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI). The diagnosis and treatment strategies highlighted in this report emphasize the clinical features  diagnosis  and management of CLI in a high-risk patient.  Case Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  a current smoker with a 50-pack year history  who presented to the hospital with a three weeks history of sharp and severe burning pain in the right lower extremity that worsens at night. He also reported that non-healing ulcers were present on the right foot with a significant loss of hair on the legs and feet. He has a known history of T2DM  PAD  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia.  Clinical findings: On physical examination  the right lower extremity was severely pale with a noticeable temperature differential below the knee area. Pulses were weak in the right dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial areas  and absent in the popliteal area. Tissue loss was evident on the right foot with deep non-healing ulcers. There was also significant reduction in tactile and pain sensation in the right lower extremity indicating peripheral neuropathy.  Diagnostic assessment: The ankle-brachial index (ABI) was indicative of severe PAD  measuring 0.40 in the right extremity. An arterial Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremity showed severe stenosis in the distal right superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery. An angiography confirmed the occlusion of these arteries. Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) was high (9.2%).  Therapeutic intervention: Revascularization was considered critical. Given the substantial risk factors and expected poor wound healing  an endovascular approach was favored over surgical bypass. Angioplasty was performed along with stenting of the occluded artery. Following the procedure  his pain notably reduced. In conjunction with a diabetic team  his T2DM was better controlled using a mix of insulin and oral hypoglycemic agents. A multidisciplinary team approach was used for wound care and management  incorporating a dietician  podiatrist  and physiotherapist.  Follow-up and outcome: The six-month follow-up showed gradual improvement in extremity perfusion  significant reduction in pain  and wound healing progress. ABI was 0.85 in the right leg  indicating improved arterial perfusion. More aggressive risk factor modification was implemented  including smoking cessation counseling and better glycemic control.  Conclusion: This case demonstrates the necessity of an interdisciplinary team and multifactorial approach when managing a high-risk CLI patient. Furthermore  it highlights the importance of aggressive management of modifiable risk factors  even in late-stage disease. The significant role of endovascular procedures in limb salvage in high-risk patients is also emphasized.

Title: Management of Critical Limb Ischemia in a 65-year-old Female with Multiple Comorbidities  Patient Description: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female  who is a retired schoolteacher. She is currently residing in Dallas  Texas. She presented with a severe  persistent pain in her right lower extremity  lasting for several weeks. Apart from her current presentation  she reported having episodes of intermittent claudication  characterized by pain/discomfort in the calf muscle during exercise or walking  which tends to subside at rest. She also noticed the formation of ulcers on her right foot that were slow to heal.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant medical history which includes hypertension (HTN)  type-2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)  and hyperlipidemia. She was diagnosed with hypertension around 30 years ago and T2DM around 20 years ago and had been maintaining these conditions relatively well with prescribed medications (amlodipine 5mg for HTN  metformin 1000 mg for T2DM  and Atorvastatin 20mg for hyperlipidemia). She also reported a smoking history of around 40 pack-years but had quit 10 years ago.  Diagnosis: Based on her clinical condition  imaging studies  and the results of a Doppler ultrasonography showing diminished blood flow in her right lower extremity  she was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI) due to peripheral artery disease (PAD).
