Management: The cardiology team consulted. They started her on a regimen of dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel) to prevent thrombosis. Considering her severe symptomology and poor quality of life  and after discussing the risks  benefits  and alternatives  the patient agreed to undergo revascularization surgery.  Postoperative: The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and reported significant relief from her previously severe  consistent limb pain. The wounds started to show signs of healing.  Follow up: She was advised to attend regular follow-up appointments  continue her medications and engage in lifestyle modification such as maintaining a balanced diet and adhering to a regular exercise program to control her blood sugar levels  blood pressure and lipid profile.   Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of prompt diagnosis and effective management of CLI  particularly in patients with multiple comorbidities. It also highlights the imperative role of regular follow-ups and effective lifestyle modifications in the management of underlying diseases which might prevent the progression of the disease and improve patient outcomes.

Case Report:  Patient Initials: J.P. Sex: Male  Age: 67 years Race: Caucasian  Presenting Complaint: J.P. presented at the hospital with severe pain in his right lower extremity. The pain level was constant and  according to the patient  worsening over the last few weeks. The pain was initially intermittent but became constant over the past week. He also reported non-healing ulcers on his right foot and intermittent night pain that was relieved by hanging the foot over the edge of the bed.  Past Medical History: J.P. has a known history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) diagnosed five years ago and has been non-compliant with his prescribed medications. Additionally  he has a 45-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 20 years ago with sub-optimal glycemic control. The patient also suffers from hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both managed with medications. However  his compliance with the prescribed regimen is poor. He has no history of any surgeries.  Physical Examination: Examination of the right lower extremity revealed a weakly palpable pulse in the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries. An ulcer measuring approximately 3 cm in diameter was observed on the lateral side of his right foot. The extremity was cold to touch  and there was a noticeable pallor on elevation. Pulses were normal in the left lower limb. No signs of gangrene were noted.  Diagnostics: With the patient's history and physical findings  the suspected diagnosis was critical limb ischemia. An ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) was performed  showing an index of 0.4 on the right side  confirming severe ischemia. Computed tomography angiography revealed severe stenosis in the right superficial femoral artery  popliteal artery  and tibial arteries.   Management: J.P. was managed urgently with revascularization with angioplasty and stenting of the occluded right superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery. He was also started on antiplatelet therapy  statins  and advised for aggressive glycemic control for his diabetes and smoking cessation. In addition  he was referred to a wound care team for the management of his foot ulcer.  To summarize  this case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and management of peripheral arterial disease  as well as patient adherence to medication and lifestyle changes. Special attention needs to be given to high-risk patients  such as those with diabetes and a smoking history  to prevent the progression of the disease to critical limb ischemia.

Case Report  Patient Information: Mr. A  a 65-year-old African American male  presented with severe pain in his right lower extremity. The patient is a regular smoker  having smoked his entire adult life  currently averaging one pack per day. He has been a known case of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type 2 for the last 20 years  along with hypertension  and has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) for which he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting approximately five years ago.   Clinical Findings: Mr. A reported increased difficulty in walking due to the pain  consistent with claudication  and explained that it had been progressively worsening for the past six months. In recent weeks  he noticed sores that weren't healing on his right foot and a prominent discoloration of the skin. On physical examination  the right foot was cold to touch with weak pulses. There was a non-healing ulcer on the right big toe  and the skin was pale with areas of dark discoloration suggesting gangrene.   Diagnostic Assessment: An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was conducted which showed a significantly reduced reading on the right. Peripheral angiography demonstrated severely compromised blood flow in the right lower extremity  shorter arterial segments filled with thrombotic material and multiple areas showing total occlusion. These findings confirmed the clinical suspicion of critical limb ischemia (CLI).   Therapeutic intervention: The patient was commenced on conservative management initially with antiplatelets (Aspirin) and statins and control of his blood sugar levels and blood pressure. However  due to the severity of his condition  a decision was made to proceed with surgical intervention. Mr. A underwent successful endovascular therapy with angioplasty and stent placement to restore perfusion in the affected limb.   Follow-up: At the patient’s follow-up appointments  he demonstrated notable improvement. The foot ulcer began showing signs of healing  and the pain had significantly reduced. The patient was then referred to cessation counsellor to address his smoking habit. He is currently under observation and is scheduled for regular follow-ups in cardiology and vascular surgery.   In conclusion  this case illustrates the importance of early detection and management of CLI  particularly in patients with known risk factors such as smoking  diabetes  hypertension  and a history of coronary artery disease. The maintenance of blood sugar levels  blood pressure and aiding patients to quit smoking plays a crucial role in mitigating further risk.

Patient Information: 75-year-old African American man  Case Report:  Introduction: This case report describes a man with significant past medical history for cardiac and peripheral vascular disease who presented with excruciating pain in his left lower extremity indicative of critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Clinical Presentation: The patient is a 75-year-old African American man who presented to the outpatient vascular clinic with complaints of severe  unrelenting pain in his left foot and calf for the past two weeks. He described the pain as burning and throbbing  rating it a 9 on a scale of one to ten. He also reported increasing difficulty in walking due to the pain which was worsening even during rest.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant medical history including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes mellitus type 2  and a 40 pack-year history of smoking. He was treated for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) 8 years prior and had a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) done five years ago for coronary artery disease.  Examination and Diagnosis: Physical examination revealed noticeable absence of pulses below the left knee and foot. His left foot was colder than the right. There were also signs of muscle atrophy and shiny skin. Doppler ultrasound showed a severe reduction in blood flow in the left lower limb  consistent with CLI. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) also reinforced the diagnosis of CLI  with an ABI of less than 0.4.  Treatment and Follow-up: He was initially put on medical management with dual antiplatelet therapy and statins. Effective glycemic and blood pressure control were also ensured. However  due to worsening symptoms  he was referred to the vascular surgery team. After evaluating the potential risks and benefits  a decision was made to proceed with a left lower limb bypass surgery. The procedure was marked by bypass grafting using his great saphenous vein.   Postoperative period was uneventful  and the patient reported a remarkable improvement in his symptoms. He was discharged with a regimen of an antiplatelet agent  statins  antihypertensive and diabetic medications along with medication for his pain. Regular follow-ups were scheduled at the vascular clinic to ensure effective management and to monitor his progress.  Conclusion: This case highlights the important role of early identification and effective management of modifiable risk factors in the course of CLI. It also reiterates the importance of considering surgical intervention in patients with CLI when the condition significantly threatens their life  limb or functional capacity. It's crucial to have a multidisciplinary involvement to manage these complex cases.

Patient Case Report  Demographics:  Mr. X is a 70-year-old male who resides in a suburban area. He is a retired car mechanic and has built up a lifetime habit of smoking. He is married with four adult children and is of African American descent.  Presenting Problem: Mr. X initially presented complaining of severe pain in his right leg  which was persistent even during periods of rest. He also reported non-healing sores on his right foot and decreased temperature in the lower part of his right leg.  Past Medical History: Mr. X has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which are controlled with oral medication. He also had a previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) five years ago  but has since shown no symptoms. He has also been battling hyperlipidemia and peripheral artery disease (PAD) for more than a decade. He is also known to be a heavy smoker averaging about 20 cigarettes per day for the past 50 years.  Clinical Examination: Physical examination showed notable pallor  decreased capillary refill and diminished pulse in the right lower extremity. The right foot was cooler than the left foot and had two non-healing ulcers on the toes. Mr. X exhibited significant discomfort and pain during the examination of the right leg.  Investigations and Diagnoses: A combination of the patient's physical signs  clinical history and investigations led to a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). Confirmation was done by a segmental leg pressure test which showed a significant drop in pressure in his right leg. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) test also demonstrated an extremely diminished ratio of ankle to brachial systolic blood pressure. Further comprehensive studies including Doppler ultrasound and angiography confirmed severe stenosis in the distal parts of his right leg arteries.  Treatment and Follow-up: Mr. X was referred to a vascular surgeon and underwent successful revascularization surgery. Instructions were provided to Mr. X and his family regarding the need for improving his foot care  regular exercise  smoking cessation  and dietary changes to control his hyperlipidemia  diabetes and hypertension. Long term medication included aspirin  a statin  and an ACE inhibitor  to manage his vascular disease. He was scheduled for a close follow-up session to monitor his recovery and manage his associated comorbidities.  Conclusion: Critical Limb Ischemia is a severe condition that requires immediate attention and comprehensive management  which includes control of risk factors and lifestyle changes. With prompt intervention and dedicated follow-up  patients like Mr. X can enjoy improved quality of life.

Patient Profile:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired firefighter was referred to the vascular department with a history of critical limb ischemia (CLI). His chief complaints included intermittent pains in both his feet  with difficulty in walking and complete rest in the past two months. On initial questioning  the patient also reported wounds that had persisted for the last six weeks. His history of pain and wounds was consistent with his condition.   Past Medical History:   The patient had been diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus Type II and Hyperlipidemia five years ago. His medications included Metformin and Simvastatin. Moreover  he also had a pack-a-day smoking habit that spanned 40 years but had stopped smoking a year ago. A year before  the patient had suffered a myocardial infarction for which he underwent successful coronary stenting and was on low dose Aspirin. There was no history of hypertension  cerebrovascular accidents  or any known allergy.   The family history was significant with his father having died of a myocardial infarction and his mother from a stroke  both in their early 70s. Consequently  the patient seemed aware of his risk factors and understood the need for lifestyle modifications and compliance with medications.  Examination and Assessment:  On physical examination  his Body Mass Index (BMI) was 31 indicating obesity. Upon inspecting the feet  minor gangrenous changes were observed on his left foot's big toe with rest of the feet showing dusky discoloration. Decreased sensation to touch and pain were noted upon neurological examination of the feet. Pedal pulses (Dorsalis Pedis and Posterior Tibial artery pulses) were palpable but significantly weakened bilaterally.   Doppler ultrasound revealed decreased ankle-brachial index (ABI) with values of 0.5 and 0.6 in the right and left leg respectively (normal range: 0.9 - 1.3). Severe arterial occlusive disease was inferred from these values. A computed tomographic angiography confirmed the presence of bilateral peripheral arterial disease involving the arteries below the knee.  In summary  this patient presented with typical symptoms of CLI which were corroborated by physical examination and radiological findings. His diabetes  hyperlipidemia  past smoking habit  and family history were significant contributors to the development of severe peripheral arterial disease and subsequently CLI.

Title: A Case Report: Presentation and Management of Critical Limb Ischemia in a 68-Year-Old Male  Introduction:  This is a case report of a 68-year-old Caucasian male with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  highlighting the importance of early detection and aggressive management of this potentially life-threatening condition.  Case Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Chronic Kidney Disease (stage 3)  and Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD). He presented to our clinic reporting worsening pain in his left lower extremity that had been persisting for six months. The pain was described as a strong squeezing sensation that escalated during movement and slightly relieved during rest.  On examination  the left lower limb was notably colder than the right  with observable pallor and delayed capillary refill. Pulses were absent on the dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial arteries. Foot examination revealed the presence of an unhealed ulcer on the lateral aspect of the left foot.  Demographic data include the patient being a lifetime resident of the local area  a retired steelworker  married with three adult children. The patient is a smoker (40 pack-years) and drinks alcohol occasionally.  Clinical Findings:  Doppler ultrasound demonstrated significantly reduced blood flow in the left lower extremity. Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) in the left lower extremity was 0.40.  Blood work revealed a mildly elevated creatinine and slightly uncontrolled glucose levels.   Diagnosis:  Given the history  physical examination  and diagnostic findings  the diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) of the left lower extremity was made.  Treatment:  The patient was referred to a vascular surgeon and was advised an immediate surgical intervention. A successful below-the-knee (BTK) amputation was performed. Post-operatively  he was started on a tailored regimen for better control of his diabetes and renal condition. A smoking cessation program was initiated alongside comprehensive rehabilitation services.   Outcome and Follow-Up:  The patient was able to go home two weeks post-operation and was seen every two weeks for the first three months during the initial post-operative phase for wound care and rehabilitation. At his 6-month follow-up appointment  the patient reported marked improvement in his overall symptoms.  Discussion:  CLI is a severe stage of PAD  leading to a high rate of limb loss if not treated aggressively. The patient's history of diabetes  smoking  kidney disease  and prior PAD made him a high-risk candidate for CLI. This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition and intervention  considering all risk factors  to optimize outcomes in these patients. It further reiterates the need for lifestyle modification and strict control of comorbid conditions.   Patient's Perspective:  ""The pain was unbearable. I'm glad the doctors were able to help me and manage it. It's hard adjusting after the operation  but I am happy that I am no longer in constant pain. I understood I had to stop smoking and better control my diabetes. I see this as a second chance at leading a healthier life"".

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information: Mr. X  a 74-year-old Caucasian male presented to the hospital with a chief complaint of severe  unrelenting pain in his right lower limb for the past week. The patient lives in a rural part of the country with limited access to healthcare facilities and is an ex-tobacco user with a history of 40 pack years. He is widowed with three adult children  retired after working as a farmer for most of his life.  Medical History: Mr. X has a known history of hypertension and dyslipidemia for the past 10 years  managed on anti-hypertensives and statins. He was diagnosed with Type II diabetes 8 years ago  currently managed with oral hypoglycemics. In his family history  early coronary artery disease in his father and a brother was noted. There was no history of deep vein thrombosis  chronic liver or renal disease.  Presenting Signs and Symptoms: The patient reported an escalating sharp and burning pain in his right lower limb  predominantly at the foot and calf region. The pain was worse at night and somewhat relieved by hanging the foot down from the bed. Associated symptoms included non-healing ulcers on the foot  discoloration  and coldness of the limb to touch.  Physical Exam: Examination revealed a thinner right leg when compared to the left  with noticeable muscle atrophy. There were palpable femoral pulses  but the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses were absent. Perfusion was poor  with the skin appearing bluish-purple and cold to touch. A non-healing ulcer surrounded by areas of gangrene was noted on the lateral side of the right foot.  Diagnosis: Based on the patient's presenting complaints  medical history  physical findings  and investigations including Doppler ultrasound which revealed stenosis of the right popliteal and anterior tibial arteries  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) secondary to peripheral artery disease was established.  Management: Aggressive risk-factor modification was initiated  including tight glucose  hypertension  and cholesterol control. Smoking cessation was reinforced  though the patient was already a former smoker. The patient was prescribed clopidogrel and cilostazol to reduce clot formation and improve blood flow. Pain management was addressed with analgesics. To restore circulation  he was scheduled for an angioplasty. Eventually  a minor amputation was done  given the presence of gangrene.  Course and Outcome: The foot ulcer was regularly dressed to promote healing. After the angioplasty and amputation  the patient's lower limb pain significantly reduced. The patient was enrolled in a cardiac rehabilitation program  with a plan of physiotherapy to improve muscle strength and gait.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the importance of proactive management of risk factors for CLI  especially in patients with a significant history of smoking  hypertension  diabetes  and dyslipidemia. The necessity for timely medical intervention to ensure functional recovery and stave off the requirement of more severe amputations is emphasized.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a Diabetic Patient - A Case Report   Patient Information: Mr. A  a 63-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the outpatient department of our hospital.  Medical History: Mr. A had been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hypertension for the past 15 years. He had a history of tobacco use but quit 10 years ago. His medications included metformin  lisinopril  and a statin. There was no known history of peripheral arterial disease in the family.   Presenting Symptoms: The patient reported right lower limb rest pain for the past 4 months and a non-healing ulcer on his right foot for the past 2 months. The pain was severe enough to hinder sleep and regular day to day activities. The patient's glucose levels were inconsistently monitored and poorly controlled.   Physical Examination: On examination  his right foot was cool to touch  with a non-healing gangrenous ulcer measuring 2 cm in diameter on the forefoot. His right dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were not palpable. A palpable pulse was noted in the left foot. Mr. A's foot also exhibited dependent rubor (redness) and pallor (pale color) upon elevation - a sign of severe ischemia.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Ankle brachial pressure index (ABPI) was 0.40 on the right side and 0.98 on the left side. Doppler ultrasound revealed severe multilevel peripheral arterial disease in the right lower limb. CT angiography of the lower limbs confirmed the bilateral peripheral arterial disease with right-side dominance. Mr. A was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI) of the right lower limb.  Treatment: Considering the severity of the patient's condition  prompt action was required to revascularize the limb and control the infection in the foot. Endovascular treatment was planned. An angioplasty was performed successfully on the right limb  significantly improving the blood flow. The right foot ulcer was debrided  and culture-specific antibiotic therapy was initiated.  Follow Up: At the 1-month follow-up  the patient reported relief from rest pain and showed signs of healing of the foot ulcer. He was advised to maintain strict glycemic control and attend regular follow-ups.   This case highlights the importance of early detection and management of peripheral vascular disease & CLI among patients with type 2 diabetes. In the presence of chronic conditions such as diabetes  careful monitoring and management are crucial to prevent severe complications such as CLI. With timely and appropriate management  even severe cases of ischemia can show improvement  as seen in Mr. A's condition.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 59-year-old Male  Patient Profile: The patient is a 59-year-old Caucasian male who presents with symptoms of critical limb ischemia. His past medical history reveals a long chronicle of cardiovascular disease  diabetes mellitus (Type II)  and hypertension. He smoked for 35 years and has quit smoking 3 years ago. He lives with his wife and has two adult children. His profession was a long-distance truck driver which made daily physical exercises difficult. There is a family history of peripheral arterial disease.  Presenting Complaints: The patient arrived at the clinic complaining of increasing levels of pain in his lower right extremity of 6 weeks duration. The pain had the characteristics of claudication initially (relieved with rest) but over 2 weeks progressed to being more persistent and dramatic (rest pain). He also pointed out that over the last week  the foot had become noticeably cold to touch and appeared to be slightly discolored.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  his right leg was found to be cool  bluish-purple in color distally  and had a weak to nearly absent dorsalis pedis pulse. Skin of the distal portion of the right limb appeared glossy with noticeable hair loss. Neurological examination of the limb revealed decreased sensation  particularly in the foot region. Pain was accentuated when the leg was at an elevated position.  Investigations: An ankle-brachial pressure index (ABI) was performed  yielding a result of 0.38 on the right side indicative of severe peripheral arterial disease. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed the ABI findings and revealed significantly reduced blood flow in the right lower limb. A subsequent magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) showed severe  multi-segment  infra-inguinal arterial occlusive disease which was consistent with the patient's clinical picture of critical limb ischemia.  Management: Following the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia  the patient was initially managed with medication  including low dose aspirin  and statins. A well-balanced diet was recommended with appropriate dietetic referral. As he was diabetic  his glucose levels were closely monitored and diabetes management strategies were reviewed. The possibility of surgical and endovascular interventions  like peripheral bypass grafting and angioplasty  were discussed with the patient and his family.  Follow-up: The patient was scheduled for regular follow-up appointments to monitor his progress. The persistent pain  the slightly blue appearance of the foot along with the poor perfusion seen in his investigations suggests that close monitoring and imminent active intervention will be essential to limb preservation.  This case highlights the imperative nature of early detection and intervention in the management of critical limb ischemia. Robust risk factor management  patient education  and efficient medical or surgical interventions can prevent major outcomes like limb loss and associated morbidities.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a Female Patient with Uncontrolled Diabetes Mellitus  Introduction:  Critical limb ischemia (CLI) is categorized as a severe obstruction of the arteries which critically reduces blood flow to the extremities. This report presents the case of a 68-year-old female patient with a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus who presented with critical limb ischemia.  Case Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old African American female who resides in a suburban neighborhood. She reported to the hospital with signs and symptoms consistent with critical limb ischemia. The focused history revealed worsening continuous rest pain in the lower extremities  specifically her right leg over the past week  associated with non-healing ulcers on her foot.  Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 25 years ago and has been on medication therapy  which she admits not taking regularly. Unfortunately  her diabetes has been poorly controlled throughout the years  as evidenced by her recorded HbA1c level which was consistently above 8%. She also has a history of hypertension and dyslipidemia but no previous events of coronary artery disease  stroke or peripheral arterial disease. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  the patient’s right foot was found to be cool  with pallor orienting at rest. When elevated  the foot became pale  and dependent rubor was noticed when it was dependent. Distinctive skin lesions were noticed  including non-healing ulcers on the medial aspect of the foot. Pulses in the foot were not palpable and intermittent claudication was positive. An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test showed a value of less than 0.5  indicating severe peripheral artery disease.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An angiogram confirmed the critical limb ischemia  diagnosing severe stenosis in the right lower limb. Labs revealed an elevated HbA1c level of 9.8%  which highlighted the patient’s uncontrolled diabetes.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient underwent a successful right lower limb angioplasty and stent placement to restore the blood supply. Concurrently  better diabetes control was targeted with adjustment of her oral therapy and insulin initiation.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  Post-procedure  she reported alleviation of rest pain. Regular foot care and strict sugar control were advised. She was discharged with medications including antiplatelets  statins  and insulin with close outpatient follow-ups for her diabetes and foot care.  Conclusion:  This case demonstrates the heightened risk of developing critical limb ischemia in patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. Clinicians should remain vigilant and proactive in managing diabetes and promoting peripheral vascular health.

Title: A Report on a Case of a 75-year-old Male with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information: The patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male  currently retired. He is married and lives with his wife. The patient  a former smoker  has a history of high blood pressure  type II diabetes mellitus  and dyslipidemia. He gave up smoking ten years ago but had been a smoker for approximately 50 years. His medications include metformin  amlodipine  and simvastatin. There is no history of any allergic reaction to medications or substances. He is also under medication for lower back arthritis.   Presenting Problem: The patient was admitted to the hospital complaining of severe pain in his left lower extremity even while in a resting state  which had been increasing in intensity over the past few weeks. He also reported skin discoloration and intermittent claudication  sleep disturbances due to pain  and had reduced mobility due to pain and discomfort. He noticed the pain was worst while he was lying down and improved when he hung his leg off the side of the bed.   Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed weak pedal pulses  presence of non-healing ulcers on the foot  and coldness of the affected limb. His toes appeared dusky  indicative of poor blood supply. His blood pressure was slightly elevated  and his Fasting Blood Sugar was also on the higher end. Lab findings showed an increased HbA1c level with a slightly elevated CRP level indicating an inflammatory process. His lipid profile was likewise showing slight elevation.   Diagnostics: Doppler Ultrasound of the left lower extremity revealed markedly decreased blood flow consistent with critical limb ischemia. CT Angiography further validated peripheral arterial occlusive disease prominently in the left lower limb's posterior tibial and peroneal arteries.   Therapeutic Intervention: Considering the patient's medical history and the critical nature of his present condition  a multidisciplinary team assembled for his treatment. The patient underwent endovascular revascularization procedure  with angioplasty of the posterior tibial and peroneal arteries  followed by a period of medically managed care for metabolic control  pain management  and wound care. He was also referred to a dietician and physiotherapist for further help.  Outcome: The patient responded well to the angioplasty procedure  as evidenced by improved symptoms and follow-up Doppler Ultrasound showing improved blood flow. His pain was controlled with medications  and the ulcers showed signs of healing. The patient and his family were educated about the disease  its implications  risk factors  and the crucial need for dietary changes  physiotherapy and regular monitoring. They were also made aware of the risk of reoccurrence and were advised on early recognition of symptoms.  This case again emphasizes the fact that early detection and prompt treatment of critical limb ischemia is essential for a better prognosis and prevention of limb loss  being particularly important in patients with a history of multiple risks such as advanced age  diabetes  hypertension  and dyslipidemia like in this case.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in an Elderly Hypertensive Patient with Multiple Cardiovascular Comorbidities  Introduction: Patient X  a 72-year-old African American woman  was admitted to the emergency department presenting signs of critical limb ischemia. The patient reported severe  persistent pain in her left foot  particularly on her toe area  which was discolored (bluish-grey) and cold to touch.  Past Medical History: Patient X had a history of uncontrolled hypertension and had been previously diagnosed with other cardiovascular comorbidities  including congestive heart failure and atrial fibrillation. She also had a previous stroke 4 years prior to her current admission but had recovered well with minimal residual deficits. She did not have any known allergies but had a significant smoking history  having smoked close to a pack a day for approximately 50 years. Her routine medication included aspirin  warfarin  statins  ACE inhibitors for her hypertension and cardiac conditions  and insulin for her type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her family history is rich in hypertension  diabetes  and cardiovascular accidents.  Findings: Physical examination of the patient revealed a non-healing ulcer on her big toe. Doppler ultrasonography confirmed poor blood circulation her left foot  and an ankle brachial index of 0.4 on her left lower extremity confirmed the ischemia. Diagnostic angiography further showed extensive atherosclerosis of the distal left popliteal artery and complete occlusion of the tibio-peroneal trunk and its branches. An examination of the right foot did not exhibit any abnormal findings.  Management and Follow-up: Given the extent of arterial disease and numerous cardiovascular comorbidities  open surgical revascularization was deemed too high risk for the patient. The decision was made by the vascular team to proceed with endovascular revascularization. The patient underwent successful percutaneous transluminal angioplasty. Immediately post-operation  the patient reported an alleviation of pain  and there was a significant improvement in the coloration and temperature of her left foot.   The patient was discharged a week after the procedure with antibiotics  analgesics  and a modification to her antiplatelet regimen to include clopidogrel. A referral was made to a diabetes nurse educator and a dietitian to optimize her diabetic control and nutritional support. Patient X was followed up at regular intervals  with significant improvements in her ambulatory function and healing of her foot ulcer over several weeks.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the importance of early recognition and aggressive management of critical limb ischemia in an elderly  multicomorbid patient. Success in this case was due to the multidisciplinary approach in managing her disease  providing medical control of her comorbidities  and giving appropriate endovascular intervention combined with comprehensive wound care.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 68-Year-Old Male   Demographics:  - Patient Initials: J.G - Age: 68 years old - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired military officer - Residency: Urban area  Washington D.C.  Medical History:  The patient has a significant past medical history including Type II Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 18 years ago  Hypertension for the last 20 years  Dyslipidemia  and a history of heavy smoking for 40 years but quit five years ago. He had no known allergies and his surgical history includes appendectomy at age 24.  Presenting Problem:  J.G presented to the emergency department with increasing pain in his left lower limb for 4 weeks. The pain  initially intermittent and provoked by walking  gradually worsened over the past week  becoming persistent  severe  and unrelieved by rest. The patient also reported experiencing episodes of coldness in his left foot  together with numbness and some motor weakness  accompanied by a loss of hair in the affected area.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the left lower limb appeared paler compared to the right  was cold to touch and had absent distal pulses. Hair loss was noticed on the distal third of the left lower limb. A non-healing ulcer was observed on the left foot. The motor strength of the limb was 3/5  and the patient exhibited decreased sensation to fine touch and pinprick below his left knee.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was conducted revealing an ABI of 0.4 in left limb suggestive of severe peripheral artery disease. Doppler ultrasound of the limb demonstrated severe stenosis in the left superficial femoral artery. Further angiographic studies confirmed the diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Therapeutic Intervention:  Following the diagnosis  the patient was started on medication including antiplatelets and painkillers. He underwent successful revascularization surgery  where the stenotic areas in the femoral artery were bypassed. Postoperatively  the patient was managed on dual antiplatelets  statins  beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors for hypertension. Glycemic control was attempted under the guidance of an endocrinologist  with the patient receiving insulin therapy and dietary counseling.  Outcome:  Following the surgery  the patient’s symptoms improved considerably within a week. His pedal pulses seemed stronger on examination. The ulcer on the foot started showing signs of healing with adequate wound care. To prevent recurrence  the patient was advised to continue his medication  control his diabetes  and lifestyle modification was emphasized.  This case is an illustration of how CLI can present and emphasizes the need for vigilance in vascular assessments  particularly in patients with multiple risk factors such as diabetes and history of heavy smoking. The successful management of this case further underscores the importance of a multidisciplinary approach involving vascular surgeons  endocrinologists  and wound management team in managing CLI.

Patient Information:   Mr. X is a 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of type II diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He is a 45 pack-year smoker  who quit 10 years ago and reports alcohol only on special occasions.  Clinical Findings:  Mr. X initially presented to the vascular surgery clinic with a 3-week history of severe pain in his left lower extremity  particularly at rest  associated with non-healing ulcers on his left foot toes. The pain would often disrupt his sleep and was only partially relieved by strong analgesics. He reported noticeable color and temperature changes in his left foot  with it becoming pale and cold compared to the contralateral foot. He lost approximately 8 pounds over the same course of time due to a decreased appetite from his severe pain.  Diagnosis:  Upon physical examination  his left foot was noticeably cooler and paler than the contralateral foot  with diminished pulses in the left pedal and popliteal arteries. His ankle-brachial index (ABI) was 0.5 on the left and 0.92 on the right. An angiogram revealed a large blockage in the left femoral artery extending into the popliteal artery. Based on clinical findings  reduced ABI  and angiogram results  he was diagnosed with Critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Treatment:  In consultation with the vascular surgery team  it was decided to perform an aortobifemoral bypass graft to restore blood flow to the left lower extremity as interventional procedures were unlikely to be successful considering the severity and extensity of the disease. The patient was educated about the serious nature of his condition and surgical plan.   Mr. X successfully underwent the aortobifemoral bypass graft surgery. Post surgery  he had regular appointments with a dietitian in order to manage his diabetes and was also seen by a podiatrist and physical therapist. He was started on statin and aspirin for long term management of his existing cardiovascular risk factors.  Follow-up:  Four weeks after the surgery  his pain at rest had significantly improved  and his foot ulcers showed signs of improvement. His follow-up ABI was 0.82 on the left  indicating improved perfusion in the left lower extremity after the bypass surgery. He continues to visit the clinic for follow-up evaluations and has shown a commitment to maintaining lifestyle modifications to manage his existing cardiovascular disease risk factors.  This case illustrates the importance of prompt recognition and treatment of CLI in order to prevent limb loss and to improve patients’ quality of life.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a Patient with a History of Diabetes and Peripheral Arterial Disease   Introduction:  Critical limb ischemia (CLI) and its related complications are often associated with underlying health conditions such as Diabetes Mellitus and Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD). We present a case of a 70-year-old male with a significant medical history  including hypertension  peripheral arterial disease  and diabetes mellitus type II complicated by CLI.  Patient Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient presented to the emergency department with a complaint of severe resting pain in his right lower extremity. The patient defined his pain as a dull and burning sensation in nature which had worsened over the past few weeks. He additionally reported difficulty in walking and a noticeable loss of hair on his right limb. His past medical history was significant for diabetes mellitus type II  hypertension  and PAD. He was a former smoker with a 40 pack-year history.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed an extremely pale  cold  and pulseless right lower extremity. The limb was hairless and showed ulcers on the extremities. Vascular examination revealed diminished dorsalis pedis and popliteal artery pulses on the right side. The patient's Ankle-brachial Index (ABI) was 0.4–indicative of severe blockage and risk for CLI.  Diagnostic Assessment: A contrast angiography was performed  which showed multi-level obstructive arterial disease affecting the iliac  femoral  and below knee popliteal arteries. Blood results showed elevated fasting blood sugars and HbA1C of 8.6%  suggestive of poor glycemic control.  Interventions: Under a multidisciplinary team including a vascular surgeon  interventional radiologist  and endocrinologist  the patient was started on a dual antiplatelet regimen with Aspirin and Clopidogrel  high-dose statin  and his diabetes was managed with appropriate insulin therapy. He underwent successful endovascular revascularization using balloon angioplasty and stent implantation. Post-operation  he was monitored closely for any signs of infection or necrosis. Options for a more aggressive surgical intervention were held as a last resort should he not improve after the endovascular procedure.  Outcome and Follow-up: At follow-up  the patient's pain significantly abated with an improved ABI of 0.9. The patient was maintaining good glycemic control  and his ulcers were showing signs of steady healing without any evidence of necrosis.  Conclusion: This case demonstrates that in patients with significant medical history  the manifestation of severe symptoms like rest pain and non-healing ulcers should alert clinicians about the potential risk of critical limb ischemia. Early recognition  appropriate diagnostics  aggressive risk factor management  and intervention can improve the patient's quality of life and outcomes.

Case Report on Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information   The patient is a 65-year-old male. He is Caucasian  retired  and with no known allergies. He resides in a suburban community with his wife. Other demographic information includes a smoking history of 30 pack-years but quit 10 years ago. He also drinks alcohol occasionally and he used to work as a factory worker.  Presenting Issue   The patient presented to the clinic with complaints of pain in his right lower extremity  which has become increasingly severe over the past three months. He reported intermittent claudication initially  but his symptoms have progressed to a point where he experiences ischemic rest pain. The pain is mostly located in his foot  particularly at the heel. The patient has noticed that the pain intensifies when lying flat and usually relieves partially when his leg is in dependence. He also reported that his foot never regains its natural color even when he stops walking and appears reddish-blue. The foot is cold to touch and the pulses cannot be palpated. He also developed a non-healing ulcer on the right foot on the great toe a month ago.  Past Medical History  The patient has a significant history of type II diabetes mellitus  which was diagnosed 10 years ago. His blood sugar level has been poorly controlled. His medical history also includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a history of myocardial infarction five years prior with subsequent bypass surgery. He had been compliant with his medications for these conditions  including insulin  a beta-blocker  a statin  and an ACE inhibitor.  Clinical Findings   The physical examination revealed a painful ulcer on the right great toe that measures approximate 2cm in diameter surrounded by skin discoloration. Distal hair loss on the right lower extremity is noticeable. Pulses on the common and distal parts of his right lower extremity are not palpable. The Doppler signals are severely diminished  suggestive of arterial insufficiency.   Diagnosis   The patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI) based on his clinical findings and symptoms. CLI is a severe obstruction of the arteries which reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to cause severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.  Treatment  The patient was immediately referred to a vascular surgeon for further management. Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) and/or bypass surgery would probably be warranted based on the advanced status of his disease.  Summary  This case depicts severely uncontrolled peripheral vascular disease leading to CLI  likely due to the combination of diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a history of smoking. It emphasizes the imperative need for a holistic approach to ensuring optimal vascular health  including strict control of diabetes  cessation of smoking  and management of other vascular risk factors.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. A  a 68-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Issue: The patient presented with symptoms of critical limb ischemia (CLI) including severe pain in the lower leg  non-healing sores on the left foot and lower leg  and noticeable changes in color and temperature of the lower leg and foot.  Medical History: Mr. A has a long-standing history of smoking and heavy drinking  dating back almost 45 years. He suffers from hypertension and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 12 years ago  for which he is currently taking Metformin. He also has stage III chronic kidney disease and peripheral arterial disease (PAD). His surgical history includes a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) intervention five years ago. There has been no noted history of strokes or transient ischemic attacks.  Investigations: On physical examination  his left foot and lower leg appeared significantly paler than their counterparts. His right foot showed normal perfusion while the left foot was noticeably cooler  indicating poor blood flow. Doppler examination of the lower limbs revealed an ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.4 on the left side and 0.9 on the right. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the lower extremity showed multi-segmental occlusive disease in his left leg.  Treatment and Management: Given the patient’s clinical symptoms  history  and diagnostic test results  he was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia. The multidisciplinary team decided on an endovascular intervention to restore blood flow due to the multi-segmental disease and critical state of his limb.  Simultaneously  Mr. A was strongly advised to quit smoking and limit alcohol intake. He was referred to a dietician to help manage his diabetes and obesity through a controlled diet plan  and was advised for active participation in a structured exercise program. His antihypertensive medications were adjusted aiming optimal control.   Follow-up details: A significant decrease in pain was reported immediately after the endovascular procedure. At a one-month follow-up appointment  Mr. A's left lower limb was warmer  with better coloration. His wounds showed signs of healing. He was strictly adhering to diet plan and medication  but had difficulty quitting smoking.   This case underscores critical limb ischemia as a severe state of peripheral arterial disease  frequently associated with smoking  diabetes  and chronic kidney disease. It highlights the importance of an early diagnosis  aggressive management  and improvement in lifestyle for better outcomes.

Title: A Case Report of Critical Limb Ischemia in a Male Patient with Long-Standing History of Type 2 Diabetes and Current Tobacco Use  Patient Information: A 65-year old Caucasian male presented to the outpatient vascular clinic with a three-week history of progressive right leg pain  predominantly at rest  along with noticeable discoloration and coldness of the right lower extremity.  Medical History: The patient has a documented history of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which has not been well-controlled for about 20 years. He is also a chronic smoker for more than 40 years  currently consuming about 1 pack of cigarettes per day. The patient had a remote history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) in the ipsilateral limb diagnosed seven years prior  but was asymptomatic until recently. His other medical conditions include hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient’s right foot exhibited a cold temperature when compared to the ipsilateral limb  with delayed capillary refill and noticeable skin discoloration involving the entire limb distal to the knee. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were markedly diminished. Multiple non-healing ulcers with necrotic tissue were observed on the toes.  Diagnostic Assessment: An ankle-brachial index (ABI) test revealed an index of less than 0.3  considered severe peripheral arterial disease. Doppler ultrasound demonstrated severe atherosclerotic disease in the right lower limb with a complete blockage below the knee. A tissue sample from the foot ulcer demonstrated gangrene without signs of bacterial infection.  Therapeutic Intervention: Given the severity of ischemia  invasive revascularization (angioplasty or bypass surgery) was discussed with the patient. An initial attempt to do endovascular recanalization was unsuccessful. The patient was scheduled for a below-knee amputation to prevent upward progression of the gangrene.  Follow-up: The patient responded positively post-surgery and expressed relief from rest pain. A multidisciplinary team including a diabetologist  physiotherapist and a counsellor were involved in post-operative care. The patient was enrolled in smoking cessation and diabetic control programs.  Conclusion: This case demonstrates the importance of prevention and early intervention in patients with known risk factors such as type 2 Diabetes and smoking to avoid severe outcomes related to chronic limb-threatening ischemia. Critical limb ischemia represents the end-stage peripheral arterial disease that can cause significant morbidity if not managed appropriately and timely. Multidisciplinary care and patient education play critical roles in the management of such chronic illnesses.

Patient Information: Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male presenting with symptoms indicative of critical limb ischemia (CLI). He is of average build and height. He is a retired construction worker and lives alone. He has a 35 pack-year smoking history but had quit smoking 10 years ago. He is a teetotaler and follows a balanced diet. History indicates no illicit drug use  sexual health concerns  or known allergies.   Past Medical & Surgical History: Previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)  hypertension (HTN)  Hypercholesterolemia  and a history of ischemic heart disease (IHD). The patient had a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) procedure done six years ago for three-vessel disease and has been on regular follow-ups since then. He has been compliant with medications for his chronic conditions. His immunizations are up-to-date. There is no known history of past surgeries beyond the CABG.  Family History: Father died of heart disease in his 60s; mother diagnosed with hypertension but lived into her mid-80s. He has one brother with type 2 diabetes and hypertension.  Presenting Complaint: He has been experiencing worsening pain in his right lower extremity for months  though recently it has increased in severity and started causing rest pain  which interrupts his sleep. The pain has been particularly severe for the past week.   Physical Examination: Upon examination  the right lower limb appeared pale  with hair loss and dystrophic toenail changes. No palpable pulses were detected in the foot. Temperature of the foot was lower than the left one  there was sensory loss  and the motor strength was decreased. Other systemic examinations were normal.  Preliminary Diagnosis: Critical Limb Ischemia with rest pain and signs of malperfusion  possibly secondary to peripheral arterial disease (PAD).   Plan: Immediate hospitalization was suggested with treatment organized to include pain management  diagnostic angiography  further vascular assessment and revascularization procedure planning. Patient was interested in discussing possible outcomes and agreed for further workup and treatment.   This case indicates the common presentation of an individual that might experience CLI. It emphasises the importance of careful examination and prompt intervention for peripheral vascular diseases in patients  particularly those with multiple atherosclerotic risk factors.

Title: Case Report: An Elderly Female with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information:  Ms. L  an 87-year-old Caucasian female  was admitted to the Department of Vascular Surgery in our hospital with a one-month history of worsening pain  especially during the night in her right lower limb.  Clinical History:  Ms. L has a known history of hypertension  which is well controlled with Amlodipine  10mg daily  and obesity with a BMI of 35. She was also diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus  which she has been managing with Metformin  1000mg two times daily  for the last 15 years. The patient reported long-standing history of intermittent claudication. Her lipid profile was within the upper normal limit  with mildly elevated LDL cholesterol. Prior to this admission  she had never smoked  did not consume alcohol  and has a sedentary lifestyle. No family history of ischemic disease was reported.  First Presentation:  Ms. L presented a non-healing ulcer on her right heel  measuring 2x2 cm with extensive necrosis centrally  surrounded by erythema and induration. There were signs of minor infection but no signs of systemic inflammatory response or sepsis. She also described severe rest pain  especially during the night  and she was unable to place her foot in a dependent position. Her right foot was cold to touch  with weak pedal pulses and reduced capillary refill time. Her left foot demonstrated a palpable popliteal pulse with reduced pedal pulses.  Diagnosis:  The patient underwent a Doppler ultrasound which revealed significant calcification of the arteries throughout all three segments of the right lower limb  with multi-segment occlusion in the superficial femoral artery  and tibial and peroneal arteries. A diagnosis of critical limb ischemia secondary to peripheral artery disease was made based on her clinical presentation and Doppler ultrasound findings.  Management:  The patient was managed conservatively initially with the administration of intravenous antibiotics  pain management  and supportive wound care  followed by revascularization screening. Due to her age  underlying diabetes  and extensive calcification  her risk profile was considered high for surgical intervention. After multidisciplinary discussions  the team decided to perform an endovascular procedure.  Outcome:  The endovascular procedure was successful  with immediate symptom improvement. Complete wound healing occurred within eight weeks post-procedure. The patient continues to be monitored regularly for follow-up and is under the management of a diabetes specialist and nutritionist.  Concluding Notes:  This case underlines that the early diagnosis and timely management of critical limb ischemia are vital in the elderly population with co-morbid conditions such as diabetes and hypertension. A multidisciplinary approach is beneficial to enhance patient care and prognosis.

Patient's Details:   Gender: Male  Age: 59 years old   Ethnicity: African-American  Occupation: Truck driver  Residence: Urban region  Miami  Florida  USA  History of alcohol intake: Yes (moderate  20 years)  Smoking history: Yes (30 pack-years)  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with severe and persistent rest pain in his right lower limb especially below the knee for the last 3 months. The pain was mainly at night along with occasional non-healing ulcers on the foot.  Past Medical History:  The patient reported a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 12 years ago  which was inadequately controlled. He also had a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. There was no history of any cardiac event. The patient had a 30 pack-years history of smoking and moderate alcohol consumption.  Physical Examination:  On examination  his right lower limb was pale and cold to touch. His distal pulsations were not palpable. His foot showed signs of non-healing ulcers with blackish discoloration.  Investigations: Peripheral artery Doppler study of the right lower limb showed multiple blockages in the anterior tibial  posterior tibial and peroneal arteries. Ankle-brachial index was 0.6 on the right side.   Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI) of the right lower limb with long-standing uncontrolled diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia.  Management: The patient was referred to a vascular surgeon. He underwent revascularization surgery. He was also advised on diabetic control and the cessation of smoking and alcohol consumption.   Follow up: The patient had a significant improvement in pain. However  the ulcers showed slow healing. He was advised regular follow-up and wound care.  In Summary: This case underscores the importance of early recognition and prompt management of CLI. It also emphasizes the need for aggressive control of co-morbid conditions such as diabetes  hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and lifestyle modification in such patients to optimize outcomes.   Author's Contribution: Sajid Ahmed  MBBS  Resident  Department of Medicine  Florida Medical College  Miami  Florida.

Title: A Case Report on a Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia   Patient Demographics:   Mr. J.B is a 65-year-old Caucasian male. He’s retired and lives with his wife in rural northern Kentucky. He’s of average build and does not smoke  but acknowledges that he is a social drinker. He has three adult children and several grandchildren.  Past Medical History:   The patient was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes twenty years back but has had moderate control over his blood sugar levels with oral hypoglycemics. He also suffers from hypertension which is managed by a combination of lifestyle modifications and antihypertensive drugs. Along with these he has Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) diagnosed three years back. His cholesterol levels have been high for past five years and he has been undergoing treatment for the same.  Case Presentation:  Mr. J.B presented to the office with escalating complaints of pain in his right lower leg  particularly noticing enhanced pain when walking  often forcing him to stop and rest. Over the previous couple of months  he also noticed that his right foot frequently felt extremely cold and was beginning to appear more pale in color. He complained of pain at rest that disturbed his sleep. Upon physical examination  the right foot was cold to touch  with decreased hair growth  thickened toenails  and the absent dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses.   Diagnostic Assessment & Therapeutic Intervention:  On the basis of the symptoms and history provided diagnostic tests were recommended. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) was significantly reduced  revealing severe PAD in the right leg. The ultrasound showed advanced occlusion of the right femoral artery. Angiography demonstrated occlusion of the right superficial femoral artery. Considering the findings  angioplasty was conducted. Anticoagulant therapy was initiated post-procedure to prevent clot formation.  Outcome and Follow-up:  He was discharged with instruction for lifestyle modifications and proper wound care. He was also counseled about the importance of tighter glycemic control  avoidance of alcohol  regular exercise  and the cessation of cholesterol-rich food. The patient has been on follow-ups every two weeks for the past three months and there has been significant improvement in the color and temperature of his right foot. His pain has considerably reduced and he can now walk without needing to stop for rest.  Conclusion:   Critical Limb Ischemia is a serious manifestation of Peripheral Artery Disease. Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are crucial to save the limb and  more importantly  the life of the patient. The case emphasizes the importance of vigilance in patients with risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  and Dyslipidemia.

Title: A Case of Critical Limb Ischemia in an Elderly Patient with Co-existing Diabetes and Peripheral Arterial Disease   Patient Description:   Mr. Arthur M  a 74-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the hospital with complaints of severe pain in his left leg  particularly the calf and foot region. The patient reported that the pain was worse at night and often disturbed his sleep. Accompanying symptoms included leg numbness  slow-healing sores on the lower leg and foot  and a discernible coldness to the touch  noticeable on that limb. The patient also reported significant weight loss in the recent past.  Background:  The patient has a longstanding medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 16 years ago and is presently managed by diet control and insulin. He was also diagnosed with Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) and Hyperlipidemia around ten years back. He is currently on statins and antiplatelet therapy for the same.   Mr. M has a past surgical history of an appendectomy in his 30s and corneal transplant in his right eye about five years ago. He is a former smoker  having quit 9 years ago after a 45-year pack history. He consumes alcohol socially. The patient is retired and lives alone  with regular help from home care aid services.  Family history includes coronary artery disease in his late father and a younger brother diagnosed with diabetes  hypertension and kidney disease. His mother died of ovarian cancer at the age of 68.   Clinical Findings  Upon initial physical examination  the physician noted pallor  diminished pulses in the left lower limb  and non-palpable foot pulses. Temperature difference was also noted  with the left foot being significantly colder compared to the right foot. A few ulcers  the largest approximately 2cm in diameter  were seen on the sole of the left foot. No signs of gangrene were visible.  Initial laboratory tests showed marginal elevation of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c – 8.1%)  a high total cholesterol (255mg/dL)  and LDL level at 160mg/dL. No remarkable elevation in markers of inflammation was noted. Doppler ultrasound revealed significantly reduced blood flow in the left lower limb  particularly below the knee.  Diagnosis and Risk Assessment:  Based on the presenting symptoms  medical history  physical examination  and laboratory findings  the patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). The presence of PAD with underlying poorly controlled diabetes posed a high risk for developing CLI.  This case demonstrates the complex interplay of risk factors leading to progressive vascular disease. The significant history of diabetes and PAD is a crucial exacerbating factor in the patient's CLI. Prompt diagnosis and a multidisciplinary approach involving vascular therapy  strict glycemic control  lifestyle modifications  and wound care could help improve symptoms and avoid limb loss.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 67-year-old Male   Introduction:   This case report discusses a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  chronic kidney disease stage 4  and active tobacco use who presents with symptoms characteristic of critical limb ischemia  an urgent circulatory state typically due to systemic atherosclerosis.   Case Report:  The patient is a 67-year-old male who complained of severe pain in his left lower leg that began three weeks before his hospital admission. The pain was described as burning and throbbing  and he rated the pain as 8 to 9 out of 10 in severity. The patient noted exacerbation of pain while walking short distances  a condition known as intermittent claudication. He reported that the pain would somewhat subside when he was at rest but never disappear completely. He also reported a lack of sensation in the involved limb and the presence of non-healing sores on the toes of his left foot.  The patient has a 30-year history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease  and he also reported a 40-pack-year smoking history. His medications included Metformin  Lisinopril  and Amlodipine. The patient does not consume alcohol and has no known drug allergies.   On physical examination  the left lower leg appeared to be pale compared to the right one and was cold to the touch. Pulses were absent in that area  and there were ischemic sores visible on the toes. There were no signs of wound infection. The patient's body mass index was within normal limits  and he did not present any neurological or cognitive deficits.   Investigations and Diagnosis:  A duplex sonogram demonstrated decreased flow to the left lower leg. Further confirmatory angiography revealed significant occlusion in the left anterior and posterior tibial arteries  confirming the suspicion of critical limb ischemia. A complete blood count  renal function test  and lipid profile were within normal limits  except for elevated creatinine levels due to chronic kidney disease.  Management and Follow-up:  An urgent endovascular procedure  including angioplasty and stent placement  was performed to revascularize the affected arteries  and the patient was started on aspirin and clopidogrel for antiplatelet therapy. Post-procedure  the improvement in circulation to the foot was apparent  and the patient reported significant pain relief.   The patient was referred to vascular rehabilitation and provided with extensive education about smoking cessation  foot care  and the importance of regular follow-up with vascular surgery and primary care. Smoking cessation services were put in place to assist him in his efforts to quit smoking.   Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of promptly diagnosing and managing critical limb ischemia  particularly in patients with pre-existing comorbidities and lifestyle risk factors. The successful management of this case depended on a combination of intervention  medication  and lifestyle modifications. Regular follow-ups will be crucial in managing his conditions and preventing the recurrence of critical limb ischemia.

Case Report:   Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who lives in a suburban community in the Upper Midwest. He is a retired engineer and has a history of smoking for 40 years  although he quit smoking five years ago. His body mass index (BMI) is 27.8  and he lives with his wife.  Presenting Issue: The patient presented with a one-month history of rest pain in his right foot  particularly in the toes. He noted that the pain was worse at night and was alleviated by hanging his foot over the side of the bed. He also complained of non-healing ulcers on his right foot for the six weeks. Upon examination  the right foot had visible tissue loss  and absent pulses were palpated in the foot and lower leg which indicated critical limb ischemia (CLI). His left foot showed decreased pulses but no evident tissue loss or ulceration.  Past Medical and Surgical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  peripheral artery disease  and type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is well-controlled with Metformin. He underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) ten years ago due to coronary artery disease. He also had a history of intermittent claudication  which has worsened in the recent past.  Diagnostic Tests: Ankle-brachial index (ABI) was measured for both the legs. Right leg ABI was less than 0.40  and left leg ABI was 0.90. The right foot transcutaneous oxygen tension (TcPO2) was 20mmHg whereas  on the left  it was 40mmHg. A Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremity arteries showed severely reduced blood flow in the right lower limb. Furthermore  Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) revealed a long segment occlusion of the right superficial femoral artery (SFA)  popliteal artery  and tibial arteries with no significant disease in the left leg arteries.  Management: In coordination with Vascular Surgery  an urgent decision was made to perform a right lower extremity angioplasty to attempt revascularization. The patient was consented and taken to the angiography suite  where multiple lesions were addressed in SFA  popliteal artery  and one of the tibial arteries. Following intervention  the foot pulses were palpable with satisfying Doppler signals  and the patient reported significant relief of his rest pain.  Follow-up and Outcome: Over the follow-up  the patient showed a significant improvement with his rest pain resolved completely  and the foot ulcer was healed with wound care over three months. He was advised to continue his medications including antiplatelet and statin therapy. He was also recommended to adhere to a strict diabetic diet and involve in physical activities to improve overall limb health and to prevent disease progression.   Conclusion: This case illustrates the importance of timely detection and management of CLI in preventing severe complications  such as limb amputation.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in Elderly with Long-Standing Diabetes Mellitus and Peripheral Artery Disease - A Case Report  Introduction: Mr. SJ  an 85-year-old Caucasian male  with a past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia for over 25-years  presented to the vascular surgery department with chief complaints of severe rest pain over both lower extremities  more prominent on the right foot accompanied with non-healing ulcers.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  he had a diminished peripheral pulse  cold extremities  loss of hair on the lower limbs  and bluish discoloration of toes. The right foot had three ulcers  two at the tip of digits two and three  and one on the heel  all involving the full thickness with underlying necrotic tissue and no signs of infection. His body mass index was 29.6 kg/m2  and the rest systemic examination was unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment: Complete blood count  renal function  and liver function tests were within normal limits. Blood glucose and HbA1c levels were 275mg/dL and 9.8% respectively. Doppler ultrasound revealed severe stenosis at multiple levels in the lower-limb arteries. Confirmatory angiography showed a long-segment occlusion in most sections of the right femoral  popliteal  anterior and posterior tibial arteries  and left anterior tibial artery obliteration. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) measurement was 0.3 on the right side indicating severe ischemia.  Therapeutic Intervention: The decisions were made to start the patient on aggressive atherosclerotic risk factor management. This included high-dose statin therapy  tight glucose control and the use of antihypertensive. In addition  surgical revascularization was planned  and after discussion among the interdisciplinary team and with the patient  an attempt of endovascular revascularization was decided  as a minimally invasive procedure posed fewer risks for him. He underwent successful angioplasty of the right limb.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Nevertheless  due to the extensive ischemic changes in the foot  he ended up undergoing amputation of the second and third digits. Antipyretic  analgesics  and antibiotics were administered postoperatively  and pain was managed effectively. Dressings were changed regularly  with the wound grade improving gradually. After rehabilitation  he was recommended for regular follow-up visits to assess graft patency and foot care.  Patient Perspective:  The patient was relieved of his resting pain in the amputated foot  was stable during regular follow-ups  and his quality of life improved considerably.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of his medical data for this case report.   Conclusions:  This case illustrates the correlation between diabetes mellitus  peripheral artery disease  and the eventual development of critical limb ischemia  highlighting the necessity of aggressive risk factor management and timely vascular intervention.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 60-Year-Old Diabetic Male   Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male who presented with lower extremity discomfort and severe rest pain in his right foot. His symptoms were progressive in nature  beginning approximately six months ago and included intermittent claudication. He eventually developed foot ulceration  non-healing skin wounds and gangrene over several toes. The patient additionally complained of significant weight loss over the past few months.  Background Information:  He has a medical history of type 2 diabetes for 18 years  hypertension  chronic kidney disease  dyslipidemia  and he is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history. His diabetes was poorly controlled with a latest hemoglobin A1c value of 9.5%.   Clinical Examination:   On examination  the right lower extremity was cold compared to the contralateral side. The pulses in the right foot (dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial) were not palpable and were unrecordable on Doppler examination. The right foot had a gangrenous patch over the first toe  extending to the dorsum of the foot with dry necrotic margins. The left foot pulses were reduced but palpable.  Investigations:  Peripheral angiography revealed multi-level occlusive peripheral arterial disease with total occlusion of the right distal superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery. Also noted were diffuse disease and several areas of subtotal occlusion in the right anterior tibial and peroneal arteries. Similar lesions were found in the left leg  albeit to a lesser extent.  Management and Outcome:  After an extensive discussion of the treatment options  the patient underwent successful endovascular intervention with balloon angioplasty and stenting to his right superificial femoral artery  right anterior tibial artery and right peroneal artery. He had a marked improvement following the intervention with resolution of his rest pain. Despite this  the patient eventually underwent a minor amputation of his gangrenous first toe two weeks post-procedure. Postoperative treatment included comprehensive wound care and intensive rehabilitation. He is currently treated with long-term antiplatelet therapy  aggressive diabetes and lipid management  and has been advised to quit smoking.  Discussion:  This case highlights the significance of early detection and intervention in patients with critical limb ischemia  particularly in patients with risk factors like diabetes  smoking  hypertension and dyslipidemia. Despite successful revascularization  the patient had to undergo minor amputation due to the extent of tissue damage at presentation.  Keywords: Critical Limb Ischemia  Diabetes  Peripheral Vascular Disease  Endovascular intervention

Patient Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia   Patient Information ------------------------ Sex: Male Age: 62  Occupation: Retired Engineer  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Marital Status: Married   Presenting Complaint: ---------------------------- The patient presented with severe and progressive pain in his right lower limb  particularly in the foot  even at rest. The pain has been persistent for the past few months but has significantly worsened over the last few weeks.   Medical History: ----------------------- Hypertension: The patient has been hypertensive for the past 16 years  managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily.  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 10 years ago  treated with Metformin 500mg twice daily and regular insulin injections.  Hyperlipidemia: Managed with Atorvastatin 40mg once daily for seven years. No history of smoking  alcohol  or drug abuse. No known allergies.  Physical Examination: ------------------------------ On examination  the right lower leg showed noticeable skin color changes  with areas of pallor and cyanosis. The patient's right foot was cold to the touch compared to the left one. On palpation  reduced pulses were noted on the dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial arteries' right side.  Diagnostic Information: -------------------------------- Doppler ultrasound showed severe disease of both the superficial femoral artery and the popliteal artery in the right lower extremity. Ankle-brachial index on the right was significantly decreased (0.45).   Clinical Progress and Management: -------------------------------------------- The findings were suggestive of critical limb ischemia (CLI). He was admitted to the Vascular Surgery Department for further management. The multidisciplinary team  including a diabetologist and a cardiologist  was involved in his care.   The patient was started on dual antiplatelet therapy and statins. Despite optimal medical treatment  he continued to experience rest pain. After multidisciplinary discussion  it was decided to perform a right leg angioplasty and stent placement to restore perfusion.  Outcome and Follow-Up: ----------------------------- Post-procedure  the patient reported significant improvement in his symptoms. His wound healing improved  and pain levels reduced. He was discharged with a strict follow-up plan  including regular observations of his limb  blood pressure and glucose levels control  and a structured exercise program.   The continuation of dual antiplatelet therapy  statins  control of diabetes  and lifestyle modifications was emphasized.  Concluding Statement: -------------------------------- This case epitomizes the management of a highly prevalent condition - critical limb ischemia (CLI) - amongst the patients with peripheral artery disease  particularly those with long-standing diabetes and hypertension. Early detection  involving a multidisciplinary team  and prompt management is essential to prevent irreversible limb damage  ensuring a better quality of life.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 67-year-old Male Patient: A Case Report  Case Report:  Introduction: Critical limb ischemia (CLI) is the severe obstructive peripheral arterial disease which leads to great discomfort and a significantly diminished quality of life.
