This case report discusses a 67-year-old male patient recently diagnosed with CLI  to better understand the manifestation  progression  treatment options and prognosis of this disorder.  Patient Presentation: Mr. X  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to our clinic with a two month history of rest pain in his left foot and non-healing wounds on his left toes. He described his rest pain as severe  located mainly in the toes and soles  and worsening at night. He also reported an inability to walk more than 30 feet without experiencing extreme leg discomfort  a condition known as claudication.   Past Medical History: He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  diagnosed at the ages of 52 and 57 respectively. He has been a smoker for the past 35 years  but reduced to 10 cigarettes per day after his diabetes diagnosis. His father suffered from a peripheral arterial disease and his mother had type 2 diabetes. There is no history of any other significant disease in the family.  Examination: His blood pressure was 155/90mm Hg and other vital signs were stable. Lower extremity examination revealed weak pedal pulses in the left foot  and dry gangrene was noted on the second and third toes of left foot. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Laboratory tests including blood count  renal  liver  and coagulation profile were within normal range except for HbA1c (8.2%). Ankle-brachial index (ABI) was 0.45 on the left side suggesting severe ischemia  consistent with CLI. Subsequent arterial Doppler and angiography demonstrated severe occlusive disease in the lower extremities  particularly the left limb.  Management: The patient was medically managed with dual antiplatelet therapy  statins  and pain management. Effective glycemic control was achieved using insulin therapy. He underwent revascularization via percutaneous transluminal angioplasty  following which his rest pain reduced significantly. The non-healing foot ulcers were addressed by wound care services. The patient was advised to quit smoking and referred to a diabetic educator for better management of diabetes.  Conclusion: This case highlights the classic presentation of CLI in a patient with multiple risk factors  including long-term uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  and a significant smoking history. It emphasizes the importance of early recognition and intervention for this condition  as it can otherwise lead to severe complications such as limb loss. Multidisciplinary management  including aggressive risk factor modification and revascularization  is key to improving the quality of life in patients with CLI.

Title: Management of Critical Limb Ischemia in a Geriatric Patient with Co-existing Pathologies  Patient Information: Mr. M is a 78-year-old Caucasian male  a retired schoolteacher by profession  living in upstate New York. His primary complaint was the chronic non-healing ulcer on the right foot  which started almost three months back.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed ten years ago  which is maintained on oral hypoglycemic agents along with dietary modification and regular exercises. He also has Hypertension for the past 8 years and Hypercholesterolemia  controlled by antihypertensive and statins respectively. He quit smoking five years ago and is a teetotaller. There is no familial history of any similar presentation or any coronary artery diseases or stroke. He's had a cholecystectomy two years ago  and other than that  his surgical history is unremarkable.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a temperature of 36.8 C  pulse 80/minute  blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  consistent with his history of hypertension. Oxygen saturation was recorded to be 96% on room air. An ulcer approximately 3cm x 4cm with purulent discharge was noted on the dorsal aspect of the right foot. Pedal and dorsalis pedis pulses were notably absent on the right foot  with presence of severe pain at rest in the right lower limb.  Diagnostic Assessment: Given the patient's clinical picture  a suspicion of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made. Lab results revealed elevated blood glucose levels and an abnormal lipid profile  consistent with his history of diabetes and hyperlipidemia.   An Angiogram was performed  which indicated extensive occlusion of right lower limb peripheral arteries. Confirmatory diagnosis of CLI secondary to peripheral artery disease complicated with diabetic foot ulcer was concluded.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initially treated conservatively with aggressive wound care and broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics to manage the ulcer. To manage his CLI  a successful revascularization through balloon angioplasty was performed  followed by strict control of his other co-existing disease.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Regular wound dressings and antibiotics led to a gradual improvement in the ulcer. Strict control of his blood glucose and lipid levels were maintained to avoid further complications. The patient has been instructed on the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle and regular follow up. He continues on low-dose aspirin therapy and statins for hypercholesterolemia  along with his regular medication.  This case reflects the complexity of diagnosis and management of CLI in geriatric patients with multiple comorbidities. It highlights the necessity of an individualized approach in such cases  with aggressive control of co-existing pathologies to prevent worsening or recurrence of CLI.

Title: Management of Critical Limb Ischemia in an Elderly Patient with Multiple Comorbidities  Abstract:  We report a case of a 78-year-old male diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI)  complicated by a medical history that encompasses diabetes mellitus  hypertension and coronary artery disease. The case highlights challenges in managing patients with multiple conditions and emphasizes the need for a balanced  comprehensive and multidisciplinary approach to patient care.  Case Report:  Patient Identification: A 78-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Complaint: Intense rest pain in the left lower limb  particularly the foot  for the last two to three months. The pain has resulted in disturbed sleep. The patient also reported worsening damage in the skin of the foot with ulcers failing to heal.   Medical History: The patient has a long-term history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and coronary artery disease. His surgical history includes coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) done 6 years ago. Therapies include Aspirin  a statin  a beta-blocker  an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor  and insulin administration.  Lifestyle: Non-smoker but used to smoke one pack of cigarettes a day for 30 years. No history of alcohol or drug misuse.  Physical Examination: Atrophic skin changes were found in the lower limbs  signifying poor distal circulation. The left foot showed two deep ulcers  one on the heel and another on the dorsum of the foot. Pedal pulses were absent in the left foot but weakly palpable on the right side.  Investigations: The ankle-brachial index (ABI) was unobtainable on the left side and was .60 on the right side. Duplex ultrasound showed severe stenosis in the left common femoral artery and more extensive disease in the left popliteal and foot vessels. Further CT angiography provided detailed delineation of the vascular disease. Lab investigations revealed poor diabetes management with an HbA1c of 8.2%.  Management: A multidisciplinary foot-care team composed a range of specialties such as diabetes  vascular surgery  infectious disease  and dietetics. Interventional radiology performed endovascular therapy  including balloon angioplasty of the left common femoral artery and popliteal artery with successful revascularization. The patient was put on broad-spectrum antibiotics to manage the existing infection. Moreover  he was advised to attend diabetes clinics and regular follow-ups with dietary advice.   Outcome: At a six-month follow-up  there was significant improvement in the foot ulcers  the intensity of rest pain  and his sleeping pattern. The department of dietetics optimized glycemic control with a revised insulin regimen and diet plan.  Conclusion:  The case emphasizes the importance of a multidisciplinary approach in managing CLI  particularly among patients with multiple morbidities. CLI demands a patient-centered approach where diverse medical disciplines work together to meet the individual's healthcare needs. The overall goal lies not only in limb salvage but also in the improvement of patient quality of life.

Patient Information: Mr. B.C.  Caucasian  75-year-old male  a retired construction worker   Chief Complaint: ""My left leg is extremely painful and changing color.""  Presenting Symptoms: Excruciating pain in left leg  not abating with rest or when elevated  ulceration noticeable around the foot and ankle  and observable change in color to pale and cyanotic. Noticed a decrease in temperature (cold limb) and absence of pulsation in the distal extremities.  Past Medical History: Patient's medical record reveals a history of intermittent claudication  cardiovascular disease  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years. Records also document a 60-pack-year history of smoking  though the patient reported quitting 5 years ago.  Physical Examination: Patient appeared uncomfortable due to pain. Lower left extremity was noticeably paler than the right one  cold to the touch. Peripheral pulses were absent on the left side. A non-healing ulcer measuring 1.5 cm in diameter was noted on the lateral aspect of the left foot.  Diagnosis: Given his symptomatology and past medical history  Mr. B.C is diagnosed with advanced critical limb ischemia (CLI) of the left leg.   Work-up/Tests: Evidence of CLI confirmed through an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) showing a value of 0.35 in the left leg. Further investigation through Doppler ultrasound demonstrated severe stenosis in the left superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery. A CT angiogram revealed multiple segmental occlusions in the left tibial and pedal arteries.  Treatment: Immediate Vascular Intervention with angioplasty considered for restoration of blood flow. The patient would be placed on antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel to prevent further clotting. Pain management initiated with opioids and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)  Discussion: CLI constitutes a severe form of peripheral artery disease caused by significantly decreased blood flow to the extremities  usually due to atherosclerosis. Risk factors include a history of smoking  advanced age  diabetes  and high blood pressure  as we see with Mr. B.C. Rapid treatment is essential to improve symptoms and prevent limb loss. Invasive procedures  primarily revascularization through angioplasty  stenting  or bypass surgery  are the typical line of treatment along with risk factor modification.  Prognosis: Uncontrolled CLI can lead to the necessity for limb amputation. However  since early intervention has been solicited for Mr. B.C.  potential chances for limb salvage appear promising.

Title: Acute Care Management of a Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Demographic Information:  The patient is a Caucasian male  67 years old  former smoker and a retired lawyer  who was living an independent life until his hospital admission. He is a widower with three adult children and resides in a suburb within New York City. He is insured under a private health insurance plan.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with severe pain in the right lower leg and foot. He has noticed an increasing intensity of pain over the last few weeks and was also distressed by a non-healing wound (ulcer) on the forefoot of the same leg.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 12 years ago  along with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) for which he was on oral medications. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he is taking Amlodipine and Atorvastatin  respectively. He quit smoking 10 years ago and takes moderate alcohol periodically. He was previously diagnosed with transient ischemic attack (TIA) 3 years ago but had no recurrences. He is allergic to Penicillin.  Clinical Findings: Examination revealed that the right lower limb was cold to touch as compared to the other limb. The limb was pale and pulses in it were impalpable. An ulcer was found on the forefoot of the same leg. No necrotic tissue or foul smell was noted.  Investigations: The patient's lab results showed elevated blood glucose  hemoglobin A1c  and lipid profile. Doppler ultrasonography of the right lower limb showed significantly reduced blood flow indicative of ischemia. Angiography revealed advanced occlusion in the femoral and popliteal arteries.  Diagnosis:  Based on the patient's symptoms  history  physical examination  and investigation results  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made.  Treatment and Outcome: The patient was managed with strict glycemic control  analgesia for pain and intravenous antibiotics to prevent infection of the ulcer. The patient was then referred to a vascular surgeon who performed a common femoral artery to popliteal artery bypass using the autologous saphenous vein. Post-surgery  the patient's lower limb pain was significantly reduced and the limb appeared pink and warm.  Plan for Follow-up: The patient was advised to attend regular follow-up appointments at the vascular clinic to monitor his symptoms and blood flow to the affected leg. He was counseled about the importance of lifestyle modifications  such as refraining from alcohol  continued cessation of smoking  and maintaining a diet low in saturated fats and simple sugars  and regular physical exercise if tolerated.  This case is important due to the patient's challenging past medical history that significantly complicates his CLI. It was also unique due to the patient's rapid progression from PAD to CLI  underscoring the need for rapid action in treating this debilitating disease.

Patient Case Report:   Demographic Information: Subject: Mr. Johansson Gender: Male Age: 65 years old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Accountant Marital Status: Married  Medical History: Mr. Johansson is a nonsmoker with a known past medical history of diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He has been on Metformin  Losartan  and Atorvastatin respectively for these conditions. He does not have any known allergies. His family history includes cardiovascular disease in his paternal line.   Presenting Problem: Mr. Johansson presents with debilitating pain in his left lower leg  particularly at rest leading to frequent sleep disturbance. He reveals a 6-month history of progressive wound worsening on his left foot  which began with a minor cut from stepping on a sharp object. Despite maintaining regular medications and wound dressings  the wound has failed to heal completely and has developed into a necrotic ulcer.  Physical Examination and Investigations: Physical examination of the left lower limb revealed absenced dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial artery pulses  the limb is cold with severe muscle wasting. There is a 3x4cm necrotic ulcer on the lateral aspect of his left foot. The capillary refill time of the left foot was delayed.  Ankle-brachial index (ABI) was significantly reduced  0.45 on the left side while it's normal  1.1 on the right. Doppler ultrasound reported major blockages in both the left superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery with minimal blood flow seen in the pedal vessels.  Further studies included an MRI angiogram  which confirmed the Ultrasound findings. A complete blood panel showed elevated glucose  cholesterol levels  and mild anemia.  Diagnosis and Treatment: Based on his medical history  physical examination  and results of diagnostic tests  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) was made. Revascularization was considered as the main treatment because of the severe ischemia and significant blockages found in his arteries. A collaborative decision was made  including Vascular Surgery team to perform a left leg bypass operation using his saphenous vein graft. Antibiotics were also instituted for managing the ulcer.  Outcome and Follow-up: Post-surgery  the limb perfusion witnessed significant improvement. The pain gradually subsided and the ulcer began to heal with appropriate wound care. He was advised to continue his diabetes  hypertension  and cholesterol medications alongside regular follow-up visits. He was also educated and counseled on maintaining foot hygiene and spotting early signs of limb ischemia for prompt medical evaluation.  Conclusion: This case represents the significant representation of typical critical limb ischemia in a patient with risk factors of diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. Early detection and intervention can help in preventing limb loss  highlighting the importance of annual foot examinations  especially in diabetic patients. Further studies are needed to determine optimal wound care and rehabilitation for patients suffering from CLI.

Title: Case Report: A 67-Year-old Male with Critical Limb Ischemia   Patient Information: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired  living alone and with an active lifestyle. The patient is a non-drinker and non-smoker.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with severe rest pain in his right leg  particularly in his right lower limb  associated with non-healing ulcerations on his right foot which he noticed two months prior to presentation. The pain had significantly dysregulated his sleep pattern which was troubling him.   Medical History: He has a known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 15 years and Hypertension for the past 10 years which are well controlled. He was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease 5 years ago. There is no significant family history of cardiovascular diseases or other vascular disorders. He has no known allergies.   Medications: He has been on regular medication for diabetes (Metformin 1000mg twice daily) and hypertension (Lisinopril 10mg once daily). Also  he took Clopidogrel 75mg daily as an antiplatelet for peripheral artery disease.   Physical Examination: On general examination  the patient was comfortable at rest but slightly anxious. Blood pressure was 130/80 mmHg  and pulse rate was regular at 80 beats per minute. Peripheral pulses on the right lower limb were not palpable. Inspection of the right foot revealed non-healing ulcerations on the tips of the second and third toes. Ankle Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) on the right was recorded as 0.3.  Investigations: Complete blood count  fasting blood glucose  liver function tests  renal profile  and lipid profile were ordered which came back within normal limits except for an elevated fasting blood glucose level. A Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities suggested severe peripheral arterial occlusive disease in his right lower limb. An angiogram confirmed this and also showed multi-segmental stenosis with occlusions in the femoral  popliteal  and tibial arteries.  Management and Outcome: Based on his symptoms and results of investigations  he was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). His condition was discussed in detail with the Vascular Surgery team. A decision was made to improve his limb perfusion through endovascular intervention with angioplasty and stenting of the occluded vessels in stages. Improvement was marked in post-procedure where he did not report rest pain and the wound healing improved.  Follow-up: He has been recommended for aggressive risk factor management including strict glycemic control  antiplatelet therapy  and statins. He has also been advised regular follow-ups with Vascular Surgery and Endocrinology.  Learning Points: This case highlights the importance of early recognition and aggressive management of risk factors to prevent and delay the progression of peripheral artery disease  and reiterates that CLI is a severe condition that requires urgent intervention to prevent limb loss.

Title: Management of Critical Limb Ischemia in a 65-year-old Male  Introduction: Herein  we present a case of critical limb ischemia (CLI) in a 65-year-old male patient.   Case Presentation: The patient  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented with a month's history of worsening left lower limb pain  non-healing ulcers in left foot  and difficulty in walking. Additional symptoms included numbness and weakness of the left leg. The presenting symptoms were progressive  with pain becoming severe enough to disturb his sleep at night and interfere with his daily activities. His medical history included Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which had been diagnosed two years prior  and hypertension for which he had been on medication for the past ten years. He was a former smoker having quit seven years prior but had a 30-year pack history.  Physical Examination: On examination  the left lower limb was cold  had pale discoloration and peripheral pulses (dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial) were absent. There was a presence of non-healing ulcers in the left foot  but no signs of gangrene were noticed. The Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) measurement was less than 0.3 in the left lower limb  revealing a severe reduction in blood flow.  Investigations: Doppler ultrasonogram of the left lower limb arteries confirmed the presence of occlusive disease in the left superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery. CT Angiogram performed subsequently showed a long segment occlusion of the above-mentioned arteries and multiple stenosis in the left leg's distal arteries.  Management and Outcome: The patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) and was started on intravenous heparin for immediate management. He received intense glycemic control for diabetes. After discussion with the Patient and his family  the decision was made to proceed with surgery. A successful femoropopliteal bypass surgery was performed using an autologous great saphenous vein graft. Following the surgery  the patient showed significant improvement in terms of reduced pain  rapid improvement of ulcer healing  and increased mobility.   Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of early detection and aggressive management of CLI  particularly in patients with long-standing diabetes and hypertension. Clinicians should be aware of the severe complications if CLI is left untreated and make a timely decision on revascularization procedures to prevent amputations and improve patients' quality of life.   Keywords: Critical Limb Ischemia  Femoropopliteal Bypass Surgery  Diabetes  Hypertension  Case Report.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a Male Patient with Hypertension and Progressive Muscular Dystrophy: A Case Report  Patient Information: Name: Anonymous Age: 63 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  Presenting Problem: The patient reported chronic lower limb pain  worsening over the last six weeks  with intermittent claudication significantly reducing his mobility. Physical examination revealed a weak pulse in both radial and dorsalis pedis arteries and digital gangrene on the first toe of the right foot. Due to persistent symptoms  lack of normal blood flow  and indicative signs such as pain at rest and non-healing sores  our preliminary diagnosis was critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Past Medical History: The patient is known to have hypertension for the past 10 years and has been on routine antihypertensive therapy. He was diagnosed with Becker Muscular Dystrophy 15 years ago  with progressive muscle weakness reported  particularly affecting his lower onsets. The patient also has a history of heavy smoking (40-pack years). He was taking oral losartan  felodipine  and simvastatin for the management of hypertension and has been on corticosteroids intermittently for the muscular dystrophy. There was no reported history of diabetes  coronary artery disease  or cerebrovascular accident.  Relevant Investigations: Peripheral angiogram showed severe multi-level arterial disease  with occlusion of the right common femoral artery  superficial femoral artery  and popliteal artery. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) was 0.5 on the right side and 0.7 on the left side  confirming peripheral artery disease. The pulse of the lower limb was not palpable below the groin on both sides.  Management Plan: Considering the patient's age  medical history  and severity of the disease  a multidisciplinary team proposed conservative non-surgical management initially  which involved optimal medical therapy  pain control  and wound care. The medical therapy was mainly aimed at increasing the blood flow in the lower legs and feet by including antiplatelet and antihypertensive drugs. He was also started on cilostazol and further counseled on smoking cessation.  Patient Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient before the preparation of this case.  Conclusion: This case highlights the challenges of managing CLI in patients with comorbid conditions like hypertension  progressive muscular dystrophy  and history of heavy smoking. Further  it underscores the importance of early diagnosis and optimization of medical therapy in CLI management. Regular follow-up was recommended for the patient to monitor his condition and for the timely detection of disease progression that would require intervention.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a Patient with a History of Long-standing Uncontrolled Diabetes Mellitus  Patient Profile: The patient is a 72-year-old African American male residing in San Francisco  CA. He is a retired real estate agent and lives with his wife in a single-family home. The patient is a non-smoker  does not consume alcohol  and denies any drug use. His family history is significant for diabetes mellitus from his paternal and maternal side.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of rest pain in the right lower extremity  particularly intense at night. The pain was accompanied by non-healing ulcers on the right foot becoming progressively worse over the past two months. He also reported a diminished sensation in his lower limbs along with increasing difficulty in walking.  Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus twenty years ago but has been poorly controlled according to his clinic records. He also has a history of hypertension managed with an ACE inhibitor and diuretic combination. The patient was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia but was irregular with his statin consumption.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  the right foot appeared pale with dusky toes and palpable coldness. Peripheral pulses in the right foot were absent. There were two ulcers on the plantar foot: one beneath the first metatarsal head with erythema  warmth  and foul-smelling discharge  and another on the heel. Bedside Doppler confirmed the absence of flow in the right lower extremity; however  the left lower extremity had a normal flow pattern.  Diagnostic Assessment: In line with the clinical assessment and the patient’s medical history  an ankle-brachial index (ABI) test yielded a result of 0.3 on the right side  reinforcing the preliminary diagnosis of right limb critical limb ischemia (CLI). An angiogram further revealed multi-level severe peripheral artery disease (PAD) consistent with diabetes-induced vascular disease.   Clinical Course: Due to the severity of the ischemia and the limb-threatening nature of the condition enhanced by the presence of ulcers  an urgent peripheral artery angioplasty was performed  with the placement of stents in the femoral and popliteal arteries. The patient was then started on dual antiplatelet therapy and low molecular weight heparin.   Patient’s outpatient medications were reviewed  with adjustments to optimize glycemic  blood pressure  and lipid control. A follow-up schedule was also established for strict monitoring of the management plan. The patient was also given referrals for dietetic assessment and a structured exercise program to supplement the pharmacological intervention.   Patient Education: Significant education was provided to the patient and his wife about CLI and its pathogenesis  especially in relation to diabetes. The importance of lifestyle modifications such as regular physical activity  optimal nutrition  and diligent foot care were underscored. Timely taking of medication and regular outpatient follow-up were also emphasized.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of diligent management of risk factors such as hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and particularly diabetes in preventing serious complications like CLI. It also illustrates the value of a comprehensive approach to care  featuring interventional treatment  pharmacological optimization  patient education  lifestyle adjustments  and diligent follow-up.

Title: A Case Report on Critical Limb Ischemia in a 65-Year-old Male Patient with Diabetes and Peripheral Artery Disease  Abstract: This report presents a case of a 65-year-old African American male with a history of diabetes mellitus  pericarditis  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease (PAD) who presented with critical limb ischemia (CLI) with gangrene at the left lower extremity.  Case Presentation:  Demographics: The patient  a 65-year-old African American male  is a retired steelworker with a 40-year history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. He has a past medical history significant for pericarditis  hypertension  PAD  and dyslipidemia. He is a former smoker of 30-pack-years but has quit 10 years ago; he also reports occasional alcohol consumption. The social history includes limited physical activity due to progressive claudication and a family history of diabetes and coronary disease.  Clinical Findings: The patient was complaining of worsening left foot pain over the last three weeks  with noted non-healing wounds and gangrene settling in. On examination  his left foot appeared to be cold to touch with black necrosis of his middle and distal toes and an ulcer under the heel. He reported numbness and continuous rest pain in his foot  even at night  disturbing his sleep significantly. Pedal pulses were absent on the left side and diminished on the right side.  Diagnostic Assessment: An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was performed  which indicated severe PAD with an ABI of 0.49 on the left side and only mild disease with an ABI of 0.91 on the right side. Duplex ultrasound showed a significant and severe stenosis in the left popliteal artery consistent with the patient's symptoms. His laboratory reports indicated HbA1c of 9.2% and elevated serum creatinine suggestive of poorly controlled diabetes and underlying renal dysfunctions  respectively. Complete blood count  coagulation profile  and liver function tests appeared within normal range.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was emergently started on broad-spectrum antibiotics  and a diagnostic angiogram was performed  which confirmed the ultrasound findings indicating the need for surgical intervention. He underwent left lower extremity bypass surgery using his own saphenous vein graft. Blood glucose was aggressively managed with insulin therapy during the hospitalization.  Outcome and Follow up: Post-operative recovery was uneventful. He required rigorous wound care during the stay and was discharged with a full course of antibiotics and upcoming outpatient follow-ups scheduled. The patient was advised on lifestyle modifications that included smoking cessation  diet modifications  physical exercise  and optimum glycemic control.  In conclusion  this case report illustrates the severe consequences of uncontrolled diabetes and PAD  leading to CLI. Early diagnosis and aggressive management are vital to prevent devastating outcomes such as limb loss.

Patient Description:  Mr. SS is a 70-year-old male of Hispanic descent who resides in a suburban community. He is a retired engineer  living with his wife of 40 years. His weight is 180 lbs  height is 5.7ft  BMI is 28 which falls under overweight category  and has a history of smoking  but quit approximately 10 years ago. His regular medications include aspirin  atorvastatin and metformin.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a significant medical history  including type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He was diagnosed with diabetes 12 years ago  which is under control with metformin (500 mg twice a day) and regular diet. The Hypertension and hyperlipidemia were reported 10 years ago and he has been on regular medication with atorvastatin (20 mg daily) and aspirin (81 mg daily).  Presenting Complaint:  The patient was referred to the vascular clinic with severe and constant pain in his right leg  particularly at rest  over the past three months. Along with the pain  Mr. SS also reports of non-healing wounds on his lower limb and has noticed color change on his foot to a pale-blue color. He also reported difficulty in walking short distances  as the pain became unbearable.  Clinical findings:  Physical examination indicated paleness and coldness in the right foot. Palpable pulses were absent in the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis regions. An ulcer about 2 cm in diameter with necrotic tissue at the center was observed on the anterior aspect of the right lower leg  and another on the fifth toe of the right foot. The skin of his right lower limb appeared shiny and hairless. His leg was tender to touch.  Diagnosis:  Based on the patient's clinical history  complaints and physical examination  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) was made.  Investigations:  Further investigations like Ankle Brachial Index were abnormal  with readings of 0.4 on the right (normal >1.0). Arterial Doppler of the lower limb revealed severe stenosis of the right superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery.   Treatment:  The patient was admitted and started immediately on intravenous antibiotics and daily wound dressings. An angiogram confirmed the diagnosis and showed extensive arterial disease. A bypass surgery was proposed in shared decision-making with the patient to alleviate his symptoms and prevent limb loss.  Outcome:  He underwent a successful femoro-popliteal bypass operation with a graft. Post-operative period was uneventful and the patient reported significant improvement in his symptoms. His wounds started to heal progressively with the improved blood flow. The patient continues to be under follow-up in the vascular clinic and wound care outpatient department.   Summary:  The patient's case underlines the severe consequences of peripheral arterial disease  the importance of timely diagnosis and aggressive management in preventing amputation in patients with critical limb ischemia.

Title: Management and Treatment of Critical Limb Ischemia in an Elderly Patient  Patient's Demographic Information: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired merchant marine  residing in a rural area  approximately 50 kilometers from the nearest healthcare facility.  Presenting Issue: The patient was brought into the Emergency Department with severe rest pain in the right lower limb  enduring for the past six days. The pain was increased over the past 24 hours  extending from the lower leg to foot with associated numbness. The patient's past medical reports revealed intermittent claudication over the past year.  Past Medical History:  This 72-year-old individual has a complex medical history  including type-II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and peripheral artery disease (PAD). He was diagnosed with diabetes and hypertension at the age of 50. He does not have any known allergies. He has been managing his blood sugar levels and hypertension for the last 22 years with medication.   Examination findings: Physical examination revealed coldness and significant pallor in the right lower limb compared to the other. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses on the right were absent. There were also visible ischemic ulcers on the foot. No symptoms of gangrene were discovered.  The patient's lab tests showed uncontrolled glucose levels  elevated blood cholesterol  and normal renal function. Electrocardiogram revealed signs consistent with left ventricular hypertrophy  likely due to the patient's history of hypertension.  Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) based on his clinical features  his complaints of rest pain alongside his past medical history of diabetes and hypertension  which can aggravate and lead to rapid progress of peripheral arterial disease  leading to critical limb ischemia.  Management and Treatment: Glycemic control was immediately started to manage uncontrolled sugar levels. Pain was managed with strong analgesics. The patient underwent an angiogram  which revealed extensive blockages in the right leg. The patient was not a suitable candidate for vascular bypass surgery due to the complexity of disease and age so therapeutic angioplasty was performed.  Outcome and Follow-Up: The procedure was successful and the patient reported significant relief from rest pain post two weeks of the procedure. He was referred to a diabetic foot care program  and counseled on smoking cessation  dietary measures  and regular exercise. The patient was discharged with a number of medications including anti-platelets  statins and ACE inhibitors alongside strict instructions for glycemic control under the supervision of an endocrinologist.  This patient will require continuous monitoring through outpatient visits every 6 weeks initially for wound care and observation for any signs of re-occlusion. Additionally  caregiver education was provided for at-home wound care and daily foot examination.   Conclusion: The case demonstrates the importance of diagnosing CLI promptly to prevent severe complications such as amputation  especially in patients with diabetes and other comorbidities. It further emphasizes the significance of patient and caregiver education in managing such complex diseases.   Note: This case report is meant for peer review and discussion within the medical community to improve patient care. It is not intended to be used for self-diagnosis or to replace professional medical advice.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 74-Year-Old Type II Diabetic Female  Introduction   Critical limb ischemia (CLI) is a severe form of peripheral artery disease that is typically characterized by continual leg pain. It usually affects elderly individuals  often associated with type II diabetes mellitus. This case report focuses on a 74-year-old female patient diagnosed with CLI alongside her battle with diabetes.  Patient Information  A 74-year-old Caucasian female was admitted to the hospital reporting of severe  burning leg pain that is persistent even while at rest. Additional symptoms included noticeable numbing and coolness in her left foot  accompanied by discolored skin and leg muscle atrophy.   Clinical Findings  Upon physical examination  her foot had no palpable pulse and exhibited signs of ulceration. A non-healing wound was identified on her left heel. Capillary refill time was delayed  and she had significant pain from her foot with minimal movement.   Medical History  The patient was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 15 years ago. In the course of her medical history  she has had hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and kidney dysfunction. She also has a 10-year history of stable angina  under control with medication and lifestyle modifications. She was  in addition  a current smoker with a 30 pack-year history  which added to her condition's complexity.   Diagnostic Assessment   The diagnosis of CLI was made based on clinical presentation and complementary studies. Colour-Doppler ultrasounds confirmed an absence of arterial signals in the left foot. The ankle-brachial pressure index was less than 0.4  unequivocally indicating critical limb ischemia. A CT angiography was also performed  revealing extensive occlusive disease involving the left superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery. Laboratory findings highlighted poor glycemic control and signs of renal dysfunction.  Treatment   The patient was managed with aggressive control of her blood glucose levels and lipid profile with insulin and statin medications. Conservative management with analgesic medication was attempted initially  but due to the persistent pain and risk of losing the limb  she was referred to vascular surgery for further attempts at revascularization.  Conclusion  This case underscores the importance of controlling risk factors like diabetes  hypertension  and smoking for successful long-term management of Critical Limb Ischemia patients. Interdisciplinary collaborations between medical personnel are crucial for patients with complex comorbidities. Early diagnosis and aggressive therapeutic strategies can significantly improve patient outcomes and reduce the risk of amputation.

Patient Initials: J.D.  Age: 70 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Presenting Complaint:  Patient J.D.  aged 70  attended the hospital with severe pain in his left lower limb  non-healing ulcers on his left foot  and significant rest pain  all of which worsened over the last three months. Notably  he indicated that the pain is more severe at night and often interrupts his sleep.  Past Medical History:  Patient J.D. has a significant medical history including type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral arterial disease. He has been a two-pack-a-day smoker for the last 50 years. Additionally  the patient had a myocardial infarction five years ago which was managed with coronary artery bypass grafting. Patient J.D. is currently on following medications: metformin  lisinopril  atorvastatin  and aspirin.   Examination Findings & Investigations:  A physical examination of the lower limb revealed absent distal pulses  cold skin and a non-healing ulcer on the dorsum of the left foot. The Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was 0.3 in the left leg and 0.9 in the right. Duplex ultrasound showed a significant reduction in flow in the left limb. Subsequent computed tomography angiography (CTA) illustrated long segment occlusion of the superficial femoral artery (SFA).   Diagnosis:  Based on the symptoms  physical examination findings  and investigation results  the patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI) secondary to significant atherosclerotic disease  exacerbated by smoking and poorly controlled diabetes.  Management:  A multidisciplinary team including vascular surgeons and endocrinologist was created for patient management. His vascular surgical team scheduled him for a left leg peripheral angioplasty. The endocrinologist altered his medication regimen aiming for tighter control of blood glucose levels. Also  patient education was provided about the importance of smoking cessation for the progression of CLI and overall cardiovascular health.   Clinical Course & Follow-ups:  Post-procedure follow-up showed that patient's leg pain had significantly improved and the ulcer wound was healing gradually. After three months  the patient had successfully stopped smoking  his blood glucose control had also improved. Currently  he is ongoing regular follow-ups on an outpatient basis.  Conclusion:  This case illustrates the severe consequences of poorly controlled diabetes and chronic smoking  leading to CLI. Early recognition and multidisciplinary management are crucial in preventing limb loss. Furthermore  patients must be educated about lifestyle changes including smoking cessation to prevent disease progression.

Title: A Case of Critical Limb Ischemia in a Diabetic Elderly Male  Introduction: This case report presents an 85-year-old male patient with a long-standing history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and hypertension who presented with critical limb ischemia (CLI) involving his right lower extremity.   Patient Information: The patient is an 85-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired farmer from rural Alabama. He lives with his wife and is reasonably active for his age. He is a non-smoker  does not consume alcohol and follows a typical western diet. The major notable points in his past medical history include uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type II for about 35 years  hypertension for 30 years  prior transient ischemic attack (TIA) around 5 years ago  and chronic kidney disease (stage 3).  Clinical Findings: The patient presented with progressively worsening pain in the right lower limb for 3 months  especially at rest  and increased sensitivity to cold. Additional symptoms included recurring ulcers on the right foot that failed to heal and an intermittently found absent pedal pulse in the right leg. On physical examination  there was noticeable skin discoloration with coolness to touch and reduced hair growth. Palpable pulses were absent at the femoral  popliteal  posterior tibial  and dorsalis pedis sites on the right leg.  Timeline: The onset of the patient's present CLI symptoms began approximately three months ago. The severity of ischemic pain at rest over the last couple of weeks made the patient seek medical attention.   Diagnostic Assessment: Considering the patient's history and symptoms  a clinical diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) was made. Confirmatory testing with Doppler ultrasound was performed  showing severe triphasic waveform reduction in the right lower limb with increased peak systolic velocity measurements. An angiogram further revealed a long occlusive lesion in the right superficial femoral artery. The patient's lab tests indicated uncontrolled T2DM (HBA1C - 9.0%) and compromised renal function (creatinine - 2.2 mg/dL).  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initially started on pain management with opioids and advised for strict glycemic control and blood pressure monitoring. He was subsequently scheduled for a right lower extremity revascularization procedure via endovascular intervention due to his high surgical risk status.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Postoperatively  the patient reported a significant improvement in his rest pain. He was discharged with advice on proper foot care and the importance of rigorous control of his risk factors  particularly diabetes and hypertension.   Patient Perspective: The approach-to-treatment and post-treatment care was understood and well-received by the patient who was grateful for the pain relief.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was taken from patient preoperatively and for the publication of this case report.  Discussion: This case underscores the importance of early recognition and aggressive management of risk factors in diabetic patients to prevent severe complications like CLI. Regular foot examination  prompt treatment of foot ulcers  and optimization of blood glucose and blood pressure are required to manage such high-risk individuals.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 62-Year-old Male with History of Smoking and Diabetes   Introductory Description: This case report describes the condition of a 62-year-old Caucasian male patient suffering from critical limb ischemia (CLI) who reported a history of smoking and diabetes.   Patient information: The patient is a 62-year-old male living in an urban area of New York  United States. He is a retired electrician and lives with his wife. He is a long-term smoker claiming to smoke about 1 pack per day for the last 40 years. In addition  he has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 20 years ago and has been poorly compliant with diet  medications  and monitoring blood sugar levels. He has no genetic predisposition to vascular or heart disease.  Clinical Findings: During the initial presentation  the patient complained of severe pain in his left foot  which had been persisting for six weeks. The pain was increased during rest and was often intense during the night. This pain was accompanied by a non-healing ulcer on the big toe of the left foot. On examination  his left foot was notably pale  cool to touch with diminished pedal pulses. His right foot appeared normal.   Further diagnostic tests indicated tachycardia  hypertension  increased HbA1c levels  and an abnormal Doppler ultrasound showing significantly reduced blood flow in left leg arteries. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) was 0.4 on the left side  indicating severe arterial impairment.  Treatment: Given the patient’s condition  he was hospitalized immediately. Considering the patient's comorbidities of diabetes and smoking  the multidisciplinary team decided to proceed with endovascular treatment. He was administered analgesics for pain management  while surgical intervention was planned for revascularization of the left leg.   Outcome and Follow-up:  Post-revascularization  the patient’s pain subsided and the toe ulcer started showing signs of healing. The patient was referred to a diabetes management team and smoking cessation therapy. Follow-ups scheduled at 1  3  and 6-month intervals showed patient compliance with both therapies and ABI improved to 0.8. At the 6-month follow-up  the ulcer had healed and the patient presented with no foot pain.   Conclusion: This case underscores the significance of early detection  appropriate clinical management  and patient compliance in chronic conditions like diabetes in preventing complications like CLI. Coordinated multi-disciplinary approach  patient education and regular follow-ups are pivotal in managing CLI effectively.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 65-Year-Old Diabetic Male Patient: A Case Report  Introduction:  Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) refers to a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet and legs)  and has progressed to the point of severe pain  even while resting. CLI is often associated with non-healing sores or gangrenes on the lower extremities.   Patient Information: We report a case of a 65-year-old African American male who presented with a 2-month history of rest pain in his right foot and non-healing ulcer on his right big toe. The ulcer began as a small blister that gradually worsened over time. Patient's medical history revealed that he was a long-term smoker and had been living with type II diabetes mellitus for 15 years  poorly controlled. He also had a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease (PAD). There was no significant family history of either diabetes or cardiovascular disease.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed diminished pulses in the right lower extremity  with a palpable popliteal pulse. The right foot was cold to touch with signs of tissue loss and severe pallor on elevation. There was a 2 cm by 2 cm necrotic  malodorous ulcer on his right big toe. He scored 8 out of 10 on the pain scale.  Diagnostic Assessment: The patient underwent an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  which showed a result of 0.6 in the right foot and 1.1 in the left foot  confirming PAD. His Complete Blood Count (CBC)  renal and liver function tests were normal except for markedly raised HbA1c and lipid profile. Lower limb angiogram revealed chronic total occlusion of the right posterior tibial and peroneal arteries with severe calcification.  Therapeutic Intervention: Upon diagnosis of CLI  the patient underwent right lower limb endovascular intervention with angioplasty and stenting. He was also taken care of by the wound care service for the ulcer on the right big toe which was debrided successfully. Optimization of medical management included increasing the dosage of his anti-platelet therapy and statins along with stricter glycemic control using insulin.  Follow-up and Outcomes: In the subsequent weeks following the intervention  the patient's rest pain significantly reduced. Over a few months  the non-healing ulcer improved significantly. Lifestyle modifications included tobacco cessation  and an exercise regimen was recommended.  Conclusions: This case highlights the significant burden of CLI in patients with peripheral artery disease  especially if comorbid with diabetes mellitus and tobacco use. Early recognition  aggressive management of cardiovascular risk factors and timely revascularization are integral for limb salvage and improving patient outcomes.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   The patient is a 67 year-old Caucasian male  currently residing in Boston  Massachusetts. He is a retired manager and non-smoker. His height is 5'9"" and weighs around 190 pounds. His family history reveals that his father suffered from coronary artery disease and his mother had hypertension. The patient has a personal medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension.  Clinical Presentation:  The patient was brought to the Emergency Department (ED) with complaints of severe pain in his left lower limb  particularly in the foot area which he had been experiencing for the past two weeks. He was also experiencing intermittent claudication and noticed an ulcer on his left big toe that was not healing. The physical examination of the foot showed signs of critical limb ischemia  such as weak or non-detectable pulses  cold skin  loss of hair  shiny skin  and gangrene involving the toe.  Investigations:  Routine blood work including complete blood count  renal function test and lipid profile were conducted  all of which were within normal limits. Random blood sugar measurement  however  indicated hyperglycemia. Ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) was carried out which suggested critical limb ischemia. Further  a Doppler ultrasound confirmed severe stenosis in the left common femoral artery and monophasic signal distally. A Magnetic Resonance Angiogram (MRA) was carried out confirming the same and revealing a completely blocked superficial femoral artery.   Diagnosis:  The patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia in the left lower limb due to peripheral artery disease (PAD)  secondary to poorly controlled type-2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension.   Treatment:  The patient was started on optimal medical therapy  which includes dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  a statin  antihypertensive drug  and strict glycemic control. Subsequently  he underwent successful percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) with bare-metal stenting to the left femoral artery.  The patient was discharged a week later and has since been attending regular check-ups. His pain has significantly reduced and the ulcer started to show improvement. He is currently on medications and has been advised to continue with lifestyle modifications  including a heart-healthy diet and regular exercise.   Future Plan  The patient will visit regularly for follow-ups in the vascular clinic and also maintain visits to the endocrinologist for control of his diabetes and hypertension.  Conclusions:  This case signifies the importance of effective management of hypertension and diabetes  as well as the importance of regular screening in patients at high risk of peripheral arterial disease. Critical Limb Ischemia is a serious condition associated with high risk of amputation and mortality  therefore early diagnosis and intervention play an important role in the prognosis.

Case Report  Patient Information  Mr. L  a famous 64-year-old African American author living in New York  presented with sudden onset severe pain in the left lower limb. As an unmarried man  he lives alone but maintains an active lifestyle with regular jogging and his passion for writing books. He is a non-smoker and practises moderate alcohol consumption. He has no known allergies.  Medical History  Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus  which was diagnosed 14 years ago  and is well controlled on metformin and dietary modifications. He also has a history of hypertension  managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily for the past ten years. There was no known family history of cardiovascular diseases or peripheral arterial disease. He had no previous surgeries  except for the right inguinal hernia repair about 18 years ago.  Presenting Symptoms  Mr. L reported sudden onset of severe pain in the distal part of the left lower limb  along with numbness and a cold sensation; he noted that his left foot looked pale. The patient reported that the pain started a night ago and increased progressively  preventing him from sleeping. He further noted that he could not feel the pulse in his left foot  which was usually palpable. He denied any similar condition in the past. He also denied experiencing any chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness.  Clinical Findings  Upon general examination  the patient was conscious  oriented and vital signs were stable except for slightly elevated blood pressure (150/90 mmHg). On physical examination  there was loss of hair on the dorsal surface of the left foot and the skin appeared shiny. Peripheral pulses were absent in the left lower limb. There was no sensory detection on the foot and dorsalis pedis artery was not palpable. Capillary refill time was prolonged  ulcers and gangrenous changes were not observed.  Diagnostic Assessment  Lab investigations revealed normal lipid profile and slightly elevated HbA1C (8%). Ultrasound Doppler study of the left lower limb arteries showed severe stenosis of the popliteal artery with significantly reduced flow. The ankle-brachial index (ABI) was calculated to be 0.5 on the left side (normal >1.0).  Therapeutic Intervention  The diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) was made based on clinical and lab findings. The patient was promptly referred for angioplasty with the intention of stent placement. Anticoagulants were immediately initiated  and Glycemic control was optimized.  With interdisciplinary intervention involving cardiology  endocrinology  and vascular surgery teams  the patient could maintain the limb's functionality post-angioplasty. The patient was discharged on dual antiplatelet therapy with regular follow-up plans from the specialties involved.  Discussion  In this case  patient's underlying diabetes and hypertension were likely the key contributors to his critical limb ischemia. This case highlights the importance of prompt diagnosis and immediate management to prevent severe complications such as limb amputation. It further emphasizes the need for regular monitoring and management of chronic diseases like diabetes and hypertension to prevent life-threatening complications such as CLI.

Title: A Case Report on Critical Limb Ischemia in a 67-Year-Old Patient with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus   Patient Information:  A 67-year-old African American male  a retired office clerk  presented to the emergency department with severe rest pain in his right lower extremity  predominantly in the calf and foot regions. The patient reports having type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)  hypertension  and a 45-year history of smoking.  History of Present Illness:  His pain started intermittently about eight months prior to arrival and gradually progressed to become persistent. Untreated  the pain became worse preventing sleep  thereby reducing his quality of life drastically. He also noted skin discoloration in the right foot and toenail changes. The patient denied any history of trauma to the extremity  fever  or recent illness.  Review of Systems:  Negative for chest pain  shortness of breath  abdominal pain  nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  headache  syncope  and visual disturbances. The patient reported decreased appetite  weight loss  chronic fatigue  and increased thirst and urination.  Past Medical History:   The patient has had T2DM for the past 15 years and has been managing it with oral hypoglycemics  which were escalated to insulin therapy five years prior to current presentation. The patient's hypertension  diagnosed 10 years back  is being controlled with antihypertensive medications. He also has a history of dyslipidemia for which he is on statin therapy. The patient acknowledged chronic tobacco use but had never sought help for smoking cessation. There is no known history of cardiovascular disease or peripheral artery disease.  Physical Examination:  Notable physical findings included a weak right popliteal pulse and absent right dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses. The right foot was pale compared to the left  with sparse hair  thickened toenails  and an ulcer on the posterior aspect of the right heel. There was reduced sensation to light touch in the right foot.  Investigations and Management:  The patient was admitted  and blood work revealed poorly controlled diabetes with HbA1c of 9.2% and a slightly elevated creatinine level. Ankle-brachial index on the right was 0.30  confirming severe peripheral artery disease. Duplex ultrasound showed significant stenosis in the right lower limb. Angiography was performed  depicting multilevel obstructions in the distal right superficial femoral artery  popliteal artery  and tibial arteries. A decision for revascularization was made.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of early recognition and management of risk factors like T2DM  hypertension  and smoking  to prevent severe complications like critical limb ischemia. It also highlights the need for adequate peripheral vascular examination in patients with known risk factors.

Title: Critical limb ischemia in a 70-year-old male with a history of peripheral vascular diseases: A case report.  Case Report:  Patient Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male was referred to the vascular outpatient clinic with a primary complaint of severe pain and restlessness in the lower limb  particularly in the right leg  which had been ongoing for the past two months.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient's right leg was noted to have non-healing ulcers on the toes  cold to touch  pallor  and diminished pulse in the popliteal and dorsal pedis region. The left leg was unaffected. Inspection of the rest of the body revealed no other significant findings.  Medical History: The patient had a long-standing history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) diagnosed ten years ago and was a chronic smoker with a 40-pack year history. He also had a history of uncontrolled type II diabetes and hypertension. Previous interventions included bilateral iliac stenting and right femoral artery endarterectomy due to severe stenosis.  Diagnostic Assessment: Ankle-brachial index revealed a measurement of 0.45 on the right sight  indicating severe limb ischemia. A subsequent peripheral angiogram confirmed a long segment occlusion of the right superficial femoral and popliteal artery. Therefore  critical limb ischemia diagnosis was confirmed.  Therapeutic Intervention: A procedure for right femoral-popliteal bypass grafting using a reversed saphenous vein was scheduled. The patient also received medical management for his diabetes and hypertension and was given nutritional support to optimize his condition preoperatively and was educated about the importance of smoking cessation.  Follow-up and Outcome: The patient had a successful surgical operation. Postoperatively  the patient showed continuous improvement. The ulcer showed signs of healing  and the pain had significantly improved. At a 3-month follow-up  the patient was successfully ambulating and manifesting improved ABI with resolving ulcers.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and effective management of peripheral vascular diseases  the role of an interdisciplinary team in managing such complex cases  and the significance of smoking cessation in preventing the progression of the disease. It also emphasized the impact of managing comorbidities like diabetes in the process of wound healing.    Note: This case report is a template and uses data typical of patients with critical limb ischemia but does not represent a specific case.

Case Report: Walt Stevenson  Critical Limb Ischemia  EDUCATION RECORDS  Case Identification:  Mr. Walt Stevenson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Contact:  Admitted to the Advanced Vascular Surgery center.  Date:  Admitted on 5th September  Year 2022.  MAIN ASSESSMENT  Chief Complaint:  Mr. Stevenson presented with severe unrelenting rest pain in his lower right limb  especially in the foot  persisting for the past three weeks. He also reported non-healing wounds on the same foot.  History of Present Illness:  Mr. Stevenson began experiencing intermittent claudication on his right leg around six months ago. It began subtly but gradually intensified over time  now turning into critical limb ischemia. He has been having sleep disturbances due to severe pain. In addition  he has developed ulcerations on his right foot  which have not healed even after pharmacological interventions.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Stevenson has a history of peripheral arterial disease  diagnosed about two years ago. He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years  controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. Other significant medical histories include hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he is taking anti-hypertensive drugs and statins. Mr. Stevenson is also an ex-smoker  quit smoking 10 years ago after having been a pack-a-day smoker for 35 years. He has no known drug allergies.  Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  the patient appeared anxious. His right foot was profoundly cold and pale due to diminished peripheral pulses  and displays signs of gangrene. Multiple necrotic ulcers were visible on the dorsum of the foot.  Investigations:  An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test revealed a below-normal ABI score of 0.30 indicating severe peripheral artery disease. Doppler Ultrasound showed significant plaque buildup in the femoral and popliteal arteries of the right lower limb. His fasting blood glucose was elevated  and HbA1c was at 8.6%  suggesting poor glycemic control.  Diagnosis:  Based on clinical findings  patient history  and investigative outcomes  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia due to advanced peripheral artery disease was made.  Treatment:  Treatment was initiated with analgesics for pain management and intravenous antibiotics for foot ulcers. Patient was counselled about the potential need for revascularization procedures  including possible angioplasty or bypass surgery. He was also advised to improve glycemic control and continue medications for hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Follow-up:  A follow-up appointment after two weeks was scheduled to reassess the condition of his right foot and decide upon surgical intervention if necessary.   Summary:  This case is an illustration of chronic critical limb ischemia in the background of long-standing peripheral arterial disease and poorly managed diabetes. Timely intervention and management  along with comprehensive patient counseling  are critical to leaning the prognosis in favor of the patient.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Patient Profile: A 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  residing at 382 Maple Drive  Maryland.  Presenting Complaint: The patient complained of severe  persistent pain in his right lower limb. Pain was reported to intensify at rest  particularly towards the end of the day. The patient also reported difficulty in walking due to the pain and described noticeable discoloration (darkening) of the right foot.  Medical History: The patient has been a smoker for the past 40 years and consumes alcohol socially. He has a history of type 2 diabetes and peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The patient had earlier undergone balloon angioplasty for PAD in the same (right) limb three years back. The patient is also hypertensive and is under medication for the same. He reported having Hypercholesterolemia and does not have any known allergies.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a cold right foot with visible pallor  absent peripheral pulses  and a non-healing ulcer on the right great toe. An ankle-brachial index was extremely low (<0.3)  consistent with critical limb ischemia. Vascular duplex ultrasound showed total occlusions of the distal right superficial femoral and proximal popliteal arteries.   On further consultation with a podiatrist  the patient was diagnosed with Gangrene in the right foot and suggested lower limb amputation to prevent the spread of infection.  Baseline Investigations:  Fasting Blood sugar - 176 mg/dL HBA1c - 8.2 % Lipid Profile - Cholesterol 225 mg/dl  LDL - 140 mg/dl  HDL - 35 mg/dl  Triglycerides - 165 mg/dl Serum Creatinine - 1.4 mg/dL Resting ABI – 0.28  Treatment Outcome and Follow-up: Considering the patient’s severe pain  non-healing ulcer  and the findings of gangrene  the vascular surgeon and the primary healthcare team decided to proceed with a below-the-knee amputation. The procedure went without complications and the patient was recommended rehabilitative care to adapt to the changes.   He was advised for strict blood sugar and blood pressure control. Smoking cessation was counseled and cholesterol-lowering medications were adjusted. The patient was scheduled for a follow-up after a week of discharge to monitor his recovery and assess for any potential complications.   In the follow-up consultations  the patient's condition has shown improvement with no postoperative complications. His pain is now under control and he has been compliant with his medications and lifestyle modifications.  Conclusion: This case illustrates that prompt recognition and intervention in patients with CLI are imperative to alleviate pain and prevent worse outcomes such as limb loss. In this case  comorbidities like diabetes  hypercholesterolemia  and smoking significantly contributed to the patient's condition.

Title: Management of Critical Limb Ischemia in a Geriatric Patient with Multiple Comorbidities: A Case Report  Introduction: Critical limb ischemia (CLI) remains a prevalent issue with significant impact on patient quality of life and mortality rate. The complex nature of patients often suffering from multiple comorbidities makes comprehensive management a challenge in daily clinical practice. We report a case of a patient with severe CLI  who successfully managed a combination of revascularization  wound care  and optimized medical treatment.  Case Presentation: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus (TiIDM) for 15 years and Hypertension (HTN) for ten years  presenting with severe pain in his right lower extremity  making him unable to walk without assistance. He also reported numbness and coldness of the same limb. Patient's past medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage-III  peripheral artery disease (PAD)  and ischemic heart disease (IHD) with percutaneous coronary interventions twice in the last five years.  The physical examination found pallor  coldness to touch  weak arterial pulsations in the right lower extremity. Preliminary investigations revealed moderate hyperglycemia  lipid abnormalities  and impaired renal function. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) showed abnormal values on the right side.  The patient underwent duplex ultrasound revealing multilevel occlusions in the right lower extremity arteries consistent with severe CLI. Despite a high-risk profile due to his comorbidities  after a thorough discussion with the patient and family  they opted for intervention given the severity of his symptoms and the risk of limb loss.  The iliac and superficial femoral arteries were revascularized using stents under local anesthesia. Postprocedural ABI showed improved values  and the pulsations in the right lower extremity were palpable.  In subsequent 6-months  the patient's painful symptoms resolved entirely with significantly improved walking capacity. Medication optimization  including more rigorous diabetes  hypertension  and lipid control  and dietary modifications were carried out during follow-ups. Attend sessions with the podiatric team for wound care also brought improvement in the limb's clinical appearance.   Conclusions: This case sheds light on the comprehensive management of CLI in a patient with multiple comorbidities. Collaborative management involving revascularization  rigorous medical treatment  and wound care can help improve prognosis and enhance the quality of life in such patients. It reinforces individualized decision-making based on patient's risk profile  preferences  and goals of therapy.    Keywords: critical limb ischemia  type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  peripheral arterial disease  revascularization.

Title: Management of Critical Limb Ischemia in a 68-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Clinical Presentation: Mr. A  a 68 year-old Caucasian male  presented to our clinic with complaints of severe rest pain in his left lower leg that had worsened over the past six months. The pain was particularly escalated at night during rest and reduced with hanging leg off the bed. Mr. A reported intermittent claudication after walking a distance of approximately 150 yards. Alongside  he reported the presence of non-healing sores on his left foot which were present for over 2 months.  The patient had a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  with intermittent adherence to medication  and a 30-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day  although he quit five years ago after being diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He also had a history of hypertension that had been controlled through continuous medication for the last ten years.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a pale left lower limb with cold skin to touch  a weak distal pulse  and several non-healing ulcers on the toes of the left foot. The left foot demonstrated diminished sensation peripherally. An assessment of the right lower limb showed normal blood flow and sensation.   Laboratory findings showed an A1C of 8.5%  indicative of poorly controlled blood glucose levels. Additionally  the lipid profile was abnormal  with an increased LDL level.  The Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was measured as 0.35 on the left  suggesting severe peripheral artery disease (PAD). Doppler ultrasound of the left lower limb showed monophasic arterial waveforms with decreased systolic velocities. CT angiography confirmed severe stenosis in the infrapopliteal arteries.  Diagnosis: Combining the clinical examination  laboratory results  and imaging studies  the patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) secondary to peripheral arterial disease  significantly impacted by his longstanding diabetes and smoking history. His poorly controlled diabetes likely contributed to the development and poor healing of the ulcers on his foot.  Management and Follow-up: The patient was immediately started on medication to control his symptoms and improve his ABI  including cilostazol and clopidogrel  alongside tight diabetic control. A peripheral vascular surgeon evaluated him  and based on the comprehensive assessment  a decision was made to conduct angioplasty to improve blood flow to his foot. Mr. A was also advised to attend sessions for a comprehensive smoking cessation program. He was followed up regularly to monitor the healing of the foot ulcers and his pain control.   To conclude  this case re-emphasizes the importance of a combined approach to diagnose and effectively manage CLI  taking into account the control of systemic risk factors alongside local treatment of the affected limb.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 67-year-old Female Patient  Patient Information:  The patient is a 67-year-old African-American female who presents to the emergency department with severe pain in her right lower limb  deteriorating over a course of 4 weeks. She reports that the pain increases upon physical activity and suggests that she has difficulty sleeping due to the persistent discomfort. There is a notable tissue loss evident on her right lower limb  with three non-healing ulcers distinguished. She is a former two-packs-per-day smoker with a history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. She quit smoking ten years ago. She lives with her husband  and they have two adult children.   Patient's Past Medical History:  The patient has been managing Type 2 Diabetes for the last 25 years with metformin and insulin therapy. She has an established history of hypertension  which is treated with Ramipril. She had an incident of myocardial infarction ten years ago and is on regular Aspirin and Atorvastatin therapy since then. She was also diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease five years ago which was treated with a right femoral-popliteal bypass grafting.  The patient denies any known drug allergies and reports adherence to her medical regimen. She has been taking her medications regularly and follows the prescribed diabetic diet. She does not have a history of alcohol or substance abuse. She is overweight with a BMI of 29 and follows an active lifestyle with regular participation in community-based physical activity.  On physical examination:  Physical examination revealed a right lower limb with diminished hair growth  pallor  three non-healing ulcers (each roughly 1.5cm in diameter)  and notable absent pulses. The left lower limb showed similar characteristics although no ulcers were present.  Based on her history  physical examination  and her severe rest pain which corresponds to Rutherford Stage IV of peripheral arterial disease  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made. Further diagnostic studies  including an ankle-brachial index (ABI)  duplex ultrasound  and computed tomography angiography (CTA)  were ordered to confirm the diagnosis and to map the extent of the disease.  Further Management:  We reviewed the available treatment options with the patient  focusing on revascularization therapies including endovascular procedures and surgical interventions along with best medical therapy. The patient opted to move forward with the recommended treatment plan.  In conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of regular monitoring and management of patients with chronic co-morbid conditions such as diabetes and hypertension  which increase the risk of Peripheral Arterial Disease and severe consequences such as CLI. Early detection and management of such patients can potentially prevent such severe complications and the risk of limb loss.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 68-year-old Female Patient with a History of Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  Abstract: This report discusses the manifestation  diagnosis  and management of a patient presenting with critical limb ischemia (CLI). The patient  a 68-year-old African-American female with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus  sought medical care for persistent pain  ulcers  and the development of gangrene in her right lower limb.  Case Presentation  The patient  a 68-year-old African-American female  with a notable history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus for 8 years and hypertension for 12 years  visited our outpatient department complaining of non-healing sores on her right lower limb and rest pain that had been persisting for the past three weeks. She weighed 86kg and had a height of 163cm  with a body mass index of 32.4 kg/m²  indicating obesity. She is a non-smoker and a teetotaler but has no regular exercises.
