Her medications upon presentation included Metformin (500mg  twice daily) and Losartan (50mg  once daily).  On examination  the patient was fully alert and oriented. Her blood pressure was 155/95 mmHg  pulse rate was 92/minute  and she had a respiratory rate of 18/minute. There were several painful  non-healing ulcers varying in size from 0.5cm to 1.5cm on her right foot. She also had a dry gangrene area of 3x3 cm at her right big toe. Pulses in her right lower limb were absent at the popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial. Distal extremity of her right leg was cold to touch and had a bluish discoloration.   Investigations  Her laboratory tests showed a poorly controlled diabetes with a HbA1c of 9.2% and a blood pressure which would classify her hypertension as stage 2. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) confirmed the presence of severe peripheral arterial disease  with an index of 0.39 in her right lower limb.  Treatment  Due to her poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension  and the extent of CLI as indicated by the ABI score  she was started on a treatment plan that includes an adjustment of her Metformin to 1000mg twice a day. She was referred to a vascular surgeon for an urgent evaluation for revascularization. A multi-disciplinary approach involving a wound care specialist for the management of her non-healing ulcers and diet and exercise counselling for weight management was also initiated.  Conclusion  This case highlights the crucial role of early identification and rigorous management of risk factors in peripheral arterial disease  especially in patients with a history of long-standing diabetes and hypertension. It also underscores the need for comprehensive management involving a multi-disciplinary approach for optimal outcomes in critical limb ischemia patients.

Title: Management of Critical Limb Ischemia in a 78-Year-old Diabetic Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Critical limb ischemia (CLI)  characterized by severe blockage in the arteries of the lower extremities  predominantly occurs due to peripheral artery disease. Here  we present a case of a 78-year-old male with past medical history significant for diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia who presented to the outpatient clinic with critical limb ischemia.  Case Presentation: A 78-year-old Caucasian male presented to the vascular surgery clinic with a six-week history of severe progressive pain in his right lower limb  particularly experienced at rest. The patient also reported skin discoloration and decreased temperature in his lower limb. He has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  and was a smoker with a 50-pack-year smoking history.  Physical examination revealed diminished distal pulses in the right foot  pallor on elevation  dependent rubor  and dry gangrene in the distal toe. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) was 0.3 in the right leg  indicating severe ischemia. Doppler ultrasound showed severe calcified plaque and significant stenosis in the distal superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery.   The diagnosis of critical limb ischemia was made based on the clinical presentation and investigations.  Management and Outcome: The patient was admitted to the vascular surgery unit considering the severity of his condition. He was started on dual antiplatelet therapy  statins  and was given administered antibiotic coverage due to his gangrenous toe. Smoking cessation was strongly advised.   Given the patient's significant comorbidities and severe unilateral disease  surgical revascularization was carried out as an appropriate intervention. The procedure involved balloon angioplasty followed by a femoral-popliteal bypass using a saphenous vein graft.  Pain reduction was achieved immediately after the procedure. ABI following surgery increased to 0.8 and the patient's skin color gradually returned to normal. Wound healing of the gangrenous toe was slow but progressive under wound care treatment. A multidisciplinary approach including endocrinological treatment for diabetes and lifestyle modifications was recommended for long-term management.   The patient was finally discharged with scheduled outpatient follow-ups. During the 6-month follow-up  the patient reported considerable pain relief and showed signs of foot recovery with the healed toe.  Conclusion: Critical limb ischemia is a severe manifestation of peripheral artery disease that requires prompt diagnosis and intervention. This case report highlights the importance of early recognition  aggressive risk factor management  and timely revascularization to prevent limb loss in patients at high risk for CLI  especially those with comorbid conditions like diabetes and hypertension.

Case Report  Patient Profile: Name: Anonymous Sex: Male  Age: 68 years Occupation: Retired Accountant Ethnicity: Caucasian Location: Detroit  Michigan  Chief Complaint: The patient presented to the hospital with severe pain in the right lower limb  marked by the inability to walk without assistance due to pain. There was a non-healing wound on the same limb noticed for about three weeks  intensified over a week  alongside a sudden decrease in temperature of the affected limb.  Past Medical History: Patient was diagnosed Type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension nearly ten years ago  for which he has been on oral hypoglycemic agents and anti-hypertension medication respectively. He had an intermittent history of smoking  concerning 30 pack-years. His family history revealed cardiovascular disease in his father and brother. The patient has no known drug allergies.  Physical Examination: On inspection  the right foot appears to have paleness and is notably cooler compared to the left foot. A small non-healing ulcer was observed on the right big toe with no signs of infection. The distal pulses (popliteal  post-tibial  dorsalis pedis) were absent in the right leg  whereas they were easily palpable on the left.   Diagnosis: Based on the clinical presentation and medical history of the patient  a presumptive diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made. This was further confirmed by a duplex ultrasonography which showed significant occlusion in the right lower limb arteries.  Management: The patient was advised hospitalization considering the severity of the condition. The management plan involves medication along with angioplasty and possible bypass surgery. Rehabilitation  wound care  and lifestyle modifications were also included in the plan to prevent similar incidents in the future.  Discussion: The patient is a classic case of Critical Limb Ischemia  mainly caused by peripheral arterial disease worsened by diabetes mellitus and smoking. The patient is risk-prone  leading to limb ischemia  given his history of familial cardiovascular disease and personal history of hypertension  prolonged smoking  and diabetes.   Conclusion:  CLI is a significant source of morbidity and mortality. In this case  comprehensive therapy including revascularization  aggressive risk factor modification  wound care management  and patient education regarding lifestyle modifications is adopted to improve limb salvage  survival rate  and quality of life.  NOTE: Patient's identifiable details have been changed to maintain confidentiality as per HIPAA policies.

Title: A Case Report on Critical Limb Ischemia in a Geriatric Patient  Patient Details: John Doe  a 76-year-old Caucasian male  was presented to the hospital reporting severe discomfort  pain  and skin changes in his right lower extremity. Additionally  he was concerned about a non-healing wound on his right foot. Current residences in a private nursing home facility situated in Downtown Chicago  Illinois. He is a retired industrial worker with a 35 years history of cigarette smoking. However  he has been abstinent for the last ten years.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe had a history of arterial hypertension that was diagnosed 15 years ago  which is controlled by regular antihypertensive medications. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago  which is managed with oral hypoglycemic drugs  mild exercise  and diet control. He also underwent treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia 5 years back. His surgical history includes appendectomy at age 23 and herniorrhaphy at age 52. The patient did not report any allergies to medications.  Present Illness: The wound on Mr. Doe's right foot had initially begun as a small blister but progressively got worse. Over the past two months  he experienced severe pain  especially during the nights. Coldness and paleness in the extremity  along with episodic claudication  were noted. He reported difficulties in walking due to severe pain in the right foot. The patient reported muscle atrophy  restricted joint mobility  and changed walking patterns secondary to the altered foot structure.  Physical Examination: On inspection  the patient appeared pale and in obvious distress due to pain. His pedal pulses were palpable but significantly weak on the right side. Right leg was also colder compared to the left one. An ulcer with dark black eschar surrounded by erythema  approximately 3 cm in diameter  was present on the dorsal surface of the right foot. There were signs of infection with malodorous discharge from the wound and surrounding cellulitis  with local temperature slightly elevated.  Diagnosis: After performing a thorough physical examination  laboratory tests  and a computed tomography (CT) angiogram  the patient was diagnosed with severe Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) of the right leg secondary to peripheral arterial disease (PAD).  Management and Outcome: The patient underwent immediate surgical intervention - a right lower limb angioplasty and stenting were performed. Post-operatively  his pain significantly improved. Wound care was carried out  and suitable antibiotics were administered to manage the foot infection. The therapy resulted in wound healing  improved limb perfusion  and reduced pain levels  providing the patient significant relief.  Summary: This case report emphasizes the importance of early identification and prompt diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia  particularly among high-risk populations  such as elderly  diabetic  hypertensive  and chronic tobacco users  to prevent potential limb amputation and to improve the quality of life.

Case Report  Title: Percutaneous Intervention on a Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia: A Case Report  Patient Demographics: Mr. J  a 70-year-old retired teacher  presented to our institution. He is a lifelong resident of New York  USA. The patient is a nonsmoker and denies any alcohol or substance use. His body mass index (BMI) is within the acceptable range  and he lives with his wife and two adult children while maintaining an active lifestyle.  Presenting Concerns: The patient presented with gradually worsening pain in his right lower limb at rest  along with skin discoloration and coldness of the limb. He reported notable difficulty in walking distances longer than 50 meters due to severe calf pain. In the past two weeks  he was increasingly disturbed by nighttime pain that interfered with his sleep. Upon examination  absence of pulse in the right lower extremity and ischemic ulcers on his foot were observed.  Medical History: Mr. J has a comprehensive medical history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled on oral hypoglycemic agents and peripheral artery disease. He had a past medical history of hypertension and dyslipidemia. He has also been on medications for cardiovascular protection  including aspirin and statins for over ten years. Additionally  he has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having died from myocardial infarction.  Clinical Findings: A detailed workup was performed for Mr. J. Ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) was extremely low <0.3  indicating critical limb ischemia. Color Doppler Ultrasound report of right lower limb arteries suggested extensive peripheral arterial disease with severe stenosis of both the superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery.   Therapeutic Intervention: Given the severity of the disease and the presence of critical limb ischemia  an invasive strategy was chosen. A successful percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) was done. Drug-eluting stents were placed in the popliteal and superficial femoral arteries to reheave the stenosis.   Follow-up and Outcome: The patient was stable post-procedure with no complications and his ABPI improved dramatically during his follow-ups. His calf pain on walking and nocturnal pain reduced significantly improving his quality of life. The ulcers also showed significant improvement and were near-complete healing at the last follow-up.  Conclusion: Mr. J's case highlights the potentially debilitating nature of critical limb ischemia and the successful management with an aggressive invasive approach with stenting. A proactive multi-disciplinary approach is pivotal in managing such complex cases. His case reinforces the fundamental principle of early detection and intervention to prevent limb loss and improve quality of life. Regular follow-up is necessary for monitoring and controlling the progression of the disease.

Patient Information:   Mrs. X  a 70-year-old Caucasian female with a 20-year history of poorly-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  presented to our vascular clinic with complaints of severe rest pain in her left foot for the past two months which had worsened in the past week.   Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  Mrs. X was found to have multiple necrotic lesions on her left foot. She informed us that she was suffering from interrupted sleep due to the intense pain. She further noted that the pain was alleviated upon hanging the foot off the bed  thereby indicating the presence of ischemic rest pain. Peripheral pulses in her left lower extremity were absent. Chronic cyanosis was also apparent in the left foot.  Past Medical History:  The past medical record of Mrs. X includes poorly controlled type-2 diabetes mellitus along with hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a 50-pack year smoking history. She had a previous history of stroke with no residual deficits and is on secondary prophylaxis. She also had peripheral arterial disease managed conservatively.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Doppler ultrasonography of the left lower extremity revealed the absence of blood flow below the level of the knee. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) was 0.4. Computed tomographic angiography confirmed extensive occlusive disease in the left tibial and peroneal arteries. Based on the clinical presentation and supporting diagnostic assessments  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the severity of her symptoms and concern for limb loss  she was immediately started on optimal medical treatment including antiplatelet therapy  statin therapy  and aggressive control of her blood sugars and blood pressure was advised. However  due to the extent of her disease  the patient was taken for angioplasty with drug-eluting stent placement in the popliteal artery and tibial arteries.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  Following the procedure  the patient reported a significant reduction in rest pain  and there was a noted improvement in the healing of necrotic lesions. The patient is currently under regular follow-up and her ABI readings have improved to 0.7. Ambulation and wound healing are under close watch. She has been advised to quit smoking and adhere to her diabetic medications.  Patient Consent:  Obtained.  Lessons Learnt:  This case highlights the importance of aggressive screening for peripheral arterial disease in patients with risk factors such as long-standing diabetes  smoking and hypertension. Early diagnosis and intervention play a critical role in improving outcomes and preventing major amputations in patients with Critical Limb Ischemia.    Note: CLI  critical limb ischemia; ABI  ankle-brachial index.

Title: A Case of Critical Limb Ischemia in a 72-Year-Old Male Patient with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Peripheral Artery Disease  Case history:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the vascular surgery department with a three-month history of severe rest pain in his right lower limb  non-healing foot ulcers  and noticeable physical impairment. His pain was exacerbated at night and by limb elevation.   The patient has a longstanding medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) for over 20 years  peripheral artery disease (PAD) for 5 years  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. His T2DM and PAD conditions were being managed conservatively with oral hypoglycemic agents  statins  and antihypertensives. He is an ex-smoker  having quit smoking 10 years ago. The patient's lifestyle includes limited physical activity due to progressing claudication. His family history is significant with his father having died of a myocardial infarction in his late 70s.   Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient had significant weight loss and seemed exhausted. Inspection of his right limb revealed dry  scaly skin with distal hair loss  nails thickening  two non-healing ulcers on his right foot - one on the medial aspect of the first toe and another on the plantar aspect  and noticeable bluish discoloration (cyanosis) suggesting poor blood supply. Pulses were absent in the right popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial arteries  and significantly reduced on the left side. There were no signs of acute limb ischemia such as pallor  poikilothermia  or paralysis.  Investigations:  Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was performed and showed a value of 0.40 on the right side and 0.69 on the left  suggesting severe arterial disease. Subsequent Doppler ultrasonography confirmed this with significant stenotic and occlusive lesions in both superficial femoral arteries more on the right side.   CT angiography (CTA) revealed a long-segment occlusion of the right superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery in continuity along with a significant decrease in the lumen diameter of the left superficial femoral artery.  The patient's blood tests showed HbA1c levels at 8.6% indicating poor glycemic control  mildly decreased kidney function  and slightly elevated markers of inflammation.  Diagnosis:  Based on history  clinical examination  and ancillary test results  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) secondary to peripheral artery disease was made.  Management:  The patient was started on optimal medical therapy including more strict blood sugar control  statins  and antihypertensive medication. Endovascular intervention was planned initially; however  due to patient's medical condition and preference  he was treated conservatively. The patient's condition is being monitored closely  with amputation being considered as a last resort if limb salvage cannot be achieved.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 72-Year-Old Male  Patient Profile:  The patient was a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting with severe pain in his right lower leg that had been worsening over a period of several weeks. He was a non-smoker and had no known allergies. He had a history of hypertension managed with medication and was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes over the past 4 years. His family history was significant for cardiovascular disease (his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 64).  Chief Complaint:  The primary concern was rest pain in the right lower extremity that increased at night and often disturbed his sleep. The patient also mentioned that the temperature of his right foot was noticeably cooler than his left  indicating poor circulation. In addition  he reported experiencing a non-healing wound on his right foot that had been present for 2 months.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient had abnormal skin features such as pallor  thin skin  and shiny skin on the affected lower limb. Peripheral pulses in his right foot were absent. The toe brachial index (TBI) was 0.2  indicating severe arterial obstruction. There was no detectable edema. The aforementioned non-healing wound was located on the sole of the foot  about 2 cm in diameter.  Diagnosis:  Based on symptoms  examination  and the patient's history  he was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood flow to the extremities and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.  Management and Outcome: The patient was admitted for revascularization surgery  including angioplasty and stent. Post-op  his symptoms noticeably improved along with increased peripheral pulses in the right foot. He was administered dual antiplatelet therapy to prevent stent thrombosis. Control of his blood glucose levels and hypertension was optimized. He was also referred to a wound care specialist for management of his foot ulcer. During the 6-month follow-up after discharge  the patient's foot wound had entirely healed  and there was significant improvement in claudication. He is continuing with regular follow-ups  monitoring his diabetes and hypertension control  and taking his antiplatelet medications.  Discussions: CLI can greatly impact the quality of life of the patients and can lead to limb amputation if left untreated. Early diagnosis and prompt intervention can significantly improve the prognosis. This case emphasizes the importance of vigilant clinical evaluation and susceptibility in at-risk populations  particularly older adults suffering from diabetes and hypertension. Regular monitoring and managing underlying conditions can prevent progression to severe stages.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 65-year-old Female with long-standing Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: A Case Report   Introduction: Critical limb ischemia (CLI) is a severe form of peripheral artery disease (PAD) presenting with chronic ischemic rest pain  ulcers  or gangrene in the lower extremities due to a significant decrease in blood flow. It is commonly caused by systemic atherosclerosis and is often seen in patients with cardiovascular risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking  and advancing age. Here  we present a case of a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) who developed critical limb ischemia.   Case Presentation: The patient  a 65-year-old Caucasoid female  with a past medical history of T2DM  hypertension (HTN)  and hypercholesterolemia  presented with complaints of rest pain in her left lower extremity for the last two weeks. She also reported intermittent tingling sensation in her left foot and non-healing ulcer on the left big toe that had been present for three weeks. She denied any history of tobacco use. However  she had poorly controlled T2DM with hemoglobin A1C (HbA1C) level of 8.2%.  On physical examination  the patient’s left lower extremity was cold with a reduced pulse in the left posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis artery. An ulcer of approximately 2X2 cm on the left big toe was noticed with no signs of infection. The ankle-brachial index (ABI) on the left side was 0.4  indicating severe limb perfusion reduction.   Investigations: The complete blood count  renal  and liver function tests were normal. Fasting lipid profile showed a high level of total cholesterol and low density lipoprotein (LDL). A duplex ultrasound demonstrated severe stenosis of the left posterior tibial artery and occlusion of the left anterior tibial artery. The patient’s chronic poor glycemic control might have precipitated the development and progression of the arterial disease.  Treatment: The patient was treated with insulin for glycemic control  antiplatelet  and statins for the future prevention of cardiovascular events. A vascular surgeon performed a successful balloon angioplasty of the left posterior tibial artery enhancing blood flow to the foot.   Followup and Outcomes: On a follow-up visit after two weeks  the patient's toe ulcer started to improve  and her rest pain substantially reduced. The patient was referred for diabetes management and lifestyle modification counseling to prevent possible future vascular events.  Patient's perspective: The patient expressed relief at the resolution of her previously unbearable rest pain and was also grateful for the educational intervention regarding her diabetes management.   Conclusion: This case illustrates that CLI is a severe manifestation of PAD which is often associated with systemic conditions  especially T2DM. The focus on optimizing the control of diabetes and other risk factors is critical to prevent the progression of the disease and improve patient outcomes. This underlines the importance of multidimensional care in managing patients with CLI.

Patient Case Report  Identification: Mr. X  a 66 years old Caucasian male  presented himself to the outpatient department with complaints of continuous and severe pain in his right leg.  Demographic Information: The patient is a retired teacher  currently residing in Seattle  Washington with his wife. He is of moderate financial status with good access to healthcare services.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. X reported acute pain in his right lower limb that started three weeks ago. The patient rated his pain level as a 9 on a scale of 1 to 10. The pain exacerbated when he would lie flat  but partially relieved itself upon hanging the limb over the edge of the bed. He also reported intermittent claudication while walking short distances and noticed dark discoloration on his right foot and toes.  Past Medical History: Mr. X has a history of unmanaged diabetes mellitus for 12 years  hypertension for 10 years  and hyperlipidemia. He also has history of tobacco use but quit 5 years ago. He had an acute myocardial infarction (heart attack) 7 years back that was managed conservatively. His medications include Metformin 500 mg twice daily  Lisinopril 10 mg daily  and Atorvastatin 40 mg daily. His father died due to stroke  suggesting a genetic predisposition to vascular diseases.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a cold right foot with decreased sensation. The popliteal and foot pulses were not palpable on the right side while being well pronounced on the left. A 2cm non-healing ulcer was also observed at the right lateral malleolus. The ankle-brachial index (ABI) was .28 on the right  and 1.15 on the left.  Diagnosis: Based on clinical findings  the patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) of the right lower limb.  Management Plan: Considering his condition  Mr. X was referred to a vascular surgeon for evaluation upon suspected Critical Limb Ischemia. A CT angiogram was suggested to assess the extent of blockage. Baseline blood tests including complete blood count  renal function test  lipid profile  and HbA1c were ordered. The patient was started on Aspirin 75mg daily  Clopidogrel 75 mg daily and Cilostazol 100mg twice daily. Pain management was initiated using Opioids and antispasmodics. The patient was also advised strict glycemic control and wound care for the ulcer.  This case highlights the importance of early detection and management of vascular complications in patients with uncontrolled diabetes and a history of cardiovascular diseases. Adequate health education  lifestyle modifications  strict glycemic control and antiplatelet therapy appear to be pivotal in the management of patients with CLI.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named J.J.  who is a retired metal worker and long-term resident of an urban area in New York  United States. He is a smoker with a 45 pack-year history. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use.  Presenting Complaints: J.J. presents with severe progressive pain in his right foot  particularly in the toe area and calf muscle  over the last month. He reveals a history of non-healing foot ulcers and noticeable changes in the color of the leg  turning it into a paler shade. He also reported experiencing intense pain during the night  affecting his sleep quality and disturbances in daily activities due to the pain and discomfort.  Medical History: The patient has a comprehensive medical history with long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed at age 45  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. His diabetes has led to peripheral neuropathy  and he reports a history of poor glycaemic control  with recent HbA1c levels around 8.5-9% over the past two years. He has previously undergone angioplasty for a coronary artery disease ten years ago. He has remained on metformin  a statin  and an angiotensin II receptor blocker since then. He has had no other surgeries or known allergies.   Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  J.J. presented with noticeable paleness and decreased temperature in the right lower limb compared to the left  with palpable femoral pulse but absent distal pulses. He has ulcers on the right foot  two on the toes  and one on the lower medial malleolus. He has no venous insufficiency signs  and prominent peripheral neuropathy in both lower limbs is noted. Duplex ultrasound performed showed bilateral occlusions in the limb's arteries.  Diagnosis: Given the clinical presentation and medical history  particularly his long-standing uncontrolled diabetes and smoking history  the patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI)  the severe obstruction of the arteries which seriously reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.  Management and Outcome: Endovascular intervention was recommended over bypass surgery due to his comorbidities  and he has been referred to a vascular surgeon. Patient education  particularly on smoking cessation  diabetes control  and foot care  was strongly emphasized. J.J received appropriate wound care and antibiotics to control the infection of the ulcers and was continued on his current medications. Close follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor his progress.   In summary  J.J.’s case presents the significant chilling effects of uncontrolled diabetes  smoking  and resulting CLI. It emphasizes the importance of proper glycaemic control and the pivotal role of primary care in early recognition and management of CLI.

CASE REPORT  Patient Information:   The patient is a 68-year-old African American male with a long history of smoking  obesity  and uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type II. Occupation involves prolonged periods of inactivity (retired). Resides in an urban setting in the Midwest region of the United States. There is a known family history of cardiovascular disease.  Presenting complaint:  The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of continuous and severe pain at rest in the left lower leg  consistent with ischemic rest pain. The pain was present for the past week  gradually worsening  described as sharp  throbbing  manifesting even when recumbent or elevated  and unresponsive to over-the-counter analgesics. The patient reports intermittent claudication for the past year  initially while walking long distances but progressively the distance was reducing.  Examination and Clinical Findings:  On examination  his left foot was cold compared to his right. He was noted to have non-palpable pedal pulses on the left with an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) value of 0.40. The left foot showed early signs of tissue loss with dry  black gangrene of the first toe and pallor on leg elevation. A Doppler ultrasound reported severe stenosis of the left superficial femoral artery and occlusion of infrapopliteal vessels.  Management:  The patient was taken into the hospital and was initially treated with intravenous heparin for anticoagulation  pain management with opiates  and strict glycemic control for his diabetes. Following a consultation with the vascular team and gaining informed consent  an angiogram confirmed the sonographic findings of arterial occlusion. Given the patient's medical history and clinical examination  he was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).   The patient was then proceeded for angioplasty with an aim to restore blood flow and prevent the progression of tissue loss. Post-angioplasty  a significant improvement in blood flow was noted. The patient was advised lifestyle modifications and prescribed long-term anticoagulation therapy  statins  strict diabetic control  and pain management.  Discussion:  CLI is largely a consequence of peripheral arterial occlusive disease and is associated with a poor prognosis  increased amputation risk  and mortality rate due to underlying cardiovascular diseases. It often represents advanced systemic atherosclerosis with coronary  carotid  and renal artery involvement. Importantly  the presence of CLI indicates the need for an aggressive and multi-faceted treatment approach. Patients suffering from CLI are often at risk of major amputations. This patient will require rigorous and intensive follow-up care  including regular assessments of limb viability  potential revascularization needs  and maintenance of cardiovascular risk factor controls.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a Type 2 Diabetic Patient  Patient Information  Mr. Paul Thompson  a 64-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the vascular unit following complaints of severe pain in the right lower limb  which had worsened over the past four months. According to the patient  he had also noticed skin discoloration and non-healing ulcers over the same period. The patient is from Cleveland  Ohio  retired  living with his wife  and has five grown-up children. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. However  he has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  which are controlled through oral medication.   Clinical Findings  Upon examination  Mr. Thompson exhibited classic signs of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  including intermittent claudication  rest pain and gangrene. His skin was deteriorated with discoloration and skin breakdown  especially around the lower portion of the right leg. Pedal pulses were absent on the affected limb. His pain was worst during the night and typically relieved by hanging the foot over the bed.   Diagnostic Focus and Assessment  An arteriogram exhibited severe peripheral arterial blockage in the right external iliac and common femoral artery. An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test revealed an ABI of 0.5 in the right lower limb  confirming severe ischemia. A comprehensive metabolic panel and complete blood count were normal  but the hemoglobin A1C level was 8.5%  suggesting suboptimal control of his diabetes.   Therapeutic Focus and Assessment  Per the vascular surgeon's recommendation  the patient underwent a femoral-popliteal bypass surgery to restore adequate blood supply  followed by antibiotic treatment for his non-healing ulcers. He was also referred to a diabetologist for better glycemic control.  Follow-up and Outcomes  Post-operative period was uneventful  and there was a noticeable improvement in his symptoms during the subsequent follow-ups; the pain decreased drastically  and wound healing was evident. He was enrolled in a diabetic education program to optimize glycemic control and encouraged to monitor his glucose levels regularly.  Patient Perspective  Mr. Thompson expressed relief regarding the improvement in his condition. He acknowledged his need to commit to managing his type 2 diabetes more efficiently and was motivated to learn more about preventing any vascular complications in the future.  Take-Away Lessons  This case serves as a stark reminder of the association between type 2 diabetes and peripheral arterial disease. It illustrates the necessity of early detection and management of diabetic patients  particularly regarding the risk of CLI. Improved glycemic control can prevent such complications  emphasizing the need for patient education on diabetes management and regular monitoring.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 66-Year-Old Female with a History of Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus  Patient Information:   The patient is a 66-year-old Asian female  weighing approximately 67 kilograms and stands 1.62 meters tall. The patient is a retired teacher  lives alone  and does not smoke. She admitted drinking alcohol occasionally.  Chief Complaints:  The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of severe pain in her right lower leg  which had persisted for the past six months. She also noted persistent sores on her right foot that would not heal and a significant decrease in the temperature of her right lower extremity compared to her left.  Past Medical History:  The patient's medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 15 years ago  and hypertension for ten years. Both conditions are controlled with medication (metformin for diabetes and amlodipine for hypertension). She has no known allergies and no previous surgeries.  Clinical Findings:   Physical examination showed skin pallor on the right leg  a cold right foot  dystrophic toenails  and two non-healing ulcers on the dorsum of the right foot. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) test indicated a score of 0.3 on her right side while her left measured at 1.1. A Doppler ultrasound also revealed severely reduced blood flow in the patient’s right lower extremity.  Therapeutic Intervention:   The patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI) and started on pain management medication immediately. She was also started on broad-spectrum antibiotics due to a high suspicion of infection from the non-healing ulcers. Urgent consultation with a vascular surgeon was made for possible endovascular or open revascularization procedures.  Follow-up:  The patient underwent successful endovascular revascularization  which included balloon angioplasty and stent placement for the right leg. Antibiotic treatment was continued as the ulcers showed signs of slow healing. Following her discharge  she was referred to a podiatrist for specialized wound care and scheduled for regular follow-ups with the vascular surgery team.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and timely intervention in potentially limb-threatening conditions like critical limb ischemia  especially in patients with known risk factors such as diabetes and hypertension. Regular follow-up  combined with effective wound care  also plays a crucial role in treatment outcomes.

Title: A Case of Critical Limb Ischemia in a 65-Year-Old Male  Introduction: This case involves a 65-year-old male of Asian descent presenting with symptoms indicative of critical limb ischemia (CLI). The patient lives in an urban setting  is a retired office worker  and is a non-smoker. There is no history of alcohol use or illegal substance use.  Patient Presentation: The patient presented with a two-week history of severe rest pain in the right lower extremity accompanied by unilateral foot ulcers that had not healed for approximately four weeks. He also complained of intermittent claudication and cold feet. His past medical history included hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 10 years  well controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents.  Physical Examination and diagnostic evaluation: Physical examination revealed a weak pulse in the right pedal and pallor in the distal parts of the right lower limb. The ulcer was located on the dorsum of his right foot  with evidence of slight necrosis and was measured to be 2x2 cm. There were no signs indicating systemic infection.   The Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) was 0.3 on the right side compared to 1.1 on the left side  suggesting severe ischemia in the right lower limb. The duplex scan confirmed the presence of occlusive disease in the right lower limb with multiple blockages in the right superficial femoral artery and popliteal and anterior tibial arteries. Echocardiography did not indicate any cardiac abnormalities.  Management: Following vascular surgery consultation  endovascular treatment (angioplasty with stenting) was decided upon due to the patient's overall health condition and the severity of CLI. The procedure resulted in restored circulation to the affected limb  with duplex ultrasound confirming improved arterial blood flow. The patient was also started on a dual antiplatelet regimen and high-intensity statin therapy to help prevent further arterial blockages.   Follow-up and outcome: The patient's excruciating pain reduced post-procedure  which he noted the following day of the treatment. Regular wound care was also included in the patient’s management. After six weeks  the ulcer in the right foot showed considerable healing  and his ABPI improved to 0.9. He was advised to continue the medication and adopt a lifestyle involving regular exercise  a balanced diet  and strict glycemic control.  Conclusion: With timely intervention  patients with critical limb ischemia can avoid a possible limb amputation and improve quality of life. It reinforces the importance of regular monitoring and stringent control of comorbidities like diabetes and hyperlipidemia  which are known risk factors for atherosclerosis leading to CLI.

Case Report – Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Case Identification:  A 58-year-old African-American male patient was referred to the vascular clinic due to recurring intermittent claudication and non-healing wounds on his left lower extremity. The patient described the pain as severe  exacerbated by walking even short distances  and occasionally occurring at rest. The patient also reported a consistent mild dull ache in the lower extremity when not moving.  Demographic Information:  The subject is an unmarried African-American man  employed as a truck driver  a former smoker and with an occasional alcohol intake. He resides in an urban  metropolitan area in Florida.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a well-documented history of type II diabetes mellitus  which he reports managing with diet and metformin. Hypertension  controlled with lisinopril and amlodipine. There was a 30 pack-year smoking history  though he quit 6 years ago. Patient has hypercholesterolemia  managed with atorvastatin. Furthermore  he experienced a myocardial infarction approximately four years ago  managed with double antiplatelet therapy and beta blockers; since discontinued. No history of peripheral arterial disease or stroke.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a non-palpable left posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulse. The left lower extremity was noticeably cooler than the right. It was observed two non-healing  superficial ulcers on the left foot: one at the tip of the first toe  second at the third metatarsal head. There was no cellulitis or deep infection noticeable. The ankle-brachial index (ABI) showcased severe left lower extremity ischemia with a value of less than 0.40. A duplex ultrasound exposed a significant stenosis in the left lower extremity.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Based on the clinical findings and the patient's reported symptoms  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia was made. Pulse volume recordings showed a significant dampening of the signals in the left lower extremity compared to the right. The patient underwent a contrast angiogram that confirmed the findings from the duplex ultrasound. It exhibited a complete occlusion in the left common iliac artery and severe stenosis in the left external iliac artery. No significant disease was noticed in the right lower extremity.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was treated initially with maximum medical therapy including antiplatelet  statin  and cilostazol to improve his symptoms. Further  angioplasty was recommended but the patient refused all the invasive strategy interventions.  Follow-up and outcomes:  Following medical therapy  his symptoms became less severe but patient still reports pain during walking. Considering the persistent critical condition  the assessment of amputation of the left lower extremity is under discussion.   Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of early recognition and aggressive management in patients with significant risk factors for atherosclerotic disease. Diagnosis of CLI must be considered in diabetic patients with chronic foot ulcers. It also demonstrates the potential pitfalls when patient hesitates for interventional strategy leading to poorer prognosis.

Case Report- Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information:   Mr. Albert  a 68-year-old African-American male  presented with progressive lower extremity pain at rest and non-healing wounds on both feet for the last three weeks.  Past Medical History:  His past medical history is significant for type-2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 40-pack years of smoking. Records indicate he was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) five years ago. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin. No known drug allergies were reported.  Complaints & Clinical Findings:  Mr. Albert complained of severe pain in both legs  primarily at rest  progressing to nocturnal pain  often awakening him from sleep. It was noted that the pain laterally subsides when legs dangle over the bedside. There were ulcerations observed between his toes and on the tips of his toes on both feet. The ulcers were dry  black  and surrounded by pale  shiny skin. There was no palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulse bilaterally. The ankle-brachial index measurement was less than 0.4 bilaterally indicative of severe ischaemia.  Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical presentation and physical examination  Mr. Albert was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe stage of Peripheral Artery Disease.  Treatment & Response:  The patient was promptly started on an aggressive regime of dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin and Clopidogrel) and statins to control his cholesterol levels. Pain management was initiated with opioids. A vascular surgeon was consulted and after reviewing the angiography showing significant occlusive disease in both his lower limbs; he recommended endovascular revascularization. The procedure was performed and unblocked the occluded arteries restoring blood flow. Mr. Albert reported a marked decrease in pain soon after.  Following the procedure  Mr. Albert’s feet wounds were carefully cleaned  debrided  and dressed. He was prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic to prevent infection. Post-procedural  he was closely monitored for signs of reperfusion injury. After 10-days in the hospital  his wounds started showing signs of healing.  Follow-up:  Given his significant comorbid conditions  Mr. Albert was referred to a multidisciplinary team to manage his diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia effectively. A smoking cessation program was recommended. He was educated on the importance of adhering to a strictly Mediterranean diet and a regular exercise routine  for maintaining the health and functionality of his lower limbs.  Currently  he is on a follow-up outpatient basis every month to monitor the healing of his ulcers and to check the functioning of lower limb arteries. Regular changes in his dressing are also done. Through concerted multi-disciplinary care and constant monitoring  he shows gradual improvement in condition and lifestyle changes.  Concluding Note:  While Mr. Albert's case is being monitored  it serves as a crucial reminder for timely recognition and intervention in critical limb ischemia  given its association with high morbidity  mortality  and reduced quality of life.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 62-year-old Male with Type 2 Diabetes: A Case Report  Patient Information: Mr. X is a 62-year-old Caucasian male from Tampa  Florida  who presented with signs and symptoms suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). The patient is a nonsmoker  moderate alcohol consumer  and has a history of poor dietary habits with a high-fat  high-sugar diet.  Presenting Issue: The patient presented with severe pain in the right leg  especially when at rest  along with an ulcer on the heel of the same foot  and noticeable color change (pallor). Additionally  the patient reported a steady decline in mobility over the past several months.  Past Medical History: Mr. X was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) around 12 years ago  and has been managing it with Metformin  though with suboptimal glucose control. Besides T2DM  he also has a history of Hypertension (HTN) for which he takes Lisinopril. Furthermore  he was diagnosed with Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) about 5 years ago. Hyperlipidemia was also recorded  which he takes Atorvastatin for control. There is no background of any heart conditions or cerebrovascular disease.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination displayed decreased peripheral pulses in the right lower extremity and an ulcerated wound on the right heel with gangrenous signs. Ankle Brachial Index (ABI) was significantly reduced (0.35 on the right  0.88 on the left)  highlighting significant arterial obstructive disease on the right side. Hypertension was noted with a blood pressure reading of 155/95 mmHg. Lab results showed poorly controlled diabetes with an elevated HbA1c of 9.2%.  Diagnosis: Based on clinical history  physical findings  and results from the Ankle-Brachial Index  the diagnosis of 'Critical Limb Ischemia(CLI)' secondary to T2DM and PAD was reached.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was counseled about the seriousness of the disease and the need for lifestyle modifications. He was initially given pain management with Oxycodone. Endovascular intervention with angioplasty or stent placement was scheduled. Medications for diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia were revised for better control. He was referred to a diet consultant for a good dietary plan. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy was suggested to aid the healing of the chronic diabetic foot ulcer.  Follow-Up & Outcomes: Mr. X showed commitment in proactively managing his conditions. His pain was controlled  and the foot ulcer showed signs of gradual healing over weeks. Advised regular follow-up visits were scheduled to track his disease progress and control of comorbidities.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed fear towards the complexity of his condition but was very cooperative and compliant with plans for lifestyle changes  regular medications  and frequent follow-ups for better disease management.  Informed Consent: The patient consented for his case to be published. He was educated that his case details would be used for educational purposes while maintaining his confidentiality. He understood and appropriately signed the consent form.   Learning Points: This case underscores the need for vigilant management of long-standing T2DM and hypertension  which if not properly managed could lead to serious conditions such as critical limb ischemia. It emphasizes the importance of lifestyle changes in preventing disease progression.

Title: Case Report on a Patient with Critical Limb Ischemia   Abstract: This case report provides the details of a 68-year-old male patient diagnosed with critical limb ischemia  and attempts to evaluate the management strategies and outcomes. Senior patients and those with diabetes or peripheral artery disease are typically vulnerable to this severe condition.  Patient Profile: The patient is a retired accountant from a rural area  who has a history of smoking and alcohol use. His past medical history revealed diagnoses of type II diabetes  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease.  Presentation: The patient presented with a 2-month history of severe pain in his right lower leg  notably on ambulation and during night time. The pain was progressively increasing  and the patient also reported symptoms of numbness and coldness in the extremity. Further physical examination revealed a non-healing ulcer (approximately 2cm in diameter) on his right foot along with weak or non-palpable pulses below the knee.  Clinical Findings: Laboratory tests indicated poor glycemic control with elevated HbA1c (8.8%). The patient's LDL cholesterol was slightly elevated (110 mg/dL)  and creatinine levels were normal  ruling out renal impairment. Doppler ultrasound confirmed significant stenosis in the below-knee arteries  and angiography corroborated severe peripheral artery disease with multiple blockages.  Treatment and Outcomes: A multidisciplinary approach was taken for treatment: optimal glycemic control was strived for  and the patient was referred to a dietitian for appropriate dietary recommendations. The patient was prescribed antiplatelet therapy and statins to retard the progression of peripheral artery disease.  Given the severity of the condition and the presence of non-healing ulcers  an endovascular procedure  specifically angioplasty  was performed. The procedure was successful  and follow-up ultrasounds showed improved blood flow in the affected region. The patient's healing progress was closely monitored  and he was advised to quit smoking and reduce alcohol consumption.  After 6 weeks  the patient reported a significant reduction in pain and improved mobility. The ulcer showed signs of healing. The patient was continued on lifelong medication for diabetes  hypertension  and cholesterol management.  Conclusion: This case underlines the need for early recognition of critical limb ischemia symptoms in patients with risk factors like diabetes and peripheral artery disease. A multidisciplinary approach with endovascular surgical intervention and lifestyle modifications proves effective in managing the condition.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 73-Year-Old Female with a History of Cardiovascular Disease  Patient Information: A 73-year-old Caucasian female was admitted to our facility on account of severe claudication in her right lower extremity which had been persisting for the past eight months. The patient is a known case of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She also has a medical history of coronary artery disease for which she underwent coronary angioplasty 2 years ago. She is a nonsmoker with no history of alcohol or substance abuse.   Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with chronic non-healing ulcers on her right foot  accompanied by severe pain in the right leg that typically intensifies at rest. Her pain  scored as an 8 out of 10 on the intensity scale  could not be alleviated by hanging her leg over the side of the bed or taking over-the-counter pain relievers. She also reported a significant decrease in mobility due to the pain  limiting her daily activities and negatively affecting her quality of life.   Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed cool skin in her right lower extremity  along with weak arterial pulses  venous filling time of over 20 seconds  and a significant decrease in hair growth. The right foot was pale with some discoloration and had deep non-healing ulcers in the heel and dorsal areas. No signs of inflammation or infection were observed in the affected area. The left leg appeared normal with strong arterial pulses and no signs of ulceration or discomfort.   Diagnostic Assessment: An ankle-brachial index (ABI) measurement of 0.45 in the right lower limb and Duplex ultrasound confirmed the presence of severe arterial occlusion. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) later revealed long segment occlusion of the right femoropopliteal artery. Blood tests showed elevated glycated hemoglobin  indicative of poorly controlled diabetes.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was administered pain management medications to alleviate her symptoms. The wound was debrided  and negative pressure wound therapy initiated for the ulcers. Considering the patient's age and her high surgical risk status due to her significant cardiovascular history  it was decided to proceed with endovascular revascularization. Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty was performed with successful recanalization of the occluded segment.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient showed significant improvement post-procedure with a remarkable reduction in her pain scores and a notable improvement in the healing of her ulcers. She was discharged with oral antiplatelets  statin therapy  and a rigorous diabetic control regimen. The patient was also referred for rehabilitation and informed about lifestyle modifications  including a balanced diet and regular exercise.   Conclusion: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) is a severe and advanced stage of peripheral arterial disease posing significant patient risk. A comprehensive individualized treatment approach considering the patient's comorbidities is requisite to manage and significantly improve the quality of life for such patients.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in a Patient with Poorly Controlled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: A Case Report  I. Introduction Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) is a severe manifestation of peripheral arterial disease and is linked to high morbidity  amputation rates  and mortality. This case report focuses on a patient with CLI  with a history of poorly controlled Type 2 Diabetes.  II. Patient Information The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian female (weight: 72 kg  height: 165 cm)  a former smoker with a 30-pack year history  and a resident of Ontario  Canada. She lives with her husband and is retired from a career in education.   III. Clinical Findings The patient presented with severe pain in her right leg  extending from the calf to the foot  much aggravated at rest. There was notable skin discoloration and coldness in the lower extremities  particularly the right leg. Additionally  she reported experiencing rapid weight loss in the past couple of months.   IV. Medical History The patient was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) 20 years ago but struggled with glycemic control due to poor medication and dietary compliance. Her latest HbA1c level was 9.2%. Additionally  she suffered from Hypertension and Dyslipidemia  both controlled with medication. She had a history of coronary artery disease but no myocardial infarction. Furthermore  she had no history of cerebrovascular accidents or known peripheral vascular disease. Her medications included Metformin and Insulin for Diabetes  Ramipril for Hypertension  and Atorvastatin for Dyslipidemia. She had quit smoking five years ago.   V. Diagnostic Assessment On bilateral lower extremity examination  no palpable pulses were noted distally  and Doppler assessment revealed markedly diminished signals in the right distal leg. An Ankle-Brachial Index was 0.5 on the right and 0.6 on the left. CT Angiography revealed severe occlusive atherosclerotic disease in the infrapopliteal vessels on the right side  confirming the diagnosis of CLI.   VI. Therapeutic Intervention and Follow-up The patient was commenced on optimal medical therapy including aspirin and a statin  with optimization of her diabetes control. She was referred for endovascular intervention. However  due to the advanced nature of the disease  distal bypass surgery was performed. Her post-operative course was uneventful  and she showed signs of clinical improvement  with wound healing and diminished pain. She continues to attend follow-up outpatient appointments every three months to monitor her diabetes control and peripheral arterial disease.  VII. Conclusion This case highlights the importance of early recognition and aggressive management of risk factors  particularly in diabetes mellitus  to potentially prevent the development and progression of peripheral arterial disease and CLI.

Title: A Case of Critical Limb Ischemia in a 62-Year-Old Male End-Stage Renal Disease Patient  Case Description:  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a significant medical history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD)  long-standing Type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease (PAD).  The patient first presented to the emergency department with acute onset severe rest pain in his left lower limb. The pain was constant and associated with a non-healing ulcer on the left great toe. He reported worsening of the pain during the night and had to dangle his leg over the side of the bed to ease it (orthopnea). He denied any trauma or history of similar symptoms in the past. On further inquiry  the patient disclosed intermittent claudication for the past year  which he overlooked and associated with his age and general health status.  Physical examination revealed a pale and cold left lower extremity. The posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses were absent bilaterally. Findings were consistent with a Rutherford category IV critical limb ischemia (CLI) on the left side. The ankle-brachial index (ABI) was 0.30 on the left side and 0.65 on the right  confirming severe PAD.  Given these findings and the patients' history of ESRD and diabetes  an urgent peripheral angiography was performed  which demonstrated a complete occlusion of the left superficial femoral artery  popliteal artery  and the proximal part of the anterior tibial artery. The patient was immediately subjected to a femoral-popliteal bypass surgery using a synthetic graft.  Post-surgery  the patient was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit for close monitoring of his hemodynamic status and renal function. Rehabilitation measures were initiated and the patient was prescribed dual antiplatelet therapy  statin  and an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor. Strict blood glucose control was advised to prevent infection of the pre-existing ulcer and progression of CLI.  Within the subsequent weeks  the patient demonstrated considerable improvement. Physical examination showed palpable dorsal pedis and posterior tibial pulses  while his rest pain and ulcer showed signs of improvement.  Discussion:  This case highlights the severe consequences of untreated PAD  eventually leading to CLI. Management requires a comprehensive approach including medical therapy  lifestyle modification  and invasive procedures like angiography and bypass surgery in extensive blockages.  Increased awareness about early signs of PAD among high-risk patients  such as those with diabetes and renal disease  is crucial to prevent severe complications like CLI. Regular ABI checks can serve as a non-invasive diagnostic tool to monitor these patients.

Patient Profile:  Mr. James Smith  a 72-year-old African-American male  presented himself in the emergency department of our hospital. The patient's primary complaint was unbearable pain in his right leg that worsened during the night  making it extremely challenging for him to sleep. He also mentioned intermittent claudication  noting that the pain became severe during walking but reduced when he was at rest. Upon physical examination  the skin of his right foot was presenting non-healing ulcers and was cold to touch. No pedal pulsations were felt. The patient's medical history revealed a diagnosis of Type II diabetes mellitus under control with oral hypoglycemic and hypertension managed with ACE inhibitors and diuretics medications.  Medical History:   Mr. Smith has had a history of atherosclerotic peripheral artery disease (PAD) for the last six years  for which he undergoes regular medical follow-ups. Besides  he has been under continuous monitoring and medication for hypertension for ten years and type II diabetes for fifteen years. The patient also has a ten-year history of hyperlipidemia managed with statins and a smoking habit of twenty years  although he quit smoking about eight years ago.  Investigations:  An immediate ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) was calculated  which indicated 0.32 in the right leg and 0.98 in the left leg. These results affirmed the presence of severe ischemia in the right limb. Further  Doppler ultrasonography of the right lower limb manifested severe stenosis of the distal right femoral artery and total occlusion of popliteal and trifurcation arteries. No significant stenosis was detected in the left leg.  Treatment:  Given the severity of the ischemia  critical limb ischemia (CLI) was diagnosed  and an urgent peripheral angioplasty with a potential stent placement procedure was recommended to re-establish blood flow to his right leg. The patient was counseled about the need for the procedure  the risks involved  and the potential outcomes if left untreated. He verbalized understanding and consented to proceed.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The angioplasty and stent placement were successful  with immediate relief reported in his leg pain. Subsequent ABPI evaluation showed significant improvement  and pedal pulses became palpable. The patient was prescribed dual antiplatelet therapy and advised to continue his medications for diabetes and hypertension. He was also advised for regular exercise  a proper diabetes diet  and to monitor blood sugar levels more frequently. He was scheduled for a one-month follow-up consultation to monitor his condition and healing progression of the foot ulcers.  This case reveals the profound impact of long-term diabetes and hypertension on vascular health  leading to critical conditions like limb ischemia. Thus  it strongly points out the importance of regular screening and early intervention for PAD in high-risk individuals  particularly diabetics.

Title: An Uncommon Presentation of Critical Limb Ischemia in an Elderly Diabetic Patient  Patient Profile: The patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus well controlled on insulin. He is a former smoker  with a 30-pack year history and quit smoking 20 years ago. The patient is also known to have hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he’s maintained on medication (amlodipine and atorvastatin  respectively). He denied any history of cardiovascular diseases or peripheral artery disease (PAD).  Presenting complaints: The patient presented to the hospital outpatient department complaining of non-healing ulcers on his right lower extremity for approximately three months. He also mentioned associated symptoms like intermittent claudication  coldness  and pallor in the same limb. No history of trauma was reported.  Clinical Findings: On inspection  the patient had gangrenous changes and ulcers in his distal right foot. Peripheral pulses  including dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial  were absent in the right lower limb but easily palpable in the left lower limb.   Laboratory Investigations: His Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) level was slightly elevated at 7.2%  indicating poor glycemic control. Lipid panel showed elevated cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein levels. Complete blood count  blood urea nitrogen  and creatinine were within normal limits.   Imaging and Diagnostic Assessment: On performing an ankle-brachial index (ABI)  values were lower than 0.40 in the right lower limb indicative of critical ischemia. Computed tomographic angiography (CTA) of the lower limbs demonstrated severe occlusive disease in the patient's right lower limb vessels  particularly involving the below-knee popliteal artery and tibial arteries.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical findings  ABI value  CTA imaging  and the chronic presence of gangrenous foot ulcers  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) was made.  Treatment: The patient underwent lower limb revascularization via angioplasty. Post-procedure  his symptoms started to improve  and the ulcers began to show signs of healing. In addition  he was initiated on antiplatelets  statins  and optimal wound care was given for his foot ulcers.  Follow-up: Given his advanced age  diabetes  and other comorbidities  a multidisciplinary team  including endocrinologists  nutritionists  and physiotherapists  formed a comprehensive care plan. The patient was advised stringent diabetes control  a balanced diet and regular follow-ups.  Conclusion: This case depicts a rather uncommon presentation of CLI in the absence of a known history of peripheral artery disease (PAD). It underscores the propensity of certain risk factors  such as diabetes and smoking  towards PAD and ultimately CLI. Early detection and appropriate treatment can mitigate the risk of major amputation and improve the quality of life in these patients.

Title: Case Report on an Older Adult Male with Critical Limb Ischemia Due to Chronic Peripheral Arterial Disease   Case Introduction: The patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian male who presented with chronic non-healing ulcers in the right lower extremity for the past 6 months. The patient has a history of progressive  exertional right leg pain over the last year which has significantly worsened over the past two months causing him discomfort during short-distance walks and at rest at night. The patient’s past medical history includes hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  hypercholesterolemia  and a 60-pack year smoking history. The patient has been a non-smoker for the past five years.  Clinical findings: Upon admission  the patient appeared uncomfortable and reported severe pain in his right leg rated at 8 on a 10-point scale. Physical examination revealed a pale  cool right lower extremity with weak pedal pulses. Multiple non-healing ulcers were noted on the forefoot and the heel  with signs of local infection. No palpable popliteal or femoral pulses were noted in the right lower limb. Bacilli Calmette-Guerin (BCG) testing came back positive  indicative of osteomyelitis.  Paraclinical Investigations: Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) reading was 0.40 on the right leg and 1.0 on the unaffected left leg  diagnostic of severe peripheral artery disease (PAD) in the right lower limb. Color Doppler Ultrasound (CDUS) of the right lower limb revealed significant arterial stenosis. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) indicated extensive atherosclerotic occlusive disease from the right superficial femoral artery to the tibial arteries. Hemoglobin levels were within normal range  while C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate were elevated  consistent with an ongoing inflammatory reaction.  Therapeutic Intervention: Endovascular revascularization was deemed the best approach for this patient  given his overall status. The patient underwent successful right lower limb angioplasty with stent placement in the stenotic segments. Post-procedure  the patient was started on antiplatelet therapy and statin. Intravenous antibiotics were administered for the management of osteomyelitis.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  There was significant improvement in the patient’s pain within the first 48 hours post-procedure. Control ABI after three weeks showed an improved reading of 0.9 on the right leg. Following 6 weeks of antibiotic therapy  the patient showed signs of ulcer healing and a decrease in infection markers.    Patient Perspective: The patient was relieved to find a significant reduction in pain and was willing to comply with the prescribed medication regimen and lifestyle modifications.  Take-Away: Early detection and interventions of PAD are crucial in preventing critical limb ischemia and subsequent complications. This report emphasizes the role of endovascular interventions in managing peripheral arterial disease effectively  preventing amputation  and improving the quality of life of patients.

Title: A Case Report of Critical Limb Ischemia in a 76-year-old Caucasian Male with History of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Introduction:  The patient  referred to as Mr. X for privacy reasons  is a 76-year-old Caucasian male. He resides in the urban outskirts of New York City and is a retired automobile mechanic. He presented with complaints of severe pain in his right lower limb  which he described as a consistent sharp and toothache-like pain. The pain had been escalating over the past few months  but it increased dramatically in the last week with an onset of unusual paleness and coolness of the limb. The patient reported that the pain was so severe it often disturbed his sleep.   Medical History:  Mr. X has a known history of hypertension  which was diagnosed twelve years ago  and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed ten years ago. He was compliant with his antihypertensive and hypoglycemic medications. However  his blood pressure control and blood glucose levels had been poorly controlled in recent years.  The patient has moderate renal impairment as revealed by his latest blood tests. He was also previously diagnosed with peripheral artery disease about two years ago. He was a heavy smoker until his diagnosis  after which he quit smoking.  Symptoms and Diagnosis:  On physical examination  there were notable signs of ischemia: the skin of the right lower limb was pale  cool to touch  and shiny with notable absence of hair. Pulses in the right posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries were absent. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed impaired blood flow to the right lower limb.  The ankle-brachial index (ABI) was 0.6 in the right limb and normal in the left limb (1.2)  which is suggestive of significant artery blockage. This  coupled with his history and the characteristic features on examination  confirmed the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia in the right lower limb.  Conclusion:  Critical limb ischemia in patients with co-morbid conditions like hypertension and type 2 diabetes requires careful management and aggressive intervention to prevent limb loss. The case of Mr. X presents an instance of poor control of these co-morbid conditions leading to the advanced symptomatology. This case indicates the necessity of controlled medical management of these conditions and close monitoring of patients with a similar profile for early identification and management of critical limb ischemia. With collaboration between the patient  his family physician and a multi-disciplinary team  it is hoped that Mr. X will achieve a beneficial outcome  allowing a return to normal daily living activities. Future studies should seek to establish clear protocols for early detection and management of critical limb ischemia in similar patients.

Patient Information:  AN  a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of Diabetes Type 2  Hypertension  Hypercholesterolemia  and past smoker (quit 15 years ago)  initially presented to the clinic with symptoms of significant pain in his right lower extremity (RLE)  even at rest. He mentioned that he had been experiencing prolonged  severe pain and numbness in that leg over the last few weeks  noticing a change of color to a bluish/purplish hue. The patient also reported difficulty walking due to the pain (claudication).  Past Medical History:  The patient has been diagnosed and managed for Type 2 Diabetes for the last ten years  with fair glycemic control (latest HbA1c-7.5%). He is on metformin  insulin glargine  and sitagliptin for his diabetes. He also has Hypertension for which he takes lisinopril and amlodipine  and he follows a strict dietary regimen to keep the numbers under check. He was diagnosed with Hypercholesterolemia three years ago  for which he takes atorvastatin. He has been a smoker in the past (40 pack-years history)  but he quit smoking 15 years prior.  Presenting Complaints:  He complains of rest pain for the last one month and a non-healing ulcer over plantar aspect of the right foot. Around 3 weeks ago  he noticed a small red wound on the bottom of his right foot which now has grown bigger and deeper despite regular cleaning and dressing.  Physical Examination:  On examination  his right foot was cold to touch with barely audible posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis artery's pulse. Distal leg and foot showed a leathery discoloration with well-defined ulcer over the plantar area of the foot. Distal pulses in his left leg were palpable.  Assessment / Diagnostic Evaluation:  The symptoms were suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). Confirmatory tests were done which included Ankle-Brachial Index (0.3 in right leg  0.9 in left leg). Doppler ultrasound showed significantly reduced blood flow in the right distal leg. CT angiography showed severe stenosis in the distal part of the right superficial femoral artery and complete blockage at the level of popliteal artery. An EKG and echocardiogram were performed to the role out Ischemic heart disease before intervention and were normal.  Treatment and Follow-up:  The patient was started on pain management  antiplatelet (clopidogrel)  and statin therapy (increased dose). Revascularization was planned with an attempt made for below-knee angioplasty. Unfortunately  due to extensive arterial disease  the procedure was unsuccessful. He was then referred for bypass surgery. The patient underwent successful bypass surgery  and his postoperative course was uneventful.   During the follow-up visits  his symptoms significantly improved  the ulcer was healing  and the color of the limb returned to normal. He was advised to maintain strict glycemic and blood pressure control. He was asked to follow up regularly with a multidisciplinary team  including the vascular surgery  diabetology  and podiatry departments.  Learning Points:  This case reiterated the importance of timely intervention in cases of critical limb ischemia  especially amongst patients with risk factors such as Diabetes  Hypertension  Dyslipidemia  and smoking history. In hindsight  proactive peripheral vascular disease screening may have helped due to the patient's significant risk profile. Also  a better adherence to diabetes and hypertension control could possibly have delayed or prevented this complication.

Title: Severe Critical Limb Ischemia in a 65-year-old Male with History of Peripheral Artery Disease: A Case Report  Introduction: Critical limb ischemia (CLI) is a severe obstruction of the arteries which seriously reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and even skin ulcers or sores. CLI is the most severe form of peripheral arterial disease (PAD).  Patient Information: The subject of this report is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with severe rest pain in the left foot  which had been worsening over the past two weeks. Accompanying this pain was the development of a non-healing ulcer on the heel of the same foot. The patient was a long-term smoker (40 years  2 packs/day) and had a medical history of type 2 diabetes and peripheral artery disease. He lived a sedentary lifestyle and was regularly wheelchair-bound due to his chronic conditions.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a palpable but weak dorsalis pedis pulse. The left foot was pale  cold to touch  and showed signs of livedo reticularis. Distal pulses were absent. The non-healing ulcer was approximately 3cm in diameter with black eschar on the surface. There were no signs of infection around the ulcer  but the severity of the ischemia suggested a high risk.  Diagnostic Assessment: Laboratory investigations revealed elevated serum creatinine levels  consistent with renal insufficiency. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) was found to be less than 0.4  indicating severe PAD. A duplex ultrasound scan and computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed occlusion of the left distal superficial femoral & popliteal arteries  along with the anterior tibial artery.  Therapeutic Intervention: Upon diagnosis  the patient was started on a regimen of antiplatelet and statin therapy. Subsequently  endovascular revascularization was attempted via percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) along with drug-eluting stent placement. The procedure was successful with restoration of tri-phasic flow.
