Follow Up and Outcomes: Postoperative checkups over a period of three months revealed continued blood flow in previously occluded vessels. The pain experienced by the patient significantly reduced  ulcer signs of healing were clear and renal function tests returned to normal.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed immense relief post-procedure with alleviation of the rest pain and improved mobility. He was optimistic about maintaining the lifestyle improvements suggested by his healthcare professionals.  Conclusion: This case report highlights the necessity of early diagnosis and intervention in management of critical limb ischemia to prevent limb loss. It underscores the need for aggressive treatment in patients with severe PAD to avoid progression to CLI. Moreover  the role of patient education in the management of risk factors for PAD  such as smoking and diabetes  should be stressed to prevent the occurrence of CLI.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 72-year-old Male  Patient Information: Mr. John B.  a retired engineer living in suburban Cleveland  Ohio  is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with an established diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) and hypertension for the past 15 years. He is a former smoker and quit around 10 years ago. There is no history of illicit drug use or alcoholism. The patient has been living a sedentary lifestyle and has persistent issues with weight gain and obesity leading to other associated health problems.   Presenting Concerns: Mr. John presented with a complaint of severe pain in his left lower limb that had been present for several months. He has been experiencing rest pain primarily in his foot that worsens at night  with numbness and occasional tingling. He has noticed a marked decrease in walking distance due to pain and described the initiation of skin color changes and coldness in his left foot. He mentioned the formation of small wounds on the foot that were slow to heal and often became infected.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination confirmed non-healing wounds on his left foot. His left foot was cold to touch with weak pedal pulses  and it showed signs of early gangrene at the toes. His body mass index (BMI) calculated was 35  indicating Class II obesity. His blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg. Laboratory studies showed a raise in fasting blood glucose level  a moderately elevated total cholesterol and LDL level  and normal kidney function tests.  Diagnostic Assessment: Based on the clinical presentation and physical examination findings  a preliminary diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) was made. This was confirmed by performing Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) that showed a value of 0.3  suggestive of severe peripheral artery disease. A Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremity was performed which illustrated impaired blood flow in the left lower extremity primarily involving the tibial and peroneal arteries.  Treatment & Outcomes: Considering the diagnosis of CLI  an immediate vascular surgical consult was made. The patient underwent successful revascularization with angioplasty and stenting of the diseased blood vessels  followed by optimization of his antiplatelet  antihypertensive  and diabetes medications. He was also provided with extensive wound care for his foot ulcers. Nutritional consultations and physiotherapy sessions were also initiated as part of the management plan.  In addition  lifestyle modification counseling was provided  emphasizing the importance of regular exercise  healthy diet  and weight control. For stronger secondary prevention  the patient was closely monitored with regular follow-up visits to evaluate the limb's progression and his overall well-being.  Teaching Points: CLI is a severe form of peripheral arterial disease and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Timely diagnosis through careful clinical appraisal and pertinent investigations is essential. Early revascularization  optimal control of comorbid conditions  and lifestyle modifications form a crucial part of managing such cases for better patient outcomes.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia in a 68-Year-Old Male   Patient Background:  Mr. John Doe is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  residing in rural Idaho. His presenting complaint is severe pain in the right lower extremity characterized by rest pain at the calf  foot  and toes. The pain is described as a constant burning sensation that is 9/10 in severity and aggravated at night. Mr. Doe also disclosed progressive discoloration of the right foot from a healthy pink to a pallor gray along with a non-healing ulcer on the right big toe.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a significant past medical history. He has been a type 2 diabetic for roughly 15 years  which is semi-controlled on Metformin. His systolic blood pressure was recorded as high as 190 mmHg on a few occasions earlier in the year. Thus  he has been diagnosed with hypertension that has been somewhat resistant to treatment. His hypertension is currently managed with a daily dose of Lisinopril and Hydrochlorothiazide.  Additionally  he has been a smoker for approximately 50 years. His quit attempts have been unsuccessful despite utilizing nicotine replacement therapy. Mr. Doe also has a history of hyperlipidemia controlled with Atorvastatin.  Family History:  He has a family history of heart disease; his father passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 63 and his older brother had coronary artery bypass grafting surgery five years ago.   Clinical Assessment:  Given his clinical presentation and past medical history  a preliminary diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was suspected. The attending physician noticed pronounced limb pallor  decreased movement and sensation  cold extremities  and weak pulse intensity in the right lower limb. The non-healing ulcer on his big toe also indicated chronic insufficient blood flow.  Doppler ultrasound  angiography  and Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) were ordered  and findings indeed confirmed severe peripheral artery disease (PAD)  consistent with CLI.   Treatment and Progress:  Mr. Doe was started on a program of revascularization therapy to restore appropriate blood flow and nutrients to his right lower extremity. He was also prescribed antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy for blood thinning and clot prevention and statins to keep his cholesterol levels under better control.  He was referred to a dietician to help manage his diabetes and obesity  provided counseling for smoking cessation  and offered wound care for his non-healing ulcer. He will be regularly followed-up with in the vascular clinic for management of his condition.  In conclusion  this case sheds light on the crucial importance of recognizing the signs and risks of critical limb ischemia in patients with diabetes  atherosclerosis  and a history of tobacco use. Proper management of these risk factors can reduce the severity or prevent CLI and its complications.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia in 63-Year-Old Male  Patient Information  Mr. B  a 63-year-old African American male with a history of heavy smoking  was referred to our clinic for evaluation of continuous pain in his left leg. The patient lives in the inner city  is married  and works as a delivery truck driver. He drinks alcohol on occasions and denies illicit drug use. He claims compliance with blood pressure and cholesterol medications.  Medical History  The patient has a documented past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes mellitus poorly controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents  and a 40 pack-year history of smoking cigarettes. He has no known allergies  no genetic syndromes  no documented psychiatric issues  and no history of surgeries or major trauma.  Chief Complaint  Mr. B primarily complained of continual rest pain in the left lower limb  especially severe during the night time  disturbing his sleep for the past 4 weeks. He also reported an open wound on the side of his left foot  which had not healed in a month. Upon inspection  the wound appeared necrotic and was approximately 2 cm in diameter  with minor pus discharge surrounding the region.  Clinical Findings  During the physical examination  the patient's left lower limb was significantly cooler than the right  and diminished pulses were noted. His left foot showed ischemic changes with hair loss  pallor  and thickened toenails. An ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) measurement was taken and showed considerably lower values for the affected left limb (0.40)  suggestive of arterial insufficiency.  Diagnostic Assessment  Given the patient’s risk factors and clinical presentation  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) was considered. Further diagnostic workup with peripheral angiography and duplex ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis showing severely reduced arterial flow in the left lower limb. Blood tests were also conducted revealing poorly controlled diabetes (HbA1c: 9.2%) and dyslipidemia.  Therapeutic Intervention  Prompt revascularization was recommended due to the presence of rest pain and necrotic wound  indicative of imminent risk of limb loss. He underwent an angioplasty and stent placement of the stenotic segments in left iliac and femoral arteries. Medication regimen was enhanced by initiating clopidogrel  a P2Y12 inhibitor for prevention of post-angioplasty thrombotic events  and optimizing his glycemic control.  Follow-up and Outcomes  During follow-up after revascularization  the patient’s rest pain markedly improved  and healing of the foot ulcer initiated. Better glycemic control was achieved over time. Overall  Mr. B showed satisfactory progress and is followed up regularly in the vascular surgery clinic.     Conclusion  This case highlights the significance of early recognition and intervention in patients with critical limb ischemia  particularly in patients with considerable risk factors such as poorly controlled diabetes  dyslipidemia  and a significant history of smoking. Furthermore  it underlines the importance of optimal glycemic control and stringent follow-up in managing such patients.

CASE REPORT:  Patient Information:   A 65-year-old Caucasian male  a retired desk-job worker who resides in downtown Texas  presented to the emergency department.  Clinical Presentation:   The patient complained of increasing pain in his left lower extremity  especially when he was lying down  and non-healing ulcer on the left foot. He also reported colour change in the affected leg  which had been worsening over the past weeks.  Past Medical History: The patient had been previously diagnosed with Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) about six years ago for which he was undergoing treatment. He had also been recently diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus a year ago but did not comply with dietary restrictions or medications regularly. He also expressed his history of regular smoking for the past 30 years until two months ago  with a history of approximately 45 pack-years. There was no known family history of any vascular or immune diseases. The patient had no allergies reported to any medications or foods.  Examination: Upon physical examination  the left foot had a noticeable colour change to pallor with signs of gangrene in the toes. The skin felt cold to touch compared to the right foot. The patient’s left foot had a large non-healing ulcer located at the plantar surface. Furthermore  severe claudication was present and magnified upon elevation of the leg. Pulses were absent in the left foot and weak in the left popliteal and femoral area.  Investigations: Arterial Doppler studies of the lower limbs showed reduced and delayed blood flow in the left popliteal artery  Anterior Tibial Artery (ATA) and Posterior Tibial Artery (PTA) confirming severe stenosis. Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was calculated to be less than 0.6 suggestive of severe PAD. Magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) also confirmed multi-level arterial blockages in the left lower limb.  Diagnosis: With the above presentation  investigations and underlying risk factors  the patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Management and Follow-up: The patient underwent successful revascularization procedure via angioplasty and stenting for the left limb occlusion. He was prescribed antiplatelet medication for preventing clot formation  pain relief medication  and medication was optimized for his diabetes management. The patient was also educated about the importance of wound care for his foot ulcer  encouraged to quit smoking completely  and nutritional counseling was provided. Regular follow-ups were scheduled for wound checks  monitoring of underlying conditions  and patient compliance.  This case portrays a typical CLI in an individual with advanced PAD aggravated by the patient's adherence to a poor lifestyle and uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. This highlights the importance of adhering to required lifestyle changes and consistent follow-up with medical management in managing and preventing further deterioration of the disease.

Patient Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia  Introduction: The following case report describes a patient diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI). CLI is a severe form of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  characterized by chronic ischemic rest pain  ulcers  or gangrenes in one or both legs  attributable to objectively proven arterial occlusive disease.   Patient Demographics: The patient is a 72-year-old African-American male with a height of 5'10"" and weight of 80 kg. He is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic and resides in a suburban area of New Jersey  USA. He is retired and previously worked as a truck driver for a logistics company. His diet can be characterized as moderate with a moderate intake of animal proteins  fruits and vegetables. He does not participate in regular physical activities fulfilling the recommendations.  Presenting Complaint: The patient initially presented to the clinic complaining of experiencing significant pain in his left lower leg during walking which subsided at rest  and the presence of non-healing ulcers on the same leg for the past two months.   Medical History: The patient has a long-standing history of hypertension (HTN) for which he is on medication (5 years). He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) approximately 10 years ago  a condition managed by oral hypoglycemic agents. Additionally  he was found to have hyperlipidemia three years ago and has since been on statin therapy. All these conditions have been well managed as per the patient's reports. He has had no previous surgeries  except for a hernia repair 20 years ago. His family history revealed that his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 69  and his mother is alive and well and has a diagnosis of osteoporosis.  Clinical Examination: On examination  the patient's pulse rate was 78 beats per minute; blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg. Pulses in the left leg's posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis were not palpable. There were two non-healing ulcers on the distal part of his left leg  about two centimeters in diameter each  with no signs of infection. There was also noted to be hair loss on the extremity  and toenails had a thickened appearance. Overall  the examination was suggestive of limb ischemia.   Conclusion: Considering the patient's medical history  clinical presentation  and physical examination results  he was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia. The patient was then referred to a vascular surgeon for further assessment and treatment plan. Lifetime control of CV factors and lifestyle changes were part of the supportive therapy recommended. His family and caregivers will need appropriate education on recognizing early symptoms for future prevention and immediate interventions.

Title: Demographic Specifics and Past Medical History: Management of Critical Limb Ischemia in an Elderly Hypertensive Patient  Patient Information: Mr. X  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain in his right lower limb.  Patient History: Factoring in the patient's chronological medical history  it was established that Mr. X was a long-standing hypertensive  with his illness diagnosed 20 years prior to the present emergency. He had been consistent with his medical treatment  which included Amlodipine and Lisinopril. He had stopped smoking 10 years ago and had a transient ischemic attack seven years back  which was managed adequately. He had no known allergies.  Current Presentation: Upon physical examination  significant pallor was noted in the patient's right lower limb  which was notably cold to touch in comparison to the other extremity. The right pedal pulses were not palpable  and the limb demonstrated decreased sensation.  Investigations: Color Doppler ultrasonography suggested decreased blood flow in the right lower limb. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) was 0.40. In the angiogram  occlusion of right femoral artery was noted.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical findings  patient’s past medical history  and investigations  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) of the right lower limb was made.   Management: Revascularization was chosen as the primary procedure to restore the blood flow  using angioplasty. The patient also started on Clopidogrel and Atorvastatin  besides the regular medication. Pain relief was achieved through opioids.  Progress and Outcome: The patient's condition improved post-intervention. He followed up regularly at the vascular clinic  where the limb condition was monitored. Six months post-procedure  he displayed prevention of limb loss and could perform walking without severe discomfort.  Conclusion: This report showcases the complex case of a patient with a history of long-standing hypertension  dealt successfully by the medical team. It underscores the need for adequate vigilance and timely intervention for preventing major complications in patients with critical limb ischemia.  (Patient details are kept confidential under patient-doctor confidentiality guidelines).

Patient Profile: - Name: [Protected for patient privacy reasons] - Age: 76 - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Engineer  Presenting Issue: The patient presented with severe pain in his left leg  which increased when in motion and decreased when at rest. He also exhibited skin color changes  cool skin temperature on his left leg and delayed wound healing time  especially with a small ulcer on his left foot.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus for about 15 years  with moderate disease management but poor glycemic control. He has also been diagnosed with hypertension  controlled by medication. He has a 40-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes per day  currently still smoking. There is no family history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD).   Physical Examination: Upon examination  the patient had absent pulses in the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis on the left leg. A small  superficial ulcer was seen on the dorsal portion of the left foot. Furthermore  he had a weak monophasic pulse on the right leg. There was noticeable pallor in the left leg  especially on leg elevation.   Diagnostic Assessment: An ankle-brachial index (ABI) was performed that revealed a score of 0.40  indicative of severe PAD. Afterward  the patient underwent a Doppler ultrasound  which detected significant stenosis in the left iliac and femoral arteries.   Treatment Plan: The patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). He was referred to the vascular surgery department and underwent successful iliac and femoral artery revascularization. Also  he was advised to stop smoking and manage his diabetes more effectively. He was started on antiplatelet therapy (clopidogrel)  statin therapy (atorvastatin)  and the ACE inhibitor (ramipril) was added to his treatment regimen to control hypertension.  Progress and Follow up: The patient showed significant improvement in leg pain and healing of the foot ulcer post-surgery. Follow-up ABI showed an improved score of 0.85. The patient was scheduled for regular check-ups to monitor his condition.  This case highlights the importance of considering CLI in patients with significant risk factors  such as long-term smoking  diabetes  and hypertension. It emphasizes the need for vigilant monitoring  and early recognition as CLI can lead to serious consequences if untreated.  Patient Consent: Obtained.  (Disclaimer: This report is a fictional representation and should not be used for diagnostic and treatment decisions.)

Presentation:  A 72-year-old Hispanic male presented to the emergency department with acute onset of right lower limb pain that had commenced about 24 hours prior. The pain was severe and persistent  accompanied by a cold sensation and significant color change in the limb.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes for the past 20 years and a 40-pack year smoking history. He also suffers from hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease (PAD). Two months ago  a toe on his right foot was amputated due to a non-healing infection.   Demographics: He lives with his wife in a suburban area and retired as a truck driver. He is a heavy smoker and has been smoking for more than 50 years. He also reports occasional alcohol consumption.  Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction  and his elder brother had a stroke. Both his brother and mother have type 2 diabetes.   Physical Exam: Upon examination  the patient's right foot was pale and colder compared to the left foot. There were changes in skin color and decreased hair growth. Distal pulses were absent with reduced capillary refill time. There were no audible bruits over the femoral or popliteal arteries.   Investigations and Diagnosis: An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was conducted  which resulted in a reading of 0.3 on the right side  suggestive of severe PAD. Computed tomographic angiography (CTA) revealed severe stenosis of the right popliteal artery and the trifurcation arteries. Based on the clinical findings and investigations  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made.  Management: Post-diagnosis  patient management included urgent revascularization of the right leg  adjustments to control his diabetes  a strict cessation of smoking  and lifestyle modification advice. He was referred to a vascular surgeon for consideration of a possible bypass or endovascular procedure. Also  he was referred to a dietitian and a diabetes educator to assist with control of his diabetes.  This case demonstrates how PAD can lead to CLI if left untreated in patients with uncontrolled diabetes and long-term smoking habits. Early detection and aggressive management of PAD may prevent the development of CLI and its grievous consequences.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Webber. He presented with a chief complaint of worsening chronic pain in his left lower limb  particularly the foot  which exacerbated during the night or when he was lying flat. Additionally  he reported numbness  pallor  and coolness in his limb. He has a history of ulcers in his left foot which failed to heal due to poor blood circulation. He also mentioned experiencing difficulty in walking long distances and climbing stairs due to muscle cramping in the leg  a condition known as claudication.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Webber has a significant history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past 15 years. He was a chronic smoker until he was diagnosed with moderate COPD five years ago. He had an episode of ischemic stroke two years ago with no significant residual disability.  Demographics:  Mr. Webber is a retired construction worker living in urban Minnesota  with his wife. He has two sons  one is a banker and another is working in a software company. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father died due to myocardial infarction at the age of 63 and his older brother is living with angina pectoris.  Clinical Findings & Diagnosis:  On physical examination  his left foot appeared pale and cold to touch compared to his right foot. No arterial bruit heard over the femoral artery. He had noticeable sores on his foot that hadn’t healed. There were no palpable pulses in the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries. His Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was less than 0.4 indicating severe arterial disease. After necessary diagnostic tests including angiography and doppler ultrasound  he was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) due to severe peripheral artery disease.  Management:  He was immediately referred to a vascular surgeon for evaluation of revascularization to prevent limb amputation. Meanwhile  he was prescribed painkillers to control his rest pain. He was also educated about the need for proper foot care  diabetes management  lifestyle modifications including dietary changes  and quitting smoking.  In summary  this case presented a 70-year-old male with critical limb ischemia associated with severe peripheral artery disease  diabetes mellitus  and history of smoking. The patient was referred for further evaluation and intervention to prevent limb loss.

Patient Presentation:  Patient ID: 12486  Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old African-American male  a retired mechanic. He lives with his wife and is a resident of Pittsburgh  Pennsylvania. His diet is characterized by high cholesterol intake  and his lifestyle is non-active. He has a 30-year history of heavy smoking and occasional excessive alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  uncontrolled  diagnosed around 15 years ago. In addition  he has been hypertensive for 20 years and struggles with obesity. He has been under medication for these conditions  with metformin for diabetes and a combination of calcium channel blocker and an ACE inhibitor for hypertension. He was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease five years ago.  Presenting Complaint: The presentation was a two-week history of increasing pain in his right lower limb  especially on walking. The pain improved with rest in the initial stages  but recently  it has persisted even at rest. He has also noticed a non-healing ulcer on his right foot. Furthermore  he complains about the temperature difference between his two feet.  Family History: His father died of sudden cardiac arrest at the age of 60  and his mother passed away due to stroke at age 70. His younger brother  aged 64 years  just had a stent placed in his coronary artery following a myocardial infarction. There's a strong family history of cardiovascular disease.  Examination: His right lower limb is noticeably cooler than the left. The foot shows discoloration with cyanosis  and capillary refill time is prolonged. An ischemic ulcer is present on his right heel. The ankle-brachial index on the right side is 0.3  and the left side is 0.9.  Investigation and management: The patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) after a Doppler ultrasound that revealed severely compromised blood flow in the right lower limb. His blood glucose level and blood pressure were poorly controlled. He was booked for peripheral angiography with possible angioplasty or bypass surgery. His medication was adjusted  and he was advised to immediately stop smoking and reduce alcohol intake. He was educated about proper foot care  the importance of a low cholesterol diet  and physical exercise in his management.  In conclusion  the patient's obesity  diabetic status  long-term smoking habit  and family history placed him at high risk for developing CLI. His condition is complex and requires thorough  long-term management to improve his quality of life and limb prognosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. X  a 68-year-old African-American male  presents to the office with a persistent  severe pain in his right lower limb which he says has been bothering him for several months. He reports the pain as being worse at night  and remarks that occasionally  he feels better when he hangs his leg over the edge of the bed. He is experiencing trouble walking due to the pain and currently uses a cane for assistance. He also mentions recurring ulcers on his foot that do not seem to improve with time or treatment.  Past Medical History:  Mr. X has a significant past medical history  including hypertension  type 2 diabetes for a successful management over 10 years ago  dyslipidemia  and a 50-pack year history of smoking  although he quit smoking two years ago. He had a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery five years ago.   Complete Demographics:  Mr. X is retired and lives with his wife. He is a military veteran  having served for 30 years. He completed his high school education and worked in manual labor occupations throughout his adult life. He drinks alcohol occasionally and quit smoking two years ago.   Family History:  His father died of a myocardial infarction and his mother had a stroke. He has one brother living with coronary artery disease and a sister who is a former smoker and is now living with COPD. There is no known family history of peripheral vascular disease  but the presence of cardiovascular disease suggests a potentially shared risk factor profile.   Physical Examination and Investigations:  On examination  his foot appears pale and shiny with a noticeable absence of hair. The foot is cool to the touch. The dorsalis pedis pulse is faint  and no posterior tibial pulse could be discerned. Distal capillary refill time is prolonged. An Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) test revealed an ABPI of 0.4.  He was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe stage of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  due to his history of diabetes  coronary artery disease  and smoking  along with his clinical manifestations of rest pain and non-healing ulcers.  Given his symptomatology and background history  he was referred to a vascular surgeon for a detailed assessment and consideration for revascularization. A multidisciplinary team approach including wound management  pain control  and tailored intervention will be essential in optimizing outcomes for this patient.

Patient Identification: Mr. T is a 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history of poorly controlled type II diabetes  hypertension  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He comes from a low socioeconomic status community with limited access to healthcare and lives alone.  Chief Complaint: Mr. T presented to the emergency department complaining of severe unbearable pain in his left lower limb which started one week ago. He associated the pain with complete loss of sensation and discoloration in his foot.  History of Present Illness: The patient reported that the severe pain started a week ago and has become progressively worse. It began as a dull pain in his left leg but escalated to a sharp and severe pain. The pain is not relieved by rest or over-the-counter painkillers. Mr. T also reported occasional episodes of claudication.  Past Medical History: Mr. T has a ten-year history of Type II diabetes which has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent access to medication and regular monitoring. He was diagnosed with hypertension five years ago but has not been taking his medication regularly.  Social History: The patient is a long-term smoker with a 40-pack-year smoking history and admits to consuming alcohol occasionally. He lives alone and is retired. He has a poor diet  low physical activity  and limited access to regular healthcare.  Family History: His father died of a heart attack in his late 50s. His mother is alive and has hypertension and diabetes.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  the left lower limb was cold to touch  with a skin color that was pale and somewhat mottled. There were ulcerations noticed on his foot. Pulses in the left leg were absent.  Investigations: An ankle-brachial index was done which showed severe peripheral artery disease. Further evaluation with CT angiography confirmed severe stenosis in his left superficial femoral artery. Lab results showed elevated HbA1c  indicative of poorly controlled diabetes.  Diagnosis: Based on the presenting complaints  history  physical examination  and investigations  Mr. T was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia.  Treatment Plan: He was started on intravenous heparin and consulted with vascular surgery for consideration of a possible revascularization procedure. He was referred to a cardiologist to manage his risk factors including poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension.  Prognosis: Although revascularization can improve limb salvage  Mr. T's prognosis remains guarded due to poorly managed comorbidities and strong risk factors.  Discussion: This case illustrates the importance of managing risk factors aggressively in prevention of complications such as critical limb ischemia  especially in patients with peripheral artery disease. It emphasizes the need for comprehensive public health strategies to improve access to quality healthcare services to underserved populations  addressing social determinants of health  and promoting preventive and therapeutic adherence.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: Mrs. Mildred Jones is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who recently arrived our Emergency Department  presenting with significant pain in her lower left leg. She's a retired school teacher and lives alone  despite having her two grown children and grandchildren living nearby.  Presenting Problem: Mrs. Jones complained of severe persistent pain in her left lower limb (rest pain)  especially profound at night  coupled with non-healing sores on her left foot. She also reports experiencing difficulty walking for the last several months due to discomfort and fatigue in her leg. These are classic symptoms of critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history reveals a long-standing relationship with tobacco  described as a ""pack-a-day"" smoker for nearly four decades  until she successfully quit five years ago. She has history of uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes and was recently diagnosed with high blood pressure. She also suffered a myocardial infarction four years ago. All these conditions indicate a high risk for peripheral arterial disease (PAD).  Family History: Mrs. Jones’ family history reveals both her parents died of heart complications. Her father passed away from a heart attack at 66 years  while her mother had congestive heart failure at 78 years. Her elder brother is currently managing his cholesterol and blood pressure.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  there was marked pallor of the left foot with an absent posterior tibial pulse. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) was measured at 0.4  indicating severe PAD. An angiogram revealed significant multi-level arterial occlusive disease of the left lower extremity  pointing towards CLI.  Treatment Plan: We plan to commence Mrs. Jones on analgesics for pain management and antibiotics for her non-healing foot ulcers. After comprehensive consultation with the Vascular team  she was deemed suitable for revascularization. This could preserving the limb  improve her functional status  and overall quality of life. Control of secondary risk factors will be intensified with antiplatelets  antihypertensives and statins. She will also need to maintain her strict diet control (considering her diabetes) as well as maintain complete abstinence from smoking. It will be essential to involve her in a pulmonary rehabilitation programme to effectively manage her condition.  Upon discharge  Mrs. Jones will be referred to the outpatient limb preservation clinic for further management. Close monitoring will be fundamental to ensure wound healing  control infection  and most importantly  prevent amputation.    Prognosis: The prognosis of CLI is very serious with a high mortality rate and increased risk of non-fatal cardiovascular ischemic events. This case makes one aware of the significant potential morbidity among patients presenting with CLI and the need for improved strategies to manage atherosclerotic risk factors in these patients. The close collaboration between primary care and various specialties will definitely provide an integral role to provide optimal care for patients with CLI.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Jane Doe Age: 65 years old Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Residential Status: Lives independently with spouse  Medical History:  Mrs. Doe has a past medical history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus (diagnosed 10 years ago) and hypertension (diagnosed 8 years ago). She has been compliant with her oral hypoglycemic agents and antihypertensives. She is a former smoker  quitting 5 years ago  with a 30 pack year history. She does not consume alcohol.   She had a myocardial infarction 3 years back and underwent a coronary artery bypass graft surgery.  Her regular medications include metformin  lisinopril  atorvastatin  and aspirin. She has no known allergies.  Clinical Presentation:  Mrs. Doe presented with severe rest pain in her left lower limb that's been ongoing for the past 6 weeks. She has noticed an ulcer on her left big toe. The pain intensifies at night and is relieved upon dangling the foot.   On examination  her left foot appears pale with delayed capillary refill and diminished peripheral pulses when compared to the right foot. The ulcer on her toe appears clean but deep with exposed bone.   She has no visible varicosities  no edema  and no evidence of deep vein thrombosis. The rest of the systemic examination is unremarkable.  Family History:  Her father suffered from peripheral artery disease and passed away due to stroke. Her mother is a well-controlled diabetic.  Diagnosis:   Given her background of diabetes  hypertension  smoking  cardiac history  and the symptoms  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia was made. This was confirmed by Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) and a Doppler ultrasound which showed markedly reduced blood flow to her left lower limb.  Management:  Mrs. Doe was immediately started on optimal medical therapy including antiplatelet (continued aspirin)  statin  and antihypertensive therapy (continued lisinopril). She was referred for prompt angiography with a view for revascularization procedure to restore blood flow. Her ulcer was dressed and she was started on antibiotic prophylaxis.   She has been referred to a dietician for better glycemic control and a diabetes educator to help her understand the importance of foot care in diabetes.  Conclusion:  Mrs. Jane Doe  a 65-year-old female with a history of Type-II diabetes  hypertension  and former smoker presented with a text-book case of Critical Limb Ischemia. After confirming the diagnosis with Doppler ultrasound and ABI  she has been started on proper medical management and planned for a revascularization procedure  showcasing the importance of early diagnosis and management in saving her limb.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J. K. is a 70-year-old Hispanic male presenting with severe rest pain in his left leg and occasional pain at rest with claudication in his right leg. He mentions the pain has been getting progressively worse over the past month and is associated with blackish discoloration at the tips of his left foot. His primary physician referred him to the vascular clinic suspecting a case of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Past Medical History:  Mr. J. K has an extensive 20-year history of Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus which has been poorly controlled. He also has a history of hypertension and dyslipidemia. He suffered a mild myocardial infarction 5 years ago and received two coronary stents. He has mild chronic kidney disease with a GFR around 45  a history of PVD  and a right carotid endarterectomy 10 years back due to transient ischemic attack syndrome.   Social History:  He is a retired steel mill worker  widowed with four children. He has a 50-pack year history of smoking but quit ten years ago.  Family History:  His mother died at the age of 73 due to Ischemic Heart Disease. His father had a history of diabetes mellitus and died due to diabetic nephropathy. A brother  3 years older  has hypertension.  Physical Examination:  On examination  his BMI is 29 and blood pressure 138/92 mmHg. His lower limb examination showed absent pulses in his left foot along with cool skin and blackish discoloration of toes suggestive of gangrene.   Investigations:  His lab investigation showed poor glycemic status with an HbA1C of 9%. His lipid profile was not at goal with LDL of 120 mg/dL. Ultrasound Doppler of the lower limb revealed an occluded left popliteal artery and significantly reduced inflow to the foot. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) was recorded to be <0.4 for the left lower limb indicating severe arterial disease.  Diagnosis:  From the patient's history  physical examination  and diagnostic testing  a diagnosis of CLI was arrived upon.  Plan:  Treatment envisages pain control  antibiotic therapy for the gangrene  improving his blood glucose  and lipid control for preventing further progression. A consult with a vascular surgeon for possible revascularisation intervention or amputation was initiated. The importance of aggressive cardiovascular risk reduction and lifestyle changes was explained to the patient.   Follow-up:  Mr. J.K was scheduled for a follow-up appointment  post his meeting with the vascular surgeon  to discuss his prognosis and the way forward.    This was a poignant case in revealing the debilitating effects of CLI and highlighting the ultimate consequence of chronic systemic disease lapse. It underlines the necessity of consistent preventative medicine and lifestyle choices.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who was admitted to the emergency room with severe rest pain in his right lower extremity. The patient is a resident of Nashville  Tennessee and was initially reluctant to seek medical attention due to financial constraints. He lives with his wife and two dogs and has a history of smoking for the past 40 years.  Past Medical History: The patient's medical history indicates a history of type 2 diabetes for the past 15 years and hypertension for 10 years. His other known conditions include hyperlipidemia and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). His diabetes has been poorly controlled  as shown by his recent hemoglobin A1C level of 9.1%. He had a right foot amputation two years ago due to a diabetic foot ulcer that progressed into gangrene.  Family History: His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 53 and his mother died of diabetes complications at the age of 67. He has two siblings  a brother and a sister  and both are alive with known hypertension. His brother also has coronary artery disease.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with severe rest pain in the right lower limb for the last 2 weeks. He describes the pain as a non-pulsating  severe  persistent cramping pain that worsens at night. The pain is not relieved with over-the-counter analgesics  and it disrupts his sleep.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  the patient's right lower limb looked pale and cold to touch. The foot's dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were not palpable. There were also necrotic lesions on the distal foot with associated edema and erythema.  Impression and Plan:  The patient's history  physical examination  long history of smoking  poor glycemic control  and foot amputation history highly suggest critical limb ischemia. An angiogram was ordered to assess his lower extremity vascular status. The patient was also started on intravenous antibiotics for suspected infection secondary to his foot necrosis. In light of his severe symptoms  consultation with the vascular surgery team for possible intervention was proposed.  This case underscores the importance of good glycemic control and smoking cessation in preventing severe complications of peripheral arterial disease.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Gonzalez  a 70-year-old Hispanic male  presented himself to the clinic with complaints of severe discomfort and constant pain in his right lower leg  which significantly worsened during short walks and became somewhat alleviated upon rest. He currently resides in the suburban region of New York and used to work as a construction laborer.  Medical History:  Upon questioning  he informed us he is a non-insulin-dependent diabetic for the past 20 years. He also has hypertension that is controlled with oral medication. Additionally  he has been a chronic smoker for 50 years though he quit about 2 years ago.  Family History:  Mr. Gonzalez's mother passed away at 80 from stroke and his father died at an early age due to a heart attack. His eldest brother is known to have undergone angioplasty following myocardial infarction. There is also a significant family history of diabetes.  Recent Symptoms:  Recently  the patient noticed that the pain persisted even during the night  interrupting his sleep. He also reported the appearance of non-healing sores on his right ankle. Mr. Gonzalez rated his pain severity as an 8 on a scale of 10 which rendered him unable to carry out daily activities. Observations also revealed pallor and coolness of the affected limb along with notable loss of hair.   Diagnostic Results:  Mr. Gonzalez demonstrates classic symptoms of critical limb ischemia (CLI)  the severe stage of peripheral arterial disease. Ankle-brachial Index was considerably low  indicating narrowed arteries. Duplex ultrasound confirmed significant obstruction in the arterial blood flow in the right lower limb. CT angiography revealed extensive femoral and popliteal artery atherosclerosis.  Management Plan:  Mr. Gonzalez has been scheduled for an endovascular procedure given the severity and critical progression of his symptoms. The multidisciplinary team consisting of a vascular surgeon  diabetologist  and dietitian will manage his case. Recommendations include tight glycemic control  proper wound care  smoking cessation  and dietary control. Comprehensive patient education regarding the management of diabetes and the risk of non-compliance will also be provided.  Summary:  Mr. Gonzalez  diagnosed with critical limb ischemia  presents a complex case due to his diabetes  smoking history  and genetic predisposition. The focus must be on providing him relief from current symptoms and preventing the need for limb amputation.

Patient Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: Mr. L  a 66-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with severe pain in his right lower leg and foot. He's a retired construction worker  living with his wife  with two grown-up children living separately. He’s a 40-pack-a-year smoker with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes managed with metformin and lisinopril. There's no known drug allergy.  Presenting Symptoms:  He has been feeling intermittent claudication for the last couple of years which worsened over the past 3 months. Recently  he has had increasing discomfort and the pain persisted even when he was resting. He noticed changes in his right foot that include cyanosis  pallor  and coolness. Minimal wound healing was also noted on his foot.  Family History:  Significant family history includes a brother with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and his father had a history of heart disease and stroke  pointing towards genetic predisposition to circulatory issues.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed weak pulses below the popliteal artery of the right leg. There was neuropathic pain when palpating the foot  revealing allodynia. Ankle–brachial pressure index (ABPI) was 0.4 on the right and 0.9 on the left. Doppler ultrasound showed reduced blood flow in the right posterior tibial and peroneal arteries.   Diagnosis:  Based on patient's symptoms  risk factors  family history  physical examination and diagnostic findings  he was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) of his right lower extremity.   Treatment & Prognosis: The patient is being managed by a multi-specialty team including vascular surgery and endocrinology. The team decided upon concurrent medical  endovascular and wound care treatment to manage the CLI symptoms and underlying conditions. The patient also received education and counseling for lifestyle modifications like smoking cessation. Given the severity of the patient's condition and his continued smoking  the prognosis could be guarded.   Pertinent Information:  The patient’s significant risk factors  including smoking history  poor glycemic control and hereditary predisposition need to be robustly addressed on top of the dedicated wound care and revascularization efforts.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: Mr. A is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who resides in rural Georgia  United States. He is a retired veteran and lives alone  but has a supportive community in the locale that assists him. Mr. A was a chronic smoker for about 50 years but quit ten years ago and has been maintaining a relatively low sodium diet under the supervision of his community health worker.   Presenting Concerns: Mr. A presented with severe intermittent claudication in his left lower extremity over the past month. He also complained about non-healing ulcers on his left foot and significant pain while resting  which has disrupted his sleep.  Past Medical History: Mr. A was registered to have Hypertension and was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 15 years ago. Five years ago  he had undergone a coronary artery bypass grafting due to unstable angina. A brief review of his medical records also revealed hyperlipidemia and peripheral arterial disease.  Family History: His father had a stroke in his late 60s and his mother was normotensive and died at the age of 87 following complications related to Alzheimer's disease. His elder brother had a myocardial infarct in his early 60s.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  his left lower extremity was pale  pulseless  and cold. All peripheral pulses in the affected limb were absent. A non-healing ulcer was identified on his left foot. The ankle-brachial index was measured and found to be less than 0.4  indicating severe limb ischemia.  Investigation: Blood investigations revealed a raised HbA1c level of 9% and lipid profile indicated dyslipidemia. Echocardiogram showed a well-maintained ejection fraction with no significant valvular abnormalities. A computed tomography angiogram showed multilevel arterial occlusions in the left lower extremity.  Diagnosis: Based on the medical history  physical examination  and investigative findings  Mr. A was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) of the left leg.  Discussion: Mr. A’s critical limb ischemia was likely precipitated by his uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and peripheral arterial disease. Further  his elder age  previous history of smoking  and hypertension are significant contributing factors. His diagnosis and management underline the importance of stringent control of diabetes and dyslipidemia  smoking cessation  and regular follow-up visits to possibly prevent such cardiovascular events.   Management Plan: Mr. A's management plan included immediate surgical consultation for possibility of revascularization or amputation alongside aggressive medical treatment of his risk factors. Tight glycemic control  antihypertensives  antiplatelets  statins and pain management were initiated.  The patient's further management and prognosis will largely depend on the revascularization success and response to the medical therapy in the context of his co-morbidities. Regular follow-ups for monitoring his diabetes control  cardiovascular disease progression  ulcer healing  and kidney function were scheduled. He was also referred to a dietician to manage his diets more appropriately and a podiatrist to look after his foot care and ulcer healing. Lastly  psychological support was arranged for emotional well-being and coping with the disease and its possible outcomes.

Patient Profile:  - Age: 67 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired truck driver - Locations: Lives alone in rural Illinois   Medical History:  - Diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2 twenty years ago  - Hypertension for the past 15 years  - History of hyperlipidemia  - Smoking: 35 pack-years record  trying to quit - He is on Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  Family History:  - Father deceased from myocardial infarction in his early 60s - Mother deceased from stroke in her late 70s - Two siblings alive and well. No cardiovascular disease  Presenting Complaint:  - The patient has been experiencing progressive pain in his right leg for the last six months  which has worsened in the last month. The pain increases while walking and abates at rest. - Examination revealed an absent right dorsalis pedis pulse and a markedly reduced right posterior tibial pulse. Skin changes noted on the leg and foot with nail changes also observed. - Barely healed ulcer noted on his right foot toes.  Diagnostic Investigation:  - Ankle-brachial index was conducted which revealed a low ABI ratio for the right leg (0.39) compared to the left (1.0).  - Duplex ultrasound scan of the leg arteries revealed significant stenosis in the right lower leg arteries. - He underwent angiography which confirmed multilevel occlusive disease in right lower extremity with involvement of popliteal and tibial arteries  Diagnosis:  Based on the presenting symptoms  clinical findings  and diagnostic investigations  the patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Treatment Plan:  - Started on dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin and Clopidogrel) - Urgent vascular surgery referral made for possible bypass graft or angioplasty. - Glycemic control and hypertension monitored and treated aggressively. - He was advised to quit smoking and connected to smoking cessation resources. - Regular wound care for the toe ulcer. - Regular physiotherapy for leg exercise.  This case highlights the importance of an early diagnosis of critical limb ischemia in patients presenting with classic clinical symptoms and the necessity of managing risk factors to prevent complications and disease progression.

Case Presentation:  Patient Information: A 65-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents with complaints of severe pain in his left lower extremity. Patient reports additional symptoms of intermittent claudication  particularly during exercise  with some relief upon resting and sores that won't heal on the toes of his left foot. He is a retired truck driver  physically inactive  lifelong smoker  has a high-fat diet  and is obese with body mass index of 32 kg/m2.   Family History:  There is a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases; both his father and grandfather died of a myocardial infarction. His mother had type 2 diabetes and his maternal aunt has peripheral artery disease.  History of Present Illness:  The patient's intermittent claudication has exacerbated over the last six months  now causing him significant discomfort even at rest. He also reported non-healing ulcers on his left foot which persisted for three months now  raising suspicion of critical limb ischemia. He has been on medication for diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia with medication adherence confirmed.  Physical Findings:  Examination reveals pallor and coolness of his left foot  diminished dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses  and atrophic skin changes. Moreover  painful necrotic ulcers measuring about 2x2 cm are visible on his left toes. The right foot appeared normal.  Assessment & Plan:  The severity of the patient’s symptomatology  along with the physical exam findings and risk factors  suggests a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) secondary to peripheral artery disease. Doppler ultrasound  an ankle-brachial index  CT angiography  and possibly angiography should be conducted to confirm the diagnosis  evaluate the extent of vascular occlusion and plan for the best possible treatment approach.  Given his risk factors and condition  a multidisciplinary approach to care will be appropriate. This includes cessation of smoking  dietary changes  glucose and BP control  exercise  along with pharmacotherapy for CLI. In case of non responsiveness to the conservative treatment or in severe blockage  endovascular procedures or bypass surgery may be required.   This patient's case highlights the importance of regular monitoring and timely management of chronic diseases such as diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia to prevent debilitating complications like CLI.

Patient Information:   Name: Mr. Smith  Age: 70   Gender: Male  Race: African American  Occupation: Retired school teacher  Medical History:  Mr. Smith has been suffering from uncontrolled Type II diabetes mellitus for the past twenty years. His other significant medical history involves hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are poorly controlled due to medication non-adherence. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year smoking history  who stopped smoking about ten years ago.  Family History:  His father died of a stroke at the age of 72 and his mother died of a heart attack at 76. His eldest brother suffered from peripheral arterial disease and underwent an amputation at the age of 68.  Presenting Complaint:  Complains of chronic pain in his right lower leg that has significantly exacerbated over the past month  interrupting his sleep patterns. He also reported non-healing ulcers on the right foot and decreased mobility due to pain and weakness. He explained the pain as worsening when his leg is elevated and decreasing when it remains in the dependent position.  Examination:  On examination  the right lower limb was cooler to touch as compared to left. Pedal pulses were absent in the right foot. There were two ulcers with formed eschars on the right foot- one on the dorsum and the other on the great toe.  Investigation:  An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was performed  resulting in a low ABI index (<0.4) suggestive of severe arterial disease.   Diagnosis:  Considering the history  clinical examination  and ABI results  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia was made.  Discussion:  Critical limb ischemia (CLI)  a severe form of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  causes significant morbidity and mortality. Risk factors include smoking  diabetes  obesity  high blood pressure  and family history of heart disease. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent limb loss. For Mr. Smith  it requires aggressive intervention to restore blood flow  control of modifiable risk factors  and wound care to prevent infections. Intervention might involve angioplasty  stent  or bypass surgery. Additionally  further attention to his existing diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension is needed.  Mr. Smith's case presents a challenging scenario where patient education about medication adherence and lifestyle modifications should be paired with aggressive medical and possible surgical intervention  to enhance both the quality and length of life.

Patient Information: Mr. Rodriguez  a 67-year-old Hispanic male  who resides in a semi-rural community  presented to the clinic with a history of progressive pain in his left lower extremity for the past two weeks. He is a long-term smoker with a 45-pack-year history and ongoing heavy alcohol consumption. He has a past medical history of Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  chronic kidney disease  and peripheral artery disease. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father dying of a heart attack at the age of 55.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez primarily complaints about excruciating ischaemic rest pain in the left foot  which is specially severe at night and deprives him of sleep. He also revealed experiencing pain upon walking short distances  described as intermittent claudication. Moreover  he reported the onset of non-healing ulcers on his left toes alongside color changes in his foot which shifted from pallor to cyanosis.  Clinical Findings: Examination revealed a pale left foot with cold peripheries  weak pedal pulses  and several non-healing ulcers most prominently at the tips of the left toes. There were signs of hair loss on the lower part of the foot and the skin appeared shiny. A dry gangrene was noted on the left great toe  pointing towards severe ischemia.   Investigations: Laboratory tests showed elevated glucose and HbA1c levels  confirming poorly controlled diabetes. An Ankle Brachial Index (ABI) was performed which showed a lower than normal index  indicative of blockage. A Doppler ultrasound demonstrated a significant decrease in blood flow indicating severe stenosis in the left posterior tibial and peroneal arteries.   Diagnosis: Based on the clinical findings and investigations  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) was made.  Treatment Plan: Mr. Rodriquez was educated about the severity of his condition and the necessity of immediate treatment. An urgent surgical consult for peripheral angioplasty and possible stenting or bypass graft surgery was scheduled. Conservative management was initiated alongside  including aggressive pain control  wound care for the ulcerations  strict glycemic control  and initiation of antiplatelets. Advice was given to quit smoking and limit alcohol consumption. Monthly follow-ups are planned to monitor clinical progress and assess the need for amputation if revascularization surgery isn't successful.   The prognosis of Mr. Rodriguez's condition is uncertain due to delayed presentation and has been explained to him. To ensure optimal care  the patient needs to follow a multi-disciplinary approach including a vascular surgeon  diabetologist  and wound care specialist on board.

Patient's Case History:  Patient's Profile:   - Age: 72 years old - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired Military Personnel  - Racial/Ethnic Group: Caucasian  - Marital Status: Married - Children: 3   Presenting Issue:  The patient came to our medical facility with symptoms of severe pain in his right lower limb  even at rest  coupled with non-healing wounds on the leg and foot. After thorough assessment and diagnostic tests  he was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes for the past 15 years and uncontrolled hypertension for over a decade. Furthermore  he has a history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) diagnosed three years ago. He also has dyslipidemia and was a heavy smoker  having quit about 5 years ago. He had a minor stroke 2 years ago with full recovery.  Family History:  There is a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases and diabetes; both parents suffered from coronary artery disease and diabetes mellitus. His older sibling died of a myocardial infarction.   Clinical Course:  On physical examination  the right lower extremity was found to be cold with diminished pulses and a large  necrotic wound on the foot. The patient complained of insomnia due to the severity of the resting pain. Initial diagnostic studies included Doppler ultrasound and ankle-brachial index (ABI)  which showed significant arterial blockages.  Treatment Plan:  The patient has been suggested to undergo revascularization to restore blood flow. A vascular surgeon is being consulted to determine whether angioplasty or bypass surgery is the best course of action. Meanwhile  the patient is being managed with analgesics for the pain  and aggressive wound care to prevent infection. Adequate blood glucose control and blood pressure management are also crucial in this scenario.  Discussion:  Critical Limb Ischemia is a severe form of PAD  a disease characterized by narrowing or blocking of arteries providing blood to the legs. This patient’s longstanding history of diabetes  hypertension and smoking  coupled with strong family history of cardiovascular diseases  places him at high risk for CLI and requires close monitoring and management. Prompt revascularization can help save his limb and significantly improve his quality of life. Long term management would focus on mitigating risks factors  including secondary prevention therapies. These include antiplatelet  lipid-lowering agents  medication for diabetes and hypertension  lifestyle changes such as diet modification and exercise.   Follow Up:  Follow-up appointments will be made to monitor the patient’s progression  manage pain  and coordinate wound care. It will be crucial to monitor any changes in symptoms such as increased pain  new wounds  or infection signs. Multi-disciplinary care involving cardiology  internal medicine  vascular surgery and wound care specialists will be essential in managing this patient.

Patient Profile: Patient is a 67-year-old African American male who has been admitted to the hospital for three days due to intermittent claudication.  Present Illness: Over the last six months  the patient has expressed increasing discomfort in his right lower leg while walking short distances. He indicates that rest seems to alleviate the pain  but the time to onset and severity of pain have been progressively worsening. For the past few weeks  the patient has also been dealing with non-healing sores on his right foot. In the last week  his leg started hurting even when he was at rest  particularly at night.  Past Medical History: Notable medical history includes type 2 diabetes present for 20 years and hypertension in control with medication (Amlodipine). He's also been diagnosed with stage 2 chronic kidney disease two years ago. The patient has also been a smoker for the past 35 years and consumes alcohol socially.  Physical Findings: Physical examination showed a pallor foot with no palpable pulses distal to the right popliteal artery. Right foot revealed two ulcers at the tip of the great toe and base of the first toe. Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was 0.4 in the right leg. A Doppler ultrasound showed severe stenosis in the right superficial femoral artery and tibial arteries occluded with compensatory collaterals.  Family History: The patient's father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 62  suggesting a history of cardiovascular diseases in the family. The patient’s mother has type 2 diabetes and hypertension.  Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) of the right leg based on his symptoms  ABI value  and ultrasound findings.  Management Plan: The immediate plan is to start on a regimen of analgesics to control pain and antibiotics for the foot ulcers. High-dose statin therapy is also planned for the patient in line with his diabetes management and CLI. The patient is referred to a vascular surgeon for the possibility of revascularization procedures. He was also advised to quit smoking and reduce alcohol consumption  as these lifestyle habits can further accelerate the progression of CLI. Furthermore  he was referred to a dietician and diabetic educator to help better control his blood glucose levels.  Long-term follow-up and intensive control of his diabetes and hypertension are also emphasized. It has been explained to the patient that if left untreated  CLI may progress to the point of requiring amputation of the affected limb. Regular follow-ups were scheduled to monitor the progress of his condition.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 69-year-old African-American male named John who resides in Springfield  Iowa with his wife. He is a former truck driver who retired five years ago. He is a non-smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. His known medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus which he has been managing for the past 10 years with medication though with poor glycemic control (HbA1c 9.0%); he also suffers from hypertension and hyperlipidemia. There’s no known drug allergy. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 75 and his maternal uncle had a stroke at age 70.  Presenting Complaint:  John presented at the outpatient clinic with a three-month history of progressive pain in his left leg  initially occurring during walking but now even at rest. The pain is severe enough to have disrupted his sleep for the last three weeks. He describes an intense  burning sensation below his left knee that spreads to his foot. He has also noticed a non-healing wound on his left foot.  Clinical Findings:  On clinical examination  pulses in the left lower limb were weakly felt  the foot was pale  cooler to touch compared to the right foot  and there was a decrease in hair distribution. A non-healing ulcer with necrotic tissue of about 2 cm diameter was noted on the dorsal aspect of the 1st metatarsophalangeal joint of left foot. Capillary refill time was significantly prolonged on the left foot and there was decreased sensation to pin-prick and light touch.   Diagnosis:  Given the patient's history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and the presenting complaint of rest pain coupled with characteristic clinical findings  a diagnosis of Left Lower Limb Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made.  Treatment and Progress:  An Ankle-Brachial index (ABI) was performed which was consistent with severe peripheral arterial disease. John was duly scheduled for a below-knee angiogram which later revealed severe multi-level lower extremity arterial occlusive disease thus confirming the diagnosis. He thereafter underwent successful endovascular revascularization with balloon angioplasty. He was also counseled on improved control of his diabetes and prescribed antiplatelets and statins for secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease. A wound care specialist was called for consultation to facilitate the management of his foot ulcer.  Follow-Up:  During follow-up  John reported significant improvement in his rest pain  and gradual healing of his foot ulcer was observed. He is to remain on regular follow-up every three months with repeat imaging every 6 months or sooner if his symptoms reoccur.  Conclusion:  John’s case illustrates the importance of early detection and management of CLI in a patient with multiple risk factors for atherosclerosis including diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. Prompt endovascular intervention coupled with strict control of modifiable risk factors can lead to favorable outcomes in patients with CLI.

Patient's Case Presentation  Demographic Information:   The patient is a 73-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. Johnson with a history of heavy smoking (1 pack/day for the past 50 years). He is a retired auto mechanic  lives alone in a suburban area. He is widowed with two adult daughters who live out of state.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus over the past 20 years. Unfortunately  he has been quite inconsistent in adhering to his medication regimen due to his self-professed dislike of taking pills. He underwent angioplasty five years ago due to heart disease. Mr. Johnson is overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 30. He does not regularly exercise or follow a healthy diet  further worsening his existing chronic conditions.   Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Johnson visited the hospital with complaints of severe leg pain  which had worsened over the last few weeks. The pain primarily occurs in his right leg and is exacerbated during physical activity  but is present even during rest. He has also noticed a mild-to-moderate decrease in the temperature of his right leg compared to his left leg.   Physical Examination:  On examination  the right pedal pulse was notably weak  and the skin on the right foot appeared discolored and slightly atrophic. There were no ulcerations or open wounds but dry scaling was noticed. He also reported an increase in pain when his leg was elevated at 60 degrees and a decrease in pain when his leg was lowered to a dependent position.   Family History:  Mr. Johnson's family history is significant for heart disease and diabetes. His father had a heart attack at the age of 65 and his mother died at the age of 70 due to complications related to diabetes. His elder brother has survived two heart attacks and his younger sister is also diabetic.   Diagnostic Findings:  Given his symptoms  past medical history  and physical examination findings  Mr. Johnson was suspected to have critical limb ischemia. The diagnosis of CLI was confirmed through an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test  which was abnormally low  and a Doppler ultrasound  which revealed significant blockage in the right popliteal artery.  Treatment Plan:  The multidisciplinary vascular team determined that Mr. Johnson is a suitable candidate for revascularization surgery. In addition  he is referred to a dietician and physical therapist for lifestyle modification interventions to manage his diabetes and promote weight loss. The patient is also urged to start a smoking cessation program.  Prognosis:  The prognosis will greatly depend on Mr. Johnson's commitment to treatment and lifestyle changes. Long term outlook demonstration improvements with successful revascularization  optimized diabetes control  smoking cessation  disciplined dietary habits  weight management  and improvement in overall lifestyle. Early detection and intervention are key to managing CLI  and patient education is imperative for the prevention of potential future health issues.

CASE PRESENTATION:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named John  who lives in rural Iowa with his wife. It's a farming community  and he's a retired carpenter. He was a smoker for over 40 years with a pack of day but quit three years back.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. John presents with a one-month history of persistent pain within his left leg  particularly upon walking  that's been becoming progressively worse. Recently  he also noticed a non-healing wound on the big toe of the same foot.  Past Medical History: John's past medical records reveal that he is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years ago  which is managed with oral hypoglycemic agents but ill-controlled with an HbA1C of 9.4%. He also has a history of hypertension under medication. He has suffered a transient ischemic attack (TIA) five years ago.   Family History: John's medical family history reveals both his father and grandfather died of strokes  and his mother had peripheral artery disease (PAD). His two elder siblings are living with hypertension and diabetes too.  Clinical Examination: Physical examination findings revealed weak  barely palpable pulses in the left foot. The non-healing wound on the left foot's big toe appeared pale  with a punched-out appearance and minimal exudate.   Investigations and Diagnosis: An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test was performed  with results showing an ABI value of 0.45 in the left leg  significantly lower than the normal 1.0-1.4 value  which is indicative of peripheral arterial disease. Further investigations with Doppler ultrasound confirmed significantly decreased blood flow in the left popliteal and tibial arteries. Given his consistent symptoms  medical history  and the aforementioned test findings  John was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) of the left leg.  Treatment Plan: Under the vascular surgeon's guidance  John was recommended with an angioplasty in order to restore the blood flow. He was also recommended to optimize the management of his diabetes  along with cessation of smoking and initiation of an appropriate exercise regimen. However  considering his family history and past history of TIA  he was advised to undergo regular follow ups for early identification of complications. His family was counselled about the disease  its implications and the importance of lifestyle modifications.   This case highlights the complexity of CLI as it includes factors like advanced age  ill-managed diabetes  smoking  and genetic predisposition  creating a direct impact on the choice of the treatment modality and prognosis.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is Mr. Anderson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presenting with worsening pain in his right lower extremity  especially at rest  and non-healing ulcers for the past two months. Mr. Anderson is a retired teacher  living with his wife in New York.  Past Medical History: Mr. Anderson has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  stage II hypertension  peripheral artery disease (PAD)  and hyperlipidemia. He has had a 35-year history of tobacco use  averaging one pack per day  but he has reportedly quit smoking 5 years ago. Besides  he had an ischemic stroke with near-complete recovery 6 years back.  Family History: His mother passed away in her 70s from Alzheimer's disease  and his father died at the age of 82 due to myocardial infarction. His older brother suffered a stroke in his early 70s  diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and PAD  indicating a clear family history of cardiovascular disease.  Examination & Diagnosis: On physical examination  Mr. Anderson appeared to be in moderate distress due to rest pain. His right lower extremity was evidently cooler than the left with weak pedal pulses and an ulcer over the right heel. An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test revealed an ABI value of 0.5 in the right lower extremity  confirming severe PAD. Blood investigations showed an elevated HbA1c level. Following further angiography investigations  he was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Treatment & Management: Mr. Anderson was scheduled for PTA (Percutaneous Transluminal Angioplasty)  along with lifestyle modifications. Aggressive risk factor management  such as optimal glycemic and lipid control  was initiated. Additionally  he was referred to a dietician  a diabetes management nurse  and sessions on smoking cessation. Cilostazol was started for symptomatic relief  and a statin was prescribed for his LDL cholesterol.  Discussion: Mr. Anderson’s case represents a typical late-stage presentation of PAD  that is CLI. His risk factor profile included type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  elderly age  past tobacco use  and family history  which is consistent with those of many patients with PAD and CLI. Apart from the direct management of CLI  aggressive management of these modifiable risk factors forms the crux of management and secondary prevention in such cases.

Patient Case Presentation: Critical Limic Ischemia  Patient Information:    The patient is a 67-year-old male. His past medical history reveals that he has been a heavy smoker for the past 45 years. He is also known to suffer from type 2 diabetes and hypertension for the past 10 years which was under control with medications. The patient reports adherence to prescribed medications but has not managed to quit smoking. His family history reveals that his father succumbed to a myocardial infarction at an early age of 55  his mother has hypertension  and one of his two brothers is diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD).   Chief Complaint and Symptom History:  The patient presents with complaints of severe test pain that has been escalating over the past 4 months. He also describes painful cramping in his left leg  especially while walking. Notably  relief from pain usually only occurs when at rest.
