Additionally  he observes ulceration on his left foot which hasn't been healing for the past 6 weeks.  Physical Examination:  On examination  his blood pressure was 155/85 mmHg. His body mass index (BMI) is 28 indicating that he is overweight. His left leg showed signs of skin discoloration  a non-healing ulcer on the foot  and cold to touch compared to his right leg. Furthermore  the pulses including the dorasalis pedis and the posterior tibialis were not palpable on the left leg. No such abnormal signs were observed in the right leg.  Investigation and Diagnosis:  The patient's blood sugar level was found to be 210 mg/dl  an indication that the patient's diabetes is not well-managed. Fasting lipid profile showed elevated levels of LDL cholesterol (160mg/dL). Ankle-brachial index (ABI) revealed an index of 0.4 on the left leg compared to 1.1 on the right (normal ABI > 0.9). Doppler ultrasound of the left lower limb revealed decreased blood flow indicting arterial occlusion. Further angiography revealed severe stenosis in the distal left superficial femoral artery and posterior tibial artery. Based on the symptoms  physical examination  and investigations  a diagnosis of left leg critical limb ischemia (CLI) was confirmed.   It is essential to take immediate action for the patient. CLI is a serious condition that can put the patient at risk for limb amputation and life-threatening cardiovascular events if not managed timely. The patient will need a thorough evaluation by a vascular surgeon for potential revascularization procedures and aggressive control of risk factors. Referral to a dietician and diabetes educator may be warranted to help manage diabetes and promote weight loss. Smoking cessation is also important for this patient.

Case Presentation:  Patient Information: Ms. J  a 70-year-old  African American female with a BMI of 28  presented to the clinic with an extensive one-month history of increasing pain and progressive discoloration of her left lower extremity. She disclosed that the pain often worsened during physical activity but didn’t completely abate at rest.   Clinical and Family History: Ms. J has a critical medical history comprising of poorly controlled Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. She has been a chronic smoker for about 50 years with COPD recently diagnosed. Her father had passed away due to an acute myocardial infarction in his late 60s; however  nothing consequential was recorded on her mother's side. No known allergies or drug reactions have been reported. Ms. J lives alone  and she could manage her activities of daily living unassisted. She is retired and gains support from her children for a medical visit or financial needs.  Physical Examination:  On the left leg  examination revealed areas of skin discoloration  significant skin pallor  an absence of palpable distal pulses  and decreased sensation. No similar symptoms were noted on her right leg. Blood pressure readings have consistently been elevated above the normal range.   Investigations and Diagnosis:  Initial tests included complete blood count  fasting blood sugar levels  lipid profiles  and EKG. Given the symptoms and her comprehensive history  further diagnostic procedures including an Ankle Brachial Index and Doppler ultrasound of her lower extremity arterial system were also ordered.   Her ABI test recorded readings of less than 0.4 in her left leg  while her right leg results were within the expected range. The Doppler ultrasound showed significant stenotic features in her left lower limb's arterial circulation.   Combining her critical symptoms of significant leg pain at rest  discoloration  history of smoking  poorly managed diabetes  hypertension  and the results of her diagnostic investigation  Ms. J was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) on her left leg.  Management Plan:  The treatment plan was to primarily address the pain and aim for limb salvage. Ms. J's poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension were planned to be addressed with suitable changes in her medication and lifestyle modification  with the cessation of smoking being critical. She was referred for revascularization following her consent. Conservative wound care was advised  given her age  coupled with physiotherapy initiation upon the surgeon’s consent post-revascularization. She will be advised on closer and regular follow-ups and reassessed at every visit.   The coordinator set an appointment with both the vascular surgeon and the diabetologist  and her case was discussed in a multidisciplinary team meeting to ensure a holistic approach to her management.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 72-year-old African-American male  John Smith  a retired construction worker  residing in downtown Dallas. He is known to have underlying medical conditions such as type II diabetes mellitus (duration of 18 years)  hypertension (duration of 20 years)  and peripheral artery disease in both legs (diagnosed six years ago). Both of his parents died at an early age due to cardiovascular events. He is a former smoker and consumed two packs daily for 40 years but quit about ten years ago.   Chief Complaint: The patient primarily complains of severe pain in his left foot for the past two weeks.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith has been experiencing excruciating pain in his left foot which exacerbates during the night even while at rest. He describes the pain as burning  sharp  and unrelenting. Along with the pain  he also noticed skin discoloration on his left foot – it appears dark blue  almost black. He also reported a decrease in temperature of his left foot compared to the other and an ulcer on his toe that has been persistent for a month. His right foot is mildly symptomatic  with occasional claudication after walking long distances.  Physical Examination: Upon further examination  distal pulses were absent in his left foot  including tibialis posterior and dorsalis pedis. The rest of the cardiovascular examination was normal  with no obvious signs of failure. Neurological examination revealed a decreased sensation over the left foot compared with the right.  Investigations: Doppler Ultrasound was carried out which showed significantly decreased blood flow in the left foot compared to the right. A blood sample was collected and sent for routine investigations.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical presentation and test results  the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia of the left lower limb was made.   Management: The patient was started on medications including aspirin and statins  along with optimal control of diabetes and hypertension. Consultation with the vascular surgery department was made for possible revascularization in view of the severe symptoms including rest pain and ulceration.  In conclusion  the patient's case is challenging due to the complexity of underlying peripheral artery disease and critical limb ischemia alongside poorly controlled diabetes. A holistic  team-based approach is required for optimal health outcomes. Smoking cessation education and motivational interviewing are further recommended to ensure the patient fully understands the risk factors and management plan.

Patient Presentation  I. Identifying Data   The patient is a 70-year-old African-American woman  currently residing in city X  USA. She has been retired for a decade. She is a widow and lives alone  but she has three grown-up children who live in close proximity and assist her as needed.  II. Reason for Admission   The primary reason for admission is severe  worsening pain in both legs  particularly noticeable at rest. The pain has become increasingly debilitating over the past three months  affecting her mobility and quality of life.  III. Past Medical History   She has been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2 for the past 15 years and has been on Metformin. The patient was also diagnosed with high blood pressure around ten years ago for which she takes Lisinopril. She underwent a left breast mastectomy five years ago for stage 2b breast cancer and has been in remission since completion of chemotherapy and radiation.  IV. Lifestyle and Habits   The patient is a former smoker; she quit 30 years ago. She consumes alcohol occasionally and maintains a moderately balanced diet in congruence with her diabetic condition. Her physical activity has been limited lately due to leg pain.  V. Family History   Her father died from a stroke in his late 70s and her mother had hypertension and diabetes  passing away in her mid-80s due to heart failure. Her elder brother and sister are alive and well  with her brother having type 2 diabetes as well.  VI. Examination & Investigations    The lower limbs appear discolored with reduced hair growth. The posterior tibial pulse is weak and femoral pulse is absent bilaterally. An Ankle-Brachial Index was 0.6 bilaterally. Further investigations included duplex ultrasonography showing severe bilateral stenosis in the superficial femoral and popliteal arteries.  VII. Diagnosis  Based on history and clinical findings  the patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI).  VIII. Treatment and Prognosis  The patient was referred for vascular consultation  and after the diagnosis of CLI  a revascularization procedure was advised. She will continue her current medications for diabetes and hypertension. Smoking cessation (passive too) and better glycemic control were stressed. Prognosis largely depends on her response to the revascularization therapy and how well she manages her diabetes and hypertension.

Patient Introduction: The patient is a 66-year-old African American male named Mr. John Preston. He lives alone in an urban setting  is a retired accountant  and is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history. The patient is generally independent in his activities of daily living.  Medical History: Mr. Preston has a history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease (PAD). His medications include daily metformin  atorvastatin  and lisinopril. He had two episodes of cardiac arrest  and he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) about 5 years ago. He has been exhibiting chronic symptoms of claudication  particularly in the right lower extremity  which have progressively worsened.  Family History: His mother died suddenly at the age of 70  but the cause of death is unknown. His father suffered from coronary artery disease and died at 65 due to myocardial infarction. One sibling has type 2 diabetes  while the other sibling is healthy.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Preston presented to the outpatient department with severe rest pain in his right lower limb  foot ulcers that were not healing for the past two months  and progressive weakness. The pain typically worsens when he lies down and slightly alleviates when the limb is in a dependent position. He also reported a recent weight loss and reduced appetite.   Examination and Investigations: On examination  the right lower limb was noticeably pale and cold compared to the left. Pedal pulses were impalpable on the right side. A wound on the right lateral malleolus  approximately measuring 2 cm x 2 cm  was noticed experiencing delayed healing. An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was performed  with a low score reported in the right compared to the left leg  supporting the diagnosis of PAD.   Doppler Ultrasound revealed a significant loss of blood flow in multiple arteries of the right lower extremity. His fasting glucose  HbA1c  and lipid profile confirmed poor diabetes and hyperlipidemia control.   Diagnosis: Combining his medical history  presenting complaint  physical examination  and investigation results  Mr. Preston was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) secondary to advanced peripheral artery disease  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia.   Treatment Plan: Mr. Preston's management plan involves an interdisciplinary team including a vascular surgeon  endocrinologist  dietitian  and physical therapist. His immediate referral was made to a vascular surgeon for possible angioplasty  stenting  or bypass. His diabetic medications were changed  and insulin therapy was initiated to gain better glycemic control. Changes in his diet were also recommended for better management of diabetes and hyperlipidemia. Pain management and wound care were also prioritized for symptomatic relief and prevention of potential infection.    Follow-Up: Mr. Preston needs regular follow-ups with his endocrinologist for continuous monitoring of his blood glucose levels & HbA1C and with his primary care physician to monitor his cholesterol levels & blood pressure. Physical rehabilitation was suggested to help improve his walking endurance and overall cardiovascular health.    Patient Education: Mr. Preston was educated about the importance of medication compliance  routine exercise  regular foot inspections  and frequent follow-ups for achieving better health outcomes and manage potential complications related to critical limb ischemia  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. He was also informed about the benefits of smoking cessation and maintaining a healthy lifestyle.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 67-year-old African-American male  known as Mr. Benjamin. He has been a regular patient at the clinic for the past 24 years.  Past Medical History: Mr. Benjamin has a long-standing history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he had been seeking treatment and medication. He has a 45-year history of smoking approximately one pack of cigarettes daily  but claims to have quit about five years ago. Six months ago  he was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). There is no known history of coagulation disorders.  Family History: His father passed away due to a heart attack in his late sixties. His mother passed away at 83 due to stroke. He has one brother who is healthy and no history of vascular disease in the remaining family.  Presenting Problem: Over the past few weeks  Mr. Benjamin has experienced a progressive increase in leg pain  particularly in his right calf  even at rest. Due to the severe pain  he has difficulty sleeping at night and has deteriorated quality of life. This pain also restricts his mobility significantly.  Examination and Diagnosis: On physical examination  his right foot was pale  cold to touch and there was an absence of pulses below the right knee. The Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) in his right leg was significantly reduced  pointing towards advanced limb ischemia. Additionally  Bedside Doppler also substantiated the absence of arterial blood flow.  Investigations and Findings: We followed up with a CT angiogram which showed blockages in the right lower limb arteries. He was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  with Rutherford's Clinically staged Category 4.  Management Plan: Given the severity of CLI  his elevated surgical risk due to the presence of hypertension and diabetes  we plan to initiate an aggressive medical therapy  including antiplatelets  statins  and optimization of his diabetes and hypertension control. We also plan to do an endovascular or surgical revascularization based on the heart team's decision.   Future Considerations: Options for revascularization will be decided collectively by the heart team  where the patient's anatomical  clinical  and personal preference will be considered. Given the presence of severe limb ischemia  the ultimate goal will be limb salvage and improvement in the quality of life. A critical part of therapy will be smoking cessation and initiation of a walking program post-revascularization.   Prognosis:  With aggressive management and suitable revascularization  we anticipate an improvement in Mr. Benjamin's symptoms and an increase in his overall quality of life. However  he is at considerable risk of cardiovascular events given his smoking history and comorbid conditions  and therefore  close follow-up will be necessary.

Patient's Profile: Mrs. Julia Svensson  an 85-year-old Caucasian female  has presented several times in our medical facility with the chief complaint of painful leg ulcers and intermittent claudication. She has a 45-year-old history of smoking two packs a day  a prominent risk factor for peripheral artery disease (PAD). Her files reveal a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Presenting Issue: Mrs. Svensson presented to the vascular clinic for a routine follow-up  however  over the past year  her condition has deteriorated. She complains of recurrent non-healing foot ulcers and resting pain in her right leg. She developed symptoms of critical limb ischemia  including discoloration of foot and the presence of non-healing ulcers. The pain has been known to disrupt her sleep  with it worsening at night.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed absent right pedal and posterior tibial pulses. The right leg was significantly cooler compared with the left one. She had right foot discoloration  and motor power in the right foot was 3/5. Doppler ultrasound showed severe stenosis in the right distal superficial femoral artery and occlusion of the right popliteal artery and anterior tibial artery. Laboratory tests indicated a glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) of 9.2% and LDL cholesterol of 160 mg/dL.  Diagnosis and Treatment Plan: Based on clinical findings  Doppler ultrasound results  and symptomatology  Mrs. Svensson was diagnosed with right leg critical limb ischemia caused by severe PAD. Given her age and medical condition  amputation was taken into consideration. However  knowing its life-altering effects and Mrs. Svensson's personal preference  a conservative approach was adopted. She was treated with a supervised  detailed plan for glycaemic and cholesterol control. Pain control was prioritized using analgesics  and antibiotics were administered for the ulcer. Smoking cessation was encouraged  and she was referred to a dietician to support her in managing diabetes.  Considering the severity and complexity of Mrs. Svensson's condition  a multidisciplinary team was put together. Her treatment involved optimization medication  endovascular intervention  wound care  and regular monitoring of her disease status and quality of life.  Future Recommendations: PAD and critical limb ischemia require continuous medical attention. If Mrs. Svensson does not respond to conservative management or shows signs of worsening symptoms  endovascular or surgical procedures will potentially be considered. Mrs. Svensson is advised to attend regular follow-up examinations and adhere to the treatment regimen to reduce the risk of disease progression.

Patient Presentation  Mr. X  a 68-year-old African-American male  presents with complaints of severe pain in his right lower leg that has persisted for the last three weeks. The pain is most severe when he is walking and lessens when he's at rest but never completely resolves. He also reports non-healing ulcers on his right foot that have been present for about a month. Upon inspection  his right foot appears to be pale with weak pulses in the dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial arteries.   Medical History  Mr. X has a known past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus (diagnosed 15 years ago)  hypertension (HTN)  hyperlipidemia  and coronary artery disease (CAD). He currently takes metformin  lisinopril  atorvastatin  and aspirin. He has a history of smoking for the last 20 years but quit smoking five years ago. Mr. X was compliant with his medications and was taking regular follow ups for his longstanding conditions. There are no known allergies. A history of intermittent claudication was reported a year ago.   Family History  Mr X's family history revealed that his father suffered from peripheral artery disease and his mother had a longstanding history of type II Diabetes Mellitus  while his older brother passed away due to myocardial infarction at an early age of 50 years.   Investigations and Diagnosis  Mr. X’s Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was performed and was 0.4 on the right  suggestive of severe peripheral artery disease (PAD). A Doppler ultrasound showed decreased blood flow to his right lower leg  corroborating with his ABI test results.   After correlating the patient's symptoms of constant pain in legs at rest  non-healing foot ulcers  physical examination findings of weak pulses and critical ABI scores with his medical history of diabetes  CAD and HTN  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made.   Management and Planned Follow-Up  He was started on conservative management with optimal wound care for his foot ulcers and maximum medical therapy including statins  antiplatelet and antihypertensive drugs. A Vascular Surgery consult was sought for potential revascularization  and the findings were explained to him and his family. A regular follow-up bi-monthly is planned to monitor his condition and symptoms.   This case emphasizes the importance of early detection and management in patients who are at high risk  such as those with a history of diabetes  smoking and known cardiovascular diseases  where the progression of PAD to CLI can significantly increase the risk of limb amputation and mortality.

Subject: 68-year-old Caucasian Male diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Initials: J.D.  Demographics:  J.D. is a 68-year-old Caucasian male currently residing in upstate New York. He is a retired construction worker  a former smoker who quit about ten years ago  and has a history of excessive alcohol consumption. He is unmarried and lives alone.  Past Medical History:  J.D. has a comprehensive history of Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) diagnosed at age 60. He was also diagnosed with Hypertension and Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) five years later. Other past diagnoses include mild Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) from long-term tobacco use and hyperlipidemia. He underwent a minimally invasive procedure to repair an abdominal aortic aneurysm two years ago. He is compliant with medication - hypertension (Atenolol)  diabetes (Metformin  Sitagliptin)  and hyperlipidemia (Atorvastatin).  Family History:  His father had died from myocardial infarction at 56  and his mother was diagnosed with T2DM  whereas his elder brother and sister are both hypertensive. No known family history of any malignancies or genetic disorders.  Presenting Issues:  J.D. visited the hospital complaining of severe pain in his right lower limb  particularly while resting  and some intermittent claudication for the past three months. He also showed signs of Ischemic ulcers and noted an unintentional weight loss (6 kg in 3 months). On examination  his right foot was pallid  cold to touch  and there were signs of gangrene in the toes. His brachial BP was 140/90 mm Hg  and his right ankle pressure was non-recordable. Arterial Doppler ultrasound of the right lower limb indicated no flow below the knee.  Impression:  Upon inspection and taking into consideration his past and current medical history  J.D. was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia  stage III Rutherford category based on clinical presentations.  Plan:  The patient requires further investigations including CTA/MRA to visualize the runoff vessels. Following this  he will likely be considered for revascularization procedures either via angioplasty or bypass surgery taking into consideration his comorbid conditions. Plastic surgery consultation may be necessary for wound debridement. A dedicated care plan including personalized diabetic  blood pressure  and cholesterol management  along with a smoking cessation program has been recommended. Moreover  the possibility of a need for amputation  if revascularization fails or is not feasible  was discussed.    Mental Health Considerations:  It will be vital for the healthcare providers to monitor J.D.'s mental health condition  given the potential psychological impact of his diagnosis and subsequent treatments. A referral for psychological counselling may be necessary.  Notes:   This case requires careful follow-up due to the presence of several risk factors for accelerated atherosclerosis  such as diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. Early detection and management of any similar cases in the family can help reduce further health complications.

Patient Information:  Mr. W.J.  a 76-year-old African-American male  retired mechanic who resides in a suburban area. He is a widower and lives with his older daughter. His primary language is English and he is under Medicare for his health coverage.  Presenting Problem: Mr. W.J. presented to the clinic with complaints of unrelenting pain in his left lower leg  especially at night. He mentioned that this has disrupted his sleep. He also reported the presence of a non-healing wound on his left foot for the past several weeks. He has not been able to walk more than a few steps without discomfort  resorting to using a wheelchair for movement.  Medical History:  He has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes for 15 years and hypertension for 10 years. He was a pack-a-day smoker but quit 5 years ago. His medical records show that his diabetes and hypertension control have been suboptimal in the past  but he has been compliant with his medications in recent years.  Family History: His father had coronary artery disease and passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 82. His mother passed away from ovarian cancer at the age of 75. He has a younger brother (73 years old) who has diabetes and hypertension.  Diagnostic Assessment: Upon clinical examination  there were weak peripheral pulses in the left foot and a small ulcer (2cm in diameter) on the left big toe. There was no palpable pulse in the left foot  suggesting critical limb ischemia. Ankle-Brachial index was 0.4 in the left lower limb. Confirmation of critical limb ischemia was achieved by imaging studies (CT angiography revealed severe peripheral arterial disease).  Management: The patient was immediately referred to a vascular specialist for further assessment and management. The plan involved initiating an intensive regimen of glycemic control  strict blood pressure control  lifestyle modifications  statins  and antiplatelet therapy. The potential for revascularization was also discussed.  Education: Patient was educated about the importance of diabetic and hypertension control  regular foot self-inspection  and lifestyle modifications such as diet and exercise.  Follow-up Plan: Regular follow-ups at the clinic were scheduled to monitor his progress  ulcer healing  and control of his diabetes and hypertension.  Overall  this situation underscores the importance of aggressive management of diabetes and hypertension  the role of smoking as a risk factor  and the potential complications of poorly managed diabetes. Early diagnosis and management of critical limb ischemia are critical for preventing amputation and improving quality of life.  (Kindly note that this particular case presentation is fictional and created for the purpose of providing an example. It may not fully incorporate all the elements or complexities of a real-life medical case.)

Patient Presentation:  Demographics:   Mr. R  is an 85-year-old Caucasian male from California  retired civil engineer  living alone since the passing of his wife two years ago. He has two adult children living in different states who visit him quarterly. Mr. R is a former smoker and quit smoking approximately 20 years ago  but he continues to have moderate alcohol consumption.   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. R was initially presented to the hospital with severe pain in his right lower extremity  especially during activity (claudication)  which gradually advanced over six months to rest pain. He complained of changing skin color to pale and coolness of the foot. He also reported ulcers on his toes that aren't healing.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. R has a significant past medical history  including type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 15 years ago  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and coronary artery disease  for which he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery seven years back.  Current Medications:  He is currently on Metformin  Lisinopril  Simvastatin  and Aspirin.  Family History:   His father had coronary artery disease and died in his late 70s from a myocardial infarction. His mother had diabetes and hypertension; she lived into her 90s. One of his two siblings had a stroke in her early 80s.  Physical Examination:  On examination  his right foot was pale  colder in comparison to the other. There were non-healing ulcers on his distal toes. Distal pulses (posterior tibial artery and dorsalis pedis) were feeble.  Pertinent Lab and Radiological findings:  Laboratory results showed elevated blood glucose and lipid profile. His ABI (Ankle brachial index) was low at 0.5  suggestive of significant peripheral arterial disease. A Doppler ultrasound revealed multilevel peripheral arterial disease with right femoropopliteal and infrapopliteal arterial occlusions.   Diagnosis and Future Planning:  The clinical presentation and the investigations confirmed the diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia of the right lower limb. Mr. R was started on pain relievers and anticoagulants initially. He is being evaluated for possible angioplasty  stenting or bypass graft surgery based on his comorbid state  the severity of his illness  and life expectancy. His diabetes and hyperlipidemia will need better control. Discussions about the lifestyle changes  including diet and exercising  have been introduced.  This case highlights the necessity of early diagnosis and intervention in patients with critical limb ischemia  especially in those with multiple high-risk factors such as diabetes  smoking history  and family history of vascular disease. It also underscores the importance of lifestyle modifications and strict control of comorbidities to prevent or slow down the progress of the disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. X is a 65-year-old African-American male who was admitted to our hospital complaining of severe pain and swelling in his right lower leg. He described the pain as persistent and said it seemed to worsen when he attempted to walk. The patient disclosed that he has been a chronic smoker for over 40 years.   Past Medical History:  Mr. X was diagnosed with diabetes and high blood pressure 10 years ago  which he manages through diet  exercise  and medication. He had a partial colectomy for colorectal cancer three years ago  and has since been in remission. He also suffers from occasional episodes of atrial fibrillation for which he is taking Warfarin.  Demographics:  The patient is retired and resides with his wife in the countryside. He used to be a factory worker  is a non-drinker but continues to smoke despite numerous attempts to quit.  Family History:  Mr. X’s family history reveals that his father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and his mother had a long-standing history of diabetes mellitus. One of his brothers has hypertension and the other has a history of intermittent claudication.  Current Presentation:  Upon physical examination  the patient's BP was 145/90 mmHg  pulse 76 bpm  afebrile  respiratory rate of 18 bpm and oxygen saturation levels were 97% on ambient air. Examination of his legs has shown changes consistent with severe peripheral arterial disease (PAD)  which include lower skin temperature in his right leg  a weak right leg pulse  and absent pulses in the right foot. His right foot also showed signs of trophic changes with non-healing ulcers on the tips of his toes.  Investigation & Diagnosis:  The patient's ankle-brachial index (ABI) was alarmingly low suggesting PAD. A peripheral angiography confirmed severe blockages in the right lower leg and foot arteries. The findings are suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  The patient was duly informed of his diagnosis and discussed options for revascularization. Recommendation for an immediate surgical intervention was given considering the extent of arterial blockage.  This case underscores the fact that early identification and optimal management of risk factors can prevent or delay the onset of complications like CLI. It also highlights the importance of soliciting a thorough patient and family history and using it to guide more personalized preventative strategies.  Management and Follow-up:  A multidisciplinary management approach has been adopted involving vascular surgeons  endocrinologists  and nursing staff trained in wound care.  (In real life  please remember to always respect the privacy and confidentiality of your patients.)

Patient Presentation  Introduction: Mr. Smith is an 81-year-old Caucasian male patient diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). He was referred to our facility after presenting with extensive pain in his left lower extremity that increases with activity and drastically limits his mobility.  Demographics: He lives with his 83-year-old wife in a single-story house in a suburban community. He is a retired engineer and has three adult children who live locally. He quit smoking 20 years ago but had a 35-year history of smoking prior (1.5 packs a day). He rarely drinks alcohol  usually only on special occasions.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has previously been diagnosed with hypertension (for which he has long been controlled on a beta-blocker) and peripheral vascular disease  diagnosed five years ago. He has a history of hyperlipidemia  which is managed by a statin. He has not been diagnosed or treated for diabetes. He underwent coronary bypass surgery around ten years ago and has been maintaining well since.  Family History: His mother died at 70 years due to a stroke  and his father died at 75 years due to heart disease. His older brother was diagnosed with lung cancer at 67 years and passed away a year later.  Presenting complaints and Associated Symptoms: The patient reports suffering from rest pain for approximately six months  where the pain intensified in the past week. The pain  located chiefly in his left foot  has transitioned from initially only being present during exercise to being noticeable even at rest. The pain is severe enough to disturb his sleep. He has also noticed that his foot appears more pale than usual and feels cooler to touch.  Physical Examination: On examination  his left foot was indeed paler than the right and was cool to touch. His distal pulses were not palpable  and there was reduced hair on his left leg. There were no apparent lesions or ulcers noted.  Conclusion: The features suggest an exacerbation of his critical limb ischemia. This is concerning and needs immediate evaluation and intervention to reduce his pain and to prevent further complications such as ulcers or even gangrene. His exacerbating limb ischemia puts him at high risk for major amputation or death if it's not managed appropriately.  Management Plan: Urgent vascular consultation has been sought for potential revascularization procedures. He was started on dual antiplatelet therapy and high dose statins to reduce the risk of plaque rupture and subsequent thrombosis.  This case presents important education points regarding the risk factors  presentation  and management of critical limb ischemia. Particularly in patients with peripheral vascular disease  it highlights the importance of early recognition of symptoms and seeking immediate medical attention.

Patient Information: Mr. John  a 68-year-old African American male  presented with a month-long history of severe pain in his left leg that has grown steadily worse over a week. Originally from Raleigh  North Carolina  he is a widower  retired mechanic and father to three adult children. His past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes  which has been fairly well-controlled with medication despite occasional neglect  and a 40-pack year smoking history.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. John reported intermittent claudication initially  followed by a progressive escalation in pain in his leg  particularly when at rest. Examination showed his left foot to appear pale with reduced skin temperature compared with the contralateral limb  absent distal pulses  and non-healing ulcers on his toes - pointing towards Critical Limb Ischemia.  Past Medical History: His notable medical history involves obesity (BMI: 31.2)  a 10-year history of Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus  and hypertension diagnosed seven years ago. He was prescribed Metformin and Lisinopril  but his compliance had been inconsistent at best.  Family History: Mr. John’s family history includes his father passed away from stroke at age 73 and a younger brother diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease in his 50s. No known history of similar presentation in other family members.   Life Style and Social History: John is a widower; his wife died 10 years ago due to breast cancer. He lives alone but is visited regularly by his children. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking cigarettes and admits to continued tobacco use.  Clinical Findings: On examination  distal pulses (dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial) in his left foot are absent  and signs of necrosis are present in his big toe. An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test was done which displayed a value of 0.3 in left leg (lower than normal). These signs pointed at the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia.   Investigations: His investigations revealed glucose levels and HbA1c indicating poorly controlled diabetes. His lipid profile was abnormal with high LDL-cholesterol and triglycerides and low HDL-cholesterol. Doppler ultrasound showed decreased blood flow in the left popliteal artery and in the vessels of the lower leg  indicating severe peripheral artery disease.  Treatment and Prognosis: He was admitted to the vascular surgical team promptly. An extensive discussion was held regarding potential treatment options  including angioplasty  bypass surgery  or potentially amputation  if limb salvage is not feasible. His condition is severe and will necessitate immediate intervention to prevent limb loss. To help prevent future health issues  Mr. John has been advised to quit smoking  follow a holistic diabetes management plan  and consider initiation of statin and antiplatelet therapy post-surgery.  This case of Mr. John reflects the importance of maintaining meticulous glucose control and smoking cessation in preventing the development and progression of complications related to diabetes and peripheral artery disease. It also underlines the urgency and complexity of managing critical limb ischemia.

Patient Information:   Mr. A is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who was referred to the Vascular Surgery department due to concerns around Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). The patient lives with his wife and has two adult children. He is retired from a lifelong career in construction. Mr. A is a smoker with a 50 pack-year history  drinks alcohol sporadically  and denies illicit drug use.  Presenting Problem:  Mr. A has been experiencing progressive  severe pain in his right lower extremity  particularly in the calf and foot. The pain persists at rest and has interrupted his sleep pattern for the past month. On presentation  he displayed signs of tissue loss on his toes  suspected to result from ischemia.   Past Medical History:   Mr. A has an established history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which have been managed with medication for the last ten years. He was diagnosed as prediabetic two years ago and has demonstrated a lack of compliance with the prescribed dietary regulations. In addition  he suffers from mild osteoarthritis but is otherwise generally fit.  Family History:   His father passed away from myocardial infarction at the age of 58  and his mother had peripheral artery disease and passed away at 76 due to stroke-related complications. His older brother was recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease.   Clinical Examination and Investigations:   An Ankle-brachial Index (ABI) was performed which showed an index of 0.4 on the right side which correlates with severe arterial disease. A Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) revealed significant stenosis of the right superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery  with multiple occlusions of the tibial and peroneal arteries  consistent with CLI.  Diagnosis:  Based on clinical presentation and investigation findings  Mr. A was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Plan/Management:  The team plan involves primarily managing Mr. A's risk factors that contribute to his CLI. He has been recommended to cease smoking and to undergo dietary changes. A referral to a dietitian has been made in order to properly manage his prediabetes. The patient will likely need an angioplasty or a more extensive revascularization procedure depending on the findings during angiography. Wound care for his toes will be conducted and monitored closely. Collaboration from the Cardiology department may also be necessary due to the family history of cardiac disease and the correlation between peripheral artery disease and cardiovascular disease.

Patient Information: Ms. X.M.  a 75-year-old Caucasian female  presents with complaints of rest pain and ischemic ulcerations on her left lower extremity. Her past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack year smoking history which she quit 5 years ago. She's a retired school teacher living alone  with two adult sons living in nearby cities. Her family history is significant for peripheral artery disease (PAD) in her father who underwent revascularization in his late 60s.  History of Present Illness: Ms. M. reports experiencing increased discomfort in her left leg over the past few months  escalating to more severe pain in the last 4 weeks  particularly at night. In addition to this  she also has wound development on her toes and heel that is non-healing and has worsened in the last 2 weeks. Ms. M. admits to delaying her visit to the hospital due to concerns related to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.  Physical Exam: On physical examination  Ms. M.'s left foot is found to be pale with noticeable temperature drop. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses on her left foot are not palpable. There are three ulcers on her left foot  two on her toes and one on her heel. Distal sensation and motor function intact.   Investigations: Laboratory investigations reveal HbA1c of 7.8%  blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg  and lipid panel indicates elevated LDL (143 mg/dL). Ankle-brachial index (ABI) demonstrates significantly reduced ABI of 0.40 on the left side while a Doppler ultrasound confirms the presence of multilevel stenosis and occlusion in the left leg.   Diagnosis: She was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI)  stage 4  of her left lower extremity  secondary to peripheral artery disease.  Treatment: The patient is being considered for revascularization therapy after multidisciplinary consultation due to her severe rest pain and limb threatening ischemia. The risks have been discussed in terms of benefits vs harm. She will also be managed by the diabetes control team  advised on dietary assessment  and a supervised exercise programme.  Follow-up: Weekly monitoring of the healing process of the ulcers and to assess the effect of measures taken. Further investigations or referrals will be decided based on the progress.  Prognosis: Her prognosis depends on several factors  including her response to the revascularization therapy  wound healing  diabetes control  and potential for lifestyle modifications.   Psychosocial Aspects: She seems anxious about her condition  especially the potential need for amputation. Stressing the importance of regular follow-ups  and clarifying doubts about the nature of her disease and the importance of lifestyle modifications (diet  exercise) in managing her condition might help alleviate her fears. Seeking support from a mental health professional or case manager might be beneficial.

Patient Background: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who lives in a suburban area. He is a retired high school teacher and has a history of smoking for almost 30 years  although he quit about five years ago. He has presented with pain in his lower extremities.  Past Medical History: Important highlights from the patient’s past medical history include hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. The patient underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) operation about ten years ago and has been managing his diabetes for fifteen years. He has been adhering to his prescribed medications  including metformin  lisinopril  and rosuvastatin. He tested negative for peripheral neuropathy.  Current Issue: The patient has been experiencing severe pain in his right foot for the past few weeks  exacerbated when he walks even short distances or climbs stairs. Apart from the pain  he has also noticed a gradual discoloration of his foot  appearing slightly blue.   Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 76. His mother has a history of type 2 diabetes and is currently alive and well at age 85. His younger brother  aged 66  was recently diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease.  Examinations: Upon physical examination  both feet were cool to the touch. Pulse in the right foot was significantly attenuated compared to the left. No ulcerations were observed but there was an evident discoloration. Blood tests showed controlled glucose levels with an HbA1c of 7.2%  but his cholesterol was slightly out of range.   Diagnosis and Discussion: Based on his history  symptoms  and physical examination  he was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI)  a severe form of peripheral arterial disease. Considering his previous smoking history  hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia  his risk for developing CLI is considerably high.   Plan of Treatment: The multidisciplinary approach would include endovascular or surgical revascularization based on the patient's angiogram report. Aggressive control of hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and diabetes were suggested  with consultation from an endocrinologist and cardiologist. A cessation of his prior smoking habit was commended. Due to his symptoms and arterial Doppler results  the vascular surgery team has been consulted for potential intervention. The patient was informed with his family about the disease process  importance of medication  and lifestyle modifications needed to manage his health condition effectively.   This case of CLI highlights the importance of early detection and comprehensive management of risk factors in patients with a history of cardiovascular disease and diabetes.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: Mr. Robert Smith  72-year-old Caucasian male. An ex-smoker for the past ten years  with a 30 pack-year history. Resides in a suburban environment with his wife. Works as a retired engineer.  Past Medical History (PMH): History of poorly managed type 2 diabetes mellitus for 20 years  peripheral artery disease (PAD) secondary to atherosclerosis for five years  hypertension for ten years  and dyslipidemia for eight years. History of smoking is approximately 30 pack-years. No history of alcohol or drug abuse.  Medications: Regular medications include metformin 500mg mornings and evenings for diabetes  valsartan 80mg in mornings for hypertension  and atorvastatin 40mg in evenings for high cholesterol.  Family History (FH): His father had myocardial infarction (heart attack) and died at 74. Mother  who lived to 84  had a cerebral stroke. He has one brother  aged 70  who has had coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) secondary to ischemic heart disease.   Social History (SH): Married with two grown-up children  both in good health. The patient is a retired engineer  now living a sedentary lifestyle. He does not drink alcohol and relinquished smoking ten years ago.  Presenting complaints: The patient reported severe pain in his left lower extremity  worsening with walking but also present at rest  especially at night. An evaluation conducted seven days ago indicated lesions  non-healing wounds on two toes of his left foot.   Physical Examination (PE): Pale  cold left foot with a weak or even absent pulse  no edema. Ulcers on the tips of his big and second toe. No sensory impairment found.  Investigations: EDGE Doppler ultrasound of the left lower extremity confirmed severe blockages in the arteries that supply blood to the foot and toes. HbA1c is 8%  indicating suboptimal glucose control. Serum lipid profile shows elevation in LDL cholesterol.  Diagnosis: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI)  characterized by chronic ischemic rest pain  ulcers  or gangrene attributable to objectively proven arterial occlusive disease.  Treatment: Revascularization was decided. The patient will undergo angiography and subsequently angioplasty  with stent placement if necessary. He was also prescribed insulin for glycemic control  wound care  antibiotic therapy  and lifestyle changes to control risk factors.  Prognosis: As per the current scenario  the prognosis for Mr. Smith is concerning. If left untreated  CLI can result in limb amputation. However  if revascularization is successful  along with optimized medical therapy and pertinent lifestyle changes  prognosis can be significantly improved.   Overall  the case presentation of this gentleman emphasizes the complexities of managing chronic diseases like diabetes and hypertension that  when poorly controlled  can lead to serious implications like CLI. It also signals the importance of generalized atherosclerosis control and early detection of PAD.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. K. is a 67-year-old African American male who presented with a three-week history of worsening pain and discoloration in his right leg. He has been a heavy smoker with a 50-pack-year history. He has a medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  poorly managed Type-2 Diabetes  and Dyslipidemia. He has previously had two myocardial infarctions  resulting in the placement of three stents.   Demographics:  Mr. K. is a retired construction worker; married with two grown children. He resides in a suburban area. He continues to smoke despite several attempts at quitting and has a history of heavy alcohol consumption up until ten years ago. Mr. K. lives with his wife  who has been concerned about his worsening condition.  Past Medical History:  Mr. K. has a history of cardiovascular disease with two MI incidents in the last ten years  episodes of angina pectoris  and a documented poor lipid profile. He has had hypertension for the past 20 years  and uncontrolled Type-2 diabetes for 15 years  with occasional episodes of hyperglycemia. There are no known drug allergies. His regular medications are metformin  lisinopril  metoprolol  and atorvastatin.  Family Medical History:  Mr. K.'s father died from an MI at 60  and his mother had a stroke at 69. One of his two siblings  a younger brother  has Type-2 diabetes and hypertension  whereas his sister is relatively healthy.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  Mr. K.'s right foot was cold to touch  with absent dorsal pedal and posterior tibial pulses. The foot showed signs of mottling and necrotic tissue at the heel  indicating critical limb ischemia. Symptoms include severe pain and numbness in the foot  even while resting. The left foot appears normal with palpable pulses and no significant findings.   His laboratory tests revealed uncontrolled blood glucose levels and abnormal lipid profile. His Ankle-brachial index (ABI) was extremely low at 0.3 (Normal ABI is 1.0-1.4).   Clinical Course and Discussion:  Given the patient's heavy smoking history  uncontrolled diabetes  and overall cardiovascular history  he has a significant risk of peripheral artery disease (PAD) and critical limb ischemia. The clinical findings support the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia in the patient's right foot and lower leg. Mr. K. requires immediate treatment  encompassing revascularization procedure  wound care  and aggressive risk factor modification  including smoking cessation and strict diabetes control. The case illustrates the influence of poor lifestyle choices and uncontrolled diabetes on the development and progression of peripheral arterial disease and critical limb ischemia.

Patient Profile:  We present the case of Mrs. Alice (anonymized for protecting patient confidentiality)  a 70-year-old Caucasian female with a documented history of uncontrolled Type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension and peripheral artery disease. Alice is a retired school teacher  a widower  living alone in her home in Seattle  Washington. She has quit smoking since 3 years but consumed 1 pack per day for 30 years. She comes into our consultation experiencing consistent and severe discomfort in her left lower extremity  characterized by rest pain  non-healing ulcers  and a notable absence of a pulse in the leg.  Medical History:  She has been managing her diabetes under an endocrinologist for the past 20 years  with her most recent HbA1c being 9.0  indicating poor glycemic control. She also has a 10-year history of hypertension. She was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) two years back. She also underwent angioplasty on her left lower limb a year ago due to significant arterial blockage.  Family History:  Alice’s family history reveals both her parents had Type 2 diabetes and hypertension. Her father also had ischemic heart disease.  Presenting Symptoms:  Alice presented with severe pain in her left lower limb  particularly during the nighttime  interrupting her sleep. Physical examination revealed non-healing ulcers on her left foot and an absence of a palpable pulse in the lower extremity. She also reported difficulty in walking and an increased dependence on her children for daily activities.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  Lab results revealed elevated triglyceride levels  LDL cholesterol  and diminished HDL cholesterol  consistent with her past medical history of dyslipidemia. An Ankle-Brachial Index registered a value of less than 0.4 in her left lower limb. She was referred for an arteriogram which revealed severe disease with multiple occlusions in the left lower limb. A toe-brachial pressure index was also completed with a value less than 0.1.  All clinical findings  lab tests  and Alice's extensive history of peripheral artery disease  we diagnosed her with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe obstruction of the arteries which significantly reduces blood flow to the lower extremities.  Treatment and Management Plan:  She was immediately prescribed antiplatelet therapy and statins  along with the strict reinforcement of her antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. She was referred to vascular surgery for a possible revascularization procedure considering the severity of her condition. She is currently awaiting her procedure.  Prognosis:  The prognosis for Alice’s condition largely depends on her upcoming surgical intervention and how well her diabetes and hypertension will be controlled. It is essential for her to emphasize diet  exercise  and strict medication compliance moving forward.

Patient Details:   Mr. Robert Anderson  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the clinic with an eight-month history of non-healing ulcers on his right foot. He resides in Naperville  Illinois  and is a retired machine operator. He has been a smoker for more than 40 years  consuming nearly a pack a day. Alcohol consumption averages to two to three units per week. He lives with his wife and is independent with his daily living activities.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Anderson has a history of Type 2 diabetes diagnosed 15 years ago  for which he takes metformin. His diabetes has been reasonably controlled with an HbA1c usually in the range of 7-8%. He also suffers from hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  has had a previous myocardial infarction ten years ago  and underwent angioplasty. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin.  Family History:   His father and an older brother passed away due to myocardial infarction in their early 60s. His mother died at 71 due to stroke. There is a history of early vascular disease in the family  but no known hereditary conditions.   Presenting Illness:  Over the past six months  he has noticed progressive pain in his right foot and leg  which worsens with activity and slightly eases during rest. He has also mentioned occasional nocturnal pain over the past month. On inquiry  he admits to claudication after walking approximately two blocks.   On examination  his right foot was pale and cold  and distal pulses were absent. He also had a non-healing ulcer on his right big toe and heel  with no evidence of infection. His left foot showed no such changes. His ankle-brachial index was 0.3 on the right and 0.9 on the left.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  A Doppler ultrasound suggested multilevel severe stenosis of the right peripheral arteries with minimal flow. Also  angiogram revealed significant right iliac artery stenosis with below-the-knee arteries being diseased and non-dilated.  Based on the clinical presentation and investigation results  a diagnosis of right lower limb Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) secondary to peripheral artery disease was concluded.  Patient Management:  Mr. Anderson was immediately started on a low dose aspirin and clopidogrel. He was also advised to quit smoking and was provided with further diabetic and cholesterol control under the guidance of physicians. The aim now is to revascularize  if possible  prevent amputation  and provide symptomatic relief.  A multi-disciplinary approach was advised  involving Vascular Surgery  Podiatry  Endocrinology  Cardiology  Dietetics  and Physiotherapy departments. A detailed discussion about various interventions  including potential bypass surgery or angioplasty  wound care  lifestyle modifications  has been initiated with Mr. Anderson and his family  keeping them informed and involved in the decision-making process.  This case emphasizes the sinister continuous risk of smoking and the importance of managing chronic conditions like diabetes meticulously to prevent such catastrophic complications. There is an ongoing focus on both the medical and psychosocial management of Mr. Anderson's condition to improve the chances of successful rehabilitation and the overall quality of life.

Case Presentation:  Demographics:  Mr. X is a 72-year-old African American male  a retired mechanic  living with his wife and two adult children.   Presenting Complaint: He presented at the clinic with severe pain in his right lower leg  which is worse while walking and improves with rest  and gangrenous changes around his toes.   Past Medical History:  The patient reports a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  for which he takes Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively. He was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 5 years ago. The patient admits to a 40-year history of smoking (2 packs/day) but quit 10 years ago. He was previously treated for Bell's Palsy. Additionally  he had gallbladder surgery in his 50s.   Family History:  His father died from myocardial infarction in his 60s and his mother suffered from Alzheimer’s disease. The patient's older brother has a history of peripheral artery disease (PAD) and underwent revascularization a decade ago. He has two sisters who are both hypertensive and diabetic.  Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Physical Exam: He is alert and oriented. He was afebrile with stable vitals. His Body Mass Index (BMI) was 31.1 - considered obese. Cardiovascular examination showed regular heart sounds with no murmurs  gallops  or rubs. Pulmonary examination was clear to auscultation bilaterally. There were significant findings on the lower extremities examination  including a noticeable pallor on elevation  cyanosis on dependency  evidence of gangrene in the right toe  lower pedal pulse  and non-healing ulcers on the toe.  Investigations:  Laboratory results showed an HbA1c of 9%. Lipid profile showed LDL of 160mg/dl  HDL 30mg/dl  and cholesterol of 220mg/dl. Ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) was 0.3. Doppler ultrasound showed significant stenosis in the right popliteal artery and distal vessels. Angiography further confirmed the severe blockages in distal right lower limb arteries.  Diagnosis: Taking into consideration the clinical findings  investigations  and patient’s history - diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia was made.  Plan: The patient was counselled about the severity of his condition  the importance of glycemic control  the need for a healthy diet  and exercise to manage his dyslipidemia and obesity. Considering the patient’s presentation and severity of disease  a vascular surgery consult was sought to discuss the possibility of revascularization or amputation. The patient's medical therapy was adjusted to include statin and antiplatelet drugs for better secondary prevention of atherosclerotic diseases. Follow-up was scheduled to assess patient's progress and determine the surgical approach.

Patient Presentation  Mr. A is a 74-year-old African American male who attended the clinic with chief complaints of severe and recurrent pain in his right lower limb  particularly when walking and during rest. The pain had progressively intensified over the past three months  hampering his mobility and quality of life.   Past Medical History  He has a clinical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes Metformin 500mg twice daily. Also  he has a ten-year history of hypertension controlled with Amlodipine 5mg once daily. Additionally  he was diagnosed with coronary artery disease three years back and underwent angioplasty with stent placement in LAD. He has a known case of Hyperlipidemia which is currently being managed with Atorvastatin 40mg. He also mentioned having chronic kidney disease stage II diagnosed five years ago. Mr. A has a 50-pack-year smoking history  although he quit ten years ago. He denies any history of illicit drug use or heavy alcohol consumption.  Family History  The patient's family history is significant. His father died from a stroke at the age of 78  and his mother died from renal failure at the age of 72. His elder sister is living with hypertension and diabetes and a younger brother passed away due to myocardial infarction at age 66.  Social History  The patient is a retired truck driver. He lives in a senior community center along with his wife who manages all his medications and routine activities. He has three daughters who visit regularly.   Physical Examination  On examination  the right limb was notably cooler with reduced pulses. A small  non-healing ulcer was observed on the right foot's big toe. There were no signs of a gangrenous patch. Motor strength was relatively preserved  but sensation was notably decreased. His BMI put him in the overweight category.  Investigations  His blood workup showed sub-optimally controlled sugar levels (HbA1c 8.1%)  elevated serum creatinine levels  and marginally high total cholesterol levels. An Ankle Brachial Index (ABI) was found to be significantly low (0.4). A Doppler ultrasound showed significant atherosclerotic plaque  leading to narrowed blood vessels in the right lower limb.  Diagnosis  With the constellation of clinical findings and the observed Doppler ultrasound report  Mr. A was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) of the right lower limb.  Treatment Plan  The current plan is for the patient to undergo lower limb angiography and possible revascularization. The patient will receive optimal medication for secondary prevention of atherosclerosis including antiplatelets and statins. Optimization of the control of sugar levels and blood pressure will also be enlisted in his management plan. He will be referred to a Diabetes educator and a nutritionist for comprehensive lifestyle modification.

Patient Background:   The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male named Mr. J. Lives on his own in the suburbs with his wife and is a retired construction worker. He is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. However  he has a history of type 2 diabetes  which is poorly controlled. He was diagnosed with hypertension at 45 years and was on medication for the same. He also has hyperlipidemia.   Past Medical History:   He has been suffering from continual foot pain with intermittent claudication for the past year. This has limited his ability to walk especially at night. Exam shows dry  cool skin  loss of hair on the legs  cyanotic nail beds  and thickened toenails. No previous history of cardiovascular disease  stroke  or kidney disease was noted. His BMI is 25.5  indicating that he's slightly overweight.  Treatment History:  For the diabetes  he has been taking Metformin 500mg twice daily and Insulin 10 units subcutaneously every night; his last HbA1c check suggests suboptimal control. For hypertension  he is on Losartan 50mg daily.  Family History:   His father died at the age of 78 from coronary artery disease and also had type 2 diabetes. His mother has hypertension and is alive at the age of 84. He has one younger brother who is a diagnosed hypertensive patient but no known diabetes or cardiovascular disease.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. J visited the hospital complaining of increasing numbness and coldness in his left leg with intense rest pain. There is no history of trauma. He also mentions non-healing sores on his legs and feet.   Examination:  On physical examination  there was a significant decrease in left lower limb pulses with delayed capillary refill time and cold to touch. The foot showed non-healing ulcers  which are painful upon palpation. Pulses in his right leg were palpable but diminished in the left. There was no obvious edema.   Diagnostic Tests:  An angiogram revealed severe peripheral artery disease with damage to the blood vessels in the left lower limb  indicating critical limb Ischemia. His lab reports showed a HbA1c of 9.2%  LDL cholesterol of 160 mg/dL  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  and a severely reduced Ankle-Brachial Index.  Treatment Plan:  Mr. J was admitted for the further management of critical limb ischemia to avoid limb loss. The treatment goals are to manage symptoms  improve function and quality of life  and avoid limb amputation. Treatment includes a combination of medical management  minimally invasive endovascular treatments  and surgical revascularization.   In his case  better diabetes control  lipid management  antihypertensive medication  and an antiplatelet agent was started. The wound care team would manage the ulcer after revascularization. The patient will also engage with a specialized team including vascular surgeons  endocrinologists  and dietitians for comprehensive care.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Xavier  an African-American  76-year-old male presented to the clinic with complaints of severe pain in his left lower extremity even while at rest  especially at night. He mentions that pain is exacerbated upon elevation of the limb and relieved somewhat by hanging his leg off the side of the bed. He also reported difficulties in walking due to the pain which has been progressively worsening over the past few weeks. In addition  he reported a non-healing wound on his left foot.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a notable history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes mellitus for 20 years  poorly controlled due to non-compliance. He also reported a history of cigarette smoking for the past 50 years (20 pack-years). He underwent a right carotid endarterectomy 5 years ago due to carotid artery stenosis.  Family History:  His father passed away due to myocardial infarction. His mother had a history of Type II Diabetes and passed away due to complications of the disease. His younger brother has also been diagnosed with Diabetes and hypertension.  Assessment:  On physical examination  there was significant hair loss on his left lower extremity and the skin temperature was cold to touch. The left foot had an ulcer with necrotic tissue. Distal pulses including dorsalis pedis and posterior tibialis were absent bilaterally.  Further diagnostic tests including an ankle-brachial index showed a value of 0.3 for the left ankle indicating severe obstruction. Arterial Doppler ultrasound revealed extensive atherosclerotic changes of the left femoro-popliteal and tibioperoneal arteries.   Diagnosis and Management:  The patient was diagnosed with Critical limb ischemia of his left leg with underlying conditions of Diabetes Mellitus and Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) as the most probable causes compounded by his history of cigarette smoking.  The patient was immediately referred for vascular consultation for further management  which could include angioplasty  stent placement  bypass surgery or even amputation  if necessary. His medications were also reviewed and optimized for better control of his Diabetes and hypertension.  Moreover  patient education was emphasized on foot care  the importance of lifestyle modifications including smoking cessation  weight control  adopting a healthy diet  and exercises to maintain peripheral circulation. Regular follow-ups were suggested to monitor his situation and prevent any further complications.   In conclusion  critical limb ischemia is a severe condition that requires immediate attention due to its high risk of limb loss if left untreated. Early diagnosis and prompt management can significantly enhance the patient's quality of life and decrease morbidity and mortality.

Patient Profile:  The patient is a 68-year-old male of African American descent. He resides in Miami  Florida  USA and is a retired construction engineer. He has been reported to smoke at least a pack of cigarettes daily for decades. His BMI is 30 (classified as obese)  and he lives a sedentarily lifestyle with minimal physical activity.  Presenting Problem and Primary Diagnosis:  The patient presented at our clinic with severe  constant pain in his left foot even at rest and various non-healing wounds present on the toes. After testing  the patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Past Medical History:  The patient has an extensive history of Type 2 diabetes  which has been marginally controlled for the past 10 years since diagnosis. Additionally  he's been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease and hypertension. Kidneys show regular function levels. Two years ago  the patient suffered a minor stroke but had completely recovered with no residual deficits.  Family History:  There is a strong family history of diabetes  heart disease  and stroke  with the patient's father suffering from coronary artery disease  which led to his death at the age of 73. The patient’s mother was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes and faced cardiovascular issues as well in her later years.  Clinical Findings and Diagnosis:  Physical examination revealed a critically ischemic left foot characterized by shiny  hairless skin and the absence of a palpable pulse in peripheral vessels. His foot was cold to touch with clear signs of gangrenous changes to the toes. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) test indicated an alarmingly low index of 0.30 on the left foot  suggesting severe obstruction.  Management Plan:  The patient has been referred to a vascular surgeon to discuss potential revascularization procedures and is on pharmacologic treatment with antiplatelets and statins. An intensive glycemic control program is also initiated considering his poorly controlled diabetes. Management also includes comprehensive wound care for his non-healing ulcers  antibiotics  and pain management.  Long-Term Expectation:  Long-term prognosis will largely depend on the success of any surgical interventions  the patient's adherence to medication  and his ability to manage his diabetes and commit to crucial lifestyle changes such as smoking cessation and increased physical activity. This case also highlighted the urgent need for primary healthcare providers to be aware of the major risk factors for CLI  notably uncontrolled diabetes and smoking. Regular screening of these patients might enable early identification and treatment of this debilitating condition.

Patient Identification: Mrs. Maria Rodriguez  a 68-year-old Hispanic woman  was admitted to our care with a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Chief Complaint: Severe pain in her left lower leg that has been causing restlessness and sleep deprivation.   Medical History: The patient has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 20 years and Hypertension diagnosed 5 years ago. She was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) 2 years ago. She also had a Myocardial Infarction 3 years ago  treated with coronary artery bypass graft surgery.   Social History: She is a widow living alone. She does not smoke nor consume alcohol but has a history of unregulated diet which contributed to her diabetes.  Family History: Both of her parents died of cardiovascular related issues. Her father suffered from hypertension and her mother was diabetic.   Current Medications: Metformin for Diabetes  Lisinopril and Amlodipine for Hypertension  and Aspirin for prophylaxis against cardiovascular disease.   Physical Examination: The examination showed an underweight woman in visible discomfort. Left leg showed signs of poor circulation  characterized by decreased hair growth  non-healing sores and shiny skin. Distal pulses were absent. Pain was induced even at rest suggesting severe disease.   Investigations: Preliminary blood tests showed a high blood glucose level and normal kidney function. Duplex ultrasound suggested the possibility of a significant narrowing/blockage in the left lower leg vessels. An angiogram confirmed total occlusion of the tibial and peroneal arteries.   Diagnosis: Based on the physical examination findings and investigations  the diagnosis is Critical Limb Ischemia.   Management Plan: The primary plan for management involves revascularization. The procedure selected depends on her comorbid conditions  the location of the blockage and her overall health condition. In her case  the non-invasive option of angioplasty and stenting could be considered. A detailed treatment plan should be established in consultation with a vascular surgeon. Other management strategies would include optimizing her diabetic and hypertension control and pain management.  Follow-Up: An extensive follow-up plan will be outlined for continued surveillance to keep track of disease progression and any potential complications from the intervention.  This case highlights the need for early recognition and intervention particularly in high-risk patients with a setting of diabetes and hypertension as diagnosing CLI has implications for increased morbidity and mortality. Appropriate education about the disease  lifestyle modifications and adherence to medication regime can greatly benefit affected patients.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  who is a retired convenience store owner from Portland  Oregon  USA.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith presents himself at the medical outpatient department  complaining of progressive lower limb pain that worsens when walking but eases with rest (intermittent claudication) and difficulty in healing of an ulcer on his right big toe  which has been persistent for two months. The pain is severe  scaling 8/10 and it also disturbs his sleep.   Medical History: Mr. Smith has a long-standing history of type II diabetes and hypertension which were diagnosed 10 years ago  currently managed with Metformin and Amlodipine  respectively. He has been compliant with his medications. He also has a past history of ischemic heart disease and underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) seven years ago. He is a smoker for the past 40 years and drinks alcohol socially. He doesn’t have any allergies.  Family History: Mr. Smith’s family history reveals that his father died of a sudden myocardial infarction at the age of 62. His mother is still alive and has been diagnosed with late-onset diabetes. His elder sister has been suffering from hypertension. Hence  there is a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases and diabetes.  Examination: On examination  the patient's right toe ulcer is poorly defined with gangrenous changes  and there is an absence of popliteal and dorasalis pedis pulses bilaterally. He also displays other clinical features such as cold feet  pallor  and loss of hair in lower extremities.   Diagnosis: Combined with the history  symptoms  and physical examination  Mr. Smith was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Plan: Mr. Smith was admitted and treated for sepsis with antibiotics. Strict blood glucose control was maintained. He was referred to a vascular surgeon for further management and it was planned for radiological imaging like duplex ultrasonography or CT angiography to evaluate the exact site and extent of arterial occlusion.   Patient education was done regarding smoking cessation  maintaining optimal weight  diabetes  and hypertension control  and the importance of a healthy diet and regular exercise. Mr. Smith and his family were made aware of the risk of amputation in the case of worsening ischemia and non-healing of the ulcer. This case presentation underscores the acute need for early diagnosis and intervention in Critical Limb Ischemia to prevent morbidity and mortality.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Summary:  Our subject is a 75-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Richards  presenting symptoms congruent with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).   Past medical history: Mr. Richards has a known history of Type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. Despite being on medication  his blood glucose and lipid levels have been poorly controlled over the years. Consequently  he has had previous hospitalizations due to diabetic foot ulcers. Moreover  he has a 30-year pack smoking history  which he quit almost five years ago.  Family History: Both of his parents had cardiovascular diseases. His father  deceased at 65  suffered from myocardial infarction  while his mother  deceased at 70  had a stroke. His elder brother  77  has peripheral artery disease (PAD).  Current Scenario: Mr. Richards visited the hospital complaining of severe rest pain in his right lower limb that's been progressing over the past two months. The pain predominantly bothers him at night and is temporarily relieved by hanging his leg over the edge of the bed. He noted a wound on his right foot that has been present for the past three weeks  showing signs of poor healing.   Physical Examination: On examination  his right foot was pale with diminished popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial pulses. The wound was located on his right heel and surrounded by dry  scaly skin with peripheral cyanosis. His Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was 0.4  indicating an abnormal result.   Treatment Plan: Considering Mr. Richards' medical history  his presenting symptoms  physical findings  and his high risk factors - including poor diabetes control  smoking  and family predisposition to PAD  he was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia. He was referred to a vascular surgeon for revascularization procedures and a plastic surgeon for wound management. Medication was optimized for better control of his underlying chronic health problems.
