Future Implications and Prevention: Mr. Richards is at high risk for major amputation if not appropriately managed. He was advised to maintain strict control of his blood glucose and cholesterol levels and to maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle. Emphasis was made on regular foot inspection  proper foot care  and immediate reporting of any abnormalities.   This case highlights the essential role of early detection and treatment to prevent the devastating outcomes associated with the advanced stages of peripheral artery disease. Regular collaboration and follow-up with endocrinologist  cardiologist  and podiatrist are established for multidisciplinary management.  Additional Note: Critical Limb Ischemia is a severe form of PAD that needs urgent attention. It's a strong predictor for cardiovascular mortality and morbidity. Through awareness and early identification  the adverse outcomes can be prevented  and the quality of life in patients with CLI can be improved.

Patient Presentation  Our patient is a 63-year-old African American male named Mr. Roberts  who is a retired construction worker and lives with his wife of 40 years. He has been a heavy smoker for nearly 45 years  consuming a pack of cigarettes daily  and drinks socially. He has a BMI of 29 and has been recently diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).   Past Medical History  Mr. Roberts had been previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hypertension 10 years ago but has been non-compliant with medications citing forgetfulness and lack of knowledge about the seriousness of their implications. He has also been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and has a history of ischemic heart disease  which was managed with coronary artery bypass graft surgery 5 years ago. There were no reported complications after the surgery  and he had been on regular follow-ups.   Family history  There is a strong family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father dying at an early age due to myocardial infarction  and his older sister currently managing peripheral artery disease (PAD). Additionally  his mother has type 2 diabetes and hypertension.   Presenting complaint  Mr. Roberts reports having severe pain in his right lower limb  especially upon exertion and at night  for the past three months. He experienced significant weight loss and has wound ulcers that are not healing  raising concerns about his quality of life and heightened risk of lower extremity amputation.   On assessment  his lower right foot is cold to the touch with visible skin color changes showing pallor and cyanosis. The pulses in his right leg are weak and no audible doppler signal is present at the dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial arteries indicating severe blood flow compromise.   Laboratory findings reveal elevated blood glucose and lipid levels. An angiogram shows severe obstruction in the superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery in the right leg. These clinical findings have led to a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia  which justifies his clinical symptoms of debilitating pain in his right leg and non-healing ulcers.   This case warrants urgent medical attention due to the severe nature of CLI  the objective is to salvage the limb  manage the pain  and slow the disease progression. The management plan for Mr. Roberts will be multifaceted  including aggressive control of his diabetes and hyperlipidemia  smoking cessation  wound care  pain management  potential angioplasty or bypass surgery  and lifestyle modifications. Regular psychological and social support will also be offered due to the high stress and anxiety level associated with this illness.

Patient Presentation  Demographics:  Mr. A  a 68-year-old African-American male  presented on October 3rd with severe pain in his left lower leg of three weeks duration.  Chief Complaint: Patient complains of persistent rest pain in the left lower leg  worse at night  with occasional pain at rest. Patient also reported skin discoloration  feeling of coldness in the leg  and difficulty in walking.  History of Present Illness: The patient's leg pain initially started around 20 days back  minimum at rest but gradually increased in severity. The pain has been restricting his daily activities. Over the past week  he noticed changes in the skin color of his foot.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes for 15 years  hypertension for ten years  and high cholesterol levels for six years. He had a smoking history of 20 cigarettes a day but quit 15 years ago.  Medications:  The patient is on oral hypoglycemic drugs  ACE inhibitors  and statins.  Family History: There is a family history of heart disease. His father had an early myocardial infarction at the age of 55 and his older brother was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease at 60.  Physical Examination: On examination  the left leg was cooler compared to the right one  with a weak pulse and skin pallor noted. There was a non-healing ulcer over the left heel adding further concern to the potential severity of his condition. No signs of gangrene noted. The ankle-brachial index was 0.6 indicating severe peripheral artery disease.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Detailed arterial Duplex ultrasound examination revealed significant stenosis of the left external iliac artery. Resting ankle brachial index (ABI) was 0.4 in the left leg and 0.9 at the right leg.   Mr. A was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI) due to significant stenosis of the left external iliac artery  secondary to long-standing poorly controlled diabetes  and a strong family history of vascular disorders.  Management: The initial management plan for Mr. A is divided into reachable goals which are: pain control  improving limb perfusion to prevent amputation  and lifestyle modifications.  Patient had undergone endovascular revascularization for his left lower limb  and pain management is achieved using opioids. He will be referred to rehabilitation to improve muscle function and physical capacity after revascularization.  Regarding lifestyle modification  it will include regular checkups for blood glucose levels  lipid profile  blood pressure along with dietary changes  and an exercise plan.  This case highlights the importance of early detection and prompt management of PAD. High-risk patients with a history of diabetes and smokers should be the target of such interventions. Regular screening for PAD among high-risk patients  prompt revascularization upon developing CLI  can prevent amputation and improve quality of life.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Khan is a 65-year-old South Asian male diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). He is a retired software engineer who has been living in the UK for the past 35 years. He has been a non-smoker and non-alcoholic throughout his life.  Past Medical History: Mr. Khan has been diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus 15 years ago and is under medication for the same (Metformin 850mg PO bid). He has been compliant with his regular blood sugar monitoring and medication. Also  he has been diagnosed with asynchronous hypertension which is being managed with Amlodipine 5mg daily.  Presenting Complaints & History of Illness: He presented with severe unremitting pain in his right lower limb- below the knee  especially at night. Further  he noted color changes (pale to bluish) and difficult-to-heal wounds on his foot which prompted him to seek medical attention.  Family History: There is a family history of diabetes mellitus with his mother diagnosed with it. His elder sister died of coronary artery disease at the age of 58.  Physical Examination: On examination  his blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg and pulse rate was 92 beats per minute. There was sensory loss in the right foot and Mild weakness was found in the muscles of the right lower leg. He had reduced peripheral pulses and cold limbs. Foot examination showed a non-healing ulcer around the heel.  Results of Diagnostic Tests:  His HbA1c was found to be 7.6%  indicating poor glycemic control. His lipid profile was abnormal with elevated levels of LDL cholesterol. His Doppler ultrasound indicated reduced blood flow in his right lower limb arteries. Angiography confirmed severe blockage in the right lower limb arteries.  Management:  His condition was managed conservatively initially with IV Heparin and then oral anticoagulants and antiplatelet drugs. His BP was optimized with a higher dose of Amlodipine (10mg/day) and an additional medication (Losartan 50mg/day) added. His diabetes management was re-evaluated and Insulin was incorporated into his treatment plan. He needed surgical intervention (angioplasty) for the blocked arteries in his right lower limb. He was also advised regular physical therapy and wound care management.  This case underscores the importance of regular monitoring and stringent control of chronic conditions like diabetes and hypertension in preventing complications like Critical Limb Ischemia  and the role of timely medical and surgical intervention in managing this potentially limb-threatening condition.

Patient Case Presentation: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Profile: The patient is Mr. R.P.  a 68-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired construction foreman. He has been living alone since his wife passed away three years ago. He is a former smoker and has consumed alcohol moderately throughout his life.  Presenting Issue: Mr. R.P. presented to the emergency department with severe  constant pain in his right lower leg that has worsened over the past week. He also reported progressive skin color changes - the leg has become significantly paler  and he has noticed a slowdown in toenail growth.  Past Medical History: Mr. R.P. was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes 5 years ago  which has been managed with oral hypoglycemics. He developed hypertension 8 years ago  which has been well controlled with medication. He also underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) 2 years ago due to ischemic heart disease. He has a 10-year history of peripheral artery disease (PAD) that was managed conservatively.  Family History: Mr. R.P.'s mother died of a heart attack at 72  and his father passed away at 76 due to a stroke. One of his two younger sisters has diabetes and the other one died due to lung cancer. His family history is thus significant for diabetes  cardiovascular diseases  and cancer.  Diagnostic Assessment: On physical examination  Mr. R.P's right lower leg appeared pale and felt cold to the touch. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were not palpable. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) test was abnormal  and color Doppler ultrasound showed markedly reduced blood flow in the right lower limb. The diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) was made based on his history  clinical features  and diagnostic findings.  Treatment Plan: The vascular team was immediately involved and an angiogram was performed  which revealed severe stenosis of the right leg's arteries. An urgent peripheral artery angioplasty and stent placement were advised  followed by serial non-invasive vascular studies to monitor the flow in the right leg. Due to his uncontrolled diabetes  adjustments to his medication regime were suggested  along with dietary changes and a podiatry review to prevent future foot infections.   This case highlights the importance of early detection and management of risk factors like diabetes and hypertension  which can significantly delay CLI progression and decrease the need for intervention. Nevertheless  this patient’s continuing care will require a multidisciplinary approach involving primary care  vascular medicine  endocrinology  dietetics  and psychiatry services for comprehensive management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Fitz  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a chief complaint of pain in his lower limbs  particularly his left leg. The pain has been constant and severe over the past three to four weeks  leading to a significant decrease in his quality of life. He reports the pain to be exacerbated by physical activity and somewhat relieved by rest  but mentions that it has started to persist even at rest. He also reports non-healing ulcers on his left foot.  Past medical history is significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which he has been managing for the past 15 years with oral medications. He was also diagnosed with high blood pressure about 10 years ago. He has a 40-year history of smoking  approximately a pack a day  and admits to moderate alcohol consumption but denied illicit drug use.   His family history is significant; both his father and paternal grandfather had heart disease and his mother had a stroke.   On physical examination  his left leg appears pale when raised and reddish-blue upon dependency. The leg is cooler to the touch compared to the other one. Pulses on the left leg are faint and there are non-healing ulcers around his left ankle and foot. An Ankle Brachial Index (ABI) is conducted  demonstrating a low ABI of 0.4 in his left leg and 0.9 in his right leg.   Further diagnostic investigations included a Doppler ultrasound  which confirmed severe blood flow reduction in the left leg  specifically around the area of his left popliteal artery.   Mr. Fitz was subsequently diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  likely secondary to peripheral artery disease (PAD) which itself appears to be related to his longstanding history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  and smoking.  Current treatment includes pain management with analgesic medication  rigorous wound care  and he was commenced on antiplatelet and statin therapy to manage his PAD. Interventional options  inclusive of angioplasty  stenting  or bypass surgery  are being considered and discussed with the patient.   We counseled Mr. Fitz on the importance of strict blood sugar and pressure control and advised him to quit smoking to prevent the progression of CLI and PAD  and other potential complications like heart disease and stroke. We've also referred him to a dietician to help create a diet plan that is heart-healthy and good for his diabetes.   This case underscores the significant impact of non-communicable diseases and health behaviors on underlying vascular issues. Timely diagnosis and management of CLI is essential to avoid complications such as amputation and mortality.

Patient Information:  Name: John Doe  Age: 72 years old Gender: Male  Occupation: Retired Navy Officer Ethnicity: Caucasian   Presenting Condition:  Mr. Doe presented with ongoing pain in his right lower limb for the past few weeks. The pain was initially intermittent  however  it’s increased in severity and became persistent over the past week. He also noted the development of sores on his right foot  which have had difficulty healing.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe is a chronic smoker with a pack history of 60 years. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 12 years ago  which is being controlled by oral hypoglycemic medications. He also has a history of hypertension diagnosed 15 years ago  managed with diuretics. No known history of any cardiac ailments  cerebrovascular accidents  or past surgeries.  Family History:  His parents are deceases  his father had a history of heart disease and his mother was diabetic. His elder sister (78 years old) also suffers from diabetes and his daughter (52 years old) recently diagnosed with hypertension.  Physical Examination and Lab Tests:  On examination  the right limb appeared pale and cold with weak peripheral pulses. Multiple non-healing sores were visible on the right foot. Capillary refill time was delayed. His BMI was found to be in the range of obesity  and blood pressure was elevated. Preliminary lab tests showed increased blood glucose and cholesterol levels.  Diagnosis:  Based on presenting symptoms  past medical history  and physical examination  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Treatment and Management Plan:  He was admitted for further investigations and management. He was started on blood thinner medications to prevent clot formation and prescribed pain relievers to manage pain. He was referred to a specialist for an angiogram to evaluate and decide on the requirement for angioplasty  stenting  or bypass surgery. In parallel  the patient has been advised to quit smoking  encouraged to maintain a diet plan to help control blood glucose  cholesterol levels  and weight reduction.    Prognosis:  CLI is a serious condition which if left untreated may necessitate limb amputation. However  with early diagnosis  risk factor control  and appropriate management  the progression of the disease can be slowed down and the quality of life can be improved.    Follow-Up:  Mr. Doe is scheduled to attend a follow-up consultation post his angiogram to decide on further management and plan for cardiac rehabilitation.    Ethical Considerations:  As part of the management plan  patient autonomy was respected by involving Mr. Doe in decision-making related to his care  explaining the consequences of the choices in a language he could understand  and obtaining his informed consent. Further  efforts were made to provide an empathetic and non-judgmental environment considering his sustained tobacco use and high stress due to progressive disease.

Patient Information:  Mr. Arthur Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presented in the clinic with severe leg pain  recurring foot sores  and cool skin on his legs. He is a retired engineer and has been living alone ever since his wife passed away two years ago.   Medical History:  The patient has been a smoker since his early 20s but has reduced the frequency over the years  averaging half a pack a day now. He exercises casually but his lifestyle denotes a lack of regular physical activity. His medical history reveals prior diagnoses of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension for which he is under treatment.  Symptoms:  Mr. Smith revealed that he's been experiencing rest pain  particularly in his legs  that often intensifies during the night. He also identified the presence of non-healing ulcers on his feet.  Diagnosis:  Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Family History:  His father passed due to myocardial infarction  his mother had hypertension  and his older brother suffers from peripheral arterial disease (PAD).  Physical Assessment:  On examination  the pulses in the patient’s lower limbs are weak. His feet appear pale and cold on touch. A bluish-red discoloration is evident due to poor blood supply and multiple non-healing ulcers are present.   Investigations:  Doppler ultrasound reveals impaired blood flow. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is less than 0.4. Computed Tomographic Angiography (CTA) shows a significant block in the arteries supplying his legs.  Management:  Considering his advanced age  a conservative approach was taken. This included optimizing the medical treatment of his comorbidities. Lifestyle changes were advised such as smoking cessation  keeping sugars under control and raising physical activity levels. Pain management steps were incorporated  wound care for his ulcers was provided and he was referred to a vascular surgeon for further evaluation.  Review:  Mr. Smith will be reviewed every two weeks to monitor his wound healing process and his pain level. Further management will be based on how the symptoms evolve over time.    Overall  this case marks the importance of early detection of CLI in preventing further deterioration that might lead to limb amputation and extended hospitalization.

Patient Case Presentation:  Subject: Mr. J. S.  Demographics: Mr. J. S. is a 72-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Issue: Mr. J. S. has been diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Past Medical History: Mr. J. S. has a extensive past medical history  which includes hypertension  Type II diabetes and hyperlipidemia. His diabetic condition has been inconsistent  which consequences in frequent oscillation of his blood glucose levels  ranging wildly from hypoglycemic to hyperglycemic states. He had a history of smoking but quit 15 years ago. In addition  he underwent angioplasty 7 years back due to coronary artery disease.  Family History: His father died of a myocardial infarction. His mother suffers from arthritis and his older brother is hypertensive and diabetic. There is no family history of peripheral artery disease (PAD) or circulatory disorders.  Symptoms: Mr. J. S. came in complaining of pain in his right leg which further deteriorates during walking. He has developed chronic leg ulcers that are not healing despite receiving normal wound care treatments.  Physical Exam: On examination  the critical limb ischemia was evident as the patient's right leg was cool to touch with weak pedal pulses. The patient also exhibited cyanosis in his toes and a non-healing ulcer was seen on the lateral aspect of his right foot.  Diagnostic Results: An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) attested the decreased blood flow to the patient’s lower extremities. Angiography also confirmed limited blood flow in the peripheral arteries of the lower limbs.  Treatment Plan: Given Mr. J. S.'s condition  we are considering aggressive control of his blood glucose levels and hypertension  as well as dietary changes to manage his hyperlipidemia. The implementation of a walking program will also be proposed  supplemented by pain medications to enhance the walking distances. As the ulcers are not healing and could potentially become gangrenous  revascularization methods such as angioplasty or bypass surgery need to be contemplated.  Potential Implications: Based on his existing medical conditions and lifestyle factors  Mr. J. S. is at a high risk of heart disease and severe PAD if his CLI is not promptly and properly addressed.  Conclusion: It’s essential to conduct regular follow-up appointments post treatment with the aim of monitoring Mr. J. S.'s progress and adjusting management protocols if deemed necessary. Comprehensive patient education about disease  dietary intakes  exercise regimen and smoking cessation will also be an integral part of the management plan.

Patient Information: Ms. E.M  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the outpatient department with complaints of leg pain  color changes  and non-healing ulcers on her right foot.   Past Medical History:  Ms. E.M. has been battling hypertension and type 2 diabetes for the past 15 years. She is a former smoker with a 40-year smoking history and has quit smoking ten years ago. Her medications include Metformin and Losartan. Ms. E.M's weight and BMI suggest low-grade obesity  a known risk factor for vascular complications.  Family History: Her family history is notable for peripheral artery disease in her mother  who passed away at the age of 75 from heart disease. There is no known family history of diabetes  hypertension  or cancers.  Examination & Diagnosis:  On examination  her right foot was markedly cooler compared with the left foot  with visible cyanosis and two non-healing ulcers on the big toe. An absence of pulsation was evident in the right pedal artery region. An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test indicated a value of 0.35 (normal range 0.9-1.3) on the right side. Based on these findings  she was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI)  the severe stage of peripheral artery disease (PAD).  Treatment:  The patient was referred to the vascular surgery team for further management. Endovascular intervention was considered given the location and severity of the lesion. Pharmacotherapy was optimized to manage her risk factors.   Plan:  Proper foot care  wound management  and patient education are imperative to reduce morbidity  along with strict blood glucose and blood pressure control.   Conclusion: Patients with Critical Limb Ischemia generally have an ominous prognosis. Given her modifiable and nonmodifiable risk factors  regular follow-up and multidisciplinary care coordination are crucial for this patient's improved clinical outcome. Regular screening and early intervention in at-risk individuals are important measures to prevent CLI.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. X is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a two-month history of progressive pain in his right lower extremity. He describes the pain as ""burning and persistent "" worse with movement  and partially relieved by rest. He has had two episodes of rest pain during the last week. The patient also reported experiencing coldness and numbness in his foot  especially at night.   Past Medical History:  Mr. X has a documented history of type II diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker  having quit 5 years ago after a 30-year pack history. The patient also had an episode of angina  treated with angioplasty and stenting 3 years ago.   Family History:  His mother had a history of peripheral artery disease (PAD) and underwent a below-knee amputation procedure in her late 70s. His father passed away at the age of 72 due to myocardial infarction.   Personal and Social History:  The patient is married with three adult children  all in good health. He is a retired laborer and has a low level of physical activity today. He admits to occasional alcohol use and no illicit drug use.   Current Medication:  He is currently on aspirin  statins  metformin  an ACE inhibitor  and a beta-blocker.   Physical Examination:  On examination  his BP was 138/92 mm Hg  pulse 82 beats/min  BMI 27.5 kg/m2. Examination of his feet revealed poorly detectable pulses  bluish discoloration  and an ulcer on his right heel.   Impression:  Considering the chronic nature of his symptoms  the clinical presentation  and the family history of PAD  the patient was suspected of having Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).   Plan:  The patient was referred for an urgent vascular consultation  including an angiogram for diagnosis confirmation and revascularization if necessary. Current medications were reviewed  and optimal controls of his hypertension  hyperglycemia  and hyperlipidemia were ensured. The patient was educated about the risks and potential outcomes  including possible amputation. He was also advised to make necessary lifestyle modifications and follow a foot care routine to prevent ulcer complications.   This clinical presentation was interesting due to the importance of early detection and aggressive treatment in CLI's prognosis  emphasizing patient education and risk factor management to prevent severe complications and improve the quality of life.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information:  Mr. Jackson is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired  residing in Durham  North Carolina.  Presenting Issue:  He presented to the clinic complaining of persistent  severe pain in the lower region of his right leg  which had been ongoing for the past two months. The pain disturbs his sleep and is present at rest. He has also noticed a couple of non-healing wounds on the same leg.  Past Medical History: Reviewing his past medical history  Mr. Jackson was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago  and type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago. He has been somewhat inconsistent with his medication adherence and has had suboptimal glycemic control. He also has a history of smoking  at approximately a pack a day for 50 years  but has cut down to half a pack in the past five years.  Family History:  His family history reveals that his father died of myocardial infarction at age 63  and his mother had a stroke in her late 70s.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  there was significant hair loss on the lower portion of his right leg  dry and scaled skin  along with two ulcerated wounds. Pedal pulses were not palpable. There was no apparent edema. The foot was cool to touch  and capillary refill time was extended.  Investigations:  Ankle-brachial index (ABI) had a low reading of 0.5 on the right side. Further Doppler ultrasound imaging confirmed insufficient blood flow to the lower portion of the right leg. These findings highly suggest severe peripheral artery disease.  Diagnosis:  Combined with the symptoms  history  and tests  Mr. Jackson was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI)  reflecting a severe form of peripheral artery disease.  Management Plan:  A management plan including lifestyle modifications (quitting smoking  a structured exercise program  and dietary changes)  foot care  effective glycemic control  optimizing blood pressure level  and antiplatelet therapy was initiated. A referral has been made to a vascular surgeon for further evaluation and intervention.   This case presents the critical importance of aggressive risk factor management in patients with a known history of cardiovascular diseases and type 2 diabetes. Patient education and regular follow-up are vital to reduce the impact of CLI and prevent the worst-case scenario of amputation.  Keywords: Peripheral Artery Disease  Critical Limb Ischemia  CLI-PAD  Hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes  Cigarette Smoking  Family History  Cardiovascular Disease.

Patient Information:   - Initials: D.P - Age: 75 Years - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired School Teacher - Marital Status: Widower - Race: Caucasian  Chief Complaint: The patient complains of recurrent pain in his left lower leg  especially during night and also while resting. He has a non-healing ulcer on the left foot's big toe and notices that his left leg is colder than the right.  Medical History:  D.P has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM) for the past 15 years and Hypertension (HTN) for the last 10 years. He is also a heavy smoker for about 50 years  which he quit only 3 years ago. He was diagnosed with Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) previously  with his right leg having been revascularized 6 months ago. He currently takes Metformin for DM  Lisinopril for HTN  antiplatelets  and statins for hyperlipidemia due to PAD.  Family History:  D.P's father passed away from a myocardial infarction in his early 70s  while his mother had a stroke in her late 70s. His eldest brother was diagnosed with PAD  and his sister is managing Diabetes with medication.  Social History:  D.P lives on his own. His children visit regularly and help manage his health conditions and related hospital appointments. He does not consume alcohol  but admits to smoking about 2 packs of cigarettes per day for nearly half a century  before quitting abruptly a few years ago. He denies substance abuse or ever having taken illicit drugs.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the left foot was found to be cold with an absent pulse and a gangrenous toe. There was an ulcer on the dorsal side of the foot. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial artery pulses were also absent on trying to palpate. The systemic examination was unremarkable.  Diagnosis:  Given the chronology  clinical presentation  and past medical history of diabetes  hypertension  smoking  and PAD  the patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) in the left lower extremity.    Plan:  The severity and the stage of the disease necessitate an aggressive approach. Surgical intervention is probably the best option for revascularization of the affected extremity. This would include angioplasty or bypass grafting. Additionally  lifestyle modification advice  foot care education  tighter control of existing comorbidities like DM and HTN  cessation of smoking  exercise  and better nutrition could play a pivotal part in managing CLI. Continue current medication  with the possible addition of Prostaglandin E1 to improve pain relief. He will need regular follow-ups to monitor his condition.  Education:  The patient was educated about the severity of his condition  lifestyle changes  necessity of early intervention  prognosis  and possible complications if left untreated. His family was informed to keep a watch for increasing pain or changes in the color and temperature of the affected leg and anything unusual.   Follow Up: The patient will be followed up every six weeks for monitoring the condition or sooner if necessary. Further testing such as Ankle-Brachial Index or ultrasound of the blood vessels may be planned to assess the severity of blockage.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Armann  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI). He is a former smoker with a smoking history of 45 pack-years and a significant history of hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) for over 25 years. He reports having persistent pain in his lower extremities  particularly in the right leg  which has progressively worsened over the past five months. This pain is described as sharp and severe  unrelieved by rest and not specific to any particular area of the leg. He also noted numbness  coolness of the right leg and foot  and an open non-healing ulcer in the right ankle for last three months.   Past Medical History: His medical history reveals multiple attempts at hypertension control with varied anti-hypertensive medications  consistently poor glycemic control in spite of being on multiple medications including insulin for DM  and previous interventions for coronary artery disease (CAD)  including a coronary stent placement ten years ago. Additionally  he was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) eight years ago and has had two attempts at percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) to improve limb perfusion. He currently takes a daily dose of clopidogrel  a statin medication  aspirin  metformin  insulin  and lisinopril.   Family History: The family history indicates significant cardiovascular risk factors with his father dying from a myocardial infarction at age 59 and a mother who died with stroke at the age of 72. Additionally  there is a history of DM and hypertension on both the maternal and paternal sides.  Review of Systems: A review of systems reveals general fatigue  decreased activity tolerance and unintentional weight loss over last four months. Moreover  he has persistent dry cough and sleeplessness due to pain. There are no complaints of chest pain  breathlessness or palpitations.    Physical Examination: On examination  he appeared frail and in pain. The right lower limb showed marked pallor compared to the left limb. There were absent pulses in the right leg including popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibialis. A non-healing ulcer measuring 3x2 cm was noted on the lateral malleolus of the right ankle. Capillary refill time in the right leg is markedly increased compared to the left.  Based on his history  clinical findings  and diagnosis  Mr. Armann was determined to be at high risk for limb loss and cardiovascular events. A multidisciplinary treatment approach involving strict glycemic control  blood pressure management  wound care  smoking cessation assistance  and a possible surgical intervention for limb salvage was considered.  Conclusion: This case demonstrates the complexity of CLI and the comprehensive approach needed in dealing with advanced PAD  especially in patients with multiple comorbidities. It is crucial to establish a tailored plan for controlling underlying diseases and addressing the acute and long-term management of CLI. Further vascular studies and aggressive treatment plans may be essential in these scenarios to prevent limb loss and avoid significant morbidity and mortality. Impressive adherence to treatment regimen should be emphasized to Mr. Armann.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Race: African-American Occupation: Retired police officer Marital Status: Widowed; 3 adult children  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Doe presented to the hospital with severe pain and non-healing ulcers in his right lower extremity  primarily his right foot  which has persisted for two months despite previous treatment. Pain reported as 8/10 on a pain scale and worsens when the limb is elevated.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe is known to have an extensive medical history  encompassing Type II Diabetes Mellitus  Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) and Hypertension. He had a myocardial infarction ten years ago with subsequent dual stent placement. He quit smoking following the MI  but reports 30 pack-years of smoking. In addition  he had a partial foot amputation 5 years ago due to a non-healing ulcer.  Family History:  Parents both deceased; father passed away at age 65 from heart disease  mother had a stroke at age 72. One older brother diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus type II.  Physical Examination:  On examination  his right lower extremity is cold to touch  with shiny and hairless skin. Distal pulses in the right foot are completely absent. A non-healing ulcer is noticed on the dorsal surface of the right foot  and gangrenous changes are evident in the toes. The left lower extremity is well perfused and warm to touch.  Investigations:  An ankle-brachial index was conducted and was less than 0.5 in the right foot. Subsequent ultrasound Doppler revealed severely reduced blood flow in the posterior tibial artery and anterior tibial artery  confirming a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Treatment Plan:  Mr. Doe was referred to a vascular surgeon for possible revascularization. Blood glucose levels were controlled and antihypertensive medication was administered. Pain management with analgesics was also introduced. For the non-healing ulcer  wound care nurses were consulted for appropriate wound care management. Heavy focus was given to the patient for lifestyle modifications such as exercise  a balanced diet  and continuous non-smoking practices.  Prognosis:  The presence of CLI in the right lower extremity necessitates immediate intervention due to the risk of limb amputation. Long-term prognosis largely depends on the success of revascularization and the patient’s adherence to lifestyle modifications and control of existing co-morbidities.   Follow UP:  Mr. Doe will need close monitoring to assess his recovery and management of his chronic illnesses. An interdisciplinary approach involving a vascular surgeon  endocrinologist  cardiologist  wound care nurse  and dietitian will be essential for his prognosis and quality of life.  This case presentation underscores the importance of promptly recognizing and managing Critical Limb Ischemia to prevent major adverse limb events  especially in individuals with risk factors such as a history of peripheral arterial disease  diabetes  and smoking.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Overview: Mr. Joseph is a 72-year-old male  a retired teacher  living in a suburban neighborhood with his wife. He is of Caucasian ethnicity.  Main Complaint: Presenting with increased pain in the left leg that escalates while walking  hence  limiting his mobility. This pain then alleviates when he is at rest. He also reported experiencing persistent numbness and a cold feeling in his left foot.  Medical History: Mr. Joseph is a known case of diabetes mellitus for the past 16 years  being managed by a metformin 500 mg twice daily. He was also diagnosed with hypertension 8 years ago  which is being controlled with lisinopril 20 mg once daily. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago after being diagnosed with COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). He has dyslipidemia and is on statin therapy. He also reports history of ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) for gallstone removal around 5 years ago.  Family History: Mr. Joseph's father died from myocardial infarction at 82 years while his mother passed away due to stroke at 80 years. His elder brother  age 75  is suffering from severe peripheral artery disease  and his younger sister  age 69  is a breast cancer survivor.  Social History:  Before retirement  he used to be a high school teacher and loves reading and gardening. He lives with his wife  who is a retired nurse. Mr. Joseph quit smoking ten years ago but was a heavy smoker in his younger years.  Clinical Examination: His lower-left extremity examination revealed decreased temperature  absence of distal pulses  pallor with elevated leg  and delayed capillary refill. No open wound observed  but the overlying skin was noted to be shiny with loss of hair.  Diagnosis: Given his diabetes  smoking history  his brother's peripheral artery disease  and his leg symptoms  Mr. Joseph was suspected of critical limb ischemia (CLI). After consultation with a vascular surgeon  a confirmed diagnosis of CLI was made based on his medical history  symptoms and an angiogram.  Management: He was prescribed pain medication along with medications for managing his existing conditions. An endovascular procedure was planned for revascularization based on his angiogram results. Furthermore  he will continue exercise therapy for COPD and was referred to a dietitian for maintaining blood glucose levels.  It is worth mentioning that Mr. Joseph was diligently educated about the seriousness of his current complaints  the implications of diabetes  the need for stringent glycemic control  foot care routine  and the risk of potential complications including amputations.

Patient Identification:  A 65-year-old African American male.  Presenting Complaint:  Pain and cramping in the lower legs upon exercise or walking. Pain is relieved only when at rest.  Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years ago  for which he is receiving metformin. He has hypertension  which is managed with lisinopril. Also  was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia  for which the patient is on atorvastatin 10mg. He is also a chronic smoker with a 30 pack-year history.  Family history: His father had a myocardial infarction in his 60s and his mother is also diabetic.   Review of Systems:  No changes in weight or tiredness. No chest pain  palpitations or syncope. No shortness of breath  cough or wheezing. No abdominal pain  nausea or vomiting. No changes in bowel or urinary habits.  Physical Examination:  Normal BMI. Lower limbs showed diminished pulses bilaterally. Skin of the feet was found to be cold and pale with minor discoloration. The patient showed signs of intermittent claudication with decreased hair and nail growth on the lower extremities.   Investigations: Ankle-brachial index (ABI) test results were 0.70 - indicating peripheral artery disease. Duplex ultrasonography showed a significant plaque in the femoral artery. The patient also underwent a transcutaneous oxygen pressure measurement that affirmed critical limb ischemia.  Current Medications:  Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin.  Assessment and Plan:  The patient has Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) which is likely stemming from his uncontrolled diabetes  a history of smoking  and hypertension. A comprehensive plan that includes medical management  lifestyle changes  and possibly surgical intervention needs to be designed. Smoking cessation and dietary modifications for proper glycemic control are essential. Antiplatelet or antithrombotic therapy with aspirin or clopidogrel  and statin therapy should be continued. For relieving symptoms  cilostazol or pentoxifylline can be given. Consider revascularization if symptoms persist or worsen.   Follow-up plan: The patient needs to be regularly monitored. We will follow up within a week to see whether or not there's symptomatic relief. ABI needs to be checked every 3-6 months.  This case highlights the relationship between lifestyle diseases like diabetes and smoking  with peripheral vascular diseases. It shows the importance of regular screening and management of such patients for early detection and prevention of such serious complications.

Patient Presentation  Demographic Data: Mr. J is a 68-year-old African American male  living in a suburban area. He is a retired teacher  married with three kids. He is a non-smoker and reports long periods of sedentary lifestyle.   Presenting Problem: Mr. J was advised to seek medical care upon experiencing persistent pain in his right leg  severe enough to disrupt sleep and cause immobility. He described the pain as ischemic  affecting his calf muscle mostly and sometimes extending to his foot and thigh. The pain has been progressively worsening over the past six weeks  also presenting with open wounds that do not heal on his lower leg.  Past Medical History: Mr. J has a history of hypertension and dyslipidemia. He has been previously treated for peripheral arterial disease (PAD) five years ago. He also has Type 2 diabetes mellitus under fair control. His diabetes  hypertension  and dyslipidemia are managed with oral medication. He has no history of hospitalization or surgical procedures.  Family History: His mother died at the age of 83 due to heart failure. His father died of colon cancer at 78. He has an elder sibling with history of stroke. No family history of critical limb ischemia is reported.  Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  there were pallor  slow capillary refilling and coldness observed in the lower right leg. No capillary pulsations were detected in both the right posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries. The foot showed signs of minor gangrene.  Diagnostic Assessments: Lower limb Doppler ultrasound showed significant stenosis in the popliteal artery. Additional analysis with CT angiography confirmed occlusion of the right popliteal artery extending into the trifurcation vessels.  Diagnosis: Based on clinical history  physical examination and diagnostic assessments  Mr. J was diagnosed with right leg critical limb ischemia  secondary to peripheral artery disease and complicated by diabetes.  Treatment Plan: Treatment plan was constructed with a multidisciplinary approach. Primarily  an angioplasty was scheduled to restore the blood flow. He was prescribed with anti-platelet drugs to prevent blood clots  statins targeting dyslipidemia  and painkillers for pain management. He was also advised to keep his diabetes under better control through medication adjustment  diet and exercise. Proper wound care was started for the non-healing wounds. He was referred to a physiotherapist for improving physical strength.  Given his comorbid conditions and severity of ischemia  the prognosis is cautious. Strict monitoring and medication adherence is paramount for him to improve and maintain his quality of life  and to reduce the risk of amputation.

Patient Details:   Patient Name: Mr. John Thompson Age: 62 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Construction Worker  Chief Complaint:   Intensity of pain in the lower right leg  non-healing ulcer on the right big toe.  History of Present Illness:   About four months ago  Mr. Thompson started experiencing mild pain in his right lower leg which got more severe with time. Notably  the pain was most severe during walks but would subside with rest. An ulcer on the right big toe remained unhealed for the past two months  despite local wound care. He also reported a feeling of coldness and some color change in his right foot as compared to the left.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of smoking (30 pack-years)  Hypertension (HTN)  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM)  and Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD). He had been diagnosed with dyslipidemia 8 years ago.   Family History:   His father died at the age of 75 due to myocardial infarction and his mother died at 72 due to complications from diabetes. He has two elder brothers  one of them has coronary artery disease (CAD) and the other brother has hypertension and diabetes.  Current Medications:  Atenolol 50mg  once daily for HTN; Glipizide 10mg  once daily and Metformin 500mg twice daily for DM; Simvastatin 20mg  once daily for dyslipidemia.  Clinical Examination:   On physical examination  the patient had an unhealed toe ulcer  noticeable pallor  diminished pulse in the right lower limb indicative of impaired circulation. The Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) for the right leg was 0.48 indicative of severe perfusion deficit.  Diagnosis:  Based upon the history  examination findings  and ABI result  the patient was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia.  Plan:  The patient was immediately referred to a vascular surgeon for further treatment  including angioplasty  stent placement  or bypass surgery  depending on the severity and extent of the vascular blockage. Meanwhile  DM  HTN  and dyslipidemia are to be properly managed in coordination with his primary care physician. Strict glycemic control would be ensured to bring Glipizide and Metformin doses to target levels. The patient was counseled on lifestyle modification  including a strict no-smoking policy  maintaining an active lifestyle  and adhering to a fixed diet plan ideal for a diabetic and hypertensive patient. Regular follow-up appointments are recommended.

Patient Information:   A 65-year-old male patient  of Asian descent  with a residence in downtown Boston presented with worsening pain in his lower limbs for the last six months. He also reported some loss of weight  fatigue  and poor appetite over the same period. The patient lives alone  has a sedentary lifestyle  and a 30-year history of cigarette smoking around a half pack/day. He does not consume alcohol and has no known drug allergies. He retired as a school teacher five years ago.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known medical history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes mellitus. Both were diagnosed 15 years ago and are on medication (Metformin for diabetes and Ramipril for hypertension).   Family History:   His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70  while his mother died of stroke complications at 68. He has one sibling  a younger sister who has hypercholesterolemia.   Present Complaint:  He started experiencing dull aching pain in his right lower leg about six months ago. The pain became constant and was aggravated on walking even short distances (claudication) to the point that he required rest to relieve it. Over the last month  he also started experiencing discomfort in his left lower leg and developed a non-healing sore on the right big toe. He denies any trauma to the site. He also shared that he often feels his feet being cold to touch  and has noticed discoloration in his foot areas.   Physical Examination:  Upon examination  peripheral pulses (dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial) were difficult to palpate on both lower limbs. There was a noticeable pallor in both feet  more pronounced in the right one which had a non-healing ulcer over the big toe. His body mass index was 26  and blood pressure was elevated at 145/100 mmHg.   Investigations:  Lab reports showed elevated fasting blood glucose  HbA1c  and lipid profile (LDL  total cholesterol). His cardiac enzymes  including troponin I level were normal. An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test indicated diminished peripheral circulation. Color Doppler Ultrasound of lower limb arteries revealed significant stenosis in both right and left posterior tibial arteries and right anterior tibial artery.   Diagnosis:  Based on the findings  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia was made  and the patient was advised for urgent vascular consultation for possible intervention to restore circulation.  This case reflects the typical sequelae of risk factors such as history of smoking  uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  and high cholesterol which often leads to end-stage peripheral artery disease like Critical Limb Ischemia. Critical Limb Ischemia is a severe obstruction of the arteries resulting in significantly reduced blood flow to the limbs. It is a serious condition  associated with poor prognosis and high rates of morbidity and mortality.   Follow-up / Plan of Care:  The patient was referred to vascular surgery for potential endovascular therapy or bypass surgery. He was advised to continue with his medications  and control his modifiable risk factors like smoking  diet  exercise  and regular monitoring of blood sugar and blood pressure. The importance of foot care was stressed upon him. He is scheduled for a follow-up after a week to chart the progress and see if further interventions are required in his management plan.

Case Presentation: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Confidentiality Reference: Patient X  Patient Background:  Patient X is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of poorly managed type 2 diabetes mellitus for thirty years. He has been reportedly non-compliant with the administration of insulin and only sporadically adheres to the recommended dietary adjustments. The patient also has a history of smoking (1 pack/day for 45 years) and heavy alcohol consumption  which he quit five years ago. Furthermore  the patient suffers from hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which he has been controlling with antihypertensives and statins  respectively.   Demographic Details and Family History:  Patient X is a retired factory worker  divorced  with two children  and currently lives alone in urban New Jersey. His father died of stroke in his early sixties  and his mother succumbed to breast cancer. His 75-year-old brother has coronary artery disease and is a long-term diabetes sufferer as well  but manages his health more carefully.  Onset of Presenting Complaints:  His current issues began approximately four months ago when he noticed intermittent pain in his right lower leg  particularly while walking - a symptom known as claudication. Recently  the pain has considerably worsened and is now present even at rest.   Clinical Examination: Physical examination revealed an absence of pulses in the right tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries. The right lower leg was cold to touch  with noticeable skin discoloration and the presence of superficial ulcers on the toes. His left leg was largely asymptomatic  and arterial flow was normal on Doppler ultrasound.   Diagnostic Tests and Results: After conducting an ankle-brachial index (ABI)  which presented values less than 0.4 and a transcutaneous oxygen pressure (TcPO2) assessment that also showed abnormal results  the patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI) in the right lower limb.   Plan: The critical stage of his illness is requiring a comprehensive interprofessional approach to his health needs. We plan to consult with a vascular surgeon for possible revascularization procedures  a dietitian  a diabetes educator  and a social worker to address his diabetes mismanagement  and a podiatrist for wound management. Patient X will require regular follow-ups with his primary care physician over a prolonged period to monitor his diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. Treatment plans will necessitate significant changes to their lifestyle and strict compliance to prescribed therapies.   This case emphasizes the importance of managing chronic diseases and adhering to treatments as the patient's non-compliance with his diabetes management escalated a possibly preventable condition to a critical state.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old African American male who has been diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI). He hails from Brooklyn  New York  and lives with his wife. He worked as a construction engineer and has been retired for 10 years.   Medical History:  His past medical history is significant for uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus for over 15 years  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. Mr. Smith had previously undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery eight years ago due to ischemic heart disease. His diabetes is associated with peripheral neuropathy  retinopathy  and nephropathy. He is a former smoker with 30 pack-years of smoking but quit after his CABG surgery.   Presenting symptoms:  Mr. Smith presented to the clinic with intense rest pain in his right lower leg that has been going on for several weeks. He also reports non-healing wounds on his right foot and slight skin discoloration. On examination  his right foot appeared pale and cold to touch  with poor capillary refill. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were not palpable.   Family History:  Mr. Smith's family history of cardiovascular disease is significant with his father having a heart attack at 54  and his elder brother has undergone angioplasty for symptomatic peripheral arterial disease (PAD). His mother was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. There is no history of stroke or aneurysm in the family.   Social History:  Mr. Smith is a teetotaller and does not indulge in any substance abuse. His diet mainly contains calorically dense foods with limited intake of fruits and vegetables. Physical activity is minimal. His BMI is 30 and falls under the obese category.  Past and Present Medications:  Mr. Smith has been taking Metformin 500mg twice daily for his diabetes along with Lisinopril 20mg once daily for his hypertension  and Atorvastatin 40mg once daily for his hyperlipidemia. Aspirin 81mg for secondary prevention of heart disease is also part of his medication regimen.  Diagnostic Work-Up:  An Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was performed which revealed an index of 0.3 indicating severe obstruction. Doppler ultrasound imaging revealed significant narrowing of the distal right popliteal artery and absence of flow in the anterior tibial  posterior tibial  and peroneal arteries. Hence  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia was made.  Plan:  The severity of his condition requires urgent intervention. Multidisciplinary care involving a vascular surgeon  endocrinologist  dietitian  podiatrist  and a physical therapist should be put in place. Mr. Smith needs angiography for further assessment followed by revascularization procedure. He needs aggressive management of his blood glucose levels  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  along with dietary modifications  smoking cessation counseling  and regular exercise to improve his overall prognosis.  Informed consent for angiography and possible vascular intervention should be obtained  while also educating the patient on the urgency and benefits of the procedure. Mr. Smith should be prepared for lifestyle modifications and informed of the need for regular follow-ups post intervention.

Patient Profile:  Mr. X  a 72-year-old male  retired mechanic  presented to the outpatient department with complaints of severe pain in his left lower limb  particularly in the foot region for the past month. He also reported experiencing intermittent claudication  or pain during walking that relieved with rest. On further questioning  he disclosed that the discomfort was significantly worse during the night  often disturbing his sleep. He mentioned a recent difficulty in healing a small cut on his foot. He resides with his wife in a suburban setting and is a father of two adult sons.  Medical History: The patient has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes  which is managed with oral hypoglycemics and diet control. He also suffers from hypertension for the past ten years  managed with medication. He is a nonsmoker  moderate alcohol drinker (3-4 drinks weekly for about 30 years)  and denies any illicit drug use. He has a 5-year history of hyperlipidemia  managed with statins.   Family History: Mr. X's father passed away at 85 due to a stroke. His mother died of congestive heart failure at the age of 90. His eldest brother has a history of coronary artery disease and underwent coronary artery bypass grafting at 70.   Physical Examination: On examination  his left foot was found to be cold with pallor and delayed capillary refill time (>3 seconds). The foot had a small non-healing ulcer with necrotic edges on the plantar surface. Pulses in the left foot were weakly palpable. No signs of deep vein thrombosis were detected.   Investigations: Peripheral arterial Doppler ultrasonography showed significantly reduced blood flow at the level of the left popliteal artery  with an ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.4  indicative of severe ischemia. Blood tests indicated poor glycemic control (HbA1c of 9.0%) and elevated LDL cholesterol level.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical scenario and investigation findings  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) secondary to Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) was made.  Disposition: The patient's risk factors like uncontrolled DM  HTN  and hyperlipidemia were addressed. Glycemic control was optimized by adjusting diabetes management  BP control was emphasized  and the statin dosage was increased. He was recommended for smoking cessation and a healthier diet. A vascular surgery consultation was obtained for possible revascularization procedures like angioplasty  stent  or bypass surgery. Multidisciplinary teams involving vascular surgeons  diabetologists  and wound care nurses were engaged for a comprehensive treatment approach.

PRESENTATION OF THE PATIENT:   Mr. Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  came to the hospital with complaints of severe rest pain in his left lower leg for the past three weeks  making it difficult for him to walk or perform any physical activity. He also mentioned the presence of non-healing ulcers on his left foot.   PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:   Mr. Smith has a known medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 20 years  managed with Metformin and Insulin  and Hypertension for 10 years  which is being managed with Lisinopril. He also has dyslipidemia and is on Atorvastatin. He was diagnosed with Renal Insufficiency 2 years ago but has not required dialysis yet. Furthermore  he quit smoking 15 years ago after having been a 1-pack/day smoker for 30 years but continues to consume alcohol moderately.  FAMILY HISTORY:   His father died from a heart attack at the age of 75  his mother is alive and suffers from osteoarthritis  and his brother had a stroke at 62. This throws light on the genetic predisposition Mr. Smith could possibly have toward cardiovascular diseases.  CURRENT MEDICATIONS:  1. Metformin for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  2. Insulin Pen for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  3. Lisinopril for Hypertension  4. Atorvastatin for Dyslipidemia   RELEVANT INFORMATION:  Investigations reveal a significantly diminished left pedal pulse with Doppler studies showing severely reduced blood flow in the left leg  while the right leg appears normal. Additional imaging  including digital subtraction angiography  reveals critical limb ischemia of his left leg and foot  due to occlusion of the distal portion of the left SFA and entire popliteal artery. A diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) is established.  Considering Mr. Smith's existing comorbidities and the severity of his CLI  it is crucial to assess him for potential revascularization. Upon discussing the prognosis and treatment options  Mr. Smith expressed his willingness to proceed with any procedure that could potentially save his leg and improve his quality of life. He understands that without proper intervention  the possibility of amputation is high. In this case  we highly recommend consultation with the vascular surgery team for further management.  Mr. Smith has been advised to regularly check his blood sugar level  maintain a healthy diet  and moderate physical activity as it permits to help manage his diabetes better. He has also been advised to abstain from alcohol. His family has been urged to monitor his health closely and encourage compliance with medication and lifestyle changes. He agrees to adhere to the management plan and schedules follow-up appointments to monitor his progress.

Patient Introduction: Mr. James Schmidt  a 65-year-old male  presented to the emergency department with severe rest pain in the left lower limb  which had been worsening over the past two weeks. An examination revealed coldness  coloring changes  and numbness. Mr. Schmidt resides in Brooklyn with his wife and has been a retired plumber for the past five years. He's a heavy smoker with a 45-year-pack history.   Past Medical History: Mr. Schmidt was diagnosed with type II diabetes approximately fifteen years ago  for which he takes oral anti-diabetic medications regularly. He had an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) six years ago  followed by successful stent placement in the left anterior descending coronary artery. He has been under medication for hyperlipidemia and hypertension for about ten years.  Family History: His father died of massive myocardial infarction at the age of 58  and his mother is alive and well at 85. His elder brother was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) at 60.  Clinical Examination: On examination  his BMI was calculated to be 30.5  and his blood pressure was 155/90 mm of Hg. The left lower limb was notably cooler than the right  with weak femoral and popliteal pulsations and an absence of distal pulses. The ankle-brachial index was 0.4  revealing severe limb ischemia.  Investigations: Lab investigations revealed HbA1c- 8.2%  indicating suboptimal control of diabetes. Electrocardiography  while at rest  was unremarkable. Three sets of angiograms revealed the left superficial femoral artery and distal vessels were profoundly diseased.  Diagnosis: Based on history  clinical presentation  and radiographic finding  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) secondary to atherosclerosis of the lower limb vessels was made.  Care Plan: An immediate referral to a vascular surgeon was arranged for possible peripheral revascularization  and a multidisciplinary team meeting was scheduled. The patient was retained under observation due to severe rest pain. His cardiovascular medications were thoroughly reviewed  and a plan was made to optimize his diabetes control and hypertension.  Preventive measures  such as smoking cessation  weight reduction  and control of lipid profile  were stressed upon. The patient was referred for physiotherapy after the proper treatment of CLI. Regular follow-ups for wound care and further management were planned.  This case highlights the importance of early detection and aggressive treatment of peripheral artery disease  especially in high-risk patients such as those with diabetes and a strong family history of cardiovascular disease. Public health initiatives to encourage smoking cessation  routine exercise  and healthy dietary habits will be a valuable addition in controlling the prevalence of these high-risk diseases.

Patient Identification: Mrs. Gladys Thompson Age: 79 Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Address: 1517 Harvard Street  Omaha  NE  68114 Occupation: Retired  Chief Complaint: Severe pain in the left lower limb  especially when walking and at rest. The patient also reports occasional numbness and coldness in the affected limb.   History of Present Illness: Mrs. Thompson’s symptoms started about 8 months ago  progressively worsening. Two weeks ago her symptoms became constant  which caused her to seek medical attention.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Thompson has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 10 years  Hypertension for 15 years  and high cholesterol for 18 years. She had a stroke 5 years ago with no residual deficits.   Medications: Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes  Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension  and Atorvastatin 20mg once daily for high cholesterol.  Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Family History: Her father had coronary artery disease and her mother had hypertension. Her older brother has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and her younger sister suffered a stroke at the age of 65.   Social History: Mrs. Thompson used to be a heavy smoker  with 30 pack-years history. She quit smoking after her stroke 5 years ago. Her alcohol consumption is minimal  1-2 glasses of red wine per week. She is widowed and lives with her daughter’s family.   Physical Examination & Clinical Findings:  BP: 160/100 HR: 90 bpm  Lower Limb Examination displays: - Left lower limb: Pale and cold to touch when compared to right.  - Left dorsalis pedis pulse: Absent - Left posterior tibial pulse: Absent - Left popliteal pulse: Weak - Right lower limb pulses: All present  Investigations & Diagnosis: Ankle-brachial index was 0.4 for left lower limb and 1.1 for right lower limb. Doppler ultrasound revealed significant stenosis in the left popliteal artery and absent flow in the left posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries. Based on symptoms  physical examination and diagnostic findings  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia was made.   Plan: Refer to a vascular surgeon. Consider managing diabetes  hypertension and other cardiovascular risk factors. Patient education on foot care and regular follow-up are also indicated. Potential treatment may involve revascularization procedures such as percutaneous transluminal angioplasty  atherectomy or bypass surgery.   Prognosis: Critical Limb Ischemia is a severe condition with an estimated 1-year amputation rate of 10%-40% and a mortality rate of 20%-25%.  Prevention & Education: Control of blood glucose  blood pressure and cholesterol levels in conjunction with regular exercise and smoking cessation will significantly reduce the risk of CLI.   References:  - Society for Vascular Surgery Lower Extremity Guidelines Writing Group et al. The management of diabetic foot: A clinical practice guideline by the society for vascular surgery in collaboration with the American Podiatric Medical Association and the Society for Vascular Medicine. Journal of Vascular Surgery 2016;63(2 Suppl):3S-21S. - Norgren L.  et al. Inter-Society Consensus for the Management of Peripheral Arterial Disease (TASC II). European Journal of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery. 2007;33(Supplement 1):S1-S73.

Patient Presentation:   Name: Mr. Johnson Age: 62 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Location: Colorado Springs  Colorado  Mr. Johnson  a 62-year-old male  has presented with severe pain in his right lower limb. The pain persists even during rest and occasionally  he feels burning or prickling sensations. The patient reports a few instances of non-healing ulcers on his right foot as well.  His past medical history includes: 1. 18 years of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  which has been fairly controlled with insulin therapy.  2. Hypertension for the past 10 years  managed with antihypertensive medications.  3. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 5 years ago due to significant heart disease.  He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking  though he quit smoking right after his bypass surgery five years ago. Mr. Johnson admits to occasional alcohol consumption but denies any illicit drug use.  In terms of his family history: 1. His father died in his early sixties due to myocardial infarction 2. His mother died in her late seventies and had been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease.  3. Both his older brother and sister are managing Type II Diabetes and Hypertension.  Examination reveals an absent pulse in his right popliteal  anterior tibial  and dorsalis pedis. His right foot is pale in comparison to the left one and shows signs of atrophy and hair loss.  Based on his symptoms  physical examination  and past medical history  Mr. Johnson has been diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI) of his right lower extremity. CLI is a severe obstruction of the arteries which drastically reduces blood flow to the extremities and has progressed to the point of severe pain and even skin ulcers or sores.  In order to plan further management  we're considering an angiogram to define better the extent and location of arterial disease. Our primary concern is saving Mr. Johnson's right leg  thus surgical or endovascular interventions like angioplasty  bypass grafting  or stent placement may be on the cards depending on angiogram results. Also  pain management  wound care  and aggressive risk-factor modification  including strict diabetic control  will be part of his treatment plan.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Richard Cooper is a 72-year-old African-American male  retired mechanic  referred to vascular surgery for critical limb ischemia diagnosed two weeks ago. He presents with increased complaints of rest pain  severe enough to wake him up at night. He has noticed non-healing ulcers on his left foot with no notable trauma or infection. He also reports intermittent claudication that is affecting his mobility and quality of life.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Cooper is obese with a BMI of 33. He has an extensive past medical history  including type II diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years  hypertension  dyslipidemia  and a 50-pack-year smoking history  but he has been tobacco-free for the last 10 years. He has a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) but no history of cerebrovascular or coronary artery disease.  Examination:  On clinical examination  he has weak pulses in left dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial arteries. There are non-healing ulcers noted on the digits of his left foot. His right leg's peripheral pulses are preserved. No signs of infection were found.  Demographics and Family History:  Mr. Cooper currently lives in a suburban neighborhood with his wife of fifty years. He finished high school and worked as a mechanic in the military. He denies alcohol use but reports quitting smoking ten years ago after the diagnosis of COPD. His father died of a stroke aged 67 and his mother at 79 of unknown cause but had diabetes and hypertension. He has five siblings  two of whom have Type II diabetes and one who had a below-knee amputation due to peripheral artery disease.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is 0.4 on the left side and 0.9 on the right side. Angiogram reveals severe multilevel peripheral artery disease (PAD)  especially in the left lower extremity. The patient is diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) based on the clinical presentation  non-invasive study findings  and angiogram.  Plan:  The goals of intervention for Mr. Cooper are pain relief  wound healing  prevention of limb loss  and improving his quality of life. Given his diagnosis of CLI  revascularization is the most appropriate initial treatment. He will require optimal medical therapy  including antiplatelet therapy  statin therapy  antihypertensive therapy  glycemic control  and smoking cessation  which he has already achieved.   Further  wound care consultation for his foot ulcers  dietary consultation for weight loss  and diabetic education for better diabetes control is also recommended. Cardio-pulmonary rehabilitation and closely supervised exercise programs can be beneficial to improve functional status and quality of life. Regular follow-up reviews are also needed for monitoring disease progression and potential complications.   This comprehensive approach should significantly improve Mr. Cooper's CLI prognosis  and prevent amputation of the limb.

Patient Background:   Mr. A. is a 67-year-old Caucasian male admitted to the vascular surgery department with severe pain in his right lower leg during rest  especially at night. He stated that the pain has been persistent for the past few weeks and has been interrupted by his sleep  which directly led to his loss of productivity and overall quality of life.   Medical History:  Mr. A. has chronic heart disease (CHD)  for which he has been receiving treatment for over a decade. His other comorbidities include type 2 diabetes mellitus that has been managed with oral hypoglycemic agents and diet control for 15 years  as well as stage 2 hypertension that has been maintained with antihypertensive medications for around five years.   The decline in his lower extremity health started around one year ago  with intermittent claudication and slowly progressive distal necrosis on his right foot. Recent progression of ischemic rest pain led the primary care physician to refer the patient to the vascular surgery department.   Family History:  There is a significant family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and his older sister was diagnosed with CHD at the age of 56. Additionally  both his parents had type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Presenting Complaints:  On admission  the patient complained of severe rest pain in the right lower leg  particularly at the toes region. The pain has been increasing in intensity  particularly at night  and is relieved to a certain extent only on hanging the leg at the side of the bed. Skin discoloration  inconsistent and weak pedal pulses  and decreased sensation in the right lower limb were noted. Moderate non-healing ulcers were observed on his right heel and first toe.  Lab Investigations/Diagnostic Tools:  Lab investigations revealed uncontrolled Diabetes (HbA1C 8.5%) and high LDL levels (140 mg/dL). Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was diminished  0.4 on the right side. A Doppler ultrasound showed significant stenosis in the distal part of the right lower extremity.  Based on the clinical picture and diagnostic results  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made.  Management Plan:  Initial management includes analgesia and attempts for swift revascularization. The patient is scheduled for angioplasty  but optimal diabetes and hypertension control is a mandatory step pre-operation. A diabetic foot care specialist has been looped in to manage the non-healing ulcers  and diet modification is advised to manage his LDL levels.  Conclusion:  Critical Limb Ischemia is a severe stage of peripheral artery disease  that often presents as severe rest pain  non-healing ulcers  or gangrene. It is often associated with cardiovascular risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  and dyslipidemia  which were present in this patient. Early recognition and appropriate management are crucial to prevent limb-loss to maintain the patient's quality of life. The ultimate aim is to achieve maximal limb salvage and improve quality of life.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old African American male  hailing from Seattle  Washington. He has been diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI). His presenting symptoms include severe pain in his left foot at rest  non-healing wounds on his toes  and significant difficulty walking short distances due to pain.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a longstanding history of poorly managed type 2 diabetes  diagnosed twenty years ago  and peripheral arterial disease (PAD) that has been worsening progressively for the last five years. He also has a history of hypertension and was previously a heavy smoker  but quit smoking ten years ago.   Family History:  Mr. Johnson's family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. His father passed away with a myocardial infarction at the age of 67  and his older sister was diagnosed with early-onset coronary artery disease at the age of 55. He also has a younger brother who is living with type 2 diabetes.  Social History:  Mr. Johnson is a retired truck driver  living with his spouse in a suburban setting. He admitted to smoking two packs of cigarettes per day over a 35-year period but quit smoking ten years ago. He denies regular alcohol consumption and has an inactive  sedentary lifestyle due to difficulty walking caused by pain. He has three children and six grandchildren and is a widower.  Current Medications and Allergies:  He is currently on Lisinopril for hypertension  and Metformin for diabetes. He has an allergy to Penicillin  presenting as a rash.   Physical Examination:  Clinical examination reveals absent pulses in the left pedal region and an ulcer on the plantar surface of the left foot which is poorly healing  displaying features of chronic ischemia. Furthermore  symptoms of rest pain and claudication further point towards CLI.  Plan:  The plan for Mr. Johnson includes aggressive limb salvage strategies due to the severity of his CLI. This would include initial imaging studies  such as an angiogram  to evaluate the vascular patency and decide on revascularization procedures like angioplasty  bypass surgery  or possibly endovascular techniques. Further examinations to assess wound healing and prevent amputation may be needed.
