Mr. Johnson will also need aggressive management of his comorbidities  including stricter glycemic control for his diabetes and better hypertension management. Lifestyle counseling about diet and exercise would also be beneficial. More frequent follow-ups will ensure progress monitoring and necessary adjustments in his treatment regimen.

Patient Profile:   Mr. Thomas is a 73-year-old Caucasian male  residing in the rural area of Lincoln  Nebraska. He is a retired post-office worker  and currently leads a sedentary lifestyle. He is a known case of Type II diabetes mellitus for the past 12 years  takes oral anti-diabetic medication  and his diabetes is generally well-controlled. He also has a diagnosis for Stage II Chronic Kidney Disease. Mr. Thomas is an ex-smoker  having quit 10 years ago but had a 30 pack-year smoking history. He is married  does occasional gardening which constitutes his minimal physical activity  and lives with his wife of 50 years.   Presenting Complaint:   Mr. Thomas presents to the clinic with chronic  worsening pain in his left lower limb  especially in the calf muscle. He mentions the pain has increasingly affected his sleep over the last month and worsens after mild activity  like walking about 100 meters (Intermittent Claudication). He also complains of ulcers on his left foot that have not been healing for a few weeks now.  Clinical Examination:   Upon physical examination  one can observe non-healing ulcers on his left foot (Gangrene not yet evident). His left leg appears to be paler as compared to his right  particularly when elevated. Pulses on the popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and post-tibial artery are not palpable in the left leg. Pedal skin is also colder on touch in his left leg compared to the right.  Investigations and Diagnosis:   Lower extremity arterial Doppler revealed greater than 50% stenoses in his left femoral and popliteal arteries. His ankle-brachial index (ABI) is below 0.4 in his left leg. Given these findings coupled with the history and examination  Mr. Thomas has been diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) of the left leg.  Family History:   Mr. Thomas's father died at 65  potentially due to a cardiac event  while his mother died at 77 after suffering from dementia. He has two brothers  both of whom are living and well but have a history of diabetes. There is no known familial history of peripheral arterial disease.  Complications and Comorbidities:   Mr. Thomas' diabetes  CKD  and history of smoking place him at high risk for atherosclerosis  potentially contributing to his current condition. If not treated appropriately  CLI could potentially lead to amputation of the affected limb.  Management:   Mr. Thomas has been referred to a vascular specialist. While waiting for his consultation  he has been advised to elevate his leg  avoid crossing his legs  and use a wheelchair for mobility to minimize limb use. His medications have been revised to include aspirin  statins  and ACE inhibitors considering his risk factors and current diagnosis of CLI.

Case Presentation:  Patient Presentation: Our patient  Mr. A  is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presenting with chronic  non-healing wounds on his right lower extremity. He reports experiencing persistent rest pain in his right foot  particularly at night. His pain is described as sharp  constant  and worsens when the leg is elevated. He also complains of numbness and a tingling sensation in the same foot.  Past Medical History: Mr. A has a 10-year history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. He was diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago  and it is controlled with Lisinopril. Due to his medical history  he has a long-standing history of dyslipidemia and a 30-pack year history of smoking  but quit smoking about 6 months ago. His BMI is 28  confirming that he is overweight. He has no known drug allergies.  Family History: His father died at the age of 72 from congestive heart failure  and his mother has a history of Hypertension. He also has a brother who was diagnosed with Peripheral Artery Disease at the age of 66.  Physical Examination: Clinical examination revealed pallor  coolness to the touch  and diminished pulses in the right foot. Ulceration and necrosis were noted on his right foot  particularly at the toes. No apparent signs of infection were present at wound sites.  Diagnostic Evaluation: Angiography revealed significant arterial blockages in his right lower extremity. His ankle-brachial index was significantly reduced  indicative of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). Additional tests  including a duplex ultrasound and CT angiography  confirmed the diagnosis.  Discussion: Mr. A's past medical history of Type 2 Diabetes and hypertension combined with his history of smoking and dyslipidemia put him at high risk for developing vascular diseases like Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). CLI is a severe obstructive peripheral arterial disease where blood supply to the lower extremities is critically reduced causing severe pain  non-healing sores  and potentially can lead to amputation if left untreated.  Treatment Plan: Mr. A was started on an aggressive treatment plan including anticoagulation and lipid-lowering therapy. A vascular surgeon was consulted  and a revascularization procedure  whether endovascular or surgical  was discussed. The patient was educated about the importance of tight blood glucose and blood pressure control  diet  exercise  and smoking cessation. He was also referred to a diabetic foot care program.  Follow-Up: Mr. A will be closely monitored over the coming weeks and months to monitor his response to the treatment. Surgical intervention or revascularization procedures may be necessary if the conservative treatment fails to improve his condition.   Ethical Considerations: Mr. A’s treatment will be executed ensuring absolute privacy  dignity  and consent. His care plan includes shared decision-making  respecting his autonomy  and fostering clear communication between him  his family  and the healthcare team. His mental health will also be constantly reviewed and acted upon due to the high-stress nature of his diagnosis.

Patient Presentation  Patient Profile: Mr. Carlos Hernandez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male residing in Corpus Christi  Texas. He is a retired steelworker and is now leading a sedentary lifestyle. Mr. Hernandez is a widower who lives with his adult daughter. As a lifelong smoker  he has consumed 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. His diet typically includes high-fat foods  which has subsequently led to obesity with a BMI of 32.5 kg/m2.  Presenting Illness:  Mr. Hernandez presented to the hospital with severe pain in his lower left leg that started three weeks ago. He describes the pain as aching and persistent  even while resting. Additionally  he complained of persistent foot ulcers that did not respond to any over-the-counter medicines.  Personal Medical History:  Mr. Hernandez suffers from chronic illnesses  including type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago  hypertension  and a past history of myocardial infarction five years prior to this admission. His regular medicines include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Aspirin.   Family History:  Both his parents died in their late 60s  the father from myocardial infarction and the mother from stroke. His younger sister was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. There is no family history of cancer.  Diagnosis  Investigations & Findings: The ankle-brachial index was performed which revealed a reading below 0.4 (indicating critical limb ischemia) in the left leg. Duplex ultrasound was then conducted  confirming two significant stenoses in the patient's left leg. Severe calcification in the arteries was also noted  which is consistent with diabetes mellitus and long-standing smoking habit.  Management Plan: The vascular surgery team decided to perform an endovascular revascularization. Given the patient's multiple co-morbidities and advanced age  this less invasive option was chosen with an aim to relieve his pain  heal the ulcers  prevent limb loss  and improve his quality of life.  Healthcare team members from cardiology  endocrinology  and nutrition are also involved in managing his cardiovascular health  diabetes  and obesity respectively. A smoking cessation program has been recommended.   Conclusion: This case of Mr. Hernandez underscores the importance of early diagnosis and aggressive management of modifiable risk factors such as smoking  obesity  and diabetes in cases of critical limb ischemia to prevent detrimental outcomes like amputation and increase the quality of life.

Patient Presentation:   Patient Initial: Mr. G    Age: 68 years old  Sex: Male   Race: Caucasian   Occupation: Retired accountant   Presenting Complaint: Severe pain in his left leg that intensified over past few weeks.   Medical History: Mr. G has a history of Type II diabetes diagnosed 15 years ago  managed by oral hypoglycemic agents. He also has hypertension under control through medication for the past 10 years. The patient is a former smoker  having quit smoking five years ago after smoking a packet per day for close to 30 years. There is no known history of allergies.   Family History: Both his parents died in their mid-seventies. His father had a fatal myocardial infarction  and his mother had documented coronary artery disease before dying after a stroke. His elder sister who is 70 lives with Type II diabetes and hypertension.  Examination & Diagnosis: Upon examination  Mr. G had a lower left leg ulcer surrounded by discoloration and foot pallor. The pulse in the left pedal was poorly felt  and a weak popliteal pulse accompanied by severe pain when the limb was raised. Based on these findings and severity of pain  Doppler ultrasound was done to confirm the suspicion which revealed severe reduction in blood flow to the lower part of his left limb. Further angiographic examination confirmed multi-segment disease with significant stenosis. Diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia was made.  Treatment & Management:   As per guidelines  Mr. G had been recommended for revascularization. Post-revascularization  he has been planned for multidisciplinary wound care for the leg ulcer. Pharmacologic therapy includes antiplatelet drugs for preventing complications and statins for managing any associated dyslipidemia. His diabetes and hypertension will be more strictly controlled concerning his new diagnosis.  Prognosis: Owing to the age  diabetes  and diagnosis of severe Critical Limb Ischemia  the prognosis would be guarded and highly dependent on his response to revascularization  wound management  and adherence to medications. Regular follow-ups would be planned to monitor the same.   Patient Education: Mr. G has been counseled about the need for strict glucose and blood pressure control  importance of foot care  wound management  adherence to medication  and healthy lifestyle habits.

Patient Profile: Name: John Doe Age: 65 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Electrician Location: New York  USA  Chief Complaint:  The patient complains of severe pain in his right leg that increases during the night. He also notes ulcers or sores in the same leg that are slow in healing  indicating possible poor blood circulation.  Medical History:  The patient has an underlying condition of Type II Diabetes which has been poorly managed over the past 10 years. He has been a smoker for over 40 years  which has led to hypertension and high cholesterol levels. In 2005  he was diagnosed with coronary artery disease resulting in a CABG procedure the same year.  Family History:  His mother died of a myocardial infarction at 73  and his father had passed away due to a stroke at the age of 80. The patient also has one brother who has been recently diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).  Physical Examination: Upon examination  the right foot presents with coolness compared to the left and distinct signs of atrophy of the skin. Pulses are weak distally. There is a small ulcer on the big toe.  Investigations: An ankle-brachial index (ABI) test showed that the patient's ratio is significantly decreased  indicating blockage or narrowing of the arteries in the leg.  Diagnosis: Given these symptoms and the results of the ABI test  John Doe has been diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Treatment Plan: The treatment focuses on risk factor modification  exercise regimen  and possible intervention by angioplasty or vascular surgery to increase blood flow to the affected leg. The patient must stop smoking. Strict control of his blood glucose  blood pressure  and cholesterol levels will be necessary to prevent further arterial damage.  John's condition needs to be monitored closely as CLI increases the chance of heart attack  stroke  and amputation. This treatment plan will require a multidisciplinary team that includes his primary care physician  a vascular surgeon  a podiatrist  a dietician  and a diabetes educator.  Prognosis: The progression of CLI can be slowed down with suitable treatment and lifestyle changes  but the overall prognosis will largely depend on how well the patient can manage his co-existing pathologies  especially his diabetes and smoking habits.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 73-year-old white male with a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). He was brought into the emergency department with symptoms of severe pain in both his lower limbs. This pain has been persisting at rest and often deprives him of sleep. On examination  the limbs were notably pale with weak to absent peripheral pulses. Doppler ultrasound confirmed lower blood flow in his limbs.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a significant medical history of type-2 diabetes and peripheral arterial disease (PAD). He also has high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia and has been a chronic smoker for around 50 years. His diabetes has been generally poorly controlled over the years  leading to the development of PAD and eventually CLI. He also has a 10-year history of coronary artery disease and had angioplasty done twice in the past.  Family History:  Mr. Smith's father died young at the age of 67 due to congestive heart failure and his mother passed away from a stroke when she was 82. His eldest brother has type-2 diabetes and a personal history of myocardial infarction. There is also a huge family history of smoking on both sides.  Social History:  John Smith is a retired truck driver and currently lives with his wife in rural Alabama. He has two children  both living out of state. His lifestyle has been largely sedentary since retiring. He has been a chronic smoker since he was 23 years old  smoking a packet a day. He denies alcohol use.  Conclusion/Discussion:  Mr. Smith's CLI custody is severe and is worrying considering his medical and family history. His history of poorly controlled diabetes  PAD  chronic smoking  and coronary artery disease makes him at high risk for cardiovascular events and limb loss. He is presently under discussion for revascularization pending additional assessment of anatomical involvement and comorbid conditions.  Prompt and effective CLI management is extremely crucial considering its high morbidity and mortality rates  particularly in patients like Mr. Smith with a multiple comorbid condition. Integrated medical and interventional treatments  lifestyle changes  and possible surgical intervention are potential options for managing his condition. Moreover  better control of his diabetes is needed to prevent further complications.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jim McBride  a 67-year-old  retired truck driver  white male presented to the clinic with a complaint of increasingly severe pain in his right lower limb which gets intense during the night. He also reported non-healing sores since the last 3 weeks  his wife had noticed the shin of the leg turning shiny and blue.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Jim has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus that has been poorly controlled for the last 15 years  as well as hypertension. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history and quit smoking ten years ago. He also has obesity with a BMI of 32 kg/m2. Past surgical history is notable for appendectomy as a young adult. His regular medication includes metformin  lisinopril  and low-dose aspirin.  Family History:  His father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 69 and his mother passed away at the age of 74 with complications related to diabetes. His younger sister underwent bypass surgery on her leg at age 64. He claimed no history of deep vein thrombosis  known clotting disorders  or malignancy in his family.  Physical Examination:  Physical exam revealed a cool to touch right foot with weak popliteal and absent dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses. Distal hair loss with shiny skin  as well as non-healing  slightly foul-smelling ulcerations on the right foot  were observed. Capillary refill was >10 seconds and pedal edema was present. He had palpable femoral and popliteal pulses on the left side. A monofilament test revealed significant peripheral neuropathy. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Pertinent Information:  Mr. Jimmy is retired and lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver. He used to consume alcohol socially but quit the same time when he quit smoking. Mr. Jim's mobility is also compromised due to consistent limb pain. His diabetes management has been inconsistent  largely due to limited health literacy.  Given the patient’s history  clinical presentation  and physical examination findings  a diagnosis of Critical limb ischemia (CLI) was made.  Management:  Multidisciplinary management is required for holistic care  including optimizing diabetes control  a cardiovascular evaluation for atherosclerotic disease  and a vascular surgery consultation for potential revascularization. Meanwhile  analgesia  wound care  diet optimization  and limb elevation strategies were encouraged.

Patient's Profile: Mr. Adams  a 68-year-old African-American male  was brought to the emergency department with complaints of increasing pain and discoloration in his right foot over the past three weeks.   Past Medical History: Mr. Adams has a 20-year history of uncontrolled Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 and hypertension. He was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease four years ago for which he has been on medication. Despite his medical conditions  he has continued to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 45 years.  Demographics: Mr. Adams is a retired auto mechanic. He lives with his wife of 40 years and is parent to three grown-up children. He maintains a sedentary lifestyle and his diet mostly includes high-fat and high-calorie foods.   Family History: His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 56 and his mother had a stroke in her late sixties. Sibling and children health history is unremarkable except for his younger sister  aged 64  who is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.   Clinical Assessment and Findings: Upon clinical examination  Mr. Adams' right foot showed signs of severe ischemia with areas of dry gangrene  suggestive of critical limb ischemia (CLI). He reported pain at rest and open sores that are slow to heal. Lower extremity pulses were diminished. His Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) was calculated to be less than 0.4 indicating severe circulation problems in the affected leg. Buerger's test was positive. His blood panel revealed an elevated glucose level and HbA1c of 8.9%. EKG showed signs of left ventricular hypertrophy.  Diagnosis and Management: Mr. Adams was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia secondary to his peripheral artery disease  uncontrolled diabetes mellitus  chronic smoking and advanced age. An urgent vascular surgery consult was obtained. He was commenced for immediate revascularization to restore blood flow. Concurrently  an endocrinology consult was obtained to optimize his diabetes control. He was also referred to a dietitian and smoking cessation program. His family was counseled about his condition and the necessity of lifestyle modifications.  Conclusion: Mr. Adams' case illustrates the detrimental impact of uncontrolled diabetes  smoking  and unhealthy lifestyle habits on vascular health leading to severe complications like critical limb ischemia. Intensive blood glucose control  lifestyle modifications including quitting smoking  and consultations with specialists for proper management can help prevent the potentially devastating consequences of this condition. Timely revascularization and adequate postoperative care are also key to improving outcomes.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 76-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Davies. He resides in a nursing home in Pennsylvania. He is a widower with two adult children  and a retired coal miner.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Davies presented with severe resting pain in his right lower leg which has been troubling him for the last 8-9 months. The pain intensifies especially at night causing sleep disturbances. He also reported the presence of non-healing ulcers in his right foot  present for around 4 months.  Medical History: Mr. Davies has a past medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 20 years  Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) secondary to a long history of smoking  and hypertension. He had myocardial infarction 8 years ago  followed by coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery  and has been on statins and anti-platelets since then.  Family History: Both of Mr. Davies’ parents suffered from heart disease and his father had suffered from a stroke at the age of 80. His sibling  a brother (now deceased) had a history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD).   Social History: Mr. Davies has been in a care facility for three years  after the demise of his wife. Prior to this  he was a heavy smoker (two packs per day for 35 years) but has quit smoking since his heart surgery in 2013.  Physical Examination & Diagnosis: On physical examination  the doctor noted coolness of the right leg below knee  pallor on elevation  dependent rubor and diminished pulse intensity. An abnormal finding was pain at rest. An ulcer was noted on the right foot with blacken changes suggesting gangrene. On auscultation  there were coarse crackles sounds in both lungs.   The weighing of all clinical information considered  Mr. Davies was diagnosed with “critical limb ischemia (CLI) of the right leg”.  Treatment Plan: Mr. Davies’ treatment plan is two-fold: management of pain  and restoration of blood flow to the limb. The doctor has planned for revascularization  either surgical or endovascular  to restore blood flow. If this proves impossible  then amputation of the gangrene-affected parts may be inevitable to stop the spread of infection. Efforts will also be made to control Mr. Davies’ blood sugar and blood pressure  to manage his COPD and to counsel him about the disease condition and its possible outcomes  as well as steps he can take to manage it. Close monitoring will be needed throughout the course of treatment and follow-ups arranged.  Prognosis:  The prognosis is uncertain due to the age and other associated comorbid conditions of the patient. It's crucial that Mr. Davies understands the severity of his condition and cooperates fully with the medical team for possible favourable outcomes.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Details: Mr. Jones  a 65-year-old African American male presents to the clinic.  Chief Complaint: He complains of rest pain in his left foot and non-healing ulcerations on his left toes that have been present for approximately six to eight weeks.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant past medical history including type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He has a 25-year pack history of smoking and admits to drinking alcohol socially. He had an MI five years ago  which was managed with angioplasty and stenting.   Allergies: He has no known drug or food allergies.  Family History: His mother died at age 70 due to a stroke and his father had coronary artery disease. He has one brother who has been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus and hypertension.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  Mr. Jones is in obvious discomfort. His left foot is pale with diminished warmth indicating poor circulation. There are two ulcerations on the dorsal aspect of the second and third toes. Pulses are absent on the left foot. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.   Lab Workup: His fasting glucose and A1C levels are elevated. His lipid profile shows high LDL cholesterol. Other lab results including kidney function tests are within normal limits.  Imaging Studies: Based on clinical suspicion  peripheral angiography was performed showing significant stenosis and occlusion in the left lower limb vessels  confirming the diagnosis of critical limb ischemia.  Impression and Plan: Mr. Jones was admitted for intravenous analgesia  antibiotics and optimized control of his vascular risk factors including his diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. A vascular surgical consult was requested for possible revascularization procedure to restore blood flow.  This case highlights the importance of recognizing critical limb ischemia in patients with risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  and smoking. Early detection and treatment can prevent serious complications such as limb amputation. Patient education about risk factor control is also crucial in these cases.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J is a 76-year-old African-American male who initially presented with a chief complaint of worsening pain in his right lower extremity for the past six weeks. The pain was described as severe  constant  and was not alleviated by rest. He reported that the pain had been intermittent for a few months  but it had progressively become more intense and continuous. The patient's lower extremity was observed to be cold  with mottled skin and no palpable pulses.  Past Medical History:  He has a significant past medical history  including a 20-year history of hypertension  well-managed type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. The patient had been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 50 years but quit about five years ago. He also had a minor stroke two years ago with no residual effects.  Family History:  The patient's family history revealed that his father died at the age of 60 from myocardial infarction  and his mother had diabetes and hypertension. His brother  currently 72  has coronary artery disease.  Pertinent Information:  Mr. J reports a decrease in his mobility due to pain  can barely walk short distances  and needs frequent rests  which has dramatically affected his quality of life and made him gain significant weight due to lack of activity. Additionally  he reported no changes in his diet and has been consistent with taking his prescribed antihypertensive and diabetic medications.  On clinical examination  his blood pressure was found to be elevated at 150/90 mmHg  but the rest of the examination was unremarkable except for the lower extremity findings. His laboratory tests were normal.  Power Doppler ultrasound revealed markedly diminished blood flow in the patient's lower right limb. Subsequent angiography confirmed severe peripheral artery disease with critical stenosis of the right superficial femoral artery.  Impression:  The diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was made based on the patient's clinical symptoms  evidence of poor blood circulation in the affected limb  and imaging studies.  Through this case  we can see how several factors played a part in the development of CLI in this patient – uncontrolled hypertension  a significant history of smoking  a sedentary lifestyle  and an undiagnosed peripheral artery disease. It reinforces the importance of regular screenings for peripheral artery disease in patients with significant risk factors or symptoms suggestive of CLI.   Treatment Plan:  Mr. J was referred for vascular intervention with angioplasty and stenting  to improve blood flow to the limb  and to a dietician to help manage his weight. He was also prescribed antihypertensive and lipid-lowering drugs to manage his cardiovascular risk factors. Regular follow-ups were scheduled to monitor his condition and adjust his treatment plan as necessary.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  referred by his primary care physician due to complaints of severe pain in his left lower extremity. He has a known medical history of diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia  all managed with medication. He is a former smoker and quit 15 years ago. He has a history of alcohol consumption but cut back substantially over the last 5 years. He is retired and is living with his wife.  Presenting Problem:  The patient has been experiencing worsening pain in his left lower leg over the past four months  especially at night and during rest. It has disturbed his sleep and routine activities  leading to decreased mobility. He also reports a non-healing ulcer on his left foot.  Physical Examination:  Physical examination revealed an active  non-healing ulcer on the dorsal aspect of his left foot. There was pallor on elevation  increased dependency rubor and cold skin temperature on the left lower extremity. Pulse palpation was diminished in the left femoral  popliteal  dorsalis pedis  and posterior tibial arteries  with normal pulses in the opposite extremity.  Tests:  A comprehensive peripheral vascular examination and an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test were performed along with a Doppler ultrasound which confirmed significantly decreased blood flow to the left lower extremity  indicative of advanced peripheral artery disease. His ABI was 0.40 which is indicative of severe arterial insufficiency. Further angiography demonstrated severe obstructive lesions in his left iliac and superficial femoral arteries.  Conclusion:  Based on the clinical evidence  medical history  and diagnostic results  the patient was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Management:  The patient was referred to a vascular surgeon for consideration of possible endovascular revascularization. A consultation with a podiatrist was also made for wound care management.  Family History:  The patient’s father had myocardial infarction at 65  and his mother had a stroke at 70. He has a brother who also has diabetes and hypertension. There’s no known family history of peripheral artery disease or similar vascular diseases.    This case underscores the importance of early recognition and management of risk factors  particularly in individuals with a known medical history of diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. It also emphasizes the importance of thorough physical examination and the use of ABI in assessing patients suspected of having PAD or CLI. Coping with CLI not only involves alleviating the painful symptoms but also managing the associated wound through proper foot care and possible revascularization.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 68-year-old African American male  Presenting Concern: Mr. Smith was brought to the emergency department complaining of severe pain and darkened skin on his left lower leg that has gradually worsened over the last 2 weeks.   Medical History: Mr. Smith is a long-standing patient and his records from prior visits reveal that he is a diagnosed Type 2 Diabetic for the past 15 years. There is a history of Hypertension and Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) as well. No other remarkable diseases are identified in his past medical history.   Social History:  The patient is a former smoker who has quit 5 years ago. He reports drinking alcohol socially. He is a retired construction worker who lives with his wife and has limited physical activity due to the pain in his leg.  Family History: His family history reveals that his father had peripheral artery disease (PAD) and died from a stroke  and his mother had coronary artery disease and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.  Examination and Diagnosis: Upon physical examination  the left lower leg was noted to be colder to touch and showed signs of mottled  darkened skin  with non-healing sores. Pedal pulses were not palpable on the left side. These signs were consistent with the onset of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Investigations: An Ankle-Brachial Index was conducted  revealing an ABI score of 0.40 (normal range: 1.0-1.4). A Doppler ultrasound showed significant stenosis in the left popliteal artery.   Management: The patient was started on dual antiplatelet therapy and statins to manage the disease. Subsequently  he was referred to a vascular surgeon to review the possibility of revascularization surgery. His diabetic medication was adjusted  and the patient was also advised to follow a healthy diet and engage in moderate exercise.   Prognosis:  The patient's prognosis is guarded considering his age and the severity of the CLI. The presence of chronic comorbid conditions (Diabetes  Hypertension  CKD) can complicate the recovery and increase the risk of amputation.   This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate management of PAD in preventing the progression to CLI  notably in diabetics. It also underscores the need for patient education and lifestyle modifications in managing chronic conditions.

Patient Introduction:   The patient  Mr. Alberto Russo  is a 64-year-old Caucasian male who resides in Sacramento  California. He's a retired construction worker and is currently living alone. Mr. Russo first came to the clinic complaining of ongoing severe discomfort and pain in his left lower limb  particularly while resting.  Medical History:  Mr. Russo has a considerable medical history. He has been a type 2 diabetic for the past 12 years and manages his condition with oral anti-diabetic agents. He is also a hypertensive patient over 10 years and currently has his blood pressure under control with the usage of ACE inhibitors. Mr. Russo is a previous smoker  having quit 15 years ago  but with a total of 30 pack-years.  Current Problem:  Mr. Russo’s chief complaint is the severe pain in left lower limb. He’s been experiencing this pain for the last 2 months  stating it's worse while resting or during the night. He also notices that wounds and ulcers on his left leg heal slower than expected. He had presented with a large non-healing ulcer on his left foot. There is no history of fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath.  Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  the skin of the affected limb was cooler to the touch compared with the opposite limb. Pulses in the left foot were feeble as compared to the right foot. There were no palpable popliteal  femoral  or dorsalis pedis pulses on the left side. The ulcer on his left foot was significant and showed no imminent signs of healing.  Preliminary Diagnosis:  Considering Mr. Russo’s medical history and presenting symptoms  along with the physical examination findings  the preliminary diagnosis was that of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).  Investigation:  Mr. Russo’s Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) test results were 0.4. Duplex ultrasound and CT angiography were conducted  revealing a significant decrease in blood flow to the left lower limb with multiple blockages. A vascular examination established the presence of peripheral arterial disease in his left leg.  Management and Treatment  The primary treatment goal for Mr. Russo is to alleviate his pain  heal the foot ulcer  halt disease progression  and improve his overall quality of life. The typical first-line therapy would be balloon angioplasty. Considering the extent and location of his blockages  a vascular specialist will need to determine if he is a candidate for a vascular bypass procedure or angioplasty. In any case  medication adjustments  regular exercise  and a healthy diet will be important parts of his overall management strategy.  Family History:  His father had a history of coronary artery disease and his mother was a type 2 diabetic. There is no known hereditary illness present in the immediate family.   This case presentation highlights the patient’s complex clinical condition and the necessity for a multidisciplinary approach to improve Mr. Russo’s quality of life and reduce the risk of amputation.  Follow-Up:  Mr. Russo was scheduled for a follow-up within two weeks  with instructions to seek immediate medical attention should his condition worsen in the meantime. A vascular specialist will be consulted within this timeframe. During the follow up visit  his wound healing and pain score will be assessed. Future follow-ups will be scheduled on a regular basis as effective management of CLI requires close and continuous care.

Patient Information:  	 Mr. Smith  a 65-year-old African-American male  is being evaluated for critical limb ischemia. He hails from a suburban background and is a retired firefighter.   Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Smith has been experiencing ongoing  severe pain in his right lower extremity  even while at rest. He reports a decrease in temperature in his right leg compared to the left one and points out visible color changes in the leg including pallor and redness. He also noticed a non-healing wound on his right toe that appeared about two months ago.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes for 15 years and hypertension for ten years. He also was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease 5 years ago and takes aspirin  atorvastatin  and ramipril. He was a heavy smoker  but quit five years ago following his diagnosis of peripheral arterial disease.   Family History:  His father succumbed to an ischemic stroke at the age of 70  and his mother had heart disease. He has one brother currently managed for diabetes and peripheral arterial disease.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the right foot had weak to non-palpable pulses. A significant decline in temperature was obvious through palpation. A 2cm by 2cm non-healing ulcer was noted on his big toe  with no apparent infection.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Mr. Smith had an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) which was less than 0.40 on the right  pathological state confirming severe obstruction. His complete blood count (CBC)  lipid profile and glucose level showed increased triglycerides and uncontrolled glycemic level.  Management Plan:  Our multidisciplinary approach to Mr. Smith’s critical limb ischemia includes managing his diabetes  hypertension  and cholesterol with appropriate medications  diet  and lifestyle management. He also undergoes revascularization using angioplasty. His wound care was managed by the wound care specialist team. We have discussed the potential of amputation if the situation doesn't improve.  He has been educated on the importance of smoking cessation  maintaining good foot hygiene  exercise  and a balanced diet. Regular follow-ups have been arranged for constant monitoring of his health status and to ensure timely medical intervention. We are also considering the possibility of including Psychosocial support  if necessary.  In conclusion  Mr. Smith's case of critical limb ischemia is complex due to his comorbid conditions. His management plan includes both aggressive treatment to restore blood flow and comprehensive management of his comorbid conditions to prevent future complications.

Patient Presentation:  Subject Details: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named John Smith.  Past Medical History: John Smith has a history of uncontrolled type-2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia. He has battled hypertension for the last five years  and is currently on medication for the same. He is a former smoker  with a history of about 50-pack years  but quit 8 years ago. He also underwent CABG (coronary artery bypass grafting) following a heart attack 6 years ago. He reports being non-compliant with his diabetic medication regimen in recent months due to financial constraints.  Social History: Mr. Smith lives alone and has been retired for six years now. He does not drink alcohol or use any illegal drugs.   Family History: His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 57  his mother had type 2 diabetes and lived till the age of 73. His younger brother is also diabetic but has it under control with oral medication. There is a family history of heart diseases and type 2 diabetes.  Presenting Illness: Mr. Smith was hospitalized following complaints of severe pain in his left leg  primarily in the calf region. The pain tends to intensify with physical activity but is consistently present  even when resting. He also reported to have noticed a non-healing wound on his left foot.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed pale skin  loss of hair on the lower left limb  non-palpable pulses  and a small necrotic ulcer on the left foot. On auscultation  reduced breath sounds were heard at the bases indicating possible peripheral arterial disease. Lab reports showed increased blood sugar levels.   Diagnosis: Based on all the clinical findings  a diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI) secondary to peripheral artery disease was made. This decision was supported by duplex ultrasound results showing severely reduced blood flow in the lower extremity.  Prognosis: The patient is at high-risk due to his age  uncontrolled diabetes  previous history of heart disease  and non-compliance with medication. It is critical to initiate appropriate treatment immediately to prevent limb loss. Long-term management of his diabetes and other comorbidities is also crucial for favorable outcomes.  Plan: The management plan includes revascularization through bypass surgery or angioplasty to restore limb perfusion. It also includes optimizing glycemic control  managing his hypertension and hyperlipidemia  quit smoking counseling  wound care  pain management  and physical rehabilitation post-revascularization surgery.   This case demonstrates the aggressive steps required for managing CLI  particularly in patients with multiple risk factors. It is essential to improve the patient’s compliance with long-term therapy and lifestyle modifications to increase the chances of a successful outcome.

Patient Profile Patient Initials: M.W  Age: 65  Sex: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired Truck Driver Residence: Nashville  Tennessee  Presentation of the Patient M.W.  a 65-year-old retired truck driver  presents with severe pain in the lower extremities  particularly in his right foot. He reports a persistent onset of rest pain over the last six weeks that is not alleviated even during non-ambulatory periods. Physical examination shows a cyanotic right foot and a cold left foot. He also demonstrates intermittent claudication after walking for short distances  further compounded by the presence of non-healing ulcers on the right foot.  Past Medical History M.W. is hypertensive and has been managing it for the past 20 years. He is also a type II diabetic and a chronic smoker  with a history of smoking for the last 40 years  a pack every day. He had a myocardial infarction five years ago and underwent successful angioplasty.  Family History There is a family history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and coronary heart disease in M.W.'s family. His father died of a heart attack at 65  and his older brother (68) suffers from PAD.  Diagnosis Considering the clinical presentation  past medical history  and family history  M.W. was diagnosed with Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  the most severe form of PAD.  Current Management Currently  M.W. is on antiplatelet agents  statins  and ACE inhibitors for routine management of his cardiovascular disease and hypertension. His type II diabetes is being controlled using metformin and diet control. He has also been prescribed pain medications to manage his ischemia pain.  In the context of M.W.'s case  his diagnosing physician has referred him to a vascular surgeon for evaluation of his CLI. The possibility of femoropopliteal bypass surgery or an angioplasty has been discussed  based on PACS results.   In addition to medical management  M.W. has been strongly advised to quit smoking  maintain a balanced diet  and keep his hypertension and diabetes under control to prevent further damage.  Prognosis M.W.'s prognosis largely relies on adherence to both medical and lifestyle recommendations given by his provider. With successful surgical intervention  his immediate relief of CLI symptoms is highly likely. However  his past history and continued smoking habit do indicate he is at high risk for recurrent PAD and other cardiovascular conditions. Early intervention and strict compliance to lifestyle modifications will be central in managing his condition.

Patient Case Presentation  Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the hospital with a primary diagnosis of critical limb ischemia (CLI). He has been experiencing worsening pain in his left lower extremity  ulcers that didn't heal  and foot discoloration that turned black over the past month.  Demographics: Mr. Smith is a retired construction manager. He is currently living in a suburban area with his wife.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 for the past 20 years and underlying peripheral artery disease (PAD). Other relevant past medical conditions include Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia which are controlled with medication. He quit smoking ten years ago but had a 30-year pack history prior to quitting. He also acknowledges sporadic alcohol ingestion. There is no history of any surgical procedures.  Presenting Complaint: He complains of severe  persistent pain in his left foot  even while at rest. Pain is reported to be 8/10  and not relieved by over-the-counter painkillers.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the left foot appeared pale with blackened areas on multiple toes  indicative of gangrene. Pulses were absent on Doppler examination in the left foot. The temperature of the left foot was significantly lower compared to the right foot. Foot ulcers were noted on the plantar surface. Neurological assessment indicates decreased sensation in the left foot.  Family History: His father died of a heart attack at the age of 70 and his mother had a stroke at 75 but is currently living. He also has a brother who is living with heart disease. Given this history  there might be a genetic susceptibility to atherosclerosis.  Investigations: Blood tests were conducted  confirming poor glycemic control (HbA1c - 8.5%) and abnormal lipid profile. Ankle-Brachial index was significantly decreased in the left lower extremity. An angiography was recommended to pinpoint the exact location and severity of artery blockage.  Next Steps: Given this clinical picture  an urgent vascular surgery consultation is crucial for possible revascularization procedures to restore blood flow and prevent amputation.  In summary  Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old male  with a history of uncontrolled Diabetes Mellitus Type 2  Hyperlipidemia  and Hypertension  presenting with critical limb ischemia. His condition is most likely a result of peripheral arterial disease exacerbated by his metabolic conditions and past history of smoking. His immediate treatment plan will aim at pain management  glycemic control  managing his lipid profile  and importantly  re-establishment of blood supply to his ischemic limb. Further education regarding smoking cessation  diet control  and management of diabetes is also essential in management to prevent further complications.

Case Study:  Patient Overview:  Mr. Carlos Gonzalez  a 68-year-old Hispanic male from Los Angeles  presents with severe pain in his left lower extremity. He lives alone and is independent with ADLs. He has no known allergies and is a non-smoker who quit 15 years ago after a 25-year history of tobacco use.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Gonzalez has a significant past medical history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and Chronic Kidney Disease (Stage 3). He is currently on Metformin  Lisinopril  and Amlodipine. Furthermore  he had a surgical history of right eye cataract removal 3 years ago.  Family History:  The patient's family history is critical  with his father passing away due to myocardial infarction at 70 years  and his mother suffering a stroke at 67 years. His younger brother was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease at 65 years old.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Gonzalez has been experiencing severe  intermittent pain in his left calf for the past six months. He reports the pain intensifies while walking but subsides at rest. Recently  he began experiencing pain at rest  predominantly at night. He also noted a non-healing wound on his left foot  which has persisted for the past three months despite ongoing wound care.  Examination and Diagnosis:  Upon examination  his left lower extremity is noticeably cooler compared to the right. Pulses are non-palpable distally and a non-healing ulcerative wound is seen on the medial side of the left foot. Lower extremity peripheral pulses are reduced on the left compared to the right. Based on these findings  a diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) was suspected and confirmed through ABI (Ankle-Brachial Index) which came back as 0.3 for left lower extremity and ultrasound Doppler showing significantly reduced blood flow.  Treatment Plan:  Mr. Gonzalez was referred to a vascular surgeon for further management. His current medications were adjusted with the addition of Cilostazol to improve blood flow and aspirin to prevent clotting. Education provided on blood glucose control  foot care  and the importance of regular follow-ups.   The multidisciplinary team - including the vascular surgeon  nurse  dietician  and a social worker - comes up with a comprehensive care plan which includes optimizing medical therapy  considering revascularization  active surveillance of foot lesions  renal protective strategies  and home assistance considering his living alone circumstances.  This case highlights the importance of a high degree of suspicion for CLI in patients with known risk factors presenting with rest pain or non-healing wounds. Swift diagnosis and management can prevent the dire consequences associated with progression of this disease  including amputation and death.

Patient Profile: Mr. John Doe  a 78-year-old Caucasian male residing in Seattle  presented with a complaint of worsening pain and skin ulcerations in his right lower extremity  particularly when lying down or walking short distances  for the past four weeks.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has been a long-term smoker with a 40-pack-year history. He has hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  poorly managed due to patient’s non-compliance to medications and diet control. He had a myocardial infarction about six years ago  managed with a coronary artery stent placement.  Family History: There is a strong family history of peripheral artery disease on his mother's side with both his mother and uncle having been treated for this condition. His older brother died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 68 and his father had hypercholesterolemia.  Presenting Symptoms: Four weeks ago  Mr. Doe began experiencing pain in his right lower extremity  particularly in the calf muscle  during walking. The condition has now worsened to the extent the pain persists at rest and increases during the night while laying flat. He has also started developing non-healing sores on the same foot  mostly on weight-bearing areas  such as his heel.  Examination: Physical examination reveals a pale  cold right foot with diminished sensation. Pulses in the right leg are decreased. An ulcer measuring 1.2 cm in diameter and surrounded by necrotic tissue is seen on his right heel. No significant edema or palpable crepitus noted.   Diagnosis: Based on presenting symptoms  clinical examination findings  and past medical history  he was diagnosed with critical limb ischemia (CLI) secondary to peripheral artery disease.  Management: Mr. Doe was immediately started on analgesics for pain and antibiotics to prevent infection at the ulcer site. Given his non-healing ulcers and the level of pain he's been experiencing  the vascular surgeon has been consulted for a potential revascularization procedure to restore blood flow. Aggressive management of his co-morbidities  particularly his diabetes and hypertension  are also being pursued. Smoking cessation counseling has been initiated.   Follow Up: He has been referred for wound care for management of the foot ulcer and will continue to receive regular follow-up to assess the effectiveness of his treatment plan and look for any potential complications of CLI  such as tissue necrosis and potential amputation.  Discussion: Critical limb ischemia is the severe form of peripheral artery disease and is a serious condition associated with poor outcomes. As Mr. Doe is also dealing with significant co-morbidities such as hypertension  diabetes  and history of MI  it is crucial that his overall care plan addresses these factors for effective management of his health.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mr. Stevens Age: 65 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired truck driver Smoking History: 30 pack-years  Chief Complaint: Mr. Stevens presents with complaints of progressively worsening severe persistent pain in his lower left extremity at rest for the past few months. The pain often becomes more intense at night to the extent of disturbing his sleep. Recently  he has also noticed a small non-healing ulcer on his left foot.  Past Medical History: He has uncontrolled diabetes for the past ten years and moderate hypertension for the last eight years. He was also diagnosed as obese a couple of years ago. He has been treated for these conditions  but his adherence to his medication and diet has been suboptimal. No prior history of surgery or any significant injury. He resigned from his job five years ago due to worsening health conditions. He has a history of smoking but quit five years ago.  Family History: His father had peripheral arterial disease and underwent amputation due to gangrene development. His mother had hypertension and died due to stroke.  Review of Systems: In addition to the significant constant pain in the left foot  Mr. Stevens reports feeling intermittent cramps in the same leg during short walks. The pain sometimes improves if he dangles his foot off the edge of the bed. He also notes occasional dizziness  loss of appetite  fatigue and intermittent night sweats.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  the left foot is cooler to touch compared to the right. There is a small  non-healing ulcer on the big toe with minimal discharge. The pulses in the left foot are considerably weaker as compared to the right foot. The rest of the exam was unremarkable.   Diagnosis: Mr. Stevens' condition is suggestive of critical limb ischemia. Subsequent investigations (including Doppler ultrasound  angiography  blood tests  and possibly tissue biopsy) are needed to confirm the diagnosis and the underlying cause.   This clinical scenario emphasizes the importance of understanding the pathophysiology  evaluation  and management of critical limb ischemia  particularly in patients with common risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  obesity  and smoking.

Case Report:  Patient Identification:  Patient X is a 65-year-old African American male.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant medical history that includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes  and smoking. He also reports a history of heart disease in close relatives.   Chief Complaint: Patient presents with severe pain in his right lower limb  particularly during rest. He also reports experiencing intermittent claudication  which has increasingly become severe over the last six months. The pain is characterized as being deep and unrelenting  often disturbing his sleep.   Physical Findings: On examination  the right lower extremity is observed to appear pale and feels cooler to touch compared to the left. There is loss of hair below the right knee and dystrophic nail changes. The patient also reports occasional numbness and the skin on the leg looks shiny. Pulses in the right leg are weak. The foot appears to be slightly discolored with non-healing ulcers on the right heel and toe.  Brief Case Overview: This case presents consistent symptoms of critical limb ischemia (CLI). The patient’s medical history and lifestyle (smoking) imply an increased risk of cardiovascular conditions. The condition is suggested by the presence of rest pain  non-healing ulcers or gangrene in the lower limbs. The severity of the patient's symptoms indicates CLI  which is the most severe form of peripheral artery disease. Timely diagnosis and treatment are crucial to limit disease progression and prevent limb loss.

Patient Information:   Mr. Johnson  a 72 year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  is presenting to the clinic today.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a significant history of Type 2 diabetes for 12 years  managed with Metformin. He is also hypertensive with adequate management on Lisinopril for the past 10 years. He has a smoking history of 30-pack years  but he quit 5 years ago. He has no history of surgeries or long-standing illnesses other than the aforementioned conditions.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Johnson complains of worsening pain in his lower right leg over the past month. He states that the pain is constant but gets worse during short walks and sometimes disturbs his sleep. Recently  he has noticed that the foot seems a bit cooler to touch than the other leg and the skin appears somewhat pale. He also mentions a new non-healing wound on his big toe which has persisted for the last 2 weeks despite using over the counter creams for healing.  Build a case diagnosis linking both pathophysiology and the above clues urging the students to diagnose the patient with Critical Limb Ischemia. This case will also provide a platform to discuss the risk factors (diabetes  hypertension  smoking)  symptoms of leg ischemia such as pain at rest  non-healing wounds  and the feeling of cool temperature which relates to less blood flow  and pale-looking skin. This will show how patient history and complaints help in diagnosing a condition like CLI.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Profile  Name: Mr. Jasper Smith Age: 62 Gender: Male Occupation: Construction worker Smoking status: Heavy smoker (20 cigarettes a day for the last 40 years) Alcohol use: Moderate (3-4 drinks per week) Exercise: None  Past Medical History: - Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  poorly controlled on medication - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago  on oral hypoglycemic agents - Hyperlipidemia diagnosed 3 years ago  on statins - No known drug allergies - No previous surgeries   Key Complaints: Mr. Smith visits the hospital outpatient department complaining of escalating pain in his left lower limb for the past few weeks  particularly below the knee. The pain intensifies when he walks even short distances (approximately half a block) and is somewhat relieved by rest. This condition is impairing his ability to carry out his regular job at the construction site.  He also mentions that his foot feels unusually cold  numb  and that he has observed a bluish discoloration of his toes. He also reports a slow-healing wound on his dominant leg. Mr. Smith also shares that he had experienced a significant loss of appetite and unintended weight loss over the last few months.  Family History: His father died of a heart attack at age 68 and his mother has diabetes and high blood pressure. He has two elder siblings: a sister living with diabetes and a brother who had a stroke at age 60.  On a further probe into lifestyle habits  Mr. Smith admits to smoking heavily and indulging in fatty  fast foods. However  there is no regular exercise and he consumes alcohol moderately.  In conclusion  the case presents a middle-aged man  with a significant history of smoking  hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia  who now presents with symptoms suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). This should provoke thorough examination and prompt intervention to reduce potential risks such as amputation and mortality.

Case Report:   Demographics:   Mr. Smith  a 75-year-old African-American male  retired construction worker  resident of Charleston  South Carolina. He is a widower with three adult children and lives alone in his own house. He has a 50 pack-year smoking history but quit smoking ten years ago.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a significant medical history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and peripheral arterial disease (PAD). He has been diabetic for the past 25 years  managed with Metformin and insulin injections  and hypertensive for 15 years  managed with Lisinopril. He was diagnosed with PAD five years back. His diabetic control has been suboptimal over the years  with a recent HbA1c level of 8.2%. His other risk factors include hyperlipidemia controlled by atorvastatin and a history of smoking.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Smith is presenting with extreme discomfort in his left lower limb  particularly in the foot  that has been persistent for 2 months. He describes the pain as a burning and cramping sensation that is notably severe at rest  especially at night. He has also observed non-healing sores on his toes. The sores started as small blisters two weeks ago and have not shown signs of healing  causing increasing pain and discomfort. Mr. Smith has noticed a progressive decrease in the temperature of his left leg  in comparison with the right one. Along with a disturbing decrease in mobility  he has also started to complain about an inability to sleep because of the unrelenting pain  causing significant distress and impacting his quality of life.  Summary:   This is a case of an elderly male with multiple risk factors including diabetes  hypertension  smoking history  and diagnosed PAD  now presenting with rest pain  non-healing sores  and temperature differences between limbs  suggestive of potential progression to critical limb ischemia.

Patient Profile: A 72-year-old Caucasian male  Past Medical History: Patient has a medical history of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and Tobacco use. He was diagnosed with Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) 5 years ago. Despite undergoing angioplasty  the patient has not seen significant improvement in symptoms.  Key Complaints:  The patient presents with severe pain in his right lower leg that has been worsening over the past six months. The pain occurs even at rest and becomes excruciating at night (rest pain). He also informs that he has been noticing non-healing sores on his right foot and some areas have turned blackish. Despite using prescribed oral antiplatelets and statins  the symptoms appear to be worsening notably the pain and sores.   Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  the patient's right leg appears discolored with a bluish/pale hue. There are some non-healing sores visible  mainly on the foot and toes. Popliteal and Pedal pulses are weak on the right leg compared to the left. The leg feels colder compared to the other limb. There is also observed muscle atrophy in the lower limb.  Given the patient's history and current symptoms  it's crucial to consider the possibility of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) in this case. This condition  a severe form of PAD  occurs when there's a significant reduction in blood flow to the limbs  generally due to atherosclerosis.   He should be subjected to diagnostic imaging tests  such as an ankle-brachial index (ABI)  doppler ultrasound or angiography  and if required  Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) or Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) for further assessment. It is crucial to manage this case promptly as CLI can lead to limb loss if not treated properly. Treatment modalities may involve medical  surgical  or endovascular approaches depending on the severity and the patient's overall health condition.    This case is designed to help you understand the signs and symptoms of Critical Limb Ischemia  its diagnosis process  and treatment options. It's essential for medical students to know the severity of this disease and the importance of early detection.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Christopher  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  from a mid-sized town in Ohio  is presenting to the hospital. He is a non-smoker (quit 10 years ago)  moderate alcohol consumption (2-3 drinks per week)  with a BMI of 28.   Past Medical History:  His past medical history includes well-controlled type II diabetes for the past 14 years  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) in 2016 which was managed with coronary artery stenting. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin.  Key Complaints:   He reports a 6-month history of increasing painful cramping and heaviness in his left calf muscle (characteristic of claudication) that only occurs with exercise or by walking short distances (approximately half a block). He also reports experiencing numbness and coldness in his left foot and ankle. In the past two weeks  he’s noticed that the pain seems to persist a bit  even when resting. He also reports a small ulceration near his left big toe that is not healing well despite local wound care.   In addition to that  the patient has noticed a slower growth rate in his hair and toenails  loss of hair on his toes  and discoloration of the skin on his legs. The above symptoms are raising suspicion for worsening peripheral artery disease (PAD) progressing to critical limb ischemia. The lack of improvement in his leg symptoms despite optimal medical therapy and lifestyle adjustments  along with the presence of foot ulcer indicates the need for further vascular assessment and possible revascularization.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. John Thompson  a 72-year-old male.  Demographics: Mr. Thompson is a retired engineer  is married  and has three adult children. He resides in a suburban residential area. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history but quit 15 years ago.   Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago and is regularly taking metformin. He was also diagnosed with hypertension 7 years ago and is on daily low-dose aspirin and lisinopril. He had colon cancer  for which he underwent surgical resection two years ago; follow-ups have confirmed he is currently cancer-free. There is no known allergy history. He reports no prior surgeries or significant illnesses.  Key Complaints:  Over the past three months  Mr. Thompson has reported experiencing progressive discomfort in his left lower leg. He initially felt the pain while walking but noted it usually disappears with rest. However  over the past month  the pain does not seem to go away  and it keeps him awake at night. He also mentioned that his left foot feels colder than the right one.  Over the past week  he has noticed a non-healing wound on his left big toe. He initially dismissed it  thinking it was an ordinary foot ulcer  but he became increasingly worried when the pain seemed to become almost unbearable.  He has not had any associated symptoms such as chest pain  dizziness  difficulty in breathing  or palpitations.   On inspection  his left foot appears dusky  and a painful ulcer measuring about 2x2 cm is seen on the first toe's dorsal aspect with surrounding erythema. There are also hair loss  shiny skin  and brittle nails indicating chronic ischemia.  Pulses in the left foot are not palpable  but the right foot pulses are intact. The capillary refill time in the left foot's toe is markedly prolonged  the motor power and sensation in the left lower limb appear reduced compared to the right side.  This clinically appears to be a case of critical limb ischemia  likely associated with his past medical history of diabetes and hypertension. The non-healing wound may represent a complication of severe peripheral artery disease. An urgent vascular surgery consult and further diagnostic studies like pressure index and arteriography are warranted. The case will require a multidisciplinary approach involving vascular surgeons  endocrinologists  and wound care specialists  along with comprehensive patient education about diabetes and foot care.

Patient Information: Mr. Robert Walsh  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  Past Medical History: Mr. Walsh has a significant past medical history  particularly of cardiovascular ailments. He was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes 15 years ago  which he manages with medication. 10 years ago  he experienced a mild heart attack and was subsequently diagnosed with coronary artery disease. He has also been managing hypertension for the past 8 years.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Walsh presents to the emergency department complaining of severe recurring pain in his left leg that has lasted for the past two weeks. He reports the pain is usually persistent  but intensifies significantly while walking and decreases when at rest. In addition  he mentions that he has observed progressive color changes (pale and bluish tints) of his left foot and noticed the foot is generally colder than the other. Recently  he experienced a few minor cuts on his toes that are not healing properly.   He reveals that the pain is causing him difficulty in going about his daily activities  such as walking or dressing  and sometimes wakes him up at night. The patient reports no fever  weight loss  or other systemic symptoms.   The patient leads a sedentary lifestyle with a dietary habit predisposing him to high cholesterol levels. He is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago. The patient lives alone and is dependent on his children for his outside work and errands.   Given his comprehensive medical history of diabetes  hypertension  and coronary artery disease along with presenting symptoms  preliminary assessments point towards the possibility of a critical limb ischemia. Care is to be given to rule out other differential diagnoses  plan for further investigations  and a management plan has to be delineated.    This case offers the students an opportunity to understand the disease pathology  possible risk factors  appropriate diagnostics  treatment options  and necessary patient education measures for critical limb ischemia.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Demographics: 63-year-old African American male  truck driver  former smoker  no history of alcohol or illicit drug use  family history of hypertension and stroke.  Past Medical History: Hypertension  controlled with medication for the last 10 years. Three years ago  diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  managed with Metformin. History of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) confirmed via peripheral angiogram 1 year ago  prescribed low-dose aspirin therapy and statins. Has a history of intermittent claudication.  Key Complaints: The patient presents to the emergency department with severe rest pain in his right lower extremity  primarily in the foot  which has been present for the past 10 days. The pain is said to be worse at night and slightly relieved when the limb is dependent. He also complains of a non-healing wound on his right foot for the past 3 weeks. The patient noticed a gradual change in the color of his foot over the last week  turning darker each day. Along with this  he experienced a marked decrease in the temperature of his right foot.  The patient has no fever  chills  chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or abdominal pain. He denies weight loss  fatigue  or appetite changes. The symptoms have affected his sleep and daily routine  including his profession as a truck driver  because he cannot sit or walk for long periods due to the pain. He rates his pain as 8 out of 10 on the pain scale.  Note: The above case is fictitious and created for a training scenario in medical student education. Kindly advice the students to conduct a thorough investigation  including physical examination  ankle-brachial index (ABI) test  and possible imaging studies  as well as discuss potential treatment strategies such as medications  revascularization procedures  and the possibility of amputation if conservative treatment fails.

Patient Profile:  - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 65 years old - Sex: Male - Race: African American - Occupation: Retired factory worker - Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a known history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 15 years  and he has been on oral hypoglycemic agents. He is also diagnosed with Hypertension for 10 years  managed with medication. Other significant past medical history includes Dyslipidemia  and he is a former heavy smoker who quit five years ago. There is no known allergy.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain in his right calf  which has escalated over the past week. Modern analgesics do not alleviate the pain. The pain is particularly pronounced at night and often disrupts his sleep. He also reports chronic non-healing ulcers on his right foot. He had earlier noticed a decreased sensation in the same leg  and recently  a change in its color to pale. He has not reported any history of trauma or injury.  Every detail of this mock scenario is purely fictional and for educational purposes only. It summarizes the typical profile and complaints of a patient with critical limb ischemia. This condition is a severe blockage in the arteries of the lower extremities  significantly reducing blood flow and thereby warranting prompt medical attention. Regular training and encounter of such cases for medical students would enhance their ability to manage this severe condition.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Sex: Male Age: 68 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Electrician Living Condition: Lives alone  semi urban area  Past Medical History:   Patient is a known case of hypertension since 20 years ago and has poor regimen compliance. He has a history of smoking 15 packs a year and quit smoking 10 years ago. He does not drink alcohol. Patient is a type 2 diabetic  diagnosed seven years ago. His paternal side of the family has a history of heart disease. He was tested negative for COVID-19 a year ago and has completed the vaccination series. He is obese with a BMI of 30.3.  Patient's regularly taken medications include Metformin 500mg twice a day  Lisinopril 20mg once a day  and Aspirin 75mg once a day.  Key Complaints:   The patient states that he presented to the hospital with the chief complaints of intermittent progressive pain in the right lower leg while walking which subsides at rest (claudication)  severe pain keeping him awake at night and noticed the foot is colder to touch when compared to the other foot. He has been feeling fatigue and discomfort in his leg for last three months. He added that lately he has seen a progressive color change in his right lower leg  now appearing pale and at times bluish. He noticed few non-healing ulcers developing on his right foot  around the toe area. He has been unable to sleep due to consistent pain in the leg and foot  despite taking painkillers.   The patient mentions that he has a marked reduction in his ability to independently manage his daily activities due to the pain in his leg. Change in lifestyle habits has been noted  with the patient avoiding activities like walking his dog due to leg pain.   This clinical situation presented should guide students to suspect peripheral artery disease (PAD) with progression to critical limb ischemia (CLI) due to poor blood supply  necessitating prompt diagnosis and proper intervention. Discuss possible risk factors including hypertension  advanced age  smoking history  diabetes  family history  and obesity. Discuss pain assessment including rest pain and claudication  and the need for a physical examination including skin color  temperature  presence of ulcers  along with additional diagnostic testing such as Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  Doppler ultrasound  angiography as necessary. The importance of treatment  addressing modifiable risk factors  and potentially life-saving surgical interventions should also be emphasized.

Patient Information: Mr. Thomas Grey  a 73-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher.  Demographic Information: Lives with his wife in suburban Ohio  nonsmoker  and drinks alcohol occasionally. His diet lacks fruits and vegetables  and he leads a sedentary lifestyle.   Past Medical History: Mr. Grey has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  which has been poorly controlled over the years. He also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He had a minor myocardial infarction 5 years ago  which was managed successfully with medication. He is currently on Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Grey visited the clinic complaining of recurrent pain in his right lower leg  especially when walking  which he describes as a cramping sensation. The pain usually subsides with rest  but in the last week  he began to feel pain even at rest. He also noticed that his right foot appears paler than the other and feels cooler to touch. He stated that he's been having trouble sleeping due to the pain and noticed the development of non-healing sores on his foot.   These symptoms hint at a progression to critical limb ischemia  characterized by excruciating pain even at rest  pale appearance of the foot (pallor)  cool sensation (suggestive of poor perfusion)  and non-healing sores. This case will help medical students understand the management of patients with critical limb ischemia. They can consider this case to improve their clinical decision-making skills regarding this pathology and to understand the essential role of controlling predisposing factors such as diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia in managing ischemic symptoms.

Patient Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mrs. Sarah Ohara Age: 65 years Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired schoolteacher Insurance: Medicare  Past Medical History: - Diabetes type 2 (25 years): Managed with Metformin 2g daily and regular insulin injections - Hypertension (15 years): Controlled with Losartan 100mg daily - Dyslipidemia (10 years): Managed with Atorvastatin 40mg daily - History of smoking 2 packs a day for 35 years  stopped smoking 10 years ago - No known allergies  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Ohara has been experiencing chronic  severe pain in her left foot at rest for several weeks. She described it as a cramping pain  exacerbated when she tries to walk and relieved partly when she dangles the foot. She reports her foot feeling colder compared to the right. A dark ulcer with well-defined margins (approximately 2 cm in diameter) appeared a week ago on the lateral aspect of her foot. Her ankle has recurrent swelling and she also noted occasional numbness or weakness in her left leg.  This case can be used to teach medical students about critical limb ischemia  familiarizing them with its common risk factors (diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and smoking)  symptoms (severe foot pain-even while at rest  foot sores/ulcers  color changes in foot/leg  temperature difference between the two legs  and decreased pulse in the leg/foot)  pathophysiology and possible management approaches.
