Case Report:  Patient Demographics: 72-year old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  married and a smoker for around 45 years.  Past Medical History:  Diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD)  hypertension and hyperlipidemia 6 years ago. Compliance with medication has been poor  often forgetting his daily aspirin  statin  and antihypertensive medications. Has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; both parents died due to heart attacks.   Key Complaints:  The patient presented with a 2-month history of progressive and severe rest pain in his right lower leg  most notably in his foot  that intensifies at night and is relieved by dangling the leg off the bed. Over the past few weeks  he also noticed skin discoloration and the development of nonhealing ulcers on his toes with numbness in the same foot. He reports unintentional weight loss and an overall decrease in his ability to participate in physical activities due to fatigue and shortness of breath.  This presentation is indicative of critical limb ischemia; a severe stage of peripheral arterial disease  highlighting the importance of early diagnosis and treatment of PAD  lifestyle modifications  and adherence to medication for the prevention of disease advancement.

Patient Background: The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male  retired construction worker named Mr. Smith.  Presenting Complaints:  He presents with complaints of severe  searing pain in his right lower limb at rest. He reports that the pain often worsens at night. He also complains of non-healing wounds on his right foot that started as minor scrapes a few months ago but have since become worse despite over-the-counter treatments and increased hygiene efforts. He has also noticed a progressive discoloration in his right foot  turning it bluish-purple.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known history of type 2 diabetes for the past 12 years and hypertension for 10 years  for which he takes medications irregularly. He has also been diagnosed with dyslipidemia about 7 years ago but is not on any treatment. He admits to smoking two packs of cigarettes daily since he was 20 years old but quit 3 years ago  and he has consumed alcohol socially but not recently. He has not previously undergone any major surgeries and does not have any known allergies.  Family History:  Mr. Smith’s father had a myocardial infarction at age 55  and his older sister is under treatment for peripheral artery disease. His mother and two other siblings are relatively healthy.  Social History:  Mr. Smith has been retired for ten years and lives with his wife. Their adult children live out of state but visit often. He is not very active due to the pain in his foot but attends regular card games with friends at the local senior center. He reports no travel history in the last year.  Key Findings:  On physical examination  his right foot is colder than his left. The skin is shiny  hairless  and bluish-purple in color. Two non-healing ulcers with a small amount of purulent discharge are present on his big toe and heel. His right dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are not palpable  and his Ankle-Brachial Index is lower than 0.4.  Given Mr. Smith's symptoms  clinical examination  and history  the case aims to educate medical students on diagnosing  managing  and understanding the implications of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI).   Key Learning Objectives: - Understand the risk factors and recognize the clinical presentation of CLI - Importance of controlling comorbidities like diabetes  hypertension  and dyslipidemia. - Understanding the use of Ankle-Brachial Index in diagnosing CLI. - Understand the current guidelines for the management and treatment options for CLI. - Importance of patient education in CLI management  dealing with quitting smoking  and lifestyle modifications.

Patient Case:   Demographics: Patient J.T. is a 67-year-old African-American male  retired factory worker  long-term smoker with a pack/day smoking history for the past 40 years. He lives with his wife in a rural area quite far from the hospital.  Past Medical History: He has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 12 years ago which is poorly controlled. His Hemoglobin A1c is consistently over 9%. J.T. also has a history of Hypertension. He has Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) diagnosed 5 years ago. A stent was placed in his right leg due to severe stenosis in the femoral artery 3 years back. J.T has a BMI of 27 indicating that he is overweight  and reports imperfect adherence with his oral medications due to financial constraints.  Key Complaints: The patient has recently been experiencing increasing pain in his left leg  even when at rest  and notes that it has been disrupting his sleep. In addition to the rest pain  he mentions an ulcer on his left big toe that hasn't healed in over a month. He reports a feeling of coldness in his left leg when compared to his right. Lastly  he mentions that the pain becomes slightly relieved when his leg is in a dependent position  thereby causing difficulty in walking.  These complaints  the patient's demographic  and medical history are suggestive of critical limb ischemia. The next steps should include a thorough physical examination  further diagnostic tests including Ankle-Brachial Index and imaging studies and consulting with a specialist for evaluating appropriate treatment options including revascularization procedures or medications.

Patient Information:  Ms. C. A. is a 70-year-old Caucasian female  a retired schoolteacher who lives alone. She is slightly overweight (BMI 27.5) and a former smoker  having quit about a decade ago.  Past Medical History:  Ms. C. A. has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has been on medication for these health conditions for approximately 10 years. She had an episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) 6 years ago but has been stable since. There is no history of any surgeries. She also reports that for about a year  she has had intermittent leg pain while walking which got better with rest.   Key Complaints:  Ms. C. A. presents with severe pain in her left leg that has been increasing over the past 3 months. She reports that she initially felt the pain only while walking but now she experiences it even while at rest  making her nights particularly difficult. The pain  she says  is mostly in her calf but sometimes radiates to the foot. The foot often feels cold. Over the past few weeks  she has noticed a dark patch developing on her big toe.   Additionally  she mentions that she occasionally feels dizzy and her balance has been off on a couple of occasions  but she hasn't fallen. Her blood pressure is well-controlled  her diabetes however has had fluctuating control with HbA1c readings ranging over 7-8% in the past year.  Assessment:  This case prompts concern about the potential worsening of peripheral artery disease  likely progressing to critical limb ischemia (CLI) given her inactivity due to pain  development of skin changes on the foot  and overall worsening of symptoms. Her diabetes  hypertension  age  and smoking history place her at significant risk. Furthermore  her occasional impairment of balance and dizziness may be associated with cerebrovascular disease  already echoed in her past TIA episode.   Plan:  A thorough physical exam focused on the cardiovascular and nervous system is warranted. She should be referred to a vascular surgeon for further evaluation. Investigations should include an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) and additional imaging as deemed suitable by the specialist. Enhanced diabetic control and proper foot care should be emphasized. Possible interventions should be considered promptly to improve blood flow if CLI is confirmed  to prevent possible complications like amputation. Additionally  her cerebrovascular health should be assessed.

Patient Information: Sex: Male Age: 70 years old Ethnic Background: Caucasian  Past Medical History: The patient is a smoker with a 40-year smoking history  diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease (PAD)  uncontrolled type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He has a history of intermittent claudication but denies any chest pain or symptoms of angina. No history of previous strokes or transient ischemic attacks. He has not had any surgeries in the past.  Key Complaints: The patient presents with extreme pain at rest in his right lower leg which has been ongoing for the past two weeks. Describing it as a severe  burning kind of pain  noticeably worse at night when he's lying down and slightly eased when he dangles his leg off the bed. He reports new onset non-healing ulcers on his toes and a noticeable decrease in the temperature of his foot compared to the other. There is no noticeable change in color. He denies any trauma to the site.   Family History: The patient's father had a history of coronary artery disease and passed away in his early 70s due to a myocardial infarction. The patient's mother has high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes.   Social History: The patient is a retired office worker who lives with his wife. He smokes one packet of cigarettes a day for the past 40 years  makes moderate use of alcohol. He denies any illicit drug use. His level of physical activity is low  mainly due to leg pain.  Review of Systems: The patient reports significant fatigue and occasional shortness of breath  which he attributes to his smoking habit. He also notes some mild constipation  which is a common side effect of his pain medication. No complaints of chest pain  palpitations  or dizziness. No other significant symptoms in other systems.   These complaints and history hints towards Critical Limb Ischemia. The patient’s uncontrolled diabetes and smoking are primary risks for the progression of his PAD to the more severe end-stage of CLI. The rest pain indicates that the ischemia is also present even in resting conditions and the non-healing wounds suggest insufficient blood supply in his lower extremities.

Patient Information: Patient is Mr. John Doe  a 67-year-old African American male.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe reports ""resting pain"" for the past three weeks primarily in his left lower leg especially at night. He also states an ulcer developed on the big toe of his left foot about a week ago which is not healing. He also notes increasing difficulty in walking and maintaining balance.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of type 2 diabetes for the last 15 years  which has been poorly controlled. He also indicates that he has a long history of cigarette smoking  averaging two packs a day for around 35 years  mate  hypertension and has been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease two years prior  managed conservatively. Last year  he underwent CABG (Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting) for triple vessel disease.  Surgical History: Apart from CABG  he underwent appendectomy at the age of 35.  Family Medical History: His father had coronary artery disease and mother had hypertension.  Physical Examination:  Examination reveals a non-healing dry gangrene at the base of the left big toe. Skin over the left lower limb is shiny  with loss of hair  and cold to touch. Both of his lower legs show decreased sensation to fine touch and temperature. Distal pulses in the left leg (dorsalis pedis  posterior tibial) were weak and femoral pulse seems normal.   This case presents a classic patient profile of Critical Limb Ischemia  the severe stage of peripheral artery disease  prompting the need for rapid diagnosis and treatment to forestall potential limb loss.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. Johnson  Age: 72 years  Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired mechanic  Past Medical History: 1. Diabetes mellitus type II for 15 years  managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. 2. Hypertension for 10 years  managed with medication. 3. History of smoking - 40 pack years. 4. Hyperlipidemia diagnosed 8 years ago  currently on lipid-lowering agents. 5. Previous Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)  2 years ago  no residual deficits.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Johnson presents with rest pain in both legs  more prominent on the right side. He reports that the pain is intense during night hours  and interferes with his sleep. There has been a noticeable change in color of his distal extremities to a bluish tint. He also mentions chronic non-healing sores on his right foot for the past two months. He experiences tremendous pain while walking even short distances  which requires him to halt (Intermittent claudication). Mr. Johnson has lost weight because of reduced activity and decreased appetite due to his illness.  Examinations and Diagnosis: To develop a suitable plan of intervention  an ankle-brachial index (ABI) test  ultrasound  angiogram  and a blood test including HbA1c and lipids can be suggested. Mr. Johnson's constellation of symptoms aligned with the results of the investigations lead to the diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia.  In this case  medical students should be taught about the risk factors for Peripheral Artery Disease and Critical Limb Ischemia  symptoms and signs of both conditions  interpretation of investigations like ABI and angiogram  and the significance of holistic management involving control of diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia along with the specific management of the Ischemia. Perfusion enhancing techniques  such as angioplasty  surgery  or even amputation in severe cases  should be discussed. Emphasize the need for smoking cessation  maintaining a healthy lifestyle to control risk factors  and regular follow-up.  Morbidity and mortality associated with untreated CLI should also be highlighted along with the economic and psychological burden endured by the patients. Additionally  the role of a diabetic foot in CLI can be an integral part of the teaching session.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Demographics: Name: John Doe Age: 70 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired school teacher Race: Caucasian Insurance Status: Medicare  Past Medical History: - Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes 20 years ago - Smoking history of about 25 years  quit 10 years ago - Diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia - Had a previous myocardial infarction 5 years ago - Current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Adderall  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the clinic complaining of an array of symptoms in his right leg  which primarily included pain  heaviness  and noticeable colour change. He explained that for the past two weeks he had been experiencing severe pain in his right calf and foot even while at rest. Unlike previous instances  the pain did not alleviate upon leg elevation  but exacerbated at night making it difficult for him to sleep.   Further  he stated that he had noticeably reduced sensation in the same leg and was having difficulty walking. He also noticed a cold feeling in his foot in comparison to his other extremities. The patient mentioned that a small wound on the calf that had not healed for a while and was becoming darker over time. Upon inspection  the right foot appeared to be pale and cooler to touch.  The above case presents critical limb ischemia which typically presents with pain at rest  non-healing wounds  and symptoms of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). This patient  being diabetic and having had a significant smoking history  is at high risk. Additionally  his cardiac history may also influence his overall prognosis and increase his risk for adverse events. Prompt diagnosis and intervention would be necessary to save the limb and to improve the patient's quality of life.

Patient Demographics:   Mr. Robert Brown  a 69-year-old Caucasian male from New York City. He is a retired banker  widowed  living alone. He has a long history of cigarette smoking (30 years) but quit a decade ago.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  and peripheral artery disease (PAD) for the past 17 years. He had a coronary stent placed 6 years ago following a myocardial infarction. The patient is on aspirin  statin  and metformin regularly.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Brown came to the hospital emergency room complaining of severe  burning pain in his left foot that has been worsening for the past week. The pain is persistent and intensifies during the night  inhibiting his sleep. He mentioned that he has been having difficulty walking due to the intense pain and limping for several days. Additionally  the patient reports intermittent claudication after walking a short distance  which was previously not the issue. He has also noticed that his foot appears paler than usual  and has been feeling colder to touch lately. He denies any history of trauma or injury in the foot.  This case report can set a platform to train medical students or residents on the critical aspects of critical limb ischemia (CLI)  such as recognizing the characteristic signs and symptoms of CLI  understanding the risk factors  formulating a comprehensive differential diagnosis  navigating through the diagnostic work-up  and formulating a treatment plan including conservative and interventional strategies  complications  and approaches to prevent disease progression.

Patient Information:   Mr. Brown  a 67-year-old African American male retiree  has been living in an urban setting.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a documented history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 20 years  and Blood Hypertension (HTN) for last ten years. He has been a smoker for the last 40 years with a smoking history of 30 pack-years  and also has a positive familial history of Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD).   Key Complaints:   Mr. Brown has been referred to vascular clinic with persistent pain in his right foot that has been worsening over the past 2 months. The pain is severe enough to keep him awake at night  which he describes as burning and aching. He feels relief when he hangs his foot over the side of the bed. Recently  the patient noticed non-healing sores on his right foot and it appears discolored (bluish). His foot is cold to touch even in warm conditions. Moreover  he also reports claudication  a pain in his calf muscle during walking  which subsides at rest. Pain has restricted him from completing his daily chores  hence has reduced his quality of life. He has been experiencing loss of appetite and unintentional loss of weight along with overall weakness.   In summary  Mr. Brown is a senior adult diabetic and hypertensive patient with a significant smoking history  presenting with a complaint of rest pain  non-healing ulcers  discoloration of the foot  and claudication. These symptoms suggest critical limb ischemia  most likely due to Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD). It is crucial to evaluate further and confirm the diagnosis by conducting proper tests and initiate necessary management steps.

Patient Case:  - Patient Description: Ms. Lopez  a 65-year-old Hispanic female - Living Situation: Lives alone in a multi-story house - Occupation: Retired teacher  Past Medical History:  - Chronic tobacco smoker for the last 40 years  - History of hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago - Diagnosed with type-2 diabetes 8 years ago - Family history of peripheral artery disease (father)  Chief Complaints:   - Ms. Lopez presented with the sudden onset of severe pain in her right lower leg for the past week - The pain is constant  dull  and seems to worsen when her leg is elevated  especially during sleep - She also complains of persistent numbness and a cold sensation in the right leg - She noticed a blister on her right toe that wasn’t healing  progressing recently to a skin ulcer  Physical Examination:  - Upon physical examination  her right lower limb was found to be significantly cooler than the left - The skin of her right foot appeared pale with noticeable loss of hair - Peripheral pulses (dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial) on her affected leg were markedly weak - An ulcer was found on her right big toe  with evidence of necrotic tissue around its edge  This clinical scenario could then unfold with investigations to diagnose critical limb ischemia  including Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  Doppler ultrasound  CT angiogram  or Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA)  followed by a management plan that may include lifestyle modification  medication  revascularization  or amputation in worst case scenario.   This case may be used to teach students about recognizing and managing critical limb ischemia  an understanding of peripheral vascular disease  its risk factors  symptoms  complications  and the impact of non-modifiable and modifiable factors. It may also highlight the significance of multidisciplinary management in such patients with complex needs and comorbidities.

Patient Profile:  - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 68 years  - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired Police Officer - Lifestyle: Smoker (30 pack years)  non-drinker  moderately active - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Past Medical History: Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago (currently on Metformin)  history of hypertension for 10 years (on Lisinopril)  previous episodes of intermittent claudication - Family History: Father died of heart disease at age 70  mother with history of stroke   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe has come for consultation complaining of severe pain in his right lower leg  especially at rest. He mentions that the pain often intensifies at night and sometimes wakes him up from sleep. He also complains of noticeable coldness in his leg compared to the other one and has noticed some areas turning dark in color near his foot. Over the past few weeks  he has developed non-healing sores on his foot. He also mentions experiencing some difficulty walking due to the pain. He reports that he often tries hanging his leg over the bed for some relief from the pain.   Summary:   A 68-year-old male patient with a medical history consisting notably of type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents with continuous pain in his lower extremities that gets worse during periods of rest and coldness in his right leg. The patient also reports having non-healing sores on his foot  a change in the color of his skin  and difficulty walking  indicating the possibility of critical limb ischemia. Given his smoking and family history  he is of high risk  making rapid assessment and intervention crucial.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 72 Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian   Past Medical History: John has a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He also has a 10 years history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. He is currently taking Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  Presentation:  John presented with a 3-week history of increasing right leg pain  which he initially attributed to ""old age"". He described the pain as a constant  severe burning sensation focused on his right calf and foot that intensified at night. In the past week  the pain has escalated  causing sleep disruption  and it is now occurring  even at rest.  On questioning  he also mentioned that he had noticed some skin discoloration in his right foot along with non-healing sores on his toes. His right foot felt colder than his left one. He admitted that he had recognized these symptoms progressively over the last two months but didn't mention them because he thought they were not serious.  His pain worsened when he elevated the right leg and slightly alleviated when he hung his leg down. He also experienced pain when walking  noting that he could barely walk a block without needing to stop because of the discomfort. The symptoms were affecting his quality of life  as he could no longer take his daily walks in the neighborhood.   No recent trauma  fever  or weight loss was reported. He also denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  or headaches. His review of systems was otherwise unremarkable.   This case provides an example of critical limb ischemia  a severe obstruction of the arteries which drastically reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to cause severe pain and skin ulcers or sores. The medical students will have to go through a physical examination  evaluate the patient's risk factors  carry out appropriate diagnostic tests  and decide on the correct course of therapeutics.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia   Patient Demographics:   Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  works as a truck driver and is currently residing in suburban Chicago. He is a lifetime non-smoker and occasionally drinks alcohol. He lives alone since his wife passed away three years ago. He has 2 children  both out of state. His eldest daughter checks on him occasionally.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe has a history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus with inconsistent blood glucose level management  hypertension controlled with medication (metoprolol)  and hypercholesterolemia maintained with statin therapy (atorvastatin). There was a recent wound on his right foot  which initiated from a minor bruise 2 weeks ago and hasn’t healed as expected. Moreover  his patient history also reveals intermittent claudication for the past two years  which has been increasing in severity.  Key Complaints:   Mr. Doe presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe right foot pain that he describes as sharp and constant. He mentions the pain is more intense at night  disturbing his sleep and occasionally awakens him. He also complains about the non-healing wound on the same foot  which started as a minor bruise and later changed into an ulcer. The wound intermittently excretes pus and shows no signs of improving despite careful wound care. He also describes his right foot as feeling unusually cold. The pain and cold sensation extends up to his calf  becomes worse while walking  and eases when he raises the foot. He further mentions frequent cramps in his right calf muscle and says he's noticed some discoloration around the ulcer on his right foot.  This case report is designed to introduce medical learners to the clinical presentation and management of a patient with risk factors and symptoms indicating Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). The case emphasizes the importance of timely and appropriate intervention to prevent serious complications such as infection  gangrene  amputation  and even death. The learner will explore the key aspects including proper diagnosis  management options  and preventive measures.

Patient Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Demographics:  • Name: Mr. Paul Matthews • Age: 68 years • Gender: Male  • Occupation: Retired Army Officer • Ethic Origin: Caucasian   Past Medical History:  Mr. Matthews has been previously diagnosed with Type II diabetes managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. He also has a history of hypertension  controlled with medication  and he is both a former smoker and drinker. In addition  he has hyperlipidemia under treatment with a statin. There is a peripheral vascular disease history confirmed 3 years prior. There is no known history of any allergy.  Current History of Present Illness:  Mr. Matthews has presented with a two week history of worsening pain in his left calf  more pronounced when walking short distances (within 200 meters) and relieved by rest. He has also been experiencing increasing instances of numbness and coldness in the same leg. Over the past few days  he has had difficulty sleeping due to severe pain in his left foot  rising to the level of rest pain.   On further questioning  Mr. Matthews discloses that he has been occasionally noticing a non-healing small wound on his left big toe for the past month  which he initially ascribed to his diabetes. He also noted that his left foot appeared paler than the right one.  The above symptomatology suggests that Mr Matthews's condition has advanced into critical limb ischemia (CLI). Further diagnostic tests and immediate clinical attention will be necessary to prevent imminent complications which can range from major amputation to a high cardiovascular risk.

Patient Information:  Name: Johansson  Alfred Sex: Male Age: 51 Race: Asian  Profession: Software Engineer   Chief Complaint:  Alfred has been experiencing severe pain in his right leg that worsens when he is at rest. He also complains about Persistent numbness and coldness in the lower part of the right leg.  Past Medical History:  Alfred has a history of Diabetes Mellitus (Type II) for the past 10 years  Hypertension  and hyperlipidemia (high cholesterol). He is also a regular smoker for the last 30 years. He had a cardiac stent placement 2 years ago due to coronary artery disease.   Vitals:  Alfred's blood pressure remains elevated  despite his hypertensive medications. His heart rate is slightly rapid. His temperature  respiration rate  and oxygen saturation are all within normal range.   Symptoms: Alfred reported discomfort in his right leg that became particularly severe at night  often disturbing his sleep. He also noticed color changes like paleness and blueness in his right leg and foot. He mentioned that he has had multiple wounds on his right foot that have been slow healing for the past few months.   He has had a weight loss of approximately 15 pounds over the last 5 months  which is not associated with any intention to lose weight or any changes in his diet or physical activity. This could be due to the associated malabsorption or hyper-metabolic state.  Alfred has been experiencing erectile dysfunction over the last year. He does not have any complaints regarding chest pain  palpitation  or shortness of breath.   Physical Examination:  Upon examination  a non-healing ulcer was noted on the distal part of his right foot. The right leg is cold compared to the left  with diminished sensation. There is notable weakness in the right leg  and peripheral pulses (femoral  popliteal  posterior tibial  and dorsalis pedis) are faintly palpable or absent on the right side compared to the left.   Possible Diagnosis:  Given his symptoms and physical examination findings  Alfred could be suffering from critical limb ischemia  likely secondary to the large amount of plaque build-up (atherosclerosis) in the arteries due to his history of smoking  diabetes  hypertension  and high cholesterol. Further investigations such as an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  duplex ultrasonography  CT scan  or angiogram may be required to support this diagnosis.

Patient Case: Patient: Mr. X Age: 68 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  Past Medical History: - Smoker (40 pack-years) - Hypertension - Type 2 diabetes mellitus (poorly controlled) - Hyperlipidemia - Prior myocardial infarction - No prior surgeries  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of severe  crushing pain in his right lower leg that had been increasing in intensity over the past 72 hours. The pain is more severe at night and often wakes him from sleep. It rapidly intensifies when he tries to walk and he notes that it is not relieved even when he stops moving. Patient further complains that the leg  particularly around the foot  is colder than the left. He had noticed intermittent pain during walking last two months  which resolved upon rest. However  he ignored it due to lack of awareness.   Upon physical examination  the right foot appeared pale and was cool to touch. Two of the toes showed signs of necrosis and there was reduced sensation in the entire foot. Pulses in the right lower extremity (popliteal  posterial tibial  dorsalis pedis) were feeble.  The patient denies any chest pain  breathlessness  or other systemic symptoms. The preliminary diagnosis was made as Critical Limb Ischemia of the right lower limb. The patient was then referred for further vascular assessment and intervention.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  67-year-old  Caucasian male  retired firefighter from a small suburb in Milwaukee.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years. He is an ex-smoker but had a heavy smoking history of 30-pack years. He also has a history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  peripheral artery disease (PAD)  and has had a previous myocardial infarction (heart attack) 7 years ago. His current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  Amlodipine  and Atorvastatin.  Key Complaints: Mr. Smith presented to the clinic complaining of severe  worsening pain in his right lower limb which he described as sharp and persistent. The pain was predominantly affecting his right foot. He indicated that the pain was exacerbated during walking and sometimes present at rest  causing him continuous discomfort  especially during the night. He mentioned a recent unintentional weight loss and declining activity levels due to the pain. On further inquiry  Mr. Smith also reported a non-healing wound on his right big toe. He had noticed it about three weeks ago  but he thought it was a small injury and would heal itself.  Summary: The patient is a 67-year-old man with a significant medical history including type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  dyslipidemia  PAD and a history of myocardial infarction. His presentation is in keeping with critical limb ischemia  characterized by severe pain in his lower right limb  even at rest  and a non-healing wound on his right toe.

Patient Case:   Ms. Jane Cyrus  a 68-year-old African American woman  presents to your outpatient clinic. Her past medical history includes smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for the last 35 years  Type 2 diabetes mellitus for 20 years  and uncontrolled hypertension for 15 years. She reports medication non-adherence due to financial constraints and difficulty understanding the importance of medication.   Key Complaint:  Over the past three months  Jane has been suffering from significant discomfort in her left leg  especially during walking. She describes it as a severe  crampy calf pain that appears after about 200 feet of walking and dissipates after a few minutes of rest. Recently  she reported having the same pain  but at rest  prominently at night. She stated that dangling her leg over the bedside appears to temporarily mitigate the pain. She also noted a progressive color change (pallor to bluish) and a decrease in temperature in her foot. She expressed concern over her left big toe  which has developed a non-healing ulcer over the past few weeks. The identified symptoms and medical history point towards the possibility of critical limb ischemia.   Educational Goals:  1. Identify critical limb ischemia considering the symptoms and the medical history of the patient. 2. Understand the crucial risk factors (smoking  diabetes  hypertension) of critical limb ischemia. 3. Recognize the importance of patient adherence to medications in managing chronic conditions. 4. Approach the management plan for a patient with critical limb ischemia. 5. Understand the implications of non-treatment or delayed treatment of critical limb ischemia. 6. Enhance patient communication skills  including discussion on the importance of medication adherence.   Suggested Additional Learning Activities:  1. Role-play: Discuss how you would approach and educate this patient about her condition and the importance of medication management.  2. Case Study Review: Examine a few more patient cases highlighting the variation in symptoms  demographics  and prognosis of critical limb ischemia patients. 3. Seminar: Invite a Vascular Surgeon to discuss the surgical aspect and latest advances in treating critical limb ischemia. 4. Journal Club: Assign recent research articles on critical limb ischemia for critical reading and discussion.

Patient Demographics:  Mr. Abdullah Ali  a 72-year-old male of Middle Eastern descent  is a retired engineer residing in a suburb outside of Houston  Texas with his wife. He is a smoker and indulges occasionally in alcohol.  Past Medical History: Mr. Ali  suffering from Type 2 diabetes and peripheral arterial disease  has a history of hypertension which is well-controlled with medication. He is also renowned for occasional episodes of angina pectoris. He had a coronary artery bypass graft surgery 11 years ago and takes daily medication for diabetes  high cholesterol  and hypertension.  Key Complaints: Mr. Ali presents with escalating pain in his left lower leg that has persisted for the past 3 weeks. Previously  the pain was intermittent  but it has become more constant over the last couple of days. The pain is especially severe at night and disturbs his sleep. He reports that even while at rest  his leg throbs painfully.   He also indicates a noticeable temperature difference when touching his left and right legs. The affected limb appears paler and feels cooler to the touch. The pain is debilitating  making it difficult for him to walk short distances. Recently  he has noticed swelling and redness around a non-healing ulcer on his left foot  which was initially a small blister but has since expanded.  Mr. Ali admits an unintentional weight loss over the last couple of months due to loss of appetite which he had attributed to stress. He hasn't been checking his glucose levels regularly  and his last HbA1C level was 9% six months ago.  Recognizing these symptoms  Mr. Ali came to the hospital fearing a critical condition requiring immediate attention. Indeed  these symptoms point toward Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe obstruction of the arteries which drastically reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores.

Patient Information: Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  who is a retired truck driver  comes to your clinic.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has been a smoker for over 40 years. He suffers from controlled hypertension  moderate obesity (BMI 32)  Type 2 diabetes (managed by oral hypoglycemic)  and peripheral arterial disease (PAD). He has no known allergies to any medication.   Key Complaints: Mr. Johnson complains of an increasing pain in his right calf that he describes as ""cramping "" especially when walking. He states this pain often subsides after a few minutes of rest. However  he reports that  over the past week  the pain has started to occur even when he's not walking but simply resting  sitting or lying down  especially at night. He also noticed that his right foot feels cooler than the left one and appears paler. He is concerned as he noticed a wound on his right big toe that is taking a while to heal. He has no fever  chest pain  palpitations  or dyspnea.   This case scenario suggests a progression of peripheral arterial disease to critical limb ischemia  complicated by poor circulation and non-healing wounds secondary to the underlying diabetes. Further investigations (like Doppler ultrasound  ankle-brachial index  and angiography) and management steps should be discussed further  with the consideration of involving a multidisciplinary team to preserve the limb and prevent amputation.

Case Summary:  Patient Demographics:   The patient is a 75-year-old African American male with a past medical history of smoking two packs per day for 50 years  chronic hypertension  and type II diabetes mellitus that is poorly controlled.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presents to the clinic with complaints of significant pain in his right lower leg. He describes the pain as ""constant"" and ""worst when I walk""  which has gradually worsened over the past six months. He also reported that his foot feels cold all the time  while the skin appears pale and dry. Furthermore  he has noticed an ulcer on the lateral aspect of the forefoot that refuses to heal and sometimes discharges a foul-smelling liquid. Moreover  he has been feeling weak and has lost over 15 pounds in the past three months due to lack of appetite.  Past Medical History:   The patient's medical history is significant for Type II Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 15 years ago and is currently being controlled with Metformin. However  his last HbA1C was 9.3%  indicating poor glycemic control. Hypertension is controlled with Lisinopril. He has also been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia for which he is taking Atorvastatin. He previously worked as a dock worker but has been retired for 10 years. No known drug allergies are reported.  Social History:  The patient reports he smoked cigarettes for the past 50 years with a 100-pack-year history but now is trying to quit. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use. He lives alone after his wife passed away three years ago. He admits that he is non-compliant with his medications and often forgets to take them.   Family History:  His father suffered a heart attack at age 62. His elder brother and sister are both hypertensive  and his sister also has Type II diabetes. No family history of cancer or any genetic diseases.   This case could be used to discuss the typical presentation of Critical Limb Ischemia and underline the importance of a thorough patient history and physical examination in reaching a proper diagnosis. It is also an opportunity to discuss the role of early prevention  risks associated with smoking  and the importance of managing diabetes and hypertension in preventing vascular complications.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 72-year-old African American male. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 27.3 and lives a sedentary lifestyle. The patient is a former construction worker. He is a retired widower living alone  with two adult children living out of state.   Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which have been managed with medication for the past 15 years. He also has a 30-pack year smoking history but quit smoking ten years ago.   Key Complaints: The patient came to the outpatient clinic complaining of severe pain in his lower left leg which has been worsening over the past few weeks. The pain escalates at night and wakes him from sleep  while slight relief is achieved only by hanging his leg off the edge of the bed.   The patient also reports intermittent claudication after walking short distances  and his movements have become increasingly limited due to the persistent pain. Additionally  the patient noticed the onset of sores on his toes that do not appear to be healing. He reports changes in color on his leg  perceived cold temperature at the foot  and some degree of numbness. The patient has not noticed similar symptoms in his right leg.   These symptoms suggest that this patient may be suffering from critical limb ischemia in his left lower extremity. The patient’s type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and extensive smoking history suggest a long-term exposure to peripheral artery disease risk factors  which could potentially complicate the medical picture. The medical teaching case will be designed with this information as a focal point.

Patient Information: Mr. Henry Thompson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  residing in a suburban neighborhood  present with complaints of chronic pain in his right lower limb. He is 5 feet 9 inches tall and weighs around 200lbs  BMI 29.5  indicating obesity.   Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a history of Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 15 years which is currently managed with Metformin. He also has hypertension under control with Lisinopril. He is a former smoker and has been smoking almost a pack per day for 40 years but quit ten years ago. He also underwent a triple coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery five years back due to his ischemic heart disease.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Thompson experiences chronic  severe pain in his right leg which has been worsening over the past several months. The pain often becomes severe at night  disrupting his sleep. He also reports experiencing pain while walking even short distances  forcing him to stop - a symptom of intermittent claudication. Recently  he has noticed his right foot turning pale and cool compared to the left. He has also pointed out a non-healing ulcer on his right toe.  Given his history of peripheral artery disease (PAD) risk factors such as diabetes  smoking  hypertension  obesity  and a personal history of other atherosclerotic diseases  Mr. Thompson shows signs of critical limb ischemia (CLI)  a severe stage of PAD.  Next steps would involve a detailed physical examination  including palpation of pulses  skin inspection  ankle-brachial index measurement  and further definitive tests such as angiography. Prompt diagnosis and targeted medical therapy  potentially revascularization  are essential to preserve limb function where possible or consider potential amputation. Extra care should be taken to manage patient comorbidities and modify risk factors.

Patient Information: Mr. Richard Thompson  68-year-old African American male.  Medical History: A past smoker with a 20 pack-year history  quit 10 years ago. He is a diagnosed hypertensive and diabetic patient with moderately controlled levels on medication for the past 5 years. Has a family history of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  Chief Complaints: Mr. Thompson reports increasing pain in his right calf  especially during walking  that has been progressively worsening over the past 6 months. Pain started to occur even at rest over the past week. He also complains of a non-healing wound on his right foot for the past 3 weeks.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination reveals a slightly overweight man with BP 150/90 mm Hg with moderate distress due to pain. Right foot shows coolness to touch  feeble popliteal and dorsalis pedis pulses  and a shallow  poorly perfused ulcer on the dorsal aspect. The left foot appears normal with palpable pulses. Blood sugar levels are mildly elevated.  Impression: Symptoms and signs suggest possible Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) of right lower limb  likely secondary to uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  and history of smoking. The patient requires immediate hematological and radiological investigations.  Discussing Points:  1. Basics of PAD and CLI 2. Importance of Risk Factors like diabetes  male sex  smoking  and African American race 3. The role of Ankle-brachial index (ABI) in initial diagnosis 4. Role of additional investigations: Doppler ultrasound  CT angiography  or MR angiography 5. Standard management including lifestyle modifications  medical therapies  and various revascularization procedures 6. Importance of early diagnosis in preventing severe complications like amputation and cardiovascular events. 7. Understanding the role of multidisciplinary care in the management of such conditions.

Patient Information: Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old African American retired construction worker  who lives alone and hails from a relatively poor socio-economic background. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago but had a 30-pack year history  and a non-drinker.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Smith has reported experiencing severe pain in his lower left leg over the past three months  especially when walking short distances. The pain has been progressively increasing and disturbing his sleep lately. He also noticed his left foot turning colder compared to his right foot and discoloration over his left toes.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a long-standing history of uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. He has been following up with a primary care doctor regularly for these issues. His medications include Metformin 1000 mg twice a day and Losartan 50 mg once daily. He is not compliant with his medications and keeps skipping his glucose testing at home. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago  treated with coronary stenting.  Family History: His father died of heart disease in his 70's and his mother has a history of stroke in her late 60's. His elder brother has well-controlled diabetes and his younger sister has hypertension.  Physical Findings: On examination  Mr. Smith's lower left leg looked slim  pale  and glossy with noticeable absent hair distribution. His pulses in the left foot were absent. Distal foot was markedly colder than the right foot. Mr. Smith also shows the presence of a nonhealing ulcer on his left big toe.  In this case scenario  the primary findings and symptoms indicate that Mr. Smith is likely suffering from Critial Limb Ischemia  which needs immediate attention. Although other differentials should also be considered  his history of longstanding diabetes and hypertension alongside his symptoms lead us to this conclusion. Further diagnostic procedures should be initiated to confirm the diagnosis and plan for the necessary interventions.

Patient's Case:  Patient Demographics: Name: Jane Doe  Age: 72 years old  Gender: Female  Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired school principal  Residence Area: Suburban  Past Medical History: Jane has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which she takes appropriate medications. She had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago and subsequently underwent coronary artery stenting. Noteworthy  she is a 40-year pack-smoker  despite multiple attempts to quit. Jane has mild chronic kidney disease  but no known history of diabetes. She has intermittent claudication which was medically managed and she underwent right femoral artery angioplasty 5 years ago.   Key Complaints: Jane presents with a 3-week history of worsening pain in her left lower leg. She describes this pain as a constant throbbing pain  which intensifies when her leg is elevated and somewhat relieves when it is in a dependent position. The skin on her left leg and foot appears paler than that on the right leg  and lately  she is having trouble walking short distances due to severe pain. Jane reports that she has noticed an ulcer on her left great toe that is not healing despite proper care. She endorses feeling pulses 'disappear' occasionally in her left foot. No fever or chills. No history of trauma to the leg. The rest of the review systems was non-contributory.  This concise training case will help medical students discuss the assessment and management of critical limb ischemia. The escalating symptoms including rest pain  impaired color and temperature  presence of foot ulcer and diminished pulses make critical limb ischemia a likely diagnosis. Furthermore  Jane's smoking history  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and previous history of angioplasty make her a quintessential candidate for peripheral artery disease  which further precipitates the condition. This case can guide a fruitful discussion about the pathophysiology  risk factors  clinical presentations  diagnosis  and management of critical limb ischemia.

Case Report - Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information: Mr. Morris  67-year-old Caucasian male.  Residence: Suburban community in Denver  Colorado.   Occupation: Recently retired office clerk.  Past Medical History: Patient has a significant history of Type II diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 12 years prior  managed with Metformin and regular insulin administration. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history  having quit 5 years prior. He also has a known history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both well-managed with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin). Mr. Morris underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) 3 years ago due to a diagnosis of ischemic heart disease.  Key Complaints: His chief complaints include persistent pain in his left lower limb  particularly the foot. The pain intensifies when he walks short distances or at night  disrupting his sleep. He also complains of a non-healing ulcer about 1 inch in diameter on his left heel that appeared 3 weeks ago.  Physical Examination: Presence of absent distal pulses in the lower extremities. His left foot displays signs of discoloration  with bluish-purple areas and is cool to touch. The ulcer on his heel is clean but deep with no signs of infection. There are no palpable pedal pulses in the left foot.  It is essential in this case to further investigate the possible diagnosis of critical limb ischemia. Given the patient's medical history and current symptoms  his risk factors include Diabetes Mellitus  a smoking history  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and past evidence of arterial disease (CABG). This makes the case suited for teaching medical students about early identification  diagnosis  and management of critical limb ischemia.

Case Profile:  Patient Demographics:   Mr. John Doe  a 68 year old male  from a non-Hispanic white background  resident of suburban Dallas  Texas.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and peripheral arterial disease  which have been managed medicinally for the past 15 years. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history and quit 2 years ago. He does not have a history of coronary artery disease  stroke  or any known chronic lung disease.  Key complaints:  Mr. Doe presented with a history of severe pain in his left lower leg that has been escalating over the last 3 weeks. He initially felt the pain during activity (walking or climbing stairs)  but recently it has been bothering him even at rest. He also mentioned experiencing intermittent mild pain in the right leg. He described the pain as a deep  intense ache that feels like a cramp and is usually felt in the calf muscle  though it sometimes occurs in the foot or thigh.  In the past week  he started noticing non-healing ulcers on his left foot. Upon further questioning  he also acknowledged experiencing mild numbness in the left foot. He has not experienced similar symptoms in the right foot. He does not have any symptoms of claudication.  Mr. Doe has not experienced any chest pain  shortness of breath  or any other cardiac complaints. His review of systems is otherwise unremarkable.    Upon physical examination  the left foot appeared pale and cold to touch  and distal pulses were not palpable. Doppler ultrasound of the leg revealed severely reduced blood flow.  This case is suggestive of critical limb ischemia (CLI)  a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood-flow to the extremities (hands  feet and legs) and has progressed beyond intermittent claudication.

Title: Critical Limb Ischemia in an Elderly Diabetic Patient   Patient Demographics:  Name: Uncleared for confidentiality Age: 68 years old Gender: Male Race: African American Occupation: Retired Industrial Worker Residence: Urban  Past Medical History: The patient has a known 15-year history of Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus. Comorbid conditions include poorly controlled hypertension and a 10-year history of hyperlipidemia. The patient is a former smoker  with a 30-pack-year history  having quit 5 years ago. He also has peripheral artery disease (PAD). There is no known history of heart disease or stroke.  Key Complaints: The patient presents with severe  constant pain in his lower right leg  even when at rest. The pain often worsens at night  and he reports disturbed sleep due to the pain. He also describes the pain as being relieved upon lowering the limb.   Signs of non-healing wounds are visible on his right foot. The patient also mentioned intermittent claudication  characterized by pain in his leg and discomfort when walking which subsides while at rest. Few days prior to the visit  the patient observed that his right lower leg and foot became cold and colorless. In the duration of one week  he noticed progressive deterioration of the condition with increasing pain  numbness  and an appearance of non-healing ulcers on the foot.  More recently  the patient reported an unintentional loss of weight and decreased appetite  which have persisted for the past two months.  The critical limb ischemia training case study is designed as such to shed light on the common clinical presentation  the importance of patient's past medical history  key complaints and the methods of diagnosing and treating the condition. The association of critical limb ischemia with diabetes  peripheral arterial disease  and other comorbid conditions  as well as its debilitating consequences such as non-healing ulcers and rest pain  lays emphasis on the need for early recognition and appropriate management.

Case:  Mr. Roberto Garcia is a 72-year-old male patient from a Hispanic background who presents with complaints of significant pain in his right lower extremity  exacerbated by movements and activities. The pain has increased in severity and frequency over the past four months and is persistent to the point that it disturbs his sleep and limits his daily activities. He mentions that the pain does subside slightly when he hangs his leg off the side of his bed. He also mentions the presence of non-healing sores on his foot and lower leg.  In terms of past medical history  Mr. Garcia has been a Type II Diabetic for the past 15 years  requiring oral hypoglycemic agents. He also has hypertension  managed with a beta-blocker and a thiazide diuretic  and moderate chronic kidney disease. Mr. Garcia is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  but smoked a pack a day for about 35 years.  He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases.   Through this case scenario  we will discuss with medical students the complexity of critical limb ischemia's diagnosis  its pathophysiology  and management strategies  focusing on the care of patients with multiple comorbidities. The students will also learn the importance of interdisciplinary collaboration and patient-centered care in managing such patients.

Patient Information:   Mr. William Brown  a 72-year-old African-American male is presented today.  Previous Medical History:   Reported medical history involves high blood pressure and chronic smoking. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes 15 years ago which is currently uncontrolled. He also has degenerative joint disease and peripheral arterial disease (PAD) which was managed with lifestyle modifications and medications.  Presenting Complaints:   Mr. Brown comes in today complaining of severe pain in his lower extremities  primarily in his left foot. The pain has been persistent for two weeks now and is more severe when he attempts to walk or climb stairs but alleviates when he is rested. He mentions that the pain often wakes him up in the middle of the night. Recently  he has noticed bluish discoloration of his left foot along with cold sensation to touch. He has also observed small non-healing ulcers on his left heel and over the big toe. He has not noticed any swelling or redness but reports feeling a decrease in the sensation of his left leg.  This case should then continue with further diagnosis  examination  procedures  and ultimately  discussions regarding the management of the patient’s condition.

Patient Demographics: Name: John Doe Age: 66 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer Residence: Urban  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension: Diagnosed 10 years ago; on regular medication. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 15 years ago  poorly managed  on insulin therapy. 3. Smoker: 20 cigarettes/day over the past 30 years  currently trying to quit but struggling with withdrawal. 4. Dyslipidemia: Under treatment for high cholesterol and triglyceride levels for the past 5 years.   Key Complaints: John presented with complaints of severe rest pain in the right leg for the past two weeks  which is more pronounced at night and has resulted in disturbed sleep. He describes it as a constant aching and burning sensation in the calf muscles. He also remarked on noticing a non-healing wound on the toes of the right foot with a blackish discoloration of the skin surrounding it.  About a month ago  John noticed occasional pain in his right calf while walking  which got relieved by rest. He initially ignored it thinking it was due to age. Over the past few weeks  the pain started occurring even during rest and considerably increased in intensity.   Additional Observations: On physical examination:  - Palpable pulses absent in the right foot. - Skin became cool  discolored  and pale in lower extremities. - Non-healing wound with necrotic areas observed on the toes of the right foot. - Right leg hair loss and brittle toenails were noted.  Conclusion: The above symptoms  signs and the past medical history strongly suggest Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  the severe stage of peripheral artery disease (PAD). Further investigations with Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  Doppler ultrasonography  Angiography  etc.  are required to confirm the diagnosis and plan the treatment accordingly.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Demographics: Mr. Lambert is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired military personnel  residing in Oregon with his wife.  Past Medical History: Mr. Lambert has a long history of type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  both controlled with medication for the past 15 years. He is a former smoker with a 40 pack-years history and quit smoking five years ago. He also underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) for Ischemic Heart Disease ten years ago. He follows up regularly with his cardiologist and primary care physician.  Key Complaints: For the past six months  Mr. Lambert has been experiencing progressive pain in his right lower extremity. The pain initially started when walking  but now it has begun to trouble him at rest too. Over the past two weeks  he has also noticed some non-healing sores on his right foot. He denies experiencing chest pain or breathlessness  recent vision changes  or uncontrolled blood glucose level. Recently he has been waking up in the middle of the night due to severe pain in his right foot. The pain momentarily eases when he dangles his leg off the bed.  Upon examination  notable findings were weak to even absent distal pulses  coldness of the right foot  reduced sensation  observable pallor upon leg elevation  and a noticeable dark wound on the dorsal side of the right foot. Based on initial findings  a working diagnosis of Critical Limb Ischemia of the right lower extremity was made.   This case represents classic signs of advanced peripheral artery disease  also termed critical limb ischemia. This diagnosis has severe implications if left unchecked or untreated  possibly resulting in amputation of affected limbs or dire cardiovascular events. It is important for medical students to familiarize themselves with recognizing and managing this condition as they progress into their clinical years and beyond.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia   Patient Demographics: - Patient's Name: Mr. X - Age: 70 years old - Sex: Male - Race: African-American - Occupation: Retired government official  Past Medical History: Mr. X is known to have chronic medical conditions including Type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  which have been managed well with medication for the past 15 years. He quit smoking approximately 10 years ago after a 30-year pack history but does not have a history of hyperlipidemia. He has no history of diseases like chronic kidney disease or cerebrovascular accidents. There is a history of peripheral artery disease diagnosed two years ago. He neither consumes alcohol nor has a family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Presenting Complaints: 1. He reports a 6-month history of gradually progressive  dull and aching pain in his left lower limb which is often precipitated by walking short distances and relieved by rest. This has started limiting his daily activities.  2. He reports experiencing pain in the left foot at rest  which has intensified over the past few days affecting his sleep. He describes the pain as a constant  sharp and burning sensation  which gets worse at night. 3. He also notes non-healing sores on the toes of his left foot.  4. Recent noticeable change- His left foot often feels cold  while the right foot feels normal  prompting his visit to the clinic.  This case presentation introduces Mr. X  an elderly diabetic and hypertensive patient suffering from progressive rest pain  non-healing wounds on the foot  and decreased temperature in the foot indicating the presence of critical limb ischemia. The students are expected to discuss the possible approach  differential diagnosis  necessary investigations  and management strategies of this critical condition contributing to significant morbidity and mortality.

Patient Presentation: A 70-year-old  African-American male presents to the emergency department with chronic  progressive pain in his lower right leg which has significantly increased over the past week. He reports that he has had difficulty walking due to the pain and has also begun to feel a constant cold sensation in the same area. Upon examination  the soles of both feet show ulcers and there is an absence of pulse in the right leg.  Patient Demographics: The patient is a retired construction worker. He lives alone  is widowed  and has three adult children who live out-of-state. He reports being a smoker for the past 50 years and drinks alcohol more than five times a week. His diet mainly consists of meat and processed food  and he neglects vegetable and fruit intake.   Past Medical History: The patient has a significant medical history for cardiovascular disease with a myocardial infarction occurring 10 years ago  and he had an angioplasty carried out at that time. Other than this  he has a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and hypertension for which he takes medication sporadically. He admits non-adherence to his medications mainly because he forgets doses and sometimes cannot afford to refill his prescriptions. He also admits to neglecting his diabetic diet and exercise plan recommended by his primary care physician.  Key Complaints: The main concerns include an escalating pain in the lower right leg  particularly when walking  the development ulceration on the soles of both feet  and the constant cold sensation in his right leg. This has caused a substantial reduction in his mobility and independence which is aggravating his underlying depression.

Patient Information: Mrs. K  Caucasian female  75-years-old  married with two kids and three grandchildren  retired elementary school teacher.  Present Complaints: The patient reported increasing pain in her left leg for a few weeks. She mentioned that the pain worsens when she walks or engages in any form of physical activity  though it tends to lessen while resting. She also complained about some degree of numbness and a consistent feeling of cold in her left lower limb. Mrs. K also indicated that she noticed a small non-healing wound on her left foot.  Past Medical History: She has a documented history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (managed with metformin) for the past decade. She also has a history of Hypertension (on Lisinopril) and Hyperlipidemia (managed with Simvastatin). Mrs. K quit smoking a year ago after a 30-year smoking history of one pack/day.  Social History: The patient lives with her husband  who is a retired police officer. She retired 10 years ago. They enjoy moderately active lifestyles  often participating in community activities and gardening.  Family History: The patient mentioned that her father had a history of Coronary Artery Disease and died from a Myocardial Infarction at age 80. Her mother died of colorectal cancer at age 76. She has a younger brother (72 years old) diagnosed with Peripheral Artery Disease.  Based on the patient's reported symptoms  demographic information  lifestyle  existing comorbidities  and family history  it is crucial to investigate the possibility of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe obstruction of the arteries which notably reduces blood flow to the extremities and can lead to amputation if not treated promptly.

Case Study: Critical Limb Ischaemia  Patient Profile: Name: John Doe Age: 63 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Factory Worker   Past Medical History: 1. Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 15 years  with the slightly irregular follow-up appointment and insulin-dependent. 2. Hypertension for 10 years  managing with antihypertensives: Amlodipine 5mg daily. 3. Mild obesity with a body mass index (BMI) of 32. 4. History of smoking for 30 years  but quit five years ago. 5. Previous Myocardial infarction 3 years ago  treated with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). 6. Routine medications include insulin  amlodipine  and aspirin.  Key Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department with a complaint of progressive intense pain in his right lower limb  primarily in the foot  that was worse at night and often disturbed his sleep. He also noticed the development of unhealing ulcers on his foot and coldness of the foot compared to the other foot. Despite the discomfort  he had noticed gradually he'd been moving it less and less over the last few weeks due to increased pain upon movement.   The patient also reported weight loss but denied any fever  chest pain  dizziness  or breathlessness. Intermittent claudication was also reported by the patient  typically after walking a few blocks.   No history of trauma or any similar incidents in the past were reported. The patient is a frequent traveler  his recent travel including prolonged flights. The diet was moderately balanced  although he expressed difficulty keeping his blood sugars in control.  The patient is rightly anxious about these symptoms and tends to his primary care provider. This case is designed to enable medical students to grasp the comprehensive approach to diagnosing and managing critical limb ischemia  which goes hand in hand with ruling out differentials  understanding the disease etiology  learning about risk factors such as diabetes and hypertension  and the importance of lifestyle factors such as smoking  diet  and exercise.

Case Report  Patient Information:   Mr. Williams is a 68-year-old African American male with a BMI of 30 kg/m2. The patient is a retired construction worker and lives with his wife. He's a former smoker with a pack history of 35 years  having quit about ten years ago. He does not consume alcohol and has no allergies.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a significant past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus for over fifteen years  and hypertension for twenty years. Additionally  he's had hyperlipidemia for about ten years and is under medication. He underwent coronary artery bypass surgery eight years ago due to coronary artery disease.  Chief Complaints:  Mr. Williams presents with a 3-week duration of worsening right lower limb pain at rest  non-healing ulcers on his right foot  and noticeable color change to a dusky hue. He also mentions that his foot often feels cold  and there's an associated noticeable decrease in hair growth. His pain significantly intensifies when his leg is elevated  especially at night  disturbing his sleep.  His wife reports noticing him walking with a limp  revealing symptoms of claudication with pain after walking a short distance. They report no trauma or injury to his foot. The chronic nature of these symptoms  accompanied by an inspection of the ischemic ulcers and the rest-pain indicates possible critical limb ischemia requiring immediate evaluation.

Patient Case Study: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. William Thompson Age: 68 years Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Accountant Ethnicity: Caucasian Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History: 1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus – Diagnosed 15 years ago  well-managed on oral hypoglycemic medications. 2. Hypertension – Diagnosed 10 years ago  well-controlled on antihypertensive medications. 3. Previous smoker – Smoked one pack per day from age 18 to 55  quit smoking due to the development of mild Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD).   4. Mild Obesity – Body Mass Index (BMI) 31.   Key Complaints: Mr. Thompson visited his primary care provider with the chief complaints of persistent  severe pain in his right lower leg for the past 3 weeks. The pain was initially intermittent and only appeared after walking a certain distance (claudication)  but recently it has stayed even while resting and is significantly affecting his sleep.   He described the pain as a deep  stabbing sensation in his calf muscle. He also reported that his right foot felt noticeably colder and appeared paler than the left one. He noticed a non-healing ulcer on his right big toe about a month ago.   He has no complaints of chest pain  palpitations  breathlessness  cough  or loss of consciousness. He has been adhering to his medication schedules and has not noticed any significant change in his dietary habits  physical activity level  or weight during this period.    This case study  on brief review  seems to suggest a clinical scenario of critical limb ischemia secondary to peripheral artery disease (PAD)  a common complication in patients with longstanding diabetes and hypertension. The non-healing ulcer  persistent pain even during rest  and the coldness and paleness of the foot are key early signs of CLI. The next steps would likely consist of a thorough physical examination  further investigation involving noninvasive vascular studies  and angiography if indicated. Appropriate therapy would be determined based on the severity and extent of the disease.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired school teacher  living in a suburban community with his wife.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents with severe  constant rest pain in his left lower limb that is worse at night. The pain has significantly disturbed his sleep pattern  and he notes it is somewhat alleviated when he dangles his leg off the side of the bed. He also complains of non-healing ulcers on his left foot.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 15 years  which is controlled by oral hypoglycemic agents. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed by prescribed medication. Forty years ago  he was a daily smoker but quit 10 years ago. The patient underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) 8 years back for ischemic heart disease. After the surgery  he adhered to a cardiac rehabilitation program and performs regular aerobic exercises.  Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 84. His mother had a stroke at 80 and passed away two years later. One of his two brothers also has a history of coronary artery disease and his sister is diabetic.  Social History: The patient lives with his wife  who is his primary caretaker. He has two children  both are healthy. He does not consume alcohol or use illicit drugs. He has a health-conscious diet following his heart surgery.  Review of Systems: He notes severe left lower extremity pain that is not relieved by OTC pain medication. He also admits to having an ulcer on his left foot that has not improved over the past three weeks despite regular dressing and cleaning. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  headaches or fever. There is no significant weight loss reported.  The described scenario forms a typical base for a case of critical limb ischemia. The next steps would typically involve a physical examination  appropriate diagnostic workup  and formulation of a management plan. The management plan should ideally take into consideration both medical and surgical options  if necessary.

Patient Information: Mrs. D  a 70-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher  living with her husband in a suburban neighborhood.  Primary Complaints: She presents with non-healing ulcers on the left foot coupled with severe pain in the foot  even at rest. She reports the pain has been increasing gradually over the past several weeks  making it increasingly difficult to walk or even sleep comfortably at night. Notably  she also mentions a sudden loss of sensation in the foot over the past few days.  Past Medical History: Mrs. D has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) duly managed with oral hypoglycaemic drugs for the last 15 years; she is also hypertensive  on medication for the past 10 years. Additionally  she has a history of smoking  though she quit 5 years ago. She was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) 3 years back.  Family History: There is a positive family history of DM and coronary artery disease in her parents.   Diagnosis: Given the above data  the presenting complaints are suggestive of critical limb ischemia (CLI)  a serious form of PAD  where there is a dramatically reduced blood flow to the extremities  causing severe pain  non-healing ulcers  or even gangrene.  The scenario emphasis the importance of managing cardiovascular risk factors to prevent severe complications like CLI. Further  it highlights the need for multidisciplinary collaboration in the management of such patients  including primary care physicians  vascular surgeons  and podiatrists.

Case Report on Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Demographics Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Civil Engineer  Past Medical History Mr. Doe has a distinguished history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 12 years. He is also hypertensive  presenting uncontrolled blood pressure values over the past 6 months. He is a former smoker who quit ten years ago after a 30-year history of tobacco use which averaged to a pack a day. His records also show hyperlipidemia (high cholesterol levels). He had a stroke 7 years ago  with no residual deficits. No known allergies on his records. Mr. Doe follows up regularly with his primary care physician and endocrinologist  where he's been compliant with medications and lifestyle modifications.  Key Complaints Mr. Doe has noticed worsening pain in his left leg over the past 6 months  which initially occurred after walking for a certain distance  but now has started to pain even at rest. He describes it as a constant cramping and burning sensation which intensifies at night  making his sleep quality poor. Recently  the pain is accompanied by numbness and a sense of coldness. There are no ulcers or sores on his lower left leg  but he has mentioned that it takes a longer time for even minor injuries to heal on the said leg. He acknowledges a significant reduction in physical activity due to the pain  affecting his overall quality of life.  The above details have been carefully put together to provide medical students with a clinically relevant scenario of a patient with likely peripheral artery disease (PAD) progressing into critical limb ischemia (CLI). The risk factors in the patient's history and his current complaints should lead one to consider the possibility of CLI which can guide further investigations.

Case Report - Critical Limic Ischemia  Patient Information:   Mr. K  a 68-year-old African-American male  presented to the outpatient clinic. He is a retired construction worker  lives with his wife  and is the primary caregiver to his 5-year old grandson. He is a non-smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History:  His past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus (DM) diagnosed 13 years ago and high blood pressure (HBP) diagnosed 8 years ago  for which he has been taking metformin and losartan  respectively. He has been diagnosed with dyslipidaemia for 5 years and is on 20 mg of atorvastatin daily. The patient also has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and had a stent placed 7 years ago.
