He has no known drug allergies. There is a family history of CAD and type II DM.  Chief Complaints:  Mr. K reported the progressive onset of pain in his right leg over the past 6 months. The pain has gradually worsened and has started to interfere with his daily activities. Initially  the pain only developed when walking more than 3 blocks and was relieved with rest (claudication). Recently  the pain has become persistent  even during rest. It's particularly severe in his right foot  and he described it as a sharp  burning sensation that worsens when he elevates his foot and improves when he dangles it over the side of his bed.  He has also noticed skin color changes on his right foot  and ulcers have developed on two of his toes. The patient has experienced a significant decrease in his ability to perform daily activities due to the pain and often has to wake up at night due to intense discomfort. He also mentioned the deterioration of his right foot's temperature  describing it as 'cold to touch' sometimes.  He has previously consulted with his primary care physician and was provided with pain medications  advice to keep the foot elevated  and an antibiotics prescription due to the ulcers. Despite this  the symptoms have persisted  and his condition has worsened  leading to his referral to the vascular clinic.   These symptoms and findings are highly suggestive for critical limb ischemia in the patient  necessitating further diagnostic evaluation and treatment considerations.

Patient Information:   Mr. Jorge Martinez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presents with a significant complaint of chronic pain in his left lower leg  particularly in the calf region.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Martinez has a previous 20-year history of type 2 diabetes that has been moderately controlled with medication. He is a long-term smoker  having smoked half a pack a day for thirty years  but quite last year upon doctors' advice. He also has hypertension for which he is on low-dose medication. Five years ago  he was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease  but was asymptomatic until now. His family history is notable for a father with early onset coronary artery disease and a mother with stroke. He has no known allergies to any food  medicines or environmental elements.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Martinez reports intense and continuous pain in his left leg that began over six months ago  which worsens while lying down  making it difficult for him to find a comfortable sleeping position. His pain is relieved when he hangs his leg over the edge of the bedside. Over this period  he has noticed a progressive change in the color of his leg skin  from regular flesh-tone to a shiny pallor and overall coolness to the touch. He also complains of hair loss on the left leg. His toenails have thickened and he has lost almost all sense of touch in his feet.  For the past two months  the pain intensity elevated  now making it difficult for him to walk even short distances  which he refers to as ""claudication"". The most alarming change Mr. Martinez reports is the development of a non-healing ulcer on his left big toe  which is not responding to local treatments.  Summary:  All of these findings suggest a case of critical limb ischemia (CLI)  most likely as a result of uncontrolled peripheral artery disease  long-term smoking history  and diabetes. Further evaluation and intervention are deemed necessary to preserve the patient's limb and quality of life.

Case Study: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Demographics:  Ms. Jane Doe  65-year-old Caucasian female  retired teacher from a urban setting.  Past medical history: - Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (15 years ago) - Hypertension (High blood pressure) - Hyperlipidemia (High cholesterol) - Previous smoker  quit about 10 years ago - Family history of peripheral artery disease and stroke  Key Complaints: - Progressive  severe pain in her right lower leg and foot for the last 3 weeks - The pain intensifies upon elevation and decreases when dangling - Appearance of non-healing  small ulcers on the right lower leg and big toe - Reports of noticeable temperature difference between lower legs  with right one feeling significantly cooler - Decreased hair growth on right lower leg - Reported significant fatigue while doing regular activities  particularly walking.  Additional Information:  On further inquiry  Ms. Doe reported that she first started noticing intermittent discomfort in her leg while walking around a month ago. The pain she described was a muscle ache  similar to a cramp  usually triggered by activities and relieved by rest. However  the discomfort progressively worsened over the past 3 weeks evolving into persistent pain.  Note: This case exposes students to Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  an advanced form of peripheral artery disease. Patient’s age  diabetic state  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking history increase her risk for developing CLI. The complaints align well with the symptoms of CLI  such as severe pain at rest  non-healing wounds  and lower-body fatigue. In this case  students should focus on recognizing symptoms  interpreting the patient's history  and ordering appropriate diagnostic tests  such as Ankle-brachial index  Doppler ultrasound  angiography  etc. Additionally  they should consider the potential need for consulting a vascular surgeon or initiating treatments like medication changes  angioplasty  stent  or bypass surgery  and understand the critical importance of addressing lifestyle factors.

Case Study: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information: Patient X is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes  Hypertension  and a 40-year pack history of smoking. He is a retired office worker and lives with his wife.  Presenting Complaint and History of Present Illness: Patient X presented with severe pain in his left lower extremity  rated at 8/10 on the pain scale which has been worsening over the 6 months. Additionally  the pain becomes significantly worse when he walks a short distance or while at rest especially during the night. The patient also complains of non-healing sores on his left foot. This has created a recent onset of sleeping difficulty for him.  Past Medical History: - Diabetes Mellitus Type 2: Diagnosed 15 years ago  poorly controlled. - Hypertension: Diagnosed 8 years ago  controlled with medication. - No known allergies - Past surgical history is non-contributorial.  Family History: - Father: Late onset diabetes mellitus and passed away from a heart attack at the age of 72. - Mother: Deceased  history of Hypertension and Stroke. - Brothers (2) and Sister (1): Alive and with a history of Hypertension.  Social History:  - He has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. - Denies any use of alcohol or illicit drugs. - His diet is predominantly high carbohydrate and fat  low in fruit and vegetables.  Review of Systems: - General: Notable weight loss over the past six months. - Cardiovascular: Left leg pain worsens with movement  non-healing sores on foot. - Respiratory: No cough  no shortness of breath. - GI/GU: Normal. - Neuro: No history of stroke or transient ischemic attacks. Cognitive abilities are sound.  The primary suspicion from the initial patient presentation is Critical Limb Ischemia  largely due to his persistent and severe lower extremity pain  non-healing sores  and his significant history contributing to vascular disease. The next step in this case would involve diagnostic testing to confirm CLI. This case provides a foundation for teaching on key symptoms of CLI  associated risk factors  diagnosis  and management.

Patient Identity: Mr. Robert Johnson Age: 65 years Sex: Male Race: African American Occupation: Retired navy officer  Presenting Complaint: The patient has been experiencing severe pain in his right lower leg for the past few months  which has intensified over the last week. The pain is often worse at night and seems to be unrelieved by rest.  Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a history of hypertension for 10 years and is under medication. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago  for which he is currently taking metformin. He has been a smoker for around 30 years but quit smoking a year ago. No prior history of surgeries. Last recorded body mass index (BMI) was 28.2.  Review of other organ systems: Unremarkable.  Family History: Both parents hypertensive and father had myocardial infarction at the age of 70. He has a younger brother who is diabetic.  Social History: He lives with his wife. He used to consume alcohol socially  but quit 2 years ago. He reports no illicit drug use.   Physical Examination: Upon inspection of the right leg  color changes are noticeable  with the skin appearing pale. The pulses in the right lower leg couldn't be palpated. The leg is colder compared to the left one and appears atrophic. Patient reported severe pain on passive motion. No visible sores or ulcers.  Given his history of diabetes  hypertension  and smoking  combined with his symptoms and physical examination  the medical students are to consider the possibility of Critical Limb Ischemia. The objective is to understand the associated risk factors  clinical features  diagnostic methods (like Ankle-Brachial Index  Doppler ultrasound  Angiography)  treatment options  and preventive measures for Critical Limb Ischemia.

Patient Information: Mrs. E. Smith  67 years old  Caucasian  weighs 75 kg  and is 160 cm tall resides in Simcoe County  Ontario  Canada. She is a retired pediatric nurse  a widow and mother of two adult kids. She is a nonsmoker but has a history of occasional alcohol consumption.   Past Medical History: Mrs. Smith has a chronic background of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 13 years and Hypercholesterolemia  both managed conservatively. Reports being compliant with her oral hypoglycemic therapy (Metformin) and cholesterol-lowering drugs (Statins).  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Smith has presented with gradually increasing pain in the left leg  primarily on walking short distances for the last 2 months. The pain is often described as severe  cramping  located in her calf muscle  and relieves on rest. Over recent weeks  she has also noticed pain in her leg at rest and at night which has disturbed her sleep.   On further inquiry  she reported noticeable slow wound healing and colder feet over the last month  particularly the left foot. She also expressed concerns about her left foot appearing slightly pale compared to the right one.  Note: This training case is an ideal opportunity to discuss the topic of peripheral arterial disease  specifically focusing on critical limb ischemia. Here  the intersection of diabetic vascular complications and the potential of limb-threatening ischemia can be explored in depth.

Patient Profile:   Name: Mr. Smith Age: 70 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a 30-year history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 40-year history of heavy tobacco use  although he quit smoking 10 years ago. He has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia but has been inconsistent with his medication regime due to financial constraints. He underwent a right leg superficial femoral artery stent placement five years ago due to peripheral artery disease (PAD).  Presenting Complaints:  Over the past six months  Mr. Smith has been experiencing progressive pain in his left foot  initially only while walking  but now at rest as well. He describes the pain as a deep  burning sensation that especially disturbs his sleep. He has also noticed a slow healing wound on his left great toe. Recently  his left foot has become persistently colder compared to the right foot. He denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations.  Key Points for Training:  This case is a good opportunity to teach medical students about the importance of recognizing critical limb ischemia (CLI)  which is a severe obstruction of the arteries  markedly reducing blood flow to the extremities and causing severe pain  even at rest. Its mention should trigger discussions around risk factors such as long-standing diabetes  smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. The patient's previous PAD and stenting should also be emphasized.   The deep  burning rest pain  foot coldness  and non-healing wound are clear symptoms suggesting the progression of PAD towards CLI. Treatment involving lifestyle modifications  aggressive control of diabetes and hypertension  the use of antiplatelet and statin therapy  and potential endovascular or bypass surgical options should be discussed in relation to Mr. Smith's case. Prognosis and potential complications  including the risk of amputation and increased cardiovascular mortality  should be mentioned.   Furthermore  the case highlights the role that socioeconomic factors play in health outcomes  as Mr. Smith's non-adherence to prescribed treatment appears to be financially motivated—an essential discussion point on the impact of such determinants of health.

Patient Information: Mr. James Wilson  a 69-year-old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History: Mr. Wilson has a significant history of type II diabetes mellitus and coronary artery disease. His surgical history includes a 5-vessel coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) performed 10 years ago. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years but quit after his CABG surgery. He is currently on insulin  metformin  aspirin  clopidogrel  and a statin.  Chief Complaint: Over the last six months  Mr. Wilson has been experiencing progressive pain in his right leg  especially when he walks. The pain usually begins in his calf and radiates down  sometimes all the way to his toes. He mentions that it seems to be relieved by rest. However  he notes that lately  he has been experiencing pain even when he is not walking  and is often awakened by it during the night.  Key Concerns: The pain itself is not the only issue. Due to pain  his walking distance has markedly decreased over time. Recently  he’s been experiencing coldness in his foot and has noticed that the color of his foot changes to a pale shade  especially when it hangs down. Since last week  he has also noticed a non-healing small ulcer over his great toe. He is increasingly concerned about the worsening symptoms. His blood sugar control has been fairly stable  and there is no history of any recent chest pain  dyspnea or syncopal episodes.

Patient Information:   Mrs. Maria Gonzales is a 68-year-old Hispanic woman living in Santa Monica  California. She is a retired schoolteacher  non-smoker  with a history of moderate alcohol consumption. Her BMI is 28.5.   Past Medical History:   Mrs. Gonzales has a documented history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years and has been non-compliant with her diet and medications. She was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago  which is controlled with medications. Five years ago  she suffered from a myocardial infarction and was managed with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). There is a history of peripheral artery disease (PAD) in her family.  Present Complaints:  She came to the clinic today complaining of excruciating ""burning"" pain in her right lower limb  particularly the foot  which worsens at night. She noticed a non-healing wound on her right forefoot that occasionally discharges pus. She reports difficulty walking distances she used to cover easily due to leg fatigue and discomfort. There has been an increasing reliance on her daughter to help her with daily chores and personal grooming due to her leg symptoms. Mrs. Gonzales has also noted the progressive change of her foot's skin color  turning more bluish and feeling cold to touch.  These symptoms suggest critical limb ischemia (CLI)  an emergency form of peripheral artery disease. This case encourages medical students to consider a diagnosis and plan appropriate management.

Patient Information:  Mr. Samuel Jacobson  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  Past Medical History: The patient is diagnosed with Type-2 Diabetes for the last 15 years  and Hyperlipidemia for the last ten years. The patient is also a pack a day smoker for 45 years. There is no past surgical history. No known allergies have been reported. The patient's daily medications include Metformin  Atorvastatin  and a low-dose Aspirin.  Chief complaints: The patient arrived at the outpatient clinic with a 6 week history of worsening pain in the right calf  which he described as deep  hollow  and persistently aching. The pain was graded at 4-6/10 and was specifically reported to be more pronounced during walks and relieved by rest.  The patient also reported a single non-healing ulcer on the right big toe which had been present for almost one month. He noticed increasing discoloration surrounding the wound and complained of experiencing coldness in the right lower limb.  Upon physical examination  his right pedal pulse was not palpable  and the lower limb appeared pale with delayed capillary refill - indicators of insufficient blood supply (ischemia).  This case of Mr. Samuel Jacobson can be utilized to discuss Critical Limb Ischemia  a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores. As it is the most advanced stage of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  detailed patient history  clinical signs and symptoms  and relevant diagnostic tests can be elaborated upon. Early recognition  timely endovascular treatment/Surgical revascularization  and risk factor management discussions based on this case will provide valuable insights into medical students.

Case Report  Patient Information Mr. LJ  a 72-year-old African American male truck driver  presents himself to the outpatient department.  Chief Complaints The patient reports experiencing rest pain in his right lower limb  particularly when lying down. He also mentions having difficulty in walking due to muscle cramps in the same leg. Further  he reports new non-healing wounds on his right foot.  Past Medical History The patient has a historical record of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension for over 20 years. He quit smoking five years back but smoked for 30 years  averaging a pack per day. The patient also has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) for which he underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) 6 years ago.  Family History His father died of stroke at the age of 70  and his mother died due to complications from diabetes mellitus at 60. He has one brother with early-onset CAD  who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting at the age of 55.  Social History The patient is married with three children and is currently living a sedentary lifestyle due to his profession. He rarely exercises and follows a diet high in fats and carbohydrates.  Examination Upon physical examination  the right foot is pale and cooler in comparison to the left one. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are absent on the right side. Capillary refill time is extended. There are two ulcers: one on the right big toe and the other on the heel  both characterized by black necrotic tissue at the center and a pale surrounding wound bed.  This case should lead to a discussion on the assessment  diagnosis  and management of Critical Limb Ischemia  focusing on the importance of aggressive management of risk factors  the usage of diagnostic tools like Doppler studies  angiography  and the relevance of revascularization techniques and amputation in severe cases. Additionally  the need for a multidisciplinary approach involving vascular surgeons  interventional radiologists  and wound care specialists should be emphasized.

Patient Case Study: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Demographics: Patient: Mr. John Doe Age: 68-year-old  Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Smoker: Yes  about 20 cigarettes a day for 45 years now  Medical History: - Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 12 years ago - Family history of Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) and cardiovascular disease - Had a heart bypass surgery 6 years ago - Hypertension for 15 years  Chief Complaint: - Mr. Doe talks about experiencing severe pain in his right calf muscle for the past two months - He claims the pain intensifies while walking and eases once he rests for a few minutes (classic claudication) - However  over the last week  he has been feeling the pain even while resting - Additionally  there's noticeable color change in the skin of his right foot  it appears paler compared to the left foot - He reports sleeping with his leg hanging off the bed to alleviate the discomfort - Complaints about ""pins and needles"" sensation in his right foot - Patient also mentioned an unhealed wound had developed on his right foot for the past couple of weeks - Significant weight loss over the past few months  This case report thus provides an insight into a diabetic patient with progressive signs and symptoms of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). Next steps in the patient's evaluation would include an objective assessment of the affected limb's perfusion status  imaging to evaluate and characterize the extent of arterial disease  and ultimately discussions about revascularization strategies balanced against the patient's overall health status.

Case Report:  Name: Mrs. Dolores Sanchez Age: 67 years Sex: Female Race: Hispanic  Occupation: Retired school teacher Location: Phoenix  Arizona  Past Medical History: Mrs. Sanchez has a 30-year history of Type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin. She is also a smoker for 40 years with a history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. She had undergone bilateral total hip replacement due to severe osteoarthritis 5 years ago. No known drug allergies.   Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Sanchez has been experiencing chronic pain over the past two months in her left lower leg  particularly in the calf area  which escalates when she walks less than one block  leading to frequent rest breaks. She also reports that she has started feeling a constant ache at rest over the past week; pain sometimes wakes her up at night. She admits that there's noticeable cooling of the foot and a sore on her big toe that stubbornly isn't healing for over three weeks. No significant weight loss.  She has not had any trauma to the leg or any recent surgeries. She states she has been managing the pain at home with regular doses of acetaminophen but with increasing discomfort  she decided to seek immediate medical help.  She admits minimal alcohol use  does not do any illicit drugs but is a current smoker  1 pack/day. Her diet is largely home-cooked Hispanic foods  and she lives with her husband in their own house.   In this case  Mrs. Sanchez's age  history of smoking  and long-standing diabetes make her at higher risk for peripheral artery disease (PAD) and its complication known as Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). Her symptoms such as the persistent pain at rest  noticeable cooling of the foot  and the non-healing wound are common signs of CLI. Medical students would be encouraged to understand how to manage her condition adequately and prevent further complications like limb loss.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. James Mitchell  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired factory worker  non-smoker  residing in Chapel Hill  North Carolina.  Past Medical History: Controlled hypertension for the last 12 years  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 10 years with mixed control  and was treated for a myocardial infarction 5 years prior. Also a history of intermittent claudication for the past year.   Presenting Complaints: Over the last four weeks  Mr. Mitchell has been experiencing escalating right lower limb pain even while in rest. The pain is severe  especially during the night. He describes the pain as a burning  sharp sensation which intensifies when he elevates his limb. He shared that his foot often feels cold and numb  and he has noticed a change in skin color to a bluish  pale hue.   He also notified that he has difficulty walking short distances and has recently noticed a non-healing wound on his right big toe that has been present for two weeks.   This hypothetical patient's presentation is suggestive of critical limb ischemia secondary to peripheral arterial disease. The patient presents with typical symptoms including rest pain  non-healing wounds  and change in color/temperature due to a reduction in blood supply. His past medical history also puts him at high risk for this condition.  Note: This case is designed to prompt further evaluation and appropriate testing to confirm diagnosis  and to facilitate discussion around proper management and potential complications if left untreated.

Patient Case Report: Patient Demographics: - Name: Mr. John - Age: 68 years old - Gender: Male - Profession: Retired factory worker - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Location: Urban area   Past Medical History: - Diagnosed with Type-2 Diabetes 15 years ago - Known case of peripheral arterial disease diagnosed 3 years ago - Smoker  approximately 20 cigarettes per day for the last 40 years - Family history of cardiovascular disease  both parents  Key Complaints:  - Presented with rest pain in his left lower leg for the last two weeks - Pain is intense  often waking him up at night - Increasing pain upon walking even short distances  formerly manageable - Noted a blackened area on his big toe of the left foot recently  with surrounding skin being pale and shiny - He also complains of a constant cold feeling in the left lower limb - Significant unintentional weight loss over the last few months  due to loss of appetite  possibly related to chronic pain - He reported a few episodes of fainting in the past month  This case essentially highlights a patient who could be suffering from Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). Factors such as patient's age  smoking status  uncontrolled Diabetes Mellitus  and history of Peripheral Arterial Disease make him susceptible. The symptoms of intense pain even at rest  changes in skin color  cold feet  and signs of gangrene demonstrate worsening of the previously diagnosed condition. Chronic CLI can cause extreme pain  leading to loss of appetite  weight loss  and even fainting. Hence  it is crucial for medical students to identify the urgency and severity of such vascular complications.

Patient Information:  Mr. Charles Rogers  a Caucasian male  aged 72 years  living in the suburbs of Chicago  Insurance holder.  Chief Complaints:  Recurrent pain in the right lower limb  particularly while walking  that gets somewhat better with rest (claudication). Recently  he observed ulcer formation and discoloration around his right foot.   Past medical history:  Mr. Rogers is a former smoker  having quit 10 years earlier after smoking a pack a day for several decades. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago  which is currently managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. He also suffers from chronic hypertension controlled through beta-blocker medication. He had a heart attack five years ago for which he underwent successful angioplasty and placement of a stent.  Social History: Mr. Rogers is a retired schoolteacher  living with his wife. He admits to having a fat-rich diet and sedentary lifestyle. He has two children who live in different states. He does not consume alcohol or use recreational drugs.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the affected foot demonstrates pallor on elevation and dependent rubor (redness)  with non-healing ulcers on the toes. Distal pulses (posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis) in the right foot are not palpable. There is loss of hair on the lower part of the right leg.   Potential Learning Point for Medical students:  This case critically demonstrates signs symptomatic of Critical Limb Ischemia  including the patient's classic symptoms  risk factors and subsequent physical examination findings. Limb ischemia often presents in individuals suffering from peripheral artery disease- a disease exacerbated by diabetes  smoking  hyperlipidemia and hypertension. With Mr. Roger's background  understanding peripheral arterial disease's risk factors and its lethal complication  such as critical limb ischemia  can educate medical students on disease management and amputation prevention.

Case Report for Critical Limb Ischemia Training:  Patient Information: Mr. Anderson is a 71-year-old African-American male  retired truck driver  with full insurance coverage  and hailing from Newark  New Jersey.  Medical History: Mr. Anderson has a long history of uncontrolled Type II Diabetes Mellitus for over 15 years  coupled with hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and myocardial infarction 5 years ago. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit smoking 4 years ago after the myocardial infarction. His father died of stroke and his mother had peripheral vascular disease. Mr. Anderson does not exercise regularly and mostly follows a high-fat diet.  Key Complaints: He visited the clinic with complaints of intermittent claudication for the past 6 months  which gradually worsened. He describes a severe cramping pain in his right calf  which occurs after walking for a few minutes and resolves with rest. Recently  the pain became persistent and started occurring at rest  which predominantly keeps him awake at night. He also noticed a non-healing ulcer on his right great toe for the past 8 weeks. Furthermore  he reports occasional dizziness and fatigue  as well as unusual coldness and color change in his foot. He denies chest pain and shortness of breath.  In summary  this case describes a patient with a high-risk profile: advanced age  long-standing uncontrolled diabetes  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  high-fat diet  sedentary lifestyle  smoking history  and a family history of vascular disease. The reported symptoms strongly suggest critical limb ischemia (CLI). This case is designed to demonstrate the importance of a comprehensive approach to patient's complaints and reminds to consider vascular causes for leg pain  especially in patients with significant risk factors. Further examination  labs  and imaging studies should be explored in the subsequent sessions to confirm the diagnosis and plan potential treatment.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Demographics:  Age: 65 years Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Ethnicity: Caucasian Residential Status: Lives alone  Past Medical History:  1) Diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 15 years  not well-managed. 2) Diagnosed with Hypertension for the past 10 years  on medication 3) History of Tobacco use  quit 1 year ago; 40 pack-years. 4) Previous intervention for Peripheral Arterial Disease in the right leg 5 years ago.  Key Complaints:  1) Severe rest pain in the left leg described as ""burning"" that has been progressively worsening over the past few months.  2) Non-healing ulcers on the left foot particularly the distal toes. 3) History of intermittent claudication  which he describes as ""cramping pain""  occurring while he walks his dog around the block.  4) Actual intolerable pain leading to sleep disturbances.   Clinical examination revealed pallor  coldness of the left leg with reduced distal pulsations. A non-healing ulcer was observed on the left great toe and lateral malleolus  suggestive of the corresponding arterial territory.   Differential diagnoses include critical limb ischemia  diabetic neuropathy  and venous insufficiency. Further investigations are needed  including arterial doppler studies  Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) measurement  and potentially angiography to characterize the arterial blockages.   Thus  this case represents a typical example of critical limb ischemia in the backdrop of long-standing diabetes mellitus  hypertension  a history of smoking  and previous Peripheral Arterial Disease. The focus here would be on recognizing typical clinical features  identifying key investigative strategies & understanding the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms contributing to this clinical picture.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. Palmer Age: 68 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired teacher Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Palmer presents with rest pain and non-healing ulcers in his right foot. He reports pain being worse in the night and often awakens him from sleep.  Past Medical and Social History: Mr. Palmer has had a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) for the past twelve years and has been managing it with diet and oral hypoglycemic medication. Other significant medical conditions include hypertension and peripheral arterial disease (PAD). He is a former smoker  having quit smoking ten years ago. He occasionally consumes alcohol.   Family history includes his father  who also had DM and died of myocardial infarction at the age of 73  and his mother who suffered from arthritis.  Review of his medications indicate that he is currently on metformin 1000mg twice a day  amlodipine 5mg once a day  and low-dose aspirin 75mg once a day. He has no known drug allergies.  Physical Assessment: Examination of his right foot reveals gangrenous changes in the toes with distal leg pallor. Pulses are weakly palpable in the right popliteal artery but are absent in the right dorsalis pedis and post-tibial arteries.   This brief case provides a clear presentation for a case of critical limb ischemia in a patient with peripheral arterial disease and a background of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Mr. Palmer's condition  if left untreated  could risk limb amputation or potentially be life-threatening.   The case is designed to teach medical students about the importance of early recognition and prompt treatment initiation of critical limb ischemia through risk factors  clinical symptoms  physical assessment  and the importance of the patient's medical history.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. Brown Gender: Male Age: 65 years Race: African American Occupation: Retired Mechanic  Medical History: Mr. Brown has a significant history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension. He has been a smoker for over 30 years and occasional alcohol consumer. His grandfather had peripheral artery disease (PAD)  which later progressed to critical limb ischemia (CLI).  Key Complaints: Mr. Brown presents with excruciating pain in his right lower leg that has persisted for three weeks. The pain seems to exacerbate when he rests or during night-time. He also mentioned of a non-healing ulcer on his right foot noticed around a month back. Recently  he has experienced a significant decrease in mobility and has started to limp due to the pain. He also reported occasional episodes of feeling cold in the affected leg and noticed that his leg appears slightly pale compared to the other one.  Summary: The given profile is a standard representation of a patient suffering from CLI. The use of this case would facilitate discussions regarding the importance of risk factors assessing  early diagnosis and proper management of critical limb ischemia.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Mr. Smith  a 71-year-old male  presents to the outpatient clinic. He is Caucasian and lives independently with his wife at their suburban home in the outskirts of Atlanta  Georgia. He's a retired high school teacher  trends towards a sedentary lifestyle  and has a 30-year history of pack-a-day smoking. The patient drinks alcohol socially with an average consumption of five units per week. He has a known history of Type 2 diabetes for 20 years and has been notified of elevated cholesterol levels in his recent past.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a 20-year history of Type 2 diabetes  which is reasonably controlled. He has been taking Metformin and Sulfonylureas  showing average fasting blood sugar 145-160 mg/dL and HbA1C 7.1. He also has a background of Hypercholesterolemia with a recent LDL cholesterol level of 155 mg/dl  despite being on Statins. He was diagnosed as hypertensive ten years ago and is using ACE inhibitors  maintaining blood pressure around 135/85 mmHg. He has not been diagnosed with any significant cardiac  respiratory  or kidney diseases. He has not had any surgical interventions in the past.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Smith reports that he has been experiencing increasing discomfort in his right leg over the past few months. The pain primarily shows up when he tries to walk more than half a block or climbs his house stairs. He finds relief in pain once he's at rest. Once he sits or stops walking  the pain goes away after a few minutes. He also mentions that the past few weeks  he’s noticed that his right foot appears slightly discolored—paler than his left foot. When asked  he notes that his right foot seems colder than the other one.  NOTE: This case focuses on critical limb ischemia (CLI)  which is a severe obstruction of the arteries that significantly reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  and legs) and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores. The patient's history reveals multiple risk factors for peripheral artery disease  which includes age (over 70)  male gender  smoking history  diabetes  hypercholesterolemia  and hypertension. Thus leading into the discussion for CLI.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information: Mr. John Lucas  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Lucas came to the hospital reporting a two-month history of severe  persistent pain at rest in the lower left leg  particularly in the foot. He also complained about non-healing ulcers on his left foot  progressive muscle weakness  and fatigue.  Past Medical History:  1) Hypertension - He has been on amlodipine 5mg daily for the past eight years. 2) Type 2 diabetes mellitus - Diagnosed ten years ago  managed by metformin 500mg twice daily and regular dietary controls. 3) Smoking history - He quit smoking five years ago after a 40-year-long smoking history. 4) No known drug allergies.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  it was noted that the patient's left foot was notably cooler than his right foot. Pulses (dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial) were unpalpable in the lower left leg. There was evidence of distal gangrene on two toes of the left foot  along with multiple non-healing ulcerations.  Risk Factors: History of smoking  hypertension  and diabetes are significant risk factors in Mr. Lucas' case for the development of peripheral artery disease (PAD) leading to critical limb ischemia (CLI).  This case can be used to teach medical students about how to diagnose and manage patients with CLI  emphasizing the role of medical history and physical examinations in identifying high-risk patients. The lessons can include discussions on the pertinent medical therapy  surgical options depending on the condition  and the importance of lifestyle modifications aimed at symptom management and slowing disease progression. Additionally  the psychosocial impacts of CLI should be considered  and the critical need for a multidisciplinary approach to patient care can be emphasized.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  The subject is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  a retired truck driver  and a current resident of Dallas  Texas.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a 25-year history of poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 20-pack-year history of smoking. He had been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) about three years ago but failed to follow up on the appropriate treatment.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented to the emergency department with a three-day history of severe rest pain in the left lower extremity  particularly focused in the calf and foot. He described the pain as aching and said it worsened at night. He also noted that the pain frequently awakened him from sleep  was exacerbated by elevation of the limb  and alleviated with hanging the foot over the side of the bed. The patient also reported progressive weakness in his left leg and was experiencing difficulty when walking. Over the last day  he noticed the foot has turned pale and cool  with a non-healing ulcer in the great toe.  Upon physical examination  the left foot was noticeably colder than the right one  and both pedal and posterior tibial pulses were absent. The ankle-brachial index (ABI) was 0.3 on the left compared to 0.9 on the right. The skin of the left foot showed signs of atrophy and shiny texture. A painful ulcer approximately 2 cm in diameter was noticed on the left great toe with necrotic base and surrounding erythema  suggestive of critical limb ischemia.  Based on these symptoms  diagnostic tests were suggested  including Doppler ultrasound  angiography  and blood tests for complete blood count  glucose  creatinine  lipids  and coagulation tests  to further investigate his condition. The patient gives consent to proceed with diagnostic investigations followed by revascularization intervention.  This case report is intended for medical students to help in understanding the pathophysiology  diagnosis and management of critical limb ischemia in patients with underlying peripheral arterial diseases  especially those with comorbidities/non-compliance increasing their risk and worsening the prognosis.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: Mr. John Smith is a 67-year-old African American male who is a retired school teacher. He resides in Atlanta  Georgia and is married with three adult children. He is generally independent in his daily activities and is a non-smoker. However  he has a history of heavy alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 15 years and has been on Metformin. He also has a history of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  both managed with medications  and had a transient ischemic attack 5 years ago. Last year  he underwent coronary angioplasty for stable angina  with significant improvement in symptoms.  Key Complaints: Mr. Smith has been facing difficulty in walking for the past 6 months. He complains of a severe burning and cramping pain in his right calf that becomes worse when walking and eases when he stops – a condition termed as 'intermittent claudication.' Recently he noticed that the foot was cooler than the left foot. He also reports rest pain at night  persistent numbness  and tingling. Additionally  he pointed out a couple of non-healing sores on his toes. He also noted reduced hair growth on his lower legs. He has not experienced any fever  chills  or other systemic symptoms.  These symptoms suggest possible Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood flow to the extremities and has progressed to the point of severe pain and skin ulcers or sores. The patient's risk factors including the history of diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and advanced age make this a prime consideration.  NOTE: Physical examination  investigations  differential diagnoses  and management strategies would be discussed subsequent to the case presentation as part of interactive teaching and learning.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. Johnson Age: 68 years old Gender: Male Race: African American Occupation: Retired mechanic  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a significant history of hypertension  uncontrolled type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. He used to be a smoker  but stopped 10 years ago. He underwent heart bypass surgery 5 years ago.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Johnson presents to the Emergency Department complaining of persistent and severe pain in his left lower leg that started several weeks ago. He mentions that the pain increases when he's lying down  and eases a bit when he dangles his leg over the side of the bed.   He reports that his left foot is colder than the right and he has noticed a gradual discoloration in the affected limb  becoming more pale and bluish.   Upon physical examination  noticeable signs include dry and scaly skin  diminished hair growth on the left leg  and weak or absent pulses in the left foot. Mr. Johnson also indicates that he has difficulty in walking due to the pain  and the foot ulcers he have had for a month aren't healing.  Based on these observations  a preliminary diagnosis of critical limb ischemia is suspected.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia   Patient Demographics: The patient is a 69-year-old African American male  Mr. Johnson  living in an urban environment. He is a retired military officer and a smoker of 45 years. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  married with three children  and lives a sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a longstanding history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) and hypertension (HTN). He is on Metformin for DM and a calcium channel blocker for HTN. There is also a history of obstructive sleep apnea for which he uses CPAP at night.  Key Complaints: Mr. Johnson has visited the emergency department due to persistent severe pain in his right lower limb that is greatly intensified on walking  leading to an inability to complete a short distance. He describes the nature of the pain as a burning and throbbing sensation that never completely subsides  but gets worse when he lies down. He also mentions experiencing intermittent claudication for the past few months.   Upon examination  the right lower limb is noticeably cooler than the rest of the body  with a diminished distal pulse. The skin is slightly discolored and shiny  with the presence of some non-healing ulcers on the foot.  The patient has been taking over-the-counter pain medication to relieve the pain but it is no longer working effectively. He also mentions that he has lost some weight over the past month due to decreased appetite.  This information points towards a potential case of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  requiring prompt investigation and treatment to prevent the progression of the disease.

Patient Information: Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver.  Past Medical History: The patient has a 20-year history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  well controlled with metformin  and a 30-year pack history of smoking  quit 5 years ago. He has a known history of peripheral artery disease  diagnosed approximately 3 years ago. He has hypertension  controlled with lisinopril. No history of any surgeries  and there are no known allergies.  Chief Complains:  Mr. Johnson visited the clinic  complaining of severe  ongoing pain in his right foot and lower leg  especially at night. He also reported his foot has had slow healing sores and wounds that have not healed even after several weeks. He mentioned his foot often feels cold compared to the left one and the color appears to look paler. He revealed that despite quitting smoking  he still has a history of chronic smoking. He has also noticed an increasing difficulty in walking due to the pain which seems to escalate when he elevates his leg.   This case is designed to shed light on Critical Limb Ischemia  a severe obstruction of the arteries which markedly reduces blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet and legs) and has started to cause severe pain and skin breakdown. This clinical scenario is an alert to medical students that early diagnosis and prompt treatment can prevent limb amputation and enhance the quality of patient's life. It also highlights the importance of counseling patients on lifestyle modifications to combat the underlying risk factors. Therefore  a comprehensive assessment following his highlighted symptoms is crucial.

Patient Information  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired fireman  Medical History  John has a 20-year history of untreated type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. His other significant medical conditions include hypertension managed with medication  and a 30-pack year smoking history. He also has a history of sedentary lifestyle with poor compliance with dietary recommendations. He has no known allergies to medications.  Presenting Complaint  Mr. Doe presents with severe rest pain in his left foot  which is worse at night and relieved by hanging his foot off the side of the bed. The intense pain  primarily in the toes and heel  has been disturbing his sleep for the past week. On examination  the distal foot is cold to touch with weak pedal pulses. There are areas of skin discoloration on his toes and a small non-healing wound on the heel.  The severity of the rest pain  the physical examination findings indicative of lower perfusion  and the lifestyle  personal and medical history of Mr. Doe including longstanding untreated diabetes and smoking history are highly suggestive of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). He should undergo further diagnostic tests including Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI)  toe-brachial index (TBI)  Doppler ultrasound  and possibly angiography to confirm the diagnosis and plan appropriate intervention. Multidisciplinary involvement including a vascular surgeon  diabetologist  and a dietitian will be critical for the comprehensive management of this patient.

Patient Case  Demographics:   A 65-year-old African American male  retired construction worker  non-smoker with a BMI of 28.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years  maintained on metformin. He also has hypertension well-controlled with lisinopril. In addition  the patient has dyslipidemia and is on atorvastatin for the same. He also has peripheral arterial disease (PAD)  for which he is on Aspirin and concluded angioplasty three years ago.  Key Complaints:  The patient presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent  worsening pain in his right foot  especially during the nights. He mentions that for the past few days  the pain has been so severe that even the weight of his bedding has been unbearable. He also reports a non-healing ulcer on the sole of his foot that started as a minor skin tear one month ago. Furthermore  the patient has found it increasingly difficult to walk even short distances due to severe pain. He has not noticed any change in the skin color of his foot or any persistent infections.  On physical examination  you find that his right foot is significantly cooler to touch as compared to the left one with an absent dorsalis pedis pulse. The patient has a full thickness ulcer of 2cm diameter on the plantar aspect of his right foot with irregular margins and yellowish slough at the base. Capillary refill time is more than 3 seconds distally.  The student should consider the given symptoms  signs  and patient history to reach the diagnosis and stratify the severity of critical limb ischemia. This would require knowledge about associated risk factors  symptoms of progression of PAD to critical limb ischemia  and strategic management plans. Awareness about the classification system to determine the severity would also be expected.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information:   - Mr. Ramirez  62 years old  - Male - Hispanic ethnicity - Occupation: Retired firefighter - Marital Status: Married  has three children - Resides in Austin  Texas  Past medical history:  The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with Metformin and a strict diet for 10 years. He also has a 15-year history of hypertension controlled with Lisinopril. 7 years ago  he was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD)  intermittent claudication managed conservatively. In addition  he has a 30 pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago  shortly after being diagnosed with emphysema. There is also a family history of cardiovascular disease  with both his father and grandfather suffering from myocardial infarction under the age of 65.  Key Complaints:  Over the past few months  Mr. Ramirez has experienced an escalation of rest pain in his right foot. He recounts cramping pain exacerbated during sleep or when his leg is elevated. Initially  the pain was infrequent and manageable with over-the-counter pain relief  but it has since increased in frequency and intensity.   Mr. Ramirez also reports a non-healing wound on his right foot. He noticed it around six weeks ago  dismissing it initially as a minor injury. However  it has since not improved and has progressively worsened  showing signs of tissue necrosis.   He is now unable to walk without assistance due to his debilitating pain and impaired foot function. His symptoms are now causing him significant distress  interrupting his sleep  and gravely impacting his quality of life. He is also concerned about his foot's appearance and fears his foot may have to be amputated.  The above features suggest a case of critical limb ischemia  a severe form of peripheral artery disease. The alarm features include rest pain  tissue loss shown by the non-healing wound  and impaired function of his foot. This case would form the basis of medical students learning the presentation  potential complications  and management of critical limb ischemia.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI)  Patient's Demographics:  - Age: 67 years - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupancy: Retired Military Veteran - Marital Status: Divorced - No history of Alcohol or Tobacco use  Past Medical History:  - Ischemic heart disease diagnosed two years ago  treated with medication - Hypertension managed with medication for the past five years - Type II diabetes mellitus diagnosed eight years ago  controlled with oral hypoglycemics - Underwent lower right extremity bypass surgery three years ago due to peripheral artery disease (PAD)  Key Complaints:  - Suffers from persistent right leg pain  described as severe and burning especially at rest  worse at night - Non-healing ulcers on the right foot’s big toe  noticed around a month ago  - The pain intensifies when elevating the leg and alleviates somewhat with the foot in a dependent state  - On and off feeling of coldness in the right foot for several months - Reduced walking distance over the past year due to claudication  currently around 50 meters  When arriving at the hospital he was wheelchair-bound due to severe pain upon applying any pressure on his foot. The patient denies any fever  chills  or sudden weight loss. He complains of occasional dizziness and shortness of breath upon exertion.  This case can be used to educate medical students about recognizing and treating critical limb ischemia  which is a severe obstruction of the arteries that drastically reduces blood flow to the extremities and has the potential to lead to amputation if not treated urgently. It also intends to stress how significant comorbidities are in relation to CLI  and the need to manage these appropriately to delay its progression and prevent complications.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information: Name: Mr. David Stevens  Age: 62 years Gender: Male Occupation: Retired military officer Marital status: Married Smoking Status: Ex-smoker Alcohol Use: Socially  Past Medical History:  Mr. Stevens has hypertension  which is well-controlled with medication (Lisinopril). He has a 10-year history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  managed by Metformin. He also has a past medical history of hypercholesteremia treated with Atorvastatin. He quit smoking ten years ago  but had a 20-pack year history prior to cessation.  Chief Complaints:  Mr. Stevens came to the clinic complaining of a progressive onset of rest pain in the right lower leg that has been worsening over the last two weeks. The pain often wakes him up at night and he has found temporary relief by hanging his leg over the side of the bed. However  the pain has become more frequent and is now persistent throughout the day.   Additionally  he reports that the skin on that leg has become noticeably paler  and he has developed a non-healing ulcer on his right big toe. He has also noticed that the foot has become cold to touch over the last few days.  Mr. Stevens has significant difficulty walking due to the pain and has started using a cane for support. He also reports feeling fatigued  which has been impacting his daily activities.  End Note: Although this patient's case is hypothetical  it is intended to depict a typical presentation of a patient with critical limb ischemia. The training case teaches students to identify key signs and symptoms  and how to connect these to the patient's past medical history  supporting the formulation of a potential diagnosis. In reality  the diagnosis would be confirmed with further diagnostic tests  such as doppler ultrasound  ankle-brachial index (ABI)  and angiography.

Case Study: Critical Limb Ischemia  Patient Information: Patient: Mr. X Age: 65 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired engineer Habitual Influences: Smoker for past 40 years  occasional alcohol consumption  Past Medical History:  Mr. X has a significant past medical history including Type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed ten years prior but poorly managed  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  and a history of Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) with stenting performed 5 years ago. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases.   Key Complaints:  Mr. X presented at the hospital with a chief complaint of persistent  severe pain in his right lower leg  specifically in the calf and foot region  for the past few weeks - even at rest. He also noted color change (paler skin) in his right foot  the appearance of non-healing  painful ulcers on his toes  and the sensation of cold in comparison to the other foot. He mentioned that he gets temporary relief with pain on hanging his leg in a dependent position. The pain has been affecting his sleep and he can barely walk due to the severity of pain and weakness.   Previous Treatments and Medications: Aspirin  statins  antihypertensives  and oral hypoglycemic agents   These symptoms and history suggest a condition of critical limb ischemia  indicating a severe obstruction in the arteries  reducing the blood flow to the extremities (hands  feet  or legs) leading to severe pain  skin ulcers or sores  or even gangrene. It's a complication of PAD and an immediate evaluation and intervention is necessary to avoid detrimental consequences like amputation.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. James  a 73-year-old African American male  retired construction worker  current smoker with a 30-pack year history.  Past Medical History: Diabetes Mellitus Type II  Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD)  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  and previous Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA). No history of surgeries.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. James has been experiencing severe pain in his right leg for the past three weeks. He describes the pain as getting worse when he walks short distances and is better when sitting with his leg hanging over the edge of a chair. He also noticed the presence of a small  non-healing ulcer on his right big toe and states that his foot often feels cold.  Physical Examination: Vital signs: BP-160/95mmHg  pulse-90bpm  temperature -98.6°F General appearance: Pale  anxious  thin built. Lower limb examination: Absent dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses in the right foot. An ulcer of approximately 1.5cm in diameter found on right big toe. Skin of the right lower limb appears slightly pale with reduced hair growth. No edema.  Investigations:   - Ankle-Brachial index (ABI): less than 0.4 on the right side. - Doppler Ultrasound of the right lower limb: significant stenosis in the tibial and peroneal arteries. - Blood tests: elevated HBA1c  LDL cholesterol  and triglyceride levels.   Diagnosis:  Critical Limb Ischemia  Problem Statement: Mr. James with underlying atherosclerotic risk factors and peripheral arterial disease presenting with resting pain and a non-healing ulcer on the toe  suggestive of critical limb ischemia.

Case Report: Critical Limb Ischemia   Patient Information:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 62 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Army Officer   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension (for about 10 years)  smoking (quit 5 years ago) and type II diabetes mellitus (diagnosed 8 years ago). All conditions are well-managed with medications: he is on Metformin (500mg twice a day)  Lisinopril (10mg once a day)  and Amlodipine (5mg once a day). His last routine check-up was six months ago  all vitals/signs were in the normal range.  Presenting Complaints:  This visit  Mr. Doe complains of rest pain in his right leg  especially at night and poor healing of a minor wound on the foot he sustained over a week ago. He has noticed that his leg usually feels cooler to touch and appears paler compared to the left one. He also has felt mild numbness in his foot. He states moderate difficulty in walking  especially long distances due to pain in his right leg. He does not report any chest pain  dyspnea  or other symptoms.  These symptoms have been slowly progressing over the last three months  causing him to seek out medical advice. He denies any trauma or recent long-distance traveling. There are no other associated symptoms like fever  weight loss  or other systemic complaints.   This case focuses on the presentation of critical limb ischemia (CLI) in Mr. Doe induced potentially by his combination of hypertension  diabetes  and past smoking history  which necessitates immediate medical management. It will provide medical students an opportunity to understand how critical ischemia is diagnosed  managed and explore the correlation between lifestyle choices and diseases of the cardiovascular system.

Patient Information:  Mr. Smith  a 70-years-old African-American male with a documented history of Type-2 diabetes mellitus and peripheral artery disease. He is a long-time smoker and a retired construction worker living independently.  Chief Complaint:  Presented with a history of severe pain in his right leg which is beyond the knee and foot for the past four weeks  increasingly worsening over the past week. Pain is constant  and more noticeable at night  negatively affecting his sleep and daily activities. He acknowledges that pain subsides slightly upon dangling his foot off of the bed. He also mentions that there is a non-healing wound on the same foot.  Past Medical History:  Diagnosed with Type-2 diabetes mellitus for the past 12 years  managed by Metformin. Suffered from peripheral artery disease (PAD) diagnosed five years ago. He is presently on aspirin and a statin for PAD. Long-term smoker with a 30-pack year history. No known allergies. There is no family history of any cardiovascular diseases.  Please note that this information is purely for educational purposes. Actual patient histories may vary significantly  and real clinical judgments should be made based on a comprehensive understanding of the patient's complete background and current health status.

CASE REPORT  Patient Information: Age: 72  Gender: Male Occupation: Retired military officer  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with severe pain in his left lower leg  particularly below the knee  muscle weakness  and a non-healing ulcer located on his left foot's big toe.  Medical History: His past medical history is notable for hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  with moderate control with medications for the past 15 years. It is also noted that he is a long-term heavy smoker with more than 30 pack-years  consuming alcohol occasionally. The patient was diagnosed with Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) in both legs around 1 year ago and underwent Percutaneous Transluminal Angioplasty (PTA) for severe stenosis in the right femoro-popliteal segment. There’s a family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  he was alert and oriented with a blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg and a heart rate of 89 beats/min. The left lower extremity had a significantly reduced temperature compared to the right leg. The foot appeared pale with a weak pulse in the dorsal pedis artery. A non-healing ulcer with necrotic tissues and pus was noted on his left foot's big toe. No pedal edema was observed.  Summary: A case of a 72-year-old male with risk factors of tobacco use  uncontrolled diabetes mellitus  hypertension  a history of PAD  and subsequent endovascular intervention  presently complain of critical limb ischemia manifesting as rest pain and gangrenous changes in the lower extremity. Given these factors  further diagnostic tests and an urgent  appropriate treatment plan should be initiated to prevent limb loss.

CASE REPORT:  Patient Demographics:  Name: John Smith Age: 67 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Origin: Rural North America  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has been a patient in the clinic for the past ten years. His recorded medical history reveals him as a long-term smoker with a 45-pack-year history. He also has a history of uncontrolled type-II diabetes mellitus  peripheral arterial disease  and hypertension. The patient's BMI falls under the obese category. Furthermore  his cholesterol levels have been persistently high  despite being on medication. He also reports a familial history of early-onset cardiovascular disease.  Key Complaints:  Today  Mr. Smith presents himself with a six-month history of gradual increasing pain in his lower legs  especially during walking  which he describes as a crampy sensation. He even reported an instance of waking up in the middle of the night due to extreme pain in his left foot  and pain seems to ameliorate with dangling the leg over the bed edge. With the progression of the situation  he noticed a slow-healing ulceration on the big toe of his left foot coupled with a change in coloration.   Over the past week  he has noticed persistent pain in his left foot  which he described as a constant  severe  and burning pain which has confined him to bed.  Mr. Smith's case is a crucial case of critical limb ischemia (CLI) characterized by his key complaints and his risk factors that include smoking  diabetes  and his familial history of cardiovascular disease. The training should address the issues of identifying symptoms early  diagnosing CLI  and managing/treating the condition.

Patient Case:  Patient Information:  Name: Robert Johnson Age: 74 Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Police Officer Ethnicity: Caucasian Location: Urban dwelling  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension managed with a calcium channel blocker 2. Smoking history - 40 pack years  quit 5 years ago 3. Type-II Diabetes Mellitus poorly controlled with Metformin 4. Has history of mild claudication for 2 years 5. Previous history of two transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)  Chief Complaints:  Mr. Johnson reports severe  persistent pain in his right leg over the past week. Pain is often described as worsened at night and partially relieved by hanging the leg off the side of his bed. He has difficulty walking and noted a significant decrease in his walking distance due to unremitting pain. There is color change on the lower half of his leg with skin appearing increasingly pale and glossy. Mr. Johnson also complains of feeling cold in the affected leg as compared to the contralateral leg.  He has noticed an ulcer near his heel that has not healed for 2 weeks which is associated with foul smell. No reported fever or chills.  His diabetes is not well controlled as evidenced by an HbA1C level measured 6 weeks ago of 9.0%. He is a non-compliant patient with prescribed medications and lifestyle modifications due to fear of side effects and discontent towards change.  Particular lifestyle habits include high fatty diet and minimal physical exercise. His mental status is intact with no cognitive impairment. His family is supportive and is willing to help Mr. Johnson modify his disease management plan.   Foot exam:  A nonhealing ulcer with necrotic tissue present on the right heel  pale skin coloration of the right foot  decreased temperature of the right foot as compared to the left  decreased capillary refill time  absence of posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses.  Key symptoms of the patient:  Severe pain in the right leg exacerbated at night  non-healing foot ulcer  color change  cold temperature  decreased walking distance.

Case Report:  Patient Profile: Name: Mr. Dennis Sutton Age: 68 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Policeman  Medical History: Mr. Sutton is a former smoker with a history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 12 years. He has peripheral artery disease that was diagnosed five years ago and has been on medication since the diagnosis. Additionally  he has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 8 years ago due to ischemic heart disease. His mother suffered a stroke at the age of 75.  Key Complaints: Mr. Sutton presents with progressive pain in his lower extremities that has been persistent for two months  especially in the right calf and foot. He reports that the pain intensifies when he walks and significantly decreases during rest  a condition referred to as intermittent claudication.   Additionally  he complains of numbness and coldness in his right foot along with a non-healing wound on the lateral aspect of the right foot which first appeared three weeks ago. On close observation  the foot appears dusky with notable absence of hair growth and brittle nails  indicative of poor circulation.   Mr. Sutton reports difficulty in sleeping due to the occurrence of pain at night  requiring him to hang his leg over the side of the bed for relief  thus indicating Rest Pain  a severe form of PAD. Over the last week  the symptoms have exacerbated  negatively impacting his daily activities and quality of life  raising suspicion for critical limb ischemia.  This case encourages the students to evaluate the severity of disease based on clinical presentation  assess the multi-factorial risk factors  consider the potential differential diagnoses  and recommend appropriate management and prevention strategies for critical limb ischemia.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 68-year old white male who is retired from a construction work job. He resides in a suburban community  and his lifestyle is moderately active.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant history of consuming one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. He also has a notable alcohol intake  averaging two glasses of red wine daily. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes six years ago  which has been managed with metformin  regular checks for blood sugar levels and adhering to a suitable diet. The patient also has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels for five years for which he uses lisinopril and atorvastatin respectively. He does not have a history of surgeries. The family history includes myocardial infarction in his father and brother.  Key Complaints: The patient came to the clinic with complaints of chronic pain in the left leg for the past week. He described the pain as severe and persistent  mostly feeling like a strong cramping sensation in the calf muscles. The pain has been disrupting his sleep  and he mentioned it even gets worse while walking but subsides with rest. Additionally  the patient reports experiencing numbness and coolness in the same leg. He also noticed that the leg was beginning to develop non-healing wounds on the foot and previously-healed wounds started reopening. The patient also reported experiencing decreased mobility and distress related to these symptoms.

Patient Information: Mr. T. Johnson  68-year-old African American male  retired construction worker.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit ten years ago. He has been non-compliant with his diabetic medication and diet regimen.  Key Complaints: The patient presents to the clinic with a three-month history of severe shooting pain in his left calf muscle that occurs after walking about ten blocks. The pain eases with rest. However  in the past week  Mr. Johnson has started experiencing pain at rest  especially at night  disturbing his sleep. He also reports experiencing mild left foot numbness. There are no associated complaints of chest pain  dyspnea  dizziness  or palpitations.  On examination  there is a 1 cm  deep ulcer on the dorsal surface of his left foot  with poor granulation tissue and a mild foul-smelling discharge. The skin on his left leg is cold to touch with shiny  thin skin  lack of leg hair  thickened toe nails  and his foot has a bluish discoloration. Pedal pulses are barely palpable on his left foot compared to his right.   The rest of the physical examination  including his cardiovascular and neurological examination  is normal.   This case scenario helps to highlight the classic clinical findings associated with critical limb ischemia (CLI)  an urgent  severe presentation of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  where prompt recognition and management can reduce the high risk of limb amputation and cardiovascular events.

Case Scenario:  Patient Profile: Name: Mr. Johnson Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Johnson has come in with severe pain in his right lower limb  especially while walking or climbing stairs. He reports that the pain is also present at rest and is worse at night. He mentions that the pain has been escalating over the past six months. He additionally states that he has noticed some non-healing wounds on his right foot.  Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He smoked cigarettes from his teenage years until a decade ago when he quit. He has also been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease about 3 years back and was treated conservatively.  Physical Examination: On examination  there is a non-healing ulcer on his right foot  and the right foot appears pale compared to the left. The foot is cool to touch  and the posterior tibial pulse and dorsalis pedis pulse are weak on the right side compared to the left.  Summary: The above presentation is a typical case of Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI). The presence of severe pain  even at rest  along with the existence of non-healing ulcers strongly suggests the progression of peripheral artery disease to CLI. Combined with this patient's age  history of smoking  and other comorbidities like diabetes  hypertension  and documented peripheral artery disease  this scenario makes an excellent training case for medical students to learn about CLI  which could help them diagnose and manage such conditions effectively in their future practice.
